fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Walk free in Madeira | Wing it to the butterflies | Give Grigson a grilling
fields.body:
Walk free in Madeira

Frustrated walkers unable to explore the British countryside because of restrictions are turning to Europe, according to self-guided walking specialist Sherpa Expeditions (020 8577 2717).

Spring is one of the best times to visit the Portuguese island of Madeira, when a myriad colourful flowers and trees are in bloom. Walkers can follow an elaborate system of levadas, ancient irrigation channels that allow easy access to remote corners of the island, or climb more challenging trails up to the rugged volcanic peaks of the interior including Pico Ruivo, the island's highest point. Walkers take a day pack with them and have their luggage transported to a different inn each night.

A seven-night holiday costs £699 including flights, transfers, bed and breakfast and some meals.

Wing it to the butterflies

Costa Rica is home to a vast array of flora and fauna, including 10 per cent of the planet's butterfly population. Sunvil Discovery (020 8758 4774) is offering a 10-night escorted tour of the central Ameri can country. The holiday starts with two nights in the capital, San Jose, before you head for the Tortuguero National Park. From there are visits to the Arenal volcano area, the Monteverde Cloud Forest and the Manuel Antonio National Park - home to 184 different species of birds.

Prices start at £1,280 per person and include scheduled flights, all transportation, river excursions, entrance to parks, 10 nights' accommodation, some meals and an English speaking guide/botanist. Departures are on 11 June and 8 October.

Give Grigson a grilling

Learn about cooking and gardening from experts at sixteenth-century Castle Ashby (01604 696696), the setting for the BBC drama Love in a Cold Climate, during a Kitchen Garden House Party between 7 and 9 September.

TV chef Sophie Grigson will hold a masterclass in the hotel kitchens, followed by lunch when guests will have the chance to grill her with their culinary queries. Later in the afternoon jewellery designer Wendy Malpass will explain how she makes the creations worn by Grigson during her TV appearances. On Sunday landscape gardener Roddy Llewellyn will escort guests around the gardens to explain his techniques and there will be opportunity for guests to pose questions over a traditional Sunday lunch. The two-night break costs £425 per person plus Vat and includes all meals, drinks and entertainment.

Turn back the floral clock

Amsterdam Travel Service (0870 727 5885) is offering day trips to the Keukenhof flower show in Lisse, Holland, featuring more than 70 acres of flowers and plants as well as ancient trees, ponds and fountains. This year's highlights include a historical garden where visitors can step back in time to the Middle Ages and contemporary Dutch art and sculpture.

The £119 day-trip package includes return flights from Heathrow, transfers to and from Keukenhof and entrance to the show, which is open from 22 March to 24 May between 8am and 7.30pm. Half-day trips for people having a short break in Amsterdam cost £15 per person including coach travel and entrance to the show.

webTitle: Travel agent turns to cafe culture

fields.headline: Travel agent turns to cafe culture
fields.trailText: A new travel agency is mixing travel guides and brochures with caffe latte and espresso.
fields.body:
Fancy a caffe latte and a two-week holiday in Tuscany? You'll be able to buy both at a new travel agency opening in Milton Keynes in May.

Travelcaf's commercial director, Warren Edwards, said it had teamed up with Esquires Coffee Houses to provide a 'relaxing and fun atmosphere' in which to book a holiday. Customers can look through brochures and travel guides and browse through an intranet featuring ideas and destination information in the coffee shop. Seventeen consultants will be on hand to offer advice and book holidays.

The two-storey, 246 square metre flagship store will also feature a bureau de change and 107cm plasma screens flashing up holiday offers. Children will be entertained with colouring books and Lego or play free computer games while parents book their holidays.

Edwards said there would be a strong emphasis on customer service. 'Instead of just sending out clients' tickets we will ask them if they want to come and pick them up so we can sit down and talk through their itinerary and answer any questions they may have.'

If successful, more Travelcafs will open later this year, with a network of up to 70 shops across the UK within four years.

fields.headline: Spice up your life
fields.standfirst: You don't fancy the country because of foot and mouth - but you can follow  Stephen McClarence on a British spice trail through Bolton, Bradford and Leicester for home furnishings, gold jewellery, temples, henna tattoos and curries
fields.trailText: You don't fancy the country because of foot and mouth - but you can follow Stephen McClarence on a British spice trail through Bolton, Bradford and Leicester for home furnishings, gold jewellery, temples, henna tattoos and curries.
fields.body:
Suraj Khandelwal likes to talk about the afternoon he met Prince Charles. 'He asked me what my trade was,' he says, 'I told him: 'I decorate ladies.' The decoration takes place at Saree Mandir, a vast Indian clothes shop that would be an essential stopping-off point on a British spice trail.

No official trail exists, but, like other Midland and northern cities, Leicester has grasped the tourist potential of multiculturalism. Its shops, temples and museums, after all, offer visitors an exotic taste of Asia without the need to travel half way round the world.

The city houses major communities of Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs and Jains, as well as Africans, Chinese, and people whose roots are in the Caribbean. It boasts that whenever you visit, someone will probably be celebrating something.

The focal point of the Asian community is Belgrave Road: busy, urban, and lined with streets of brick terraces. It is known as the Golden Mile because more gold jewellery is reputedly sold across the counter here than anywhere else in Europe.

The road comes into its own during the Hindu autumn festival of Diwali, when its display of 6,000 lights - tiny oil lamps, candles or electric bulbs - is said to be the biggest outside India.

Khandelwal's warehouse-sized Saree Mandir - it means temple of saris - was one of the road's first Asian shops. It opened before Catholic churches, such as Our Lady's in Moira Street, started being converted into Hindu temples, with the Stations of the Cross replaced by statues of the deities Rama and Krishna.

'When I came over from Delhi in 1963, I realised there was no one in the whole of Leicester selling saris,' says Khandelwal. 'Now I have customers coming from all over the country - from Newcastle, from Gravesend, every where - to buy everything from one sari to 100.'

The saris, a kaleidoscope of patterns and colours, cost from £2.50, in plain green polyester, to £1,095, in exquisite pink tissue silk with gold embroidery and a strong implication of handle with care.

'When I first started, my customers were all English ladies who had never seen saris or all these colours,' he says. 'They were very, very interested by it all.'

Sital Raja tells a similar story of Western interest in the East in Bolton, Greater Manchester, where she runs the House of Raja's, one of Britain's biggest Asian department stores. It pulls in coach parties from all over Britain for its curry tastings and cookery and henna-painting demonstrations.

'A lot of people who come here have never been in an Asian shop before,' says Raja. 'When we started advertising to the Western community, people said, "We've known about you for years, but we thought we weren't allowed in because we were white."

'Then they heard me with my Bolton accent, and said: "Oh, you're more English than I am!"'

The store, The Little India of the North, opened 20 years ago in the former Fletcher Street Methodist Church, a sober-looking nineteenth-century building next to a drive-though McDonald's. It has the atmosphere - and the sweetly pungent spice-laden smell - of an Asian bazaar, with bangles by the yard, rice by the sackful and Bollywood film music pulsating over the public address system.

Raja's husband Pravin (they had 1,400 guests at their wedding) sits at the check-out and runs through a gazetteer of stock: cardamom from Guatemala, cloves from Madagascar, mung beans from Australia, saffron from Spain, green lentils from Canada, peppercorns from Brazil, pickles and chutneys from Bolton, made on the premises.

The coach parties sample the food during regular Asian evenings that climax with a version of the Generation Game in which visitors are taught the finer points of putting on saris.

'It's generally the men who want to try it out most,' says Sital Raja, whose parents migrated from Kenya when she was three. 'But most people who buy saris wear them as sarongs or use them as curtains or tablecloths.'

Across the Pennines, Bradford promotes itself as 'the curry capital of Britain' on the strength of its 300 Asian restaurants, mostly run by Pakistanis.

There are restaurants in converted Presbyterian chapels, restaurants that serve nans as big as duvets, restaurants that have opened branches in Majorca to 'recreate the authentic flavours of a Yorkshire-made curry'. The city even runs its own curry website.

The city's major Asian event is the annual Mela, a huge cultural festival that attracts crowds of 100,000 and is reckoned to be one reason why Bradford is likely to be shortlisted as Britain's next European Capital of Culture.

Back in Leicester, Europe's only Jain Centre features mirror mosaics and 250 tons of intricate, hand-carved sandstone pillars that bring a uniquely Indian atmosphere to a former Congregational chapel.

A 10-minute walk away, and boasting the resonant address 9 Holy Bones, is the Guru Nanak Sikh Museum, a former hosiery factory where visitors, with their shoes left at the door and heads covered, can trace the history of Sikhism through photographs, documents and detailed models of South Asia's major temples.

Down in the open market, Dev Persaud's stall is piled high with vegetables whose knobbly, multi-coloured exoticism makes tomatoes and cucumbers look sadly mundane. As he serves his customers, he gives a running commentary: 'These are tindola - like crunchy cucumber, put them in stir fries and salads. And these are Indian onions, sweeter and softer than ordinary ones; and this is karela , very good for dia betes. There's such an appetite for these things,' he says. 'When I first started selling mangos, I sold 100 boxes every day for a month.'

Persaud's stall and the Asian shops of the Belgrave Road area - try Shiva Shakti Foods and the basement Cash & Carry - have the fascination of a parallel way of life. The area's multiculturalism is reflected in its supermarkets, where Indian paneer (curd cheese) is stacked next to Red Leicester, and Choose Your Baby's Name books cover all options: Eladevi, Elizabeth, Emily, Eshtalakshmi, Evelyn. And the Sharmilee restaurant, over a shop selling pink and green Asian sweets, wryly includes English dishes in its menu descriptions, such as, 'Fries: fried potato chips served with tomato ketchup'. Back at Saree Mandir, Suraj Khandelwal has a pragmatic line on bargaining, the central creed of Asian commerce.

'People always try to get things cheaper; it's human nature,' he says. 'But look at this sari. I am asking just £6 for it. People say, "Can I bargain with you?" I say to them, "How much more do you want to pay me?"'

While you're there...

Tourist information: Leicester, 0116 299 8888. Bolton, 01204 334400. Bradford, 01274 753678.

www.bradfordcurryguide.co.uk

To follow in Stephen McClarence's footsteps around Leicester, start at Saree Mandir (0116 266 8144), 117-129 Belgrave Road. All the other Asian shops, and the Sharmilee restaurant (0116 261 0503), are a few doors away. Dev Persaud's vegetable stall (079 711 91231) is in the city centre open market off Gallowtree Gate (open from Monday to Saturday). The Jain Centre (0116 254 3091) is in Oxford Street and Guru Nanak Sikh Museum (0116 262 8606) in Holy Bones.

In Bolton, the House of Raja's (01204 532890) is at 14 Fletcher Street in the town centre.

fields.headline: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports
fields.trailText: Some resorts, even high ones in France, are doing poorly. Conditions are often better in Switzerland and Italy. North America is enjoying the last few weeks.
fields.body:
Some resorts, even high ones in France, are doing poorly. Conditions are often better in Switzerland and Italy. North America is enjoying the last few weeks.

Andorra: Arinsal 60cm on lower slopes and 100cm higher up, Pas de la Casa (65/95cm), and Soldeu (50/110cm). Warm temperatures playing havoc.

Austria: Heavy snow in St Anton (55/350cm) improved conditions on higher pistes. Mayrhofen (0/170cm) had some welcome snowfalls, then colder clear days. Kitzbühel (0/107cm) warm.

Bulgaria: Only optimists should head for Borovets (0/25cm) and Pamporovo (2/10cm), both with resort runs closed and other pistes rocky.

Canada: Ever popular Whistler (115/185cm) basks in sunny, cool, perfect skiing weather.

France: In Courchevel (20/112) off-piste was described as 'powder on crud'. Meribel (45/130cm) pistes were described as wet and worn with ice turning to slush in warm weather. Conditions best in the highest Three Valleys resort Val Thorens (90/200cm).

Italy: Slopes here standing up well to warmer weather. The vast Dolomiti Superski area (25/300cm) had 1,220km of pistes and 460 lifts open. Cortina (30/250cm) had avalanche risks off-piste with deep powder. Cervinia (140/330cm) had great piste skiing.

Switzerland: More avalanche risks in Davos (75/190cm) and St Moritz (150/330cm) but excellent skiing too. Tried and tested Zermatt (70/270cm) was revelling in powder and sunny weather midweek.

USA: Conditions excellent if cold in Telluride, Colorado (120/150cm). Farther north in the state at Vail Resorts, which owns Vail (140/190cm), Breckenridge (130/ 175cm) and Keystone (155/165cm) among others, there has been a 62 per cent rise in revenues 'thanks to some of the best snowfalls for more than a decade'.

On the slopes: Oprah Winfrey regularly visits Telluride where, after first owning a modest home under a chairlift, she bought a sprawling $3m lodge.

Best skiing: Mayrhofen, seven nights all inclusive, by coach £199pp sharing, departing Saturday 24 March by air from Gatwick £249pp. Snowcoach (01727 833141).

 The AITO directory of ski operators, whose reps help with this report, is available free by calling 020 8607 9080.

fields.headline: Carry on  indulging
fields.standfirst: Rory Bremner  settles in at an Aman resort, the holy grail of luxury hip hotels, where he's given a naked scrub down with olive soap in the steam room followed by a four-hand massage
fields.trailText: Rory Bremner settles in at an Aman resort, the holy grail of luxury hip hotels, where he's given a naked scrub down with olive soap in the steam room followed by a four-hand massage.
fields.body:
Problem: where to go for a five-day winter break in the sun to revive the spirits before the first daffodils appear and the groundsmen start to crank up their lawnmowers for the new cricket season.

Long-haul flights are out. The Caribbean is too far, northern Europe too cold, the Canaries too packaged.

The answer is to head south, like the birds. About two-and-a-half hours' flying time away are the open roads and mountains of Andalucia, alive with wild flowers, and the hidden ranches of Arcos de la Frontera, La Bobadilla or Aznacazar, near Seville, provide an early spring adventure.

But another hour's flying takes you to Morocco, and another world. While the Moors played away in Andalucia, home was Marrakesh, Fez or Tangier. Forget Casablanca: its romance faded with the departure of the last DC3. The airport no longer bears the name Casablanca, but the obligatory Aeroport Mahomet V. Last time I flew there we stopped in Gibraltar, but only for the time it took to unload my luggage - so I arrived in Casablanca with no clothes. Of all the towns in all the world...

This time was different. A brief stopover and on to the pale terracotta city of Marrakesh. Not to La Mamounia or the city's other hotels but 15 minutes away, to a sublime oasis of calm.

Amanjena, the latest of the Aman resorts, opened just over a year ago. I discovered it in the travel guide Nota Bene, a valuable find among the bewildering plethora of travel brochures. It promised a lot, and Amanjena exceeded even those expectations.

The place is spacious and serene on an imperial scale: in daylight the palatial buildings can resemble a dusky pink mausoleum, windowless and imposing, but behind the walls all is space, water and light. Open courtyards, cloisters, green-tiled roofs and waterways are glimpsed through Moroccan arches and columns created by Ameri can architect Ed Tuttle. This is Morocco, California-style.

Picked up from the airport in one of the hotel's Volvos, we arrived in time for dinner, when Amanjena is at its romantic best. You step through the gate into a kind of Moroccan Taj Mahal: lanterns and candles, placed around vast pools and narrow canals, cast shimmering reflections across the water and throw the arches and cloisters into relief. Around the 60 sq metre central basin you can make out the 'pavilions' and 'maisons' that make up the hotel's 40 rooms.

The pavilions are stunning, the walls rough-textured and flecked with straw on the outside, polished on the inside to that marble sheen you only find in Morocco and World of Interiors magazine. Approaching along one of the narrow waterways, you step through an arched gate into your own pri vate courtyard. The room alone is the size of a small chapel. Under a domed ceiling are sliding glass doors on three sides with sliding cedar shutters within. In the corner is a log-burning fire. Berber rugs are placed on the tiled floors.

The marble bathroom has a semi-sunken bath beneath a sealed window looking onto a small basement garden of grapefruit trees. The view from your bath is rather like looking into the reptile house at the zoo. I would have tapped at the glass for hours had my wife not told me that the exotic snake I was studying was in fact a hose.

Outside the room, beyond a little fountain, is a vaulted gazebo. We went to sleep by the light of the log fire and opened the cedar shutters in the morning to see the early sun glinting on the snow-capped Atlas mountains an hour's drive to the west. Pavilions 14 to 21 have this view, seen over the fairways of the golf course that borders the hotel on two sides. Pavilions in the thirties overlook a scratchy olive grove but would get the evening sun.

Breakfast, like all meals at the Amanjena, can be Moroccan or European. We never did try the Berber corn soup, but the French toast with citrus curd, strawberries, almonds and lavender honey melted in the mouth, and the sweet almond milkshake was, well, sweet. And delicious. Once.

The idea of Amanjena is to relax completely: read, sleep, be pampered at the health centre. A lot of the women guests - and, surprisingly, some of the men - seemed to be in the later stages of pregnancy. The hotel is the ideal place to escapebefore birth restricts your travel to somewhere only a couple of loo-stops away with easy access to a good maternity unit.

Those in search of pampering should head for the Hammam, where gommage awaits. This is blissful, if at first disconcerting. A young male attendant beckons you to sit naked in the steam room before washing you with black olive soap, scrubbing you with a coarse grooming mitt and applying a mixture of clay, dried lavender and rose petals, eucalyptus oil and rosewater to your body and limbs. Throwing buckets of water over fat guests must provide some fun for the attendant, but otherwise the pleasure is all yours. The same goes for the four-hand massage. Two therapists who (slightly worrying, this) giggle simultaneously.

For the rest, there are day trips, camel rides, a gym, and a golf course, which provides stunning views of the mountains, as picturesque as the Himalayas or the Sierra Nevada. We played in the afternoon and as the evening light threw a rosy wash over the peaks, the sky filled with huge ibises drifting in on the thermals to roost in the olive trees behind us. At one point I thought I heard the start of the call to evening prayer carry across the fairways, only to realise it was a distant cry of 'Fore!'

For your ventures into Marrakesh, there is the inevitable trip to the souk, that teeming labyrinth of sights and smells, from the sweet cedar scent of the woodcraft shops to the leather shops, spice stalls and tiny supermarkets whose stock consists of soap, candles, leather polish and, usefully enough, limitless outfits for Lady Penelope dolls. Indulge in that embarrassing haggle with a rug salesman who will ply you with mint tea until you're persuaded to buy that carpet. Stroll through the evening crowds in the Place Djmaa el Fna, where jugglers and street vendors jostle between scores of makeshift food stalls, bracelet sellers and rich carpet salesmen.

Visitors are often directed to Marrakesh's most famous restaurant, El Yacout, though from our experience it now seems to be trading heavily on its reputation. Make no mistake, the place is spectacular. The unassuming door leads into a magical setting: tables in cloisters set around an internal fountain; narrow stairs lead past more side chambers up to a roof terrace from which to take in the evening atmosphere over the city rooftops.

You'd have to climb a good deal further to have sufficient appetite for the food, which is something of a trial by quantity. Course after course keeps arriving: pale, fatty chicken, mutton with couscous and watery vegetables, oranges in syrup. El Yacout is the haunt of the well-heeled (you may well see your rug salesman there), but Le Tobsil may provide an alternative.

Back at base, Amanjena provides European fare (a truly delicious wild mushroom ragout, for example) or traditional Moroccan tagine or kebabs. Entertainment is provided by the kind of local dance troupe I imagine is kept tethered round the back in a compound somewhere. It's not something we have here. I don't think. Or do we? Is there a hotel in the Peak District somewhere that entertains guests with Morris Dancers?

Amanjena provides a perfect retreat, ideal for a short break. But a word of warning: it doesn't come cheap. A friend of mine was once working on a book entitled Europe on a Thousand Dollars a Day . I never knew if he finished it before the publisher went bust, but to be honest, he'd have struggled here. Pavilions are around £450 a night, maisons more. But you do save on the air fare (around £350 with British Airways), and four nights here will leave you more relaxed than a week in the Caribbean, with no crack-of-dawn departures, overnight flights or jetlag - the kind of stress-laden travel that can easily wipe out the benefits of going away. The 230-room Mamounia, for all its tradition and beautiful gardens, seems like a Costa del Sol package hotel by comparison.

If you want authentic Marrakesh, with all its sights, sounds and smells, best stay in town. Amanjena is the ultimate place to relax with as much, or as little, attention as possible. If you're unlucky with the weather, take refuge in the health spa or repair to the library, which in addition to books about Moroccan culture and traditions has a good stock of popular fiction and a surprisingly good selection of DVDs to enjoy in bed by your log fire. Marrakesh is even on GMT, so that if you really want to you can stride along the poolside talking to the office, like one particularly annoying Italian, but I don't recommend it.

I wanted to be sceptical on your behalf, I really did. But everything, from the temperature of the pool to the warmth and friendliness of the staff, disarms you. The greatest drawback is the cost: everything carries a 20 per cent tax and service charge, and at these prices they really shouldn't charge to take you into town. Those with pressing reasons to flee the country immediately (livestock farmers, Tory MPs, former Northern Ireland Secretaries), might well be scouring the brochures as I write. This may ease their burden. It will, however, also lighten their wallet. Just go.

For ever and ever Aman

What are Aman junkies?
An elite group of travellers who spend their lives jetting from one minimalist Aman resort to the other. Once hooked, no other hotel will do.

What's the lure?
Life is cool, cool, cool (and we're not referring to the sea temperatures). These 12 resort hotels combine stark design based on local materials with outrageously attentive service on remote desert beaches, tropical jungles and up misty mountains. Not a hint of chintz, frills or gilt in sight. It's so good, most people don't want or need to leave the resort. The hotel is the holiday.

So what's new about that?
The original one, Amanpuri, started a global trend among hotels when Singapore-based visionary founder Adrian Zecha opened it in Phuket, Thailand, in 1988. Till its invention, the more money you spent on hiring a hotel room, the more fuss you got. At Aman the philosophy is small is beautiful and less is more. Now rival hip hotels from deepest Patagonia to Sao Paulo follow in its wake.

Who do these junkies include?
Prince Andrew, Naomi Campbell and Pierce Brosnan are fans (remember the pics of Andrew on that yacht with those topless women? That was on an Amanpuri holiday). There's also an army of twentysomething dotcom millionaires (who cashed in their shares before the slump) and City folk following the Aman trail between French Polynesia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Mexico, US and France.

How much does it cost?
The average room is about £500 per night rising to around £4,000 for a top three-bedroom villa. Service is second to none. There are often five mind-reading members of staff to every guest. Wrapping orchids round your suitcase handles on departure is the sort of nonsense guests come to expect. The Mahakua Hacienda de San Antonio in western Mexico, a converted ranch with its own private airstrip, serves honey straight from nearby beehives and milk from the resident cows, has 26 rooms built from local lava stone and incorporates seven kilometres of Mexican woven fabric in the bedding and curtains.

Anything else?
Personal butlers, rooms with private pools, sunken baths and your own motorised private buggy to get from bed to beach are not uncommon. At Le Mèièzin in Courchevel you can ski straight in and out of the resort. At Amanwana on the tropical island of Moyo, a nature reserve east of Bali, you can stay in tents with air-con and enjoy massages in the jungle. At the Amanpulo, an entire coral island called Pamalican in the Philippines you stay in small houses modelled on native dwellings called bahay kubos . They range in size from nine to 55 rooms and fill up quickly (despite the price), usually by word of mouth.

So if I win the lottery or rob a bank where can I book?
Try Elegant Resorts (01244 897000); Western & Oriental (020 7313 6600); Classic Connection (0870 751 9310)

webTitle: Egypt acts to ease the Nile cruise crush

fields.headline: Egypt acts to ease the Nile cruise crush
fields.trailText: The Egyptian government has stopped issuing licences for new cruise boats, to ease overcrowding on the Nile.
fields.body:
The Egyptian government has stopped issuing licences for new cruise boats, to ease overcrowding on the Nile. Tourists on Nile cruises are having to step across up to five other boats at main tourist sites before reaching the shore.

Samia Khafaga, director of the Egyptian Tourist Office in London, said no new boat licences would be issued for the foreseeable future while new piers were built at ports such as Luxor and Aswan.

Helen Nicholls, of tour operator Hayes & Jarvis, welcomed the move. 'It is about time the government intervened,' she said. 'There are far too many cruise boats on the Nile and they tend to all berth alongside one another, which gives us major safety concerns. I have seen tourists clamber along from one berthing to another across many boats in order to gain access to their own boat. This is not acceptable.'

Nicholls urged the government to limit the number of vessels cruising the Nile at any one time. 'The hold-ups at Esna Lock can be very severe with boats waiting for up to eight hours to get through due to the sheer volume of cruisers,' she said. The number of boats on the river has increased rapidly from about 200 four years ago to 300 now.

Visitors are returning to Egypt as memories of the massacre of 58 tourists in Luxor in November 1997 recede. Last year a record 5.5 million tourists came to the country, a 14 per cent increase on the previous year.

Mandy Bales, managing director of Egypt specialist Bales Worldwide, said one confused client set off on the wrong cruise boat after having to step across a number of vessels to reach her own.

'It's also not very nice to be moored against another boat. Do you really want to look out of your cabin into someone else's cabin?' said Bales. 'You spoil the whole magic of the Nile if you overexploit it.'

 The Egyptian government will increase admission fees at tourist sites by 25 per cent in October. It will be the first increase in five years. Entrance fees to the Valley of the Kings near Luxor, for example, will increase from £4 to £5. A further 25 per cent increase is planned for October 2002.

webTitle: Travel Insurance: Don't shoot yourself in the foot

fields.headline: Don't shoot yourself in the foot
fields.standfirst: Check before cancelling a trip to the country, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Check before cancelling a trip to the country, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
If the foot and mouth epidemic threatens to spoil your Easter holiday in the English or French countryside, don't cancel your break until you work out whether you can get your money back.

Not all travel insurers will pay up, but there are other options. It is possible to go into the country, but farms, open areas and public footpaths are closed. A hike could cost you a £5,000 fine.

Although people cannot catch foot and mouth - they only carry it from place to place - you may feel you will no longer have enough freedom to enjoy your holiday.

But wriggling out of the booking could be expensive. 'The problem is that cancellation insurance is usually very specific about what it covers,' says Malcolm Tarling of the Association of British Insurers. 'You are insured if you or your travelling companion becomes ill, you are called for jury service or have your car stolen the week before you go away. But the outbreak of a contagious disease is not usually covered.'

The exception is when there is a clause saying you will be entitled to compensation if the cancellation is due to circumstances beyond your control provided - and this is key - you did not know about the problem before you took out the policy. Norwich Union offers this type of policy, and will pay out if your holiday home turns out to be in an exclusion zone.

Home & Overseas, the third-biggest provider of travel cover after CGNU and Axa, says foot and mouth does not qualify under its policies, though it looks at each case individually. 'No one foretold that foot and mouth would be a problem,' says spokeswoman Lisa Marshall.

Many people do buy cancellation cover, even for holidays in Britain, the ABI says. If you are not one of them and you call off your trip, you must ask the firm you booked with for a refund, which is at its discretion.

If you have a package, such as a train journey with hotel accommodation, approach the travel agent who sold it. Agents adhering to the Association of British Travel Agents' voluntary code of conduct will try to offer you an alternative holiday or a refund.

One million Britons usually take a break at Easter, according to broker Screentrade.co.uk. Foot and mouth may cramp your holiday style this year, but pity the poor people in the quarantined areas, who will not be allowed to go anywhere.

webTitle: Winging it: The need for speed

fields.headline: The need for speed
fields.standfirst: Martin Buckley flies higher than a 747 back from America in a Lear Jet, the choice of VIPs in a hurry
fields.trailText: Martin Buckley flies higher than a 747 back from America in a Lear Jet, the choice of VIPs in a hurry.
fields.body:
The factory-fresh Lear Jet took off from Santa Monica Airport like a bullet, banked steeply over the Pacific and began to climb. Swaddled in buttery leather and burnished mahogany, I observed the world from the perspective of the Fortune 500. It's surprisingly difficult to find out who actually does travel in these flying Ferraris, since the manufacturer and the airlines maintain a Trappist silence on the subject. Beyond glamour, Lear Jets give their customers something even more desirable: anonymity.

While the paparazzi mill around at Heathrow, Elton John or Julia Roberts could slip into Biggin Hill and be on their way to the Dorchester without anyone but the bloke in the tiny customs post being any the wiser.

The red landscapes of Indian country - the Grand Canyon, Monument Valley - slid beneath us; 90 minutes later we had crossed half of the USA, and were already starting our descent on the Midwest. The flat farm town of Wichita is, puzzlingly, the home of a large chunk of the American aviation industry. 'They say it's because Wichita's close to the geographic centre of the US,' said pilot Will Curtis, 'but I think it's because Wichita is America's most boring city. Plane building developed so people could get away as quickly as possible.'

We refuelled and flew on into Canada. Our last fuel stop needed to be as far east as possible, but blizzards were sweeping the East Coast. As weather information poured onto the cockpit's computer displays, we were threatened with diversions as far north as Greenland or Iceland. Finally we landed in snow at the small town of Stephenville, Newfoundland, at 3am. We had around 30 minutes before the engines iced up or the weather worsened. Another tiny corporate jet emerged from the driving snow and parked beside us. I walked past snow ploughs to the shack where coffee and piles of that Canadian delicacy, the doughnut, waited to reinforce passing aviators. Then we were airborne again.

Dawn approached, and the autopilot bore us across the Atlantic towards Ireland. Lear pilots sit before three TV screens that represent the scores of rotary dials in a conventional plane. I took the co-pilot's seat beside Will. The cockpit was eerily still and silent. The sky straight ahead of us - due east - was slowly growing pink.

Will pointed down. 'I used to be down there, you know. I was a yacht-delivery captain for years. There was this one transatlantic crossing that was particularly nasty - I mean, really wet. I got to the airport in New York to come back home, and as they were weighing my luggage there was seawater coming out of my suitcase onto the scales. I climbed on the plane, and I thought, "Whoever flies this thing never gets wet, and sees his family more than I do." I got back, and told my wife I wanted to train to be a pilot. Six months later, I had my licence.'

Will is a man of action. He'd hate that description, but he's no ordinary pilot. At weekends he does displays of aerobatic precision in a red biplane. In the last decade he's gone from an impecunious yacht captain to managing director of Gold Air International, which is currently taking delivery of five Lear Jets at a cost of $50 million.

webTitle: Your room with a view of history

fields.headline: Your room with a view of history
fields.standfirst: Stay in a palace in the heart of the serene city for as little as £50 a night
fields.trailText: Stay in a palace in the heart of the serene city for as little as £50 a night.
fields.body:
Traditionally, the weekend visitor to Venice faced a stark choice: blow the budget on a luxury palace hotel or pay over the odds for a grotty dive with cramped, damp rooms, the bathroom at the end of a cold corridor, and a tepid cappuccino for breakfast.

And that's if you were lucky enough to get a room. A shortage of accommodation means that for peak weekends in spring and autumn, hotels are fully booked as much as six months in advance. As one city break operator points out: 'If you've got rooms in Venice you can charge what you like for them, and most of them do. You won't get a decent three-star hotel room for less than £150 a night.'

However, the good news is that local restrictions on opening and operating small bed and breakfast properties were lifted last year resulting in a new type of accommodation for Venice: locandas are small, family-run inns in beautifully renovated palaces. In the last year, about 20 have sprung up, offering double rooms from as little as £50 a night.

Decorated with chandeliers, frescoes and antiques, they offer all the luxury of a grand hotel, lacking only the trappings such as a concierge and 24-hour room service. The owners are usually on hand themselves running the place, the fur nishings are exquisite, breakfast is meticulously prepared and guests have the luxurious feeling of staying in an authentic Venetian palazzo.

Often hidden away in back streets, these locandas are the perfect places to base yourself, quietly discover sights that are off the usual tourist track, and come upon bars and restaurants where you will also discover Venice's outstanding local cuisine and wines. Here are a pick of the best and newest spots.

1 Locanda Martini
Rio Terra San Leonardo, 1314 Cannaregio
Tel: 041 717 512
www.casamartini.it
double room from £60

There's not even a sign outside to help travellers find this tiny lodging house, a mere five rooms occupying one floor of an ancient mansion. There's a real feeling of staying in a private Venetian home, with a friendly communal kitchen for making tea and coffee and a sunny verandah overlooking a walled garden for romantic breakfasts. This locanda is just off one of the city's prettiest canals, the busy Canale di Cannaregio, where you can bag an outdoor table at one of the many waterside osterias and watch the non-stop traffic of boats, water buses and rowers rushing past.

2 Locanda ai Santi Apostoli
Strada Nuova 4391, Cannaregio
Tel: 041 521 2612
double room from around £133

One of the earliest private palaces to be transformed into an intimate locanda, the Santi Apostoli is on the top floor (there is a lift) of an elegant palazzo, with wonderful views over the Grand Canal. Prices are not so cheap, though. Expect to pay an additional 100,000 lire for a room with a view over the canal. This locanda is just by one of the access points for a 'traghetto', the local gondola service for crossing the water. Everyone visiting Venice should try this at least once, as this fun trip will set you back only 30p. Arriving on the other side, you're right in the heart of the bustling Rialto fish and vegetable market, whose sights, sounds and smells are not to be missed by anyone with the vaguest interest in Italian food.

3 Locanda Leon Bianco
Corte Leon Bianco 5629, Cannaregio
Tel: 041 523 3572
www.leonbianco.it
double room from £68

Located almost next door to the Santi Apostoli, the Leon Bianco is a much more down-to-earth residence, though it offers similar views. Check out one room that is decorated with a stunning fresco copied from a Paolo Veronese painting.

4 Locanda Casa Verado
Calle Castagna 4765 Castello
Tel: 041 528 6138
double room from around £85

Newly renovated, the cosy Casa Verado is one of the most seductive of the city's new locandas. Filling one floor of a sixteenth-century palace, the rooms are decorated with tasteful antiques, and most have views over the canals. In the summer there's an airy terrazza for breakfast, while in winter guests are served their food in the comfortable lobby. Casa Verado is located in a down-to-earth, working- class area of the Castello neighbourhood.

5 Locanda Vivaldi
Riva degli Schiavoni 4150, Castello
Tel: 041 277 0477
www.locandavivaldi.it
double room from £112 (lagoon view £34 supplement)

Of all the new locandas, the Vivaldi is the chicest and the closest to being a real hotel, which is not surprising given its location overlooking St Mark's basin, a stone's throw from the grand palace hotels lining Riva degli Schiavoni. The antiques furnishing every room are sumptuous, and the plush entrance cannot fail to impress. It is worth paying a supplement for a room with the ultimate view of St Mark's.

6 Locanda la Corte
Calle Bressana 6317, Castello
Tel: 041 241 1300
www.locandalacorte.it
double room from £102

This locanda takes its name from the palace's interior courtyard, the kind of Venetian secret that most visitors never realise exists behind the closed door on the street. The young owners serve breakfast and early evening drinks in the courtyard. The rooms have all been beautifully renovated and decorated with antique furniture and Murano glass chandeliers. Just by the locanda is one of the city's prettiest and liveliest squares, the Campo Santa Maria Formosa, perfect just for sitting out on a cafe terrace and watching local life pass by.

7 La Residenza
Campo Bandiera e Moro 3608, Castello
Tel: 041 528 5315
double room from around £68

The 'piano nobile' of this venerable gothic palace makes for one of the most stunning lobbies in all Venice, the perfect place for reading and taking afternoon tea or cocktails. Although the rooms are fine, they don't quite match up to the first impressions when you check in. From here, it's a short walk to explore the narrow backstreets around the Arsenale, once the great shipyards providing the galleys for the Venetian fleet.

8 Locanda al Leon
Campo Santi Filippo e Giacamo 4270, Castello
Tel: 041 277 0393
www.hotelalleon.com
double room from £54

This friendly, family-run locanda has more of the feel of a country bed and breakfast place than a city hotel. The rooms are cosy but quite small, tastefully decorated without feeling plush. The big plus is the central location, a minute's walk from St Mark's, the Doge's Palace and the Bridge of Sighs, and directly behind the far more expensive Danieli Hotel.

9 Locanda San Barnaba
Calle del Traghetto 2786, Dorsoduro
Tel: 041 241 1233
www.locanda-sanbarnaba.com
double room from £85

The entrance and reception area of this locanda are not terribly impressive, but wait until you climb to the first floor, where the vast drawing room of this sixteenth-century palace is decorated with delicate pastel frescoes. The rooms are designed around themes such as 'the artist's studio' and 'the playwright's chamber'.

10 Locanda Casa Querini
Campo San Giovanni Novo 4388, Castello
Tel: 041 241 1294
double room from around £68

The setting could not be more perfect - a discreet palace hidden away in a tranquil campo just a couple of minutes from the crowds thronging the Piazza San Marco. The rooms are well decorated, though the breakfast salon doesn't quite live up to the rest of the surroundings. This locanda takes its name from the nearby Museo Querini Stampalia, an often overlooked museum set in a Renaissance palace that hosts offbeat temporary exhibitions, often on glass or photography, and has an excellent series of Tiepolo paintings of daily Venetian life in its permanent collection.

11 Locanda Antico Doge
Sottoportego Falier 5643, Cannaregio
Tel: 041 241 1570
www.anticodoge.com
double room from £68

This plush residence is set in a thirteenth-century palace, the Palazzo Falier, once the home of a Venetian Doge. It looks over a busy canal where gondolas whisk back and forth, with the packed square Campo Sant' Apostoli in the background. A couple of minutes' walk from the hotel is an undistinguished church that most tourists walk straight past, the Chiesa Giovanni Grisostomo. Take the time to drop in though, as you'll discover a gem of a portrait by Bellini, painted in 1513 when he was over 80.

Eating out

John Brunton offers a personal selection of the most intimate restaurants and osterias where you can rub shoulders with the locals and try out Venetian specialities:

 Venetian wine lovers adore La Cantina (041 522 8258), which is great for a light lunch of grilled vegetables and home-made soup accompanied by some of the finest vintages of Italian wines.

 The Osteria al Pampo Sant' Elena (041 520 8419) offers great 'home cooking' favourites. The atmosphere is similar in the little-known Osteria Alle Alpi (041 528 5163), or Dante's Place, where the patron's wife serves tiny baby octopi and grilled squid.

 For a romantic meal at a serious gastronomic address, book a table at the Ristorante Al Covo (041 522 3812), where the chef, Cesare, is a native Venetian, while the dining room is run by his friendly American wife, who is excellent at explaining local dishes and advising on regional wines.

 Al Mascaron (041 522 5995) has become something of a Venetian dining institution, as well-known these days among tourists as locals. The chef, Carlo, delivers an unforgettable spaghetti con astice, pasta covered with succulent lobster morsels.

 The Corte Sconta (041 522 7024) restaurant is one of the city's gastronomic landmarks. Prices are not cheap these days, but you'll experience a non-stop feast of delicious local dishes, culminating in an unforgettable fritto misto.

 If you feel like a change from the fish and seafood that dominates Venetian cuisine, reserve a table at L'Incontro (041 522 2404), a rustic, Sardinian-run restaurant that specialises in meat dishes. Especially tasty are the grilled baby chicken and crackling roast pork.

 The tiny bar of the Trattoria Alla Rivetta (041 528 7302) is always packed with tourists waiting for a table and locals popping in for a glass of chilled white wine. The friendly patron, Stefano, serves up delicious titbits of crisply fried calamari to keep everyone happy.

 Just across the square, L'Aciughetta (041 522 4292) - the Anchovy Bar - serves a great choice of anchovy tapas and has a lengthy list of fine Italian wines.

 For a serious taste of Venetian cooking, such as minuscule prawns heaped on creamy polenta, book a table well in advance in the stylish Fiaschetteria Toscana (041 528 5281), a restaurant much favoured by locals.

 For a cheap and cheerful self-service bar which is great value for lunch, check out the Enoteca Boldrin (041 523 7859). It also has a wide selection of regional wines on sale to take away.

 La Vedova (tel: 041 528 5324), 'the widow's place', is one of the city's oldest and most beautiful traditional osterias. The food lives up to the surroundings, especially spaghetti alla busola , in a spicy seafood sauce.

 For a contrast, stop off for an ombra, a 30p glass of wine, at Osteria Alla Rampa (041 523 0024), a local watering-hole run by the formidable but charming Signora Leli.

 Almost opposite the entrance to the Locanda Leon is one of Venice's most famous pastry bars, the Pasticceria da Bonifacio (041 522 7507). The crowds thronging the counter aren't here for the sweet pastries, though, but for the lethal cocktails - spritz al bitter, negroni and americano - all based on Campari.

Getting there...

British Airways (0845 7799977)
Alitaliar (0870 5448259)
Ryanair (0541 569 569)
Go (08456 054321)

The international dialling code for Venice is 0039, followed by 041 (do not drop the zero). When dialling local numbers within Venice, the 041 code is required.

fields.headline: Londoners are the lightest packers
fields.trailText: A quarter of Londoners take only one piece of hand luggage away for a one-week break.
fields.body:
Not everyone travels with 20 suitcases like Posh Spice when they go on holiday. A new survey commissioned by Visa has revealed that the British public are travelling much lighter than they used to.

Londoners are the lightest packers with almost a quarter taking only one piece of hand luggage away for a one-week break.

The Scottish follow closely behind with 17 per cent taking one piece of hand luggage when they go on a trip.

'People are now packing prudently, judging items by their usefulness,' said a spokeswoman for the credit card company. 'Most travellers are finding that they simply do not use the vast majority of items they take with them and they end up with overpacked, heavy luggage of no real use. It's definitely a case of quality over quantity.'

The top five most popular travelling items taken overseas are credit/debit cards, camera, foreign currency, mobile phones and sun tan lotion.

However, Posh Spice may have had some influence over people from south-west England, who take more than two pieces of hand luggage and two pieces of check-in luggage when they go away.

fields.headline: Swiss bank on spliffing image
fields.trailText: A new Bill legalising cannabis may be passed by the Swiss government.
fields.body:
One of the unlikely candidates of Zurich or Geneva could soon take over from Amsterdam as favourite European city for a weekend of spliff-induced fun, if a new Bill legalising cannabis is passed by the Swiss government.

The success of the Bill could mean the stereotypical tourist image of Switzerland as all mountains, lederhosen, chocolate, watches and boring bankers being thrown into disarray as young travellers are lured by the attraction of cheap soft drugs, the strong pound and cheap airline connections.

Until the recent launches of low-cost airlines such as EasyJet and Buzz, air fares from the UK were prohibitively expensive. But you can now fly to Geneva from Stansted on Buzz for as little as £100 return or on EasyJet from Luton or Liverpool for £50 return. Zurich is available on EasyJet from Luton from £60 return.

A spokeswoman for the Swiss Travel Service said: 'It might increase Switzerland's popularity if the Bill went through. Zurich is quite trendy and has quite a young image. If this Bill is passed, it could bring a younger element to Switzerland.'

An EasyJet spokesman thought the move might spice up Switzerland's image.

'Would it have some impact on our business? Yes. Would we specifically market Switzerland as a place for drugs? No,' he said.

Russell Palmer of Switzerland Tourism said it was too early to predict if the government would this week fully endorse the Bill to legalise the use of cannabis and allow a limited number of 'dope shops'.

Zurich already has a big drug scene and Switzerland is a large producer of marijuana. Although to many Brits Zurich has a squeaky-clean image, there is a seedy side to it and a hedonistic nightlife.

 Swiss Travel Service (0870 727 5910). Buzz (0870 240 7070). EasyJet (0870 6000 000).

The success of the Bill could mean the stereotypical tourist image of Switzerland as all mountains, lederhosen, chocolate, watches and boring bankers being thrown into disarray as young travellers are lured by the attraction of cheap soft drugs, the strong pound and cheap airline connections. Until the recent launches of low-cost airlines such as EasyJet and Buzz, air fares from the UK were prohibitively expensive. But you can now fly to Geneva from Stansted on Buzz for as little as £100 return or on EasyJet from Luton or Liverpool for £50 return. Zurich is available on EasyJet from Luton from £60 return. fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Late bargains, by  Jeannette Hyde
fields.trailText: Paris | Crete | Eilat
fields.body:
Under £150

 To extend your range of pulling power, why not do a night out in Paris and sleep off the hangover on the dawn train home? Eurostar has £35 returns to Paris going out early evening, returning on the first train next day. If you're a student you qualify for this deal - and are probably in a position to go clubbing mid-week (valid Tuesday-Friday till 31 March). Phone STA Travel 020 7361 6143.

 Rummage for antiques in Brussels. One of Europe's best antiques markets is held at the Place du Grand Sablon from nine till five on Saturdays and nine till one on Sundays. Shortbreaks (020 8402 0007) has two-night packages including breakfast and Eurostar for £149 per person (sharing) if booked and taken before 17 April.

Under £300

 Don't assume you need a whole week off work to catch some rays on the Med this spring. Thomson now has trips lasting three nights which means you can pop to the Med, catch a quick tan and be back at work one bonkbuster later. Three nights at the Thomson Gold Hotel Levante Park, Majorca (where kids are banned), is £269 per person (sharing) half-board including flights and transfers, departing 30 April. Phone 0990 502555.

 You can buy two weeks in Crete through Direct Line Holidays (020 8239 3399) for £299 per person (based on two sharing), staying at the Aeolos Apartments in the fishing village of Almirida at the mouth of Souda Bay. Depart Gatwick on 17 or 24 April. Pack your fleece. Weather can be patchy at this time of year, although 20C is common.

 Spring's one of the nicest times of year to stroll round Barcelona admiring the Gaudi architecture and guzzling cava and tapas along the way. The clammy heat of summer hasn't yet set in and the biting cold is over. Eurobreak (020 8780 7700) has three-night breaks at the two-star Santa Marta Hotel on a B&B basis, flying from Manchester or Birmingham with Iberia, starting at £287 per person travelling between 17 April and early July.

Under £600

 For a short break with a difference, pop over to San Francisco for four nights at the Hotel Bijou, which houses an Art Deco theatre with nightly screenings of movies set in the city. The hotel can also help you become an extra in a film (jetlag permitting). Prices start at £485 per person including return flights from Gatwick, B&B and Alcatraz tour. Bookings must be made by tomorrow.

 Now's the time to pick up a bargain to Eilat. Troubles elsewhere in Israel have dampened interest in the Red Sea resort - but tourist authorities stress that Eilat is unaffected. Longwood Holidays (020 8551 4494) has one-week packages departing Luton on 23 April for £525 per person, including B&B at the Holiday Inn Express, return flights, five days diving and a boat trip.

 Some people insist Barbados has become the Blackpool of the Caribbean but, whatever they say, the weather's better. Trailfinders (020 7937 5400) has one-week packages for £590 per person including return flights from Gatwick and room-only at the Bougainvillaea Beach Resort. Book by 31 March for departures between 12 May and 28 June.

webTitle: If it's snowing, it must be time for Turkey

fields.headline: If it's snowing, it must be time for Turkey
fields.standfirst: It has perfect pistes, plus minarets and hookah pipes.  Nigel Lloyd  finds a warm welcome in chilly Palandöken
fields.trailText: It has perfect pistes, plus minarets and hookah pipes. Nigel Lloyd finds a warm welcome in chilly Palandöken.
fields.body:
It is not often these days that you discover a ski resort with 50km of piste and eight lifts which few people in this country have heard of, let alone skied.

Where then is this unknown mountain resort? Does it help if I tell you it is just 6km south of Erzurum, an ancient, mysterious city, which for most of its long existence has been closed to foreigners? And that it is 1,299km east of Istanbul in Eastern Anatolia. There you have it: Palandöken is a Turkish resort, the best of that country's burgeoning collection of developed ski areas.

The mountain rises to a summit of 3,200m, with a vertical drop of 1,100m, and a long run from top to bottom. There are two black, eight red and seven blue runs, all pisted. And there are four off-piste itineraries as well as an immense variety of free-riding opportunities all over Palandöken's open, treeless flanks which are virtually all skiable. This makes them ideal for snowboarding as well as skiing.

There are two resort hotels, the four-star Dedeman at 2,450m and the five-star Polat Renaissance only just opened at the base station. Both are large, well-equipped hotels with pools and gyms. We stayed in the Dedeman, though at one stage it seemed we might not make it. After a rather dry winter Turkey was in the grip of a freezing storm as we flew in, and the hotel bus came to a grinding halt on the icy road, forcing us to continue the hair-raising journey by taxi.

Next day dawned calm, sunny and very cold, and the lifts began working even if the piste machines were frozen solid for a while. After some warm-up runs on the hotel's T-bar, then a longer run down beneath the gondola and back up a double-chair, I was glad to dive into the welcoming warmth of a mid-mountain restaurant and its blazing log fire.

Our instructor, Chetin, a 32-year-old local lad who had been a ski-racer until the almost inevitable knee trouble, was happy to sit and chat over Turkish coffee and pastries while the winds picked up outside. A few last runs and it was time ski back down to our hotel.

From there we drove into town - taxis are very cheap - for a late lunch at the Erzurum Evleri, a traditional Turkish restaurant. It is a myriad of interconnected little windowless rooms in which you sit on cushions around low circular tables. Lunch was a delicious hot yoghurt soup, followed by huge plates of salad and mixed grills. After more Turkish coffee, a hookah water pipe stoked with tobacco suddenly appeared and was passed round for everyone to try a puff.

Erzurum is a city of ancient mosques - one, built in the thirteenth-century is famous for its twin minarets. We also drove up to one of the hilltop fortresses surviving from the Middle Ages when Turks and Byzantines fought over this religious stronghold.

Much later Erzurum was taken three times by the Russians but the Turks always got it back. It is not often you can mix skiing with such interesting sightseeing. Mt Ararat, Turkey's highest, where Noah's ark is thought to have come to rest, is only a few kilometres further east.

There is also plenty of good-value shopping in Erzurum. Leather jackets, Turkish rugs, local jet stone jewellery, all make a pleasant change from the usual ludicrously expensive goggles and ridiculous ski hats.

Our hotel had the pool tables, without which no ski holiday seems complete, bars and discos, as well as tea-dancing on the terrace tables in ski-boots, and a shopping mall.

The locals have a saying that proved only too true during our visit: 'The weather in Erzurum may be cold, but the hearts of the people are warm.' Nothing was too much trouble for anybody in the well-staffed hotels, from bell boys to managers. They and the ski instructors are all looking forward to British skiers enjoying their resort next winter.

Getting there

Inghams (020 8780 4444), the Swiss-owned British tour operator, has chartered a 180-seat plane to fly each Sunday next winter to Palandöken direct from Gatwick in four hours 45 minutes. The resort is family friendly with a free baby club (6 months - 2 years) and Kindergarten (3-8 years). Up to four children ski free when one adult pre-books a lift pass. Half-board prices start at £349 per person sharing.

webTitle: Republicans feud over hunger striker's legacy

fields.headline: Republicans feud over hunger striker's legacy
fields.standfirst:
Bobby Sands's family attack Sinn Fein in dispute over protest anniversary

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: It was supposed to be a golden opportunity to unite the republican movement at a difficult time in the Northern Ireland peace process. The name of Bobby Sands has for two decades been invoked by the Sinn Fein and IRA leadership as the ultimate example of dedication to the cause.
fields.body:
It was supposed to be a golden opportunity to unite the republican movement at a difficult time in the Northern Ireland peace process. The name of Bobby Sands has for two decades been invoked by the Sinn Fein and IRA leadership as the ultimate example of dedication to the cause.

But far from promoting union, plans to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the H-Block hunger strikes, in which Sands and nine other men died, have descended into acrimony and bitterness as dissident republicans vie with Sinn Fein for control of his legacy.

Twenty years ago, the IRA and INLA prisoners starved themselves to death in the Maze prison - formerly known as Long Kesh - in an attempt to gain political prisoner status from the British government. A watershed in the Troubles, the deaths led to a huge outpouring of support for the Provisional IRA.

Sands was 26 and serving 14 years for firearms offences when he began refusing food on 1 March 1981. Elected an MP during his fast, he resisted all pleas to call it off. His death after 66 days sparked violent protests and led to worldwide condemnation of Margaret Thatcher and her government.

Now Sinn Fein has been attacked for planning a series of events including lectures, rallies, plays and a protest outside Thatcher's London home to commemorate the event. Critics, including the Sands family, have reacted with fury, accusing the Republican leadership of betraying the cause of a united Ireland and using the emotion of the anniversary to boost its own election chances.

A painting by Robert Ballagh, a leading Irish artist, was commissioned to depict the death of the ten. It shows a large H breaking apart and 10 white doves flying into the air. Above is the word 'Legacy'.

Sands's family and friends, including Bernadette Sands McKevitt, linked to the Real IRA, said the painting did not reflect the period or represent what he died for. They object to the use of 10 white doves to symbolise the hunger strikers, an image they believe fits in more with current Sinn Fein peace strategy. 'Bobby was many things but he was not a dove,' a friend of the family told The Observer .

The Sands family has also complained about the use of Sands's writings and image to promote Sinn Fein's policies. Relatives are currently engaged in a legal dispute to wind up the Bobby Sands Trust, an organisation that still owns his writings, claiming the trust is too close to the Sinn Fein leadership.

Some of the 13 prisoners who survived the hunger strike have, in general, remained loyal to the republican leadership of Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness. They include Laurence McKeown who survived more than 70 days and recently recorded his experiences in a documentary he co-directed.

Other ex-IRA inmates who took part in a previous hunger strike, such as Brendan 'Darkie' Hughes, the former Provisional commander in Belfast, believe Sands and his comrades did not die in order to achieve the present political settlement. They wanted a united Ireland.

www.larkspirit.com/hungerstrikes

webTitle: Police given new powers to test for drug-driving

fields.headline: Police given new powers to test for drug-driving
fields.standfirst:
Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Motorists will be tested for drug abuse in the first nationwide crackdown on drug-driving, beginning this week. Police have been given new powers to force drivers whom they suspect have taken drugs to perform a series of 'coordination' tests.
fields.body:
Motorists will be tested for drug abuse in the first nationwide crackdown on drug-driving, beginning this week. Police have been given new powers to force drivers whom they suspect have taken drugs to perform a series of 'coordination' tests.

Strathclyde Police will launch the scheme on Wednesday, after which it will be copied by forces across the country. The crackdown comes after surveys by System Three and Glasgow University revealed that one in 10 drivers under the age of 40 had taken to the wheel after taking illegal drugs ranging from cannabis to cocaine; four-fifths had accepted a lift in a car driven by someone who had taken drugs.

The studies showed many young drivers took drugs in the belief the police could not conduct effective roadside tests. But ministers have given officers powers to conduct 'field impairment tests' similar to those used to detect drink-drivers before the introduction of breathalysers. Motorists will be asked to stand with feet together, eyes closed and head tilted back, and to estimate time periods of between 30 seconds and one minute. They will be told to walk in a straight line, turn around and walk back the same way. They can be asked to touch their nose with the index finger on one hand and then the other index finger. They can also be told to stand on one leg.

Officers will check for symptoms of drug abuse, including dilated pupils, sweating and slurred speech. If they suspect a driver has taken drugs, he or she will be taken to the nearest police station for a blood test. Drivers who refuse to take the tests will be forced to give a blood sample.

'There is no drugs breathalyser and roadside blood or saliva tests are impractical, but these coordination tests work,' a spokesman for Strathclyde Police said. A two-week pilot scheme on roads around Glasgow last year led to the arrest of 22 people. Prescription drugs, including cold and cough remedies, can also affect driving ability.

The scheme is welcomed by road safety groups. Neil Grieg of the AA said: 'People taking illegal drugs and then driving believe they can get away with it... officers now have a real weapon to tackle the problem.'

Lord Whitty, the Roads Minister, said: 'The techniques are simple and straightforward, and can be applied anywhere to help enforce existing laws with greater rigour.'

The scheme was developed in Strathclyde because the Glasgow region has the highest number of registered and suspected drug abusers in the UK, with an estimated 10,000 heroin addicts in Glasgow alone.

john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: How the market made us stupid
fields.standfirst: Financial crises in the United States and Japan are about to teach the world an awesome lesson: the money-go-round must be regulated
fields.trailText: Will Hutton: Financial crises in the United States and Japan are about to teach the world an awesome lesson: the money-go-round must be regulated.
fields.body:
Four trillion dollars is a lot of money. It is the entire annual output of Britain and France put together. It is also the amount American investors in high-tech shares have lost over the past 12 months - and that's before their losses in the rest of the stock market.

The entire rickety American economic success story has rested on a crazy stock market boom so that even taxi drivers were trading in dot.com stocks and running up unparalleled levels of debt because they felt so wealthy. Now they are left, like the rest of America, with the debts and worthless stocks.

And the crisis in the American financial system is matched by one in Japan. Japan's massive financial bubble burst 10 years ago and it has yet to clear up the financial detritus. The banking system is racked by up to $350 billion of bad debts, but the banks' capacity to ride the financial hit is undermined by the downward plunge of the Japanese stock market because their own capital is invested in the shares of other banks - a double whammy which already means many are technically bankrupt. And if we take seriously the hint from Japanese finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa that Japan might be the first major state since the war to unilaterally write down the value of its national debt, its financial system has to be regarded as on the brink. For the world to have one calamity would be bad enough; to have two simultaneously is more than careless.

It is eerily reminiscent not of the kind of recessions of the post-war period - which have been painful enough - but of the recessions up until 1930, as Larry Summers, the outgoing US Treasury Secretary, has said. Japan and the US have in their different ways made the cardinal error; they allowed their stock markets to become too intertwined with their overall financial system, reinventing the impulses that made nineteenth and early twentieth century recessions so vicious. What made those recessions last twice as long as post-war recessions was that they were accompanied and reinforced by bank and stock market collapses.

In Britain there is no longer any folk memory of what it means for a bank to go bankrupt, but as recently as the 1880s major banks could go bust, sending local economies into tailspin; firms lost their credit lines and workers and consumers their savings. In the US the experience was no less raw. The New York stock market began to have national importance as early as the mid-nineteenth century, and its ups and downs rippled out across the national economy. Banks were no more stable than the strength of the city or town in which they traded, and if one went down others followed like nine-pins. As the pace of industrialisation and urbanisation quickened in Europe and the US, workers could be suddenly thrown out of work by equally sudden contractions of credit lines and investment funds. The 1930s slump was the last of the great stock market and bank-induced economic collapses.

The great success story of the 50 years that followed, led by liberal and social democratic politicians, was to tame these wild forces. A mixture of regulation, credit control and state intervention in the banking system stabilised the financial system while welfare states helped underwrite the risk to ordinary workers and give them buying power that contributed to stabilising demand.

But as the consequences of the irrationalities of stock market gyrations and wild bank-lending - the consequence of applying free market economic principles to finance - were forgotten, so the reasons for the regulations were forgotten too. Know-nothing politicians of the Right, their intellectual acolytes and financier paymasters lobbied increasingly for 'deregulation' and 'liberalisation'. Bit by bit the controls came off. In the US, Rooseveltian financial reforms of the New Deal were scrapped over the 1980s and 1990s as hindering the competitiveness of US banking. American finance now has all the 'freedoms' it had in the nineteenth century, taking us back to the same wild capitalism.

My hunch is that the world is about to learn an awesome lesson; the conservative theorists were wrong and the liberal Keynesians right. Moreover, IT has been one of the reasons it has been so hard to regulate finance, with the borders between banks and the stock market becoming so much more porous; banks may be bigger but their disastrous nineteenth century-type exposures to stock market losses have been reinvented. To be effective regulation had to become smarter, faster and more international, but in the current environment building the essentially left-of-centre coalitions that might effect such regulation has been difficult.

So we are where we are. In the US, rather like the 1920s, the stock market boom spawned a massive misallocation of savings as Americans abandoned caution and played the markets. They have been duped into running up a scale of personal debt rarely witnessed. Worse, the prospect of easy profit has created a new populism in which stock ownership and speculation are portrayed as democratically enfranchising - while progressive politics, with its instinct to contain and regulate finance, is cast as against the best interests of the people.

Unravelling stock market bubbles is always painful when the linkages have been allowed to infect the entire financial system; the ordinary credit lines that lubricate the wider economy become polluted by what has happened in the stock market. In this respect Japan presents a warning. The losses go so deep that policy interventions such as lowering interest rates and reducing taxes are much less effective than they were in the immediate post-war period. The US has a market structure that means it will get the adjustment over more quickly and radically than Japan - but that means any recession will be compensatingly more intense.

Europe will not escape the fall-out - but it is in a much stronger position precisely because its stock markets (except in Britain) have a much less central role in its financial system. And despite some wobble under fire from ignorant American critics and their British poodles, Europe has maintained a regulatory structure that retains that insulation. As that realisation grows, the European Union will be seen as a safe haven. And Britain will be glad to be a member of a club in which economic activity is not seen as the by-product of a casino.

fields.headline: Tube row ends in £13bn deal
fields.trailText: Up to £13 billion is to be spent upgrading London's Underground system after an historic agreement on ownership of the Tube was thrashed out by the Government and the London Transport Commissioner Robert Kiley.
fields.body:
Up to £13 billion is to be spent upgrading London's Underground system after an historic agreement on ownership of the Tube was thrashed out by the Government and the London Transport Commissioner Robert Kiley.

Senior sources said last night that John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, and Kiley, the man who turned around the New York subway, will agree in the next two days to a fundamental change in the way the Underground is managed.

The deal will bring to an end one of the longest running and embarrassing disputes the Government has faced. Kiley threatened to walk out of his post and return to the United States because of rows over Government plans for partially privatising of the Tube.

'It has been quite a battle,' said a Government official last night. 'But we have fought our way through and there seems to be agreement.'

The major sticking point was over Government plans to bring private investment into the Tube, the so-called public-private partnership (PPP). Three companies would own different Underground lines and would run them in competition with each other.

Kiley said that the plans were 'idiotic', overly complex and would increase the risk of safety lapses.

The breakthrough came on Friday night when Kiley, who was hired by the Mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, produced a 55-point plan on how the Underground should be run.

The Government has now conceded to most of Kiley's demands, although it has not agreed to him owning a 51 per cent share of the Tube. Instead Kiley will be given hiring and firing powers over the chief executives of the three companies that will take over running the Tube. He will also be left in sole charge of maintenance - and therefore safety - of the Underground which will be paid for by the companies.

Livingstone based his mayoral campaign on his rejection of PPP. But it is thought that, because Kiley has now been given responsibility for safety, he can agree to the three-company structure.

Kiley will also be given powers to take control of some aspects of the private companies if he thinks that investment plans or safety projects are not up to scratch.

'Now that we can go ahead it will mean a lot more money being released to modernise and maintain the Tube,' the government official said. 'We want the public to start seeing a difference by the end of the year.'

The £13bn will be released over a 15-year period, but much of it paid upfront to get emergency work done.
