webTitle: Comment: we could make this land beautiful again

fields.headline: The farmers ruined our  countryside.  Now we have a chance to  take it back
fields.standfirst:
Scrap the obscene agriculture subsidies and we could make this land beautiful again, says forestry chief David Cox

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Scrap the obscene agriculture subsidies and we could make this land beautiful again, says forestry chief David Cox.
fields.body:
Perhaps it was the news that the extermination of Dartmoor's ponies is only off the agenda 'for now'. Or the realisation that the lives of bed-and-breakfast owners are being smashed to maximise the export earnings of a privileged few. Or the contrast between automatic compensation for farmers and official indifference to other victims.

Whatever it was, the great plague of 2001 seems to have created a seismic shift in attitudes to Britain's rural regime.

The BBC's lingering pictures of tearful farmers' wives seem to have evoked something other than unqualified sympathy. At last people are beginning to ask why we have to put up with all this. Before foot and mouth closed the countryside and demanded yet another dollop of taxpayers' cash, we had swine fever and BSE. All these were brought to us by an industry which pollutes our water, abuses its animals and engages in the wholesale destruction of our landscape, wildlife and archeological heritage. An industry whose practitioners expect us to pay for all this through limitless subsidy and inflated food prices, and then object to a right to roam.

Why? There is no obvious answer. Britain's farming industry is a marginal player in a globally ever more competitive business. To survive, it finds it necessary to wreak continual havoc on the rest of us. Yet it could not exist on its current scale without the array of subsidies and other privileges we choose to bestow on it. Guess what? We do not have to provide these.

We must eat; but it has been clear for centuries that we should do better to buy most of our food from countries more suited to sheep runs and prairies than our own crowded island. Other industries have had their day, turned subsidy-junkie and eventually become more trouble than they were worth - mining, textiles, shipbuilding, steel-making. All were subjected to the harsh laws of economic reality. New activities have taken their place, and re-employed their former workers. If our farming industry were subject to the same rules, we should now be putting it out of its misery. Yet we have treated it as sacrosanct. Just why, exactly?

The idea learnt from childhood picture books that farming is more real, purer, closer to the soil, more in touch with the rhythm of the seasons than our own post-lapsarian activities may have something to do with it. Such misplaced sentimentality has made us easy prey for whatever message the farming industry's potent propaganda machine happens to be pumping out. Yet the current message is hardly persuasive.

Our farmers know that we know that food surpluses, not shortages, are the problem nowadays, and that their strategic importance is a thing of the past. So they are telling us that we need them now to be the custodians of our countryside. Without their efforts, they would have us believe, what remains of our landscape would disintegrate. The tourist industry, now suffering so painfully on their behalf, would therefore collapse as well.

But what would really happen if support for British agriculture were withdrawn? Probably around a third of the land currently under cultivation would continue to produce food competitively. Some of the farms which survived would be high-grade specialist outfits, delivering niche products at premium prices. More, however, would be large units turning out vast quantities of grain, efficiently and soullessly. These would offer few charms for walkers and sustain little wildlife. Yet, unpopular though such farms are, their profitability would equip them to meet environmental, hygiene and animal welfare obligations more easily than the struggling, small-scale, mixed establishments which polite opinion currently favours.

Meanwhile, agriculture could be expected to beat a slow retreat from much of the rest of the countryside. With it would go its trim and tidy fieldscape. Farmers would like us to believe we are inextricably attached to this kind of rural scenery. Yet the idea that as much as 80 per cent of our rural landscape should be farmed, as it is at present, is relatively novel. Until subsidy revived it after World War II, farming in Britain suffered a 100-year recession. Much of the marginal land which has now been ploughed up was left derelict, to be colonised by bramble and hawthorn, cornflower and dog-rose. The resulting landscape, unkempt and wildlife-rich, formed the countryside of pastoral myth which most of us now know only from art galleries.

We need to learn once more that, in spite of our farmers' grim warnings, we have nothing to fear from the incursion of indigenous flora into our landscape. On the contrary, we desperately need more wilderness in our over-domesticated outdoors. Where, under the Common Agricultural Policy, farmers have been paid 'set-aside' to leave land be, we already see welcome rashes of forgotten wild flowers reappearing. Birds and butterflies have seized on these oases, and used them to restore some fraction of the populations they maintained before these were devastated by modern farming.

While other countries make a point of dedicating wilderness areas, Britain has almost none. We could do with spaces where we could see what happens to our country when left to its own devices, to follow the progression from flowers to scrub to woodland. Our wild red deer, rather than farmers' sheep, could graze our open moorland, as they already do in the Highlands. We lecture Third World countries about the need to preserve their rainforests without making any effort to restore the lost habitat of our own wildlife.

Abandoned farmland, recolonised by our own wild fauna and flora, could be our contribution to the restoration of biodiversity.

Yet, away from remoter areas, would redundant farmland really lie as desolate as farmers like to suggest? In our crowded island, there is a desperate hunger for land. Some of this comes from demand for building development, particularly for homes. Yet the fear that Wimpey estates would fill any gap left by agriculture is misplaced.

Whenever they get the chance, farmers are all too willing to pocket the enormous profits they gain from selling their fields for homes. What stops them most of the time is the planning system, which tightly restricts new building in the countryside. There are plenty of potential new owners of rural land who would have no problem with current planning restrictions. At present, high land prices, bloated by agricultural subsidy, are keeping them out. If subsidies were withdrawn, land prices would fall. Then, conservation and wildlife organisations such as the National Trust, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and the county wildlife trusts would be able to extend their holdings. Individuals keen to establish their own nature reserves or amenity woodlands might be able to do so. Local authorities could afford to create more country parks. Tree cover in Britain is only a fraction of what it is in continental Europe: foresters would be able to begin to redress this shortfall. And the army of would-be subsistence smallholders might at last gain a foothold in our countryside.

Between them, these new owners would create a very different countryside. We have every reason to believe it would be far more attractive to us, and to the wild creatures with whom we would share it, than the existing farmscape, devoid of skylarks, orchids, newts and buttercups.

If we wanted to adjust this new landscape, to create more wetlands for the bittern, say, or steppes to lure back the bustard, we could use public money to do so. But instead of giving farmers limitless sums to do what they want, we could apply money surgically, to pursue the purposes we choose.

Rather than dictating the shape of our landscape, some former farmers might find a new role, managing grazing stock to achieve the conservation and recreation goals of the private and public owners who would supplant them.

None of this is fantastic. It is all within our grasp. What is fantastic is our inability to shake ourselves free of the idea that our countryside must be one big farm, however much money this wastes and however much nuisance it causes. Instead, our countryside can be once more the landscape of our dreams. Why not make it so?

webTitle: Leader: At last, Labour is working

fields.headline: At last, Labour is working
fields.standfirst:
Jobs for all is now a real aspiration

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It is a sign of our depoliticised, cynical times that last week's fall in unemployment below one million was greeted so coolly.
fields.body:
It is a sign of our depoliticised, cynical times that last week's fall in unemployment below one million was greeted so coolly. When unemployment on the same measure rose above a million in 1975, it was rightly seen as a national calamity which spelt misery, waste and social disaffection. Politicians could not control the economy, a charge Conservatives used to hammer the Left. Labour, famously, was not working.

On the internationally accepted measure, unemployment may still be half a million higher and there may be more people who want work even if they are not searching. For all that, the trend signals a world - unknown for a generation - with the chance to work and fully participate in economic and social life open to everyone. Part of the explanation is our current economic structure with its strong service sector demanding more labour; part is growth. The Government has done nothing to disturb this pattern of employment generation and plenty to enhance it. Almost no 16- to 24-year-olds are now out of work for more than six months - a declared aim of the New Deal. A range of initiatives have signalled an inventiveness about lowering unemployment that is good to see. Ministers deserve more credit than their critics allow.

The Prime Minister and Chancellor have now been emboldened, embracing full employment as a policy aim with a social democratic confidence that would be equally welcome across a range of Labour's policies. From now on, however, progress will be harder. Financial turmoil in Japan and the US along with higher oil prices will slow the economy down. Moreover, the hard core of unemployed are harder to reach, and the skills they need to succeed in the labour market are harder to teach. A generation of men over 50, mainly unskilled, have no intention of working again - and if they did, the new skills along with social confidence and good presentation that are essential in today's service sector are difficult if not impossible to acquire so late in life.

Last week's Green Paper on Employment showed a welcome appreciation of these challenges. A second-term Labour Government will need luck and determination as well as good policy to make more progress. But for now, unemployment has fallen below a million with Labour in power. Relish the moment.

Almost no 16- to 24-year-olds are now out of work for more than six months - a declared aim of the New Deal. A range of initiatives have signalled an inventiveness about lowering unemployment that is good to see. Ministers deserve more credit than their critics allow. The Prime Minister and Chancellor have now been emboldened, embracing full employment as a policy aim with a social democratic confidence that would be equally welcome across a range of Labour's policies. From now on, however, progress will be harder. Financial turmoil in Japan and the US along with higher oil prices will slow the economy down. Moreover, the hard core of unemployed are harder to reach, and the skills they need to succeed in the labour market are harder to teach. A generation of men over 50, mainly unskilled, have no intention of working again - and if they did, the new skills along with social confidence and good presentation that are essential in today's service sector are difficult if not impossible to acquire so late in life. Last week's Green Paper on Employment showed a welcome appreciation of these challenges. A second-term Labour Government will need luck and determination as well as good policy to make more progress. But for now, unemployment has fallen below a million with Labour in power. Relish the moment.

webTitle: Fury as Prescott hires transport firm lobbyists

fields.headline: Fury as Prescott hires transport firm lobbyists
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott was at the centre of a furious row last night over his decision to use private-sector lobbyists working for the transport industry to advise him during the general election.
fields.body:
John Prescott was at the centre of a furious row last night over his decision to use private-sector lobbyists working for the transport industry to advise him during the general election.

The Deputy Prime Minister, whose portfolio includes transport, and his usual special adviser, Joe Irvine, will work closely with Mike Craven, chief executive of lobbying firm Lexington. The company's clients include British Airways and Metronet, the consortium involving Balfour Beatty which is bidding to run parts of London Underground under Prescott's contentious privatisation scheme.

Craven, who worked for Prescott in the Eighties, will be his speechwriter and conduct 'research'.

He also lobbies for Serco, the firm leading one of the controversial consortia bidding to run a privatised National Air Traffic Control Service, championed by Prescott. Lexington also lobbies for Novartis, the biotech firm heavily involved in genetically modified crops.

As well as transport, Prescott's huge department is responsible for the environment and regional affairs. Stephen Hardwick, the chief lobbyist for the British Airports Authority (BAA), which owns Heathrow and Gatwick, will also be working for the Labour Party and is a close friend of Prescott's special adviser.

Prescott has just received a planning inspector's report on BAA's plans to build a fifth terminal at Heathrow, and is personally responsible for deciding whether to give it the go-ahead. The planning inquiry lasted six years and was bitterly fought.

John Stewart, head of the campaign against the terminal, said Labour's decision to use Hardwick was 'outrageous'. He claimed it could be grounds for a judicial review of the entire process.

'I am shocked. This is completely unacceptable and raises serious questions about the impartiality of Prescott. This just shows how close the Minister is to BAA. What would BAA say if they discovered our group and Friends of the Earth were advising Ministers? They would go mad,' Stewart said.

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: 'New Labour seems to have forgotten the first rule of the market. There is no such thing as a free lunch.

'These lobbyists will want paying, and they obtain their payment after the election by being able to win lucrative contracts from companies, claiming they can get privileged access to Ministers and [can] influence policies.'

After the last general election, The Observer revealed that many Labour advisers went on to work for political lobbying firms and used their contacts with Ministers to obtain special favours for corporate clients.

Prescott will not be alone in using corporate lobbyists this time.

Colin Byrne, managing director of lobbying firm Weber Shandwick will work for Labour's business relations unit, which will be responsible for securing donations and ensuring its pro-business message gets through. Shandwick acts for construction giant Carillion, Tesco and the investment bank Goldman Sachs.

New laws governing political donations to parties say any 'help' given by private sector firms during the campaign will count and must be published in the party's accounts.

General Secretary Margaret McDonagh is keen to use Labour-supporting lobbyists to bolster operations at the party's Millbank headquarters, but is understood to be aware of the danger of potential scandals after polling day, when the lobbyists return to advise companies wanting to influence government policy.

She is understood to have agreed with a number of lobbyists that they should keep a low profile, and is privately furious that Craven has been speaking openly about his role with Prescott.

Neither Craven nor Hardwick responded to calls.

A Labour Party spokeswoman said it was 'very pleased and proud that so many people want to work for us at election time'.

'All parties use volunteers. Those working for Ministers will be Labour Party members and not working on any departmental issues. Whoever we take on, we will abide by the law and the advice of the Electoral Commission.'

webTitle: Has cautious Kennedy lost the plot?

fields.headline: Has cautious Kennedy lost the plot?
fields.standfirst: As Lib Dems muster in Torquay, some fear their leader is too soft for the hard fight ahead, writes  Gaby Hinsliff
fields.trailText: As Lib Dems muster in Torquay, some fear their leader is too soft for the hard fight ahead, writes Gaby Hinsliff.
fields.body:
For all his charm, Charles Kennedy is not exactly a morning person.

Yet as the Liberal Democrat leader peruses today's papers over breakfast and a cigarette in his Torquay hotel, where the party is holding its pre-election conference, he will have to be on his toes. The reviews of his keynote speech will show how far he has silenced growing criticism - both inside and outside his party - that he has still not demonstrated what the Lib Dems are actually for.

Disgruntled Lib Dem MPs mutter that the party is drifting: that with the Tories in a shambles and Labour's core vote restless, they should not have just slipped five points in the polls. 'There is a feeling that all around the leader is inertia,' says one senior Lib Dem source. 'A lot of people wish there was a bit more verve and drive and a lot less waiting for things to happen.'

Kennedy's gung-ho predecessor Paddy Ashdown is said to be fretting. Even television chef Clarissa Dickson-Wright, briefly a party pin-up, has defected to the Tories.

More serious tensions are brewing with Kennedy's Labour allies, who fear Tony Blair may dump a firm commitment to electoral reform - risking the fury both of Lib Dems who know it is their best chance of winning power, and Labour reformers who blame Kennedy bitterly for not fighting his corner hard enough.

Yesterday Kennedy gambled on confronting his critics head on. 'It's said I'm laidback. Well that's true, but that's because I'm tolerant, and because I'm a liberal,' he told the conference in his keynote speech. 'And I'm proud of that, but I'm also ambitious for our party, and I'm ambitious for our country.'

Friends insist the Scot's natural relaxed manner is being misinterpreted as inaction. While Ashdown came to politics late in life and was racing against the clock, Kennedy - only 23 when he got into Parliament and 40 when he made leader - always felt he had time to make his mark.

'People think that because he's not making a huge song and dance and populist gestures that his heart isn't in it, but it is precisely because he wants to be there in 10 years' time that he is taking it slowly,' said one colleague.

'He has a very long-term agenda which involves some big ambitions but he is simply not ready yet to say what they are. When people talk about how he is just dabbling in politics they misread him completely.'

He is also wary of repeating the mistakes that dogged William Hague's first few months. 'He refuses to get bothered by the criticism. He thinks that if he does he will do something he will regret for the rest of his years - like going down a water chute in a baseball cap,' says one aide.

Kennedy does hold some strong personal views: he is outraged by Hague's stance on asylum and immigration, accusing him yesterday of 'playing to people's fears' and appealing to One Nation Tories to defect. He wants to stand for the poor and powerless, for what is right not what is popular.

His speech was scathing about Labour's 'poverty of ambition', its fear of raising taxes to fund proper public services, its pandering to the Right. 'They're scared of being condemned by the Daily Mail. Small ambitions, large fears,' he said.

The Lib Dems would stand for those who believed in public service: 'That's why, if we didn't exist, you'd have to invent us.'

But his determination to avoid Ashdown's habit of inventing policy without consulting colleagues has led to what some see as excessive caution. 'MPs say the atmosphere in the party is much nicer now, but that is partly a case of pupils liking a teacher who doesn't make them do their homework,' said one ex-staffer.

And there is anxiety too among proponents of closer co-operation with Labour over the future of the Lib-Lab love-in. Kennedy's personal relationship with Blair is warmer than Ashdown's was - they chat easily about music, and Blair likes Kennedy's sense of humour - Labour MPs say Ashdown was a steelier negotiator. The ex-leader's remarks in Torquay on Friday that if the electoral reform pledge was dropped Labour would suffer at the ballot box 'and would deserve to do so' were seen by some as an attempt to stiffen backbones.

Insiders argue that Downing Street decided six months ago they could afford not to commit to a referendum over PR in Labour's next manifesto. Blair will not toughen up the wording of the pledge which Labour backtracked on in this Parliament - and may even ditch it altogether.

'Charles is in grave danger of sending the wrong signals,' said one source close to Robin Cook, Labour's chief champion of electoral reform. 'The fact is that Blair will do the minimum he can get away with to keep Lib-Labbery on the road, and if the minimum is no movement on PR, that is exactly what they will get.'

Although the Lib Dems do hold trump cards - Labour needs the tactical votes of their supporters in many marginal seats, plus their support in the Lords - reformers in both parties fear Kennedy is not playing them. 'He relies too much on private understandings with the Prime Minister,' said one senior Lib Dem source. 'We are down to the wire on this.'

Realistically, Kennedy's hopes for this election, for all the bullish talk of a programme for Government, are mainly of increasing his party's share of the vote - which may not even necessarily mean more MPs under the current electoral system.

But does he actively want to be Prime Minister one day? The jury, despite the confidence in Torquay, is still out.

webTitle: Call for new probe after Vaz overturns 50 visa rulings

fields.headline: Call for new probe after Vaz overturns 50 visa rulings
fields.trailText: Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz has personally overturned decisions by immigration officers an unprecedented 50 times since he took charge of overseeing visa applications to Britain in October 1999.
fields.byline: Antony Barnett and Luke Harding in Delhi
fields.body:
Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz has personally overturned decisions by immigration officers an unprecedented 50 times since he took charge of overseeing visa applications to Britain in October 1999.

One former senior Foreign Office official who is intimate with the visa application process has described this as 'an astonishing number'. Opposition MPs are demanding an urgent investigation by the Prime Minister.

According to Whitehall sources, it has been 'extremely rare' for both recent Labour and Tory Ministers to overturn decisions by embassies and British High Commissions around the world when entry visas are denied to people wishing to visit the UK.

Vaz, who is fighting for his political life following his role in the Hinduja passport affair and damning evidence that he tried to obstruct a parliamentary investigation into his financial affairs, will now come under intense pressure to give full details of the cases he has been involved in and explain why he has been rejecting advice from senior immigration officials.

Opposition MPs who have been calling for his resignation believe this could be the final nail in his Ministerial career. They claim there is a potential conflict of interest because the Minister's wife, Maria Fernandes, is an immigration lawyer whose practice specialises in visa issues. She has always denied that such a conflict arises.

She is the author of a guide - dedicated to her husband - aimed at assisting people from Asian countries in obtaining visitors' visas to Britain.

MPs are demanding to know whether the Minister's wife has been involved in any of the cases or whether the individuals are linked to Vaz's business associates or Labour donors.

Vaz and the Foreign Office have refused repeated demands to release details of the cases where the Minister, has personally intervened claiming it would breach 'confidentiality' rules.

A parliamentary answer from the Foreign Office to Liberal Democrat MP David Rendel confirmed that Vaz intervened 18 times to overrule decisions by the British High Commission in India not to allow Indian nationals to enter the UK.

Sources claim that officials in the British High Commission in Bombay have privately expressed 'concern' at Vaz's interventions although no one would comment on the record and all questions were referred to London.

Vaz became embroiled in the Hinduja passport affair, after an Observer investigation revealed his close links with the Indian billionaires and how he had intervened with the Home Office over their passport applications.

Last night Liam Fox, the Tory shadow health spokesman who was Minister for visas under John Major's government, said: 'In my personal experience as a Minister, British immigration officers working overseas are highly experienced professionals working within strict rules set down by House of Commons.

'Ministers need exceptional reasons to overturn their decisions and I can only recall three times this happened when I was in office. It calls into question Cook's judgment in giving him the job in the first place. Tony Blair must investigate.'

Liberal Democrat MP David Rendel began asking Vaz parliamentary questions over his role in overturning visa decisions after reading an Observer investigation into the use of illegal 'slave labour' from India at a Hindu temple in north London. He has now written to the Minister demanding details of all those who Vaz has helped into the country and his reasons for overruling immigration officials.

Last week it emerged that Vaz requested the visa portfolio from Foreign Secretary Robin Cook when he became a Minister in the Foreign Office.

The visa guidebook written by Vaz's wife covers family, business, transit and medical visits to the UK and is designed to do away with the long delays and problems many Asians face when entering Britain.

It is dedicated 'to my husband Keith for his inspiration and encouragement' and 'to those who struggle every day to grapple with the complexities of our immigration system'. Income from selling this guide was channelled into a company called Mapesbury Communications, which was originally set up by the Minister when he was a backbench MP in 1996.

The company became a key focus for the parliamentary commissioner Elizabeth Filkin, who was concerned that revenues from Mapesbury were being used to support the Minister's parliamentary office without his having declared it.

Despite repeated requests for information from Filkin and the Standards and Privileges Committee, both the Minister and his wife declined to open the firm's books.

A spokesman for the Foreign Office denied there was anything improper about Vaz's overrulings. He said: 'Almost two million visas are applied for a year and fewer than 150,000 are rejected. The fact the Minister has overturned 50 decisions means we are talking about a minute percentage.

'We cannot compare his record with previous Ministers because the figures have only been collated since Vaz took over the brief and personally requested we kept such statistics.'

webTitle: Millbank, do we have a problem?

fields.headline: Millbank, do we have a problem?
fields.standfirst: If Tony Blair postpones the election, it will not be a sign of weakness, but a demonstration of the Prime Minister's self-confidence
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair postpones the election, it will not be a sign of weakness, but a demonstration of the Prime Minister's self-confidence.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
The mood inside Labour's Millbank headquarters is rather like mission control at Houston just before launch. Crouched over their blinking terminals, the technicians are going through the final checks that the rocket is aligned for a perfect trajectory to the second term. Unemployment has dipped below one million, a moment of great symbolic resonance for Labour. Goodies from the Treasury are about to flutter into the pockets of the voters. The primary thrusters are on line.

The debris scattered into the atmosphere by the Mandelson supernova has proved less lethal than first feared as the fragments of that exploded star spin into deep space. Those close to the Prime Minister are relieved that the Government has taken much less of a hit from the Hinduja affair than they anticipated.

As for the opinion polling, the results are just sensational. No government in modern times has approached an election campaign with more reason to be confident that it will return to office. One survey awards to Labour the stratospheric lead of 26 points over the Conservatives. All systems are go; Tony Blair is cleared for launch.

Suddenly, seconds before the completion of the countdown, the urgent order comes through from Number 10 to disengage engines: 'Abort! Abort! Abort!'

This is not what they want to hear at Millbank. The grids are plotted; the poster sites booked; the printing presses primed; the sound-bites sharpened and the photo-opportunities cast; the attack units are battle-ready. I entirely understand the enormous resistance among Labour's campaigners to the idea that they should be forced to postpone the election under pressure from such an unholy coalition as the National Farmers Union, a bellow of right-wing newspapers, a hand-wring of liberal commentators and a whinge of minority parties.

Why should one nasty little virus, which was probably spread by unscrupulous livestock dealers, ruin everything? Don't all those bloody farmers vote Tory anyway? No one at Labour headquarters will lightly sacrifice all the meticulously crafted plans for a poll on the first Thursday in May.

Nor does mission controller Blair want to issue instructions to postpone the launch. Put aside the political hazards of sacrificing what seems to be the most propitious timing for an election. At a personal level, the Prime Minister wants the campaign done and dusted. Even the most assured and powerful of leaders shred their nerves at these moments. Even Margaret Thatcher in her pomp wobbled badly at the junction of decision. For weeks now, Tony Blair has been psychologically coiling himself up for the spring election.

He must also be mindful that those of his predecessors who delayed elections do not set an encouraging precedent. In modern memory, two Prime Ministers have dithered and delayed. Jim Callaghan flunked going to the country in the autumn of 1978 with the result that his government was wrecked by the Winter of Discontent. A member of the present Cabinet was telling me only the other day - these livid memories are so deeply burnt - that she would never forgive Callaghan for the blunder that handed the North Sea oil money and 18 years in power to the Conservatives. At the other end of the stretch, John Major prolonged his government well beyond its natural life. By clinging on until the very fag-end of the last parliament, he only managed to make his defeat that much worse.

If Mr Blair calls off May, can he be sure it will be OK by June? If he's pushed into the autumn, can he be certain he'll still be popular in September? And if that goes pear-shaped, he may find himself contemplating next spring. The folklore of British politics says that Prime Ministers are highly unwise to trap themselves against the buffers.

Such are the arguments raging within the high command of the Government. Number 10's implacable statements that there are no plans to postpone the election put a brave face on inner agonising. Election timing is the staple of private conversation between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, who has the most decisive other voice on the question. Technically, the final choice does not need to be made for another three weeks. A May election could be called as late as early April. For most practical purposes, because to call off the general election implies rushing through emergency legislation to postpone the local polls as well, the moment of truth for Mr Blair is this coming week.

He can safely cast aside the bogus arguments for delaying the election. For the vast majority of the country, including the greater part of the countryside, campaigning will be unaffected by foot and mouth. A senior member of the Tory front bench, who has a highly rural constituency, admitted to me last week that it would make next to no difference to his electioneering. Only nostalgics believe that modern elections turn on stump campaigning in draughty village halls. The contest will be fought on television, radio and through the press. One-to-one communing between candidate and voter was long ago supplanted by telephone, post and now email.

The issue for Mr Blair and those who guide him is not about mechanics. It is to do with the atmospherics. The spread of foot and mouth has so far confounded the Government's protestations that everything is under control. The saturation media coverage has also defied Alastair Campbell's often reliable private rule that few news stories last for more than 48 hours, and only the most exceptional crisis endures in the headlines for more than a week. If the disease is still raging in early May, then the campaign will be fought against the smell of putrid cattle flesh and the noise of millions of sheep being shot in the head. Rural skies blackened by burning carcasses, that image from the Dark Ages, is not exactly the ideal scenery for Tony Blair to explain his vision of a government of competent reform putting Britain on the leading edge of the twenty-first century.

The Cabinet's best strategist is a worried man. During private debates about the issue, Gordon Brown has been heard to ask: 'Would we look cynical?' He and Mr Blair both know that they will most certainly be accused of that. The risk of an unnecessarily early election, called in disregard of pleas to delay, is that it emphasises the least attractive features of New Labour. It will be called not just cynical, but arrogant and tasteless. The Prime Minister will be charged - and is bound to suffer from the accusation - that he has put his own selfish interests above those of the country.

The question for Tony Blair about the election is not how big he wins; what matters most is how well he wins. The precise scale of his majority is not as significant as the style of his victory. New Labour needs this election to be an instrument of renewal. To make a success of its second term, the Government wants to win the election with a reinvigorated sense of purpose and some endorsing enthusiasm for a radical second term from the country. Out of the election must flow a sense that they have made their arguments and won a mandate. The Dead Cow Election does not fit that picture.

Tony Blair is in a crucially different position to Jim Callaghan and John Major. They put off elections because they were weak. Postponement of polling day by Mr Blair would be a display of self-confidence. It would say that winning for him is not down to accidents of timing, but to the intrinsic appeal of his ideas and the strength of his government. The Prime Minister has a few, difficult days remaining before he must make up his mind. Should his decision be to delay the election, this will be the act, and it will deserve to be acknowledged as the act, of a strong man.

webTitle: MPs to demand tighter controls over Railtrack

fields.headline: MPs to demand tighter controls over Railtrack
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The management of Britain's railways is so shambolic that passenger safety is still being compromised, five months after four people were killed in the Hatfield crash.
fields.body:
The management of Britain's railways is so shambolic that passenger safety is still being compromised, five months after four people were killed in the Hatfield crash.

A report by the House of Commons Select Committee on Transport, to be published next week, will reveal failings at the highest levels of Railtrack and demand a tightening of rules on hiring contractors to maintain the track and signalling.

It will reveal evidence of unchecked workmen being recruited in pubs and, on one occasion, of a man who was colour-blind and inexperienced being put in charge of a team fixing railway lines.

Lack of communication between Railtrack and the companies it hires to maintain the railways was cited as one of the reasons for the Hatfield crash.

The report will say large-scale investment in the railways is being squandered by managers who are unclear about what they are trying to achieve and bogged down in structures too complicated to understand. Hundreds of new trains and carriages that would improve journey times are not being brought into service because of wrangling over safety checks and engineering problems.

The committee will say such problems have not been experienced on the Continent and that the disputes over the new trains appears to be 'a peculiarly British disease'.

The report will again turn the spotlight on the failing railways a few days before Tony Blair is expected to call a general election.

Last week The Observer revealed that Railtrack figures on chronic train delays showed it could not meet the Government's Easter deadline to get the network back to normal. The Strategic Rail Authority said last Tuesday it would be Christmas before it was operating properly.

Rail passenger complaints about long-distance travel rose by more than 80 per cent following the Hatfield crash and the miles travelled fell by more than 10 per cent.

Although the select committee's report will not call for the railways to be re-nationalised it will say a public share should be taken in Railtrack to ensure that the Government has influence over the industry.

webTitle: Comment: Millbank, do we have a problem?

fields.headline: Millbank, do we have a problem?
fields.standfirst: If Tony Blair postpones the election, it will not be a sign of weakness, but a demonstration of the Prime Minister's self-confidence
fields.trailText: If Tony Blair postpones the election, it will not be a sign of weakness, but a demonstration of the Prime Minister's self-confidence.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
The mood inside Labour's Millbank headquarters is rather like mission control at Houston just before launch. Crouched over their blinking terminals, the technicians are going through the final checks that the rocket is aligned for a perfect trajectory to the second term. Unemployment has dipped below one million, a moment of great symbolic resonance for Labour. Goodies from the Treasury are about to flutter into the pockets of the voters. The primary thrusters are on line.

The debris scattered into the atmosphere by the Mandelson supernova has proved less lethal than first feared as the fragments of that exploded star spin into deep space. Those close to the Prime Minister are relieved that the Government has taken much less of a hit from the Hinduja affair than they anticipated.

As for the opinion polling, the results are just sensational. No government in modern times has approached an election campaign with more reason to be confident that it will return to office. One survey awards to Labour the stratospheric lead of 26 points over the Conservatives. All systems are go; Tony Blair is cleared for launch.

Suddenly, seconds before the completion of the countdown, the urgent order comes through from Number 10 to disengage engines: 'Abort! Abort! Abort!'

This is not what they want to hear at Millbank. The grids are plotted; the poster sites booked; the printing presses primed; the sound-bites sharpened and the photo-opportunities cast; the attack units are battle-ready. I entirely understand the enormous resistance among Labour's campaigners to the idea that they should be forced to postpone the election under pressure from such an unholy coalition as the National Farmers Union, a bellow of right-wing newspapers, a hand-wring of liberal commentators and a whinge of minority parties.

Why should one nasty little virus, which was probably spread by unscrupulous livestock dealers, ruin everything? Don't all those bloody farmers vote Tory anyway? No one at Labour headquarters will lightly sacrifice all the meticulously crafted plans for a poll on the first Thursday in May.

Nor does mission controller Blair want to issue instructions to postpone the launch. Put aside the political hazards of sacrificing what seems to be the most propitious timing for an election. At a personal level, the Prime Minister wants the campaign done and dusted. Even the most assured and powerful of leaders shred their nerves at these moments. Even Margaret Thatcher in her pomp wobbled badly at the junction of decision. For weeks now, Tony Blair has been psychologically coiling himself up for the spring election.

A member of the present Cabinet was telling me only the other day - these livid memories are so deeply burnt - that she would never forgive Callaghan for the blunder that handed the North Sea oil money and 18 years in power to the Conservatives. At the other end of the stretch, John Major prolonged his government well beyond its natural life. By clinging on until the very fag-end of the last parliament, he only managed to make his defeat that much worse.

If Mr Blair calls off May, can he be sure it will be OK by June? If he's pushed into the autumn, can he be certain he'll still be popular in September? For the vast majority of the country, including the greater part of the countryside, campaigning will be unaffected by foot and mouth. Only nostalgics believe that modern elections turn on stump campaigning in draughty village halls. The contest will be fought on television, radio and through the press. One-to-one communing between candidate and voter was long ago supplanted by telephone, post and now email.

Out of the election must flow a sense that they have made their arguments and won a mandate. The Dead Cow Election does not fit that picture.

webTitle: A superior night's sleep -  yours for only £5,287.50

fields.headline: A superior night's sleep -  yours for only £5,287.50
fields.standfirst: If the Lanesborough is good enough for Michael Jackson, then it's good enough for  Ian Belcher, who checks in for a night at Britain's most expensive hotel suite - two butlers and chauffeured Bentley included, but cashew nuts are extra
fields.trailText: If the Lanesborough is good enough for Michael Jackson, then it's good enough for Ian Belcher, who checks in for a night at Britain's most expensive hotel suite - two butlers and chauffeured Bentley included, but cashew nuts are extra.
fields.body:
It all happened very fast. One minute I was strolling towards Hyde Park Corner to catch a late-night tube, the next I was surrounded by earnest young Germans. Some looked close to tears, others stared at an upstairs window and clutched hand-written cardboard placards. All wore strangely glazed expressions.

After an unnerving few seconds when I feared I was about to be kidnapped by a cult, I realised I had unwittingly stumbled on the travelling throng of Michael Jackson worshippers. His website had revealed he was staying at London's Lanesborough Hotel during his recent visit to speak at the Oxford Union, and the students were camped out hoping to glimpse their idol.

They may be misguided but they had their directions spot-on. Jackson was staying in the Lanesborough: more precisely he was staying in the Royal Suite. At £4,500 a night, it claims to be the most expensive hotel accommodation in the UK - and that's before you add on Vat, taking it to a cool £5,287.50. Oh yes, dinner and breakfast are not included.

The cosmetically enhanced singer is not the only superstar to think it's worth the money. Madonna, Mariah Carey, Sly Stallone, Celine Dion and Michael Bolton have all stayed, as have business gurus such as Oracle's Larry Ellison and politicians including President Bush Sr and various Russian Prime Ministers. Stanley Kubrick filmed the strangely un-erotic sex scenes for Eyes Wide Shut in the suite's junior bedroom.

By mere mortals' standards £5,287.50 - the equivalent of more than 75 nights at Battersea Travelodge - is an extraordinary outlay for a night's kip. So in the spirit of investigative journalism, I checked into the suite at the central London hotel, at present on the market for about £110 million, to find out exactly what bang you get for your big bucks.

For starters there was the chauffeured £160,000 seven-litre Bentley Mulliner - 8mpg, £75 to fill up - which came with the suite. My driver, Zoran Matic, who is perhaps more used to ferrying celebrities after they've passed through the paparazzi at Heathrow, seemed unfazed by a pick-up outside a small flat in Clapham. And yes, curtains did twitch.

Then there were the butlers. Not one but two, and as with the Bentley, they were available throughout my stay. On arrival at the Lanesborough I was handed over like the Olympic torch from driver, via doorman and house manager, David Cowdery, to Sean and Karen, my personal butlers. Nothing like Jeeves, they mixed friendliness with frightening efficiency.

It was the kind of welcome I could get used to. There were personalised business cards and stationery, explosions of flowers from the in-house florist, a bottle of Perrier-Jouet champagne on ice, and a fruit bowl containing the largest strawberries seen outside Chernobyl.

Delusions of grandeur immediately kicked in. As Sean told me about the hotel's fitness studio, I asked if I had to train in front of other guests - global superstars rarely like to wobble in public. 'Course not Sir,' came the straight-faced reply. 'I can have the equipment moved up to your suite. You can work out by the window, it's a lovely view over Green Park.'

He was right. Floor-to-ceiling windows offered a stunning outlook over the Wellington Arch. The only thing missing was glassy-eyed German students gazing in my direction. I made a mental note to ask Sean to arrange for them to be outside later.

After a parting observation on our Buckingham Palace neighbours, 'they don't cause us much trouble, they're very quiet' - banter that Americans must love - he dis creetly withdrew.

I was alone in my nine-room (not counting the extra toilet, washroom and kitchen), 2,845 sq ft suite. There was the 45ft sitting room, dining room for 12 that Princess Diana used for a Red Cross party, master bedroom with bathroom en-suite with Jacuzzi and steam shower, and two other bedroom/bathrooms, all connected by a maze of doors and tunnels. Anyone with a short-term memory lapse could be lost for days.

Decor-wise, the Royal Suite is a minimalist's nightmare. Originally the country home of Viscount Lanesborough, to which a spectacular Wilkins frontage was added in 1812, after serving many years as a hospital the building was turned into a hotel a decade ago under the management of the Dallas-based Rosewood group. They commissioned a British interior designer to reproduce the style of a Regency country home - and that meant a heavy gilt trip.

There are gilt-framed portraits and huge mirrors at either end of the sitting room, gold-coloured clocks and giant eagles supporting marble table tops, gold and black candle sticks, gold friezes around the ceilings. A magnificent writing desk is decorated with gold-headed Egyptian figures and surrounded by gold wood chairs. The main bedroom has a gold-canopied four-poster, golden walls and curtains and ornate gilt table mirror. If Regency's your style, it's a reproduction treasure; if not, the decor can become oppressive, and the more modern Metropolitan across Hyde Park Corner would be a better bet. I quickly found myself seeing the world through gilt-tinted spectacles.

Ironically, at the same time as the Lanesborough opened, Cowdery was working on the launch of the Royalton in New York, the first sleek collaboration between Ian Shrager and Philippe Starck.

Behind the early nineteenth-century facade I discovered a stack of hi-tech gadgets: an in-room computer with lightning web access and, from this week, there is internet radio so you can listen to local stations from New York to Buenos Aires. There are no less than 15 phone handsets - useful if your demented aunt has got lost at the other end of the suite - and a mobile so you can be reached via your room number even when you're out about town.

Reclining on my gold four-poster in a luxurious Lanesborough dressing gown after a spin in the Jacuzzi, I dimmed the lights through my computerised bedside panel, and enjoyed a perfect Leslie Phillips moment.

But according to Cowdery, the £4,500 price tag shouldn't be related to the facilities. 'It's about intangibles,' he insists. 'It's about prestige and a unique experience, like the butler who can find whatever you're looking for. For people who want the Royal Suite at the Lanesborough, it's not about money. The price could be £5,000 or £6,000.'

Whatever the appeal, it appears to work. The suite was occupied for three quarters of last year, of which half had paid full price, with the others on upgrade. So if you booked in for your wedding anniversary on a standard double rate of £370 plus tax, you never know your luck. If you were upgraded, I would strongly advise caution on the mini bar (cashews £12.50) and the in-room wine list (Château Pétrus 1970 £2,900, Château D'yquem 1921 £3,550).

At 12.10am, it was clearly time to call on the famed services of the Lanesborough butler. I urgently needed a recommendation for an Ethiopian restaurant, a fresh 35mm film, and fitness cycle delivered to my room for when I woke next morning. Tony, my night butler, did not disappoint. Within minutes he recommended the Ethiopian restaurant in Brixton - 'would you like us to make a booking Sir?' - and had tracked down a night chemist who unfortunately did not stock film. It appeared as if by magic by 8.30 next morning, as did the member of staff asking where I required the cycle. The extraordinary level of pampering was an insight into exactly why global icons and power brokers head for the Royal Suite.

After a final breakfast overlooking a traffic-congested Hyde Park Corner, I resisted the urge to take a memento (Sean, Karen and Tony are hard to smuggle out) and departed to make room for the next arrival, whose private plane was landing at the same time. Checking out was like leaving the womb. There were no screaming teenagers, just a couple of elderly tourists with Harrods bags, as I headed for the 77 bus and back to reality.

fields.bodyText: It all happened very fast. One minute I was strolling towards Hyde Park Corner to catch a late-night tube, the next I was surrounded by earnest young Germans. Some looked close to tears, others stared at an upstairs window and clutched hand-written cardboard placards. All wore strangely glazed expressions. After an unnerving few seconds when I feared I was about to be kidnapped by a cult, I realised I had unwittingly stumbled on the travelling throng of Michael Jackson worshippers. His website had revealed he was staying at London's Lanesborough Hotel during his recent visit to speak at the Oxford Union, and the students were camped out hoping to glimpse their idol. They may be misguided but they had their directions spot-on. Jackson was staying in the Lanesborough: more precisely he was staying in the Royal Suite. At £4,500 a night, it claims to be the most expensive hotel accommodation in the UK - and that's before you add on Vat, taking it to a cool £5,287.50. Oh yes, dinner and breakfast are not included. The cosmetically enhanced singer is not the only superstar to think it's worth the money. Madonna, Mariah Carey, Sly Stallone, Celine Dion and Michael Bolton have all stayed, as have business gurus such as Oracle's Larry Ellison and politicians including President Bush Sr and various Russian Prime Ministers. Stanley Kubrick filmed the strangely un-erotic sex scenes for Eyes Wide Shut in the suite's junior bedroom. fields.headline: Women flock to scalpel safaris
fields.standfirst: Britons are taking holidays in South Africa and coming home looking years younger, but this owes more to the surgeon than the sun
fields.trailText: Britons are taking holidays in South Africa and coming home looking years younger, but this owes more to the surgeon than the sun.
fields.body:
They are calling them scalpel safaris. Hundreds of British women are flocking to South Africa to witness the delights of the country's wildlife - and arrive home looking years younger.

Travel agents are marketing the joys of constant South African sunshine with the opportunity to have plastic surgery through special combined packages that cost a fraction of the price here.

Surgeons and Safari will help patients organise a whole package of game viewing and plastic surgery. Clients are met at the airport and guided through every stage of the process for one week or a fortnight.

It is already proving a success. Last week two British women from Guernsey, Diana Davison and Kathleen Rosenthal, were recovering after their surgery. Davison said they were looking forward to returning home looking a few years younger. 'I had an insurance policy payout and I didn't want a cruise. This just seemed a good idea,' said Davison, 65.

For Perin Lewis, plastic surgery was not a matter of looking younger. It was just a desire to press the pause button on the ageing process. 'I just wanted to suspend the effects of gravity for a while,' said the 61-year-old Londoner.

Everything is on offer in South Africa and the market is estimated to have quadrupled over the past two years as a result of foreign women - and a few men - taking advantage of low prices and well-trained surgeons.

Lewis, who organises conference events from her Hampstead house, has no regrets about choosing to go to South Africa, where her daughter, a model, had already had several operations.

'It has been fantastic. I was so impressed,' said Lewis, who has had a face and eye lift. Lewis has recommended the treatment to dozens of her friends, 10 of whom have since followed her advice and headed south for an operation and a spot of game viewing.

The result has been boom time in the spotless and ultra-modern clinics of Johannesburg and Cape Town. 'At first it spread just by word of mouth, mainly from people who had left South Africa to go and live in Britain and told their British friends about standards here. But now the demand is just exploding,' said Dr Saul Braun, who runs the Rosebank Clinic in Johannesburg and operated on Lewis and her friends.

Braun believes he has operated on more than 130 British women in the past year. They constitute the bulk of foreign women coming for operations, with the rest being made up of patients from elsewhere in Europe or the United States. About 70 per cent of the women are after face-lifts or breast operations, but others come for nose operations or liposuction.

Despite South Africa's international image often being associated with crime and declining standards in public services, South African plastic surgery is among the best in the world. 'At first glance people might think coming here might be like going to some place such as Ecuador or Brazil, but it is not like that. The standards here are exceptional,' said another Johannesburg-based plastic surgeon, Alastair Lamont.

In part this has been created by a healthy local market. Like much of the United States - and unlike Britain - many wealthy South Africans, especially whites, see plastic surgery as a run-of-the-mill operation and nothing to try to hide or be ashamed of.

Another of the main driving forces behind the boom in foreigners is economic. Due to the collapse of the rand, surgery in South Africa is very cheap. In Britain a face-lift could cost around £9,000. In South Africa it will cost around £3,200, and that includes flights, a two-week stay in a top hotel and meals in quality restaurants.

Trips to the game reserves are optional, but most people will spend at least some time on safari.

'Why have a boob job in the UK, when you can have it done here, have a holiday, and still pay less. Essentially it is a first world service at third world prices,' said Dr Paul Skoll, a Cape Town-based plastic surgeon.

Another advantage of combining a holiday in South Africa with a spell under the surgeon's knife is the opportunity to cover up the fact that the operation has been done. In Britain many patients are reluctant to admit they have been operated on and want to disguise their new youthful appearance as the product of a rejuvenating holiday in the sun.

Jane Matthews, 59, used that excuse when she returned to her job in the investment industry after having an eye-lift. 'People just put it down to having a relaxing holiday,' she said.

fields.headline: For ever and ever Aman
fields.standfirst: Jeannette Hyde on the appeal of Aman resorts
fields.trailText: Jeannette Hyde on the appeal of Aman resorts.
fields.body:
What are Aman junkies?

An elite group of travellers who spend their lives jetting from one minimalist Aman resort to the other. Once hooked, no other hotel will do.

What's the lure?

Life is cool, cool, cool (and we're not referring to the sea temperatures). These 12 resort hotels combine stark design based on local materials with outrageously attentive service on remote desert beaches, tropical jungles and up misty mountains. Not a hint of chintz, frills or gilt in sight. It's so good, most people don't want or need to leave the resort. The hotel is the holiday.

So what's new about that?

The original one, Amanpuri, started a global trend among hotels when Singapore-based visionary founder Adrian Zecha opened it in Phuket, Thailand, in 1988. Till its invention, the more money you spent on hiring a hotel room, the more fuss you got. At Aman the philosophy is small is beautiful and less is more. Now rival hip hotels from deepest Patagonia to Sao Paulo follow in its wake.

Who do these junkies include?

Prince Andrew, Naomi Campbell and Pierce Brosnan are fans (remember the pics of Andrew on that yacht with those topless women? That was on an Amanpuri holiday). There's also an army of twentysomething dotcom millionaires (who cashed in their shares before the slump) and City folk following the Aman trail between French Polynesia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Mexico, US and France.

How much does it cost?

The average room is about £500 per night rising to around £4,000 for a top three-bedroom villa. Service is second to none. There are often five mind-reading members of staff to every guest. Wrapping orchids round your suitcase handles on departure is the sort of nonsense guests come to expect. The Mahakua Hacienda de San Antonio in western Mexico, a converted ranch with its own private airstrip, serves honey straight from nearby beehives and milk from the resident cows, has 26 rooms built from local lava stone and incorporates seven kilometres of Mexican woven fabric in the bedding and curtains.

Anything else?

Personal butlers, rooms with private pools, sunken baths and your own motorised private buggy to get from bed to beach are not uncommon. At Le Mèièzin in Courchevel you can ski straight in and out of the resort. At Amanwana on the tropical island of Moyo, a nature reserve east of Bali, you can stay in tents with air-con and enjoy massages in the jungle. At the Amanpulo, an entire coral island called Pamalican in the Philippines you stay in small houses modelled on native dwellings called bahay kubos . They range in size from nine to 55 rooms and fill up quickly (despite the price), usually by word of mouth.

So if I win the lottery or rob a bank where can I book?

Try Elegant Resorts (01244 897000); Western & Oriental (020 7313 6600); Classic Connection (0870 751 9310).

fields.headline: A ploy named 'sue'
fields.standfirst: Writs are flying between historians. But who gains when academics resolve their quarrels in court?
fields.trailText: Writs are flying between historians. But who gains when academics resolve their quarrels in court?
fields.body:
Telling the truth about lies is dangerous in Britain. An MP may be a demonstrable liar, but if other MPs call him a liar the Speaker orders them to retract 'unparliamentary language' or be thrown out of Westminster. The rest of us are at once in a better and worse position. We are free to call a liar a liar, and for that we must be grateful. But while MPs can't be sued for what they say in the Commons, we can be ruined in the libel courts.

Not the least of the many virtues of D.D. Guttenplan's The Holocaust on Trial (Granta Books £17.99) is the struggle by an American author to get a grip on English law. As he dissects the David Irving libel case, you can almost hear him questioning lawyers: 'Let me see if I've got this straight. The defendants have to show that what they said was true? So they're guilty until proved innocent? No shit? And they can't argue they were honestly trying to get it right? Wow!'

In the 1990s, Irving convinced many who ought to know better that he was a good historian being persecuted for exercising his freedom to speak and write freely. The heirs of Voltaire must have been disappointed when Irving showed that if you disagreed with what he said, he would litigate your right to say so to the death. He sued Penguin for publishing Denying the Holocaust by Deborah Lipstadt, an American academic.

As Guttenplan puts it, Irving's complaint against Lipstadt was that: 'When [Irving] writes that Hitler had no knowledge of the Final Solution, or says that there were no gas chambers at Auschwitz, and that fewer people died there in four years than were killed in one night by the Allied bombing of Dresden, what he is doing is no different from... an archaeologist who doubts whether the Greeks and Trojans really went to war over Helen of Troy.' His claims that the death camps are a fiction are legitimate and to suggest otherwise is libellous. Nazism may yet be rehabilitated in part as one bloody but confused reaction among many to the terrors of the twentieth century.

Irving admitted speaking at British National Party rallies and addressed the judge as 'Mein Führer'. He asserted that it was 'a basic principle of English law' that Hitler, or 'Adolf' as he chummily called him, did not share the handicaps of the defendants and was 'innocent until proved guilty'.

Mr Justice Gray delivered his verdict on 11 April last year. He concluded that Irving shared the political beliefs of the 'militant neo-Nazis', whose meetings he had graced. 'The content of his speeches and interviews often displays a distinctly pro-Nazi and anti-Jewish bias.' He wasn't an honest historian, struggling with the inevitable difficulties understanding the past brings, but a deliberate falsifier of the record, 'motivated by a desire to present events in a manner consistent with his own ideological beliefs even if that involved distortion and manipulation of historical evidence'.

Well that's a relief, I thought at the time. Even in England you can criticise those who say there were no gassings at Auschwitz as nutters or fascists or both.

Anthony Julius QC, one of the defence team, wasn't so much relieved as ecstatic. Gray's verdict was 'a sparkling vindication of the libel laws' which should silence opponents of the status quo. The 'fantastic result softens one's attitude to the courts and the litigation process... everything looks rosy'.

Julius won because the professor of modern history at Cambridge had demolished Irving's scholarship. Richard J. Evans went through Irving's sources and produced an exhaustive 740-page analysis which detailed how Irving had twisted evidence in the Nazi interest. Irving had censored himself as well as the past by cutting references to death camps from his early work when it was reprinted.

Evans has written a book on the affair - Lying About Hitler: History, Holocaust, and the David Irving Trial. You are free to buy it in America and read the professor's account of the case and reflections on historical interpretation. I've no doubt it is a serious study. Evans is the author of In Defence of History, a patient critique of the wild subjectivity of postmodernist theory. You were meant to be free to read Lying About Hitler in Britain. But last week, Evans's publishers, Heinemann, a branch of the Random House conglomerate, ordered that the book should be pulped.

Gray's verdict, which came after years of collecting evidence and months of cross-examination in an enormously expensive trial, might as well never have happened. Heinemann said they did not dare publish because Irving was appealing against Gray's ruling. In fact, Irving has been refused permission to appeal, and it is that decision he is contesting. In the very unlikely event of Irving winning and the Court of Appeal agreeing to consider Gray's condemnation, the crushing evidence against him should deny him victory.

Granta Books certainly think so and snapped up Lying About Hitler . Granta didn't 'see any terrible legal nightmares' and was 'very enthusiastic and keen to publish'. We shall still be able to make up our own minds about Evans's writing. If the story stopped there, the moral of the censorship of Evans would merely be that robust authors should think hard before signing a contract with Random House. In January, nine months after Irving was demolished in the High Court, Weidenfeld & Nicolson published The Hitler of History by John Lukacs. Americans had been able to read it for three years, but Irving warned he would sue if it appeared in Britain. Publication would have been a triumph for free speech over a bully if criticisms of Irving had not been bowdlerised. In the American version, Lukacs says 'many of Irving's references and quotations are not verifiable'. In the British edition enforced gentility has made that 'some of Irving's references and quotations are inaccurate'.

Next month, Palgrave will publish Remembering for the Future, a collection of essays on the Holocaust edited by John K. Roth and Elisabeth Maxwell-Meynard. Judges and QCs allowed the old crook to use the libel laws to suppress disclosure of his numerous corruptions. I know it's a cliché to say the law is 'beyond satire'. But I can't think of anything else to write.

I should declare an interest and add that despite everything Irving is still threatening to sue The Observer. Even if he weren't, the ability of such a man to stifle debate would be chilling. It is not too fanciful to say that Irving is a symptom of a sickness which enfeebles the culture. On the rare moments when the media tear themselves away from the self-obsessed and the trivial to investigate, the libel laws produce a stilted discourse, afflicted with snideness and coyness, in which every speaker must pepper their sentences with 'seemses' and 'no one is suggesting thats', or give up.

Libel is generally a rich man's game, so they're protected while it's open season on the working and middle classes. But libel isn't only about money. We are meant to be living in a world where power has passed from politicians to corporations, but libel law ensures that corporate power is barely examined.

The media are big businesses themselves and so wariness of the courts combines with the self-interest of executives. At the BBC, to quote the most telling example, Greg Dyke, the new multi-millionaire director-general, assured an audience of corporate movers and thrusters that he wanted his reporters to be 'pro-business'.

Randall had come to Dyke's notice when he had attacked the Corporation for having an 'institutionalised bias against free-enterprise wealth-creators'. fields.headline: Schizophrenia 'helped the ascent of man'
fields.standfirst: Scientist says gene mutation is key to genius and despair
fields.trailText: Tiny mutations in our ancestors' brain cells triggered mankind's takeover of the world 100,000 years ago. But these changes also cursed our species to suffer from schizophrenia and depression.
fields.body:
Tiny mutations in our ancestors' brain cells triggered mankind's takeover of the world 100,000 years ago. But these changes also cursed our species to suffer from schizophrenia and depression.

This is the controversial claim by biochemist David Horrobin in a new book, The Madness of Adam & Eve: How schizophrenia shaped humanity, to be published by Bantam Press next month.

Horrobin - who is medical adviser to the Schizophrenia Association of Great Britain - argues that the changes which propelled humanity to its current global ascendancy were the same as those which have left us vulnerable to mental disease.

'We became human because of small genetic changes in the chemistry of the fat in our skulls,' he says. 'These changes injected into our ancestors both the seeds of the illness of schizophrenia and the extraordinary minds which made us human.'

Horrobin's theory also provides support for observations that have linked the most intelligent, imaginative members of our species with mental disease, in particular schizophrenia - an association supported by studies in Iceland, Finland, New York and London. These show that 'families with schizophrenic members seem to have a greater variety of skills and abilities, and a greater likelihood of producing high achievers,' he states. As examples, Horrobin points out that Einstein had a son who was schizophrenic, as was James Joyce's daughter and Carl Jung's mother.

In addition, Horrobin points to a long list of geniuses whose personalities and temperaments have be-trayed schizoid tendencies or signs of mental instability. These include Schumann, Strindberg, Poe, Kafka, Wittgenstein and Newton. Controversially, Horrobin also includes individuals such as Darwin and Faraday, generally thought to have displayed mental stability.

Nevertheless, psychologists agree that it is possible to make a link between mental illness and creativity. 'Great minds are marked by their ability to make connections between unexpected events or trends,' said Professor Til Wykes, of the Institute of Psychiatry, London. 'By the same token, those suffering from mental illness often make unexpected or inappropriate connections between day-to-day events.'

According to Horrobin, schizophrenia and human genius began to manifest themselves as a result of evolutionary pressures that triggered genetic changes in our brain cells, allowing us to make unexpected links with different events, an ability that lifted our species to a new intellectual plane. Early manifestations of this creative change include the 30,000-year-old cave paintings found in France and Spain.

The mutation Horrobin proposes involves changes to the fat content of brain cells. 'Sixty per cent of the non-aqueous material of the brain is fat. Humans have bigger heads than chimpanzees because their heads are full of fat.' By adding fat to our brain cells, we were able to control the flow of electrical signals more carefully and make more complex connections within our cortexes.

Our 'schizophrenia inheritance' was 'the single most important event in human history' and marked the break 'between our large-brained, possibly pleasant but unimaginative ancestors, and the restless, creative creatures we are today,' he adds.

This idea was last week described as 'a reasonable hypothesis' by palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer, of the Natural History Museum, London. 'It is well known there have been key brain cell mutations in our species in our recent past. It is also likely there would have been undesirable side-effects.'

Horrobin points out that schizophrenia is found in every racial group, at a frequency of between 0.7 and 1.0 per cent. However, mankind would initially have been largely unaffected by the disease because our hunter-gatherer forebears ate meat and other fat-rich foods.

These supplied our brain with the chemicals needed to maintain proper mental operation. With the invention of agriculture our diets changed and the fat content of our food altered - making us more vulnerable to mental diseases, says Horrobin.

Many scientists remain sceptical about the ideas of Horrobin, former managing director of Scotia Pharmaceuticals, which made evening primrose oil and other chemicals until it fell into insolvency this year.

Professor Tim Crow of Oxford University agreed genetic changes may have made us vulnerable to schizophrenia. 'The trouble is Horrobin's mechanism does not explain why so very few of us ever develop the disease.'
