webTitle: Outrage over plan to make Oxford library a 'theme park'

fields.headline: Outrage over plan to make Oxford library a 'theme park'
fields.trailText: Since books were first kept on the site in the early twelfth century, the Bodleian Library in Oxford has stood as a symbol of British learning.
fields.body:
Since books were first kept on the site in the early twelfth century, the Bodleian Library in Oxford has stood as a symbol of British learning.

Now a radical plan to turn the university library, a national treasure house, into a pay-as-you-enter visitor centre is provoking a fierce war of words.

The so-called theme park proposal, described by its opponents as 'sacrilegious' and 'a desecration', has been put forward by the management of the library itself. If approved, it would mean a complete change to the nature of the historic Old Quad at the heart of the library.

Opposition to the scheme from Oxford's town and gown already echoes the ferocity of last year's long-running feud about the fundamental changes made to the Great Court in the centre of London's British Museum. It also threatens to split the heritage community in two, as the impoverished Bodleian struggles to find a way to make ends meet.

The Oxford courtyard, properly known as The Old Schools Quadrangle, is the familiar subject of thousands of paintings and postcards and is used as a backdrop in films and in television advertisements and dramas.

Traditionally, it has been freely used as a thoroughfare by students, tourists and the people of Oxford, but a suggested new side entrance for paying visitors would mean the closure of all other points of access between the hours of 10am and 6pm. It would also mean cutting a new doorway right through the library's Great Gate, which dates back to 1610.

Dissenting staff members have argued the plan is nothing but commercial vandalism. One insider, who wished to remain anonymous, has attacked his employers for disregarding the founding principles of the library, which was established for the use of everyone.

Representations have been made to the Vice-Chancellor of the university, Colin Lucas, and this weekend he is believed to be considering calling on the library to hold back its plans.

But the proposed building work has been drawn up for scrutiny by the local planning authority and could eventually be funded by a Lottery grant. The university says it hopes that its visitor programme would reduce noise and congestion, as well as boosting library funds. It has also said it is willing to look at a permit system to allow some residents to use the quad without paying a fee.

'The university believes it is important that local residents can continue to enjoy free access to the historic spaces of the Bodleian,' a spokeswoman said.

'Rather than simply closing the gates to all tourists, we are taking a great deal of care to find a proposal which balances the operational needs of a working library with efforts to provide well-managed access to an important heritage site.'

One critic of the scheme, Maria Hamilton, from nearby Abingdon, has compared the library authority's activities with those of the Taliban in Afghanistan. 'Even the Taliban did not go so far as to ask for money to carry out their vandalism of historic artefacts', she argues in the Oxford Times .

John Goddard, the chair of the city's planning committee, has voiced his strong disapproval of the plan too. 'This is desecration. I find it very hard to believe that this is a good idea,' he said. 'I don't see why we need to knock a hole in this great building.'

Jeanine Alton, who works as a tour guide at the Bodleian, has questioned the financial assumptions behind the scheme. She argues that the cost of hiring new staff to handle the paying customers will eat into the projected cash benefits.

Some academics, however, are more sympathetic to the Bodleian's plight. Mark Philip, a politics don at Oriel College, said he could see why the library had considered a commercial venture.

'It is a shame,' he said. 'Without any other visible means of income for the library, though, what else can they do? It is a fantastic building and a major national research resource, but they have already had to cut back on services for the reader.'

The Bodleian is a deposit library which is legally entitled to free copies of all books printed in Great Britain, and it is particularly rich in Oriental manuscripts and collections of English literature. An early library on the site was fully secured by the university in 1410. Over the next century and a half it gradually declined in importance until it was restored by the collector Sir Thomas Bodley and reopened in 1602.

Several new buildings went up at this point and other additions were made up to the beginning of the nineteenth century. A new building designed by Sir Giles Gilbert Scott, architect of the brick shell of Tate Modern in London, was opened in 1946.

The current controversial proposal is not the first time the quiet world of the Bodleian has been threatened. As far back as 1866 it was mooted that the library should move to the grounds of the Angel hotel in the High Street to make way for a new examination schools complex. A little later, the authorities even suggested it should be moved out to the university parks, an idea that prompted a campaign of protest. This weekend, facing a modern campaign of protest, the University of Oxford has agreed to go into consultation with planning officers and to refine their proposals.

'The university is conscious of the comments raised during the ongoing consultation process, which we would hope to reflect in subsequent planning applications,' a spokeswoman said.

The architect Maxwell Hutchinson, a former president of the Royal Institute of British Architects, said that, while he was not against additions to listed buildings in principle, the architects who were engaged would have to work sensitively with English Heritage.

fields.headline: Under-fives face dyslexia checks
fields.trailText: Millions of pre-school children will be screened for special needs such as dyslexia or behavioural problems in a radical new scheme to identify problem youngsters before they start school.
fields.body:
Millions of pre-school children will be screened for special needs such as dyslexia or behavioural problems in a radical new scheme to identify problem youngsters before they start school.

Education Secretary David Blunkett fears that too many pupils are struggling through their education without their difficulties being recognised.

But the £11 million scheme, to be announced this week, could prompt concerns over the labelling of very young children as 'problem' pupils. Some critics blame overanxious middle-class parents for the explosion in the number of pupils designated as 'special needs', and there is concern at the repeated testing of pupils from a very young age.

The programme will involve training up to 850 specialists to visit nursery classes and children's centres, identifying youngsters who may need extra help when they start formal schooling.

'All children have rights to a high quality education,' said a source close to Blunkett. 'If a child has special educational needs that aren't identified and tackled early they fall behind other children and lose out. We can't allow this to happen.'

Blunkett, who attended a special school for the blind, is expected to unveil the new scheme when his Special Educational Needs and Disability Bill - strengthening children's rights to be included in mainstream school - returns to the Commons this week.

Under-fives will not have to undergo formal tests. Experts will watch them at play to pick up warning signs that would be relayed to primary schools, where all children now undergo assessment of their basic skills at five.

The rise in the number of children designated special needs - up more than 16 per cent in three years - has prompted fears of a rush to judge what may be normal variations in development.

However, parents' groups argue the rise is mainly due to greater recognition of complex conditions such as attention deficit disorder or mild autism.

Some local authorities may also have been reluctant to class pupils as special needs because of a lack of funds.

The rise in the number of children designated special needs - up more than 16 per cent in three years - has prompted fears of a rush to judge what may be normal variations in development. However, parents' groups argue the rise is mainly due to greater recognition of complex conditions such as attention deficit disorder or mild autism. Some local authorities may also have been reluctant to class pupils as special needs because of a lack of funds. gaby.hinsliff@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Which books would you admit to not having read?

fields.headline: Let's play literary humiliation
fields.standfirst:
Which titles would you admit to not having read? Robert McCrum investigates the world of book-guilt
Tell us what you feel guilty about not having read
fields.trailText: One of the secret reasons why some people read Sunday book reviews is to be able to talk knowledgeably about books at parties
fields.body:
The internet is a wonderful invention for which, if for nothing else, Al Gore deserves every top job in the civilised world. But it is also, as we know, a curse.

In the past week, two emails arrived at The Observer, each of which has ruined hours of productive time. The first was an invitation, from that prince of time-wasters, Malcolm Gladwell, to nominate an obscure, but seminal, volume that had been unjustly forgotten. The second was a request, from Microsoft's online magazine Slate, for a shortlist of books I would gladly confess to never having read.

The Gladwell questionnaire was not too troubling, and since its author never fails to publish the results of his research to profitable effect I will not steal his thunder. The Slate inquiry, however, proved to be far more searching. As Slate's Jodi Kantor puts it, 'Book-guilt and frustration are universal conditions.'

What book is any of us willing to admit not knowing? To admit an ignorance of, for the sake of argument, Macbeth or Anna Karenina is to expose a chink in your personal armour that could be fatal. If you are going to expose, as it were, a literary Achilles heel, it had better be in some part of your intellectual anatomy that will not lead to pain or social embarrassment.

Hypothetically, then, you can probably get away with never having read The Waves but might be ill-advised to confess an ignorance of Pride and Prejudice. In this tricky arena, it's better to choose a writer to whom modern taste is generally indifferent - someone like Thomas Hardy, say, or Ivy Compton-Burnett. Or you can adopt a position of de haut en bas and grandly concede that, alas, no, you have never got around to The Faerie Queen or the Book of Isaiah, but that, as soon as you've got to the end of The Man Without Qualities you will, of course, dive into The Collected Works of Thoreau, etc etc.

Civilisation is all about the successful organisation of hypocrisy, but the more you look at this tricky subject the more you realise that your average book conversation will, as likely as not, be based on bluff. One of the secret reasons why some people read Sunday book reviews is to be able to talk knowledgeably about books at parties.

Universities are quintessentially havens of literary bluff and counter-bluff. In David Lodge's campus novel, Changing Places, his characters play a game called 'Humiliation' in which the winner is judged to be the player who confesses to the most startling (and shameful) piece of literary ignorance. From memory, the plot turns on the fortunes of a visiting American academic who, in his desperation to win the game, admits to never having read Hamlet, with disastrous consequences for his career in the English faculty.

With minor Shakespeare, however, it's probably almost honourable to own up to never having read, say, Henry VIII or The Two Noble Kinsmen. Paradoxically, such an admission could suggest a deep scholarly intimacy with Coriolanus, King John and The Sonnets.

Nevertherless, I certainly wouldn't go as far as one of Slate's US campus correspondents who merrily claimed to have taught Julius Caesar having only 'rented the Marlon Brando video'. But I particularly enjoyed Alice Truax of the New Yorker's recollection of the Oxford professor who once exclaimed: 'You can't be serious: You've never read The Romance of the Rose?'

One plausible line of defence that might, or might not, work for medieval poetry, is that you have never been able to 'get into' a particular book. Every reader has had the experience of picking up a book that's only become wholly absorbing on a second look.

How much, then, are you willing to give away? A straw poll of The Observer was revealing. My neighbour says she has never read The Great Gatsby. That's worrying, but not, I think, irretrievable. (There's always the video.) Someone else on Review has never got around to War and Peace. The Foreign Desk hasn't managed Proust, but did not seem particularly dismayed. Deep in the interior of the newsroom there are colleagues who, subjected to routine interrogation, betrayed ignorance of both Ulysses, and even, strangely, of Romeo and Juliet.

So far so classical. What about contemporary titles? This, of course, is to stray into the minefield of literary fashion. My own list of overhyped books and recent prizewinners it's perfectly OK not to have read goes something like this: The Blind Assassin, Angela's Ashes, Come Together, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, When I Lived In Modern Times, English Passengers, Chocolat and A Man In Full.

You can of course buy all of the above at Amazon. The internet is great for book buying.

fields.headline: Go see
fields.standfirst: Slow food week
fields.trailText: Slow food week.
fields.body:
For anyone who thinks the Pot Noodle really is the greatest thing since sliced bread, next week's Slow Food Event at the Isola restaurant in Knightsbridge could be something of an eye-opener. Entitled La Sagra del Gustom, the week long event will celebrate indigenous Italian produce and cooking for those who believe eating should be an experience of epicurean proportions.

The International Slow Food Movement began in Italy in 1989 and aims to 'savour and rediscover the flavours of regional cooking and banish the degrading effects of fast food'. Oliver Peyton, owner of Isola, is a long-standing supporter of the cause and hopes to enthuse the British restaurant industry with the same passion for fresh, local produce. He and Isola's executive chef, Bruno Loubet, were so inspired by a recent trip to the Italian food festival, Salone del Gusto, that they decided to demonstrate how it can be done on their own turf.

As the proof of the pudding is in the eating, the Isola boys are drafting in three Italian chefs for the week to guest in the main kitchen as well as a host of experts on Italian rare food to run daily workshops. The chefs are from three diverse regions, Cervere, Bruzzio and Lombardia, where they run traditional family restaurants. What they lack in Michelin stars and city glamour they make up for with their in-depth knowledge of local produce and simple cooking, often growing and picking their own produce. So keen are they on their particular regional specialities that each chef will bring his own supplies for the week from Italy.

You can sign up for workshops on every aspect of Italian cuisine, from the cured meats to the great pastry tradition of the south for between £10 to £15. Workshops include extensive tasting and a chance to sample regional wines. This could well prove to be important sustenance because, as Oliver Peyton puts it, 'these guys can talk about salami for hours'.

 Slow Food Week at Isola, 145 Knightsbridge, London SW1 (020 7838 1044/1055) runs from 26-31 March.

fields.headline: £800,000 bill for Hoddle
fields.standfirst: After George Graham's exit, goals bring joy to Spurs as the club ponders price of the fans' favourite
fields.trailText: How ironic if Tottenham Hotspur, who sacked a manager for making inappropriate remarks to the press, appointed another who infamously lost a job for committing the same offence. Strange morals at work here: George Graham's opinion on transfer funds are unacceptable, whereas firm favourite Glenn Hoddle's religious views on the disabled - so unpalatable at the FA it cost him his position as manager of England - are unlikely to bar his potential homecoming to White Hart Lane.
fields.body:
How ironic if Tottenham Hotspur, who sacked a manager for making inappropriate remarks to the press, appointed another who infamously lost a job for committing the same offence. Strange morals at work here: George Graham's opinion on transfer funds are unacceptable, whereas firm favourite Glenn Hoddle's religious views on the disabled - so unpalatable at the FA it cost him his position as manager of England - are unlikely to bar his potential homecoming to White Hart Lane.

The path for appointing Hoddle is cleared by the get-out clause in his Southampton contract, which runs to the end of next season: a condition that would allow him to leave the Dell for £800,000 compensation.

If Spurs roll out the blue-and-white carpet, as has been rumoured for months now, the chief principle behind ENIC's choice of management will be abundantly clear. Hoddle is a Tottenham man, Graham anything but.

Yesterday, non-executive chairman Daniel Levy admitted the first he knew of the short cut to Hoddle was in the press. But speculation that he would be in place before the FA Cup semi-final in three weeks' time appears to be a long shot. 'It is very unlikely there will be any appointment until the end of the season,' he said. 'We as a board do not have a favourite. We will put together a list of candidates, both from the UK and overseas. David Pleat is a very experienced individual who has managed the team before. We want him to continue for the moment.'

Pleat, who has always cut a frustrated figure as a director of football and been ever eager for a more hands-on role with the first team, would surely leap at the chance to make his current role permanent. It cannot be a disadvantage that he goes back a long way with executive vice-chairman David Buchler, who was instrumental in bringing Pleat back to Luton when he was the receiver at Kenilworth Road.

Pleat must be a satisfied man right now. In possession of the job, unshackled from an uneasy working relationship with Graham, and able to do something about the frustration he felt watching his predecessor's interpretation of Tottenham. He was often as disenchanted as the hardcore fans by what was perceived as Graham's failure to appreciate the club's raison d'etre (style, style, style and sod the rest). His thinly veiled criticism of Graham during Alan Sugar's recent libel case suggested as much.

Does Pleat fit the long-term bill (and let's not forget he was ousted from Tottenham in the late Eighties after some pretty unsavoury press coverage of his personal habits)? Is Hoddle the fait accompli ? Does Gianluca Vialli or Marcello Lippi tickle Spurs' fancy? What are the qualities Levy wants from his new manager? 'Somebody we can completely trust,' he replied, perhaps with Graham in mind... 'somebody who will work as a team player, and somebody who accepts we can't have immediate success because we are not only concerned with the first team. We want to build up the club to be successful for years to come.'

Tottenham's chances of success in this year's FA Cup have slimmed down with Graham's dismissal. Aside from the dreadful timing, there is no doubt their most powerful psychological weapon is gone. The local enemy from Highbury were unquestionably far more scared of their old friend George than eleven men in white. Perhaps that explains why there was no outpouring of gloating at the Lane yesterday. 'One Georgie Graham,' mocked the Coventry fans. Tottenham didn't rise to the bait.

None the less, news of his departure was a blessed relief for the Tottenham purists. Ever since the day when Graham strolled into White Hart Lane in his navy suit, with his knowing smile, to begin one of English football's unlikeliest partnerships they have campaigned for two things: to bid good riddance to a manager who could never be trusted or loved for his Arsenal past, and a chairman, Alan Sugar, who committed the heinous sin of appointing him in the first place.

Their wish was ENIC's command. Just flick through the Coventry programme. 'There have certainly been a few smiles about the place following our marvellous FA Cup quarter-final against West Ham,' wrote Graham in yesterday's unchanged notes. Apparently he was busy planning his travel arrangements for Old Trafford an hour before Bulcher's boot.

'We've only really been involved for approximately 10 days, it feels like a lot longer,' mused Levy. 'Internally within the club, apart from the George Graham situation, there is a lot of optimism. It's very important the staff come in to work because they love to, not just to do a job. There has been a real sea change there.' Hearsay about a bust- up with senior players, notably captain Campbell, cannot have done Graham any good.

For liberating Tottenham from the agonising discomfort of the Sugar-Graham era, ENIC have curried favour with the masses and manufactured a honeymoon period for themselves. That was the easy part. Now that the man in the raincoat is out and the money men are in control, the complex challenge lies ahead.

If Sol Campbell chooses to clear off in the summer (and don't believe it's as simple as George goes, Sol stays) and sufficient top-quality signings are not brought in to augment a squad who are beginning to look promising, the fans will once again be twitching.

They may be on the road to getting their Tottenham back, but if Graham's ill-fated comments about 'limited' funds prove correct, the golden age of flamboyance will not return in a hurry - Hoddle, Pleat, or whoever.

webTitle: Observer review: Blackbird Singing by Paul McCartney

fields.headline: You've got to hide your lines away
fields.standfirst: Paul McCartney's song lyrics don't work on the page. And as for the poems... John Kinsella despairs of Blackbird Singing
fields.trailText: Paul McCartney's song lyrics don't work on the page. And as for the poems... John Kinsella despairs of Blackbird Singing
fields.body:
Blackbird Singing: Poems and Lyrics 1965-1999
Paul McCartney
Faber £14.99, pp164
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Only a hagiographer could have compiled this collection of McCartney's poems and lyrics. I'll admit, when I was a kid, it was John Lennon who interested me - and even he sold out. Paul McCartney was the guy who made 'Mull of Kintyre', the song that personified sentiment and schmaltz. And in his indulgent introduction, editor Adrian Mitchell tells us: 'Paul takes risks, again and again, in all of his work. He's not afraid to take on the art of poetry - which is the art of dancing naked.' This is just fatuous.

Mitchell goes on to tell us that 'Paul's not a primitive'. No, he's a wealthy pop icon. He's a shrewd marketer of 'art'. He knows about surrealism, I'd guess; it's almost there in some of his poems and songs. And, of course, the 'people' enjoy what he gives them, he is of the people! Once removed from the music, the lines have little rhythm. The timing is all wrong. And that's because the words aren't allowed to do the work themselves. That's what poetry is about, and that's why the song-lyric and the poem-lyric don't always operate in the same space.

There is nothing remotely radical or challenging in this book. The cultural changes the Beatles helped facilitate (and I would place these firmly within the mainstream), worked within the processes of Cold War capitalism and were ultimately sanctioned by the so-called Establishment. It is doubly ironic to read Mitchell noting that an issue of the New Statesman carrying McCartney poems sold 'several thousand' more copies. So what? Nude pictures sell magazines. The desire to conflate this with leftist ideals is an insult to the Left.

In terms of the selection of song-lyrics, this book has been gender-sanitised, or so it would seem. This is in keeping with the 'aware' McCartney promoted here; but the association of the black woman with the blackbird (as we learn in the introduction), the earth-mother biological determinism of a piece like 'Golden Earth Girl' - 'Golden earth girl, female animal/ Sings to the wind, resting at sunset/ In a mossy nest/ Sensing moonlight in the air/ Moonlight in the air' - are far from being sensitive to cultural and gender issues.

Reading the song lyrics, you can't help singing them in your head, which detracts from the poetic experience in some way, where the language generates its own music, but saves them from the trough the non-song lyrics fall into: doggerel and sentiment. With the lyrics to 'Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band', you can see innovation, how the shifts in tonal register and almost strophe/anti-strophe play would work innovatively within the monotheisms of rock and roll, and get a sense that it even enlivens the frame of the page. But that's the extent of it. It scares me when I read that Mitchell had to convince McCartney to include the song lyrics; without them this would have been a travesty of a book. As it happens, it is an archival document and disembodied song-book of some interest. It is an artefact.

I find it amusing that someone of the Left should have so consciously played the games of book construction he indirectly mocks in his introduction - the thematic arrangement and sequential-cum-symphonic shifts are nothing but pretentious. These sections are semi-thematic, but we feel the composer, editor (and author) are making grander gestures: 'Playing at Home', 'Yesterday', 'Friends and Enemies', 'The Business', 'The World Tonight', 'All the Lonely People' and so on. Social and environmental conscience is at work, but it often seems like lip-service. Despite the sincerity in a poem like 'Looking for Changes', against animal testing, many of the pieces lack genuine feeling.

You can't hide bad art behind the term 'popular poetry'. And Mitchell's comparisons of McCartney to Blake and Burns are ludicrous - the lack of technical control over language and vernacular is evident even in the great song-lyrics; without the melody, they are strangely lifeless. McCartney, if he ever understood irony, did so in the lightest (but not delicate) of ways. 'Back in the USSR'; without the irony of the pumping jauntiness of the tune, it looks ridiculous, and the stuff from McCartney's post-Beatle years appears as linguistically inept as it is musically devoid. It may be a truism by now, but McCartney needed Lennon; they played through and against each other.

The only reason I would encourage people to buy this book - and in some senses it's like a newly released (bad) Beatles song; it's gotta succeed - is not for appreciation of accomplishment, but in the hope Faber might put some of the profits into the rest of their poetry list and support further publications by the significant poets they carry.

But that's the extent of it. It scares me when I read that Mitchell had to convince McCartney to include the song lyrics; without them this would have been a travesty of a book. As it happens, it is an archival document and disembodied song-book of some interest. It is an artefact. I find it amusing that someone of the Left should have so consciously played the games of book construction he indirectly mocks in his introduction - the thematic arrangement and sequential-cum-symphonic shifts are nothing but pretentious. These sections are semi-thematic, but we feel the composer, editor (and author) are making grander gestures: 'Playing at Home', 'Yesterday', 'Friends and Enemies', 'The Business', 'The World Tonight', 'All the Lonely People' and so on. Social and environmental conscience is at work, but it often seems like lip-service. Despite the sincerity in a poem like 'Looking for Changes', against animal testing, many of the pieces lack genuine feeling. You can't hide bad art behind the term 'popular poetry'. And Mitchell's comparisons of McCartney to Blake and Burns are ludicrous - the lack of technical control over language and vernacular is evident even in the great song-lyrics; without the melody, they are strangely lifeless. McCartney, if he ever understood irony, did so in the lightest (but not delicate) of ways. 'Back in the USSR'; without the irony of the pumping jauntiness of the tune, it looks ridiculous, and the stuff from McCartney's post-Beatle years appears as linguistically inept as it is musically devoid. It may be a truism by now, but McCartney needed Lennon; they played through and against each other. The only reason I would encourage people to buy this book - and in some senses it's like a newly released (bad) Beatles song; it's gotta succeed - is not for appreciation of accomplishment, but in the hope Faber might put some of the profits into the rest of their poetry list and support further publications by the significant poets they carry.

webTitle: 'The quiet man of the Cabinet has delivered'

fields.headline: 'The quiet man of the Cabinet has delivered'
fields.trailText: When Labour rode into the sunrise almost four years ago, the arts world believed that at last its prince had come. Under-investment had affected the arts as much as health, education and transport. There were companies whose performers were, in effect, subsidising the arts with their meagre wages; there was a film industry reeling nowhere.
fields.body:
When Labour rode into the sunrise almost four years ago, the arts world believed that at last its prince had come. Under-investment had affected the arts as much as health, education and transport. There were companies whose performers were, in effect, subsidising the arts with their meagre wages; there was a film industry reeling nowhere.

But Tony Blair declared that the arts were now on the agenda, and there were many who understandably but unrealistically expected instant nirvana. The longing for positive change was so intense that longing alone, it seemed, in those early days, would deliver. Moreover, there was Chris Smith, a man of application and commitment, thoroughly at ease with his brief, and full of promises. But when the time it takes for change seemed to make a mockery of these promises, it was Chris Smith who got it in the neck.

Arts people have good access to the media and the howlaround of disappointment, though wholly justified in particular cases, in general failed to notice the green shoots, the unglamorous research, the longer game of Treasury stalking, Arts Council reform and the identification of key targets.

As in other areas, what was actually being achieved in those early New Labour years was obscured by the noises off. Who would have thought that what was being put in place was to emerge as the most comprehensive overhaul and reinforcement of state subsidy for the arts since the time of Jennie Lee in the Sixties? Who would have believed that the real-time increase in funding under Chris Smith is the best ever, even better than that under Jennie Lee?

When Labour was in opposition and Chris Smith was gathering the information to feed his policies, I said at several meetings that I thought he would be compared favourably with Jennie Lee if he was given the time. There was some whistling in the dark in that morale-boosting claim but I wish I had taken a bet on it. There can be no doubt that the quiet man of the Cabinet, the polite, rather fastidious arts lover has delivered. Now that the smoke has cleared, Chris Smith can been seen as the unlikely bespectacled hero in a western, the guy who won the shoot-out.

The big building blocks have been put in place. By far our most influential cultural institution is the BBC and by providing it with a secure financial base for seven years, Smith has given it a unique opportunity to take the best of its traditional strengths firmly into the next and most testing stage in the communications evolution. A lot depends on how it seizes that opportunity. After hard graft and tenacity, he has also delivered free access to museums for everyone. The previous policy of free entry for children and pensioners has already resulted in a 20 per cent increase in numbers of children and 40 per cent in pensioners. So stand back!

General funding for the arts - that 60 per cent increase over five years - is said to be set to increase yet further. The recent £25 million extra for more than 190 regional theatres is worth dwelling on. Not only have these theatres received a life-changing subsidy, but the money has been deployed shrewdly. There will be more productions in more theatres countrywide. Serious attention is being paid to the variety of needs which theatre is now expected to fulfil. There have been some casualties - York, Chester and Croydon for example - and one hopes that the appeals system is in place. Nothing slapdash, nothing careless but a thorough overhaul implemented with verve and authority.

It is somehow not easy to construct a success list. In this country, pain is more expected than paean - and the latter is harder to achieve. Something in the present culture likes to smell a rat or at least to spot one. It is as if today we distrust the possibility that we are good where once, not many decades ago, we dismissed the possibility that we could be bad. Good news sometimes appears unwelcome or, at least, unwelcomed.

Yet, through gritted teeth, we may have to accept the fact that Chris Smith has discovered the pot of gold for the arts. One achievement which particularly delighted me, because so many young people and their parents have written to me in despair about it, is the firm beginning of a long-term effort to solve the iniquities in public funding for young people, people doing professional training in dance, drama and stage-management.

This is the Billy Elliott escape route, if you like, and literally a lifeline to scores of talented people from low-income families. Add that £20m to the £40m for creative partnerships in deprived areas - an admirable attempt in places which boom time has by-passed. I know there will be those whose fine, upper lips will curl at the phrase 'creative partnerships' but any detailed examination of what opportunities these will bring to people with such a minute sliver of our national cake should cure that.

And all children will have access to musical instrument tuition. All children everywhere; £270m put into that. Not bad. And the deficits of orchestras will be wiped out! The country will soon be on song.

I could add to this drum-roll but I won't. Partly because it will seem too much, unEnglish, rather worryingly excessive and partly because there are still unattended miseries in the world of the arts; companies panting hard just to keep walking, galleries, individuals desperately clinging on for their turn, their break. But no one has said this is the last act.

There was a meeting in the Cabinet Room at Number 10 the other week. The Prime Minister and Chris Smith had shepherded together a score or so of us from the arts world, including Jude Kelly, Nick Serota, Alan Parker, Neil McGregor, Shobana Jeyasingh, Sue Hollick, Chris Frayling, Gerry Robinson, Deborah Bull, Richard Eyre, Michael Jackson.

A strange sound was heard, rare, I would guess, in that room, rarer in what is sometimes, without irony, called the arts community. The Arts Minister was being praised. Without any prior consultation or conspiracy of any sort, speaker after speaker prefaced their brief presentation with praise for the increasingly embarrassed Chris Smith, who had taken so much flak but had battled on. It was a good moment. The quiet man had won, through, and was still on the case.

Melvyn Bragg is president of the National Campaign for the Arts

webTitle: Blair takes risk with bid to grab the 'ethical' vote

fields.headline: Blair takes risk with bid to grab the 'ethical' vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to put his religious beliefs at the centre of the general election campaign and call for a new style of ethical politics where the Church is the bedrock of local communities.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to put his religious beliefs at the centre of the general election campaign and call for a new style of ethical politics where the Church is the bedrock of local communities.

In a high-risk strategy, the Prime Minister will say in a speech to the Christian Socialist Movement that organisations based around religion should get more involved in helping communities, particularly in schools.

His forthcoming speech will be one of the last events Blair will attend in this Parliament if, as expected, he calls an election for 3 May. It is the first time since Labour won the election in 1997 that he has agreed to speak at such a high-profile Christian event.

The Prime Minister's move will reignite the debate about the role of religion in politics. Many Downing Street staff are uneasy about Blair appearing to wear his religion on his sleeve because of fears that it turns off some voters.

Blair has asked one of his key Downing Street aides, Andrew Adonis, to write the speech. It is expected to develop themes of 'faith communities' which help the disadvantaged, and the role religion plays in supporting society. He will also say that churches provide continuity during times of rapid change and that the moral values expounded by religious teaching have an important lesson for politicians.

Officials say that the Prime Minister will be wary of making too close a link between religion and the values of the left. He caused a storm of protest last year when he suggested in a foreword to a book called God's Politicians that there was a direct link between socialist beliefs and the beliefs of Christianity. Close religious friends of Blair said he did not want to 'ram it down people's throats'.

One of the key guests at the event will be Jim Wallis, the religious adviser to both the former US president, Bill Clinton, and the new one, George W. Bush. Wallis, who is expected to meet Blair, argues that religion-based organisations should have a greater role to play in society.

The Prime Minister's speech marks the start of a battle for the 'ethical vote' during the election campaign. He wants to ensure that he keeps his high levels of support among Christian voters who have been wooed by William Hague in a series of speeches by the leader of the opposition over the last three months.

Hague has revealed that he is close to Marvin Olasky, the right-wing American religious leader who argues that benefits should only be given to those who deserve them because of the effort they put into their life.

webTitle: Feathers fly in Chicken Run row

fields.headline: Feathers fly in Chicken Run row
fields.standfirst: Aardman's hit film was copied from my book insists children's author
fields.trailText: Aardman's hit film was copied from my book insists children's author.
fields.body:
It was a simple story that won the hearts of America and turned the Oscar-winning British animator Nick Park into a major Hollywood player.

But Chicken Run, the comic film that made more than $100 million in the United States, has made at least one man miserable.

Alan Davidson, the children's author, has watched with growing annoyance as the cartoon feature, co-produced with Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks studio, became the third most popular film of last year on both sides of the Atlantic, beaten only by Toy Story II and Gladiator.

Behind the scenes, Davidson is fighting a battle. He claims the story about a plucky band of chickens who break out from a battery farm was stolen from his own book, Escape from Cold Ditch, published in 1994. The author first alerted the Bristol-based film-makers to the similarity in the plot last year and asked them to explain the coincidence, but his allegations have been firmly rejected.

Since then the dispute has been continued in a sharp exchange of letters between his solicitors, Sheridans, and D. J. Freeman, which represents Nick Park and his partner, Peter Lord.

'Mr Davidson has not wanted to speak out publicly about this at the moment, but he is extremely angry,' said Stephen Taylor, his solicitor.

'We believe we have a strong case of breach of copyright, and we will be demanding substantial damages. There are more than 300 points of similarity between the stories, particularly when you compare the recent novelisation of the film with theoriginal, Escape from Cold Ditch. There are matches both in plot points and in characterisation.'

Taylor said that his legal team were about to send out a letter detailing all the alleged copyright infringements and that they were prepared to trace the link between the two creative processes in court.

When it came out, Escape from Cold Ditch, published by Straw Hat, was described as a 'marvellously original fable' and adopted for use in school reading lessons. It tells of a chicken which yearns to set its incarcerated sisters free. Just like Chicken Run, the narrative mimics the style of a Second World War prison escape drama. Its writer grew up with hens in his backyard and is a campaigner against battery farming. In spite of the prospect of a long legal wrangle with Park's company Aardman Animation and with DreamWorks, Davidson has told his solicitor he is not prepared to back down.

A spokesman for Aardman said any legal action would be vigorously defended. 'Chicken Run is based on an original concept and story by its directors Nick Park and Peter Lord and the claim is strenuously denied.'

Aardman has always confidently maintained that the idea came from a one-off sketch by Park of a chicken escaping from a farm.

The film depicts the farm as a prisoner-of-war camp, down to the hand-crafted barbed wire, and Park has always referred to it as The Great Escape with hens. He said the story went down particularly well with Spielberg who told them the PoW film was his favourite movie and that he also had a farm with 300 chickens.

Park's plot has an egg-layer named Ginger who leads a revolt among the birds held on a grim farm in Northern England. The characters were voiced by Jane Horrocks, Julia Sawahla and Mel Gibson.

Aardman was founded by Lord and David Sproxton in 1976 and began on a kitchen table. Their first national success was as creators of the Plasticine character, Morph, which appeared on the television show Take Hart.

Lord and Sproxton spotted the talent of Park in 1986 when he was a student and together they went on to make the three award-winning Wallace and Gromit films: A Grand Day Out, A Close Shave and The Wrong Trousers. Revenues from the merchandising of the characters in the films now runs to more than £50 million a year.

In October 1999 the company signed a £155m, five-film deal with DreamWorks SKG, the new studio run by Jeffrey Katzenberg in partnership with Spielberg. DreamWorks has already challenged Disney's domination of feature animation with the films Antz and Prince Of Egypt.

The next Aardman feature is to be an updated version of time-honoured tale of The Tortoise and the Hare.

fields.headline: Facts of racial life
fields.trailText: Race in Britain today
fields.body:
Women from ethnic minorities hold more educational qualifications than white women. Black African women are twice as likely as white women to be qualified above A-level standard

Unemployment among young black women is nearly four times greater than for young white women

More than half of all 16 to 29-year-old Indians and Pakistanis have English as their main spoken language, compared with only one-fifth of their Bangladeshi peers

Young people from ethnic-minority groups are up to one-third less likely to use drugs than their white peers

Almost one in five of the total prison population of England and Wales is from an ethnic-minority group

71 per cent of 16 to 19-year-olds from ethnic minority groups were in full-time education in 1997, compared with 58 per cent of young white people

Half of families headed by a black person are lone-parent families, compared with one in 13 Indian families

39 per cent of children under 16 with a black Caribbean mother or father have a white other parent

More than half the racial attacks against south Asians, and more than one in three against black Caribbeans, are committed by 16 to 25-year-olds. In nine out of 10 cases, perpetrators are white

The proportion of Asian women who have separated or divorced is less than half that recorded among whites

60 per cent of Bangladeshi and Pakistani Britons are poor, four times the poverty rate among white people

Among British-born Caribbeans, half of all men with a partner live with a white woman and a third of women with a partner live with a white man

One in 10 white women with children is a single mother, compared with half of Caribbean mothers

Three-quarters of Pakistani and Bangladeshi women are in partnerships by the age of 25, compared with two-thirds of Indian women and just over half of African, Asian and white women

Just over a third of Muslims and Sikhs who married after they came to Britain feel that their partner was chosen by their family, rather than by themselves

Nearly half the ethnic-minority population is under 24, compared with one-third of the white population

One in seven Bangladeshi women are clinically underweight, compared with one in 16 of the female population

(Sources: Institute for Social and Economic Research, Commission for Racial Equality)

fields.headline: Wycombe come down to earth
fields.trailText: Hard-earned win over Oldham for cup heroes.
fields.body:
Basking in FA Cup glory does have its drawbacks, especially when, as in the case of Wycombe, the build-up to an FA Cup semi-final against Liverpool coincides with matches like yesterday's Second Division scrap at home to Oldham. This header by Roy Essandoh failed to find the net, but at least Wycombe won 2-1.

It will certainly have pleased their chairman, Ivor Beekes, who has called upon the players to forget about that Cup magic and 'get themselves refocused.' But that is easier said than done when you are suddenly attracting the sort of publicity that Wycombe are experiencing. No fewer than 90 media representatives turned up for their last home tie - compared to 18 for Second Division matches) - and the quarter-final at Leicester was televised live in 16 different countries.

Last week, Beeks says he was 'amazed' to be given a Hong Kong paper, with coverage of Wycombe's Cup success plastered across its front page. On top of all this have been the messages of congratula tion from other chairmen 'thanking us for keeping the Nationwide flag flying' in the competition.

The high confidence levels translate well to the league, but as he says: 'It is important that we keep it flying in the Second Division as well. I really feel we have a good chance of making a strong push for the First Division next season.'

It will certainly have pleased their chairman, Ivor Beekes, who has called upon the players to forget about that Cup magic and 'get themselves refocused.' But that is easier said than done when you are suddenly attracting the sort of publicity that Wycombe are experiencing. No fewer than 90 media representatives turned up for their last home tie - compared to 18 for Second Division matches) - and the quarter-final at Leicester was televised live in 16 different countries. Last week, Beeks says he was 'amazed' to be given a Hong Kong paper, with coverage of Wycombe's Cup success plastered across its front page. On top of all this have been the messages of congratula tion from other chairmen 'thanking us for keeping the Nationwide flag flying' in the competition. The high confidence levels translate well to the league, but as he says: 'It is important that we keep it flying in the Second Division as well. I really feel we have a good chance of making a strong push for the First Division next season.'

fields.headline: Reuser-sharp strike sinks Hammers
fields.trailText: Ipswich continue remarkable push for champions league as Hammers season seems to fade and die.
fields.body:
There is something poignantly appropriate about the West Ham club song. 'Just like my dreams they fade and die', Upton Park sings and once again their season is in danger of doing exactly that. Dogged Ipswich, meanwhile, extend their remarkable pursuit of the third Champions League place.

Martijn Reuser's well-struck free-kick was enough to do that, and to see off a depressed West Ham, devoid of creativity in a team that usually boasts an abundance. After their FA Cup exit it was said they had only an outside chance of a European place; actually they have an outside chance of being relegated.

Expectations of a thrilling encounter should not have been high. It was a dank East London afternoon to mirror an air of gloom that has hung over Upton Park since the quarter-final defeat by Tottenham last week, which left a feeling that West Ham's season was effectively over. Like floundering actors, their players might have been asking 'what's my motivation?'

Ipswich arrived having lost their previous five away games in the Premiership, so were in no mood to take part in a free-flowing game. Instead it was a case of keeping it tight and hoping that their leading scorer Marcus Stewart, returning after a three-game suspension, might poach a goal on the break.

The game began as a scrappy contest with the ball frequently surrendered on the threadbare surface, chances few and far between. Stuart Pearce did his best to drive West Ham on, a wicked early corner forcing Richard Wright to scramble and palm the ball away under his crossbar, which almost gave West Ham a lift.

He also fired in a free-kick from 35 yards, which Wright held comfortably, and Paolo Di Canio also tested the goalkeeper with a low cross-shot after Nigel Winterburn had found him in space, but they were isolated attempts. Not that Ipswich produced much in reply. With their only real opening of the first half, Stewart missed his kick in front of goal from Reuser's low cross.

The West Ham manager Harry Redknapp changed to a back four for the second half and brought on John Moncur for Joe Cole - out of sorts, as might be expected of a such a young player after receiving criticism for his part in two of the Spurs goals - and Svetoslav Todorov for Sebastien Schemmel.

It was Ipswich, though, who looked the sharper at the outset of the second period, profiting from the absence of a player on the right flank of their midfield in a 4-3-3 formation. A neatly worked move in that area almost brought them the lead.

Ian Pearce fouled Stewart on the edge of the West Ham penalty area - actually inside, Ipswich claimed. No matter, though. Up stepped Reuser, who had cemented his place in the team after two similar goals against Bradford City, and curled a neat shot past Shaka Hislop's left hand and into the corner of his net.

Now Ipswich's Tractor Boys were making hay and Hislop had to go full length to turn aside another shot by Reuser. Jim Magilton also saw a shot deflected just over the bar. At the other end, Di Canio's appeal for a penalty under challenge by Fabien Wilnis was not convincing. Nor was anything else about West Ham.

webTitle: Carlos Menem's plans to marry a former Miss Universe and win back power

fields.headline: New Evita faces a tide of mockery
fields.standfirst: Ageing ex-President Carlos Menem's plans to marry a former Miss Universe and win back power in Argentina are running into trouble, reports  Hugh O'Shaughnessy
fields.trailText: Ageing ex-President Carlos Menem's plans to marry a former Miss Universe and win back power in Argentina are running into trouble, reports Hugh O'Shaughnessy.
fields.body:
Beauty has met the Beast, and they claim to have fallen in love. Now all South America is waiting to find out whether the two 'lovers' are telling the truth or whether this is just another self-regarding encounter between pulchritude and turpitude.

For this is a love story about two of South America's most prominent people but from very different worlds: Cecilia 'Chechi' Bolocco, 35, Chilean and Miss Universe in 1987 and Carlos 'Carlitos' Menem, aged 70 of Argentina, and former president of that Republic.

Bolocco did a television interview in 1999 with Menem; the two were seen to hit it off, and since then the gossip columnists have not looked back.

With a mane of blond hair and a perfect figure the beautiful Chechi is the darling of the Chilean small screen. Chileans love her Davidoff perfume, her Baume et Mercier watch, her Charlie's Angels shades. On the subject of bearing Carlitos's child she warbles: 'If God sends me that marvellous gift I will be the happiest woman in the world.'

Menem is a different proposition, a slippery politician who during his election campaign swore he would throw the Brits out of the Falklands 'by fire and sword'. But when he became President in 1989 he slashed military spending and angled desperately for an invitation to Buckingham Palace. So many times did he announce he had been invited to London that the Foreign Office eventually had to let him come.

Doing little to hide his well publicised lapses from marital fidelity, he had furious screaming matches with his wife Zulema whose family, like his, came from a small Syrian town north of Damascus. Both were born in the Muslim faith, though Carlos soon recognised he would get nowhere in Argentine politics as a Muslim. So he became a Catholic. Zulema and he soon had their marriage annulled.

Before polling day he promised massive public spending for all and faithfulness to the memory of General Peron and Evita: after he installed himself in the presidential palace he pursued the purest Thatcherism, privatising everything that moved and cutting public expenditure until teachers had to go on strike to get their back salaries paid.

He promoted to senior positions dubious businessmen and others later found guilty of major frauds. In one notorious instance he appointed a friend from Syria head of Argentina's customs agency, although he could not speak Spanish. Currying favour with the armed forces, he gave amnesties to generals already found guilty and imprisoned by Argentine courts for worse crimes during Argentina' s Dirty War than anything Augusto Pinochet has so far been charged with.

Chechi and Carlitos have repeatedly and excitedly talked of a wedding day with 5,000 guests to which George Bush senior has already promised to come. It was to be in Las Vegas. Then it was to be in Menem's birthplace, Anillaco, the parched Andean village from where his father sallied forth on a donkey selling nicknacks in the surrounding hamlets. So far there is no date and no venue and the suspense is killing million of readers of the continent's tabloids.

Meanwhile a few drops of rain are falling on the idyll. Chechi contracted a civil marriage in Chile in 1990 with unknown US film producer Michael Young. They had a child but the relationship died five years later without, it seems, either of them formally ending their union. Chilean lawyers have warned that they could both be charged with bigamy unless that little problem is solved - though it is claimed that nothing now prevents Chechi and Carlitos from having a church wedding.

Carlitos's daughter Zulemita, 30, is furious with her father and dismisses Chechi as just the latest in a long line of women, blond and brunette, he has bedded. 'If they do have a child, who'll look after it - her next husband?' she sniffs.

More hard-headed analysts are meanwhile spoiling the image of the two lovers. Is Menem romancing Chechi merely to burnish his image as a macho septuagenarian in advance of the 2003 presidential electionthat he wants to fight?

Is she merely out for the chance to play on the big stage of Argentina for big money rather than on the small stage of Chilean showbiz for a comparative pittance?

Worse still the tale is beginning to excite ridicule in Buenos Aires. Though the tall and sculptured Chechi is still popular in her own country, where Chileans are quite proud that their girl has captured the heart of the former leader of their powerful neighbour, the tide of laughter is lapping round the ankles of the diminutive Carlitos. He is seen by many Argentines as a character from The Rocky Horror Show. Not long ago the happy couple went to see her father Enzo, a Chilean factory owner, and the journalists worked out that if they did eventually marry Enzo would have a son-in-law three years older than himself.

And the jokes about his sexual prowess are multiplying in the Argentine capital. One cartoon shows Chechi saying to Carlitos: 'I want to make love on the ground.'

'On the ground, my love? Why?' Menem exclaims.

'Well,' she says, 'so I can feel something hard.'

Another has Chechi meeting an old girlfriend who asks her how it is going with Menem.

'Well,' replies Chechi. 'We have a treatment ( tratamiento in Spanish). He tries (trata ) and I lie (miento ).'

webTitle: Cricket: England clinch fourth successive series win

fields.headline: England win in Colombo
fields.standfirst: Hero Thorpe celebrates as England clinch fourth successive series win. Bring on the Aussies
fields.trailText: Hero Thorpe celebrates as England clinch fourth successive series win. Bring on the Aussies.
fields.byline: Vic Marks in Colombo and Denis Campbell
fields.body:
An extraordinary day's cricket in Colombo, during which 22 wickets fell, ended with England winning a series on the sub-continent for the second time this winter. After bowling out Sri Lanka for 81 on a relatively blameless pitch, England, despite a few alarms, knocked off the 74 runs for victory with four wickets to spare.

Every player contributed towards this brilliant victory - which took England to joint fourth in the world rankings - but the star was undoubtedly Surrey's Graham Thorpe, who chose to rest from last winter's tour of South Africa. He has returned to England colours refreshed and renewed though he admitted that he had 'never been so tired on a cricket field' as he was last night in the stifling heat of Colombo.

Thorpe, undefeated on 113 was the mainstay of England's first innings, just as he was in the second when he shepherded his team home with an unbeaten 32. As he set off on his second innings of the day he felt 'dizzy and sick in the stomach. I've never played in such demanding conditions and maybe the tension added to the fatigue as well', he said afterwards.

While England wobbled in pursuit of their victory target, their captain, Nasser Hussain, hobbled. 'My body's falling apart,' he said and it was announced yesterday that he would take no further part in the tour, missing the three one-day internationals. Hussain has a collection of groin, knee and thigh strains but there was no way he was not going to take to the field yesterday to oversee the clinical demolition of Sri Lanka's much-vaunted batting line up.

Hussain regrets his early departure. 'I enjoy being with this team and the coach,' he said, reflecting the new spirit in the England set-up. Hardly surprising since Hussain is proving to be the most successful English captain since Mike Brearley, the last man to lead England to victory in four consecutive series. But discretion demands he should try to get himself fit for the summer when Pakistan visit England to be followed by a potentially enthralling clash with the Australians. This time there just might be a contest for the Ashes.

Hussain pinpointed the victory in the second Test at Kandy as the crucial moment of the tour. 'After that win Darren Gough started talking about the win bonuses, Mike Atherton about winning four in a row.' Hussain said that 'there were 15 drained people in that dressing room' and stressed the need for his players to be given time to recuperate after their efforts this winter. Another heroes' welcome at Heathrow should be enough to soothe aching bodies and minds before the challenges of a fascinating summer, which could well prove to be a bonanza for the England Cricket Board. For once English cricket is sexy. The grounds will be packed with fans desperate to see the team continue their winning streak.

'Ticket sales have been buoyant anyway for the forthcoming matches, especially for the Australians', said Terry Blake, marketing director of the ECB. 'We are heading for sellouts, at least in the Ashes, and the victory over Sri Lanka will help us fill the grounds against Pakistan as well. People just want to see this exciting team in action. 'The revival began last summer - remember we locked out 5,000 at The Oval for the last Test against the West Indies - and the two away wins this winter have added extra momentum.'

Channel 4, which will broadcast all five Ashes Tests live, can't wait. 'We have a cricket team to be proud of for the first time in a long time. There's nothing like success to get people interested in the sport, particularly kids', said David Kerr, C4's editor of sport. 'The Ashes will have the best England team in years against the best team in the world in the greatest event in cricket. It's set up beautifully to be the sporting event of the summer.' William Hill have cut the odds on England beating Australia from 5-1 to 100-30, but Australia are hot favourites at 1-2.

webTitle: Pool bite back after Mayo starter

fields.headline: Pool bite back after Mayo starter
fields.trailText: Hartlepool United, the butt of music-hall jokes for decades, set a new club record of 18 league matches undefeated with this draw in a match which was a sparkling advert for Division Three.
fields.body:
Hartlepool United, the butt of music-hall jokes for decades, set a new club record of 18 league matches undefeated with this draw in a match which was a sparkling advert for Division Three.

The last time Hartlepool were beaten was back on 25 November, a run which has lifted them into fourth place. Things would look even brighter had the last five matches not ended in draws. But many here believe fourth will be enough to earn promotion for only the third time in their history, should the leaders Chesterfield be punished for financial irregularities.

Strange things have been happening here in the North East. Earlier in the week Hartlepool had even been featured on the BBC Holiday programme. It seems that the only person here left for the music hall comedians to exploit is the town's local Labour MP.

Peter Mandelson was among the crowd, leaving one club official to remark ruefully that there must be an election on the horizon. The opening exchanges must have seemed all very tedious to a man whose normal habitat is more usually the ballet or opera. This passion play was ignited in the 22nd minute by Brighton's Kerry Mayo, whose 25-yard shot left Hartlepool keeper Anthony Williams beaten - only for him to be saved by a post. Far from galvanising the out-of-sorts visitors, it was the home side who drew inspiration.

Directed by Paul Stephenson, a former Newcastle team-mate of Paul Gascoigne, they went close on three occasions in four minutes. First, in the 29th minute, Tony Lormor saw a shot from six yards blocked by Michel Kuipers, a save the Brighton keeper repeated minutes later from the same player.

Confidence rising, Hartlepool fell victim in the 36th minute to a well-worked Brighton corner. Paul Watson rolled the ball into the path of Richard Carpenter, whose crisp, rising drive arrowed beyond Williams to put his side ahead.

It took less than a minute after the break for Hartlepool to equalise when Lormor headed Stephenson's corner beyond Kuipers. Kevin Hen derson should have put them in front in the 54th minute when he was left unmarked but headed straight at the keeper. Seconds later, at the other end, Michael Barron was harshly penalised for handling after Bobby Zamora fired at him from close range. Zamora converted the penalty himself for his 22nd goal of the season.

To their credit, Hartlepool kept their cool and brought themselves level again straight from the restart - Henderson running through to shoot low into the net. But Pool, try as they might, couldn't find the winner they craved and deserved.

But many here believe fourth will be enough to earn promotion for only the third time in their history, should the leaders Chesterfield be punished for financial irregularities. Strange things have been happening here in the North East. Earlier in the week Hartlepool had even been featured on the BBC Holiday programme. It seems that the only person here left for the music hall comedians to exploit is the town's local Labour MP. Peter Mandelson was among the crowd, leaving one club official to remark ruefully that there must be an election on the horizon. The opening exchanges must have seemed all very tedious to a man whose normal habitat is more usually the ballet or opera. This passion play was ignited in the 22nd minute by Brighton's Kerry Mayo, whose 25-yard shot left Hartlepool keeper Anthony Williams beaten - only for him to be saved by a post. Far from galvanising the out-of-sorts visitors, it was the home side who drew inspiration. Directed by Paul Stephenson, a former Newcastle team-mate of Paul Gascoigne, they went close on three occasions in four minutes. First, in the 29th minute, Tony Lormor saw a shot from six yards blocked by Michel Kuipers, a save the Brighton keeper repeated minutes later from the same player. Confidence rising, Hartlepool fell victim in the 36th minute to a well-worked Brighton corner. Paul Watson rolled the ball into the path of Richard Carpenter, whose crisp, rising drive arrowed beyond Williams to put his side ahead. It took less than a minute after the break for Hartlepool to equalise when Lormor headed Stephenson's corner beyond Kuipers. Kevin Hen derson should have put them in front in the 54th minute when he was left unmarked but headed straight at the keeper. Seconds later, at the other end, Michael Barron was harshly penalised for handling after Bobby Zamora fired at him from close range. Zamora converted the penalty himself for his 22nd goal of the season. To their credit, Hartlepool kept their cool and brought themselves level again straight from the restart - Henderson running through to shoot low into the net. But Pool, try as they might, couldn't find the winner they craved and deserved.

webTitle: Lucky Gers leave it till late

fields.headline: Lucky Gers leave it till late
fields.trailText: On-loan Fernandes is the unlikely hero at Fir Park.
fields.body:
Fabrice Fernandes took the short route into the affections of the Rangers supporters, scoring an extraordinary equaliser for the Ibrox side within two minutes of taking the field and delivering the corner kick from which Bob Malcolm scored an improbable winner.

Fernandes, the 21-year-old striker on loan from Fulham, was an unlikely hero, as Motherwell had been appreciably better than their visitors, taking an early lead through Don Goodman. Malcolm should have been even less expected as a redeemer, as he should have been sent off for drawing his foot across the face of Motherwell's Said Chiba 10 minutes earlier. The referee, Alan Freeland, completed a dreadful performance by taking no action.

Goodman's goal delivered the justest of rewards, Freeland having one minute earlier denied Motherwell a penalty with a decision met with astonishment by everyone in the ground.

As Goodman threatened to get away from Bert Konterman inside the area, the Dutch defender appeared to foul him three times, the last of these being conclusive, putting Goodman on the floor as he was on the point of shooting. When Freeland awarded a goal-kick even the Rangers supporters looked embarrassed.

But Goodman exacted the sweetest revenge when Motherwell were given a free-kick about 10 yards to the right of the penalty box. Chiba, the Moroccan signed by the Fir Park manager, Billy Davies, just two days earlier, whipped the ball in and Goodman, unchallenged, glanced the header to the right of Klos from six yards.

It was the precursor to a series of threats the home side carried to the distressed, outgoing champions through the first half. Assured in midfield and alert in defence, Motherwell were a gratifying contrast to Rangers, both sides having been similarly afflicted by personnel problems.

The home team's difficulties arose from injuries and, especially, suspensions to half-a-dozen first team players, to say nothing of the regulars who have had to be sold in the past three weeks out of financial necessity. Yet those players who came in appeared for most of the time to be much more committed than the players Dick Advocaat drafted in as a result of his lengthy casualty list.

Motherwell, in fact, should have been two or three ahead by the interval. Stuart Elliott was given a free header by Dougie Ramsey's precise centre from the right, but he sent the ball straight at Klos. And when Goodman escaped Klos, his left-foot shot was slightly deflected onto the post rather than over the line.

With Rangers' only feasible opportunity of the first half, a header from Allan Johnston which found Flo, the big Norwegian almost hurt himself with a wild swipe which made only tangential contact with the ball, spinning it into the side net from the edge of the six-yard box.

In the circumstances, the introduction of Fernandes was all the more dramatic. The young Frenchman had replaced Sergio Porinni just two minutes before he gathered the ball some 25 yards out and sent a magnificent left-foot drive high to the left of Andy Goram.

Clearly encouraged by the return to equality, Rangers produced their most fluent move soon after, when the largely ineffective Barry Ferguson played a one-two with another substitute, Billy Dodds, which left him looking at Goram inside the area. He shot weakly straight at the goalkeeper, but was saved embarrassment by Malcolm's late, unlikely intervention.

fields.headline: Luckless Leicester
fields.trailText: Two late goals give United an unconvincing victory as foxes suffer another blow.
fields.body:
You don't have to tell Leicester City that football can be cruel. Dumped out of the FA Cup by Wycombe Wanderers last week, Peter Taylor's side recovered their composure manfully and were three minutes from taking a point off the Premiership leaders, only to fall to a harmless Ole Gunnar Solskjaer shot that was deflected by Dwight Yorke.

United had no David Beckham, Ryan Giggs or Andy Cole - and Dwight Yorke playing in goal? Manchester United fans arriving just before kick-off must have thought Sir Alex Ferguson was taking the mickey, but it turned out there was a rational explanation.

Giggs is still injured, Cole completing a suspension, and Fabien Barthez pulled a muscle in the warm-up so 19-year-old American reserve goalkeeper Paul Rachubka was propelled from the bench into the starting line-up. Yorke drew the short straw among the remaining substitutes as emergency goalkeeping cover, and greatly enjoyed himself prancing up and down the touchline in gloves, but on the evidence of his brief practice with Teddy Sheringham before the start United must have been relieved he was not needed. Yorke was unable to save a single shot.

As for Beckham, he was once again rested, in fact he was not even on the bench. Given that he is supposed to be leading England in a World Cup qualifier on Saturday this is irregular, to say the least. Ali G has seen more of the England captain than Sven-Göran Eriksson in the past week. Presumably Beckham can still expect to lead England out against Finland at Anfield, although when Eriksson names his squad this evening he will delay an announcement on the captaincy until the following day, although the manager is not expected to make a change.

United did not miss Beckham in the Sturm Graz game, but they missed him here. Jonathan Greening at the moment is not an adequate replacement, and in a dreary first half the home side lacked penetration down the flanks, for all Roy Keane and Paul Scholes's busy promptings from midfield. Those two players conjured the best chance prior to the interval, when Scholes picked up Keane's run into the penalty area only for the final shot to roll a foot the wrong side of Simon Royce's post. Leicester, with the whole of their regular midfield missing, began as if they expected to be overrun but grew more adventurous the longer the game remained scoreless. For all that, Rachubka's only scary moment came right at the end of the first half, when he ended up trying to tackle Gary Neville after an innocuous cross from Junior Lewis caused momentary panic.

United sent on Yorke for Greening for the second half, switching Ole Gunnar Solskjaer to the left. Perversely the Norwegian was immediately presented with a couple of chances in the middle, bringing a save from Royce with one and skying the other, but otherwise United's attempts to quicken the tempo made little impression against some determined defending.

With Matt Elliott in charge of an organised back line, Leicester got men behind the ball assiduously and even managed one or two notional counterattacks. For the most part, though, they defended so deep that Jaap Stam was encouraged to try his luck in attack, which, with due respect to the Dutchman,is not what supporters expect of a club of United's attacking resources.

When one of Stam's upfield forays coincided with one of Leicester's breakaways Gary Neville appeared to pull a hamstring in winning a race with Ade Akinbiyi, though the England defender managed to stay on the field until the end.

Instead it was Leicester whose luck was out, when Solskjaer's speculative shot was diverted past Royce by Yorke. Mikael Silvestre's goal in the final minute, cutting in from the left to find the bottom right corner, simply confirmed that Leicester's luck is well and truly out.

webTitle: Homesick Forest laid low by Bolton

fields.headline: Homesick Forest laid low by Bolton
fields.trailText: Bolton took full advantage of Forest's susceptibility to be laid low by homesickness with a win that has put daylight between them and their rivals for the second automatic promotion spot.
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge at The City Ground
fields.body:
Bolton took full advantage of Forest's susceptibility to be laid low by homesickness with a win that has put daylight between them and their rivals for the second automatic promotion spot.

The win lifts them two points clear of Blackburn Rovers but has done Forest's hopes of qualifying for the play-offs few favours. This was their eighth League defeat at the City Ground and they will be central as just three of their remaining fixtures are at home.

Whoever chose the picture of David Platt to sit alongside his ramblings in the match programme has a sense of foreboding as far as the first half was concerned.

The picture showed the Forest manager looking intently at his watch and long before the referee, Trevor Parkes, blew for the interval most inside the City Ground were doing just that.

It was difficult to believe both sides needed victory to enhance their chances of Premiership football next season. Perhaps they had been struck by a chronic case of play-off paralysis.

Not that the stumbling on the pitch had much to do with the respective managers' off the field planning.

Platt binned the familiar 3-5-2 line-up in favour of a more adventurous 4-4-2 formation while Bolton's Sam Allardyce made five changes to the line-up that, drew with Gillingham 3-3 after leading 3-1.

The changes included giving full debuts to striker Liam Richardson and Andy Campbell, who is on loan from Middlesbrough.

There was Richardson, who with Forest not even firing blanks at the Bolton end, delivered the first shot worthy of the name late in the first period. Put through by Dean Holdsworth, Richardson fired past David Beasant but into the side netting. Holdsworth reprised his role as provider in injury time and this time the Forest keeper got involved.

Earlier he had come yards out of his penalty area to dispossess Holdsworth and this time he produced a similar save to block Kevin Nolan's close range shot.

Thankfully Forest began the second half showing more ambition but they needed the visitors to almost self-destruct before giving Bolton keeper Tommy Wright his first serious action.

Wright was the source of the danger with a short pass to Simon Charlton. The fullback dallied, allowing David Johnson to dispossess him and deliver a low cross to leave Wright to keep out Stern Johns' close range shot.

Within seconds Bolton almost scored themselves when substitute Nicky Summerbee, with his first touch, found Holdsworth at the far post but the striker sent the ball back across goal.

Holdsworth atoned for his profligacy in the 61st minute, finishing a penetrating run by Ricky Gardiner in firing home his 200th career goal.

The visitors put the result beyond doubt in injury time when substitute Gareth Farrelly slid the ball home.
