fields.headline: Manager-less Spurs ease to victory
fields.trailText: George Graham has gone - and the Spurs go marching on.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
George Graham has gone - and the Spurs go marching on.

Tottenham swept to a comfortable victory over an increasingly relegation-haunted Coventry City to banish any doubts that the timing of George Graham's dismissal as manager might upset Spurs' rhythm.

In fact it seems to have had the opposite effect, with Spurs playing some of their best football of the season under caretaker David Pleat as they swept to an easy win thanks to goals from Stefan Iversen, Les Ferdinand and Sergei Rebrov.

With all the brouhaha around White Hart Lane over the sacking of Graham one could almost be forgiven for forgetting an important game was at stake. Coventry are fighting for their lives and Spurs sorely needed of a couple of victories to ease their nerves ahead of the FA Cup semi-final against Arsenal, the game that will make or break their season.

By then Tottenham may have a new manager and the word from supporters outside the ground made Glenn Hoddle the overwhelming favourite to return to the club where he made his name as a player. And still involved at the Lane, ironically, is Pleat, the man who sold Hoddle to Monaco from Spurs during his first spell as manager in 1987.

Pleat, the director of football, kept the team that won impressively in the FA Cup at West Ham last weekend. He was rewarded with a swift response from the players as Spurs rattled up a 2-0 lead inside 33 minutes.

Iverson opened the scoring in the 28th minute, when his near-post flicked header from a Stephen Clemence corner flew into the net via the out-stretched hand of Chris Kirkland, Coventry's teenage goalkeeper.

Kirkland got a firmer touch five minutes later when Iverson thumped in a header from a Clemence free kick but succeeded only in diverting the ball into the path of Ferdinand, who headed in to give Spurs a 2-0 lead.

But it was far from comfortable for Tottenham.

Craig Bellamy caused problems cutting in from Coventry's left wing, sending in a cross which John Hartson just failed to convert in the opening minutes.

Bellamy also had a long-range curling shot tipped away by Neil Sullivan in the Spurs goal, although Kirkland was generally the busier keeper. He was beaten in the opening minutes when Ledley King looped the ball over him but it rebounded off the woodwork. He then made two superb saves in the space of seven minutes to keep out long-range shots from Clemence.

The interval brought no substitutions - except for the referee Graham Poll, failing to reappear because of a hamstring strain and replaced by Paul Taylor.

His first real note was to record Spurs' third goal in the 59th minute with a beautifully taken effort from Sergei Rebrov. The little Ukrainian striker is growing in confidence - helped no end by two masterful goals last weekend - and he hit another beauty here, beating Coventry's attempts to play offside to run on to Ledley King's astute pass, turning calmly and sliding the ball passed Kirkland from an acute angle.

The goal effectively killed Coventry off and put Tottenham in total control, the dominance so much in evidence that German midfielder Steffen Freund almost scored his first goal in two years at the club. He ran on to a perfectly weighted crossfield pass from Clemence and ran in on goal but, not for the first time in his career, managed to miss the target when he really should have scored.

Clemence, who is revelling in a more central midfield role, almost increased the lead in the 68th minute when he met a cross from the equally-impressive King but headed just over the bar.

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan tried to shake things up for this side by using his substitutes, although Youssef Chippo lasted only 14 minutes as a replacement for Thompson before himself being replaced by Marc Edworthy.

Rebrov was full of confidence, just like his strike partner Ferdinand, and Tottenham started to toy with Coventry who had virtually given up the ghost once the third goal went in. Rebrov was chopped down by Coventry defender Gary Breen, which earned the defender a booking, and when Iversen suffered a similar fate on the edge of the penalty area, Rebrov took the free kick himself and fired just wide.

He even tried his luck from long range in the closing minutes by which time it was all over bar the shouting - Spurs' first home win since 2 January, and the points that should finally end any lingering relegation worries.

For Coventry, it looks grim and life in the Nationwide beckons.

fields.headline: Saving slums is less taxing
fields.standfirst: Buy to let and you can benefit from Brown's £1bn boost, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Buy to let and you can benefit from Brown's £1bn boost, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
Aspiring investors in property could benefit from the Chancellor's £1 billion Budget rescue package for run-down areas.

You can take advantage of six tax cuts designed to breathe new life into inner city slums and other disadvantaged places by buying in one of these so-called designated areas.

Experts say they are a particularly good choice for budding private landlords with an eye on the buy-to-let market.

This gives you the potential to generate an income in the short term and capital in the long term as long as the property market, whose growth is now slowing down, holds up.

Along with the introduction of relief for companies cleaning up land comes the abolition of stamp duty on all property transactions in rundown areas, and reduction in VAT from 17.5 per cent to 5 per cent for conversions to residential use.

'This is good news for the development sector,' says David Moulton of London property consultants Knight Frank. He believes it will encourage residential investment into blighted areas.

'If you buy when the market is in a trough and then that market is stimulated, you are in a good position to make money out of your investment,' Moulton believes.

'First-time buyers who have been priced out of the market may want to take advantage of the Chancel lor's plans. Those looking to make a buy-to-let purchase may also wish to do so.'

He says canny homebuyers should find out from their local authority which areas will be targeted by the Government.

The identities of the designated areas are still under wraps, but the scheme could eventually cover 10 per cent of the inner cities.

But not everyone is so positive. David Hollingworth of mortgage broker London & Country warns: 'The stigma of the dubious accolade of a designated urban regeneration area is likely to deter the potential purchaser rather than encourage.' Property values may even fall in the short term, Hollingworth says, adding: 'Let's hope negative equity does not rear its ugly head.' But even Bath-based London & Country admits that you can snap up a bargain in the meantime.

The whole London rental market, especially the top end, is experiencing robust growth, according to figures from estate agent Savills. It predicts that rents will grow by an average of more than 10 per cent this year, outpacing an estimated 7 per cent increase in house prices.

Many savers have turned to investment property as continuing low interest rates provide unattractive returns on more usual savings plans. The Equitable Life saga has added to the trend by cutting savers' confidence in the pensions industry.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders says buy-to-let lending grew by 10 per cent in the last six months of 2000. These loans typically cost 1 per cent above base rate, giving a payable rate of 6.75 per cent, and they are falling as competition intensifies. Sixty-five lenders offer them.

Five-year fixed-rate deals are particularly attractive, says researcher Moneyfacts.

Bank of Ireland and Bristol & West both offer five-year fixed rates at 6.5 per cent, says Hollingworth.

NewWorld, the Australian lender, has just launched a flexible buy-to-let mortgage discounted to 4.95 per cent for six months, after which it is 6.74 per cent. You need a 20 per cent deposit.

Is buy to let the right bet?

Experts agree on the key question to answer when deciding whether buying to let is for you: Could you pay both the loan on an investment home and the mortgage on your own house if you had no rent coming in?

Think long term if you want to make money out of buy to let. 'Getting a deal costs money and so does getting out,' says David Hollingworth of broker London and Country. 'While property has done well, it has not done as well as equities.'

To see how much the property will yield in a year work out your annual rent, subtract the mortgage interest and calculate this total as a percentage of your deposit.

For example, £7,200 rent, minus £6,000 comes to £1,200. On a deposit of £15,000, the yield - or return - will be 8 per cent. The average yield on rental property is currently 8.3 per cent.

Rental income should outstrip mortgage interest payments by between 25 and 50 per cent in most cases. If there is a gap - or 'void period', in the jargon - between tenants you will have to stump up the loan repayments. You can offset the mortgage interest, plus some maintenance costs, against income tax.

Have a big deposit at the ready. If you have only a small one you will effectively be gambling on property prices, and there is no guarantee they will go up.

Looking after a rented property is a responsibility in terms of time and money. You can pay a management agent to do it for you, but the fees can absorb 15 per cent of the rent. Agents do have advantages: they ensure contracts are handled properly, for example.

Remember, it is more difficult to find a mortgage for properties above a shop, says Mark Harris of independent financial adviser Savills Private Finance. Halifax and Woolwich won't lend on these flats, but Royal Bank of Scotland is more flexible. Some lenders will also turn their noses up at student or multiple tenancies.

Be careful where you buy. Some analysts consider the supply of rental properties in central London and central Manchester to be near saturation point. University towns are a safe bet. Look also at places where companies have announced relocations. Talk to local letting agents about rental demand in your chosen area. Obtain a list of agents from the Association of Residential Letting Agents (Arla) on 01923 896555.

Tyne and motion

Sue and John Harrison from Newcastle have caught the buy-to-let bug. They currently have three properties for rent in the city - one on the quayside and two in Jesmond - all of which they have just remortgaged with a Leeds & Holbeck five-year fixed deal at 6.64 per cent through London & Country.

They see the properties as a good long-term investment to be passed on to their four children.

In the short term the Harrisons feel rental income is guaranteed by the fact that the properties are of good quality and in popular areas where the city's young executives (both Nissan and management consultancy Accenture have branches in Newcastle) want to rent.

Any advice for someone thinking of becoming a private landlord? 'Do your research,' says Sue who, besides being a landlady, works part-time at her husband's web engineering firm, Maxsi. 'Some flats look attractive but if they are not in a popular area they will be hard to rent out. Ask a letting agent.'

fields.headline: Sour grapes
fields.standfirst: A nasty row may have broken out between rival wine writers, but most journalists like to keep  their noses clean
fields.trailText: A nasty row may have broken out between rival wine writers, but most journalists like to keep their noses clean.
fields.body:
Years ago, when I was still a baby wine writer, someone tried to bribe me. This being the wine trade, where these things are done with comparative subtlety, there were no Neil Hamilton-style brown-paper bags involved. No one offered to show me the inside of a broom cupboard at Nobu or told me that I should consider spending an all-expenses weekend in the Maldives. All they did was give me a case of wine.

A what, you're probably thinking? He must need one of those like a bullet in the pre-frontal cortex. And you're quite right. As a wine writer, I get sent so many free samples that if I didn't regularly open the boxes that pile up outside my door, The Observer would have to send in the St Bernards before long. There is wine and wine, however, and the point about this particular case was that it was special.

Researching an article on De Luxe Cuvée Champagnes, I'd asked for a sample of a well-known and very expensive fizz. Instead of a bottle, the importer sent me a case. Thinking they'd made a mistake, I called to point out the error. 'We thought you deserved a case,' came the reply. Needless to say, he picked up the remaining 11 bottles the next day.

Why bring this up now? The reason is that ethics, and more specifically conflicts of interest, are the subject of ferocious debate in wine-writing circles at the moment. My counterpart on The Times, Jane MacQuitty, was the first to point the finger, claiming that 'there's a lot of bad plonk out there, but cosy trade deals stop you reading about it'. In particular, she put the steel toecaps into Malcolm Gluck of The Guardian, who has blended a very ordinary wine, Superplonk, which sells in Tesco. The debate has rumbled on for months.

I shall not comment on Ms MacQuitty's allegations other than to say that Mr Gluck is a hard-working and extremely professional hack who takes his job and his readers very seriously. I don't always agree with his palate, but wine is a subjective business and it would be boring if we all recommended the same bottles. I could say the same about some of Ms MacQuitty's choices.

Is British wine writing riddled with corruption? Are there people with their noses in the trough, or possibly spittoon? I honestly believe not, especially if you look at what goes on in producing countries such as France, Spain, Italy, Portugal and even Australia, where hacks are expected to cheer for the home team. The diverse origins of the wines we see in the UK means that we are free to speak our minds.

I won't deny that we lead enviable lives: free trips, nice hotels, good food and wine. No wonder a producer friend of mine says he believes in reincarnation and wants to come back as a wine hack next time. Does this influence what we write? As far as I'm concerned, it does not, never has done and never will do. But, as Mandy Rice-Davis once put it, I would say that, wouldn't I?

The only test of a wine writer's integrity is the bottles that he or she recommends from the thousands tasted each year. That and the tone and subject matter covered in their columns. If you don't like what I tell you to drink, I hope you'll let me know. As Americans like to say, I'd like to think we have a relationship going here.

Best cellars: Five wines that won't let you down at a dinner party

1998 Landskroon Shiraz, Paarl (£6.49, Safeway).
The quality of the red wines emerging from South Africa never ceases to surprise me. Gone are the baked, rather unyielding flavours of the past, to be replaced by something softer and more appealing. This peppery, blackberry and cherry-fruity, winningly oaked Shiraz is a brilliant buy at under £6.50.

1998 Yalumba Bush Vine Grenache, Barossa Valley (£7.99, Thresher, Victoria Wine, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up).
Old bush vine Grenache is one of Australia's great secrets. Just plunge your nostrils into this broad, richly fruity, violet-scented red, with its flavours of raspberries, wild strawberries and sweet oak and you'll see what I mean. A wine that puts a smile on your face and sends you skipping out into the street.

2000 Palliser Estate Sauvignon Blanc (£9.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up).
A Martinborough Sauvignon Blanc that is always among the best in New Zealand, this ripe, full-bodied, guava, gooseberry and passion-fruity white has real intensity, poise and class. One of the white wines of the vintage in the North Island, this would be perfect with sea bass or monkfish.

1996 Palacio de Otazu, Navarra Reserva (£9.99, Waitrose).
The prices of the best Riojas have got so silly of late that people are beginning to look to neighbouring Navarra for alternatives. If so, this stylish, oak-aged, vanilla and cassis-style blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and a little Tempranillo really delivers the goods. Like a cross between a Rioja and a fine Bordeaux.

1998 San Fereolo, Dolcetto di Dogliani (£8.99, Oddbins).
Dolcetto is sometimes regarded as an inferior grape in the Piedmont region. This example, produced from low-yielding old vines in the commune of Dogliani is a dark, comparatively well-structured red with layers of plum, black cherry and damson fruit and firmish tannins. Great with cheese or a stew.

fields.headline: Facts of narcotic life
fields.trailText: Britain's drug culture
fields.body:
There were 152,000 drug seizures in Britain in 1998

The average hit of heroin costs £10

Well over half of theft is drug-related; the market value of goods stolen is estimated at more than £2 billion each year

Half a million 16 to 24-year-olds (8 per cent) have used Class A drugs

More than a quarter of people aged 16-24 use cannabis

Amphetamine is the most impure illegal drug. It is often cut with sugar, vitamin C, chalk or talcum powder

Crack costs £20-£25 for a rock the size of raisin. It may have slivers cut from it which are sold for about £10

Valium pills can be bought on the street for 50p. Glasgow dealers spraypaint the cheaper 'whites' to resemble the stronger 'blues'

Drugs are a factor in 18 per cent of violent incidents

Seizures involving heroin almost doubled between 1996 and 1998

(Sources: Office of National Statistics, Drugscope)

fields.headline: The deal thing
fields.standfirst: Drew, a black Londoner aged 34, deals cocain to a select clientele of celebrities, musicians and executives - all with as much to lose as himself
fields.trailText: Drew, a black Londoner aged 34, deals cocain to a select clientele of celebrities, musicians and executives - all with as much to lose as himself. Tony Thompson hears his story.
fields.body:
'I guess you could say I've reinvented myself. I used to deal to pretty much anyone who wanted it. My mobile would go off, I'd take an address and head straight over. That was when I was dealing mostly weed and just a little bit of coke. But then the demand for coke just exploded. That's what this game is all about at the end of the day. Supply and demand.

'I say I've reinvented myself because I deliberately went after a certain type of customer. The people I deal to now - they all have something to lose. There are a couple of well-known actors, a few musicians and lots of people in serious, big-money jobs. Lawyers, City types, that sort of thing.

'I feel safer now than I ever did before. You have to be a good actor. People feel most comfortable buying from people who they think are exactly like them. They want to know you understand what they are doing and why and that you are making the same sacrifices, taking the same risks. They want to know that if you get careless, you have as much to lose as they do.

'I started out as a user. Nothing heavy, just a couple of lines now and then. I was into music too and knew people who are now starting to make it big. But my roots were pretty rough so when people wanted stuff, it always seemed to be me who ended up getting it. It grew from there. Now I hardly use at all. Maybe if I'm out working all night, I'll have a line to keep myself sharp but you have to be careful. There's enough to worry about without making yourself paranoid.

'The most difficult thing is when you step up the ladder and start buying larger amounts. You have to start dealing with people who you really don't want to mix with. Scary people. The only way you can get through it is to remind yourself that they need you. People like that, they've got no social skills, they have got no way of getting through to the people who actually use the stuff. They are way too frightening to mix in those sort of circles. But at the same time, they want you to go to them so they can check you out. It honestly scares the shit out of me every time.

'Once there was this Irish guy, a big, big dealer. He took me into his office and there was just piles and piles of cocaine on a table. The guy had obviously been snorting a lot himself, celebrating the arrival of the shipment. He was in that state where he could have turned totally paranoid at any moment. And while I'm looking round, I notice there's a gun on his desk. My insides fell apart at that moment. Then the guy took me to one side and said, 'If you want anything, just ask. If anyone ever messes with you, just tell us and we'll eliminate them.' Heavy shit.

'I always pay upfront. A lot of dealers like to give you stuff on credit but I always pay in full and I never give my customers credit. The police love to bust people who owe money. They know that the pressure is on and that to save themselves they are going to have to grass someone up. Getting caught is bad news. Either way you are fucked. If, somehow, you manage to get off or you only get a short sentence, then everyone thinks you are a grass anyway, no one is going to touch you again.

'The truth is you can't stop. It's not about the money. How much is enough? That's a question that doesn't have an answer. The problem is the longer you do this, the more information you accumulate. You know things about the people above you, the people below you and the people you sell to. That whole chain is only secure when no one tries to break out. The only thing that stops anyone grassing you up is the fact that they are at it too. No one is going to stay friends with someone who used to deal. If I stopped, even if I had some other way of making money, I'd lose everything else. I'd be an outcast.

'It's not perfect. You get some dealers who make it sound like it's the best job in the world - full of glamour - but that's a load of bollocks. It's like being a flight attendant. Yeah, you get to travel round the world and stay in fantastic hotels, but at the end of the day, you are nothing more than a fucking waitress. It's the same for me. Yeah, I get to go to the best parties, meet cool people and I have more money than I know what to do with, but at the end of the day I'm just a delivery boy. People invite me to parties because they want to know there will be some good drugs there. People don't call me up to chat or find out how I am, they call me up because they want something. And if I don't get off my arse and get it to them, they go somewhere else.

'Then you've got the constant worry that it might all come to an end. Don't get me wrong - I'm happy, I've got no complaints. IÍm not knocking it. I'm just saying that it's a job. It's not like being on holiday all the time: it's work. I donÍt take shit from anyone and I'm my own boss, but I still have to work really hard.'

(Author's note: Drew is not his real name).

fields.headline: Facts of school life
fields.trailText: Education in Britain.
fields.body:
92 per cent of pupils go to state schools, 7 per cent attend independents and 1 per cent go to maintained or non-maintained special schools

Private school students are 30 times more likely to get into a top university than someone from a less advantaged background; 47 per cent of Cambridge places go to private pupils

86,000 parents lodged appeals against non-admission of their children to desired schools in 1998-99

10,400 children were permanently excluded from school in 1998-99

The most frequently studied subjects at A-level/Higher are English, general studies, maths and biological sciences. Home economics is the least popular

Nine half-days are missed per pupil in primary school on average each year; 18 days in secondary comprehensives.

Only 10 per cent of pupils who have been persistent truants in year 11 are in full-time education at 18

350,000 pupils under 16 have a mobile phone, although they are banned from using them at school except in emergencies

The average class has 27 pupils in English primary and secondary schools

8.7 per cent of primary school pupils have English as an additional (i.e non-native) language

3 per cent of all pupils have statements of special education needs: 60 per cent are sent to state maintained schools, 35 per cent to special schools, and 5 per cent are in independent schools

Ethnic minorities make up 11 per cent of pupils in maintained schools

Bangladeshi, black and Pakistani pupils perform worse than others all through compulsory education, but a higher percentage choose to stay in fulltime education, 85 per cent compared with 67 per cent of white pupils

1.07 million free school meals were consumed last year

Under one-third of white boys with parents in manual occupations achieve five or more GCSE grades A-C, compared with the average of half for all white pupils. Fewer than a quarter of black boys gain five high-grade GCSEs

Two-fifths of 18-year-olds are in full-time education

Britain has 88 universities, 58 other higher education institutions and 516 further education colleges

Last year 53 per cent of women got first-class or upper-second degrees, compared with 46 per cent of men

(Sources: Philips, Youth Cohort Study, Higher Education Statistics Agency, Department for Education and Employment, Office of National Statistics)

fields.headline: Class divide
fields.standfirst: Dulwich College is the biggest independent school in Britain; nearby Kingsdale School is a comprehensive due for a 7.5 million pound revamp after a damning Ofsted report.
fields.trailText: Sarah Helm examines, from the inside, two schools that stand yards apart but occupy different worlds. Is the gap between state and private one of attitude or money? What - if anything - do they share?
fields.body:
It's a drizzly Monday morning. Joseph Clarke slams the door of his parents' suburban home near Croydon, heading down the road, anorak over blazer, rucksack on his back, to catch his coach to school.

An hour later the coach turns into College Road, Dulwich, and lines up with four-wheel drives waiting for the barrier to lift so they can deposit boys in front of the vast terracotta pile of Dulwich College. Past the rollers on the playing fields, other boys troop across from boarding houses. A master in a gown is standing waiting to shepherd boys across the road, pausing to smile at mothers in Burberry macs who are hauling violins out of boots. Joseph now streams off with the others into the school cloisters where Ernest Shackleton's boat is on display, and, putting his rucksack into his locker, he pulls his chair up under his desk and awaits morning roll.

The P13 bus also carries boys into school and it too stops outside the Dulwich College gates, though the schoolchildren on the P13 don't get out here. Most don't even glance out of the window. Kenneth During comes this way from his home in Peckham, but doesn't notice the Dulwich boys as he prepares instead to descend a short distance further on. Then walking up beside the railway tracks, Kenneth turns through a gap in the railings, where a sign, half-obscured by graffiti, says Kingsdale School. The prefab blocks are patrolled by 'inclusion officers' in navy uniforms, and CCTV cameras are positioned over dank stairwells. Boys are kicking footballs around on the patches of concrete. The children here have no form rooms to go to while they wait for classes; no desks to call their own. Not even a locker to store belongings - Kenneth will heave his rucksack around with him all day.

Nowhere is Britain's educational divide drawn more starkly than in this London suburb. The biggest independent school in the country, which selects boys from the brightest 20 per cent and spends almost £8,000 a year on each pupil, sits alongside a state school which takes anyone who turns up and spends £2,000 a year on its pupils. Dulwich College ensures that 95 per cent of its pupils get A-C passes at GCSE and sends 95 per cent of sixth-formers to top universities - 12 or so pupils go to Oxbridge each year. Kingsdale gets 15 per cent of its pupils through GCSE with five A-C grades and doesn't know how many go to university as it has no sixth form. One school takes up two columns in the top schools guide, the other is still recovering from an Ofsted ruling three years ago that it was 'failing'.

In affluent Dulwich, where private education flourishes on the edge of one of London's poorest boroughs, the contrast here is not just between these neighbouring schools, but between two groups of teenagers living in entirely different worlds. They hardly ever meet. Their timetables are even staggered to try and keep them apart in case the meetings are violent.

The school day is about to begin. In the Dulwich College drama school a small group of 12-year-old Prosperos and Calibans are sitting in a circle, considering this question: 'Will educating Caliban make him a happier person?'

The college educates a dozen or so poor boys in any one year by offering bursaries to bright state-school pupils - a tradition going back to the college's foundation by Elizabethan actor-manager Edward Alleyn as a school for 'twelve poor scholars'. Dulwich old boy Sir Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, went there on a bursary.

In a religious education class, 13-year-olds are talking about the meaning of the word incarnation and wondering: 'Why does a good God allow suffering?' Small hands, white, black and brown, shoot up; 30 per cent of the college intake is from ethnic minorities. So Graham Able, master of the college, can present the Dulwich as a school with a social conscience, and certainly not the white man's ghetto that it used to be in Shackleton's day. 'It reflects the racial mix of London,' he says. Indeed listening to Able (Worksop and Cambridge) sitting in his study under the campanile, one could almost dream that this is a model of egalitarianism. And, momentarily, Peckham seems a million miles away.

Until recently, Dulwich College boys and staff were unlikely to come across pupils from its neighbouring state school. The Kingsdale intake was traditionally from the west of the borough and from Lambeth, which meant there was no need for children arriving at its gates to come past the college to its east. Then, another comprehensive, Dulwich High School, with a large intake from Peckham to the north-east, was closed. Its boys were sent to Kingsdale, and to get there they had to pass close to Dulwich College.

Mixing the rival Peckham boys with Brixton boys not only brought gang friction into Kingsdale, it also brought clashes with the private-school kids. Those who hadn't noticed Kingsdale before now began to see it as a place to fear. 'They just see us as privileged rich toffs and they hate us. We see them as mostly black, mostly petty criminals,' says one Dulwich boy.

'They are just as likely to be the trouble-makers,' says Steven Morrison, headteacher at Kingsdale, who sits in front of a CCTV camera trained on his car. 'We get calls from shopkeepers complaining about our boys and it's often them. They take their ties off and look just the same.' His view is supported by pupil Kenneth. 'They wear the same uniform as us. People mix us up. If there's trouble, people would rather blame us,' he says.

It is mid-morning at Kingsdale School and a Tannoy blares out into the music room and the drama block as well as every class and every examination room, telling children missing from an exam to hurry there. Mary Graham, head of music here for 28 years, has been rehearsing pupils for a concert of soul music in memory of Damilola Taylor, the primary schoolboy murdered last November on the North Peckham estate. Her stars will all be there. Kenneth, 15, has reached grade six on the trumpet in only three years.

Graham has high hopes of her pupils who are taking GCSEs this year. Some years 100 per cent have got A-C grades in music. The school has steel bands, soul bands, jazz bands, a guitar ensemble and a percussion ensemble.

In the teaching block, four new boys who have arrived at the school from countries in Africa are being assigned to special English lessons. Three weeks into the term, and with only 15 weeks to go before the exams, these boys will be placed in GCSE classes. As many as 400 pupils, many refugees and many without English as a first language, join classes at Kingsdale midway through a term. Omar, just arrived from Sierra Leone, prefers to speak in French. He came here because of 'la guerre'. Currently the school has 40 Kosovan refugees. 'They want to stay and finish their education here rather than return home,' says Devon Hanson, a head of year at Kingsdale, with pride.

The new boys chat to each other about the school. The toilets are 'odorous' says one. Some of the pupils are 'very rude' says another. 'I feel sorry for the teachers. The pupils would not be able to behave like that in my country.' But the boys, in crisp, white shirts and new ties, are eager and listen for words of encouragement. Behind Hanson's desk is a diagram showing staff how they should motivate pupils and raise achievement. Nearby is a poem about self-esteem and a poster of Martin Luther King. 'You will not get eight or nine GCSEs but you will get some. It will not be easy but it can be done,' says Hanson.

Tunde Jussef, a school prefect whose family came to the UK from Nigeria when he was two, has come to guide the new boys on to their next class. 'Here is a boy who has done well,' says Hanson. 'We would never have thought you would be doing five GCSEs when you arrived.' Hanson, a Jamaican, says that teachers in state schools have to know their subject and be able to motivate kids who are not motivated because of the failure all around them. 'These are kids who might have been woken up by the police banging at the flat next door to ask about the murder,' he says, referring to the Damilola case.

'It is not the teachers who have low expectations of these children but the system itself,' he adds. 'There is pressure on us to push these kids to vocational exams, not A-levels. Ask Dulwich College how many vocational exams their children do?' I do, and Able says: 'None.' In fact, he would clearly rather not have to bother his boys with GCSEs. 'A lot of mundane material. Not inspirational. Here, we are educating boys towards A-level from the moment they arrive.'

Able says his teachers are from a 'different pool'. They have 'tremendous admiration' for colleagues in the state-school sector but they do a different job. At Dulwich there is an enthusiasm for know'edge but in some inner-city state schools children don't want to learn, he says. ïIf academic standards are not seen to be important by the pupils or the parent body there may be an ethos against learning in the playground.'

When Kingsdale opened in 1958 the school was hailed as one of London's new utopian comprehensives where children of all abilities would learn, and where 'nobody would be allowed to feel a failure'. Pastoral care was to be administered through a system of houses and form teachers. Three decades later every pupil in the same school was made to feel a failure thanks to Ofsted, which in 1998 paraded Kingsdale as a failing school, putting it on 'special measures' - a euphemism for collective punishment.

But Kingsdale had failed to achieve the impossible. A school designed to take the 'full range of ability' in order that pupils could learn from their peers - the driving idea behind the comprehensive - found that by the Eighties it was taking only pupils from the poorest, most disadvantaged homes. The school became known as a recruiting ground for local gangs: the Brixton Boys, the Dulwich Crew and, more lately, the YPB (Young Peckham Boys). Middle-class parents fled from the school en masse. Girls simply stopped coming (boys now outnumber girls by four to one).

Soon the only parents who 'selected' Kingsdale were those whose children had either been excluded from all other schools or parents who lived near schools whose reputations they thought were worse. They include Abbey and Ola Jussef, Tunde's parents, who live on the edge of the North Peckham estate. 'I didn't want my son to go to the schools near here,' says Abbey, who works as a catering manager at Ofsted's London offices. She says the inspectors she met at work advised her to send her son to Kingsdale. 'It is a very good school. I want the very best for Tunde. I even bought him a computer,' she says.

So whose fault was Kingsdale's 'failure'? The fault of governments for failing to see the very special needs of inner-city schools; for luring away the brighter kids with assisted places and other better choices? The fault of the media for sensationalising the fights, the knives, the CS gas? The fault of the LEA who sold off playing fields, decapitated the school by removing its sixth form, and then dumped upon it an entire cohort of disadvantaged boys - 150 of them - salvaged from the wreck of another 'failing' school, Dulwich High?

Or was it the fault of kids such as Dom (excluded from Kingsdale for fighting); Sue (excluded and pregnant at 14); or Carl (excluded for assaulting a teacher). Carl could have told Ofsted a lot about failure. Excluded from one school after putting another boy's face through a car windscreen for being rude about his mother, he went to Dulwich High, where he started to settle well. 'I was good there. I was good at geography.' But then the school was closed and he was moved on with the rest of his friends to Kingsdale. One day, he says, a teacher asked him to take his hat off. He was angry and beat the teacher. 'That's one thing I regret,' says Carl. 'That teacher - he never recovered.'

'Carl is doing well now,' says Camilla Batmanjehda, of Kids Company, a centre where the 16-year-old has been given therapeutic help and intensive teaching. 'The schools don't know what to do with children like this. They are treated like a herd and they react against it.'

Sitting now in a Burberry sweatshirt, Carl remembers how the Dulwich locals used to cross over the street when they saw 'us black boys - us Peckham boys'. And he remembers once straying down an alley and looking through a line of trees towards another school close to his. ïIt was big, yeah, as big as you can imagine. Lots of grass and trees all over. Massive, that building was. I used to go and stare at the girls there. They used to come out at lunchtime and sit under the trees. They talked to me sometimes. We got along OK. I liked going there.'

Carl had stumbled over the boundary of James Allens Girls' School (JAGS) another jewel in Dulwich's private school crown.

Now the classes at Kingsdale are breaking up for lunch and pupils are thundering out of doors, down corridors so narrow their sides can be touched by outstretched teenage arms. In the dining hall some will eat standing as there are not enough seats for all.

Dulwich College has three dining rooms and today the menus are: chicken chasseur, beef goulash with stuffed peppers or lamb rogan josh. At the high table are Charlie, Adam, Imre, Dipesh, Simon, Russell and Joseph. Most are prefects and wear striped blazers, showing they have their school colours. All are going to university, several to Oxford or Cambridge. Joseph hopes to read maths at Trinity Hall.

All the boys say they are proud to be here and would never have achieved half as much if they had gone to state schools. 'It's the people you meet as much as anything,' says Charlie Butcher, captain of rugby.

Do they meet state-school kids ever? 'No.' Do they play sport against Kingsdale? 'No.' Do they play any music together, share facilities or teachers? Not that they know of. But there is no 'class division' say the boys. 'We may be a public school but we are all south Londoners.' Muggings have usually been over mobile phones - not about who is at what school, says their headmaster.

Asked about the violence, however, the boys seem uncomfortable. Charlie says a friend was recently stabbed. Imre, captain of hockey and cricket, was attacked. 'It was my own fault, I had not covered up my colours,' he says. And younger boys had been picked on when they were out alone, they say. Things have been better since CCTV was installed at the stations but they have had to stop using the one at Sydenham Hill. The boys largely stay on the school premises at lunch break. They have their own 'commissariat' where they can get their mobile phone top-ups, and they can read newspapers or play chess in the Wodehouse library, where Bertie Wooster himself might have made himself at home, reading the papers in an armchair.

Joseph, who plays clarinet and saxophone and runs his own barber-shop choir, rehearses at lunchtime in the music school. 'I am very proud to be here. My parents have given up a lot. No foreign holidays. We don't get what some other kids get. They could only afford to buy us a computer last year.'

Ian Clarke, Joseph's father, says there was no going back to 'bog-standard comprehensives' once he had seen what the private schools had to offer. 'We remortgaged the house,' says Clarke, an actuary with an insurance company. He read maths at Oxford. Both he and his wife, Caroline, went to grammar schools and educated their first two children in the state system, but a third son, a talented child, needed extra attention. Sitting in their small front room dominated by a piano and the complete Encyclopaedia Britannica, they relive the moment they first saw a private school. 'It was incredible. You can't believe it at first. It's another world,' says Caroline. 'I think it's the way they value every child. Everyone is included somehow - even if they are not very good at something, they encourage them to do it. Joseph got into the fourth rugby team. We thought he was no good at French but he got an A-star.'

Kingsdale's library is at the top of concrete steps, daubed with red arrows, directing pupils up and down. Morrison introduced the arrows - and the lines along the corridors - to stop pupils crashing into one another, which has helped restore discipline. 'How can children be expected to be civilised when the building itself encourages poor behaviour,' he asks. 'When there are six different options for getting from A to B; when there are 10 entrances and exits; when there are four classroom doors within the space of 50 feet opening onto 5ft-wide corridors; when you canÍt hear what anyone says because there's no sound-proofing?' When, as a headteacher, you have to spend time drawing lines on the floor, he might have added. Morrison took over as head after the Ofsted report and has already improved results, leading to the removal of 'special measures'. But he, along with everyone else here, is still smarting from the criticism. Outside Morrison's office an honours board for the brightest and the best is tucked away next to dusty trophies from years ago and a faded certificate for food hygiene from Southwark Council.

But here are the brightest and the best now, around the table in the library: Guyson, Wendy, Alex, Freedom, Nicola, Bemmy, Kenneth and Tunde, all talking of a brighter, better future. Bemmy and Nicola have even taken GCSEs early, and passed with As and Bs. 'The school is improving all the time. I am proud to be here,' says Guyson, who is taking a lead part in a forthcoming production of Grease. 'You hear them talking in the streets about us. Everyone says it. They think the children get bullied here. But that's just a stereotype. They don't know what goes on here at all.'

The school has things to boast about. Its football team won the London cup three years ago. It has produced singers such as Karen Wheeler of Soul II Soul and jazz vocalist Gail Thomson. Do the teenagers know anyone from Dulwich College? Nicola says she once knew a boy who went there. 'He told me how they used to stick up a finger when they saw Kingsdale kids just to provoke us,' and she demonstrates. ïIt was their laugh of the day,' she says, bitterly. But mostly they donÍt draw comparison with their neighbours: 'The only difference I can see between what they have and we have is the money - they have the money.'

Guyson says: 'There is no difference. We have the same standards, the same talent to follow it through.' The pupils are all going on to sixth-form college. Some will do A-levels - computer studies, graphic design, media studies are mentioned. Some will do vocational exams. Tunde is going to college to do a BTEC in media studies - if he gets five GCSEs above grade C. Then, he says, he will go to university. He has a talent for graphics. The teenagers at Kingsdale have another reason to look forward. The school is about to undergo a £7.5 million redesign. It is an experimental project, which could be a model for other schools. Architects and anthropologists have drawn up plans which will end what they describe as the culture of 'custodial containment' making it a 'hub of learning' in the community.

Classrooms will be rearranged to promote rather than hinder learning. 'Does maths have to be taught in a classroom at all?' asks one of the planners, who have thought of everything from bright toilet paper to a new house system, ensuring better pastoral care.

There are those in the LEA who believe a revamped Kingsdale might one day compete with Dulwich College for pupils. The children themselves ask less from the new make-over. Just new chairs would be good, says Guyson 'so my knees don't bang into the desk'. They would like somewhere to meet and relax and more room to eat. 'Lockers,' says Tunde.

But not everyone is as optimistic for KingsdaleÍs future as the school planners. Even as the redesign gets under way, Southwark LEA has found a new way of depriving Kingsdale of a more balanced intake. Close by, a different kind of 'model school', known as the Charter School, has been opened. The Charter School was once known as Dulwich High School (which was once known as William Penn). Not only has Dulwich High been redesigned and given a new name, it has also been given a brand new set of hand-picked children, and is already hoovering up the privileged middle-class kids who might go to state schools. At Dulwich College, Able looks bemused by the suggestion that he may face competition from the state sector: he is looking forward next year to his biggest ever intake into the school. 'It is simply not possible to provide the education we offer with the money the state currently provides in the maintained sector.'

It is the end of the school day and the coaches are lining up again to take college pupils home. Kingsdale pupils have already left. There have been occasional glimmers of real interest in each other's worlds. 'What did they say about us?' asks Morrison. And occasional glimmers of understanding. 'Talent can always be brought out,' says Able.

'It is not the teachers who have low expectations of these children but the system itself,' he adds. 'There is pressure on us to push these kids to vocational exams, not A-levels. Ask Dulwich College how many vocational exams their children do?' I do, and Able says: 'None.' In fact, he would clearly rather not have to bother his boys with GCSEs. 'A lot of mundane material. Not inspirational. Here, we are educating boys towards A-level from the moment they arrive.' Able says his teachers are from a 'different pool'. They have 'tremendous admiration' for colleagues in the state-school sector but they do a different job. At Dulwich there is an enthusiasm for know'edge but in some inner-city state schools children don't want to learn, he says. ïIf academic standards are not seen to be important by the pupils or the parent body there may be an ethos against learning in the playground.' When Kingsdale opened in 1958 the school was hailed as one of London's new utopian comprehensives where children of all abilities would learn, and where 'nobody would be allowed to feel a failure'. Pastoral care was to be administered through a system of houses and form teachers. Three decades later every pupil in the same school was made to feel a failure thanks to Ofsted, which in 1998 paraded Kingsdale as a failing school, putting it on 'special measures' - a euphemism for collective punishment. But Kingsdale had failed to achieve the impossible. A school designed to take the 'full range of ability' in order that pupils could learn from their peers - the driving idea behind the comprehensive - found that by the Eighties it was taking only pupils from the poorest, most disadvantaged homes. The school became known as a recruiting ground for local gangs: the Brixton Boys, the Dulwich Crew and, more lately, the YPB (Young Peckham Boys). Middle-class parents fled from the school en masse. Girls simply stopped coming (boys now outnumber girls by four to one). Soon the only parents who 'selected' Kingsdale were those whose children had either been excluded from all other schools or parents who lived near schools whose reputations they thought were worse. They include Abbey and Ola Jussef, Tunde's parents, who live on the edge of the North Peckham estate. 'I didn't want my son to go to the schools near here,' says Abbey, who works as a catering manager at Ofsted's London offices. She says the inspectors she met at work advised her to send her son to Kingsdale. 'It is a very good school. I want the very best for Tunde. I even bought him a computer,' she says. So whose fault was Kingsdale's 'failure'? The fault of governments for failing to see the very special needs of inner-city schools; for luring away the brighter kids with assisted places and other better choices? The fault of the media for sensationalising the fights, the knives, the CS gas? The fault of the LEA who sold off playing fields, decapitated the school by removing its sixth form, and then dumped upon it an entire cohort of disadvantaged boys - 150 of them - salvaged from the wreck of another 'failing' school, Dulwich High? Or was it the fault of kids such as Dom (excluded from Kingsdale for fighting); Sue (excluded and pregnant at 14); or Carl (excluded for assaulting a teacher). Carl could have told Ofsted a lot about failure. Excluded from one school after putting another boy's face through a car windscreen for being rude about his mother, he went to Dulwich High, where he started to settle well. 'I was good there. I was good at geography.' But then the school was closed and he was moved on with the rest of his friends to Kingsdale. One day, he says, a teacher asked him to take his hat off. He was angry and beat the teacher. 'That's one thing I regret,' says Carl. 'That teacher - he never recovered.' 'Carl is doing well now,' says Camilla Batmanjehda, of Kids Company, a centre where the 16-year-old has been given therapeutic help and intensive teaching. 'The schools don't know what to do with children like this. They are treated like a herd and they react against it.' Sitting now in a Burberry sweatshirt, Carl remembers how the Dulwich locals used to cross over the street when they saw 'us black boys - us Peckham boys'. And he remembers once straying down an alley and looking through a line of trees towards another school close to his. ïIt was big, yeah, as big as you can imagine. Lots of grass and trees all over. Massive, that building was. I used to go and stare at the girls there. They used to come out at lunchtime and sit under the trees. They talked to me sometimes. We got along OK. I liked going there.' Carl had stumbled over the boundary of James Allens Girls' School (JAGS) another jewel in Dulwich's private school crown. Now the classes at Kingsdale are breaking up for lunch and pupils are thundering out of doors, down corridors so narrow their sides can be touched by outstretched teenage arms. In the dining hall some will eat standing as there are not enough seats for all. Dulwich College has three dining rooms and today the menus are: chicken chasseur, beef goulash with stuffed peppers or lamb rogan josh. At the high table are Charlie, Adam, Imre, Dipesh, Simon, Russell and Joseph. Most are prefects and wear striped blazers, showing they have their school colours. All are going to university, several to Oxford or Cambridge. Joseph hopes to read maths at Trinity Hall. All the boys say they are proud to be here and would never have achieved half as much if they had gone to state schools. 'It's the people you meet as much as anything,' says Charlie Butcher, captain of rugby. Do they meet state-school kids ever? 'No.' Do they play sport against Kingsdale? 'No.' Do they play any music together, share facilities or teachers? Not that they know of. But there is no 'class division' say the boys. 'We may be a public school but we are all south Londoners.' Muggings have usually been over mobile phones - not about who is at what school, says their headmaster. Asked about the violence, however, the boys seem uncomfortable. Charlie says a friend was recently stabbed. Imre, captain of hockey and cricket, was attacked. 'It was my own fault, I had not covered up my colours,' he says. And younger boys had been picked on when they were out alone, they say. Things have been better since CCTV was installed at the stations but they have had to stop using the one at Sydenham Hill. The boys largely stay on the school premises at lunch break. They have their own 'commissariat' where they can get their mobile phone top-ups, and they can read newspapers or play chess in the Wodehouse library, where Bertie Wooster himself might have made himself at home, reading the papers in an armchair. Joseph, who plays clarinet and saxophone and runs his own barber-shop choir, rehearses at lunchtime in the music school. 'I am very proud to be here. My parents have given up a lot. No foreign holidays. We don't get what some other kids get. They could only afford to buy us a computer last year.' Ian Clarke, Joseph's father, says there was no going back to 'bog-standard comprehensives' once he had seen what the private schools had to offer. 'We remortgaged the house,' says Clarke, an actuary with an insurance company. He read maths at Oxford. Both he and his wife, Caroline, went to grammar schools and educated their first two children in the state system, but a third son, a talented child, needed extra attention. Sitting in their small front room dominated by a piano and the complete Encyclopaedia Britannica, they relive the moment they first saw a private school. 'It was incredible. You can't believe it at first. It's another world,' says Caroline. 'I think it's the way they value every child. Everyone is included somehow - even if they are not very good at something, they encourage them to do it. Joseph got into the fourth rugby team. We thought he was no good at French but he got an A-star.' Kingsdale's library is at the top of concrete steps, daubed with red arrows, directing pupils up and down. Morrison introduced the arrows - and the lines along the corridors - to stop pupils crashing into one another, which has helped restore discipline. 'How can children be expected to be civilised when the building itself encourages poor behaviour,' he asks. 'When there are six different options for getting from A to B; when there are 10 entrances and exits; when there are four classroom doors within the space of 50 feet opening onto 5ft-wide corridors; when you canÍt hear what anyone says because there's no sound-proofing?' When, as a headteacher, you have to spend time drawing lines on the floor, he might have added. Morrison took over as head after the Ofsted report and has already improved results, leading to the removal of 'special measures'. But he, along with everyone else here, is still smarting from the criticism. Outside Morrison's office an honours board for the brightest and the best is tucked away next to dusty trophies from years ago and a faded certificate for food hygiene from Southwark Council. But here are the brightest and the best now, around the table in the library: Guyson, Wendy, Alex, Freedom, Nicola, Bemmy, Kenneth and Tunde, all talking of a brighter, better future. Bemmy and Nicola have even taken GCSEs early, and passed with As and Bs. 'The school is improving all the time. I am proud to be here,' says Guyson, who is taking a lead part in a forthcoming production of Grease. 'You hear them talking in the streets about us. Everyone says it. They think the children get bullied here. But that's just a stereotype. They don't know what goes on here at all.' The school has things to boast about. Its football team won the London cup three years ago. It has produced singers such as Karen Wheeler of Soul II Soul and jazz vocalist Gail Thomson. Do the teenagers know anyone from Dulwich College? Nicola says she once knew a boy who went there. 'He told me how they used to stick up a finger when they saw Kingsdale kids just to provoke us,' and she demonstrates. ïIt was their laugh of the day,' she says, bitterly. But mostly they donÍt draw comparison with their neighbours: 'The only difference I can see between what they have and we have is the money - they have the money.' Guyson says: 'There is no difference. We have the same standards, the same talent to follow it through.' The pupils are all going on to sixth-form college. Some will do A-levels - computer studies, graphic design, media studies are mentioned. Some will do vocational exams. Tunde is going to college to do a BTEC in media studies - if he gets five GCSEs above grade C. Then, he says, he will go to university. He has a talent for graphics. The teenagers at Kingsdale have another reason to look forward. The school is about to undergo a £7.5 million redesign. It is an experimental project, which could be a model for other schools. Architects and anthropologists have drawn up plans which will end what they describe as the culture of 'custodial containment' making it a 'hub of learning' in the community. Classrooms will be rearranged to promote rather than hinder learning. 'Does maths have to be taught in a classroom at all?' asks one of the planners, who have thought of everything from bright toilet paper to a new house system, ensuring better pastoral care. There are those in the LEA who believe a revamped Kingsdale might one day compete with Dulwich College for pupils. The children themselves ask less from the new make-over. Just new chairs would be good, says Guyson 'so my knees don't bang into the desk'. They would like somewhere to meet and relax and more room to eat. 'Lockers,' says Tunde. But not everyone is as optimistic for KingsdaleÍs future as the school planners. Even as the redesign gets under way, Southwark LEA has found a new way of depriving Kingsdale of a more balanced intake. Close by, a different kind of 'model school', known as the Charter School, has been opened. The Charter School was once known as Dulwich High School (which was once known as William Penn). Not only has Dulwich High been redesigned and given a new name, it has also been given a brand new set of hand-picked children, and is already hoovering up the privileged middle-class kids who might go to state schools. At Dulwich College, Able looks bemused by the suggestion that he may face competition from the state sector: he is looking forward next year to his biggest ever intake into the school. 'It is simply not possible to provide the education we offer with the money the state currently provides in the maintained sector.' It is the end of the school day and the coaches are lining up again to take college pupils home. Kingsdale pupils have already left. There have been occasional glimmers of real interest in each other's worlds. 'What did they say about us?' asks Morrison. And occasional glimmers of understanding. 'Talent can always be brought out,' says Able.

fields.headline: Aurora, London W1
fields.standfirst: There are two Aurora restaurants in London. One is intimate, friendly and unpretentious; the other is part of the Conran empire. Guess which Jay Rayner prefers?
fields.trailText: There are two Aurora restaurants in London. One is intimate, friendly and unpretentious; the other is part of the Conran empire. Guess which Jay Rayner prefers?
fields.body:
Telephone: 020 7494 0514
Address: Aurora, 49 Lexington Street, London W1
Dinner for two, including wine and service, £70.

It is very easy to sneer at the restaurant operation of Sir Terence Conran; that doesn't necessarily mean it's wrong to do so. There is something so very mediocre and unfulfilling about the 11-strong group that depresses both the soul and the wallet. There is only one star among them, the Orrery, which holds a Michelin star. The rest, almost without exception, represent a victory of form over content, where it is the look of the tables, the cutlery, the staff and, of course, the food (rather than what it tastes like) which matters most.

Harden's, the restaurant guide which is compiled from the reports of real people who eat out, each year surveys the major quality groups which have come to dominate so much of the restaurant scene in central London. The Conran group as a whole - which includes Quaglino's, Bluebird, Sartoria and Mezzo - holds down the bottom of the chart as if it were a finely designed lead brick. 'No aspect - food, service or ambience - of any group restaurant is rated exceptional,' Harden's reports in its latest edition.

There is nothing intrinsically wrong with restaurant groups. In principle they can provide a framework within which talent can be encouraged and, through bulk buying, should be able to offer value for money. On the down side, restaurant groups can use their economic muscle to grab the best locations, cutting out the smaller and generally more interesting independent operators, by offering landlords the kind of copper-bottomed guarantees on rents that first-timers simply can't match. What's more, they are in a position to use tactics which, while entirely legal, place lesser-funded outfits at a serious disadvantage.

Which is exactly what Conran is doing right now. When you telephone the restaurant at 49 Lexington Street near Piccadilly Circus in London, they announce themselves as 'Aurora Soho'. They do this because there is another Aurora, which has absolutely nothing to do with them, in the Great Eastern Hotel near Liverpool Street Station in the City of London. It's owned by Conran. The Soho Aurora is the original, having opened six years ago; Conran's opened in 1999. At the time, Conran said he was aware the name was already in use but that he was satisfied 'the size and nature of our operation was sufficiently different to avoid confusion being caused'. His confidence was unfounded. Gillian Mosley, who owns the Lexington Street business, reports an endless stream of people booking and then either not turning up or turning down the table when they realise they've got the wrong place.

Now Conran is trying to take it one stage further. He has an application going through the courts to trademark the name Aurora which Mosley is determined to fight. Should he win, it would mean, in effect, that he could stop her expanding into another branch under the name she chose six years ago, while setting up one more of his own. That would be a crying shame because we could do with more places like Mosley's and less like Conran's.

The Lexington Street Aurora is the perfect antithesis of a Conran enterprise. It is small and intimate with space for only 20 people inside and a few more in a walled garden outside in the summer. The unmanicured walls are painted a lovely bohemian blood red, and the food, while sometimes a little ragged around the edges, has an equally unfussy charm.

Four of us gave the five starters and five main courses a full shakedown and there were very few dishes that misfired. Most of the starters are salads of one kind or another, the strength of which lies in the sourcing of ingredients: the Orkney herrings which came with a salad of new potatoes and green leaves and a dressing of wholegrain mustard and dill (£6.50), were sweet and soft without lying on the uncomfortable side of squidgy. Likewise, the smoked-trout fillets with a watercress and beetroot salad were mellow and not too savagely smoky. An assembly of smoked cheese with rocket, pears, asparagus and pine nuts with sundried tomato pesto was as good as that list of ingredients sounds. All portions were generous. Celeriac soup with shallots and stilton (£3.95) was a real winter warmer, and had great depth.

Of the main courses, the star was the sweet-chilli-glazed chicken breast on roast vegetable couscous (£11.50) which had my wife practically humming with delight, and the grilled tuna on spring onion and herb mash was perfectly cooked - seared on the outside, pink in the middle.

The wine list is short and well selected and from it we chose a fresh and grassy Caliterra Sauvignon Blanc at £12. As to the service, it is as cheerful and efficient as it could be with just one person performing all the duties. What's more, she doesn't sneer at you as you walk in or look irritated at the interruption to her modelling career that your request for bread or mineral water might present, as so often seems to be the case at one of Conran's places. Clearly this whole trademark battle has a touch of the David and Goliath's about it. I know who's side I'm on.

Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk.

webTitle: Monty Don: La vie en rose

fields.headline: La vie en rose
fields.standfirst: Taking stock of your beds now will ensure everything comes up roses in May
fields.trailText: Taking stock of your beds now will ensure everything comes up roses in May.
fields.body:
It is a funny time to be writing about roses, when the snow is filling the window with jerking, berserk flakes. The garden below is lost in a swirl. Ten minutes ago the sun was shining. In half an hour it will probably be doing so again. March, you see. And not a rose to be seen. Nor will there be until May, when Rosa cantabridgiensis will undoubtedly be the first to bloom in this garden, its little snouts of primrose flowers breaking along the length of its branches against the fern-like leaves. This makes me extraordinarily happy when it happens. A rich day.

But now, despite the weather, it is time to be taking stock of the roses in your garden and for making last-minute plans to plant some more. It is best to get them in the ground as soon as possible, certainly if they are bare-root (and so much better and cheaper if you can). Even if they're in a container and therefore - in theory - plantable at any time of year, day or night, it is best to give the growing roots as long as possible to get used to your soil before they flower. Containerised plants planted after about May have an incredible tenacity when it comes to restricting themselves to the potting compost of their container, and take until the following season to grow out of it.

There was a rose blooming furiously at the Chelsea Physic Garden when I was there in January, which apparently flowers every single day of the year. But the Physic Garden is exceptionally sheltered and mild and I don't think that it would withstand the temperature lows of this garden. Anyway, I feel no urge at all to stretch the boundaries of the possible in this garden. I don't really want roses in January any more than I want asparagus in October. I like seasonal variation, and May, June and July are measured as much by roses as the sunshine or leathery smell of a cricket ball.

I came to roses late, not really knowing anything about them other than their obvious and conventional status as an icon of beauty. I then assumed the rigour and rigid parameters of the newly converted, affecting to love only 'old' roses and publicly despising all hybrid teas, floribundas and china roses. This is as silly as limiting yourself to only liking rap music or pre-1750 cantatas. But, of course, the whole point about a little knowledge is that it can be terrifying. Affecting to like only that which you know is a way of covering up how limited your knowledge is. It is true of me, at any rate. This shows a lack of trust in one's judgement, too; if a flower is lovely, who cares if it belongs to a gallica, centifolia, floribunda or rambler?

But as I learn a little more about roses, I do tend to get more pleasure from shrub roses than hybrid teas and more from the older shrubs, such as the rugosas, bourbons, damasks or albas, than modern ones. I particularly like the combination of delicacy and opulence, the way that none are designed to be labour-saving, fast, long lasting, thornless, small or whatever attribute is thought to be desirable for the modern gardener. They are themselves - almost. I am being selectively disingenuous. Roses have been bred for many centuries and by the end of the 18th century new hybrids were being produced by the hundred. But they were, as far as I know, bred entirely for their aesthetic qualities rather than their user-friendliness.

If you want the real, untrammelled thing, then you must turn to the species roses. These are the pure, essential thing. The first thing one notices if you see a selection of species roses in flower is that they are pretty unshowy. No petal-crammed blooms but single flowers which in turn develop a range of extraordinarily beautiful hips. The thorns vary enormously, from the bristle of R pimpinellifolia to the famous shark's fin thorns of R sericea pteracantha , or the spiralled interlocking helix of R willmottiae .

In hybrid teas we endure a hideously ugly shrub for (sometimes) glorious flowers. Fair deal. With centifolias or some gallicas, we endure balled flowers, blackspot and grey mould for the few weeks when the shrub is weighed down by its fragrant, subtly voluptuous blooms. But with species roses you take the plant in its entirety and the flowers are merely the more conventionally all-singing, all-dancing aspect of its performance. The sum of any individual species rose's parts tends to amount to more than the whole. That is their great charm.

One of the less likely parts are their coloured stems. Of the species roses I grow, R moschata and R ' Complicata' are both green-stemmed, even in the heart of winter, but R californica plena is orange, R wintoniensis red and R ferri persetosa 'Nan of Painswick' a deep alizarin. (This latter, by the way, is a seemingly 'wild' sport of the much more common Threepenny bit rose, R elegantula 'persetosa'). R primula has chocolatey, spiky stems. Oh, and it has ferny, incense-scented leaves. And beautiful, soft buttery flowers.

I have no problem with single flowers and feel no need to apologise for the small size of the flowers on R hugonis or the delicate simplicity of R ferreri . And if R moyesii had any more petals it would explode, so intense is its red. Talking of numbers of petals, R sericea is the only rose with only four petals on each flower. The least that any other rose can reduce to is five. It is extraordinary that these modest flowers can develop in so many of the species roses into such showy, swollen hips. R rugosa 's are like tomatoes, and R moyesii' s like miniature orange bottle gourds, while those of R glauca are bunched like grapes. R wintoniensis has great clusters of flagon-shaped hips with a curious purplish bloom.

Species climbers tend to have great vigour and masses of small flowers that appear just the once. In the 80s and early 90s, vast quantities of R filipes 'Kiftsgate' were sold to cover a couple of square yards of trellis or wall - one woman bought six from a friend of mine for her roof garden. 'Kiftsgate' will grow to a height of at least 50ft and as much again across. I grew one up a lawson cypress once, in the hope that it would smother and kill the tree.

R filipes is less powerful but dramatic enough for most gardens. R multiflora has bunches of flowers and will grow as a shrub or clamber over a support up to 20ft high. R moschata has grey-green foliage and stems and climbs modestly, good for a tripod or shady wall and it flowers from July right into September. R longicuspis, on the other hand, has almost evergreen, leathery leaves and real climbing vigour, with what the great Peter Beales, in his indispensable book Classic Roses (£40, Harvill), calls 'huge, cascading panicles of bunched, medium-sized, single, white flowers'. All these climbers have white flowers, but if you have a very sheltered south-facing wall then R banksiae 'Lutea' would cover it with yellow double flowers in May - it is one of the first of all roses to flower. R banksiae ' Lutescens' has single flowers, but they are bigger, better scented and have wonderful exaggerated stamens.

By now, you are either sold on the idea of species roses or have dismissed them utterly. But if you are going to plant any - and there is still time to order them from a specialist nursery and get them in the ground before they start to grow too aggressively - consider their context. These are plants that like to sprawl, and you need to indulge their laxity. The conventional place to put them is a 'wild' garden, with lots of longish grass and other vigorous, large plants around them - but that suggests more space than most people have at their disposal. I have planted all mine in borders of various kinds, but they are positioned at the back so they can grow tall and floppy. They make good hosts for clematis, although pruning the late-flowering ones can be a bit tricky as they twine through some of the more aggressively thorned roses.

Species roses are among the toughest plants in the garden and will grow in almost any soil and any position, but place them where you can get close enough to appreciate their detail throughout the seasons and yet with enough space for them to sprawl in the untrainable, unbred manner that is such important part of their immense charm.

My roots: a week in Monty's garden

The ground has frozen hard every night for the past week. This is great. For a start it means when I go outside first thing I can keep my shoes on. Wonderful! For those of you who are used to being carelessly dry shod - wearing shoes as though they were part of your dress, deliciously soft leather, co-ordinated perhaps, chosen for they way that they make you look... crazee - that is not the way it is in these parts.

The magic of frost is that I tread above the ground, ride the surface like a conveyor belt. I stick the kettle on the Aga, go out the back door (dogs stamping impatiently as I fiddle with the bolt) and straight to the greenhouse to check if the electric thermostatic heaters worked. (Mind you, when it was really cold I couldn't even do that because the aluminium door froze.) Then I check the thermometer. After that it's onwards to the chickens via the Jewel garden, relishing the hard bobbles and ruts of the mud, softly crushing the frozen grass and stamping contemptuously on the quagmire in the chickens' pen. In my slippers! Gardening doesn't hold many more triumphs than this.

The mud is entirely responsible for the indignity of having to wear slippers in the first place. Because I go in and out like a yo-yo, the only sense is to wear shoes indoors that slip on and off.

A hundred 3'6" sharpened split chestnut stakes were delivered the other day. Stacked in the yard, sharp ends at right angles in alternating layers, they are ravishingly beautiful - as aesthetically inspiring to my eyes as any piece of carefully constructed installation art. They are the uprights to take woven hazel rods for the low fences around my vegetable beds. These fences only last about three years because the wet soil rots the hazel, which, if dry, will last three times as long.

The posts are of chestnut, partly because it splits beautifully so you can have very strong quarter-split posts, but mainly because chestnut is very slow to rot in the ground. So each post lasts about three batches of hazel renewal. But now the time has come to change it all over. This is hard work. The secret is to have them rock firm and perfectly upright in a dead straight line - then the interweaving is easy. I adore doing this and love the results. The only bad thing about them is that the snails love them, too, sheltering within the weave during the day before slipping out to dine on my vegetables throughout the night.

Ten minutes ago the sun was shining. In half an hour it will probably be doing so again. March, you see. And not a rose to be seen. Nor will there be until May, when Rosa cantabridgiensis will undoubtedly be the first to bloom in this garden, its little snouts of primrose flowers breaking along the length of its branches against the fern-like leaves. This makes me extraordinarily happy when it happens. A rich day. But now, despite the weather, it is time to be taking stock of the roses in your garden and for making last-minute plans to plant some more. It is best to get them in the ground as soon as possible, certainly if they are bare-root (and so much better and cheaper if you can). Even if they're in a container and therefore - in theory - plantable at any time of year, day or night, it is best to give the growing roots as long as possible to get used to your soil before they flower. Containerised plants planted after about May have an incredible tenacity when it comes to restricting themselves to the potting compost of their container, and take until the following season to grow out of it. There was a rose blooming furiously at the Chelsea Physic Garden when I was there in January, which apparently flowers every single day of the year. But the Physic Garden is exceptionally sheltered and mild and I don't think that it would withstand the temperature lows of this garden.
