I like seasonal variation, and May, June and July are measured as much by roses as the sunshine or leathery smell of a cricket ball. I came to roses late, not really knowing anything about them other than their obvious and conventional status as an icon of beauty. I then assumed the rigour and rigid parameters of the newly converted, affecting to love only 'old' roses and publicly despising all hybrid teas, floribundas and china roses. This is as silly as limiting yourself to only liking rap music or pre-1750 cantatas. But, of course, the whole point about a little knowledge is that it can be terrifying. Affecting to like only that which you know is a way of covering up how limited your knowledge is. It is true of me, at any rate. This shows a lack of trust in one's judgement, too; if a flower is lovely, who cares if it belongs to a gallica, centifolia, floribunda or rambler? But as I learn a little more about roses, I do tend to get more pleasure from shrub roses than hybrid teas and more from the older shrubs, such as the rugosas, bourbons, damasks or albas, than modern ones. I particularly like the combination of delicacy and opulence, the way that none are designed to be labour-saving, fast, long lasting, thornless, small or whatever attribute is thought to be desirable for the modern gardener. They are themselves - almost. I am being selectively disingenuous. Roses have been bred for many centuries and by the end of the 18th century new hybrids were being produced by the hundred. But they were, as far as I know, bred entirely for their aesthetic qualities rather than their user-friendliness. If you want the real, untrammelled thing, then you must turn to the species roses. These are the pure, essential thing. The first thing one notices if you see a selection of species roses in flower is that they are pretty unshowy. No petal-crammed blooms but single flowers which in turn develop a range of extraordinarily beautiful hips. The thorns vary enormously, from the bristle of R pimpinellifolia to the famous shark's fin thorns of R sericea pteracantha , or the spiralled interlocking helix of R willmottiae . Oh, and it has ferny, incense-scented leaves. And beautiful, soft buttery flowers. I have no problem with single flowers and feel no need to apologise for the small size of the flowers on R hugonis or the delicate simplicity of R ferreri . And if R moyesii had any more petals it would explode, so intense is its red. Talking of numbers of petals, R sericea is the only rose with only four petals on each flower. The least that any other rose can reduce to is five. It is extraordinary that these modest flowers can develop in so many of the species roses into such showy, swollen hips. R rugosa 's are like tomatoes, and R moyesii' s like miniature orange bottle gourds, while those of R glauca are bunched like grapes. R wintoniensis has great clusters of flagon-shaped hips with a curious purplish bloom. Species climbers tend to have great vigour and masses of small flowers that appear just the once. In the 80s and early 90s, vast quantities of R filipes 'Kiftsgate' were sold to cover a couple of square yards of trellis or wall - one woman bought six from a friend of mine for her roof garden. 'Kiftsgate' will grow to a height of at least 50ft and as much again across. I grew one up a lawson cypress once, in the hope that it would smother and kill the tree. R filipes is less powerful but dramatic enough for most gardens. R multiflora has bunches of flowers and will grow as a shrub or clamber over a support up to 20ft high. R moschata has grey-green foliage and stems and climbs modestly, good for a tripod or shady wall and it flowers from July right into September. R longicuspis, on the other hand, has almost evergreen, leathery leaves and real climbing vigour, with what the great Peter Beales, in his indispensable book Classic Roses (£40, Harvill), calls 'huge, cascading panicles of bunched, medium-sized, single, white flowers'. All these climbers have white flowers, but if you have a very sheltered south-facing wall then R banksiae 'Lutea' would cover it with yellow double flowers in May - it is one of the first of all roses to flower. R banksiae ' Lutescens' has single flowers, but they are bigger, better scented and have wonderful exaggerated stamens. By now, you are either sold on the idea of species roses or have dismissed them utterly. But if you are going to plant any - and there is still time to order them from a specialist nursery and get them in the ground before they start to grow too aggressively - consider their context. These are plants that like to sprawl, and you need to indulge their laxity. The conventional place to put them is a 'wild' garden, with lots of longish grass and other vigorous, large plants around them - but that suggests more space than most people have at their disposal. I have planted all mine in borders of various kinds, but they are positioned at the back so they can grow tall and floppy. They make good hosts for clematis, although pruning the late-flowering ones can be a bit tricky as they twine through some of the more aggressively thorned roses. Species roses are among the toughest plants in the garden and will grow in almost any soil and any position, but place them where you can get close enough to appreciate their detail throughout the seasons and yet with enough space for them to sprawl in the untrainable, unbred manner that is such important part of their immense charm. webTitle: Axe that may not cut it

fields.headline: Axe that may not cut it
fields.standfirst:
The Express's boss may think staff cuts and Catherine Zeta Jones's cleavage will spell salvation for his titles, but he'll also need the vision thing, says Peter Preston

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Express's boss may think staff cuts and Catherine Zeta Jones's cleavage will spell salvation for his titles, but he'll also need the vision thing, says Peter Preston.
fields.body:
So, does size really matter? The size, that is, of a paper's editorial budget and staff. Richard Desmond, new owner of the Express group, thinks not, and is preparing to axe as many as 145 jobs on his two main titles.

Those in the firing line (and their union) don't agree. The Vandals and the Goths from OK! magazine are at it again. Desmond doesn't 'understand newspapers'.

This isn't yet another ritual dumping of bodies off Blackfriars Bridge. It is a high-profile encounter in the most fundamental debate about modern news-paper publishing. Can a slashing of costs bring rescue and revival? If it can, then there may be more jobs and papers in the end. If it can't, then Rupert Murdoch's (much delayed) vision of a Fleet Street reduced to a handful of survivors will edge a little nearer.

Let's try and do something that the threshing Desmond doesn't do so well for himself: make a coherent case for these cuts. Though you have to roll rumour, hint and fact together, it is surprisingly easily done. A few decades ago both the daily and Sunday Expresses were kings of the middle market, selling over 4 million copies. Even 10 years back, the daily sold 1.5 million. Last month it was at 950,000 and falling fast.

Maybe Richard Desmond promised to restore his new babies to their 'rightful position' and 'spend what it takes' when he took over, but that couldn't mean carrying on as before. Pouring cash into the same old structures was a recipe for the same old failure.

Look at the 440 or so jobs in question. You can't be exact, because contracts and correspondencies vary from paper to paper, but the Mirror seems to manage with around 290 journalists. Why should the Daily Express and Sunday Express need a bigger staff than the Independent and Independent on Sunday (or the Guardian and The Observer )? There may have been squeezings and trimmings over the years from other failed owners, but this is the fabled last chance saloon. Remember, the only other prospective buyers left in the ring last autumn were the brothers Hinduja.

Thus we need radical surgery to match staffing and reality more closely. There is, anyway, no particular magic about staffing ratios. Strong regional papers pound out every day with a staff of 80 or 100. Big city American papers prophesy doom when their editorial strength dips below 1,000 (more than the Times, Guardian and Indy put together). In Desmond's own backyard, the leanest, meanest title - the Daily Star - is also the most successful: sales up 6.5 per cent year on year. Spend what it takes, to be sure: but spend on the things that matter, like glossy mags and marketing. Why triplicate features commissioning or financial reporting across three papers when one consolidated desk could serve the lot?

Why shell out for routine reportage when Associated's Metro series makes such notable use of Press Association tapes? Does anyone today really buy this Express for its news? Why fight on all fronts - like sports coverage - when you think Catherine Zeta Jones's cleavage is your real salvation? Why give the hacks top dollar and six weeks' holiday, when you built OK! on far shorter commons (and your hacks in the North are restive)?

Oh, there'll be wailing and moaning. But in the end, if they're still there, they'll thank you. And meanwhile, lopping £7 million off costs turns a dubiously profitable enterprise clearly into the black. Perhaps Rupert is right; perhaps one day the Mail will rule the middle market alone. But in the meantime, you'll have given them a good run for your money.

Here endeth the case for the spring offensive. It is not, at many points, without merit. It deserves to be taken seriously rather than merely denounced. The question - of practicality rather than some higher morality - is whether it's right or wrong? Does taking a cleaver to costs bring salvation?

Conrad Black would say so. He made the buy of the century when he rescued the Daily Telegraph. But those were production, not editorial, costs. Mark Willes from General Mills was a brief Wall Street darling when he sought to produce a falling editorial bill and rising circulation on the Los Angeles Times. But Willes is sacked history and the LA Times belongs to the Chicago Tribune now. The Independent and Independent on Sunday - given the David Montgomery memorial treatment - have only steadied since Tony O'Reilly put in editorial resource. Save for the lonely Star, it's hard to find any example where cost-cutting has seemed to go with the circulation trick.

Who made the old Express a market monarch? An editor, Arthur Christiansen. Who saved the Mail from oblivion? An editor, David English, and a proprietorial Rothermere who never let profit margins get in the way of editorial investment. Managers, on their record, can't go it alone. Ask the wan ghost of Lord Hollick. There has to be a different, creative spark in the mix for recovery. There has to be an inspired combining of ends and means.

This is where, politely, the clouds gather around Richard Desmond. The Star was a sparky and showbizzy tabloid on the rise (thanks to shrewd editing) long before he took over. The OK! celeb network helps that narrow focus. It does not pretend to be, nor need to be, a full-service newspaper (any more than the News of the World). Its means and its ends are a fit.

But has the Daily Express set a similarly defined course? Not yet, though the celeb count and the OK! transfer market grows ever more obvious. It is shrugging off the grey readers who remember Lord Beaverbrook and the younger ones who joined for Rosie Boycott's brief essay in New Labour intelligence.

It is heading away from the choking embrace of the Mail - with double the editorial resources - and down into the mud wrestling pit where the Sun, Mirror and - yes - the Star await.

That may be an inspired decision; but pigs may also fly. For the moment, Desmond has three messy months of statutorily imposed negotiations over job losses to go: a descant of despair and strike ballots to drown out any ring of confidence as circulation goes on slipping. Voluntary redundancy schemes will strip him of his brightest (because most marketable) talent. Necessary replacements will be hard - going on impossible - to find. Those who recall previous efforts to combine departments to serve many masters wince over the culture clashes that provoked.

Collapsing morale? Maybe, as some Fleet Street managers say, morale rings no cash registers. Perhaps Desmond will find the vision thing along the way. But newspaper life - as Mark Willes found out - involves no static models. Even if you have a goal, you have to have a way of reaching it - and the process of getting there can do terrible damage.

The Daily and Sunday Express are already selling 100,000 fewer copies in the UK than they were last year; the difference between managed decline and unmanageable decline becomes ever mistier. After you've done the cutting, what have you got left? Who will there be left to despise? This isn't really a problem of understanding newspapers, just understanding management.

fields.headline: All-out war threatens Balkans
fields.standfirst:
UN warning of refugee exodus

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ethinc Albanian guerillas battling Macedonian forces issued a declaration of war last night, calling on all 'able-bodied men' to join their uprising in favour of self-rule. They also ordered ethnic Albanians serving in Macedonia's armed forces to desert.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll in  Tetovo Nick Wood  in Selce and Peter Beaumont
fields.body:
Ethinc Albanian guerillas battling Macedonian forces issued a declaration of war last night, calling on all 'able-bodied men' to join their uprising in favour of self-rule. They also ordered ethnic Albanians serving in Macedonia's armed forces to desert.

The call came as the United Nations issued a chilling warning to the international community that Europe was facing the threat of a massive refugee crisis in the region, following the worst day of fighting in the former Yugoslav republic since trouble erupted five days ago.

The UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Ruud Lubbers, warned of an impending humanitarian crisis as residents of Tetovo, the city at the centre of the fighting, continued to flee the city.

He said: 'We cannot afford another humanitarian tragedy in the Balkans, where millions have been uprooted by violent conflicts in the last decade'.

The general call up - put out by the self-styled National Liberation Army which appeared in Macedonia two months ago - came as world leaders contemplated for the first time the horrifying prospect of a full-scale war in Macedonia that threatens to divide the country along ethnic lines.

Macedonia split from Yugoslavia a decade ago and had been the only former republic to secede without violence. Now the international community fears the growing conflict could ignite a conflagration that threatens to draw in Greece, Bulgaria and Turkey and suck Nato-led peacekeepers in Kosovo into the fighting.

In a worrying new development ethnic Albanian guerrillas in the neighbouring Presevo Valley of southern Serbia - who with the NLA are fighting for a 'Greater Kosovo' linking Albanian areas outside Kosovo - broke a week-long ceasefire and appeared on the verge of opening a new front in their escalating border war.

Yesterday Albanian leaders in Macedonia hardened their support for the extremists behind the rebellion.

'We would welcome international mediation, but I fear we are running out of time,' said Fadil Sulejmani, rector of the once-outlawed University of Tetovo, a centre for young Albanian radicals. 'This is becoming a kind of holy war.'

The latest escalation of the fighting has found Nato and the international community in disarray over how to end the violence, amid fears among European government's over America's commitment to the Balkans. US peacekeeping forces in Kosovo have been criticised for standing by as former KLA fighters crossed the border into Macedonia to launch their rebellion.

Yesterday Tetovo was again scene of the heaviest fighting. Soldiers in the largely Albanian-populated city used heavy machine guns mounted on armoured personnel carriers to unleash torrents of fire into the surrounding mountains, while snipers tried to pick off insurgents in the forest above. Smoke plumed from burning trees and blasts boomed through empty streets as people fled the city or hid.

At the Albanian rebels' headquarters in Selce, a mile from Tetovo, new recruits continued to pour in.

In an effort to contain the violence Greece announced yesterday that it would host talks with the foreign ministers of Albania and Macedonia to negotiate a ceasefire.

Nato Secretary-General Lord Robertson, on a visit to Athens, said Nato forces were responding to Macedonian calls for Nato-led peacekeepers in Kosovo to shut off the flow of arms and weapons into Macedonia and Serbia.

The growing crisis in the Balkans will top the agenda at the EU heads of state meeting in Stockholm this week.

Ethnic Albanians account for at least a quarter of Macedonia's 2 million people, dominating western regions of the country.

Ethnic Albanians believe government will give way but fighting fuels hatred between communities: Special report by Rory Carroll and Nick Wood in Tetovo, Macedonia, and Peter Beaumont in London

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Ethnic Albanians believe government will give way but fighting fuels hatred between communities: Special report by Rory Carroll and Nick Wood in Tetovo, Macedonia, and Peter Beaumont in London
fields.byline: Rory Carroll and Nick Wood in Tetovo, Macedonia, and Peter Beaumont in London
fields.body:
Two weeks is a long time in the Balkans. A fortnight ago, in the smoky offices of the Albanian Democratic Party in Macedonia's second city, Tetovo, the leader of the country's main Albanian party, Arben Xhafari, was entertaining journalists over coffee and juice to reassure them that Macedonia's ethnic Albanian minority was not bent on violence.

'Some people believe in the domino effect in Macedonia,' he explained in a voice slowed by the Parkinson's disease that is slowly crippling him. 'I don't believe in the fatality and inevitability of war.'

Five days ago - despite his best efforts to prevent it - war came to Tetovo and to Macedonia. The cafes, bars and shops that even a week ago were packed with people were deserted and electricity was cut off to part of the town.

In the narrow streets of the Koltak district, heavily-armed Macedonian police poured fire on guerrilla positions on Baltepe mountain on the edge of town, while rebels responded with machine-gun and rifle fire into the district of small two-storey houses where most of the ethnic Albanian-dominated town's Macedonian population live.

At two o'clock on Friday afternoon the rebels of the National Liberation Army blew away the last remnants of Xhafari's reasons for hope as four mortar rounds fell directly into the central square not far from his office.

It is a scenario sketched out a month ago by a balding guerrilla leader known simply as Hoxha. From his hillside base along Kosovo's border with Macedonia, he claimed the NLA had 4,000 members throughout Mace donia and the situation was 'going to explode everywhere'. With just a few dozen fighters scattered across a handful of hilltops and with Nato-led peacekeeping troops in Kosovo on one side, and the Macedonian army on the other, his claims seemed ridiculous. Now Tetovo is shaking to the sounds of explosions. Shooting has also been reported in the village of Kicevo, 70 miles south-west of Skopje. Hoxha's claims no longer seem far-fetched.

The battle for Tetovo began on Wednesday afternoon after a rally by ethnic Albanians. There was a crackle of semi-automatic fire. Someone was shooting at the Macedonian police from Mount Baltepe. By sunset 15 police were injured and an Albanian civilian, Sulejman Ramadani, lay dead, shot through the head.

Even on Thursday - the second day of fighting around Tetovo - residents could still not quite believe it. Men drank in cafes, hairdressers blow-dried customers' hair and taxis waited in the square. 'It's a spectacle. We can watch from here, it's totally safe,' said Blerim, 18, on a bench with two friends.

By Friday the pretence was over. Rebels had moved closer to the city centre. Houses were shaking and walls crumbling. Four hundred families had fled their homes, shops were shut and the streets had emptied.

The fighting has forced a wedge between Macedonia's two main ethnic communities. Prejudices long suppressed have rushed to the surface. 'They're animals. We've given them everything; now look what they are doing,' said a Macedonian man in a grocer's store. 'They have schools, jobs, a university, everything.'

On the other side of the ethnic divide the gunmen have galvanised support among the Albanian community. An insurgency that seemed limited to a handful of extremists suddenly seems to have deep roots. What they are fighting for is harder to grasp. Albanians in Macedonia have not suffered the same history of appalling political repression as their brothers in Kosovo.

Albanians may feel that they are 'second-class citizens', but what that boils down to is harder to define. Xhafari's party was one of the more stable members of the coalition government. The NLA says it is fighting for the equal rights of Albanians in Macedonia's constitution and recognition of Albanian as an official language.

Shpresa Sinani, the 52-year-old president of Tetovo's Albanian Woman's League, told The Observer a few hours before fleeing her home: 'Better 600 years of talking than six minutes of fighting. But the glass is overflowing. We've waited long enough.'

She itemised the grievances of her community: official recognition of the Albanian language, a state-funded Albanian university, enfranchisement of Albanians excluded from voter rolls. Tetovo had five Macedonian kindergartens, she said, but only one for Albanians, who comprise more than three-quarters of the 80,000 population. On it went, a roll-call of discrimination which some Macedonian officials admit is a scandal. But a reason for civil war?

'They [the NLA] are fighting for our rights,' said Krenar Osmani, 23, a student. 'For 10 years we have sought our rights with dialogue, but they are answering with the language of torture. I have a broken rib from when the police arrested me in a demonstration,' he said. 'I don't care about my house, I only care about freedom,' chipped in another man, who produced a revolver and showed how he would use it to defend his family.

The almost unanimous view of Albanians on the streets of Tetovo is that the fighting would stop if the government would listen to the gunmen's demands. 'If they have a political agenda,' said Nicola Dimitrov, national security adviser to Macedonian president Boris Trajkovski, 'I think the solution is ballots and not bullets. It is really a pity that when we will probably have EU membership in 15 to 20 years we are now facing this threat.'

Already the fighting is threatening wider inter-communal violence. A bus-load of Albanians were stoned on their way back from Mecca. A Macedonian couple were surrounded in Tetovo, but allowed to leave, after being spotted in an Albanian quarter. The language is of a hatred familiar from Yugoslavia's wars. 'Give me a gun and I will go into the woods to shoot Albanian terrorists,' said Dragan, 27.

Most dangerous of all is the way that fiction is becoming gospel as the anger grows. 'They are worse than the Serbs, they burn our villages,' said one of a group of young Albanian men. Which villages? Mumbles and silence.

They believe their war can be won. They scoff at the notion that a conflagration, another Bosnia or Lebanon, is imminent. 'Don't worry my friend. The government will soon give us what we want,' grinned a waiter. That his Macedonian neighbours are screaming for guns bothers him not at all.

Capital: Skopje

Independence: Macedonia split from Yugoslavia in 1991.

Population: 2 million.

Ethnic breakdown: Macedonian, 66.6 per cent (Slavs), Albanian 22.7 per cent (the Albanians claim they make up one third) Turkish 4 per cent, Roma 2.2 per cent, Serb 2.1 per cent, other 2.4 per cent. The mixed population has inspired the name of a fruit cocktail in Italy - a 'Macedonian'.

Major languages: Macedonian 70 per cent, Albanian 21 per cent, Turkish 3 per cent, Serbo-Croat 3 per cent, other 3 per cent.

Major religions: Christianity, 67 per cent, Islam, 30 per cent.

Form of government: Parliamentary democracy.

President: Boris Trajkovski

Prime minister: Ljubco Georgievski, leader of the nationalist VMRO-DPME party.

Climate: Warm and dry in summer, cold and snowy in winter.

Terrain: Mountainous with deep valleys. 40 per cent forested.

fields.headline: Our Balkan mess
fields.standfirst:
With courage we can save Macedonia

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: War, even in the Balkans, is not inevitable. Despite a decade of warnings of the risk of violence between Slavs and minority Albanians, the tragedy of the conflict now taking hold in Macedonia is that it need not be happening at all.
fields.body:
War, even in the Balkans, is not inevitable. Despite a decade of warnings of the risk of violence between Slavs and minority Albanians, the tragedy of the conflict now taking hold in Macedonia is that it need not be happening at all. The demands of ethnic Albanians - for better education, official recognition of their language and a fairer rewriting of the constitution - are hardly a cause for violent conflict.

Unlike Kosovo under Milosevic, where Albanians were fired from their jobs and suffered widespread persecution, the Albanians of Macedonia have been slowly winning their battle for equal rights. They are represented in government, police and the armed forces, although that is not to say there is no discrimination.

When history comes to apportion blame for the present violence, Nato and the United States must share the burden equally. For the causes of the present trouble lie not in Macedonia, but across the border in Kosovo, an international protectorate. The border areas where the National Liberation Army and its sister organisation fighting in the Presevo Valley are based are under American control.

For reasons of domestic politics - avoiding US casualties - and pragmatism - keeping up pressure on Milosevic while he was still power - American forces have turned a blind eye to the activities of a group of extremists who have grown in confidence in their ambition to unite all the Albanian areas around them.

The choice facing the international community is all too simple. Withdrawal of Nato peacekeepers from Kosovo would lead to an even wider war. Instead, the peacekeepers must do the job they are in Kosovo to do - keep the peace by disarming the guerrillas and sealing the border. If that means Nato casualties, it is still better than a wider Balkan war.

fields.headline: Sexy novel shakes rugby world
fields.standfirst: Novel to lift lid on steamy side of overseas tours
fields.trailText: Novel to lift lid on steamy side of overseas tours.
fields.body:
It will do for rugby what Jilly Cooper's Riders did for showjumping. A steamy new book is set to reveal the sexual exploits and off-field antics of Britain's top rugby players. The sport is bracing itself for disclosures that show events get as mucky off the pitch as on it.

Rugby Studs is an exposé of the groupies, heavy drinking, orgies and infidelity on overseas tours for which the game is infamous. Although fiction, it is said to be based on real-life scandal involving top stars. Wives and girlfriends are unlikely to be amused.

The game's rulers are worried because the author, Alison Kervin, is a well-connected insider who knows many of its secrets. The respected rugby editor of the Times, Kervin is friendly with many leading players and a veteran of overseas tours. She is also a former employee of England's Rugby Football Union, and has seen women throw themselves at players.

'Rugby players are fit young men who are attractive to women and have a huge female following,' says Kervin. 'When I worked for the RFU, the letters that arrived for them were unbelievable. Women would send their underwear to a particular player or write them letters saying things like, "My husband's out between two and seven, why don't you come and see me?". One even sent her door-key.'

She describes how, at post-match dinners and balls, rugby groupies would rush up to players. 'They'd say things like, "I've fancied you for ages," or, "I think you're wonderful," even if the player's wife or girlfriend was there.'

Thirty-three-year-old Kervin says Rugby Studs reflects the fact that some players do occasionally succumb to such temptations.

Much of her bonkbuster is set in South Africa during the British Lions tour in 1997, which she attended. It charts the efforts of Isabel Jenkins, a glamorous reporter with a muck-raking Sunday tabloid, to reveal how the team's best-known player is cheating on his girlfriend with a leading South African actress.

'He is the team's main sex symbol and a golden boy - a handsome, athletic, young David Beckham lookalike - and she has been seen leaving the team's hotel. They are having an affair and her newspaper has got wind of it,' says Kervin.

She accepts many readers will assume the scenario was inspired by the widely rumoured affair between England captain Will Carling and the Princess of Wales, but recommends that no one should jump to such conclusions. Carling insisted he and the Princess were simply close friends - and he was not picked for the 1997 Lions tour.

The tour led to rugby's biggest off-field scandal. In May 1999, Lawrence Dallaglio told the News of the World how he and two Lions team-mates had taken ecstasy at a post-match party at a Johannesburg hotel, and described how he and other players had hired prostitutes in Amsterdam. Dallaglio later retracted the remarks, and the RFU cleared him of wrongdoing.

Drugs form part of the backdrop in Rugby Studs. But sex, including orgies, is the main vice on show. One Lions player gladly accepts some of the offers of intimate female company, but at least he is single. 'Rugby has a huge reputation for sex, and people think that players all go off and misbehave all the time,' says Kervin. 'That's not actually the case, as they're also training a lot.'

The author says that, while players are meant to have become less hedonistic since the game turned professional in 1995, their opportunities for illicit liaisons have increased. 'Rugby women traditionally wore Barbour jackets, rugby shirts and sensible trousers. But a new breed of female fan has emerged who sees it as glamorous, sexy and alluring, and hangs around waiting to meet the players, especially the famous ones,' says Kervin.

'If you go to any club on a Saturday afternoon, like Harlequins, you can see these women. They wear skimpy clothes and are dressed up as if they're going out on a Friday night.'

Kervin has more sympathy for the wives and girlfriends left behind while their men go on tour. 'Their insecurities are one example of the damage fame can do, which is one of the book's more serious themes.'

She will be in Australia for the Times for the forthcoming Lions tour, but will also be keeping her eyes open for material she can work into Rugby Studs, which will be published in the summer.

Mike Burton, a veteran of England overseas tours in the Seventies, says: 'Club teams touring places like Jersey and Guernsey are much more boisterous than serious tours by England or the Lions. Alison has a very vivid imagination, and that may reflect the way she spent her girlhood! Regrettably, I missed out on most of the stuff she's written about.'

webTitle: The last love song of a husband beaten by cancer

fields.headline: The last love song of a husband beaten by cancer
fields.standfirst: Stuart Browne lives on in his book, writes  Julia Langdon
fields.trailText: Stuart Browne lives on in his book, writes  Julia Langdon.
fields.body:
Stuart Browne's cult novel has been celebrated as a loud 'shout for life'. Critics have hailed it as a modern classic, perhaps even the first great book of the new century, and Britain's most talented film makers have now seized the opportunity to turn it into a screenplay. Yet the author's own life is over.

Browne, whose debut novel Dangerous Parking was published posthumously, was diagnosed with terminal cancer only five days after he clinched his publishing deal.

Although it was a first book, Bloomsbury accepted it immediately and with enthusiasm. It came out exactly a year ago on the author's fifty-second birthday with a big party at Waterstone's in Piccadilly. He had been dead then for four months.

Next Sunday, as the book comes out in paperback, a group of his friends and fans, including the actors Pete Postlethwaite, Janet Suzman, David Bamber, Michael Gunn and Geraldine James and the award-winning playwright Timberlake Wertenbake, will pay tribute to his life and work in a fundraising performance of words and music for the cancer charity of which Browne was a trustee.

By the time he had completed his book, Browne had been fighting the cancer - first in his bladder, then in his kidneys - for more than six years. His second child was born during this time.

Yet on an ancient computer in the study upstairs in his Sussex home, he had discovered the wonder of writing fiction.

He called his semi-autobiographical novel Dangerous Parking after the charge he and someone known as Blue Sky faced in court after they had been picked up by US cops in the fast lane of Interstate 95 in their green VW microbus with orange polka dots, both so stoned that neither of them realised they weren't moving.

It proved a good title and an even better book. 'Brilliant' is a recurring epithet; one reviewer predicted, when it was first published on on March last year, that no better novel would come out in the course of the whole year.

A year later the suggestion still seems warranted. In the week of paperback publication it moved up 4,500 places in the tracking lists compiled by the trade publication, the Bookseller .

The film rights have already been bought by the distinguished producer, David Aukin, the former head of film at Channel 4. He read it on a Friday and put in an offer by first thing the following Wednesday; Danny ' Trainspotting' Boyle is to be the director; Shane Connaughton, who adapted Christy Brown's My Left Foot for the screen, is doing the adaptation.

We're in The Catcher in the Rye sort of country here. It's a whoop of joy, a personal exultation, and it's funny.

'The book is a love song to me and his family and a pat on the back to his friends,' says Kathryn Pogson, his widow and the mother of their two little girls, Daisy and April. It is about Stuart Browne's life but a great deal more besides. It is a story of our times: about sex and drugs and rock and roll, and about the cancer that killed him.

'This is it,' he had told Kathy as he wrote, exulting in his work. 'I understand exactly what I am doing.'

Then, after the news of the gravity of his illness was broken to him, he stood looking out at the countryside from their front door in the village of Mayfield and turned to Kathy and told her and she watched him square up to death.

It is difficult for Kathy to talk about all of this. She is doing so because she wants the book to be read - 'in squillions, everywhere, across the world' - because it fulfils her definition of a work of art by being life-enhancing.

'I hope the film is great and I hope it's a success, but really I just want everyone to read the book because the book is Stuey.'

Her grief is constant. She wakes to it every morning and lives with it. Kathy is an actor and played Ophelia once, in Jonathan Miller's production. Now she is not so much crazed by grief, as Ophelia was, just uncomprehending about the relentless sweep of it.

'I can never imagine being happy again,' she says. Tears fill her eyes.

'Those little girls,' she says, describing the anguish of wanting her daughters to remember and allowing them to forget. 'They were so in love, 'she says, pathetically, of their relationship with their father.

He only ever saw his book in proof form. 'How many pages?' he demanded from the bed when the first copy arrived. 'Four hundred and two,' Kathy reported. 'I did it!' he said, triumphant. 'Do you like the cover?' she asked. But he didn't care about ephemera like that. Kathy searches to remember his words, then recalls them: 'I am beyond judgment.'

Stuart Browne was born in Cumbria, and was an academic, a playwright and a screen-writer.

'I am never, ever, writing a screenplay again,' he announced after he had embarked on his novel. He would not have needed to do so.

He met Kathy in 1985, when she was appearing off-Broadway in an award-winning production of Wallace Shawn's Aunt Dan and Lemon . He was Professor of Creative Writing at New York University. He was also an alcoholic. He told her he had been dry for two years (a lie; it was actually three months). They fell in love in a spectacular fashion, and he followed her back to Britain. They were married two years later.

In his book fact and fiction are interwoven and, for most readers, that couldn't matter less. But there are a million secret messages for Kathy contained within it.

'It is so recognisable to me as our lives,' she says. 'He would always say that the emotional arc is absolutely biographical: so the love story, the alcoholism, the cancer - all that is absolutely biographical; the fiction that brings it all together is not.'

fields.bodyText: Stuart Browne's cult novel has been celebrated as a loud 'shout for life'. Critics have hailed it as a modern classic, perhaps even the first great book of the new century, and Britain's most talented film makers have now seized the opportunity to turn it into a screenplay. Yet the author's own life is over. Browne, whose debut novel Dangerous Parking was published posthumously, was diagnosed with terminal cancer only five days after he clinched his publishing deal. Although it was a first book, Bloomsbury accepted it immediately and with enthusiasm. It came out exactly a year ago on the author's fifty-second birthday with a big party at Waterstone's in Piccadilly. He had been dead then for four months. Next Sunday, as the book comes out in paperback, a group of his friends and fans, including the actors Pete Postlethwaite, Janet Suzman, David Bamber, Michael Gunn and Geraldine James and the award-winning playwright Timberlake Wertenbake, will pay tribute to his life and work in a fundraising performance of words and music for the cancer charity of which Browne was a trustee. By the time he had completed his book, Browne had been fighting the cancer - first in his bladder, then in his kidneys - for more than six years. His second child was born during this time. Yet on an ancient computer in the study upstairs in his Sussex home, he had discovered the wonder of writing fiction. He called his semi-autobiographical novel Dangerous Parking after the charge he and someone known as Blue Sky faced in court after they had been picked up by US cops in the fast lane of Interstate 95 in their green VW microbus with orange polka dots, both so stoned that neither of them realised they weren't moving. It proved a good title and an even better book. 'Brilliant' is a recurring epithet; one reviewer predicted, when it was first published on on March last year, that no better novel would come out in the course of the whole year. A year later the suggestion still seems warranted. In the week of paperback publication it moved up 4,500 places in the tracking lists compiled by the trade publication, the Bookseller . The film rights have already been bought by the distinguished producer, David Aukin, the former head of film at Channel 4. He read it on a Friday and put in an offer by first thing the following Wednesday; Danny ' Trainspotting' Boyle is to be the director; Shane Connaughton, who adapted Christy Brown's My Left Foot for the screen, is doing the adaptation. We're in The Catcher in the Rye sort of country here. It's a whoop of joy, a personal exultation, and it's funny. 'The book is a love song to me and his family and a pat on the back to his friends,' says Kathryn Pogson, his widow and the mother of their two little girls, Daisy and April. It is about Stuart Browne's life but a great deal more besides. It is a story of our times: about sex and drugs and rock and roll, and about the cancer that killed him. 'This is it,' he had told Kathy as he wrote, exulting in his work. 'I understand exactly what I am doing.' Then, after the news of the gravity of his illness was broken to him, he stood looking out at the countryside from their front door in the village of Mayfield and turned to Kathy and told her and she watched him square up to death. It is difficult for Kathy to talk about all of this. She is doing so because she wants the book to be read - 'in squillions, everywhere, across the world' - because it fulfils her definition of a work of art by being life-enhancing. 'I hope the film is great and I hope it's a success, but really I just want everyone to read the book because the book is Stuey.' Her grief is constant. She wakes to it every morning and lives with it. Kathy is an actor and played Ophelia once, in Jonathan Miller's production. Now she is not so much crazed by grief, as Ophelia was, just uncomprehending about the relentless sweep of it. 'I can never imagine being happy again,' she says. Tears fill her eyes. 'Those little girls,' she says, describing the anguish of wanting her daughters to remember and allowing them to forget. 'They were so in love, 'she says, pathetically, of their relationship with their father. He only ever saw his book in proof form. 'How many pages?' he demanded from the bed when the first copy arrived. 'Four hundred and two,' Kathy reported. 'I did it!' he said, triumphant. 'Do you like the cover?' she asked. But he didn't care about ephemera like that. Kathy searches to remember his words, then recalls them: 'I am beyond judgment.' Stuart Browne was born in Cumbria, and was an academic, a playwright and a screen-writer. 'I am never, ever, writing a screenplay again,' he announced after he had embarked on his novel. He would not have needed to do so. He met Kathy in 1985, when she was appearing off-Broadway in an award-winning production of Wallace Shawn's Aunt Dan and Lemon . He was Professor of Creative Writing at New York University. He was also an alcoholic. He told her he had been dry for two years (a lie; it was actually three months). They fell in love in a spectacular fashion, and he followed her back to Britain. They were married two years later. In his book fact and fiction are interwoven and, for most readers, that couldn't matter less. But there are a million secret messages for Kathy contained within it. 'It is so recognisable to me as our lives,' she says. 'He would always say that the emotional arc is absolutely biographical: so the love story, the alcoholism, the cancer - all that is absolutely biographical; the fiction that brings it all together is not.'  The tribute, 'Celebrating Stuart Browne' will be held in aid of the Cancer Resource Centre in St James's Church, Piccadilly, London W1 on Sunday 25 March at 6.30 p.m. Tickets costing £15, £25 and £40 are available from the Centre at 20-22 York Road, London SW11 3QE (T el 0207 924 3924).  The paperback version of 'Dangerous Parking' is priced at £6.99.

fields.headline: Facts of young life
fields.trailText: Mobile phones account for 20 per cent of a typical youth's spending.
fields.body:
Young adults are 12 times more likely to commit crime as the over-35s

Children from lower-income households are up to two and a half times more likely to display a mental disorder than those from high-earning backgrounds

16 per cent of teenage girls are dieting to lose weight

Just 29 per cent of 16 to 19-year-old women have not had a sexual partner

The UK has the highest teenage pregnancy rate in the EU - 30 per 1,000 women aged under 20. The Netherlands is the lowest

1,100 students aged 19 or above committed suicide from 1990-98

A recent survey showed that one-fifth of children had not eaten fruit in the previous week, and three-fifths had not eaten any leafy green vegetables

While fewer than 20 per cent of the total population think it is important to wear designer labels, 40 per cent of 18-24s believe it is so

Mobile phones account for 20 per cent of a typical youth's spending

The happiest time of your life? Only a quarter of 15 to 24-year-olds say they are 'very happy', compared with two-fifths of those over 55

Half of all young people have been bullied. More than one in 10 suffered severe bullying, including physical violence

90 per cent of 10-year-olds think they will be richer than their parents

148,000 children experienced the divorce of their parents in 1999

Just over a quarter of the population were aged under 20 in 1999, compared with just under half in 1821

5.8 children per 1,000 died before the age of one in the UK in 1999. It was 14 times that figure 80 years ago

Only one in 20 young people say they would not buy the products of a large multinational company that had done something 'wrong'

16 to 34-year-olds made up 29 per cent of the UK population in 1991. This will fall to 24 per cent in 2011

Children of the 1990s received an average of 85 minutes per day of concentrated care from their parents, compared with 25 minutes in 1975

The average parent will consult a doctor about each child 32 times in the first four years of his or her life

Today's 18 to 25-year-olds were not allowed out to play in the street alone until they were nine. The over-65s were playing alone from the age of six

50 per cent of young people think it is important to stand out from the crowd

(Sources: Office of National Statistics, Mori, Future Foundation)

fields.headline: Facts of sex life
fields.trailText: By 2015 men and women will be doing the same number of hours' housework each week. More facts.
fields.body:
20 per cent of those married or living as married admit they sometimes wish they were single

By 2005 less than half the female population will be married

A quarter of women born in 1974 will be childless when they reach the age of 45

In 1951, one in four married women went out to work. Today, nearly three out of four do

By 2015 men and women will be doing the same number of hours' housework each week

Women have 1.7 babies on average

Single parents head a quarter of families with children, three times as many as in 1971. Almost all single parents are women

1.2 million women care for an elderly parent

Single men under 65 made up 4 per cent of all households in 1978 - today, they account for more than 8 per cent

One in five males aged 16-24 was a victim of violence in 1999, more than twice the rate for females of the same age, the next highest 'at risk' group

Women are two and a half times more likely to be treated for depression than men

Men are three times more likely to commit suicide than women, and single men twice as likely than married ones

Men are experiencing increasing problems with body image. One in three thinks his stomach is too large

Between 1979 and 1998, the proportion of non-married women cohabiting almost tripled from 11 per cent to 29 per cent

WomenÍs earnings are increasing faster than men's and will equal menÍs by 2036 is the current rate of change continues

62 per cent of couples with dependent children are both in work

In one generation the number of first marriages has halved and the number of divorces has trebled

In 1996 there were 5.8 million households containing only one person. By 2011 there will be 7.9 million, one third of total households

In 1971, women took one in three available jobs: today it is just under half

Women start 30 per cent of all new businesses in the UK and 25 per cent of all businesses are run by women

The majority of employees in the lowest-paid occupations are women

A mother born in 1950 would spend a quarter of her life childbearing and looking after her family. A mother born in 2010 will spend one-fifth

fields.headline: Facts of techno life
fields.trailText: By 2005, 90 per cent of the population from the age of 12 will own a mobile phone, compared with only 3 per cent in 1988. More facts about technology in Britain today.
fields.body:
The greatest increase in internet use is among 35 to 44-year-olds

In the working population of 35 million, 39 per cent are qualified scientists and engineers

Nokia predicts global demand for internet capacity will grow by 4,600 per cent over the next three years

Three out of 10 of us cannot use all the features on a CD player, microwave or digital TV. The proportion rises to almost half (46 per cent) in the case of video recorders, and more still cannot work out internet access

By 2005, 90 per cent of the population from the age of 12 will own a mobile phone, compared with only 3 per cent in 1988

The digital pay TV market in the UK is set to grow to more than 8 million homes in three years, and 65 per cent of households are set to be able to receive interactive services at home via a PC by 2010

Internet access is fast becoming the norm in British households, with 34 per cent of homes online in July 2000, a figure projected to rise to 43 per cent within the next few months

A third of adults say they would never subscribe to digital TV, blaming the cost of the service

More than two-thirds of people think science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier and more comfortable

Two-thirds of households have a microwave and nearly four out of five have a video

By 2010, 90 per cent of people will have access to the internet through PC, TV, or mobile phone

29 million adults still do not use a PC, of whom nine million say they never will

Banking is becoming an important internet service; 13 per cent of net users use it for banking or buying financial services

In the US, women are the fastest-growing group of internet users, set to overtake men in the next few years

Social use of mobile phones now exceeds business use: 68 per cent bought their phone to organise their social lives, 39 per cent to be more productive at work

We have high expectations for the future. By 2009, 42 per cent of us want instantaneous world travel and 31 per cent calorie-free food

29 per cent of people want an intelligent electronic assistant - and men want it to have the looks and personality of Carol Vorderman

(Sources: Department of Trade and Industry, Future Foundation, Mori)

webTitle: How do you like me? Diary of a cyber liar

fields.headline: How do you like me?
fields.standfirst: He's 40 and lives alone by the seaside, but on the net he can be any age - or 'become' a woman. This is the diary of a cyber liar
fields.trailText: He's 40 and lives alone by the seaside, but on the net he can be any age - or 'become' a woman. This is the diary of a cyber liar. By Michael Collins
fields.body:
Sunday: suited and booted

Here I am, standing in a white suit, with silver hair, and a poodle at my side. I wouldn't normally do this sort of thing. Not in the real world, anyway. But in cyberspace, you can be or do whatever you want - can't you?

That's the theory, at least. I'm in a room entitled Cosmic Vibe, part of a site called Cycosmos. For those interested in getting to know me further, I have an identity card listing my interests in film, literature, sport and music. What's more, in Cycosmos you also get an avatar - an online disguise, your 'digital being' - a choice of clothes and a choice of prop. Hence the poodle. And the white suit? Perhaps I was thinking of Tom Wolfe who, it's said, wore white to reflect the lives and opinions of others, while giving away nothing of himself.

Watching my avatar emerge in the room, like Spock being beamed up, I realise what might be the real magic of cyber life. Whatever your age, wherever you live, whatever you look like, you can get access to the hearts, the minds, the CD collections of a rising generation, with whom you would never share air space in the real world.

And yet something gives me away. Before I can even introduce myself the clothes clearly set me apart. There are characters with dayglo dreadlocks and shades. There's a Slim Shady (the real one?) and a Foxy Chick. Slim moves towards an avatar close to me called Shagmehard. I imagine he is a kid in some suburban bedroom, who threatens his parents with Marilyn Manson and masturbation. I can almost feel his anger as he takes in the white suit, the silver hair, the poodle. Words appear in his speech bubble: 'e luks lik e taks it up the ars.' Charming. And all before I'd even revealed my chosen name for the night.

Monday: love is in the air

When you become virtual, you begin with the name. It's your brand. It's how you're known throughout your travels in cyber-reality. And, initially at least, it's how you attract others. You should avoid obvious names, and also those who choose obvious names. If you're bereft of any imagination when it comes to naming yourself, chances are you're equally inept at virtual conversation. Do I really want to speak to people called Hotchick and Hardman2 at Uboot? I don't think so. Instead I venture to CosmicCupid, I become Lester Burnham, one for fans of American Beauty. Burnham is the Kevin Spacey character, the one undergoing some serious mid-life crisis. Perhaps the character is a clue to my real age or predicament. However, the eyes of Manga are upon me as a female figure straight out of Japanese comic culture is the guide through a community that has a true sense of purpose: flirtation.

Here the goal is to target the names of others with a view to intimacy in the real world, where CosmicCupid scouts gather at real venues, spreading the message of the virtual world. A message reaches Lester. 'Didn't I see you dancing in a tight singlet at the Hanover Grand?' Lester doesn't have the heart to reply that he lives at the seaside, is going to seed, and has just turned 40.

Tuesday: thank you for the music

Napster is not only the place where (until music-industry injunctions took force) you have gone to download songs, it also provides community groups, though napster.com, being musically orientated, has 'channels' instead of rooms. Downloading an MP3 of Black Box Recorder's rendition of 'Uptown Top Ranking' takes me to the playlist of somebody called Voodoochile. It's an impressive list (or at least, I think so), just the sort of marginal pop I like - Magnetic Fields, Lemon Jelly, the High Chaparral theme! - and says more about the other person than e-chat ever could. I feel like I'm clinging to a flower and dragging out the pollen. Voodoochile sends me several emails, informing me that if I don't respond she will cut me off at the source. It's too late to talk. Computer crashes.

Wednesday: Come and have a go

To another room at Cycosmos. The virtual community, when populated by avatars, is like the early days of the computer game. Put one or more virtual characters in a room and virtual violence will ensue, unless a female character enters the room, and introduces the characters to the real prospect of virtual sex. In the Flirting Room, the busiest place in Cycosmos, you get a real sense of what passes for currency, in the absence of real conversation. The words in the bubbles, which emerge like a genie and follow the characters - these move sideways, slowly, like a crab - are mis-spelt, and the letters, in keeping with the fact that for many texting is now a first language, are kept to a minimum.

These characters - Coolguy and a cast of six are in the house - could be speaking early Prince lyrics, but what is actually taking shape is a kind of Esperanto. A number of those present, inhabiting this other world, are, of course, from other countries. Cycosmos is a German concept that became massive on its own turf, before launching itself in other tongues.

The chat room starts to resemble any theme pub in anytown when two teens go to war. Zee and Wardog have become embroiled in an altercation in the centre of the room. They've not come to blows but the words in their bubbles have moved into double figures. 'U r a wanker,' types Zee. Wardog takes minutes to retaliate with: 'Cum 'ere and say that.' The former takes an age to crawl in the direction of his foe, and the most extraordinary thing happens. All the other avatars, we all back away to a corner of the screen, and congregate. Absolutely no reason to do so. We are, after all, just marks on a screen, but, immersed in the site, it's amazing how 'real-world' instincts take over. Two log out. When the going gets tough, the timid get going.

Thursday: time for a sex change

I cut out the cryptic clues, keep it simple, and become female in an effort to hook up with a fellow traveller. I become Saffron (black bodice, thigh boots, and a bottle of champagne, as the prop of choice). It's odd.

Cycosmos describes itself as the first cyber society, and claims that the more people return the closer they tailor their avatar to resemble their real selves. I've done the opposite. A male avatar appears. He has a shrimp-coloured suit; his prop is a sofa.

I put words in my bubble. 'Hi, my name is Saffron. I'm desperate to fit in.' Three times I say it, and get no response. Each time the avatar moves closer to me. When I move, he moves, eventually trying to place himself on top of Saffron. Cybersex! I leave the room as fast as my pixels can carry me, change my prop to a gun and return. He's gone.

Friday: this town ain't big enough

To Cybertown, avoiding the Cyberhood Colony, 'where the morphs and the rebels hang out'. I choose the Entertainment Colony, and the literature neighbourhood. Entry is strict. You choose a name, return to your real life, and await an e-mail informing you of your immigration number. This gets you into Cybertown, where you have 'cash' in your bank account. You 'buy' a 3D house and furnish it, and 'shop' at the Cybertown Plaza. There's simply no need to visit the 3D chatrooms. There's so much to do. I 'live' in the Dr Seuss block. It's next to the JK Rowling block. My house looks like a deflated marshmallow. It is next to a stream. This magnificent metropolis is as great as the futurescapes that emerged from the mind of Fritz Lang, or on the set of Bladerunner.

I furnish the house. I ignore the choice of space-age silver decor on offer, and plump for a room as plain and white as a hospital, with a coal fire. Just as, at Cycosmos, your avatar ultimately begins to resemble your real self rather than your fantasy, in Cybertown your home becomes more like your real home than your ideal home. Log off. Home by 10.

Saturday: propping up the bar

Be it the nightlife or the netlife it comes down to standing in a corner with a drink, swinging your arms back and forth, like someone the police would move on in a built-up area. At MobilesDisco they call it dancing. You can do a virtual dance and hold a virtual drink. And for the soundtrack you can choose music, or the sound of silence.

I am simply Spaceman here, and like all the other figures, my character looks like a hybrid of a Lego person and Bob the Builder. The site is beautifully designed. The disco has flashing lights that switch from amber to eau de nil, and the bar upstairs, in another room, is like a modern youth club. People converse in groups at tables, with the odd word appearing in their bubble, as though they were in a real club, talking above the music. Spaceman sits alone in the corner. No one joins him. For 40 minutes no one joins him. And then, and this really is the magic of the cyber life, and being both anonymous and virtual, I walk to the centre of the room and 'shout' (i.e. in bold capitals) from my speech bubble: 'You say it best when you say nothing it all.' Suddenly a crowd begins to gather. They recognise the lyric. I begin to take requests. Houston, we have contact.

If you would like to visit the sites mentioned, they are:


www.uboot.com


www.napster.com


www.mobilesdisco.com

It's an impressive list (or at least, I think so), just the sort of marginal pop I like - Magnetic Fields, Lemon Jelly, the High Chaparral theme! - and says more about the other person than e-chat ever could. I feel like I'm clinging to a flower and dragging out the pollen. Voodoochile sends me several emails, informing me that if I don't respond she will cut me off at the source. It's too late to talk. Computer crashes. Wednesday: Come and have a go To another room at Cycosmos. The virtual community, when populated by avatars, is like the early days of the computer game. Put one or more virtual characters in a room and virtual violence will ensue, unless a female character enters the room, and introduces the characters to the real prospect of virtual sex. In the Flirting Room, the busiest place in Cycosmos, you get a real sense of what passes for currency, in the absence of real conversation. The words in the bubbles, which emerge like a genie and follow the characters - these move sideways, slowly, like a crab - are mis-spelt, and the letters, in keeping with the fact that for many texting is now a first language, are kept to a minimum. These characters - Coolguy and a cast of six are in the house - could be speaking early Prince lyrics, but what is actually taking shape is a kind of Esperanto. A number of those present, inhabiting this other world, are, of course, from other countries. Cycosmos is a German concept that became massive on its own turf, before launching itself in other tongues. The chat room starts to resemble any theme pub in anytown when two teens go to war. Zee and Wardog have become embroiled in an altercation in the centre of the room. They've not come to blows but the words in their bubbles have moved into double figures. 'U r a wanker,' types Zee. Wardog takes minutes to retaliate with: 'Cum 'ere and say that.' The former takes an age to crawl in the direction of his foe, and the most extraordinary thing happens. All the other avatars, we all back away to a corner of the screen, and congregate. Absolutely no reason to do so. We are, after all, just marks on a screen, but, immersed in the site, it's amazing how 'real-world' instincts take over. Two log out. When the going gets tough, the timid get going. Thursday: time for a sex change I cut out the cryptic clues, keep it simple, and become female in an effort to hook up with a fellow traveller. I become Saffron (black bodice, thigh boots, and a bottle of champagne, as the prop of choice). It's odd. Cycosmos describes itself as the first cyber society, and claims that the more people return the closer they tailor their avatar to resemble their real selves. I've done the opposite. A male avatar appears. He has a shrimp-coloured suit; his prop is a sofa. I put words in my bubble. 'Hi, my name is Saffron. I'm desperate to fit in.' Three times I say it, and get no response. Each time the avatar moves closer to me. When I move, he moves, eventually trying to place himself on top of Saffron. Cybersex! I leave the room as fast as my pixels can carry me, change my prop to a gun and return. He's gone. Friday: this town ain't big enough To Cybertown, avoiding the Cyberhood Colony, 'where the morphs and the rebels hang out'. I choose the Entertainment Colony, and the literature neighbourhood. Entry is strict. You choose a name, return to your real life, and await an e-mail informing you of your immigration number. This gets you into Cybertown, where you have 'cash' in your bank account. You 'buy' a 3D house and furnish it, and 'shop' at the Cybertown Plaza. There's simply no need to visit the 3D chatrooms. There's so much to do. I 'live' in the Dr Seuss block. It's next to the JK Rowling block. My house looks like a deflated marshmallow. It is next to a stream. This magnificent metropolis is as great as the futurescapes that emerged from the mind of Fritz Lang, or on the set of Bladerunner. I furnish the house. I ignore the choice of space-age silver decor on offer, and plump for a room as plain and white as a hospital, with a coal fire. Just as, at Cycosmos, your avatar ultimately begins to resemble your real self rather than your fantasy, in Cybertown your home becomes more like your real home than your ideal home. Log off. Home by 10. Saturday: propping up the bar Be it the nightlife or the netlife it comes down to standing in a corner with a drink, swinging your arms back and forth, like someone the police would move on in a built-up area. At MobilesDisco they call it dancing. You can do a virtual dance and hold a virtual drink. And for the soundtrack you can choose music, or the sound of silence. I am simply Spaceman here, and like all the other figures, my character looks like a hybrid of a Lego person and Bob the Builder. The site is beautifully designed. The disco has flashing lights that switch from amber to eau de nil, and the bar upstairs, in another room, is like a modern youth club. People converse in groups at tables, with the odd word appearing in their bubble, as though they were in a real club, talking above the music. Spaceman sits alone in the corner. No one joins him. For 40 minutes no one joins him. And then, and this really is the magic of the cyber life, and being both anonymous and virtual, I walk to the centre of the room and 'shout' (i.e. in bold capitals) from my speech bubble: 'You say it best when you say nothing it all.' Suddenly a crowd begins to gather. They recognise the lyric. I begin to take requests. Houston, we have contact. If you would like to visit the sites mentioned, they are: www.uboot.com www.napster.com www.mobilesdisco.com

webTitle: Shoot Phil to stop TV killing democracy

fields.headline: Shoot Phil to stop TV killing democracy
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: What does 'Who shot Phil?' have to do with the health of British democracy? Phil's attempted murder, for those unfortunate souls who still believe that foot and mouth disease is the big story of the moment, is the story line which is apparently revitalising Eastenders. (I confess to being a non-worshipper, which has more to do with children's bedtimes than any aversion to soaps.) The questioning of Phil's array of sworn enemies by the Old Bill is designed to boost ratings from the piddling 14 million before the shooting.
fields.body:
What does 'Who shot Phil?' have to do with the health of British democracy? Phil's attempted murder, for those unfortunate souls who still believe that foot and mouth disease is the big story of the moment, is the story line which is apparently revitalising Eastenders. (I confess to being a non-worshipper, which has more to do with children's bedtimes than any aversion to soaps.) The questioning of Phil's array of sworn enemies by the Old Bill is designed to boost ratings from the piddling 14 million before the shooting.

This would be good news for the BBC, and a partial explanation of why we are seeing a soap explosion: a new edition of Eastenders coming in the summer, the return of dear old Crossroads, Channel Five replacing its news with Home and Away, and Brookside beefing up its profile with grisly pictures of tied-up burglary victims. And all in the same week that Melvyn Bragg defends the cultural significance of Coronation Street .

Where does democracy come into all this? We now travel 5,000 miles across the Atlantic to Florida and the continuing fall-out from the presidential election. (It's a tenuous link, but bear with me.) Of all the shocking revelations to emerge from the shambles of the Florida voting procedures, perhaps the most scandalous was the purging of 64,000 mostly black or Hispanic 'criminals' from Florida's voting lists, the vast majority of whom were not criminals at all. The purge was undertaken under the auspices of Florida governor Jeb Bush, brother of the man who won Florida (and therefore the presidency) by fewer than 1,000 votes.

The story was broken in The Guardian and on the BBC's Newsnight by journalist and Observer columnist Gregory Palast. Writing this week for independent media website mediachannel.org, Palast told the story of how these astonishing facts never saw the light of day on US network television.

He was, he says, contacted by a CBS producer for some details. He told her that Jeb Bush's office had illegally removed the names of some voters who were entitled to vote, but that the details would need to be checked out. Next day, the CBS producer called with some bad news: the story didn't stand up. How did she know? 'We called Jeb Bush's office.' A simple denial from the person accused of mind-blowing political skulduggery and one of the wealthiest broadcasters in the world shrugs and walks away.

Palast advances a number of explanations for this corporate cowardice: too complex a story for the sound-bite culture; not enough journalistic time; fear of libel costs; and fear of provoking a political backlash (remember that Katharine Graham, proprietor of the Washington Post, nearly lost her TV franchises in the early Seventies as Nixon sought to 'discourage' the Watergate investigations). Finally, American news chiefs are quite convinced that viewers are simply not interested in politics.

This is the crux of the problem. For though large numbers of Americans are interested in politics, they seem to be outnumbered by those with a taste for Hollywood showbiz, gruesome crimes and all the other weird and wonderful tales that make up most of America's television news.

The dreadful state of American television journalism is confirmed by the story of WBBM, the CBS-owned channel in Chicago. Desperate to reverse its declining audience share in news, the station took the unprecedented step last February of switching to 'basic, old-fashioned journalism'. It would eschew the titillating and the trivial for more serious items. Sport and weather would be covered only when they were real stories, not just as cheap fillers. What happened? Collapse of audience, removal of serious news anchor and, in October last year, reinstatement of news as glamour and glitz.

America is not Britain, and it's possible that news appetites are different - but don't hold your breath. Far more important in the UK is a broadcasting system in which programmes are not treated as self-contained profit centres which must pay for themselves. On the commercial channels, the fact that each bulletin does not have to earn its keep means that editors don't worry about maximising viewers through sexy stories.

The BBC could pursue a worthier news agenda even if only 10 people watched. That's why we pay the licence fee. Except the absence of viewers would diminish the BBC and undermine the case for the licence fee. And how many government-sponsored broadcasters would report electoral corruption leading to the illegitimate victory of the current leader in a silent coup d'etat?

So there you have it: whoever plugged Phil, they are making a substantial contribution to British democracy for which we should all be profoundly grateful.

webTitle: It may be good business. It's patently not science

fields.headline: It may be good business. It's patently not science
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It is not often that the Government does something right, so let us raise a glass of free-range champagne this morning to the pinstriped officials of Her Majesty's Patent Office.
fields.body:
It is not often that the Government does something right, so let us raise a glass of free-range champagne this morning to the pinstriped officials of Her Majesty's Patent Office.

They have for some time been pondering the questions of whether UK patents should be granted for (a) computer software and (b) new ways of doing business. And they have come to broadly the right conclusions.

On the first question they have decided to reaffirm the principle that patents are for technological innovations, and that 'software should not be patentable where there is no technological innovation, and technological innovations should not cease to be patentable merely because the innovation lies in software'. Amen.

On the second issue - of whether so-called 'business method' patents should be allowed under UK law - they have rightly decided that these legal abominations have no attraction for this country.

This is an important and possibly far-reaching victory, because the Government is now committed to trying to persuade its European partners to take the same enlightened view.

A business process or business method patent is essentially a business idea - which may or may not have a technological basis - which is granted the protection of patent law. Going shopping on Wednesdays in a yellow car would be an example of a 'business method' within the meaning of the act. More famous instances are the patents Amazon.com holds on its 'one-click' online ordering process, and on its 'affiliates' programme - under which an affiliate site that signs up with Amazon gets a fee every time a book is bought from Amazon as a result of a click- through from that site.

Now both of these are smart business ideas, but they are not rocket science. Indeed they are not science of any description, and they do not deserve to be protected by patents. Until 1998 they were not, even in the US, despite many hopeful arguments to the contrary by men in suits.

In 1981 the suits got as far as the US Supreme Court - which ruled that methods of doing business were not patentable because they were nothing more than abstract ideas. And abstract ideas (along with 'laws of nature' and 'natural phenomena') were deemed to be beyond the reach of US patent law. This doctrine became known as the 'business method exception'.

All of this changed in 1998 when the US Court of Appeals decided that the exception was, in modern circumstances, 'ill-conceived' and ruled that that a patent claim may be 'directed toward or otherwise involve' a method of doing business.

This judgment opened the floodgates to a raft of business method patents like Amazon's infamous pair. The result is that virtually every conceivable online business idea is now patented by US entrepreneurs.

The long-term insanity of this has been eloquently pointed out by Lawrence Lessig and other distinguished commentators. The unique thing about the internet is that it is the first communications network we've had which is not owned by anyone and which is entirely permissive in what it is used for. Exploitation of the web is limited only by the ingenuity of those seeking to exploit it - which is what has given rise to the explosion of economic and other creativity generated by the web.

But that explosive creativity is precisely what the business method patent is designed to choke off. It means that the first employee a start-up will henceforth require is not an engineer or a gifted marketing director but the lawyer needed to find out who owns the business patents that the new firm intends to exploit, and how much a licence will cost.

This is the nightmare scenario that the UK Patent Office has decided to avoid. So let's hear it for the pin-striped suits.
