fields.headline: Paper tigers outrun the net
fields.standfirst:
To online publishers' despair, printed words are more efficient - and more profitable. Edward Helmore reports

MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: To online publishers' despair, printed words are more efficient - and more profitable. Edward Helmore reports
fields.body:
If you read this paper a year ago you would have been looking at what online publishers liked to call a 'legacy publication' - one printed on paper. The term summed up what they thought of newsprint: outmoded, outdated and soon to be sent the way of the telegram.

In those good old days, before the dotcom dream collapsed, online publishers could afford to be confident that the nimbleness of the internet would give them an edge over old media. When Slate and Salon were launched five years ago, it was amid claims that 'webzines' would become multimillion-dollar businesses and ruin print publications by stealing their readership and advertising. They were flush with venture capital, internet advertising was increasing, and readership was on the rise.

Even last year, when the important-sounding Powerful Media launched media website Inside.com just as the tech-stock bubble burst, confidence was still on their side. Not only would Inside.com have 30,000 subscribers forking out over $200 for the service within a year, but within three years that number would climb to 100,000 and it would be in profit. But like most businesses with a dotcom suffix, the reality turned grim. In the past year, subscriptions have dried up and advertising has deserted the internet. A dozen web-only publications have folded; others have had to retrench and revise their plans.

'Things look really bleak right now' for online content companies, says an analyst at Jupiter Communications. Many have given up trying to charge subscriptions and are instead building relationships with healthier partners. And with an irony not lost on 'legacy publications', many webzines have turned to what they once scorned - print.

'We realised pretty early on that being an independent, web-only provider was not entirely viable,' says Michael Hirschorn, editor and co-founder of Inside.com, which recently launched a print edition. Salon.com has cut staff and branched out into newsletters. Rival Slate, though somewhat protected by its owner, Microsoft, has also launched an edition that can be downloaded and printed out. They all have one aim: to build readership and hang on long enough for someone to work out how to make money publishing on the internet. That does not look likely to happen soon. Inside.com is understood to be looking for a buyer before it suffers a cash crunch; it is even holding talks with arch-rival Variety.

But analysts say the retrenchment does not signify a retreat from the internet as a means of communication. According to Jupiter Media Matrix, a New York research firm that tracks online readership, the number of people who go online for news and analysis is growing faster than that for any other medium. A similar pattern was observed during the infancies of cable, television and radio. This supports the argument that to judge the internet solely by stock valuation and profit is to miss the point. Slate publisher Scott Moore argues that the audience that matters is not Wall Street analysts and media critics but the readers. After all, Slate on the web attracts 2 million visitors a month.

'From my perspective, a lot of the negative stuff that has been written about internet content is from the perspective of Wall Street,' he told the New York Times . 'If you look at it from a users' perspective, online content is not only alive and well but thriving.' Some webzines, including those that found readers were unwilling to pay subscriptions, such as TheStreet.com, hope to start charging for their stories at some point. Others are likely to increase the space given to advertising. Currently online publishers devote only about 20 per cent of screen space to ads; the proportion for newspapers is 60 per cent.

Web content businesses are not alone in feeling a cold draught. Established print media companies have also cut back staff and investment in their online editions. Last week Pearson slashed $75m from the budget for FT.com. It was a significant move. Pearson poured $294m into its web operation last year, with the aim of making FT.com the world's 'leading global business portal'.

In recent months, companies from CNN to Condé Nast have scaled back their web ambitions, and the retrenchment mirrors a downturn in newspaper business. Last week, two of America's most powerful newspaper companies warned that they had been hit by the economic downturn. Dow Jones, publisher of the Wall Street Journal, said it would earn about a third as much as analysts had expected in the first quarter and would shed staff. The New York Times issued a similar earnings warning, and the San Jose Mercury News, in once-booming Silicon Valley, has also said it will lay off some employees.

Few online content businesses are immune. Last summer, book publishing giant Random House announced the debut of an e-book imprint, AtRandom.com. The company proclaimed that tech-savvy readers could use their computers to download the prose of writers such as Elizabeth Wurtzel, New Yorker staff writer Tad Friend and dotcom chronicler Po Bronson. New titles by these authors would be available only as e-books. But Wurtzel's Radical Sanity was downloaded just 40 times in the first two weeks of release. At $10 each, she has now sold 100 copies. Random House recently reversed its pledge and announced that it would, after all, offer print versions of its e-books.

'Words printed on a page provide a reading experience that is one we're accustomed to, but also, as it turns out, one that is extremely efficient,' says AtRandom.com editorial director Mary Bahr. 'A paperback is not enormously expensive for us to produce, or for the reader to buy.' Her sentiments are similar to those heard across business as the commercial realities of electronic information delivery become clear.

In the absence of revenue, a system launched last month by Amazon allows internet users to give money to their favourite, struggling webzines. The company launched the Amazon Honor System to take advantage of its 30 million credit card database and allow customers to donate. Surfers at participating sites can click on an image and be whisked to Amazon.com, where they can decide how much money to give, with donations beginning at one dollar. Amazon's servers recognise the person as a customer, charge the amount to the customer's card and pass the money to the website, minus 15 cents per donation, no matter what the size, and 15 per cent of the total as commission.

For some, the service has already proved a boon. Journalist Andrew Sullivan, former editor of the New Republic, raised more than $5,000 in the first 10 days his site andrewsullivan.com was hooked up to the system.

But others have yet to reap a windfall. In the first five weeks of operation, Modern Humorist has raised $565.99, SatireWire has pulled in $657 from 153 donors and E [as in Environmental] magazine just $11.

The programme launched with 50 sites, and Alan Kaplan, Amazon's vice-president of payment services, says that 'thousands' have signed on since. Chank Diesel, editor of Chank.com, says about $50 a week is flowing into his company through the honour system. 'We're not getting rich, but we're getting something,' he says. 'I guess you could make a living at it, but it's the honour system. You give people a choice to pay or not pay, and most aren't going to pay.'

Last week, two of America's most powerful newspaper companies warned that they had been hit by the economic downturn. Dow Jones, publisher of the Wall Street Journal, said it would earn about a third as much as analysts had expected in the first quarter and would shed staff. The New York Times issued a similar earnings warning, and the San Jose Mercury News, in once-booming Silicon Valley, has also said it will lay off some employees. Few online content businesses are immune. Last summer, book publishing giant Random House announced the debut of an e-book imprint, AtRandom.com. The company proclaimed that tech-savvy readers could use their computers to download the prose of writers such as Elizabeth Wurtzel, New Yorker staff writer Tad Friend and dotcom chronicler Po Bronson. New titles by these authors would be available only as e-books. But Wurtzel's Radical Sanity was downloaded just 40 times in the first two weeks of release. At $10 each, she has now sold 100 copies. Random House recently reversed its pledge and announced that it would, after all, offer print versions of its e-books. 'Words printed on a page provide a reading experience that is one we're accustomed to, but also, as it turns out, one that is extremely efficient,' says AtRandom.com editorial director Mary Bahr. 'A paperback is not enormously expensive for us to produce, or for the reader to buy.' Her sentiments are similar to those heard across business as the commercial realities of electronic information delivery become clear. In the absence of revenue, a system launched last month by Amazon allows internet users to give money to their favourite, struggling webzines. The company launched the Amazon Honor System to take advantage of its 30 million credit card database and allow customers to donate. Surfers at participating sites can click on an image and be whisked to Amazon.com, where they can decide how much money to give, with donations beginning at one dollar. Amazon's servers recognise the person as a customer, charge the amount to the customer's card and pass the money to the website, minus 15 cents per donation, no matter what the size, and 15 per cent of the total as commission. For some, the service has already proved a boon. Journalist Andrew Sullivan, former editor of the New Republic, raised more than $5,000 in the first 10 days his site andrewsullivan.com was hooked up to the system. But others have yet to reap a windfall. In the first five weeks of operation, Modern Humorist has raised $565.99, SatireWire has pulled in $657 from 153 donors and E [as in Environmental] magazine just $11. The programme launched with 50 sites, and Alan Kaplan, Amazon's vice-president of payment services, says that 'thousands' have signed on since. Chank Diesel, editor of Chank.com, says about $50 a week is flowing into his company through the honour system. 'We're not getting rich, but we're getting something,' he says. 'I guess you could make a living at it, but it's the honour system. You give people a choice to pay or not pay, and most aren't going to pay.'

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Formula gone
fields.body:
Formula gone

It's no surprise to seasoned watchers of Tom Rubython that his new magazine, F1 (backed by Bernie Ecclestone), is in the pits. After one issue, Formula One ace Nikki Lauda has resigned as editor-in-chief. To anyone ever involved with Rubython, this will be old news. When he launched the original Sunday Business, Rubython told everyone he had BBC economics supremo Peter Jay as a columnist. Er ... not true. As a close friend of Diary said : 'I wouldn't be surprised if the next issue of F1 carries James Hunt's byline.'

Mob-handed

Diary's avid reader, Andrew Neil, has a sane and wholly balanced theory for his growing unpopularity in the national press. Apparently a shadowy Irish media mafia are out to nobble the Presbyterian, Rangers-supporting army officer's son. Remember where you read it first. Diary, the column that is not afraid of the truth. No matter how bonkers it is.

Tim bomb

A top source (ahem) rings credulous Diary to punt what must be one of the most fantastical publishing stories de nos jours. Tim Waterstone, looking to raise funds to buy back his old company from HMV, is no longer looking for backing from venture capitalists PPM. No, he's looking for a deal with Jon 'didn't bag Rover' Moulton.

Apparently, the head of Alchemy Partners, which nearly bought the West Midlands car company from BMW last year, was seen entering Waterstone's office the other day. We ring Jon to test the theory. Unfortunately he's sunning himself abroad so, no dice. Then a 'pal' suggests that as the two men look somewhat alike, it could be a case of mistaken identity. Diary's three readers should be the judge. Were Tim and Jon separated at birth? Answers to Andrew Neil, Rue De La Conspiracy, France.

Never Too Late

Interesting article in Broadcast magazine the other day. A story headlined 'NTL scraps spring interactive plans' went on to recount how the hapless cable company has had to postpone the roll-out of its much-hyped enhanced TV service. Unfortunate, then, that on page 13 of same publication is a large ad from none other than NTL, boasting: 'You can trust us to deliver.' Yes, but when?

fields.headline: Murderers, not heroes
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: About six months after Veronica Guerin was murdered I was shown a wedding video starring John Gilligan. It was filmed on St Lucia in 1995 and showed Gilligan and his cohorts celebrating the marriage of one of his children. There were close-ups of Gilligan sipping champagne and singing 'Molly Malone'.
fields.body:
About six months after Veronica Guerin was murdered I was shown a wedding video starring John Gilligan. It was filmed on St Lucia in 1995 and showed Gilligan and his cohorts celebrating the marriage of one of his children. There were close-ups of Gilligan sipping champagne and singing 'Molly Malone'.

The camera focussed on some of the more unsavoury guests, such as Paul Ward, one of the men convicted of murdering Guerin. This tacky band of thuggish drug dealers from Dublin made the opulent surroundings look cheap.

The film was found by garda officers investigating Gilligan's gang and their role in the Guerin murder and the drugs trade. What this video depicted was a gang of criminals enjoying themselves on the backs of other people's misery. It should be screened in every school and college.

Gilligan was cleared of ordering Veronica's murder but he is thankfully behind bars this St Patrick's weekend, facing at least a decade of imprisonment. Hopefully one of the casualties of Gilligan's incarceration is the end of the criminal-as-sexy-rebel myth propagated by the media, particularly the movies.

The fascination in criminals has spawned a raft of films and television series glorifying the Gilligans of this world. Take John Boorman's The General, the biopic of Dublin master criminal Martin Cahill. The General managed to build Cahill up into a latter-day Robin Hood caught between the competing forces of the state (garda) and the IRA. The Dublin fraud investigator crippled by one of Cahill's bomb did not get a mention.

Since Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs, every rich kid director has been repeating that notorious backtracking shot of four funereally-suited criminals striding through their manor. The worst offender is public schoolboy Mockney Guy Ritchie and his awful film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. Ritchie has generated a cult out of the nattily dressed, Cockney-rhyming, diamond-geezer gangster. Rarely do we get to see those on the sharp end of crime, the victims and addicts hooked on drugs peddled by the Gilligans of this world. The Sopranos may be vastly superior, but there is still something morally dubious about the obsessive focus on the central character, Tony, the tortured soul on the psychiatrist's chair, to the detriment of his many victims.

The criminal as cinematic sex symbol is most acute in the Mafia movies, particularly Coppola's Godfather films. While they are art, they fail to convey the corrupting Mafia influence on public life.

Excellent Cadavers, written by the New York Times 's Robert Stilles, details the war against the Cosa Nostra in Italy, especially the heroic efforts of investigating magistrates such as Paolo Borsellino and Giovanni Falcone. What comes across is an organisation bent on subverting the will of the people and destroying the democratic core of the Italian republic. It is Borsellino and Falcone, both murdered, rather than the Mafia dons who are heroes. The Kenneth Noyes and real-life Tony Sopranos of this world are trash compared to brave men and women like Borsellino and Falcone, or indeed the garda officers who put Gilligan behind bars.

After Gilligan was sentenced, Judge Dairmuid O'Donovan said: 'Never before in the history of the state has one man been responsible for so much wretchedness to so many.' These words should be an impetus to Irish film-makers to look at the underworld through the lens of those seeking to thwart Gilligan and the legions of other wannabe drugs barons who destroy so many lives.

It is probably a throwback to our colonised past, but the deep mistrust of authority has left art entwined with the outlaw. But that was then and this is now. It is time to shatter the image of powerful criminals as the romantic Rob Roys of the Republic and start portraying in a more realistic light those that, in Judge O'Donovan's own words, 'cause a haemorrhage of harm'.

fields.headline: You couldn't make it up...
fields.standfirst: As two new films satirise the excesses of TV   Adam Smith  asks  why does Hollywood always sneer at the small screen?
fields.trailText: As two new films satirise the excesses of TV Adam Smith asks why does Hollywood always sneer at the small screen?
fields.body:
The rules are simple: contestants don't volunteer, they are selected at random. They are assigned a TV crew and a gun. They are given a list of names. They must kill these people. Or be killed themselves. Welcome to Series 7: The Contenders.

Happily, this latest demented instalment of reality TV exists only as the central conceit of a movie. But though it's a low-budget indie debut, film critics who caught its first showing at the Sundance Film Festival are saying it is set to be this year's Blair Witch Project.

The makers encourage that comparison by using the gimmick of a website that pretends the whole thing is real. There you'll find the eight-month pregnant reigning Series 7 champion, who is prone to dietary cravings and mood swings while she continues her murder spree. 'Have you got any bean dip?' she demands of a terrified store clerk after yet another televised slaying.

This is a world where teens give each other bullet-proof vests as tokens of their puppy love, and it's all packaged with the zappy graphics and sloganeering of tabloid TV: 'Real People. Real Danger. In A Fight For Their Lives!'

The film has its origins in writer/ director Daniel Minahan's background in reality TV. After working with fellow cutting edge director Mary Harron ( I Shot Andy Warhol, American Psycho) on BBC arts programmes in the Eighties, he ended up working for Rupert Murdoch's Fox network, producing MTV-ish 'news' segments. After the rarefied atmosphere of The Late Show, it wasn't a happy experience. 'I got a real taste of corporate television,' he says. 'Part of what the film is about is what I learnt about the exploitation and representation of people in those shows.'

Series 7 isn't the only big screen take on small screen culture coming our way. John Herzfeld's Fifteen Minutes stars Kelsey Grammer as a sleazy tabloid TV host who pursues a pair of psychotic mass murderers for a videotape of their crimes, and Robert De Niro as a media-dazzled cop. It's a film which alleges that television is complicit in promoting the violence and mayhem it pretends to condemn while simultaneously serving it up, pre-edited and packaged to a ravenous public.

Hollywood's sniping at the small screen might appear disingenuous in a week when US courts, after much legal hand-wringing, dismissed a lawsuit against Oliver Stone and the makers of Natural Born Killers which alleged that it was the cause of a shooting in Louisiana in 1995. But, of course, it's nothing new. Hollywood's strained relationship with television goes back to the early Fifties. The birth of TV horrified movie executives who feared that audiences would rather stay home than travel to the cinema. Not only that, but television offered something movies couldn't: real people. The quiz shows and soaps that crammed those early TV schedules were filled with people and situations your average American householder could instantly recognise - a world away from the glitz that Hollywood had made its own.

The result was that TV was at first ignored - try spotting a television set in any living room from a Fifties movie - and then rubbished. Actors weighed in, Groucho Marx famously remarking that he found television a fabulously educative medium. 'Whenever someone turns it on I go into another room and read a good book,' he informed America. (That didn't stop him hosting a quiz show, however.)

Dirk Bogarde refused to appear on the smaller screen at all. 'I don't want my audience going for a piss or making tea while I work,' he reasoned.

By the Seventies, satire had become Hollywood's favoured mode of attack. Writer Paddy Chayefski and director Sidney Lumet fashioned a masterpiece in Network (1976), complete with Peter Finch's immortal mantra 'I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take it anymore!' It painted television as a medium so corrupt that it would exploit a man's nervous breakdown and screen his suicide in the name of ratings.

And as it got harder and harder on television, Hollywood was noticeably soft on itself. With the possible exception of The Player (1992) - director Robert Altman genuinely loathes the movie business - satires about Hollywood tended to be of the ever-so-gently self-deprecating type. Sweet Liberty (1986), with Alan Alda directing and starring, The Big Picture (1989), directed by Christopher Guest and starring Kevin Bacon, and indie fare such as Tom DiCillo's Living In Oblivion (1994) all took a soft line. Hey, they said, Hollywood might be insane, corrupt and venal, but it's all just a bit of a laugh really.

Things settled down a little in the Nineties. With the exception of The Truman Show and Natural Born Killers, movies about television tended to be gentle comedies (Soapdish, Groundhog Day) or soapish dramas (Broadcast News, Up Close And Personal). Part of the reason, no doubt, was that the major studios were now all heavily involved in producing television programmes themselves and cross-fertilising between the two media. Successful television series could be given the big screen treatment (The X Files, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Star Trek: The Next Generation) while failed movie projects could be transferred to the small screen and given a lucrative new lease of life (Buffy The Vampire Slayer).

And although one of last year's Oscar Best Picture nominations, The Insider, was an intelligent exposé of the vested interests within a US TV news network, it was the exception that proves the rule.

All of which provokes the question: what rocked the apple cart? Why the sudden recommencement of hostilities? For a start there may be the creeping realisation that, in quality terms at least, television has been outperforming cinema for at least the past decade. Few big screen comedies have been as deftly written as Seinfeld, Frasier or The Simpsons at their best. It's difficult to find a cop movie as well acted as NYPD Blue or a crime thriller as compelling as Murder One.

Then there's the small matter of Washington's avowed intent to clean up Hollywood. With censorious eyes from both main parties directed towards the movie business, now would be the perfect time to nod towards the small screen and its excesses.

But most of all, movies like Series 7 and Fifteen Minutes point to the fact that with reality TV the small screen has come up with a format that movies can neither emulate nor top. While in drama and comedy the two are at least theoretically evenly matched, in this new arena Hollywood has no way of competing with its precocious younger relation. Satire is the only option.

We should be worried. Only a few years ago the idea that audiences would tune into a show dedicated to watching the minutiae of everyday life from all angles was a ludicrous proposition aptly captured in Peter Weir's The Truman Show. Then came Big Brother, and the stuff of speculative satire became reality.

The current vogue for reality TV is beyond satire, especially in the States. Imagine just a few years back pitching a show where long-term couples were separated and had their relationships deliberately tested (Temptation Island). Or a survival programme where the viewing highlight will be a middle-class group's clumsy attempts to slaughter a pig (Survivor). You'd have been laughed at. But it all came true.

And with current formats running out of steam the last thing we need is some telly executive staring at a screening of Fifteen Minutes and wondering 'what if ...'

Fifteen Minutes opens next Friday and Series 7 on 1 June. Official website is www.series7movie.com

webTitle: All good people go to haven

fields.headline: All good people go to haven
fields.standfirst: A mother seeks asylum from a grim life in Moscow, and ends up in an equally grim Margate
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...it's less a picture about the problems of refugees than a transposition to Europe of a longstanding Hollywood feminist genre that one might call 'the relocation movie'
fields.body:
The first feature film by the highly regarded, Polish-born, London-based documentary director Pawel Pawlikowski, Last Resort, arrives in the cinema garlanded with praise and prizes from various festivals. As well as winning the Michael Powell Award at Edinburgh, it recently received Bafta's Carl Foreman Award for Most Promising Newcomer to British film. It is not at all a bad picture, and deals with a timely subject, though the acclaim is something of a reflection on the indifferent state of our native cinema.

The plight of the refugee has been a subject for movies since the exodus of Nazi victims from Germany in the 1930s; indeed, Casablanca, one of the most popular pictures of all time, turns upon political fugitives caught in that no man's land between emigration and immigration.

There was a tradition, in Britain at least, of treating such matters as comedy, as cat-and-mouse games between rigid bureaucrats and wily immigrants - one thinks of Michael Hastings's play Gloo Joo, and Michael Poliakoff's Coming in to Land. Recent pictures have been more sombre - a string of pictures about refugees from the former Yugoslavia, and three Ken Loach films featuring Latin Americans, Carla's Song, Ladybird Ladybird and Bread and Roses.

Last Resort occupies an odd position between these two streams. The heroine, Tanya (Dina Korzun), is a pretty young Russian, a would-be children's book illustrator, twice married and divorced, coming to London with her streetwise 10-year-old son, Artiom (Artiom Strelnikov), to join her British fiancé. When he reveals his suspected fecklessness by not turning up to meet her at the airport, Tanya claims in an amusing encounter with a jargon-spouting immigration officer, played by Perry Benson, a familiar exponent of comic ineptitude, that she's really seeking political asylum.

In consequence, she and Artiom are bused off to a holding area for refugees in the bleak, off-season seaside town of Stonehaven (actually Margate). They're billeted in a crumbling tower- block as awful as anything in the suburbs of Moscow or Warsaw, and along with refugees from a hundred other places they're observed by CCTV, monitored by police with dogs, and made to exist without work on vouchers for which no change is ever given.

The cold, overcast, thinly-populated Stonehaven is a reflection of Tanya's state of mind, though despite Artiom calling it 'the armpit of the world', it is not put down socially the way Margate was in Lindsay Anderson's 1953 short, O Dreamland, a documentary of Larkinesque misanthropy. Certainly, Tanya and Artiom are strangers in a strange land, but Last Resort is no documentary and indeed is frequently implausible.

In fact, it's less a picture about the problems of refugees than a transposition to Europe of a longstanding Hollywood feminist genre that one might call 'the relocation movie'. In these films, a blue-collar widow or divorcée pulls up her stakes and, with a querulous son or daughter in tow, drives west in search of a new life and to realise her dreams.

Always she encounters two men - one seductive, brutal and exploitative, the other gentle, gauche and helpful - and suffers bitter disappointment and briefly neglects her troubled teenage child before coming to terms with reality. Martin Scorsese's Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore is the most famous example, the Susan Sarandon vehicle Anywhere But Here among the most recent.

Last Resort touches all the bases of this genre. The bad guys are a pair of filmmakers who inveigle her into participating in erotic videos for the internet. The good guy (attractively played by Paddy Considine, the psychopathic swain in A Room for Romeo Brass) is a simple arcade owner and bingo-caller, recovering from a difficult childhood and a jail stretch for GBH.

Generously and disinterestedly, he helps the pair and saves Artiom from the band of juvenile thieves he's fallen in with. A beached boat that offers her the hope of escape is called Lucky Lady.

Tanya's pivotal line is pure Hollywood and might well have been spoken by Ellen Burstyn in Alice: 'I have to stop dreaming. I've been dreaming all my life. I've got to go back and restart my life.'
fields.bodyText: The first feature film by the highly regarded, Polish-born, London-based documentary director Pawel Pawlikowski, Last Resort, arrives in the cinema garlanded with praise and prizes from various festivals. As well as winning the Michael Powell Award at Edinburgh, it recently received Bafta's Carl Foreman Award for Most Promising Newcomer to British film. It is not at all a bad picture, and deals with a timely subject, though the acclaim is something of a reflection on the indifferent state of our native cinema. The plight of the refugee has been a subject for movies since the exodus of Nazi victims from Germany in the 1930s; indeed, Casablanca, one of the most popular pictures of all time, turns upon political fugitives caught in that no man's land between emigration and immigration. webTitle: The Bonesetter's Daughter by Amy Tan read by Lorelei King and Pik-Sen Lim

fields.headline: The Bonesetter's Daughter by Amy Tan read by Lorelei King and Pik-Sen Lim
fields.trailText: A many-layered tale of the complex relationship between mothers and daughters.
fields.body:
The Bonesetter's Daughter
Amy Tan
Read by Lorelei King and Pik-Sen Lim
Running time 3 hrs
HarperCollins £8.99

The mystery of China has always been an evocative subject for fiction. Perhaps it is the old superstitions and legends that provoke such passion. The Bonesetter's Daughter is a story based on such superstition. It is a many-layered tale of the complex relationship between mothers and daughters.

It begins in present-day San Francisco with LuLing, a Chinese woman in her eighties whose senial dementia is exacerbated by the guilt she feels for the death of Precious Auntie, the 'nursemaid' of her childhood in China and the daughter of the bonesetter, a woman with a blackened, scarred face and burned mouth, who only 'blind beggars could bear to look upon'.

It is also the story of Ruth, LuLing's daughter, who has been brought up in America and who, at 46, moves in with her ailing mother to look after her. As a petulant teenager, she played on her mother's superstitious nature and only in adulthood discovers the extent of the hurt she caused. It is no secret that Amy Tan wrote a first draft of this book after her mother had been diagnosed with Alzheimer's and that there are similarities between Ruth and Tan.

The other thing about Chinese fiction is that it sounds good. Lorelei King is faultless without stealing the show from Pik-Sen Lim, who obviously delights in the richness and tragedy of a Chinese imagination.

webTitle: Classicwatch: The People of the Sea

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Subtitled 'Celtic Tales of the Seal-Folk', David Thomson's strange and haunting account of his travels through the Gaelic communities of the Scottish islands was first published in 1954.
fields.body:
The People of the Sea
By David Thomson; introduction by Seamus Heaney
Canongate £6.99, pp229
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Subtitled 'Celtic Tales of the Seal-Folk', David Thomson's strange and haunting account of his travels through the Gaelic communities of the Scottish islands was first published in 1954.

The book is far richer than a mere travelogue, however; Thomson blends Gaelic legend with glimpses of a way of life almost unchanged for centuries and on the verge of disappearing. The crofters and fishermen he encounters live in a misty world where the edges of myth and reality, sea and land become blurred; their stories are the fables passed down the generations, largely concerned with the anthropomorphic myth of the Selkie, or grey seal.

Heaney's warm introduction places great value on Thomson's style and imaginative sympathy: 'His writing combines a feel for the "this-worldness" of his characters' lives with an understanding of the "otherworldness" they keep a place for in their consciousness.'

The People of the Sea is a unique and beautiful literary achievement.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: Conversations with Wilder

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: This book began in 1995 when former rock journalist and then little known writer-director Cameron Crowe took Tom Cruise with him to persuade his idol, the 89-year-old Billy Wilder, to make a cameo appearance in Jerry Maguire.
fields.body:
Conversations with Wilder
Cameron Crowe
Faber £12.99, pp376
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This book began in 1995 when former rock journalist and then little known writer-director Cameron Crowe took Tom Cruise with him to persuade his idol, the 89-year-old Billy Wilder, to make a cameo appearance in Jerry Maguire. Wilder refused. But when Crowe's account of their meeting appeared in a diary about the making of Jerry Maguire that Crowe wrote for Rolling Stone, a friend of Wilder's, Karen Lerner, suggested a book along the lines of Truffaut's Hitchcock. She is credited as editorial consultant on the handsomely designed result.

Unlike the chronological Truffaut-Hitchcock encounter, this is a rambling affair, jumping back and forth in time. But as the pair meet over two years in Wilder's spartan office, his luxurious home and restaurants, we observe the growing friendship between a young director and a maestro who has not made a movie in 20 years.

This is a riveting book that captures Wilder's wary, puckish personality and razor-sharp mind bet ter than any other study, and there are nuggets on every page. We learn that the inspiration for his favourite film, The Apartment, came from the tryst at the friend's flat in Brief Encounter. To Wilder, Battleship Potemkin is 'the greatest movie ever made', Charles Laughton 'the greatest actor who ever lived', Dean Martin 'the funniest man in Hollywood'. He acknowledges Ernst Lubitsch as his chief influence and had the sign 'How would Lubitsch do it?' above his desk, and though he loathed working with Chandler he learnt from him 'what real dialogue is'. Bing Crosby ('the great stylist') he prefers to Sinatra.

His two great regrets are not having worked with Cary Grant and not being able to direct Schindler's List as a memorial to his mother and other family members killed at Auschwitz. But he speaks warmly of Steven Spielberg's film, and is generously disposed to the younger generation of moviemakers while being generally pessimistic about the industry. Of his own aspirations he says, modestly, that 'it interested me to lift the taste of the average person, just lift it up a little bit'.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Carol Shields is shackled by the everyday, plus Tamara de Lempicka, Saddam Defiant and Beneath the Skin
fields.body:
Dressing up for the Carnival
Carol Shields
Fourth Estate £6.99, pp249
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As an avatar of the author argues in 'Ilk', the sixth story here: 'A narrative isn't... perpetually thrusting. It's this little... cottage by the side of the road... [It] doesn't need a fully rigged sailing vessel... A footstool is all it needs.' While limiting oneself to chronicling the small losses and gains of small lives can be a spur to creativity, here reality seems to shackle more than it inspires.

Shields can evoke a carnival - as 'all over town people are putting on their costumes' - simply by describing everyday events. At her best, she can persuade you to fall in love with a girl writing about Thomas Tallis 'because he's second best'. At her least good, she has no shortage of elegantly phrased observations about the joys (and joylessness) of food, shopping and relationships. But there still seem to be a few too many footstools and not enough sailing-ships.

Tamara de Lempicka: A Life of Deco and Decadence
Laura Claridge
Bloomsbury £8.99, pp437
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The painting as schematic; the model as titanic brutalist edifice; the voluptuary as a virtual landscape; the nude an orgy (but never a riot) of geometric shapes - de Lempicka imbued her portraits of tycoons and terebinths with an android sexuality all her own. The artistic axiom to paint 'hot and cold together' has rarely been so excitingly reinterpreted as in her mingling of cubism and concupiscence.

De Lempicka's genuine decadence (as opposed to mere lip service to the pre-modernist conception of the artist as libertine) almost doomed her to critical ignominy, but in the wake of an Eighties revival, she has been reinstated (or finally acknowledged) as an innovator and at last given a painstakingly detailed, often fascinating biography that seems to omit nothing, in terms of both candour and scholarship.

Lost White Tribes: A Journeys Among the Forgotten
Riccardo Orizio
Vintage £7.99, pp271
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As if, just as the global village becomes a global hamlet, an immense forest were to appear beyond the Thank You For Driving Carefully sign, so this is a book that makes the world a larger and stranger place, seeming to collapse history with its foretaste of the end of Eurocentricity. Lost White Tribes may be non-fiction - a history of the white colonists who went native, intermarried and became the lowest rather than highest caste - but it has the mystique of a Ballard or Vonnegut novel.

Haitian Poles with a cult-like anticipation of the Pope's return; Ceylonese Dutch burghers working as waiters and living in crumbling mansions; German slaves in Jamaica: almost too odd to be true, but never objectified, these fossil cultures and the lives of pioneer ancestors are sympathetically treated. Their untold histories would have been extraordinary even without such a fine raconteur as Orizio.

Saddam Defiant: The Threat of Weapons of Mass Destruction and the Crisis of Global Security
Richard Butler
Phoenix £7.99, pp271
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Ten years on and little has changed with regards to the Iraqi situation (indeed history seems to be turning in an ever-narrowing gyre, as Dubya gears up for a reprise). What's taken us so long? Put simply: business interests. In 1999, Russia's policy of abstention on the issue of sanctions - in order to protect their trade with Iraq - spooked France enough to delay further, and the dithering goes on. Butler's account of the vacillations and ineffectuality of the supposed peacekeepers of the free world is thorough and never preachy, but he lacks the journalistic skills (of, say, Naomi Klein) to really inflame public consciousness. The global perspective appears too infrequently; a shame when there is so much evidence here to damn the money-before-morality policy that plagued the past, bloodiest of centuries.

 Michael Mellor

Beneath the Skin
Nicci French
Penguin £6.99, pp370
Buy it at a discount at BOL

With this, their third joint project, husband-and-wife writing team Sean and Nicci French have produced a seamless psychological thriller that builds up the tension with perfect dramatic timing and will have you double-checking your locks every night for a long time to come.

The narrative is divided between the italicised internal monologue of the stalker and would-be killer, and the stories of the three women he threatens with chilling letters and drawings over the course of a hot, oppressive London summer: Zoe Haratounian, a young schoolteacher; Jennifer Hintlesham, a wealthy housewife and mother; and Nadia Blake, a bubbly children's entertainer. As in the best cinema thrillers, the suspense comes from what the author doesn't show you; the killer's calculating voice is used sparingly, but the women's detailed accounts of the minutiae of their own lives - how they put on their make-up, the meals they make - creates a sense of uneasy voyeurism in the reader.

This is an astute study of the destructive effects of terror on ordinary lives, and the way men exert power over women. But don't be fooled into thinking you can predict the book's climax; French keeps the strings brilliantly taut until the end

 Shelley Craig

fields.headline: They're talking our language
fields.standfirst: Britain may have lost an empire, but it has gained a planet. Now all of us, from Filipino judges to Basque fishermen, conduct our business in English - and that includes the French
fields.trailText: Britain may have lost an empire, but it has gained a planet. Now all of us, from Filipino judges to Basque fishermen, conduct our business in English - and that includes the French
fields.body:
In Septmber 1977 the Nasa spacecraft Voyager One blasted off on its historic unmanned mission to Jupiter and beyond. On board, the scientists, who knew that intrepid capsule would one day spin through distant star systems, had installed a recorded greeting from the people of the planet Earth. Preceding brief messages in 55 languages for any inhabitants of outer space, the gold-plated disc played (and still plays) a longish statement from the then secretary-general of the United Nations, an Austrian named Kurt Waldheim, speaking on behalf of 147 member states - in English.

Twenty-five years ago, Nasa's choice of language was as controversial as the man who uttered its bland but historic sentences. Today it looks more than slightly prophetic. At the dawn of a new millennium, if ever a language had the right to represent the planet to distant galaxies, it is the language one that more and more commentators refer to as 'global English'.

In the European Year of Languages, it's English that dominates not only the international scene - that's old news - but also, incredibly, the European linguistic map. If you put to any European the simple proposition that everyone should speak English, you probably would not be surprised to learn that 70 per cent of Britons and 82 per cent of Dutch people concur. You might raise an eyebrow at the 76 per cent of Italians who share this point of view. But you would be gobsmacked - dare I say bouleversé ? - to discover that in France, home of that supremely civilising international force la langue Française, an astounding 66 per cent of those questioned in a Eurobarometer poll, said it would be a good idea if the people of Europe spoke English.

OK, it's only a poll, but after decades of French government propaganda and even legislation in defence of the beleaguered French tongue, supported at the highest level by presidents of left and right from Giscard to Chirac (who always uses French to the 'Anglo-Saxon' media) it represents a jolt to French linguistic self-esteem. After the substitution by the French Academy of unequivocally French words for 'la langue du Coca-Cola" (for example capitaux febriles for 'hot money', gros porteur for 'jumbo jet' and pr t à manger ' for 'fast food'), the news that two-thirds of French people are now acknowledging the superior usefulness of English will come as a blow to those, like the late Georges Pompidou, who believed 'we must not let the idea take hold that English is the only possible instrument for industrial, economic and scientific communication'.

'We've won the battle,' says Charles Tannuck, a Conservative MEP sitting in his office high in the European Parliament. He adds, as an afterthought: 'Though we have to thank Uncle Sam for this.'

It's all happened so fast: 25 years ago the nascent global supremacy of English was inextricably bound up with US power and US technology. In hindsight, the high point of Anglo-American linguistic hegemony was the launch of the Voyager space probe with its message of 'peace and goodwill' for the people of outer space. From that moment, British and more particularly American English acquired a supranational momentum which has, so far, proved unstoppable.

The speed with which this astonishing linguistic revolution has occurred mirrors the speed at which change in communications technology has transformed the world's media. Just 20 years ago, when I was involved in the making of a BBC television series about the evolution of English, The Story of English, there was no CNN, no online OED, no Wap phones and absolutely no world wide web. So anxious were we to avoid a historically suspect linguistic triumphalism that it was an unwritten production rule never to refer to our subject as 'the world's first global language', even though all the signs were there to read. In those far-off days we were excited to find European truck companies such as Iveco transacting business exclusively in English, or SAS and Air Italia pilots transmitting only in English, or those first, cumbersome personal computers storing data predominantly in English. Now, in the year 2001, all that seems rather quaint.

If, as I have argued before in The Observer, we are living through a second Gutenberg Revolution, we are also the helpless, and possibly fortunate, witnesses to the apparent realisation of one of mankind's oldest and deepest dreams - the end of Babel. Or, to put it another way, the traditional language kaleidoscope - an entrancing, many coloured, fractured thing derived from the Greek kalos (beautiful) and eidos (form) - has become closer to something I'd want to christen a kal-anglo-scope.

Look through the kalangloscope of global English and you will find Greek and Finnish translators at the European Commission in Brussels translating EU business from minority languages like Czech or Turkish via English. Down the road in the Parlia ment building you will find Dutch, Swedish, Spanish and Irish delegates arguing at the bar in English. At the Commission's headquarters, the Italian deputy head of President Prodi's private office likes to pepper his conversation with lines from Yes Minister. 'That was a courageous argument,' he will say, with a knowing wink to his mystified fellow Europeans.

Charles Tannuck, a thoughtful Eurosceptic who actually speaks at least four European languages, says the MEPs who can't speak English in Brussels have a 'miserable time'. None of this, of course, means Europeans are abandoning their mother tongues - far from it - but it does strongly suggest that if there's an internationally acknowledged lingua franca it is English.

Elsewhere in the world we find Israeli businessmen doing deals in English with European partners in Johannesburg, who will in turn pass on the terms and conditions of the contracts to their local Zulu-speaking South African subsidiaries. Turn the kalangloscope again, and we find European Commission civil servants defending fishing quotas with Basque tuna fishermen, then parrying inquiries from the Spanish media - all in English. And across the globe in the Philippines, the Estrada corruption trial was almost exclusively an English language affair.

Focus the kalangloscope on Europe and you find that last year the Swiss-German cantons of Switzerland caused a local sensation when they voted to adopt English in place of French as their official second language, after German.

In the world of the kalangloscope, presidential contenders, trades union leaders, terrorists, Nobel laureates, tennis players and independent film-makers all use English as the essential medium for putting their message across internationally. During the Nato intervention in Kosovo, the public face of the operation was conducted on all sides, even by the Serbs, in English.

Overnight, the world moved from a situation of sustained superpower conflict to a condition of US superpower predominance. Just as in the early Middle Ages it was Latin, the language both of the defunct Roman Empire and of the resurgent and all-powerful Roman Catholic church, that held sway throughout Europe, so in the aftermath of the revolutions of 1989, it was American English, underpinned by US culture and fashion and US media, that carried the English language into the furthest corners of the globe. Blue jeans and Hollywood movies played their part in this, but it was Cruise missiles and Stealth bombers that became crucial to the process. Language has always been about power first, culture and learning second. A language, as the saying goes, is 'a dialect with an army and a navy'.

In the aftermath of the Soviet collapse there was a global flight from the Russian language. Quickly, in countries as diverse as China, Russia and Brazil, the language most commonly taught as a foreign language became English. Parts of Europe formerly under Soviet domination - the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Romania - switched enthusiastically to English as a lingua franca.

In strictly European terms this is not entirely logical.There are, for instance, far more German-speakers in the EU. But not only has German been shunned, in Germany itself there are now fears that English threatens the native tongue in the way it was once perceived to threaten French. In recent months a proposed 'language purification law' (against the invasion of English nouns, verbs and adjectives) has received widespread support from academics, linguists and politicians. This movement wants to impose hefty fines on any German caught using the bastardised tongue known as 'Denglisch'. Similar movements to defend the mother tongue from English are found in Spain and Brazil.

'Flirt', 'baby', 'power', 'administration' and 'underwear' have become an everyday part of German vocabulary, joining other English imports such as 'kidnap', 'relax' and 'pick-up'.

Senator Eckhart Werthebach, a conservative politician, is the moving spirit behind the Language Purification Law. He wants, he says, to protect German from extinction. 'Our language is being abandoned thanks to a growth in Americanisms. Older, less educated people, and foreigners living in Germany who don't speak English, are excluded,' he says.

The Language Purification Law sounds bizarre, but it has popular backing. A recent magazine poll showed that 53 per cent of Germans are against the use of English words. Another survey showed that English words like 'shopping', 'happy', 'event' and 'statement' have largely cancelled out their German equivalents. English terms like 'slow-motion', 'last-minute' and 'highlights' have usurped homegrown words. Some of these expressions are based on comical German misunderstandings of English slang. In Denglisch a 'handy' is a 'mobile phone'.

The German Language Union's chairman, Professor Walter Kramer, said: 'We protest at the totally one-sided takeover by English expressions.'

In the European Union, German is one of the so-called 'working languages'. But virtually no one, apart from the poor old Germans, uses it. Even French, the traditional language of foreign affairs, is under pressure from English. A European parliamentarian like Charles Tannuck says he is keen 'not to destroy national culture' but a moment later will agree that for EU email 'the default language is always English'.

Tannuck, who has thought deeply about the language question, is a far cry from the kind of Eurosceptic who displays photographs of RAF Spitfires on his office wall. He sees himself as a pragmatist. He says: 'If we want a really successful single market, all documents, all road signs, every piece of official information should be in English as well as in the national language.'

He stresses the feasibility of this by pointing out that 75 per cent of European children are now learning English in school. This Eurosceptic says that, paradoxical as it may seem: 'If you believe in a strong European identity, English is vital.' He thinks it's time to put the language question on the political agenda - which would certainly make a change from the interminable debates about the euro.

History is on his side. After the Nice summit, the planned enlargement of the EU to incorporate former Soviet-bloc countries such as Hungary, Estonia, Bulgaria and Slovakia is going to deal a body blow to the use of the French language in community affairs. Steve Morris, a Commission spokesman, notes that English is now 'everybody's second language'. For the first time in the history of the EU, the Commission's spokesman, Jonathan Faull, is English. To illustrate the dominance of English, Morris says that he gave up going to his Italian language classes because he found his fellow students always answered him in English. He acknowledges that the language question is 'an emotive issue', but points out that, de facto, 'it's difficult to find somewhere in Europe where they don't speak English'.

Away from the European heartland, the end of the Soviet imperium meant something else, too - the proliferation of small, independent states (Croatia and Bosnia, for example) which, while fiercely nationalistic about their mother tongues, have been only too eager to establish English As A Foreign Language on their campuses and in their business schools. Where, in the days of the USSR, there were fewer than 150 UN member states, now in the globalised world of the new century there are more than 180 UN member states for whom American English is the second language of choice after the mother tongue.

The figures tell their own story. According to the best estimates available, English is now the first language of about 380 million mother tongue speakers, based in traditionally English-speaking countries such as Britain, Australia and the United States. Add to this approximately 350 million second language English speakers in countries like India, Nigeria and Singapore, and a staggering further 500-1,000 million people in countries like China, Japan and Russia that acknowledge the importance of global English as an agent of global capitalism, and you arrive at a total of nearly 2,000 million - at least a third of the world's population. It's further estimated that by 2050 no less than half the world's population will be competent in English.

For these participants in the global kalangloscope the dominant tone is the American of American English. American English is a vast and complex subject that traces back to the landing of a few English-speaking settlers in Jamestown, Virginia, and then at Plimouth Rock in New England. The resulting marriage of unbridled, pioneering adventurism and straitlaced puritan simplicity was a variety of English that is both marvellously innovative and yet capable of a positively Calvinist precision and understatement.

In its infancy, American English played wayward child to its unbending British parent. Later, as the British Empire, which had done so much to spread English across the globe, declined, the story of the English language became a tale of American world domination. First, and most obvious, there is the contribution of US culture: Hollywood movies, the advertising of Madison Avenue and the newspapers and television channels of the great media corporations such as Time-Warner and CBS. Second, there's the role played by the scientific community in the dissemination of Anglo-American usage. Although there is now decisive evidence that English is being challenged on the net by other languages, the first decade of activity has been a familiar tale of English language domination (80 per cent of home pages on the web are in English, compared to 4.5 per cent German and 3.1 per cent Japanese.)

Finally, there's trade and tourism. As Naomi Klein has shown in No Logo, multinational trade, tearing up frontier restrictions in a kind of capitalist hurricane, has spread English into the export processing zones of Far East Asia, into the sweatshops of Bangkok and Shanghai and into the hypermarkets of Japan and Korea.

The commercial logic described in No Logo goes hand in hand with the package deal. Tourism and mass consumerism are opposite sides of the same coin. The language of Thomas Cook, of Mastercard and of Sheraton is English - in hundreds of thousands of kalangloscopic transactions every day.

The success of English sometimes induces a kind of triumphalism that is inappropriate. If English today is a global phenomenon, this is due to non-linguistic forces, not because it has unique or special qualities. Despite the myths, English is, from some points of view, a spectacularly bad choice as the world's leading language. It is not easier to learn than French or Russian. It is not more beautiful, mellifluous or eloquent than Italian or German, or any other language. Such judgments are almost meaningless. Mellifluous for whom?

English is, moreover, highly idiomatic. How do we begin to explain such phrases as 'put up with' or 'get on with it'? English also has some impossible characteristics. ' Th' is famously difficult for foreigners. There are some rare and difficult vowels: the vowel-sound in 'bird' and 'nurse' occurs in virtually no other language. The 13 spellings for a sound like sh - shoe, sugar, issue, mansion, mission, nation, suspicion, ocean, conscious, chaperon, schist, fuschia and pshaw - are a source of weakness, not strength.

Weak or strong, global English now has a supranational momentum that has set it free from the political fates of Britain and the United States. The colossal global financial underpinning of the language ensures its continued supremacy. The estimated gross language product (GLP - the money generated by language-related commerce) of English is $7,815 billion, compared to $2,455bn for German and $1,789bn for Spanish.

Even so, there are signs that a resurgent multilingualism will keep the spread of global English in check. David Crystal, a leading commentator on the English language, says you find 'a rampant multilingualism on the web. People are adopting English for intelligibility and their local language for identity.'

This is an important development, possibly even a turning-point. Crystal and others have argued that one of the negative consequences of global English has been an acceleration of 'language death' - the disappearance of minority languages in predominantly English-speaking parts of the world. In almost every quarter of the globe there are shocking examples of language death to be found.

There are, of course, numerous contra-indications. In America some see Spanish as a real challenge to the primacy of English. Closer to home, Jack Straw recently publicised his efforts to acquire French, and, according to Labour MP Denis MacShane: 'Ministers have been told they must learn a foreign language if they are to do work for the Government in Europe.'

What, then, is the future of the kalangloscope? Where will it end? Only one thing is certain: every prediction about the future of the English language has ultimately been proved to be wrong. If, in the year 1601, you had asked for odds on the global future of English you'd have been lucky to get 1,000-1.

All we can say with confidence in the year 2001 is that, as participants in global English, in all its myriad manifestations, we are probably closer in spirit and self-expression to the Shakespearean extravaganza than at any time since the seventeenth century. Spoken and written, global English offers a medium of almost limitless potential and surprise.

Europeans on English

Number of Europeans who think everyone should speak English:

Dutch 82%

Spanish 78%

Austrians 64%

French 66%

Irish 62%

Number who think foreign language skills are useful:

Danish 96%

Greek 91%

Finns 88%

French 75%

Germans 62%

41 per cent of Europeans speak English, after their mother tongue

Source: Eurobarometer

fields.headline: Marriage made in heaven
fields.standfirst: Two-and-half years after the death of his beloved Iris Murdoch, John Bayley is happily married to family friend Audi Villers. But Iris is still very much a part of their lives - in fact she's their 'favourite subject'. Here, he talks to Tim Adams about Alzheimer's, academia and the power of love
fields.trailText: Two-and-half years after the death of his beloved Iris Murdoch, John Bayley is happily married to family friend Audi Villers. But Iris is still very much a part of their lives - in fact she's their 'favourite subject'. Here, he talks to Tim Adams about Alzheimer's, academia and the power of love.
fields.body:
There are undoubtedly three people in John Bayley's marriage to Audi Villers; that's the beauty of it. The ever-present other woman is Iris Murdoch, Bayley's first wife. When she died, just over two years ago, Bayley had no plans for a new life. He had spent the previous five years caring for her as she lost her extraordinary mind to Alzheimer's and, at 74, he wanted to turn in on himself, needed nothing fresh from the world - 'In so far as I had any feelings about the future after Iris had gone,' he says, characteristically chuckling a little to himself about the bleakest moment of his life. 'I thought of it as being quite blank and quiet, and I rather looked forward to that. Seeing nobody, going nowhere, doing nothing at all.'

That, within a year, he should have committed himself to another relationship perhaps says something about John Bayley, but it suggests more, he believes, about the fact of being a widower. In their 43 years of marriage, and particularly latterly when her illness had warned people away, Iris had proved, for her husband, 'a formidable bulwark against life outside'. After she was gone, he found that rather than being left to enjoy his emptiness and silence, 'outside' crowded in on him. His widower's house, the subject of the third volume of an impromptu trilogy about life with and without Iris, was 'sieged' by friends and well-wishers and admirers wanting to take Bayley in hand, tidy him up, and even - he confides, alarmed - share his bed. Marriage seemed once more the best defence against unwanted fuss. And so, partly as a way of insulating himself again to the world, he proposed to Audi, a long-time companion and friend to both him and Iris, and - appropriately - the inheritor of a small fortune made from the patent to electric blankets.

They have, he says, a good deal in common - 'I mean, Audi and I talk incessantly about Iris; never stop, really. It's our favourite subject, if you like' - and the match was not without romance. Once, Bayley recalls, a large and rather expensive pork pie inexplicably went missing here. Though he and Iris searched and, over the years, always half expected its re-emergence, it has not yet turned up.

Originally, some of this cosy anti-domesticity seems to have derived from Iris's fear of the institution of marriage itself. She dreaded anything, particularly routine, getting in the way of her writing, and consoled herself with the thought that theirs might be the kind of relationship that preserved surprise. Bayley recalls his first wife's stubborn vision of a marriage in which, as she used to say, 'I imagined you coming home in the evening, and me running down and saying: "Oh, darling, such excitement, the badgers have broken in."' (Early in their life together, at her insistence, Bayley bought his wife a sewing box, which she kept unopened on her writing desk, a source of some amusement to them both.)

I wonder if their domestic disarray had been established over the years, or if it had emerged fully formed.

'I think it came almost at once,' Bayley says, thinking back. 'We seemed to know it by instinct, just as we knew that I liked to do a bit of cooking, and she didn't.'

(Among his Oxford friends and colleagues, Bayley is a famously experimental chef; he once described some of his revolutionary methods to Harpers & Queen : 'Boil eggs in an electric kettle and then use the water for Nescafé,' he suggested. 'Or try Heath Robinson Pasta, which only needs one saucepan, a tin of spinach, some nests of vermicelli, olive oil, shavings of mild English cheddar, nuggets of garlic and boiling water. One of the errors made by the kind-hearted and misguided women who sought to 'rescue' Bayley after Iris died was to mistake his curious habits for neglect: they tried, as he relates in his book, to cook him casseroles, wash his charity-shop sweaters, replace (as well as get inside) his greying undergarments. Which for someone like me is an alarming sensation. I think it was EM Forster who wrote that the thing about marriage is that a soundless glass bell descends over the two betrothed and no one hears of them again. I rather like that idea...'

Talking to Bayley you find yourself occasionally forgetting, like Margot and Mella, that his is a remarkable interrogative mind. In his dusty home, with his stutter and his gift for self-deprecation, he seems like a favourite shuffling uncle; I am tempted to speak slowly and shout a little to make myself understood. One friend, AN Wilson, who was once guilty of an inadvertent condescension to his former tutor, found himself brought up sharply by the then-lucid Iris, who told him, with a steely look from under her straight fringe, that he might care to remember that her husband was perhaps the 'greatest critic since Coleridge'.

Bayley, born in Lahore to a military family and educated at Eton, was for 30 years the Warton Professor of English at Oxford. At a time when the study of literature was becoming a kind of hi-tech business, he stuck resolutely to the notion that a great critic was first and foremost an inspired and humane reader. However, despite his exacting insight into Pushkin and Housman and Conrad, among others, he is more than happy that it will be for his trilogy about his wife's illness that he will be best remembered. In some ways, the books are a culmination of a life of acute reading; their unadorned prose carries an effortless weight of allusion and emotional insight. Willingly trapped by Iris's dependency, Bayley would find Shakespeare in his head. Up all night trying to persuade his mithered wife to come to bed, he'd think of the lines from Lear: 'Let's away to prison - we two alone will sing like birds in a cage...' In the course of writing the current book, it is to the poems Thomas Hardy dedicated to his first wife Emma that Bayley has returned.

In that other quietly obsessive widower's poetry, he says he has felt something of a sense of kinship. 'The great emotion in those poems,' he suggests, arguing against my suggestion that they were born of guilt, 'is rather of Hardy's liberated sense of the possibilities of the writing, of "I can now say exactly what I like and what I feel." In death even, it seems, he was grateful that his wife had given him this gift. In a way, it is the best thing you can possibly leave to a writer: a wonderful subject.'

Partly for this reason, Bayley has no qualms, he says, about having turned the intimacies he shared with his late wife into something so very public, an industry almost. 'We really were secretive,' he says, 'but as you get older you anyway sort of cast shame aside.' 'So I have no doubts about that. None at all.'

The other impulse in the writing was a kind of therapy, both for himself and for other sufferers and their carers ('hateful word'), and one of the triumphs of his books - and his life - is the way he has made Iris's illness, the noble mind overthrown, something natural and of a piece with what had gone before. This conviction - of a kind of 'marriage of true minds' - allowed him, for example, to laugh a little at the alienating horrors of the onset of the illness when, at a talk she was due to give in Oxford about her work, instead of discussing her novels Iris stood up and 'smiled sweetly and began to sing an Elizabethan madrigal by Orlando Gibbons called "The Silver Swan"'. His routine in the last five years would be, after feeding her a supper of baked beans or ice cream or mashed banana, to put his wife to bed at 8pm and have a little 'hermit space' to himself. His days were spent on walks on which she hoarded fragments - leaves and stones - to bring home. He would watch Teletubbies with her, try to painstakingly explain old jokes, and they would chatter away happily together in their private language of animal noises, their communication, as he wrote, like the sonar of whales: 'bouncing pulsations off each other and listening for echoes'.

Right up to the end, he maintained his faith that his love would protect his wife. Sometimes this faith was tried severely. In the latest memoir he describes how, out driving with Iris one night, he looked across to the passenger seat and discovered she was not there; she had undone her safety belt and, on a bend, rolled out of the car. In the country darkness Bayley crawled through the undergrowth looking for her; he eventually found her underneath a hedge, calling out quietly to him. 'Even towards the end,' he says, 'I was pretty confident that Iris would never deliberately harm herself. I mean, she often tried to escape and one or two times she did get out and would wander off, but I think she would never have deliberately put herself in harm's way, that the self-preservation instinct survives to the end.'

Another part of the clue to his wife's 'let ting go' of her reason, he believes, lay in her extraordinarily sympathetic imagination, which earlier had allowed her to inhabit so fully the lives of her 22 novels. Who does he imagine playing him?

He wouldn't know, he says, but he thinks Judi Dench 'genuinely is rather like Iris'.

Having confronted his wife's death, he is now entirely unconcerned about his own. As a carer, he says, 'you stop fearing it entirely. Partly because it seems like a natural thing, and partly because you feel, well, "I wouldn't mind going. I'm ready, too."'

Does he still feel that now? 'In a sense I do,' he chuckles, 'but only in a very serene way. I mean, all the stoic philosophers have always suggested that you should be prepared for death, and once you come to a certain age I think you are. Or I am, anyway.'

And then he gets up as if he remembered something, looks at his watch, changes his cap, makes his apologies about leaving the photographer and me to lock up, and wanders off to a lunch appointment, blinking a little in the early spring sunshine.
