fields.headline: I drink therefore I scam
fields.standfirst: The Svengali behind Marc Bolan and Wham! has pulled a lot of stunts. Now he's spilling the beans, says  Sheryl Garratt
fields.trailText: The Svengali behind Marc Bolan and Wham! has pulled a lot of stunts. Now he's spilling the beans, says Sheryl Garratt
fields.body:
Simon Napier-Bell's career spans a large part of the history of British pop. He worked for Johnny Dankworth's big band and is old enough to have met Larry Parnes, the impresario whose stable of pretty-boy singers kickstarted the business here in the 1950s.

He managed the Yardbirds in the 1960s, drank in the same clubs as the Beatles and the Stones and became great friends with the Who's eccentric manager, Kit Lambert. He co-wrote the words to Dusty Springfield's 'You Don't Have To Say You Love Me', and produced acts including Peter Sarstedt and the Scaffold. Later, he managed Marc Bolan for a while, then dabbled in punk before steering Japan to success.

But perhaps the pinnacle of his career was getting his group Wham! to be the first Western group to play in China, a publicity coup that made the duo household names worldwide. Just a few weeks away from his sixty-second birthday, he still has projects on the go. This week sees the debut British single by his latest protégée, Alsou, a pretty 17-year-old Britney soundalike who is already a massive star in her native Russia.

Napier-Bell is a manager. He sorts things for people. So, when I realise I've come to meet him without my tape recorder, he immediately takes control. Before I can finish my apologies, he's postponed his next interview and we're in his car cruising around west London to buy a replacement. He's a charming man, covering my embarrassment with a stream of enjoyable stories too libellous to repeat here. The lawyers, he says regretfully, cut some of the best bits out of his new book, Black Vinyl, White Powder, a string of lively anecdotes and personal experiences shoehorned somewhat uncomfortably into a more general history of the music business and its excesses. Nothing big had to go, he says, just a detail here, a punch line there. 'Anyone who dies between now and next year goes back in the paperback.'

He's also annoyed that the Mail on Sunday, while serialising his book, took the sections referring to the rise of ecstasy in the late 1980s/early 1990s, added references to Peter Mandelson, John Prescott and Cherie Blair and, under the headline 'Ministry of Drugs', seemed to imply that James Palumbo's Ministry of Sound club was still some hotbed of drugs activity.

Anyone who has been frisked by Ministry's bouncers will know this isn't so and, besides, Palumbo is a friend. Napier-Bell tells me a story from a business trip they made together to Thailand, where Palumbo ate raw jellyfish to psyche out a potential new business partner. After Napier-Bell and his publishers complained, the Mail on Sunday dropped the second instalment. 'I wasn't a bit sorry,' he wrote in a piece for the Telegraph 's media section last week.

Though full of repeatable stories, the new book lacks the flippant charm of his first music business exposé. Published in 1982, You Don't Have To Say You Love Me shocked critics at the time with its casual references to drugs, homosexuality, chart-fixing and the stories in which Who drummer Keith Moon ended up saving the author from sticky situations in brothels. Twice.

Napier-Bell readily agrees, saying he found the research for this longer book tedious, but then he's never been shy of admitting his mistakes. Some of the funniest parts of the new book concern his failures. He encouraged Marc Bolan to join a band called John's Children, an atrocious outfit he managed in a misguided attempt to cash in on flower power. Looking for a Latin singer, he rejected Julio Iglesias in favour of a terminally mean singer called Junior. He managed Culture Club's Jon Moss, but only when he was in an appalling punk band called London. Failures are always funny, he says, and besides, 'in between I got a few winners'.

Simon Napier-Bell was born in Ealing. His father was a documentary film-maker and a life-long communist, even though he left the party after the tanks rolled into Hungary. The family moved around a lot, and Simon was educated in a mixture of state and public schools, depending on how the finances were going at the time. Too posh for state schools, too common for public schools. As he moved from one to the other, he was constantly bullied and had to learn to adjust his accent and behaviour to fit in.

It was, he says now, perfect training for pop management, which in the 1960s required a certain chameleon-like quality. 'Ninety per cent of all the middle to senior staff in record companies were upper class. They found it very difficult to talk or deal with the artists.' This, he feels, is why so many of the successful managers of this period were gay. From the same class as the record company staff, they were equally at home with the kind of alternative lifestyles their artists often pursued. 'You're leading a double life all the time. Which is why, of course, the other people who are very good are Jewish.'

Napier-Bell's own sexuality has always been flexible. His current boyfriend is Thai; they've been together 11 years and he remains grateful to New Labour for making changes in the immigration rules that finally allowed them to live together in London. But he says it's sheer coincidence that the three major relationships of his life have been with men. 'I've always had sex with women as well. What I like is feminine men or self-sufficient women. All my life it's just been a certain type of person. It's of no interest to me what gender they are.'

Once, over lunch in 1966, he and his friend, Vicki Wickham, decided to get married. They were going to the premiere of Alfie that night, and would announce it at the party afterwards. 'I was the manager of the Yardbirds, she was the producer of Ready Steady Go. It would have been a big showbusiness marriage. We'd have big Sunday lunches with all our mutual friends; she could have her girlfriends and I'd have my boyfriends and where they overlapped, which they sometimes did, it would be no problem. And if we decided to have kids, we'd have kids. It was a brilliant idea.'

On the way to the party, Wickham stopped off to break the news to a girlfriend. Furniture flew. By the time they got into town, the party was over and so was the engagement. 'It didn't seem like fun any more.'

There was one excess Napier-Bell didn't get involved in. Despite being all around him, he has rarely taken drugs. He tried amphetamines once in the 1960s and hated them. He has always smoked joints, he says, but they give him a sore throat, so he prefers drinking. 'I like being drunk, falling over, behaving badly. If you ask me what have been the best, funniest experiences of my life, 90 per cent of them would be when I was disgustingly drunk.'

He's not anti-drugs. 'They should be legalised as quickly and sensibly as possible.' He talks intelligently about prohibition, arguing that were drugs to be legalised now, the big pharmaceutical giants could dedicate themselves to developing safer, better substances for us to enjoy. 'It's absurd. If you're feeling bad, you're allowed to take a pill to make you feel better, but if you're feeling all right, you're not allowed to. But we all take them anyway. Of some sort or other. Mine come in liquid form.'

What is noticeable in his books is that his friends tend to be other managers or musicians he didn't work with. He says this distance was always a conscious choice. 'We always get fired, in the end. Artists are great sponges, they soak things up. They learn it, and eventually they look at the manager and say, "Why should I pay you 20 per cent". I don't object to that at all. It's like bringing up a child - you put them through school and then suddenly they're an adult.'

Napier-Bell would prefer not to work at all, but if he does it has to be fun. Wham!'s concert in China may have been the last great pop scam. Dreamed up as a way to get the attention of the media, especially in the US, without months of tedious promotion, it was negotiated almost by stealth with the Chinese government, then presented to them as a fait accompli . 'I loved the scams,' Napier-Bell says wistfully. 'You don't do them nowadays. In the 1960s and 1970s we did them every day.'

He recalls the PR who shopped his clients, the Walker Brothers, to the police, saying they were bank robbers, the manager who had Goldie the eagle released from London Zoo to promote his act, Goldie & The Gingerbreads, and the riots he provoked on tour with John's Children. Back then, no one really understood how the music business worked. Now, your average teenager knows all about marketing and hype and they'll only enjoy a scam if they're allowed in on the joke.

Besides, soon after Wham! played in China, MTV made the video the main means of communication and video directors took over from PRs and managers as kings of the hype. 'It's less fun now,' he admits. 'There's no creative input any more, and you are just a go-between between all the people involved. There isn't any feeling of outrage in the music business and I don't think it will come back, really.'

Given his background, I say I'm surprised that he isn't manipulating a boy band right now, but he's shocked at the suggestion. 'You've got to feel some quality in the artists you work with. When I started managing Wham!, a lot of people said, "How could you do that after Japan?" But George was a great songwriter and they had a good act. I'd manage a boy band if it was a good laugh and they all had PhDs, but I haven't seen many of those around.

'The awful thing now is that they're mainly chosen by the record companies, not by managers, and they deliberately miss out the people with potential star quality. Because stars are always difficult people. I'm amazed Robbie Williams got through, because he's an archetypal star. Record companies take the dullest, most obedient people, the people who do what they're told. Where's the fun in managing that? It's just being a secretary, really.'

webTitle: I declare this fire well and truly Lit.

fields.headline: I declare this fire well and truly Lit.
fields.standfirst: Books are sacred and must never be destroyed, but  Bella Bathurst had a broken boiler and needs must...
fields.trailText: Books are sacred and must never be destroyed, but Bella Bathurst had a broken boiler and needs must...
fields.body:
It was on a dark and stormy night two years ago that I began considering the flammability of hardbacks. The pavements outside glittered with black ice and the neighbourhood cats sat with their tails curled round their toes. Inside, I stood close to the oven door, watching myself breathe. The boiler in my flat had shuddered to a halt two days previously and all the plumbers in London were urgently elsewhere.

My flat is one of three in a Victorian terrace and is blessed with something rare in London; two open fires. Since the Clean Air Act of 1956, which eliminated the pea-soup smogs, burning fires has retained a hazy legal status. As with most legislation it allows space for creative interpretation. It's all right to burn fires if smokeless fuel is used and it's - erm - sort of all right to burn fires if you have got no other source of heat and are about to lose a couple of limbs to hypothermia.

For most of the year the fires remain ornamental. It is possible to buy wood from a couple of distant garages, but it is always overpriced and usually takes a month to dry out. The best supply can usually be scavenged from the builders' skips spiked with scaffolding planks and abandoned kitchen fitments. But this was January and there were no builders. The few logs I had were damp and I had already burnt half a self-assembly shelving unit, three wooden coathangers, a stool, the wooden frame of an old sewing machine, a small chest and a chopping board. It was about the moment I started eyeing up the kitchen table that it occurred to me. Here in the flat I already had an everlasting supply of fuel, an inexhaustible, perpetually replenished multitude of substitute logs. I had books.

I had too many books. I had books oozing up the walls and leaking over the floor, I had books in boxes shoved to the back of cupboards, I had books toppling over my desk and pushing their way down the stairs. I had books for work, books for research, books for pleasure, unsolicited books from publishers, review copies, proof copies, limited editions, hardbacks, paperbacks, folio editions, hand-tooled leatherbound Victorian anthologies, encyclopedias, compendiums, sentimental presents and guilty inheritances. I had the books I'd read aged eight and 18 and 28, chocolate-smeared plays from two decades ago and wine-ringed novels from last month. I had books for long-ago articles I'd never look at again, books for self-improvement I hated the sight of and books I thought I ought to read but never would. Occasionally I would sell a bundle of them, but as fast as they went, they got replaced. I had all these books because it was my job to have them, but also because I loved them. Loved them for their content and their context - half my life could be traced back through their buckled covers and broken spines. They represented work, friendship, ambition, possibility and knowledge. They also represented a health hazard.

I pulled out a hardback from a pile by the door, a guide to Highland crofting law. It was heavy, substantial, earnest; the sort of book I hoped I would not have to read again. Holding it over the fire I thought, I can't do this. I can't burn a book. I don't want it, but I can't burn it. Books can be sold or given away, but they must not - they should not - be burnt. I put the hardback down, made another cup of coffee and stared a while longer at my own breath. Then I went back downstairs and placed the book on the flames. It burnt sharp and clean, much better than the logs. Watching it, I felt a surreptitious glee, like a child trashing exam notes. After a few hours I developed a technique. A hardback, then a log, turn and turn about. Paperbacks were useless; they left an acrid smell of melting glue and a clump of singed pages at the bottom of the grate. Cheap 1960s hard backs were not much better. Though crisp with age, they burnt too quickly. The best were hardbacks from the Eighties, not too plump, with quality paper and a strong binding. Only the most infuriating books should go, I decided; they must either be badly written or arrogant or dull or all three at once. I got particular joy, I remember, from watching three cookery books, a volume of Welsh medieval history and Sir Walter Scott go up in flames.

The next day, I mentioned my new fuel to a friend. 'But you can't,' he said. Why not? 'Because you just can't. You don't burn books. Goebbels,' he said accusingly. 'Stalin.' As he saw it, books, like altars and icons, belong to that dwindling group of sacred objects which cannot be destroyed. Books contain our history, our humanity and our culture. By burning those books, I was falling among low company. The SS burnt books, Stalin burnt books, the Ayatollah Khomeini burnt books. The first act of any repressive regime was to destroy the ideas contained in books. Books are dangerous things, full of dangerous possibilities. Books are inflammatory.

Yes, but, I said When Savonarola first lit his Bonfire of Vanities, he wasn't concerning himself with copies of Dealing With Sudden Hair Loss. And he wasn't in serious danger of developing frostbite. When I told a couple more people, I got the same reaction; same unspecified outrage, same implication that I had committed some kind of desecration. No one could quite specify exactly why the idea made them uneasy; it just did. Books is art, innit? You don't fiddle around with art. Art is pure, art is inviolate. Would it, I asked, be the same with paintings? Yes, they said, just the same. But at least paintings are unique; however bad, they are still the only one of their kind. Books, though, are one of 3,000 or 30,000 or 3 million; if you burn a John Grisham novel, there will still be another 2,999,999 copies left. Besides, the aim of most twentieth-century publishing had been to make books cheap, mass-market - and disposable.

So what is this taboo? And what about all the other stuff? What does one do with culture once it becomes junk? What about the videos, the CDs, the PlayStation games? We have to find some way to filter, or we will drown.

The alternative is either to burn, or to do as Michael Landy has done. For two weeks, you could watch him destroying all his possessions in the name of art. In an empty branch of C&A, the artist stood watching a conveyor belt full of yellow trays while below him someone shredded all that remained of his old life. There were many people watching him. They seemed curious or amused, but they didn't look outraged, not even when a tray rolled past containing the mangled remains of several young British novelists. So how does that work? Does that mean it is all right to destroy art for the sake of art but not all right to destroy art for any other reason?

And so, since I'm unlikely to be able to turn myself into an Oxford Street installation, I've gone on burning despite the occasional shivers of alarm. But I do have one final test to apply. My own first book was published a while ago. Like all writers I was sent several author's copies some of which I gave away and some of which I kept. Later, somewhere between proof stage and publication of the American edition, a gremlin crept into the machine. The book is poxed with typos. The British edition is fine, but the US hardback is - well, it's prime material for a bonfire, actually.

Can I be as insouciant about smoking out my own words as I have been about other people's? I think so. All I have to do is wait for a dark and stormy night, and the sound of the boiler collapsing.

I put the hardback down, made another cup of coffee and stared a while longer at my own breath. Then I went back downstairs and placed the book on the flames. It burnt sharp and clean, much better than the logs. Watching it, I felt a surreptitious glee, like a child trashing exam notes. After a few hours I developed a technique. A hardback, then a log, turn and turn about. Paperbacks were useless; they left an acrid smell of melting glue and a clump of singed pages at the bottom of the grate. Cheap 1960s hard backs were not much better. Though crisp with age, they burnt too quickly. The best were hardbacks from the Eighties, not too plump, with quality paper and a strong binding. Only the most infuriating books should go, I decided; they must either be badly written or arrogant or dull or all three at once. I got particular joy, I remember, from watching three cookery books, a volume of Welsh medieval history and Sir Walter Scott go up in flames. The next day, I mentioned my new fuel to a friend. 'But you can't,' he said. Why not? 'Because you just can't. You don't burn books. Goebbels,' he said accusingly. 'Stalin.' As he saw it, books, like altars and icons, belong to that dwindling group of sacred objects which cannot be destroyed. Books contain our history, our humanity and our culture. By burning those books, I was falling among low company. The SS burnt books, Stalin burnt books, the Ayatollah Khomeini burnt books. The first act of any repressive regime was to destroy the ideas contained in books. Books are dangerous things, full of dangerous possibilities. Books are inflammatory. Yes, but, I said When Savonarola first lit his Bonfire of Vanities, he wasn't concerning himself with copies of Dealing With Sudden Hair Loss. And he wasn't in serious danger of developing frostbite. When I told a couple more people, I got the same reaction; same unspecified outrage, same implication that I had committed some kind of desecration. No one could quite specify exactly why the idea made them uneasy; it just did. Books is art, innit? You don't fiddle around with art. Art is pure, art is inviolate. Would it, I asked, be the same with paintings? Yes, they said, just the same. But at least paintings are unique; however bad, they are still the only one of their kind. Books, though, are one of 3,000 or 30,000 or 3 million; if you burn a John Grisham novel, there will still be another 2,999,999 copies left. What does one do with culture once it becomes junk? What about the videos, the CDs, the PlayStation games? We have to find some way to filter, or we will drown. The alternative is either to burn, or to do as Michael Landy has done. For two weeks, you could watch him destroying all his possessions in the name of art. In an empty branch of C&A, the artist stood watching a conveyor belt full of yellow trays while below him someone shredded all that remained of his old life. There were many people watching him. Does that mean it is all right to destroy art for the sake of art but not all right to destroy art for any other reason? Later, somewhere between proof stage and publication of the American edition, a gremlin crept into the machine. The book is poxed with typos. I think so. All I have to do is wait for a dark and stormy night, and the sound of the boiler collapsing.

Darkness Falls from the Air
Nigel Balchin
Abacus (out of print)
fields.body:
Darkness Falls from the Air
Nigel Balchin
Abacus (out of print)

The triangular love affair and the Blitz setting are near identical to Graham Greene's The End of the Affair, but Balchin's book came first and is infinitely better and sexier. Here the true love affair is between husband and wife, not wife and lover. And there's no Catholic angst about God. Instead, Balchin's Blitz is an omnipresent feline menace that stalks the characters.

fields.headline: Gothic Scot
fields.standfirst: Ian Rankin talks to Robert McCrum about Jekyll and Hyde, dreams of pop stardom, and the pleasures of a bestselling backlist
fields.trailText: Ian Rankin talks to Robert McCrum about Jekyll and Hyde, dreams of pop stardom, and the pleasures of a bestselling backlist
fields.body:
Observer: What do you think The Falls is about?

Ian Rankin: It began with a piece of serendipity. A French TV crew wanted to interview me about the new Scottish Parliament. I suggested that we do the interview at the new Museum of Scotland on Chamber Street. As we walked in the door, a member of staff said: 'You should do something about the Arthur's Seat coffins.' So I went up to the fourth floor and here were these little six-inch high wooden coffins with tiny dolls inside, found in a cave on Arthur's Seat by some kids in 1836. I'm attracted to real-life mysteries with no ending. That got me thinking, What if Rebus got involved in an investigation of this hidden Edinburgh I've always tried to write about?

I came to Edinburgh as an outsider. I was from a small mining town 30 miles north and it seemed to me a very strange place, a city that liked to hide itself away. It presented this facade of history, as if you weren't allowed to look at Edinburgh in the present day. At that time nobody was writing Trainspotting - style books about Edinburgh. In the Eighties, when I was first trying to write, the modern Edinburgh novel was The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie which had been published in 1961 and was set in the 1930s.

Obs: Muriel Spark was one of your subjects, wasn't she?

Rankin: She was my PhD at Edinburgh University. Instead of finishing the PhD I wrote three novels. The first one was never published. Eventually I just stuck it in the bottom drawer, where it lingers to this day. My wife still says it's my best book.

Obs: Did you always want to be a writer?

Rankin: I've always written. At the age of six or seven I would get sheets of A4 paper and fold them in half, cut the edges to make a little eight-page booklet, break it up into squares and put in little stick men with little speech bubbles, and I'd have a spy story, a space story and a football story. I would show it to my mum. I was just an obsessive kid and I wasn't happy. I think part of it was growing up in what had been a mining community in Cardenden, a village of about 7,000 people in Fife. By the 1960s the coal had run out; the town was beginning to go downhill. We tried to make Cardenden a more exciting place than it really was. So we pretended the town was surrounded by aliens.

Obs: What books were you reading?

Rankin: We didn't have many books in the house. I was allowed lots of comics and eventually, around the age of 12 or 13, there was this astonishing realisation that I couldn't see X-certificate films but I could go to the library and get One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, The Godfather, A Clockwork Orange.

Obs: At what age did you come across Robert Louis Stevenson?

Rankin: Kidnapped and Treasure Island when I was 10 or 11. Jekyll and Hyde I read in high school. I was expecting a Hollywood-type horror story and couldn't believe it when I got this very complex narrative from all these different points of view. Later, I just happened to be at university at the time when the Scottish novel was getting big again. Alasdair Gray came on the scene, and James Kelman. William McIlvanney had already been there. He was a huge influence because he was a serious writer who'd won the Whitbread Prize.

Obs: Did you want to write the great Scottish novel?

Rankin: Not at that time. After the comic books I got into pop music. I made a band up in my head. I wrote all the lyrics, I took them on tour. I had the Top 10 every week, with nine other fictional groups. The band was called the Amoebas and I was doing these really bad two-minute pop tunes with lyrics like 'Hello, hello, hello, hello, how are you doing today?/ Are you doing OK, are you feeling all right?/ Baby out of sight.'

Obs: There's a lot of music in The Falls.

Rankin: I would have loved to have been a rock 'n' roll star. But none of us was musical and none of us had any instruments. If I'd become a rock musician in real life I couldn't have had the fantasy.

Obs: How did you get from music to literature?

Rankin: It was an accident. At school when I was 16 or 17, a poetry competition came up run by the Scots Language Society and I thought, well I write poetry, I write the lyrics for the Amoebas. So I wrote a new poem called 'Euthanasia' which won second prize and I got five quid. That was the start. By the time I arrived at university, the poem had been published in a magazine, so I joined the Poetry Society. The poems I was writing were narratives: so and so went here, and did this, and this was the consequence. It wasn't emotion recollected in tranquillity. I wrote my first short story for a competition and won second prize. Another competition came up and I won first prize. The first story was published in a newspaper. The second went out on radio.

Obs: The reader is very aware of the Scots language in your work. Is that self-conscious?

Rankin: Right from the very beginning I knew I wanted to write palpably Scottish fiction. I took the first James Kelman novel, The Bus Conductor Hines, home to my dad. I thought, my dad will like this; it's written in Scots. But my dad said: 'I can't read that.' He was reading James Bond and John le Carré. That was part of what attracted me to crime - the idea of getting a wide audience. Everything I wanted to say about Scotland I could say in a crime novel.

Obs: Are you a novelist who happens to write crime fiction, or a crime writer who's been acclaimed by the literary press?

Rankin: Ah, that's a tough one. I don't think it matters, really. In the early days it did annoy me. I wrote Knots and Crosses, the first of the Rebus books, not even realising that I was writing crime fiction. The Falls is dedicated to Allan Massie. He once said: 'Who would be James Joyce if they could be John Buchan?' And in Scotland there was no tradition of the crime novel. The English crime novel was perceived as being an entertainment, a puzzle. In Scotland, the tradition I was coming from was much more the Gothic novel.

Obs: I lost count of the number of references to Jekyll and Hyde in The Falls.

Rankin: One of the theories behind the Arthur's Seat coffins is that they represent the victims of Burke and Hare. It brings you back to that period in Scottish history that Stevenson wrote about in The Body Snatchers.

Obs: In The Falls Edinburgh has almost become a character.

Rankin: It's a major character because it has influenced Rebus. The real mystery in these books isn't the crime. OK, it's a crime novel, with a crime, an investigation and a resolution, so it's got the structure of the crime novel. But underneath, the real mystery is Rebus coming to terms with Edinburgh.

Obs: Is he you?

Rankin: At the start, no. As I've got older, either he's become more like me or I've become like him. I think I've grown into his skin because now I spend about 10 months of the year inside his head. In the first book he was a cipher, a way of telling a story. It was going to be a one-off, and I nearly killed him off at the end of the first book.

Obs: Do you ever feel like Arthur Conan Doyle wanting to kill off Holmes?

Rankin: Well Rebus lives in real time. He was 40 in the book and he's now in his early fifties. He'll retire at 60. I think by then I may even have grown out of him, or he may have grown tired with me. I haven't planned a series, like J.K. Rowling.

Obs: What do you think the purpose of fiction is?

Rankin: For me it's therapy. Anything that's going wrong in my life, anything like that, I just give to Rebus as a plot. So I'm working through my worries through him.

Obs: You took a long while to sell.

Rankin: The longest apprenticeship in literature. The first book came out in 1986 and from then, one or two books a year were published, but I wasn't making money I could live on until Black and Blue. It's in the last two or three years that things have really taken off, because the back list suddenly clicked.

Obs: Now your books dominate the best-seller list in Scotland.

Rankin: I got a little citation from the Guinness Book of Records which was very nice. Every month, say, each title sells 5,000 copies. I've got 12 Rebus titles; that's 60,000 books a month selling on the back list. Multiply that by 12 months and then add in a new book every year - that's a million sales in the UK.

Obs: Are you proud of that?

Rankin: I think it's astonishing that so many people would want to read about a dour Presbyterian Edinburgh cop. Crime fiction is going through a second golden age. It seems to me, looking at the Whitbread short list or the Booker, that the literary novel is actually looking back. The crime novel is dealing with illegal immigrants, paedophiles, drugs, and it's dealing with the big moral questions of good and evil.

Obs: And what would you do if you weren't writing?

Rankin: I'm not qualified for anything. I've had lots of little jobs, like picking grapes and being a tax man. I can't imagine not writing because I've done it since I was five or six. Maybe I'd work in academia. That's always what the plan was.

Obs: What are you working on now?

Rankin: I should be writing the next Rebus, which is probably gonna be called The Resurrection Men.

Obs: How much do you owe to the so-called Scottish literary renaissance?

Rankin: Nothing was happening in Edinburgh when I was trying to be a writer. Then I moved to London, and France. While I was in France, Trainspotting came along. Now we've got J.K. Rowling, Kate Atkinson, Dorothy Dunnett, Irvine Welsh, Iain Banks, me and half a dozen other crime writers who have all written about Edinburgh. I wish we all got together and chatted in pubs but we don't. Iain Banks and I get together occasionally with a bunch of poets for long whisky-tasting sessions, but we end up talking about Carry On films.

 Ian Rankin is Scotland's bestselling crime writer. The first volumes in his Rebus series have recently been adapted for TV, starring John Hannah

webTitle: Observer review: Kind of Blue by Ashley Kahn

fields.headline: It's just too good to be blue
fields.standfirst: Ashley Kahn tells how Miles Davis made his most sublime album in just nine hours, but does he manage to solve the mystery of Kind of Blue?
fields.trailText: Ashley Kahn tells how Miles Davis made his most sublime album in just nine hours, but does he manage to solve the mystery of Kind of Blue?
fields.body:
Kind of Blue: The Making of the Miles Davis Masterpiece
Ashley Kahn
Granta £20, pp224

Everyone has a favourite Miles Davis album. During his endlessly shape-shifting 30-year career, the trumpeter reinvented jazz again and again in an unstoppable series of genre-defining releases. Taken individually, they cater to nearly every conceivable musical taste. Hard bop aficionados rave about recordings from the early 1950s like Steamin' or Workin'. Classically minded listeners celebrate his collaborations with the arranger Gil Evans - such as Miles Ahead or the flamenco-flavoured Sketches of Spain. More adventurous souls flock to the sonic maelstrom of Bitches Brew or the mutant funk of On the Corner.

The one record that has enjoyed a truly universal appeal, though, is Kind of Blue. Perhaps it is the effortless restraint of the playing, or the sublime sense of mood. Perhaps it is just the album's reputation as the ultimate seduction record. But somehow, four decades after its release, its popularity seems, if anything, to be steadily growing. It has taken on a life of its own - becoming a businessman's dream in the process. As one awestruck record company executive remarks in this book, Kind of Blue still routinely shifts 5,000 copies every week, without any real promotion at all. And the figures continue to climb steadily.

The bare facts behind Kind of Blue's genesis are even more extraordinary. On 2 March 1959, at 2.30pm, seven musicians went into Columbia's studio on East 30th Street in New York and emerged after six hours with what would become the first side of the record. They returned a few weeks later for another three hours and polished off the second. What really happened in that room to produce such instant magic? That's the mystery that Ashley Kahn tries to unravel here, exploring the making of the record in those two short sessions.

As pianist Bill Evans's now-famous sleeve-notes tell it, the Kind of Blue sessions represent a perfect embodiment of the spontaneous, freewheeling spirit of jazz. Although the musicians - Davis, Evans, John Coltrane, Cannonball Adderley, Paul Chambers, Jimmy Cobb, and Wynton Kelly - had plenty of experience of playing together, the material they worked on for Kind of Blue was entirely new in form and content. Davis himself wrote out sketches of the tunes only hours before the sessions. The rest, it seems, was pure group improvisation, following Davis's usual no-nonsense studio procedures: one perfect take for each tune.

Drawing on evidence from photographs of the sessions, and by listening to the original master tapes, Kahn manages partially to resurrect the atmosphere of the recording on those two fateful days. But in terms of getting closer to how the music really came about, he inevitably comes unstuck. The tapes merely reinforce the mythical magic of Kind of Blue 's immaculate conception. The studio banter they preserve is extremely limited, revealing only a few typically minimal comments from Davis to the other members of the group and a few jokes.

There's precious little surplus musical material, either. At the start of the first session, the producer calls out: 'The machine's on... here we go: CO 62290, no title, take one.' After three false starts, the group finish the complete take that ends up on the album. The other tracks seem to have been created equally fluently, tainted only by the slightest of improvisational hiccups. As drummer Jimmy Cobb - the only member of the group who is still alive - memorably once put it: 'We just went ahead and did it'.

More fruitful, however, is Kahn's in-depth analysis of Davis's career in the years leading up to the sessions. He traces his evolution from the early days with Charlie Parker in 1945 (when he was famously described as a player who 'couldn't blow his nose'), to the assured, economical phrasings of Kind of Blue.

He shows how he redirected jazz away from the feverish sound of bebop, towards a much more pared, lyrical sound and influenced scores of later players. It is a wonderfully clear, fascinating insight into the trumpeter's chameleon-like creative processes.

As for Davis himself, it seems that he merely saw Kind of Blue as a beautiful failure. In his autobiography, he relates how the initial inspiration for the record was rooted in a childhood memory of walking home from church, his head filled with gospel music. Years later, he tried to recreate 'that feeling I had when I was six years old, walking with my cousin along that dark Arkansas road... But then you write something... and you just miss where you thought you wanted to go'.

One can only wonder what a direct hit would have sounded like.

Although the musicians - Davis, Evans, John Coltrane, Cannonball Adderley, Paul Chambers, Jimmy Cobb, and Wynton Kelly - had plenty of experience of playing together, the material they worked on for Kind of Blue was entirely new in form and content. Davis himself wrote out sketches of the tunes only hours before the sessions. The rest, it seems, was pure group improvisation, following Davis's usual no-nonsense studio procedures: one perfect take for each tune. Drawing on evidence from photographs of the sessions, and by listening to the original master tapes, Kahn manages partially to resurrect the atmosphere of the recording on those two fateful days. But in terms of getting closer to how the music really came about, he inevitably comes unstuck. The tapes merely reinforce the mythical magic of Kind of Blue 's immaculate conception. The studio banter they preserve is extremely limited, revealing only a few typically minimal comments from Davis to the other members of the group and a few jokes. There's precious little surplus musical material, either. At the start of the first session, the producer calls out: 'The machine's on... here we go: CO 62290, no title, take one.' After three false starts, the group finish the complete take that ends up on the album. The other tracks seem to have been created equally fluently, tainted only by the slightest of improvisational hiccups. As drummer Jimmy Cobb - the only member of the group who is still alive - memorably once put it: 'We just went ahead and did it'. More fruitful, however, is Kahn's in-depth analysis of Davis's career in the years leading up to the sessions. He traces his evolution from the early days with Charlie Parker in 1945 (when he was famously described as a player who 'couldn't blow his nose'), to the assured, economical phrasings of Kind of Blue. He shows how he redirected jazz away from the feverish sound of bebop, towards a much more pared, lyrical sound and influenced scores of later players. It is a wonderfully clear, fascinating insight into the trumpeter's chameleon-like creative processes. As for Davis himself, it seems that he merely saw Kind of Blue as a beautiful failure. In his autobiography, he relates how the initial inspiration for the record was rooted in a childhood memory of walking home from church, his head filled with gospel music. Years later, he tried to recreate 'that feeling I had when I was six years old, walking with my cousin along that dark Arkansas road... But then you write something... and you just miss where you thought you wanted to go'. One can only wonder what a direct hit would have sounded like.

webTitle: Observer review: Poker by Al Alvarez

fields.headline: You show me yours...
fields.standfirst: Al Alvarez, poet and poker player, gives a romantic sheen to a money-obsessed game in Poker
fields.trailText: Al Alvarez, poet and poker player, gives a romantic sheen to a money-obsessed game in Poker
fields.body:
Poker: Bets, Bluffs and Bad Beats
Al Alvarez
Bloomsbury £20, pp128
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Perhaps the most entertaining place to watch the current stock-market crisis is on the investment bulletin boards. It is here that characters such as 'To The Moon', 'The Hen', and 'Swish Tony' log on to discuss the markets. Their comments are unintentionally hysterical. At 2.05 in the morning, To The Moon - drunk or stoned or indefatigably optimistic - will log on and tell the world: 'My source tells me the deal will be announced tomorrow a.m. This stock is going NORTH. Fill your boots and book your holidays.'

Eight hours later, his confidence proves to be misplaced: 'A 20 per cent fall!! Is everyone insane??? What is going on????.' No one knows. The investors have watched their shares fall and fall and fall. But will they sell up? Will they take a loss? Will they hell. The talk is of averaging down and topping up. The fundamentals are good. The sources keep whispering. The gamble goes on.

Al Alvarez would have nothing to do with it because he doesn't care for gambling. And it is his contention in this marvellously entertaining paean to the game that 'serious poker is no more about gambling than rock climbing is about taking risks'. This may seem counter-intuitive to someone who has been diddled out of more than he can afford to lose in what was intended to be a friendly game of cards, but it is surely correct. There is as much skill in poker as there is in bridge, which means that, in the long run (even if 'the short run is longer than most people know'), the better player will keep winning.

Further, and crucially, there is not as much skill as there is in a game of chess, which ensures that the weaker player will keep playing. He will blame his luck, his cards, the size of the moon, anything and everything for his losses, but until it dawns on him that the fault is his own for sitting down with superior players he will continue to lose. And they, being frightfully polite and consoling him all the while, will keep on winning. As Alvarez himself did in his long-running Tuesday game when one player 'helped pay our mortgages and educate our kids, he subsidised our vacations and nights out on the town, and all because of his vanity'.

The game has not only brought Alvarez, many years ago the poetry editor of this newspaper, financial reward, but provided a guide as to how he might live his life. 'Poker changed my life, and sometimes I think it may have saved it.' This moment occurred when his life went awry in his late twenties and he read Herbert O. Yardley's The Education of a Poker Player. 'What was true of money in a card game was equally true of the feelings I had invested in my disastrous personal affairs: "Do the odds favour my playing regardless of what I had already contributed." I knew the answer. The only puzzle was why I should have discovered it not in Shakespeare or Donne or Eliot or Lawrence or my other literary heroes, but in a how-to-book about cards written by an American cryptographer. It was more than absurd; it was humiliating.'

Not necessarily. First, Yardley was a clever man with a nifty prose style. Second, numbers have always been more precise than words and reducing a problem to an odds on or against proposition provides a stark clarity.

Given the role poker has played in his life it is unsurprising that Alvarez relishes the myths and anecdotes and cracker-barrel wisdom surrounding the game and he lovingly retells some of the old favourites. Walter Matthau saying, 'the game exemplifies the worst aspects of capitalism that have made our country so great'. Big Julie from New York saying, 'the guy who invented gambling was bright, but the guy who invented the chip was a genius'. And the time a stroppy Texan asked Kerry Packer, 'what makes you so special? I've got 100 million dollars in the bank'. To which Packer replied: 'That's very impressive. I tell you what: I'll toss you for it.'

All of these and many more are contained in this book which offers a perfect introduction for beginners and a nostalgic romp for those already addicted. A slight problem with such a romantic approach is that it does rather gloss over the fact that poker is only a game. A very materialistic game, moreover, which revolves around the making and losing of money. And for all the living outside of society posturing which most of the big players adopt, for all their protestations that money means nothing, they dedicate far more hours a week than the most thrusting Wall Street executive to the remorseless accumulation of... money.

Watching the World Series in Vegas, a tournament about which Alvarez has written the excellent The Biggest Game in Town, is a confusing experience. It's exciting, absorbing but, after 90 hours of non-stop card-talk, somehow deflating.

There is an absence of fun. Even when the pros are larking around they are only doing so to set up some convoluted bluff. Every means towards just the one end - winning more money. They are even more self-absorbed in their craft than comedians and their tales of 'bad beats' - always, always they talk of the hand that should have been - as wearisome to listen to as a comic re-telling his jokes. Poker pros are forever on. Always re-writing the history of their last game as they scout around for people to take part in the next one.

How different they are from the gambler for whom the casino offers escape and hope. Alvarez quotes the Barthelme brothers writing about those who visit the casino because 'they imagined something wonderful might happen, something that could change their lives. This was their fool's secret, one they shared with drunks, artists and children, all of whom they resembled... essentially they came to the casino to be children because gambling is a child's vice practised largely by adults.' Poker at the highest level is an adult pursuit where those who cling to childish hopes are swiftly disabused of their innocence and parted from their money. A cruel rather than a beautiful game.

Poker, for all its charms, can appear pointless. Amarillo Slim, about whom one had read so much, is reduced to an old bloke in a stetson cosying up to blondes young enough to be his grand-daughters. The game itself seems curiously old-fashioned and other-worldy.

Alvarez writes that 'poker is generally reckoned to be America's second most popular after dark activity. And even there it has the edge. "Sex is good," they say, "but poker lasts longer."' Once this was true. But America has changed. Those that shuffled cards in taverns now deal shares on the net. We have moved on from Nick the Greek to Nick Leeson. A development which, if the slide continues, may lead to an updating of Matthau's adage: 'Share-dealing exemplifies the fundamental aspects of capitalism which are currently making our country so poor.'

webTitle: Observer review: Hildegard of Bingen by Fiona Maddocks

fields.headline: Nun for all seasons
fields.standfirst: Prophet, artist, politician, healer... all of this and she never gave up her day job. Fiona Maddocks gives a pragmatic account of the life of Hildegard of Bingen
fields.trailText: Prophet, artist, politician, healer... all of this and she never gave up her day job. Fiona Maddocks gives a pragmatic account of the life of Hildegard of Bingen
fields.body:
Hildegard of Bingen: The Woman of Her Age
Fiona Maddocks
Headline £15.99, pp332
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The 12th century anchorite Hildegard of Bingen possessed a clutch of talents which would make even the most eclectic of media-donnas curdle with envy. Writer, visionary, prophet, composer, artist, herbalist, politician, preacher, property owner, upbraider of emperors and favourite of Popes, she could even exorcise demons and heal the sick. She invented her own language, wrote one of the earliest surviving morality plays, established her own convent, terrorised her detractors, and, when she died, was mourned by nuns and reverently biographised by monks.

Born in 1098 in the Rhineland, Hildegard's unusual abilities were visible from an early age, when she startled her nurse by predicting the colouring of an unborn calf. At eight, she was given by her parents as a tithe to the Church. In middle age a visitation urged Hildegard to write down her visions. She produced a vast corpus: allegories, prophecies, cosmologies, a medical encyclopedia, a guide to herbal cures, an elaborate sequence of chants and hundreds of letters.

Her writings are strewn with apocalyptic images - the stars, the serpent, the jaws of hell. Her medical suggestions are enticingly chaotic: advice not to eat carnivorous animals seems practical; suggested treatment for epilepsy (a small cake made from the blood of a mole, duck beak, the feet of a female goose and wheat flour) would surely cure only a hypochondriac.

Accounts of her life generally start with her Vita, written by monks before and after her death. There are also almost 400 letters in Latin, and her own accounts of visions and visitations. She was written to by monk and nun acolytes, eager for spiritual advice. As a firm supporter of the religious and social status quo, she was occasionally attacked for the rigid separation of social ranks in her order, which she defended with a hardly diplomatic analogy: 'And who would gather all his livestock indiscriminately into one barn - the cattle, the asses, the sheep, the kids?' She was a stalwart defender of the papacy, to the point of rounding on the emperor, Frederick Barbarossa, who supported three consecutive anti-popes. No proto-feminist, she insisted that her influence on the age exposed the lacklustre womanishness of the clergy; only in dire necessity, would God have resorted to her.

Fiona Maddocks offers a densely researched and archly understated account of the nun-polymath. Her argument is less for Hildegard's freakishness and more for the peculiar circumstances of the time, which permitted her talents to flourish. She unearths other, nearly-Hildegards to argue that the monastic life fostered women of intellectual range and curiosity, permitting them the time, resources and status to produce work.

Maddocks's is a pragmatist's account, continually emerging out of a tangle of opinion with an argument resonating with wit and fairness. To those who dismiss Hildegard's rehabilitation in the early twentieth century as anti-Semitic, she quietly suggests Hildegard's 'negative attitude towards Jews' was 'in keeping with Orthodox and Christian thought in the Middle Ages.' Of the neurologists who have deduced Hildegard's visions were symptoms of migraine she demands, 'Where is the migraine in the music?' Or in the art? To those who claim Hildegard's art, writings and music may have been executed by others, she proposes, slightly tricksily: 'As the figure who by not existing would have caused their non-existence, she must be their one true begetter.'

And for those who scoff at Hildegard's visions, Maddocks prescribes a dip into William James, the pragmatic philosopher and brother of Henry. In The Varieties of Religious Experience, he argues that an individual in a receptive state may experience a sense of 'something there', a glimpse of an 'unseen' world. This 'spiritual' state might be understood as a 'different' state from 'everyday' consciousness; the predilections of the times will influence how we interpret it. Maddocks adds that this does not necessarily mean we can skip backwards to previous eras re-diagnosing religious fervour as clinical depression or anorexia.

Maddocks's is a wonderful, subtle portrait, which lets the subject emerge half out of the shadows, without pouring conclusions and diagnoses upon her head. This strange, dynamic nun will slide away from contemporary labels, just as we will eschew her mole's blood gateaux.

webTitle: Observer review: Dirty Havana Trilogy by Pedro Juan Gutiérrez

fields.headline: Look, no scruples - or deodorant
fields.standfirst: Filth and lust from our man in Havana, but does Pedro Juan Gutiérrez's Dirty Havana Trilogy lose something in translation?
fields.trailText: Filth and lust from our man in Havana, but does Pedro Juan Gutiérrez's Dirty Havana Trilogy lose something in translation?
fields.body:
Dirty Havana Trilogy
Pedro Juan Gutiérrez
Faber £10.99, pp392
Buy it at a discount at BOL

There is a scratch-and-sniff ambition to Pedro Juan Gutiérrez's writing. He is determined that his readers should take in the particular reek of Havana's slums. Hardly a page of this three-book novel goes by without an instruction to inhale a lungful of the air of the interminable 'terrible, damp, dark and foul-smelling rooms, measuring about ten by thirteen' in which most of its drama occurs.

The atmosphere of these rooms, you imagine, is seldom significantly enhanced by the arrival of Pedro Juan, the author's alter ego and narrator, who works variously as a hod carrier, a salesman of knock-off lobsters, a slaughterhouseman and a repairer of sewage pipes. Pedro Juan's appearance invariably heralds sweaty afternoon sex with the generously-proportioned women who call these rooms home. Most of them, apparently, prefer him not to wash.

Dirty Havana is intended as something of a revelation of the truth of Castro's Cuba, where it is banned. The 'issues of the day' are briefly delineated - 'food, dollars, poverty, hunger, Fidel, people leaving, people staying, Miami' - but only obliquely addressed. Pedro Juan used to be a journalist but gave it up as 'an unhealthy and cowardly living... always making concessions, everything censored'. Now, liberated by the streets, he is free to write what he wants. And what he wants is mainly the 'big-assed women' of Mantilla and Baracoa, who, apparently, 'make you feel like you've got the sweetest prick in the world'.

Led by his saccharine manhood in a mini-odyssey through the city's crumbling walk-ups and lean-tos, Pedro's life develops into a pattern of chance encounters, each a short chapter, which tend to end in violence or copious ejaculation or both. As in the books of some of the more excitable horror writers, where new characters appear on one page in order to meet violent ends on the next, there is a kind of juvenile fascination in the introduction of each new woman, black and white, mullata and mestizo, and a swift calculation as to how long it will take before each is fabulously and repetitively satisfied by Pedro's priapic charms.

A few of these encounters have a dark humour: that with a poetess whose ardour - 'I swoon in the voracious cataclysm of the impossible' - he cannot quite take; or with a 'confused woman' who uses 'insane' phrases like 'making love' and 'we could be happy'. Mostly, though, the joke seems forced or inadvertent (witness the man who masturbates to the smell of his own armpits). This sense is not helped by a translation which, despite its command of pejorative, labours to find a convincing vernacular for some of Pedro Juan's semi-comic posturing.

His defence of his life and his methods is the Sadeian one that 'only an angry, obscene, violent, offensive art can show us the other side of the world, the side we never see or try not to see so as to avoid troubling our consciences'.

The book is at its best, however, not in its anger but in its occasional portrayal of the desperate detail of street life: the Russian roulette, for example, played by young boys on bikes, who, for 20 pesos, attempt to make it across eight-lane highways just as the lights turn green.

Gutiérrez can make the fabric of the city come alive in these passages; the ramshackle rooming houses become characters in their own right; the elevator in Pedro Juan's apartment building is, thus, like a 'senile old man, it moves down very slowly, shivering and snorting, as if it no longer had the strength for so much work'. When this book was published in America, Gutiérrez was compared, perhaps for intent as much as execution, to other like-minded liberators such as Henry Miller and Charles Bukowski. Though he shares their amorality, his writing lacks the edge of their invention.

Given the context, this was no doubt a brave book to have written, possibly even an 'important' one (certainly, a self-important one). Still, for this reader it was hard not to concur with Pedro Juan's 'faggot friend', Aurelio, when, early on, he tells him he's 'sick of watching you pretend to be so macho'. And then there are still 300 pages to go.

His defence of his life and his methods is the Sadeian one that 'only an angry, obscene, violent, offensive art can show us the other side of the world, the side we never see or try not to see so as to avoid troubling our consciences'. The book is at its best, however, not in its anger but in its occasional portrayal of the desperate detail of street life: the Russian roulette, for example, played by young boys on bikes, who, for 20 pesos, attempt to make it across eight-lane highways just as the lights turn green. Gutiérrez can make the fabric of the city come alive in these passages; the ramshackle rooming houses become characters in their own right; the elevator in Pedro Juan's apartment building is, thus, like a 'senile old man, it moves down very slowly, shivering and snorting, as if it no longer had the strength for so much work'. When this book was published in America, Gutiérrez was compared, perhaps for intent as much as execution, to other like-minded liberators such as Henry Miller and Charles Bukowski. Though he shares their amorality, his writing lacks the edge of their invention. Given the context, this was no doubt a brave book to have written, possibly even an 'important' one (certainly, a self-important one). Still, for this reader it was hard not to concur with Pedro Juan's 'faggot friend', Aurelio, when, early on, he tells him he's 'sick of watching you pretend to be so macho'. And then there are still 300 pages to go.

webTitle: Observer review: A Regimental Affair by Allan Mallinson

fields.headline: Waterloo sunrise...
fields.standfirst: Hervey is alive and well. Jane Austen isn't... A Regimental Affair confirms Allan Mallinson undoubted talents
fields.trailText: Hervey is alive and well. Jane Austen isn't... A Regimental Affair confirms Allan Mallinson undoubted talents
fields.body:
A Regimental Affair
Allan Mallinson
Bantam £16.99, pp326

It takes either an extremely brave or an extremely foolhardy author to set forth on a monumental series of books by squandering its natural denouement. Yet this is exactly what Allan Mallinson did in A Close Run Thing, in which he introduced his hero, Matthew Hervey of the Light Dragoons. That book's climax was the Battle of Waterloo, an event, you would think, which would serve as a natural conclusion to the life of a dashing cavalry officer.

But no. Mallinson used Waterloo not as an occasion to tie up neatly his military career but to establish the credentials of Hervey. Further, the second book in the series, The Nizam's Daughters, transported Hervey to India, following the calculating orders of the victor of Waterloo. In both, Mallinson established himself as a master of military detail and a social mores.

The third in the Hervey series, A Regimental Affair, is firmly rooted in 1817, a time of great social and political upheaval in this country, rather than a time of huge military possibilities. Newly returned from India, Hervey almost immediately finds himself bound up in the foment occasioned by 'Orator' Hunt, witnessing a hanging and the hatred of mob rule in the compressed streets of the City of London.

With his regiment, he is then dispatched to intercept a group of owlers and smugglers, a vain pursuit. All the while that Hervey is warring against the forces of civil disobedience, he is being thrown into sharp conflict with his commanding officer, Lord Towcester, a coward and martinet. This conflict deepens as the regiment is first sent to the Midlands to counter the malign threat of the Luddites, and from there to Canada to deal with an uprising among the Indians.

Mallinson deals with the historical and military minutiae with his customary panache, as one has come to expect from a serving officer in the Royal Hussars, now stationed in Rome as military attaché. It is his consummate ability to incorporate the social details and niceties of the time that marks his novels out from the common herd of big boys' books of big boys doing jolly brave things.

Whether it be Hervey's clergyman father's alleged popish tendencies, which occasion conflict with the bishop; the matter of Jane Austen's death, an event Hervey admits he's ignorant of, averring, as he does, that he rather prefers to read poetry; the use of Bow Street investigators (this was a time long before the introduction of the police force) to solve crimes;; or a rather sly allusion to menstruation, Mallinson's book benefits from his clear love of research.

He still has an eye for the set-piece. In the space of six paragraphs, describing an encounter between a troop of cavalry under Towcester's command and group of Mississauga Indians - an incident which offers full proof of Towcester's cowardice - Mallinson captures vividly the confrontation between two clashing cultures.

This is not even to touch on Hervey's long-postponed marriage to his sweetheart, Henrietta, or the birth of their first child in deep-frozen Canada, or an in-depth (literally) analysis of early nineteenth-century veterinary skills. While nothing can matches, nor could, the verve of Mallinson's account of Waterloo in A Close Run Thing, A Regimental Affair confirms his undoubted talents and marks him out as the heir to Patrick O'Brian and CS Forester.

fields.headline: When babes were bold...
fields.standfirst: Taschen put art into softback in their new Icons series
fields.trailText: Taschen put art into softback in their new Icons series
fields.body:
Taschen Icons: Encyclopedia Anatomica and others
Taschen £4.99, pp191

The Hayward Gallery's recent exhibition, Spectacular Bodies, was not for the squeamish, but many observers were fascinated by some of the famous anatomical wax models permanently housed in the Specola museum in Florence. While the show was on, bookshops in London quickly sold out of Encyclopaedia Anatomica, a door-stopping photography book, published by Taschen, which catalogued the entire Specola collection. What might once have been imagined as a gory sideshow became a popular paperback, and the curiosities of the eighteenth century found a new audience in the twenty first.

Now Taschen has embarked on a new venture: it is publishing a series of small, neat softbacks called Icons. Icons are like tasters - affordable versions of Taschen's larger books, more smart collectables than hefty art tomes.

The pocket-sized Encyclopaedia Anatomica, with its sinewy sculptures and its model of a pregnant woman whose middle can be taken apart in layers, is one of the first. It is published alongside Gilles Neret's book on nineteenth-century erotica (the lesser-known sketches of Toulouse-Lautrec, the lewder Degas, the early Ingres - as well as some hardcore anonymous Victorians). There is a book of Karl Blossfeldt's photographic collages, another of Piranesi drawings and a collection of Edward S. Curtis's portraits of native Americans.

One about pin-ups charts the 1940s' publications of American impresario Robert Harrison. Wink, Flirt and Eyeful all had garish, stylised covers featuring cartoon-like girls in fishnet stockings and push-up bras. Unlike the photo-stories inside, the covers were hailed as a kind of popular art almost immediately. But by the 1950s, the coy looks that brightened up the war had been superseded by girls baring all.

Porn took over from pin-ups and Harrison, seeing that no holds were barred, founded a magazine that made him infamous: Confidential, the scandal-sheet to the stars. Harrison brought icons down, but with his images, Taschen's Icons series has only just begun.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Don't be led up the path by hedge funds

fields.headline: Don't be led up the path by hedge funds
fields.trailText: 'You may think that a long/short equity hedge is something a skilled topiarist might create in your garden.'
fields.body:
You may think that a long/short equity hedge is something a skilled topiarist might create in your garden. In fact, it is the latest wheeze dreamt up by investment companies to persuade you to part with your savings.

Hedge funds have been available to US investors for years. Now, a few firms - Henderson Global Investors, Morley Fund Management and HSBC among them - are starting to offer them here. If stock markets are falling, even the most skilled fund manager in the world will find it hard to increase the value of conventional equity funds.

Hedge funds, however, can make money whether shares are rising or falling.

An example of one of the simplest techniques illus trates how complicated the area is. If the manager thinks Marks & Spencer's shares are likely to fall, he could sell them short - selling shares that he does not own now in the hope of buying them more cheaply later. And remember that hedge funds will typically take huge bets - remember George Soros punting on Britain leaving the exchange rate mechanism. They can also borrow heavily to back their hunch (remember the huge debts that sunk Long Term Capital Management) and are often not covered by investor protection rules and it is clear that hedge funds are not for the financially naive.

Yet they are being marketed to just that audience, the small investors looking for somewhere to put their £7,000 Isa allowance. The Financial Services Authority is concerned enough to warn savers that they 'may not be appropriate for the majority of consumers'.

That is putting it mildly. Plain vanilla equities are risky enough, but even investment professionals find it hard to understand how hedge funds operate. Nor are they cheap: good hedge fund managers demand high rewards, and that is reflected in fees.

The funds being launched vary in structure. Henderson is calling on the services of up to 30 specialist hedge managers; Morley is just asking its existing fund managers to turn their hand to derivatives; and the offerings from Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank are so complicated that it will be hard to work out exactly how they are doing.

Jason Schmidt of Allenbridge, which analyses hedge funds, says it is vital to chose a transparent fund, with an experienced manager. He likes the structure of the Henderson trust but questions the experience of its lead manager and the complexity of the Deutsche and Credit Suisse funds. His favourite is HSBC's Republic trust.

His analysis of the performance of hedge funds over the past 10 years shows that they have produced an average return of 15 per cent, better than the stock market.

Allenbridge runs a website - www.hedgeinfo.com - on hedge funds. Most of the information is available only to intermediaries but there is a list of retail funds available and the firm will suggest an experienced independent financial adviser to anyone who is interested in investing in this area.

webTitle: Maria Scott: 'Protective' Equitable tightens its trap

fields.headline: 'Protective' Equitable tightens its trap
fields.trailText: 'Crashing stock markets are not supposed to cause immediate pain for investors in with-profits funds. But it's different at Equitable Life.'
fields.body:
Crashing stock markets are not supposed to cause immediate pain for investors in with-profits funds. These funds have grown fat on marketing spin that promotes their steady returns, smoothed through good times and bad. But it's different at Equitable Life.

On Friday, barely in time to allow examination by the media, the insurer increased the charge for transferring out of its with-profits fund from 10 to 15 per cent. As one adviser put it: 'An extra 5 per cent is a very large amount of money.'

Equitable, forced to close to new business before Christmas because of a £1.5 billion liability to policyholders with guarantees on their pensions, blames falling share prices.

Other insurers have the power to impose exit penalties on with-profits products but rarely, if ever, do so on such a widespread or swingeing basis; at least not so far. Equitable's move will further knock confidence in this popular form of investment.

Financial advisers attempting to counsel Equitable's pension investors on what to do with their funds, are still getting to grips with the latest news, although the general conclusion is that fewer people are likely to be able to get out now.

Making up for a 15 per cent penalty elsewhere requires a much longer lead-time to retirement than even a 10 per cent charge in order to make up for that loss, espe cially in poor market conditions. One small consolation is that Equitable's enforced investment conservatism, with a heavy emphasis on bonds, may take the edge off falling share prices.

Another small ray of hope is that the Office of Fair Trading has warned the insurer of its disquiet over the clause in its contract being used to apply the exit charges. The watchdog is considering Equitable's response to its warning although , disappointingly for investors, it has stressed it is not questioning the size of the penalty as much as the wide discretion the insurer has in applying it.

For Equitable's long-suffering investors, this is the third piece of bad news in as many weeks; there are no guaranteed bonuses this year and those bonuses that are being paid are down.

The insurer argues that it is raising the charges so it can protect returns for investors who stay. But this weekend, most Equitable investors will feel trapped rather than protected.

fields.headline: ONdigital net plan in disarray
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: ONdigital's ambitious plans to generate substantial new earnings by offering subscribers internet access through its pay-TV services received a dramatic setback last night.
fields.body:
ONdigital's ambitious plans to generate substantial new earnings by offering subscribers internet access through its pay-TV services received a dramatic setback last night.

Granada, joint owner of ONdigital, is to stop selling the ONnet box in its 500 Box Clever stores. The box makes its TV set-top devices capable of accessing the internet. An internal memo sent to store managers states: 'Sales of ONnet boxes have been lower than anticipated through Box Clever and other retailers, as a result of which we will cease to stock this product.'

News that Granada is to pull the product will surprise media analysts. In January, ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble said he was 'very pleased' that ONnet - which launched last September - had attracted 70,000 subscribers, each of whom pay £5 a month for the service.

Until recently, the company, whose other shareholder is Carlton Communications, has seen ONnet as a platform for delivering a range of interactive services. In addition to offering users email services, ONnet also provides secure online shopping facilities - opening up potentially lucrative e-commerce revenues to ONdigital.

The company's promotional material boasts: 'Fifty six brands have now signed up to provide content to the ONnet portal. ONnet is adding new partners virtually every week.'

Analysts have expressed concerns that French firm Netgem, which makes the ONnet boxes, has seen demand level off.

fields.headline: Taxing the mind
fields.trailText: 'The man behind it notices that my MOT is out of date, which is news to me, though not surprising, I point out, when you marvel at how long I've been in the queue.'
fields.body:
God knows I'm not one to begrudge Britain's old age pensioners their leisure time after living through the Blitz and then having to sell their dream bungalows for the privilege of going into nursing homes managed by bogus care workers on the run from the Hague War Crimes Tribunal, but I do wish they wouldn't spend their mornings organising coach parties to the post office when I need to buy a new tax disc, which I should say in my defence has been allowed to expire only as a result of the incompetent vehicle licensing authorities failing to remind me to tell them that we moved house in 1999.

But then I've no sooner reached the counter than the man behind it notices that my MOT is out of date, which is news to me, though not surprising, I point out, when you marvel at how long I've been in the queue. Ha-ha-ha . At this stage, of course, I am still under the impression that he is mentioning my MOT merely out of courtesy, but no - it is his way of saying that I am wasting his time so if I wouldn't mind sodding off now and let some bona fide customers see the rabbit?

'Hang on, so you're suggesting I've now got to drive round with an out-of-date tax disc looking for an MOT garage?' I say. No, it is hardly within the province of his office to suggest how I spend the rest of my day, with or without the full portfolio of legal motoring documentation - he's just saying I can't have a tax disc.

I pause to let steam out of my ears, because by this time I have turned into someone from Incident in Cairo (1942), which I admit is not, strictly speaking, a real film, but if it were I would be the incensed haughty type standing at a desk exasperatedly looking round for someone in higher authority who speaks English to please explain to the mustachioed imbecile in the fez that I am the French ambassador and that I am about to miss my flight to Istanbul.

'Sorry,' he says (the man in the post office, not the fez), employing much the same politely strained rictus, sidewardly inclined head and crisp note of finality as the person who I remember this time last year refused me a tax disc for the offence of turning up with an insurance schedule rather than the required insurance certificate , which is quite different, though, as I pointed out at the time, not to the naked eye of people without microscopic vision.

I drive recklessly back home to pop my head in the fridge and leave the Yellow Pages in the capable hands of my wife, who is already slightly anxious about our tax disc in the belief that it is only a matter of time before one of the Neighbourhood Watch people in the village tips off the police and a SWAT team arrives to launch tear gas grenades through our windows and drag us away in handcuffs. Luckily, she says, the Texaco garage do an MOT while you wait. Off I go. Naturally I'm expecting the man in the overalls to whistle through his teeth and point out that he can't issue a certificate to anyone unable to produce an up-to-date pair of driving gloves but, no, he is perfectly happy to accept a large sum of money instead. Which seems orthodox enough, though predictably 'MOT while you wait' turns out to be a shortened version of 'MOT while you wait for your life to end', so when I do finally emerge with two new tyres, brake lights that go on and off, and a full beard, I reckon I can just about make it to the postie if I drive on the right and park on somebody's front lawn.

I dash inside with my new MOT, insurance and proof of ownership tattooed across my forehead, fill in the form and hand over my Switch card. 'Sorry, cheque or cash only, I'm afraid,' the man says, indicating the hidden notice advising customers that credit or debit cards are not acceptable as the post office is affiliated with a branch of our public services still twinned with pre-war Bulgaria.

Clearly we are going to have to turn ourselves in.
