webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Red faces, red eyes and red noses

fields.headline: Red faces, red eyes and red noses
fields.trailText: 'Celebrity Big Brother was obviously yet more TV heroin, even more addictive than the original, but, that apart, confusion reigned.'
fields.body:
If Big Brother was the unedifying spectacle of nobodies scrabbling to become somebody, then at least everybody knew where they stood. With Comic Relief's edition of Celebrity Big Brother, featuring Vanessa Feltz, Anthea Turner, Jack Dee, Chris Eubank, Boyzone's Keith Duffy, and Brookside 's Claire Sweeney, one could never quite work out what was happening. Obviously, it was yet more TV heroin, even more addictive than the original, but, that apart, confusion reigned. Were we witnessing nobodies thinking that they were somebody? Somebodies swiftly becoming nobody? Or nobodies, who'd always thought they were somebody, suddenly realising they were nobody, and screaming horribly, as they embarked on their freefall descent into Z-list oblivion?

Whoever dreamt up the idea of locking 'real' celebrities up in the Big House should be knighted. Not merely because it raised a lot of money for charity. (If my frantic telephone calls to friends during the ad breaks is anything to go by, BT should do the decent thing and give a slice of its profits to Comic Relief.) But also because it produced such televisual gems as Dee's desperate pleas to leave, Turner's tear-streaked nomination 'wobblies', and Feltz's (am-dram?) Norma Desmond tantrum at being turfed out (if she wasn't a gay icon before, she is now).

The theatrical blubbing of the 'girls' is a case in point. Considering that they're both 40ish, and had only been incarcerated for about 20 minutes before they succumbed to neurotic meltdown, Feltz and Turner gave rise to the feeling that Celebrity Big Brother was not so much 'Reality TV' as much as it was 'Priory TV', with the viewer being given delicious insight into how little it takes to provoke modern celebrity-jessies into having a nervous breakdown. Watching Feltz worry and snivel about her unpopularity with the public was at times akin to observing a child soil her pants and attempt to blame the mess on the cat.

With the exception of Dee, nobody could deny that the CBB contestants were a poor shower, reminiscent of those Ealing war comedies, where the sergeant major walks up and down the line of new recruits, berating them for being 'orrible wastes of space. The irony being that several of the featured 'celebrities' seemed to crave fame far more, and deserve it far less, than the nobodies from the original series. While it is beyond one to actually dislike such fragile fairy children as Feltz and Turner, it surely cannot be healthy for personalities (oxymoron alert!) such as themselves to spend their lives scrabbling about in a kind of VIP limbo. A terrifying halfway house, which is neither illuminated by the dazzling spotlight of fame, nor dignified by the soothing amber glow of obscurity. The inhabitants being not pure-breed celebrities at all, rather second time-around wannabes - fame's lost boys and girls, who simply aren't needed anymore.

Maybe this is the biggest achievement of Celebrity Big Brother - to shine a harsh unforgiving light on the nature of British celebrity itself, in particular those celebrities who seem to be famous for some reason that we've forgotten, if there ever was a reason in the first place. More and more these days, Britain seems to be doing a roaring trade in 'People Famous Simply For Being Famous'. So much so that maybe we should stop mourning our farming industry, and use the empty livestock barns for the likes of Tania Strecker and Jamie Theakston to mate in, and produce more of their lovely kind. Indeed, it is probably not too fanciful to suggest that those people who are famous simply for being famous might eventually become our favourite kind. Or that, in the future, we will find it extremely odd when famous people have any kind of talent at all.

All these things and more Celebrity Big Brother underlined brilliantly. A friend commented to me that poor deluded Anthea and Vanessa probably thought that their stay in the house would lead to a charity-fuelled career renaissance in the style of Queen bursting out of their chest wigs at Live Aid. However, maybe something even more beautiful happened. If Celebrity Big Brother taught us anything it was that fame, that thing the original Big Brother crew, and, more recently, the PopStars, were so achingly desperate for, is actually a pile of pants. As proved by Feltz, Turner and the rest, these days, in the year of our lord Nigel Lythgoe, celebrity has become so debased, so devoid of cachet, so bereft of value and dignity, that, to endeavour to remain resolutely non-famous is actually far cooler.

webTitle: Militant farmers plot rural revolt as the slaughter begins

fields.headline: Militant farmers plot rural revolt as the slaughter begins
fields.standfirst:
The Army is on stand-by, and the man who led the fuel protests is ready to halt the cull. What was an emergency is becoming a battle. Special report by Jason Burke, Kamal Ahmed and Paul Harris

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Army is on stand-by, and the man who led the fuel protests is ready to halt the cull. What was an emergency is becoming a battle. Special report by Jason Burke, Kamal Ahmed and Paul Harris
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Kamal Ahmed and Paul Harris
fields.body:
David Handley was sitting at home yesterday in his tidy, pink house in the rolling Monmouthshire hills, watching grey skies that promised rain. Outside his pedigree herd of Jersey cows grazed in the fields of the Old Llanishen farm.

It seems an unlikely place to be plotting a war, but, mobile phone in hand, that is what Handley is doing. The 49-year-old dairy farmer, head of the militant group Farmers for Action, has issued an ultimatum to the Government. Either the mass cull ordered last week to stop the spread of foot and mouth disease is halted - or the Government will face a rural revolt. Handley isn't messing around.

'I hope they see common sense. The Government in London just does not understand what they are doing. It is madness. This is a senseless slaughter. Either they stop it or we stop them.'

Handley has been here before. At the head of last November's fuel protests he set a 60-day deadline for a cut in petrol prices. That ultimatum failed. He does not intend to let that happen again. Using the networks of friendships and phones created during the fuel crisis, the FFA activists plan to block slaughtermen heading for the farms. They will stop them at the farm gate, Handley says. They will not back down. If necessary they will go to jail for their cause.

Once more the countryside is in revolt. The battle lines are drawn. From Dumfriesshire to Devon, farmers stand guard over their cherished flocks and herds. Some talk of violence others of more passive resistance. Some, as an Observer investigation has discovered, have opted for civil disobedience. In a dangerous move that threatens to jeopardise the containment efforts their colleagues are so angry about, they are deliberately flouting the restrictions on movement that the Government has imposed since the disease was first discovered last month.

Yesterday nine new cases were discovered, bringing the total to 282. The situation is now so serious that Ministry of Agriculture officials have begun to discuss the use of police to get their staff on to farms to complete the cull. The Army is standing by. MI5, the domestic intelligence service, and the Special Branch have sent the Home Office preliminary assessments of the situation and its implications for national security.

Both agencies have been monitoring the crisis, and key characters, in recent days. Now, faced by old foes like Handley and Andrew Spence, last seen leading a convoy of trucks from the North East to London in the final days of the autumn's fuel protest, old files have been dusted off.

The fuel protests took 10 days to bring under control, not least because the men who led them had the sympathy of much of the country. The Government lost 20 points in the polls in a single week. Five months later, people like Handley cannot be dismissed as isolated firebrands in love with their own rhetoric. They have undoubted support. 'We are desperate men,' said one Cornwall farmer yesterday. 'There is death all around us. Our lives are literally going up in smoke and we are not in control of events. We've got to try and make a stand and claw back some power over our own lives.'

The contrast with just seven days ago is massive. Last weekend the focus was on the disease and its causes and cures, and on the threat it posed to rural life. This weekend the focus has turned inwards. And it's turned nasty.

As the skies of rural Britain thicken with black smoke from the pyres of tens of thousands of animals, as a bewildered nation remains isolated - physically, psychologically, diplomatically and medically - from the rest of the world, as economists predict a £9 billion bill, as the likelihood grows of an embarrassing postponement of May elections, the Government has its back to the wall.

Tomorrow Jim Scudamore, the Government's chief veterinary officer, will travel to Cumbria to tell angry farmers why he advised Nick Brown, the Agriculture Minister, to order the cull. They will take some persuading. The cull involves the slaughter of up to a million animals, most of them quite healthy. All animals within three kilometres (1.75 miles) of infected farms in the two 'hot' areas of Cumbria and Dumfries and Galloway are to die in a bid to create 'firebreaks' to hold back the disease. It's a radical solution for an extraordinary situation. But though the National Farmers' Union has reluctantly backed the plan, many of its members are incensed. Even the RSPCA joined the clamour of voices raised against it. And increasingly, Ministers are the target for the countryside's anger. 'They don't understand the countryside and they have just massively over-reacted in the way they have handled the disease,' said Russell Butler, a 25-year-old Berkshire farmer.

The Government never wanted this. From the very outset it has been playing down talk of emergency and playing up words of consensus and cooperation. In the offices of the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) and in Downing Street it was agreed, whatever happened, that the Government must not become the target of the protest. That policy is now coming apart at the seams.

The Government is between a rock and a hard place. On the one hand, pictures in the press of police forcing their way on to farms will add to the sense of national crisis and further damage the country's tattered image overseas. But to allow the farmers of Cumbria the upper hand would mean Maff's 'contain and destroy' policy on foot and mouth had failed. The Government cannot allow that to happen. Today the big worry is that Scudamore will fail to win over the Cumbrian farmers and the Government will have to move into 'enforcement mode'.

With troops on the streets and police at the farm gate it will be far harder for Tony Blair to push through an election on 3 May. That timetable has been in place for three years. With Labour miles ahead in the polls, any delay is a gamble. The stakes over the next 48 hours are very high.

Chancellor Gordon Brown and Environment Minister Michael Meacher will announce a multi-million pound rescue package on Tuesday. There will be cash for farmers and, it is thought, soft loans for the battered rural tourism and leisure industry. It may head off the growing anger of Britain's rural communities, never Labour's natural constituency. Then again, it may not.

But while the farmers rage about a distant and disorganised government, an Observer investigation has revealed that one of the main catalysts for the ferocious spread of the disease - among the most infectious known to man - may have been illegal movements of livestock by the farmers themselves. In the two weeks after the first case of foot and mouth was discovered in a sow at an Essex abattoir on 19 February, hundreds of farmers throughout the country ignored restrictions imposed to control the outbreak. The movements, usually carried out under darkness, are still continuing according to local government authorities charged with stopping them and prosecuting wrongdoers. In the worst cases farmers are being investigated for trying to deliberately infect their animals and claim compensation.

Local council trading standards officers at 15 of the 28 councils with infected farms in their territory told The Observer that they are preparing to prosecute a total of 24 farmers. They stressed that they have only been able to apprehend a tiny fraction of the lawbreakers.

'We know that across the country there have been hundreds of individual movements of sheep, pigs and cattle, either on the same farm or between separate properties,' one trading standards source said. 'But it is very hard to get enough evidence to go to court.'

Nationwide, scores of prosecutions are expected.

Maff has ordered that no sheep should be moved within 10kms (6.5 miles) of an infected farm. That means hundreds of thousands of sheep left out in the cold, without fodder, in the run-up to lambing. The temptation to move the livestock to safety can prove too great to resist.

Ken Yorston, trading standards manager in Montgomeryshire, branded farmers who broke the law 'grossly irresponsible'. He stressed that it was a single smuggled sheep from Cumbria to a farm in South Armagh that brought the virus over the Irish Sea and into Northern Ireland. Though just one animal had the disease, the discovery of foot and mouth prompted panic and the slaughter of 1,000 pigs, 400 cattle and 250 sheep.

Last week Norman Dalgarno, a 49-year-old sheep farmer from Tregony in Cornwall, was fined £3,500 after caught moving eight sheep from one field to another several miles away. He later admitted he had moved around 50 animals. The prosecutions represent the 'tip of the iceberg', say trading standards officers. In Devon, Cumbria and Powys nearly 200 individual movements of animals that breached the restrictions have been reported. The true amount of illegal transporting is far larger. 'In the countryside people stick together, so when they do call in it is because they have seen something that they are genuinely very angry with,' said Phil Ashcroft, a trading standards official with Cumbria County Council.

Cumbrian trading standards are hoping to prosecute two farmers next week who they believe moved healthy sheep to fields adjacent to a farm infected with the virus in order to infect them and claim compensation payments - currently farmers are paid a good rate for slaughtered animals in a very slack market. 'They will be interviewed next week and if we get enough evidence we will prosecute them,' a Cumbrian investigator said.

Officials in Staffordshire suspect a farmer of deliberately not taking anti-foot and mouth precautions because he planned to leave farming and wanted to claim compensation before he sold up. The farmer's animals, however, are still uninfected. His property is now being observed by trading standards officers.

There is also concern that farmers are still feeding unprocessed swill to pigs, despite suspicions that this caused the initial disease outbreak at a farm in Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumbria. Swill, usually a mix of leftovers from schools, canteens and restaurants, has to be heat-treated to kill viruses before it is fed to pigs. Last week three pig keepers - two with business links to the Heddon farm - admitted keeping improperly treated swill on their premises. Two were fined.

The truth is that no one knows where the disease comes from. And no one knows how much the out break is going to cost. Last week the respected Centre for Economic and Business Research estimated a £9bn bill. Economists are divided over its impact. Some were confident that Britain's strong economy would be unaffected. Others felt the country could be forced into a recession.

Worst hit, says the CEBR, will be the travel industry. 'The image of Britain now is of beef burning not beefeaters. That's hardly attractive to holidaymakers,' said Paul Crawford, a CEBR analyst. The loss to the economy will be mitigated by the diversion of money not spent on rural tourism.

However £9bn is more than one per cent of the country's gross domestic product for the year, and the tax receipts lost by the Treasury will be three times greater than the tax cuts made by the Chancellor in the Budget. Some economists have talked of a 'confluence of negative factors' that could spark serious problems for everyone.

But in the fields, cottages and barns, the hurt is more personal. Yesterday 78-year-old Robert Brough walked to the gates of his 200-acre Cumbrian farm, bolted them and carefully arranged a 'Keep Out' sign. On the hills around him smoke plumes rose from the pits where his neighbour's cherished flocks were burning.

'I know it won't stop the disease - but it might hold up the Maff vets for a bit,' he says, with a weak smile.

'This farm is my life. Now it is going to be reduced to nothing. It has become a killing field.'

 Additional reporting by John Arlidge in Scotland, Ed Helmore in New York and Kate Connolly in Berlin

Step by step to meltdown

In only a month, Britain has gone from the first sighting of the disease to turmoil throughout the country:

 Outbreak discovered on 10 February at an Essex abattoir and traced to a pig farm in Northumbria. Two days later a quarantine ban is imposed on two farms that had supplied livestock for slaughter. Too late.

 Now more than 160,000 animals have been destroyed with hundreds of thousands more to come. There are 282 confirmed cases of the disease with nine new ones reported yesterday. One of the fresh cases is in the previously disease-free county of Shropshire.

 The National Farmers Union estimates foot and mouth is costing agriculture £64 million pounds a week. The total cost to Britain is expected to run into billions. Culture Secretary Chris Smith is considering aid to the tourist industry which fears a 'lost summer' if the crisis continues.

 Timing of a general election expected to be called for 3 May is under threat. Thousands of other events across Britain have already been cancelled, from hunts to horse racing meetings to St. Patrick's Day parades.

 The Government vows to press ahead with mass cull of up to one million animals to create 'firebreaks' around infected areas, mainly in Cumbria and Dumfries and Galloway, to halt virus's spread.

 Militant farmers groups promise a 'rural revolt' to prevent the slaughter of healthy animals. They accuse the Government of sacrificing their flocks for political ends.

Some economists have talked of a 'confluence of negative factors' that could spark serious problems for everyone. But in the fields, cottages and barns, the hurt is more personal. fields.headline: Britons 'fight with rebels in Chechnya'
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Video footage purporting to show that British Muslims have been fighting alongside Chechen rebels in the separatist republic has been released by Russia's presidential spokesman on Chechnya.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow  and Martin Bright
fields.body:
Video footage purporting to show that British Muslims have been fighting alongside Chechen rebels in the separatist republic has been released by Russia's presidential spokesman on Chechnya.

A video cassette allegedly showing a PE teacher from Manchester, dressed in camouflage gear with a Kalashnikov on his lap, was produced as evidence for a claim that Islamic extremist organisations in Britain may have sent 'several dozen' fighters to the region.

The tape takes the form of a plea to Muslims across the world to join the fight against Russia. Sitting cross-legged in the undergrowth, smiling at the camera, the young man introduces himself as Assadullah, and speaks in a Mancunian accent. He says he left his family in England because he believed the Chechen people needed help.

In the 15-minute rambling appeal he urges committed Muslims to abandon their homes and give themselves up to the holy war.

'You tell your family that you might not come back,' he says. 'You come here and you burn your bridges.' Later he is shown with armed rebels, standing in the snow receiving orders from a commander.

The decision by Sergei Yastrzhembsky, President Putin's spokesman on Chechnya, to hand the video to The Observer is evidence of a campaign to show international terrorists are fighting Russian forces in the region.

During a visit to London last week, Yastrzhembsky said he had provided the British authorities with evidence Britons had fought with Chechen rebels. 'I think we are in a position to expect London to be cooperative in finding out the circumstances under which fighters from the territory of Great Britain appeared on the territory of Chechnya,' he said.

Muslim leaders in Manchester last week were sceptical about the Russian claims. Lawyer Afzal Khan, a local councillor, told The Observer : 'I have been a community worker for over 20 years and I have never heard of a single family in Manchester where someone has gone to fight in the jihad.'

Khan and other prominent Muslims met Home Secretary Jack Straw last week and warned him new anti-terrorism legislation was feeding a growing climate of Islamophobia.

Yastrzhembsky said Russia had called on Britain to close down the extremist group al-Muhajiroun run by Sheikh Omar Bakri Muhammed in London. 'According to our information, under his leadership several dozen fighters have been sent to Russia,' he said. Bakri, who addressed 300 al-Muhajiroun followers in Manchester on Friday, said: 'We are a political organisation. It is a Muslim's duty to support jihad verbally, financially and physcially. But we are not involved in the recruitment of fighters.' He said he did not know Assadullah.

'Abdullah', 19, al-Muhajiroun's Manchester coordinator, said: 'I have the greatest admiration for this man. He is a hero. But, as far as we know, he has no connection with al-Muhajiroun in Manchester.'

Russian officials say they have seized hundreds of cassettes from 'rebel archives' in the region. Another video with footage of rebels executing prisoners has also been deployed as a propaganda tool by the Russians. The question of how many fighters from the West may have been attracted to Chechnya remains uncertain.

webTitle: Wright killer in hiding from IRA

fields.headline: Wright killer in hiding from IRA
fields.standfirst:
John Kennaway, one of King Rat's assassins, breaks his silence to tell Henry McDonald of his fears that he is now a republican target

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: John Kennaway, one of King Rat's assassins, breaks his silence to tell Henry McDonald of his fears that he is now a republican target.
fields.body:
One of the men who helped to murder loyalist leader Billy Wright, known as King Rat, is in hiding this weekend - from fellow republicans rather than from avenging Protestant paramilitaries.

In his first interview since Wright's assassination inside the top-security Maze prison, John Kennaway accused the Provisional IRA of orchestrating a smear campaign against him and his family which could lead to his murder.

Kennaway, who was part of a three-man INLA unit which shot Wright dead inside the courtyard of H-Block 6 on 27 December 1997, said he feared that rival republicans rather than loyalists would be the first to try to kill him.

Speaking at a safe house in west Belfast yesterday, the 38-year-old INLA prisoner, who was released early under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement, said he had 'absolutely no regrets' about helping to kill Wright, but felt bitter that other republicans were vilifying him and his son, John junior.

The diminutive convicted INLA killer claimed he had incurred the IRA's wrath because of his association with the Notarantonios, a republican family in Belfast whose nephew, a Real IRA member, was shot dead by the Provisionals last October.

Chain smoking in the back kitchen of the house on a staunchly republican estate, Kennaway told The Observer why he has broken his silence for the first time since Wright was murdered.

'I got out of jail last October and I broke all my links with the INLA in order to start a new life. I think the political settlement was a sell-out, so many people lost their lives. But I wanted to get to know my four children and see them growing up. I was in jail for nine years, firstly for trying to assassinate Laurence Kennedy (leader of the Conservative Party in Northern Ireland during the late Eighties and early Nineties) and then for Billy Wright.

'Once I got out it never left my mind that I would always be a target for loyalists for the rest of my life. That I could accept, and I built as much security around myself as possible. But about a month ago an ex-comrade of mine in the INLA came to me and said I was in a lot of trouble because of the people I was associating with, the Notarantonios. These were my friends, they were people who looked after me in jail and I couldn't ignore them. Two weeks ago the INLA came and told me that they could no longer protect me if I kept associating with that family. The INLA man said the IRA was carrying out investigations into me.'

Kennaway said he believed the IRA imagined he was some kind of threat: 'Maybe they saw me as a rallying-figure for young nationalists and republicans who admired what I did in the Maze to Billy Wright.'

Shortly after Wright was buried in his native Portadown, the INLA's political wing, the Irish Republican Socialist Party, printed T-shirts to commemorate the killing. They depicted a rat with a gun target on its back caught inside a giant H.

The words, plagiarised from a Boomtown Rats hit, below the image stated: 'It's a rat trap Billy, and you've been caught.' In nationalist areas the T-shirts sold like hot cakes. Wright, the Portadown-based loyalist, was a hate figure among nationalists for helping to organise scores of sectarian murders in Mid-Ulster.

However, when pressed on whether he has now joined the anti-ceasefire Real IRA - the group responsible for the Omagh atrocity - Kennaway denied it. 'My war is over,' he said. 'The reason I'm giving this interview is that I'm afraid they (the IRA) will try to portray me as Real IRA. I'm 38 now. I want to build a new life.'

Kennaway said he supports the right of groups like the Real IRA to carry on the 'armed struggle' and has spoken out against attacks by mainstream republicans on the dissidents in west Belfast.

Acutely security conscious, he has not been living at his home in recent weeks fearing he could suffer the same fate as Joseph O'Connor, the Real IRA member shot dead by the Provisionals last October.

'I honestly believe the IRA see me as some kind of threat, which I'm not,' Kennaway said. 'Even if they don't target me, as a friend in the INLA warned me, they would get to me through my son John. He was a tearaway when I was in prison and once I was released I was determined to straighten him out, but now they've done this.'

Kennaway points to a leaflet on the kitchen table, distributed the day before by IRA members, which accuses several families and teenagers of anti-social activities in the Ballymurphy and Springhill area. Among those youths named is his son.

Billy Wright's assassin is at first reticent to talk about his role in killing the Loyalist Volunteer Force's founder inside the Maze. He points out that he has left the INLA and will not betray any of their operations.

But when he is asked about security at the prison during the period leading up to Wright's murder, Kennaway smiles.

'Before we killed Wright security had all but collapsed in the Maze. We were getting drink into the jail every week. A loyalist even managed to smuggle a puppy dog into H6 before he was caught with it on the wings. It was a joke. Remember that myself and my comrade who killed Wright, Crip McWilliams, had already smuggled guns into another jail, Maghaberry prison before that.

'This was funny because when we were transferred to the Maze and into H-block 6, which we shared with the LVF, the loyalists were taunting us. They were laughing at us saying that we could have used the guns in Maghaberry to shoot their leaders there. But we were only ever interested in taking out Billy Wright.

'He was directing the murder of Catholics by the LVF from his prison cell. Every time the LVF killed a Catholic on the outside Wright's men would cheer and play their flutes on their wing of the H-block. But they were total fools.'

Kennaway said he and the two other prisoners involved in the assassination were well aware of the consequences.

'We discussed it in our cells; we all volunteered freely and were willing to spend the rest of our lives in jail. We knew that we would be caught, that's why on the day we did not wear balaclavas or gloves once we got the gun inside.'

On the killing itself, Kennaway claims that the prison alarm system actually helped them pen Wright, who was waiting in a van for a post-Christmas visit, inside the courtyard.

'When we cut out of wing and got on to the roof we were actually depending on the screws to be around, to see us. We wanted them to be there to sound the alarm, which leads to the automatic lock-down of the gates. We got into the courtyard and Wright's van was stuck there because the gates were automatically locked. If there had been no alarm the truth is that Wright might have got away and survived. The joke is that the screws thought we were trying to escape, that's why they shut the gates. Had they not have seen us the gate would have been open and the van could have driven away when we pulled out the guns.'

Kennaway revealed that he was actually unarmed when he held up the prison driver in the van: 'The driver was meant to think I was armed but the truth is I didn't have the gun - it was Crip that fired the shots into the van.'

The former INLA prisoner said he supported Billy Wright's father's demand for a public inquiry into the killing. 'There is no doubt about it that security was a joke in the Maze. We took a risk smuggling the guns in, but it was not impossible.'

He admitted that he was lucky to avoid a life sentence, thanks to the Good Friday Agreement and the early release scheme for paramilitary prisoners.

'I was resigned to the fact that I would spend the rest of my life inside prison for killing Billy Wright,' he said. 'I knew that even while we were planning to kill him. It's true that we got out of jail on the IRA's backs; that their ceasefire and Sinn Fein's support for the Agreement helped us get free.'

Kennaway added that he acccepts that he is a hunted man. He will never be able to shop or socialise in Belfast city centre. There are parts of Northern Ireland he can never visit.

But while republican sources dismiss his concerns over IRA threats on his life, alleging paranoia on the part of the ex-prisoner, Kennaway is deeply bitter that it is fellow republicans who are orchestrating a campaign against his son and possibly even himself.

'To people who say the IRA would never take me out, I just say to them: what about Joe O'Connor? I know I have got to be careful and the hurtful thing is it's not only loyalists I have to worry about.'

fields.headline: Disease spread in 'cash scam'
fields.standfirst:
Army on standby as farmers against cull warn of violence

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Army on standby as farmers against cull warn of violence
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Paul Harris  and Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
Police will be told to arrest farmers who refuse to allow the mass slaughter of infected animals as the Government signalled its intention to face down threats of violence and prevent the foot and mouth crisis spinning out of control.

In the most significant worsening of relations between government officials and the farming community since the disease broke out four weeks ago, farmers last night retaliated by warning that they were willing to 'go to war' to protect their herds.

David Handley, head of the Farmers for Action, predicted violence. 'They won't get near a farm and if they try, then they had better build new prisons, because they are going to need the space for all the farmers who are going to try to stop it,' he said.

The FFA is seeking a judicial review of the cull. The farmers claim that the decision was made for political motives - to allow local, and possibly general, elections to be held on 3 May. Last night government sources admitted that departments were already preparing for a May poll, a key Labour Party objective since 1998, despite polls showing that 61% of people think the election should be postponed.

Underscoring how seriously the government is taking the threat by farmers to refuse access to their animals, MI5, the domestic security service, has begun gathering intelligence on key activists among the farmers. Police Special Branch units have also been alerted.

Government officials yesterday said that nothing would stop the cull going ahead. If farmers did not allow slaughtermen access to their animals, police would be deployed to arrest anyone obstructing the work.

With nine new cases of foot and mouth disease yesterday - bringing the total to 282 in the UK - there is no sign that the virus is being contained. The cost to the economy is predicted to reach £9bn because of the crisis.

But the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) said yesterday that the slaughter would go ahead despite continued threats of demonstrations and violence. The aim of the killing is to create a 'firebreak' around infected sites and the tactic depends on farmers abiding by the strict restrictions placed on the movement of livestock in areas hit by the highly infectious disease.

Yesterday the Agriculture Minister Baroness Hayman said that Jim Scudamore, the Government's Chief Veter-inary Officer, would visit Cumbria tomorrow to convince local vets and farmers that the cull should go ahead.Yet farmers, who believe they are innocent victims of a natural catastrophe, were in danger of losing public sympathy yesterday after it emerged that hundreds of incidents of lawbreaking by farmers, including cases in which animals were intentionally infected with foot and mouth, could explain the rapid and uncontrollable spread of the disease.

Trading standards officers revealed that they are planning dozens of prosecutions of farmers who have illegally transported animals.

Only a fraction of such offences ever reach court and investigators speak of hundreds, if not thousands, of illegal movements taking place nationwide since the outbreak of the disease.

Richard Cawthorne, Deputy Chief Veterinary Officer, admitted yesterday that there were more movements of infected animals than had ever been envisaged, which was making control of the disease far more difficult.

Maff made no move to lift restrictions on movements yesterday, although Michael Meacher, the Environment Minister, stressed that rural areas were 'not out of bounds' for visitors. Currently there are restrictions on access by foot to huge swaths of Britain, largely in the North West, the Welsh Marches, the Scottish Lowlands and the South West. Dartmoor, the Highlands and Snowdonia remained effectively closed to walkers and climbers.

Meacher said an urgent review was under way to find footpaths which could be quickly and safely opened.

Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary, signalled that the Government was ready to help hard-pressed rural tourism businesses hit by the foot-and-mouth crisis. He said Ministers were looking 'very carefully' at a number of measures, including emergency business tax relief and the setting up of a hardship fund.

Smith cautioned that the Government could not produce an 'instant chequebook' to deal with all the problems caused by the foot-and-mouth outbreak.

The scale of illegal movements revealed will affect sympathy for the farming community. Trading standards in Cumbria hope to prosecute five farmers. Four face court in Staffordshire and three in both Norfolk and Herefordshire. Ken Yorston, a trading standards officer in Powys, where authorities plan to bring five cases to court soon, said: 'These people are running the risk of spreading this disease all over. It is grossly irresponsible.'

The trading standards team in Powys has received tip-offs about 25 alleged incidents in total. In Devon more than 150 such calls have been received. In Cumbria, 50 illegal movements have been reported.

A spokesman for the National Farmers' Unionsaid: 'We cannot condone anyone who does this. These are awful times for farmers but we have to deal with this virus.'

fields.bodyText: Police will be told to arrest farmers who refuse to allow the mass slaughter of infected animals as the Government signalled its intention to face down threats of violence and prevent the foot and mouth crisis spinning out of control. In the most significant worsening of relations between government officials and the farming community since the disease broke out four weeks ago, farmers last night retaliated by warning that they were willing to 'go to war' to protect their herds. David Handley, head of the Farmers for Action, predicted violence. 'They won't get near a farm and if they try, then they had better build new prisons, because they are going to need the space for all the farmers who are going to try to stop it,' he said. The FFA is seeking a judicial review of the cull. The farmers claim that the decision was made for political motives - to allow local, and possibly general, elections to be held on 3 May. Last night government sources admitted that departments were already preparing for a May poll, a key Labour Party objective since 1998, despite polls showing that 61% of people think the election should be postponed. Underscoring how seriously the government is taking the threat by farmers to refuse access to their animals, MI5, the domestic security service, has begun gathering intelligence on key activists among the farmers. Police Special Branch units have also been alerted. Government officials yesterday said that nothing would stop the cull going ahead. If farmers did not allow slaughtermen access to their animals, police would be deployed to arrest anyone obstructing the work. With nine new cases of foot and mouth disease yesterday - bringing the total to 282 in the UK - there is no sign that the virus is being contained. The cost to the economy is predicted to reach £9bn because of the crisis. But the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff) said yesterday that the slaughter would go ahead despite continued threats of demonstrations and violence. The aim of the killing is to create a 'firebreak' around infected sites and the tactic depends on farmers abiding by the strict restrictions placed on the movement of livestock in areas hit by the highly infectious disease. Yesterday the Agriculture Minister Baroness Hayman said that Jim Scudamore, the Government's Chief Veter-inary Officer, would visit Cumbria tomorrow to convince local vets and farmers that the cull should go ahead.Yet farmers, who believe they are innocent victims of a natural catastrophe, were in danger of losing public sympathy yesterday after it emerged that hundreds of incidents of lawbreaking by farmers, including cases in which animals were intentionally infected with foot and mouth, could explain the rapid and uncontrollable spread of the disease. Trading standards officers revealed that they are planning dozens of prosecutions of farmers who have illegally transported animals. Only a fraction of such offences ever reach court and investigators speak of hundreds, if not thousands, of illegal movements taking place nationwide since the outbreak of the disease. Richard Cawthorne, Deputy Chief Veterinary Officer, admitted yesterday that there were more movements of infected animals than had ever been envisaged, which was making control of the disease far more difficult. Maff made no move to lift restrictions on movements yesterday, although Michael Meacher, the Environment Minister, stressed that rural areas were 'not out of bounds' for visitors. Currently there are restrictions on access by foot to huge swaths of Britain, largely in the North West, the Welsh Marches, the Scottish Lowlands and the South West. Dartmoor, the Highlands and Snowdonia remained effectively closed to walkers and climbers. Meacher said an urgent review was under way to find footpaths which could be quickly and safely opened. Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary, signalled that the Government was ready to help hard-pressed rural tourism businesses hit by the foot-and-mouth crisis. He said Ministers were looking 'very carefully' at a number of measures, including emergency business tax relief and the setting up of a hardship fund. Smith cautioned that the Government could not produce an 'instant chequebook' to deal with all the problems caused by the foot-and-mouth outbreak. The scale of illegal movements revealed will affect sympathy for the farming community. Trading standards in Cumbria hope to prosecute five farmers. Four face court in Staffordshire and three in both Norfolk and Herefordshire. Ken Yorston, a trading standards officer in Powys, where authorities plan to bring five cases to court soon, said: 'These people are running the risk of spreading this disease all over. It is grossly irresponsible.' The trading standards team in Powys has received tip-offs about 25 alleged incidents in total. In Devon more than 150 such calls have been received. In Cumbria, 50 illegal movements have been reported. A spokesman for the National Farmers' Unionsaid: 'We cannot condone anyone who does this. These are awful times for farmers but we have to deal with this virus.' What's going on? webTitle: 'Chatrooms are great - except for the liars'

fields.headline: 'Chatrooms are great - except for the liars'
fields.standfirst:
Teenagers can still enjoy going online as long as they recognise the perils, say reporters from Children's Express


Special report: child protection
More net news
fields.trailText: Teenagers can still enjoy going online as long as they recognise the perils, say reporters from Children's Express.
fields.body:
Information technology still puzzles many adults, including most parents. Kierra, 15, said: 'My mum is crap at anything with an "on" button really.' And her mother is typical - a survey by Amazon.com, the internet bookshop, last year found that 75 per cent of children had helped their parents to solve computer problems.

More mystifying still are the chat rooms - websites where complete strangers can talk to each other about whatever they like, with as much anonymity as they wish. 'Chat rooms are great,' said Ben, 14, 'because you can make up so much about yourself.'

But there are people, such as paedophiles, waiting to take advantage. Kierra said: 'Bad things about chat-rooms are people who lie all the time. Like, "Honest, I'm 14." Except I'm a 55-year-old bald man named Malcolm. Or he'll say, "My name's Sadie, I'm 13 and I like Barbie. Do you?"'

Unlike Kierra, many teenagers don't recognise the dangers. Rachel O'Connell, director of research at the Cyberspace Research Unit, in Preston, Lancashire, said: 'When teenagers go online for the first time, many are not aware of the warning signs - like when somebody asks for personal information, or asks to meet them offline [in the real world]. Those kinds of requests should set off alarm bells in teenagers' heads, just as the sound of an oncoming car would warn them not to step out into the street.'

But some parents tend to overreact. O'Connell said: 'It would be such a shame if parents panicked about the internet and stopped their children using it, because it's such a wonderful place.

'A much more effective way to ensure a child's safety would be to go through the safety guidelines with them. Just as they would teach a child to cross the road safely, parents should initially accompany their children online.'

Safety guidelines are freely available on dozens of websites, including cyberangels.com and chatdanger.com. O'Connell is working on an EU-funded project to bring education about online safety into schools and homes.

 Children's Express is a programme of learning through journalism for young people aged from eight to 18. This article was produced by Abeyna Jones and Tinu Adeniji-Adele, 17, and Jonathan Hudson, 14.

webTitle: Net baby mother lashes out at 'official smear campaign'

fields.headline: Net baby mother lashes out at 'official smear campaign'
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: The custody battle over the twins bought on the internet took a new twist last night when Judith Kilshaw, the British mother who says she legally adopted the American-born twins, accused social services of conducting a vicious smear campaign against her.
fields.body:
The custody battle over the twins bought on the internet took a new twist last night when Judith Kilshaw, the British mother who says she legally adopted the American-born twins, accused social services of conducting a vicious smear campaign against her.

Kilshaw said Flintshire Social Services Department, which goes to court tomorrow to try to prove that she and her husband are not the twins' legal parents, have told court officials that she has shown confidential care documents about the case to journalists. She fears this could lead to her being accused of contempt of court.

Her husband Alan, a solicitor, said: 'This allegation is total mischief and designed to influence the judge. No one has any evidence of Judith's wrong-doing. This smacks of a witch hunt by the establishment.'

He added: 'Showing confidential documents about a court case to other people is a contempt of court issue. But Judith has never even seen the report.'

His wife said: 'There is no proof. They're trying to discredit me.'

The county council was unable to comment.

Last year, the Kilshaws paid an internet adoption agency, run by Californian Tina Johnson, £8,200 for the twins, born to a woman in Arkansas. The Kilshaws returned with the babies to their farmhouse in Mold.

An American couple also claim they paid for the twins, and have disputed the Kilshaws' adoption.

A US court recently ruled that the twins should be returned to America where their rightful home can be decided by the courts.

The Kilshaws will appear in Birmingham Crown Court tomorrow to continue their appeal against the county council's attempts to annul their adoption. They will be represented by a barrister working for free. Alan Kilshaw believes his family is entitled to legal aid for its legal battle.

fields.headline: Palestinians turn backs on violence
fields.standfirst:
After 430 deaths in six months, intifada activists say it is time to move on from guns and bombs

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: After 430 deaths in six months, intifada activists say it is time to move on from guns and bombs.
fields.body:
A few days after Israel's ageing warrior Ariel Sharon ignited a Palestinian uprising with his now notorious jaunt to a disputed sacred site, a petition began making the rounds of the West Bank.

What do we call this intifada, it asked. Are we fighting for the al-Aqsa mosque in Jerusalem or do we want a revolution?

Six months on, and with nearly 430 dead and Sharon now installed as Israel's Prime Minister, the Palestinians are confronting the same old question: What are we fighting for, and what is the best way to get it?

The debate is double-edged. In the past few days several prominent Palestinians have called for a non-violent protest movement, in the hope of enlisting civilians to an uprising so far fought almost exclusively by the armed militias of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement.

But they also want Arafat to put his own house in order, to punish the corrupt, sack the incompetent and build the institutions of a future state. 'There is an urgent need at this time to rearrange the Palestinian home,' said a leading article in al-Quds newspaper.

The debate looks set to intensify after today, when Sharon heads to Washington to reveal at last to President George W. Bush his strategy for snuffing out the intifada.

Some elements became clear last week, when Israeli troops tore up a road and dug two three-metre trenches to sever the university town of Bir Zeit from Ramallah, the commercial and political hub of the West Bank.

For many Palestinians, the event was a flashback to the last intifada of the late 1980s, when every household seemed involved in the struggle. Until last week this uprising was a much more professional affair, the preserve of a few dozen militia leaders, but the threat to the premier Palestinian academic institution brought designer-swathed twentysomethings and academics to the barricades. A few young hotheads threw stones, but there was no use of firearms from the Palestinian side.

'The election of Sharon and his policies are pushing more and more people into participating in the intifada. He brought the debate about the nature of the intifada back on the scene,' said Mustafa Barghouti, director of the Palestinian medical rescue committee, who organised the protest rallies at Bir Zeit. 'At the same time, more people are talking about repairing and fixing what is going on in Palestinian society.'

Some people have been talking about an internal clean-up since last October when 10,000 people signed that petition seeking to transform an uprising against the Israeli occupation into a larger movement for democracy and human rights.

But many more have come out in the open during the past few days, and people are growing bolder. In the Gaza Strip, a prominent psychiatrist has called for a Mahatma Gandhi-style civil disobedience campaign against the Israeli forces.

At a funeral in Ramallah last week, activists called for a ban on what has become the customary parade of masked men firing automatic weapons in the air. A town meeting called for renewed contacts with Jewish peace activists, so that they in turn could put pressure on the Israeli government.

Lawyers demanded that the legal union call elections which are long overdue, and which have been resisted by the governing Fatah council.

In nearby El-Bireh, and in Beit Jala, a suburb of Bethlehem, widespread anger at the gunmen whose nightly pot shots at Jewish settlements have provoked devastating reprisals from the Israeli army forced Fatah commanders to order a new ban on the use of firearms in popular areas.

'People have become so frustrated. They saw that during the last six months we just achieved nothing, and it seems we cannot achieve anything in the future, so let us do it another way,' said Bassam Eid, a prominent human rights activist, who issued a personal call to non-violence last month. 'The Palestinians realise now that all this shooting never achieved their aim, and it damaged their cause in the international community and media.'

Nobody is talking about a ban on throwing stones - which Palestinians regard as a symbolic form of protest - and most people see Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers as legitimate targets in a fight against Israel's 34-year-long occupation.

There is also great uneasiness about asking Palestinian civilians to turn out for mass rallies because of the Israeli army's use of sharpshooters who have picked off protest leaders with lethal effect.

'I think Israel took a decision from the beginning on a tactical and field level to take an approach to the intifada that prevented it from being a peaceful and mass movement,' said Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian analyst who organised civil disobedience in the first intifada in the 1980s. 'The way they did that was to use excessive force against demonstrators. That is why on the very first day they killed seven people in Jerusalem.'

Others argue that the Palestinian reliance on firearms in this intifada was also in the interests of Arafat's Fatah movement because it allowed his commanders to exercise control over an uprising that initially caught them by surprise.

Now, however, they want to recapture the spirit of the last intifada. 'We are going to see a new wave of civil demonstrations, civil and peaceful forms of struggle,' Barghouti said.

'In my opinion, this is much more effective and gives a far better impression of the Palestinian people to the world. Instead of being seen with guns and bombs, we will be seen protesting injustice and oppression and the violence exercised by Israel.'

fields.headline: Tube row ends in £13bn deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Up to £13 billion is to be spent upgrading London's Underground system after an historic agreement on ownership of the Tube was thrashed out by the Government and the London Transport Commissioner Robert Kiley.
fields.body:
Up to £13 billion is to be spent upgrading London's Underground system after an historic agreement on ownership of the Tube was thrashed out by the Government and the London Transport Commissioner Robert Kiley.

Senior sources said last night that John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, and Kiley, the man who turned around the New York subway, will agree in the next two days to a fundamental change in the way the Underground is managed.

The deal will bring to an end one of the longest running and embarrassing disputes the Government has faced. Kiley threatened to walk out of his post and return to the United States because of rows over Government plans for partially privatising of the Tube.

'It has been quite a battle,' said a Government official last night. 'But we have fought our way through and there seems to be agreement.'

The major sticking point was over Government plans to bring private investment into the Tube, the so-called public-private partnership (PPP). Three companies would own different Underground lines and would run them in competition with each other.

Kiley said that the plans were 'idiotic', overly complex and would increase the risk of safety lapses.

The breakthrough came on Friday night when Kiley, who was hired by the Mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, produced a 55-point plan on how the Underground should be run.

The Government has now conceded to most of Kiley's demands, although it has not agreed to him owning a 51 per cent share of the Tube. Instead Kiley will be given hiring and firing powers over the chief executives of the three companies that will take over running the Tube. He will also be left in sole charge of maintenance - and therefore safety - of the Underground which will be paid for by the companies.

Livingstone based his mayoral campaign on his rejection of PPP. But it is thought that, because Kiley has now been given responsibility for safety, he can agree to the three-company structure.

Kiley will also be given powers to take control of some aspects of the private companies if he thinks that investment plans or safety projects are not up to scratch.

'Now that we can go ahead it will mean a lot more money being released to modernise and maintain the Tube,' the government official said. 'We want the public to start seeing a difference by the end of the year.'

The £13bn will be released over a 15-year period, but much of it paid upfront to get emergency work done.

fields.headline: Our worst nightmare
fields.standfirst:
Observer journalist Oliver Owen thought his 10-year-old daughter was playing an innocent game on her computer. But when her schoolwork began to suffer, he discovered the sinister reality of her new internet friends

More net news
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Observer journalist Oliver Owen thought his 10-year-old daughter was playing an innocent game on her computer. But when her schoolwork began to suffer, he discovered the sinister reality of her new internet friends.
fields.body:
Like the vast majority of parents I revel in the successes of my children. Every good grade is celebrated; every note in the homework diary that applauds effort or improvement is greeted with joy and pride.

Over the years I have been extremely fortunate, as both my kids, Jemima and Zac, have worked hard at school and their reports make considerably happier reading than anything my parents were confronted with.

On the education front there appeared to be no worries. Or so I thought. A couple of months ago Jessica, my wife, called me at work with the news that Jemima's teacher had been on the phone and wanted to chat about our daughter. Apparently things had slipped a bit. Homework wasn't being done, corrections were being overlooked and there had been a big drop in standards.

This came as a shock. It was a complete about-turn from what we had become used to and it needed to be sorted out. We also needed to discover what had caused it. We racked our brains. Was she unhappy about something? Were there problems at school with bullying? Ten-year-old girls can be pretty sharp-tongued.

The answer was far simpler and was lurking at the top of the house. Back in September we bought Jemima a computer game she had wanted for her birthday. It was called 'Babyz' and the object was to raise and care for virtual infants. It provided hours of fun but it was also the catalyst for a sinister chain of events, the potential consequences of which don't bear thinking about.

'Babyz' players came from all over the world and displayed their 'kids' on websites which offered the latest 'Babyz' fashions and even virtual schools and baby-sitting services. Jemima wanted to be a part of this and set about building her own site. I was chuffed.

The problem with hosting a website is that it requires maintenance. This is time-consuming and costly, as we discovered with the arrival of a crippling phone bill. Jemima's creation had brought her into contact with 'Babyz' fans from all over the world. In the car on the way to school she would update me with who had signed her guest book and how many hits she had.

The internet never sleeps, so at the crack of dawn she would scuttle to the top of the house and log on to see who had visited from America, New Zealand and anywhere in between. Through trial and error she had taught herself any number of new skills.

The big snag, apart from the cost, was how all-consuming this had become. The birth of the website tied in with Jemima's downturn in performance at school. Jessica and I decided we would have to limit severely the time Jemima spent online. The internet was banned during the week, but at weekends she could update her site and catch up with all her new faceless friends. Problem solved.

Just before half term Jemima got some very good exam results and it appeared we were back on track, until the next phone bill arrived. While not as bad as the last one, it still made the eyes water. Obviously there was still some midweek internet action going on. Jessica took a look at the emails and I could tell by the look on her face when I returned from work that it hadn't been pleasant.

Traumatic was how my wife described it. It became clear that Jemima had been keeping up with her new-found internet friends and in particular someone called Debbie. We'd heard a lot about Debbie. She said she was 11, Dutch and a graphics wizard. As Jemima's site developed, Debbie had offered to create graphics and send them to my daughter for use on the site. What also came from Debbie was at first friendly chat.

Back in January the correspondence dealt solely with 'Babyz'. Jemima's game had crashed and Debbie emailed offering to help make it work again, while also announcing that two of her Babyz were getting married. Two days later Debbie was asking Jemima what kind of music she liked and whether or not she could call her Jemi. All very innocent up to that point, but things were heading for a darker turn.

One Friday last month, Jemima was off school because of a dental appointment. Debbie was not at school either, though I didn't know why. The following day Debbie offered to start building graphics. Over the weekend the messages came thick and fast. Debbie sent the graphics and asked that they should be put on the site as soon as possible.

Occasionally her tone appeared quite abrupt and she was using two different email addresses. The following Monday Jemima and Debbie had a long 'chat' about what they wanted to do when they were older. Jemima said she wanted to do something with graphic design, as she loved to draw, while Debbie said she wanted to write and suggested they do a book together. It began: 'You are 23 and you have two children. One girl of five years old and a boy of two. Then you find out that you are pregnant. When you want to tell it to your man, he says "I want to tell you something first. I am in love with another woman". What do you do??'

All day the story went on. Jemima is saved from being run over by a stranger and, according to Debbie, thanks him by going to the 'sleeping room' and 'doing it'. The story often put the onus on Jemima to describe things, trying to lead her. 'You chat with him and then as you get up to go to your bed... he follows. And then you say, "What are your plans?" You give him a kiss. And what happens then? And he stays with you. What happens?'

She was also asked how she felt when a man touched her leg. Did she like it? Was it nice? Debbie's story for Jemima was wound up only after Jemima had been through countless fictional sexual encounters for her virtual children.

In the evening Debbie began a story about herself. The story continued off and on for three days. Debbie went through a number of men and kept her child in an attic. In one section she found one of her men with another woman. 'I say, "What's the matter? You are a big Asshole man, a big asshole." And to the woman I say... Yesterday I did it with him, and now he wants to do it with you.'

All through the story Jemima kept trying to steer off the subject, but was sucked back in because she wanted Debbie to send her more graphics. After the transmission there was one more that included a graphic. Disturbingly it asked: 'When do we go further with my story?' Jemima's school friend also received some 'stories' from Debbie, and her parents, like Jessica and I, have now stopped any further contact with Debbie.

Jemima was clearly shocked by what she read, but said she felt compelled to reply because of the graphics. It became a bizarre addiction that almost ran out of control. Frighteningly she admitted that had Debbie asked for contact details she probably would have given them. She trusted her. The matter is now closed, but one question remains. Who is Debbie?

Research to be published this week by the Home Office will show that one in five teenage internet users receives a sexual solicitation or approach online. The study, carried out by the Internet Crime Forum, will also show that many children were exposed to 'inappropriate conversations', forced to listen to depraved fantasies or sent pornographic pictures.

Debbie might be an 11-year-old girl with a fertile imagination. She might also be a man who wanted to take things further, slowly deceiving my daughter or just getting his kicks as he typed, knowing that she would read it. Were the graphics what used to be the bag of sweets, the carrot with which to lure the innocent? We will never know, because how can you know who is on the keyboard at the other end?

Jemima clearly understands computers and hopefully some of the knowledge she has gathered will one day be put to good use. The internet is unavoidable. As a research tool it is vital, and as a means of communication it has revolutionised how we interact both at work and socially. A child of 10 today is going to go through life with this fantastic technology as a constant companion.

It is terrifying to think that while online a child can be watched and preyed on. Duped by a kind word or a hollow promise.

On occasion Jessica and I have been criticised by friends who are parents because we let Jemima and Zac walk round to the shop or down to the library. 'It's not safe,' they say, 'because you don't know who they might meet.'

But gradually they have to be allowed some independence and learn for themselves about the world beyond the front door and the school gate.

The frightening thing is that men you wanted your children to avoid might already be in touch with them right under your nose and in your own house. He could be in your computer. You just don't know.

Paedophiles on the net

 One in five children using internet chat rooms is targeted by paedophiles.

 'Grooming' - where a paedophile encounters children on the web or over the phone and plans a meeting - is not illegal.

 Five million British children are now regular online visitors either at school or at home.

 Internet crimes are to be tackled by a new high-tech crime group to be set up next month.

webTitle: Comment: Indie editor Simon Kelner on the Saatchi exhibition

fields.headline: Turn of the Screws
fields.standfirst:
The News of the World 's outrage at Tierney Gearon's photographs was fuelled by hypocrisy and vengeance, argues Simon Kelner, editor in chief of the Independent on Sunday which sponsored the exhibition of the pictures

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The News of the World 's outrage at Tierney Gearon's photographs was fuelled by hypocrisy and vengeance, argues Simon Kelner, editor in chief of the Independent on Sunday which sponsored the exhibition of the pictures
fields.body:
At about 2.30 last Saturday afternoon, my doorbell rang. On the step was a tall man in a dark suit, holding some papers. I thought he was an estate agent, but he announced himself as a reporter from the News of the World. This was unnerving enough in itself, but his inquiry had a sinister, unpleasant edge. 'You have a daughter,' he said. 'What do you think of these photographs?' He then showed me colour photocopies of some of the pictures from the now infamous exhibition of Tierney Gearon's portraits of her children at the Saatchi Gallery.

I didn't comment. He persisted with his questioning. 'What about this one? Don't you think it suggests oral sex?' I said goodbye and closed the door.

So why did the News of the World come knocking? Why were they so concerned about an exhibition at a private gallery that had already been on show for seven weeks and which, as the paper itself admitted, was seen only by 'upper-crust art lovers'? And why were they taking such a personal interest in me?

The previous day, the police had acted on a complaint from a member of the public - it is not beyond the realms of possibility that this was a News of the World reporter - and warned the Saatchi Gallery that it faced prosecution under the Protection of Children Act unless two of Ms Gearon's photographs, in which her children are unclothed, were removed. The exhibition is sponsored by the Independent on Sunday, of which I am editor-in-chief. In the normal course of events, I might expect to be telephoned for a comment.

It is at this point that the political becomes the personal. When Rebekah Wade took over as editor of the News of the World last summer, she gained instant notoriety by launching, in the wake of the murder of Sarah Payne, a campaign to name and shame paedophiles, promising to print the pictures of every sex offender in Britain. The Independent, together with the Daily Telegraph, the NSPCC, the police, the probation service and many MPs, took a stand against this campaign. Ms Wade attacked me in a leader column, saying I was out of tune with public opinion and that I 'know nothing of the real world'. Two weeks later, her campaign, which had resulted in civil disorder, the victimisation of innocent citizens, the driving underground of known sex offenders and the release of convicted paedophiles, was abandoned.

There was, and is, something distasteful about the serious issue of child abuse being turned into a spat between two newspaper editors. But when I telephoned Ms Wade last Saturday to express my concern about being 'doorstepped' by one of her reporters, she revealed something of her motives and of the newspaper's modus operandi .

She professed shock that I had been visited by a reporter. 'That's terrible,' she said, incredulously. 'I just asked them to get a comment from you. I'll find out who did it and have a word. It's awful that your daughter was dragged into it.' I, too, found it surprising that they would go to the trouble of coming to my home when all they wanted was a simple quote. Also, how did they get my address? I then remembered that an hour or so before the doorbell rang, I had had a phone call from the TV licensing department asking me to confirm my address. Surely this was a coincidence too far.

I felt wrong-footed by the whole experience, and not a little paranoid; the first thing I did was to remove a picture of my 11-year-old daughter in a swimsuit from my wall. (As a newspaper editor, I understand that I have a limited right to feel squeamish about the ways of the media. It did make me realise, however, how threatened and distressed ordinary members of the public must feel when confronted by these tactics.)

I gave Ms Wade a comment about the exhibition, which she took down, and the paper represented faithfully the next day. She then said: 'Don't worry, I shan't be calling for your resignation', a reference to our dispute over her name-and-shame campaign. 'In fact,' she said, 'every time you call for my resignation, Rupert gives me a pay rise.' So there we have it: whatever the rights and wrongs of this campaign, it did at least raise her profile, please her proprietor and boost her pay packet.

Seven months on, the criticism clearly still rankles with Ms Wade; she even remembers our headline, even though she dismissively refers to the Independent as an 'unpopular, low-circulation offering'. So last Sunday, hiding behind the moral indignation about the 'vile' and 'lurid' exhibition at the Saatchi Gallery, she returned to the personal attack. In a leading article, she effectively accused me, and my newspaper, of promoting paedophilia. We were guilty of 'backing a revolting exhibition of perversion under the guise of art' and I had sought to justify a 'degrading exploitation of child nudity for commercial gain'.

She obviously didn't feel too upset by the photographs, because she used a selection of them over two pages of her newspaper. But to spare her readers' delicate sensibilities, she blacked out the children's genitals. This, as the artist pointed out eloquently last week, had the effect of making them look like pages torn from a pornographic magazine, particularly in the context of the genuinely sordid material that makes up the News of the World 's news pages. When viewed as they are meant to be (ie on a gallery wall), these photographs are anything but exploitative. It is difficult to imagine that anyone could find them arousing, and it surprised nobody when, last Thursday, the Crown Prosecution Service ruled that the photographs were not indecent and that the case was closed.

The definition of indecency in law is 'anything likely to offend right-minded people'. The law cannot make the assumption that everyone has paedophile instincts. The issue of how best to protect our children is of paramount concern to all parents. The fuss over some pictures in an exhibition diverts attention from the real dangers our children are prey to every day when they log on to the internet in the sanctuary of their homes.

For all the outrage of the News of the World, this was not a debate about the exploitation of children. The exploitation was purely on the part of the News of the World in creating a moral panic while seeking to settle an old score.

And the net result? Tierney Gearon, a hitherto unknown photographer, has received attention she could not have anticipated. The Saatchi Gallery has decided to extend the exhibition for another month. And no doubt Rebekah Wade is waiting for the telephone call from Rupert Murdoch offering her a raise. Trebles all round.
