webTitle: Comment: Mary Riddell on paranoid parenting

fields.headline: Leave those kids alone
fields.standfirst:
We pamper them and show them off (sometimes naked on a gallery wall). But do we really care?

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Mary Riddell: We pamper them and show them off (sometimes naked on a gallery wall). But do we really care?
fields.body:
Five years have passed since Thomas Hamilton walked into the gym of Dunblane Primary School, shooting 16 pupils and their teacher dead. Last week's anniversary passed quietly in a town determined to move on. Beyond its boundaries, any positive legacy of the revulsion inspired by the massacre faded long ago. Gun crime has increased by 50 per cent in the intervening years. Criminals use weapons smuggled in as easily as bootleg cigarettes, and, for fashion-conscious night-clubbers, replica weapons are the hot accessory.

How quickly we forget. And still some memory persists, if only in an escalating terror of the dangers assailing children. Shortly before Dunblane remembered its dead, the police called on the Saatchi Gallery and demanded the removal of children's photographs described by a Sunday newspaper as a 'revolting exhibition of perversion'. As antidote to such anxieties, Frank Furedi's new book, Paranoid Parenting, describes a generation of mad riskophobes keeping their pampered children under virtual house arrest. And, lest anyone should still be feeling complacent, a study for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation claims that the offspring of women who work get fewer A-levels.

To unpick all this, start with the Saatchi show and the nude pictures taken by Tierney Gearon of her daughter, Emilee, seven, and her son, Michael, four. The British are notoriously squeamish about art, as demonstrated by Tony Blair's alleged refusal to pose for pictures at the Royal Academy's 'Genius of Rome' exhibition, for fear that his head might be overhung with the penis of Hercules. Had such an image emerged, it would have been Constable's 'Haywain' in comparison with the Gearon pictures. To some, Andreas Whittam Smith included, the masked portraits were sinister paedophile-bait. For others, the threat of censorship was an assault on liberty and a tacit admission that perverts now set society's rules.

Both views, though ponderously and furiously debated, missed the only two relevant points. The Saatchi case was no more than a media spat initiated by the News of the World, still smarting at the denigration of its naming and shaming child-sex offenders by the 'snooty' Independent. The NoW verdict ('lurid, vile, should be closed down') was not muted in deference to the show's sponsor: the Independent on Sunday .

Even so, Gearon's pictures, though neither lurid nor vile, should not be on public view. It is axiomatic that parents do not grossly exploit their children for their own gain. That holds true whether the mother in question is a Romanian refugee sending her toddler through a Tube train carriage with a begging bowl or an ambitious photographer with a reputation to make. The single difference is that the first is driven by fear that her child may starve, while the latter, one imagines, was motivated less by need than by flattery at the interest the influential Charles Saatchi evinced in her charmless family snapshots.

If she was disturbed by the controversy, Gearon did not show it. On the contrary, she inflated the debate, denying in interviews illustrated with the notorious pictures, that her children would have future problems. 'I don't think they will be embarrassed, because I have never made them feel ashamed of their bodies, or of their nudity,' she said. Even if true, that is not the issue. Children have rights too, and being a parent is not an exemption clause from their observance. Unless Gearon is casual enough about nudity to pose, like her son, with her knickers round her knees, she should not assume that her children will be as sanguine as she on discovering that their pictures were, however ludicrously, reviled as objects of disgust and a peepshow for perverts.

The first rule of parenthood is to shield your children from hurt or harm. Will Gearon's breach of that rule have any adverse consequences? Frank Furedi would probably say not. Last week Furedi introduced his own young (though fully-clothed) son, Jacob, into the public domain as a publicity adjunct to the launch of his book on parental paranoia. In his view, we are all neurotics fixated on determinism. Parents may behave badly. Awful things may happen to children. But the belief that such events must leave lasting scars is Freudianism bloated beyond all proportion.

We are, in Furedi's thesis, obsessive interventionists who believe that we must feed our children Mozart in the womb and breast milk from birth in order to launch them on the road of golden outcomes. The rules of 'hyper-parenting' decree that children are fragile and vulnerable, whereas they are actually tough survivors being mollycoddled half to death, according to Furedi, whose arguments are threaded with nostalgia. Oh, for the good old days, when playgrounds were full of swings and slides so high that a fall (on to traditional concrete rather than the rubber now demanded by irrational safety freaks) would smash small skulls like eggshells. But not many died, Furedi argues, for lack of safety precautions or of a supervising parent with better things to do. In his Zolaesque Utopia, fathers staggered home from 12-hour factory shifts, mothers worked correspondingly hard, and there was no feeble hand-wringing about getting more time with the children.

There is not a word about the flaws or the autocracy of those who believed it their children's duty to absorb and honour unquestioningly the parental take on morality (rigid), religion (plentiful), and sex (never before marriage).

The new generation of parents, however over-attentive or over-anxious, has a more open, respectful and generous relationship with its children. Furedi does not say so. Nor does he explain how his scorn for social determinism squares with the irrefutable linkage between deprivation and failure. In scoffing at unnecessary worries over 'children at risk', he does not mention the result, for children like Chelsea Brown and Anna Climbie, when such insouciance is duly observed. Most irritating of all is the inference that Furedi's experience of fatherhood qualifies him to lecture, Dr Spockishly, on how the rest of us are getting it wrong. Like Tierney Gearon, he would have been wiser to leave his family out of it.

None the less, Furedi is sometimes right. It is true that the media gives shape to bizarre, unhealthy fears for children's safety. It is a pity that the breakdown of community means that parents regard other adults as potential predators rather than allies. It is a shame that we have reached a point where politicians imply, absurdly, that society has no problems that a few seminars on parenting skills can't put right. But the influence of politics on parenting is not all adverse.

With the single exception of compelling lone parents of under-fives to attend 'work-focused' interviews, Gordon Brown's Budget was helpful to working mothers and fathers.

Child care is still not plentiful enough. It is, however, a great deal better and more widely-available than it was for Seventies children, whose experiences inform the Rowntree survey alleging that working women have thicker kids. As Furedi fails to say, unfulfilled lives are determined not by parents' paranoia but by their poverty.

webTitle: How can I save on my car insurance?

fields.headline: How can I save on my car insurance?
fields.trailText: How can I save on my car insurance?
fields.body:
You may be thinking of buying a new Y-registration car, but have you considered new car insurance?

Premiums on a typical comprehensive policy can vary by up to 60 per cent, says broker AA Insurance Services. The cost of car cover has been increasing since 1996, when insurers started to claw back money they lost fighting tough competition in the early Nineties and making more claims pay-outs. Prices are still rising: the AA predicts an average increase of 19 per cent this year.

Yet a few telephone calls could save you hundreds of pounds. Comprehensive insurance now costs an average of £620.53 a year, but AA insurance services says it can easily find you a deal from its panel of 20 lenders at £385.70, almost that half that.

The lesson is not to automatically renew with your existing insurer. Ring round or go to a broker such as Screentrade.co.uk, which will do it for you. Buying online is often cheaper. The AA offers a 5 per cent discount for buying or renewing cover in that way.

If you can't get a quote you think is reasonable because, for example, you are in a high-risk group - young people and drivers with convictions are among those who pay more - you can save by limiting the terms of the cover. Restrict the number of drivers on your policy and you could cut the cost by up to 25 per cent.

Fitting an alarm or immobiliser can cut premiums, but make sure it conforms to government standards. Passing an advanced driving test may qualify you for lower premiums. This may also protect your no-claims bonus - and help you avoid accidents.

As well as the variations in price, there is some variation in terms and conditions across the industry. Watch out for high policy excesses - to £400 - and check whether the policy will automatically cover you for accidents abroad. This is one of the criteria that AA insurance services, which offers standardised policies, demands from its providers.

 Contact AA insurance services on 0800 444777.

fields.headline: It's a mad life, but it keeps me sane
fields.trailText: Judi and Michael Apichella talk about their experience of bringing up five children.
fields.body:
'We take our Christian faith seriously, which helps when it comes to praying for money - which we need to a lot,' laughs Judi Apichella, 45. 'Having five children makes life expensive, obviously, and though we wouldn't want it any other way, it isn't always easy.'

Judi and husband Michael, 47, always knew they wanted several children. 'The first four were planned, and the last one had been talked about if not exactly planned,' says Judi. 'We love children, we love a busy house with lots going on - and there's always room for one more.'

For several years life was a bit of a squeeze for the Apichellas. 'We had a three-bedroom house with one downstairs loo in Oxfordshire, and there were seven of us. It was tight - our youngest, Michael, shared our bedroom until he was nearly three, which wasn't ideal.'

A job opportunity for Michael, a writer, in East Anglia, meant the chance to move somewhere with cheaper housing. 'Our current home has three bedrooms, but it's a lot bigger all round,' says Judi. 'We're currently trying to buy the flat next door to expand into - it's very exciting for the older girls, Maria, 15, and Lizzy, 14, because they'll have their own bedrooms for the first time in their life.'

Having a big family forces the family to think creatively about solutions to their economic problems - as with the decision to buy the adjoining flat.

Another creative decision was to educate Maria at home for a year when they felt she needed extra help. 'We'd moved her to a private school in Oxfordshire, but it was hard to afford. Then we moved over here so had to think again anyway. Home schooling was hard work, especially as I had a pre-school child as well at the time. But it was worth it - a private tutor was something we just couldn't run to.'

School trips are out, too. 'We've told the children they just aren't on the agenda,' says Judi. 'It is very hard when they come home and they've had their appetite whetted by some teacher - it makes me really angry, actually - but we just have to say no.

We encourage them to do other things, such as sailing with a teen group. The two older girls are trying to save at the moment, and it's hard on them that they don't get pocket money, but they've started babysitting as a team and it's been really good for them.'

When Michael, five, started school, Judi turned to childminding to make some extra money. 'Friends thought I was mad - I'd finally got all my own children off to school and here I was taking on other people's toddlers,' she says. 'But it made sense to me. I love children, and it fits in with the needs of running a family of five because I'm home-based.'

Judi feels that holidays are something no family can do without, but they have to be budget-priced. Usually, that means borrowing a holiday home or renting an inexpensive house. Shopping, says Judi, isn't as much of a problem as you might think. 'When you've got loads of kids you can't hang out at the shops, so you're not tempted,' she says.

'You can't be the kind of person who's easily jealous or you'd be unhappy. In fact I think having a big family makes you quite humble .'

'In many ways we do live a mad life. But what's the alternative? For us both to have big full-time jobs? Maybe then we could send the children to private schools, but we'd have to work so hard we'd hardly ever see them.

'Life our way is much, much more fun - we wouldn't swap it for anything.'

webTitle: Four. Now what will we do?

fields.headline: Four. Now what will we do?
fields.trailText: Janet Bonthron and Iestyn Roberts explain how they adjusted their lifestyle to suit their four children.
fields.body:
Janet Bonthron, 42, and Iestyn Roberts, 44, always knew they wanted four children, so sitting down to see whether they could afford it didn't seem to make much sense. 'We didn't do it that way,' says Janet. 'We thought we'd have the children and then adjust our lifestyle accordingly.'

Because Iestyn's job running out-of-town retail parks is well-paid, adjustment hasn't been as difficult as it might have been. But the couple did take the decision to send their children Mair, nine, Jesse, eight and Owain, six, to private schools - and three-year-old Huw will follow in due course. 'If we hadn't done that, we'd have a reasonable disposable income now,' says Janet. As things are, the family has to keep a tight rein on spending to allow for the school fees.

'We did go through a phase of budgeting and set up a spreadsheet on our computer and thought about our monthly income and outgoings,' says Janet. 'We don't do it on a regular basis any more, but it has made me aware of the outgoings, which probably helps.'

Downsizing holidays has been one of the ways the family has cut back. 'Several years ago, before we had the children, we bought a cheap cottage in northern France with the money we got from my flat when we married, and now it's the backbone of our holidays,' says Janet.

'It's small and it's not near the sea, but it means we can have cheap holidays - although the ferry isn't cheap with a people carrier and the six of us.

'We've also joined the Youth Hostel Association and had a weekend away earlier this year in York in a youth hostel. It was great - a lot cheaper than a hotel would have been, and a very easy-going place to stay with lots of children. They all thought it was great.'

Getting there by train using a Family Railcard also made good economic sense. Eating out in restaurants is a luxury the family don't run to that often. 'Even going to a pizzeria with our lot costs at least £60,' says Janet.

'And when you're out somewhere for the day, going into a cafe for a drink and a snack is horrendously expensive. It helps if I remember to pack everyone a drink and some biscuits - but I'm not always that organised. I think the main difference between us and some other families I know who've either got fewer children or more money or both is that they have more luxuries. I don't spend much money on clothes, for example - either for me or for the children. The boys have only got their school coats, and they wear those whenever they go out. Mair isn't one of those little girls with loads of pairs of shoes, either.'

The couple are committed urban dwellers, and home is a five-bedroomed house in Balham in south London.

'We'd look at moving out of town if we had to for Iestyn's job, but unless we had to we wouldn't choose it,' says Janet.

webTitle: All good people go to haven

fields.headline: All good people go to haven
fields.standfirst: A mother seeks asylum from a grim life in Moscow, and ends up in an equally grim Margate
fields.trailText: A mother seeks asylum from a grim life in Moscow, and ends up in an equally grim Margate
fields.body:
Last Resort (77 mins, 15) Directed by Pawel Pawlikowski; starring Dina Korzun, Paddy Considine, Artiom Strelnikov

The first feature film by the highly regarded, Polish-born, London-based documentary director Pawel Pawlikowski, Last Resort, arrives in the cinema garlanded with praise and prizes from various festivals. As well as winning the Michael Powell Award at Edinburgh, it recently received Bafta's Carl Foreman Award for Most Promising Newcomer to British film. It is not at all a bad picture, and deals with a timely subject, though the acclaim is something of a reflection on the indifferent state of our native cinema.

The plight of the refugee has been a subject for movies since the exodus of Nazi victims from Germany in the 1930s; indeed, Casablanca, one of the most popular pictures of all time, turns upon political fugitives caught in that no man's land between emigration and immigration.

There was a tradition, in Britain at least, of treating such matters as comedy, as cat-and-mouse games between rigid bureaucrats and wily immigrants - one thinks of Michael Hastings's play Gloo Joo, and Michael Poliakoff's Coming in to Land. Recent pictures have been more sombre - a string of pictures about refugees from the former Yugoslavia, and three Ken Loach films featuring Latin Americans, Carla's Song, Ladybird Ladybird and Bread and Roses.

Last Resort occupies an odd position between these two streams. The heroine, Tanya (Dina Korzun), is a pretty young Russian, a would-be children's book illustrator, twice married and divorced, coming to London with her streetwise 10-year-old son, Artiom (Artiom Strelnikov), to join her British fiancé. When he reveals his suspected fecklessness by not turning up to meet her at the airport, Tanya claims in an amusing encounter with a jargon-spouting immigration officer, played by Perry Benson, a familiar exponent of comic ineptitude, that she's really seeking political asylum.

In consequence, she and Artiom are bused off to a holding area for refugees in the bleak, off-season seaside town of Stonehaven (actually Margate). They're billeted in a crumbling tower- block as awful as anything in the suburbs of Moscow or Warsaw, and along with refugees from a hundred other places they're observed by CCTV, monitored by police with dogs, and made to exist without work on vouchers for which no change is ever given.

The cold, overcast, thinly-populated Stonehaven is a reflection of Tanya's state of mind, though despite Artiom calling it 'the armpit of the world', it is not put down socially the way Margate was in Lindsay Anderson's 1953 short, O Dreamland, a documentary of Larkinesque misanthropy. Certainly, Tanya and Artiom are strangers in a strange land, but Last Resort is no documentary and indeed is frequently implausible.

In fact, it's less a picture about the problems of refugees than a transposition to Europe of a longstanding Hollywood feminist genre that one might call 'the relocation movie'. In these films, a blue-collar widow or divorcée pulls up her stakes and, with a querulous son or daughter in tow, drives west in search of a new life and to realise her dreams.

Always she encounters two men - one seductive, brutal and exploitative, the other gentle, gauche and helpful - and suffers bitter disappointment and briefly neglects her troubled teenage child before coming to terms with reality. Martin Scorsese's Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore is the most famous example, the Susan Sarandon vehicle Anywhere But Here among the most recent.

Last Resort touches all the bases of this genre. The bad guys are a pair of filmmakers who inveigle her into participating in erotic videos for the internet. The good guy (attractively played by Paddy Considine, the psychopathic swain in A Room for Romeo Brass) is a simple arcade owner and bingo-caller, recovering from a difficult childhood and a jail stretch for GBH.

Generously and disinterestedly, he helps the pair and saves Artiom from the band of juvenile thieves he's fallen in with. A beached boat that offers her the hope of escape is called Lucky Lady.

Tanya's pivotal line is pure Hollywood and might well have been spoken by Ellen Burstyn in Alice: 'I have to stop dreaming. I've been dreaming all my life. I've got to go back and restart my life.'

Last Resort occupies an odd position between these two streams. The heroine, Tanya (Dina Korzun), is a pretty young Russian, a would-be children's book illustrator, twice married and divorced, coming to London with her streetwise 10-year-old son, Artiom (Artiom Strelnikov), to join her British fiancé. When he reveals his suspected fecklessness by not turning up to meet her at the airport, Tanya claims in an amusing encounter with a jargon-spouting immigration officer, played by Perry Benson, a familiar exponent of comic ineptitude, that she's really seeking political asylum. In consequence, she and Artiom are bused off to a holding area for refugees in the bleak, off-season seaside town of Stonehaven (actually Margate). They're billeted in a crumbling tower- block as awful as anything in the suburbs of Moscow or Warsaw, and along with refugees from a hundred other places they're observed by CCTV, monitored by police with dogs, and made to exist without work on vouchers for which no change is ever given. The cold, overcast, thinly-populated Stonehaven is a reflection of Tanya's state of mind, though despite Artiom calling it 'the armpit of the world', it is not put down socially the way Margate was in Lindsay Anderson's 1953 short, O Dreamland, a documentary of Larkinesque misanthropy. Certainly, Tanya and Artiom are strangers in a strange land, but Last Resort is no documentary and indeed is frequently implausible. In fact, it's less a picture about the problems of refugees than a transposition to Europe of a longstanding Hollywood feminist genre that one might call 'the relocation movie'. In these films, a blue-collar widow or divorcée pulls up her stakes and, with a querulous son or daughter in tow, drives west in search of a new life and to realise her dreams. Always she encounters two men - one seductive, brutal and exploitative, the other gentle, gauche and helpful - and suffers bitter disappointment and briefly neglects her troubled teenage child before coming to terms with reality. Martin Scorsese's Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore is the most famous example, the Susan Sarandon vehicle Anywhere But Here among the most recent. Last Resort touches all the bases of this genre. The bad guys are a pair of filmmakers who inveigle her into participating in erotic videos for the internet. The good guy (attractively played by Paddy Considine, the psychopathic swain in A Room for Romeo Brass) is a simple arcade owner and bingo-caller, recovering from a difficult childhood and a jail stretch for GBH. Generously and disinterestedly, he helps the pair and saves Artiom from the band of juvenile thieves he's fallen in with. A beached boat that offers her the hope of escape is called Lucky Lady. Tanya's pivotal line is pure Hollywood and might well have been spoken by Ellen Burstyn in Alice: 'I have to stop dreaming. I've been dreaming all my life. I've got to go back and restart my life.'

fields.headline: In league with the devil
fields.standfirst: Tubbs and Edward are horrific grotesques, but the Gents are just as good when they leave Royston Vasey
fields.trailText: Tubbs and Edward are horrific grotesques, but the Gents are just as good when they leave Royston Vasey
fields.body:
The League of Gentlemen Presents A Local Show For Local People Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London WC2

It must be every comic's dream: strutting on to the stage of a packed West End theatre to present something which began life in smoky fringe venues, went on to storm the Edinburgh Festival, scooped armfuls of prizes (including Perrier, Bafta and Golden Rose), graduated to Radio 4, was then transmuted into two £200,000-per-episode BBC series with several million regular viewers, and has been exported to 12 countries.

It has come a full circle with this latest conversion into a live sketch show for a sell-out national tour which opened for a West End run last week. The League of Gentlemen are approaching levels of cultiness usually associated with their spiritual fathers, Monty Python.

The curtain was late going up, so that by the time Reece Shearsmith, Steve Pemberton and Mark Gattis gyrated through the ripples of dry ice to the hard rock strains of 'Voodoo Lady', the audience - many of them with 'Are You Local?', 'Hello Dave' or 'Dole Scum' emblazoned across their T-shirts - were jigging up and down with anticipation like a school trip needing the loo. Johnny-come-lately fans must have been baffled if they'd been expecting the villagers of Royston Vasey to cavort about the stage for two-and-a-half hours.

Instead, for the first half of the show, the League returned to the format of their early Fringe material. Dressed in tuxedos, they produced a slick succession of short sketches, some new, some familiar, with scant props and minimal costumes.

The Gentlemen have been keen to assert that this is 'a theatrical revue' and not an attempt to recreate a successful television show live. On screen, the actors have successfully bridged the divide between sketch show and sitcom in a similar way to The Fast Show: familiar characters in familiar settings appear in a series of discrete sketches that gradually build up an ongoing narrative. Given the limits of space and time on stage, however, the sketch format comes back into its own.

In fact, the first thought that springs to mind as they launch into the first sketch, in which Pemberton and Gattis appear as two football supporters watching Hamlet, is 'so that's what they look like, then'.

Without the make-up and costumes that transform them into the largely middle-aged grotesques of Royston Vasey, the three Gentlemen look surprisingly boyish and freshly scrubbed in their dinner jackets, and it's a delight to see them conjuring up different characters, from the mild-mannered doctor trying to comprehend the Byzantine rules of the card game Go Johnny Go Go Go Go, to Captain Scott and his expedition team contemplating mutual masturbation as the fatal blizzard sets in.

But the wanking jokes conceal a subtle erudition: the sketches are littered with allusions to Shakespeare, Chekhov, Jean Genet and Dr Faustus . One of the finest new characters is Tish, the Camden Town fag-hag, who tramples all over the sensibilities of her gay 'friends', punctuating her mindless stream-of-consciousnes with air kisses and the refrain 'God, I just love gay guys!' Gradually, though, the famous 'dark edge' seeps in; while Shakespeare may not actually have used the phrase 'Who ate all the pies?' in Hamlet, the League's interpretation of comedy shares much with his later plays. Death, fear and cruelty are only just held at bay by the humour, but the sketches usually pull back from the abyss at the last minute.

The pièce de résistance of the first half features Olly Plimsolls of Royston Vasey's theatre group, Legz Akimbo, presenting his experimental new northern verse play, Scumbelina, a magnificent parody of avant-garde theatre and northern realism in general, lampooning the likes of Willy Russell, Tony Harrison, Jim Cartwright and 'John Fucking Godber!', as Plimsolls's 'cast' shouts repeatedly at the end. It's also a clever jibe at the critics' relentless labelling of the League as 'northern comics'.

After the interval, the curtain whipped back to reveal a set of Royston Vasey's infamous 'Local Shop', over which the grotesque Edward and Tubbs hover on wires with angel wings. The subsequent story is loosely based on Edward and Tubbs's posthumous mission to revisit Royston Vasey and redeem themselves for the serial killings of anyone not 'local' who attempted to buy their 'precious things'.

The audience experienced fresh paroxysms of delight each time a favourite character or catchphrase appeared, but the early pantomime innuendo of camp German teacher Herr Lipp, who drags a frightened 'volunteer' from the audience ('Don't vorry, I made a boy come on stage last night') gives a false sense of security: the sketches featuring the sinister blacked-up ringmaster Papa Lazarou, who abducts women with the inexplicable phrase 'You're my wife now, Dave', and especially the butcher Hillary Briss, who serves up human meat, confirm that horror influences the League's material just as much as Python, and are likely to provide nightmares for weeks to come.

While there was a little too much set and costume changing in this half, obliging the audience to listen to voice-overs while looking at a blank curtain, it was undoubtedly what the fans wanted. A Local Show may not be family entertainment, but it's a splendid showcase for the League of Gentlemen's versatile talents.

webTitle: Getting it down to a Divine art

fields.headline: Getting it down to a Divine art
fields.trailText: The Divine Comedy Southampton University
fields.body:
The Divine Comedy Southampton University

Neil Hannon's group, the Divine Comedy, have always been a band that polarises opinion. For every critic prepared to praise their cultivated eccentricity and knowing lyrics, another could be guaranteed to dismiss them as a group mired in the worse kind of art-school pretension. Indeed, Hannon seemed to have one eyebrow permanently arched. Cockier than Jarvis Cocker, Hannon was the Britpop antidote to Britpop.

Easy-listening pastiches such as 'National Express' and 'Becoming More Like Alfie' delved into the national stock of kitsch and, as a result, were sprinkled with more pop-culture references than the average sketch show.

The navel-gazing and postmodernist malarkey made the Divine Comedy an easy target, but they have changed. They moved from indie label Setanta, signed to Parlophone and recruited Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich to oversee their latest album, Regeneration.

The result is a triumph of melancholy and wonderfully textured guitars held together by Hannon's songwriting gifts. Some of the songs are meandering, and few are ripe for audience participation.

Live, it's clear that Hannon and Co are no longer pop's dandies as soon as they launch into their first song, a speeded-up version of their current single, 'Love What You Do'. Hannon, thin, pale and lank-haired, may look like a callow pop star, but he is an assured performer.

Hannon sacrificed little of his lyrical inventiveness. In the absurdist 'Bad Ambassador', he sings: 'I'm gonna abseil down my ivory tower and buy myself a Jaguar.' But even stripped of Godrich's rich production values, these songs stand up, despite the best efforts of the dodgy acoustics to dampen the set.

The audience sings along to old favourites like 'Sweden' but it's easy to see some of the newer songs usurping it in the fans' affections. The bad sound obscures the occasional witty flourish but we still get the gist. On the languid 'Eye of the Needle', Hannon, the son of a bishop, laments bourgeois Christianity: 'The cars in the churchyard are shiny and German/ Distinctly at odds with the mood of the sermon.'

Hannon lifts the meditative 'Mastermind' into a magnificent showpiece: 'Tell me that I'm normal and tell me that I'm sane,' he implores. Under the spotlight and with scant musical accompaniment, Hannon is the lonely balladeer and it's enough to provoke the person in front of me to express regret that he'd forgotten to bring a lighter to wave aloft. No irony intended, I'm sure.

The Divine Comedy provide that themselves with their customary rendition of Status Quo's 'Pictures of Matchstick Men' accompanied by swinging guitars and hips. Then, in the encore, Hannon segues into Robert Palmer's 'Addicted to Love' and can't resist a little smirk. He returns on his own, armed with an acoustic guitar to perform 'National Express' and 'Frog Princess'; both songs benefit from the simplified treatment.

If the new songs and direction bemuse the audience, it doesn't show. The Divine Comedy have jettisoned much of what made them so distinctive, which is no bad thing. No longer fops, the Divine Comedy really have undergone a regeneration.

webTitle: I've told you not to call me at the office...

fields.headline: I've told you not to call me at the office...
fields.standfirst: This article was written despite the demands of children, a steady stream of visitors, and an ever-beckoning fridge. So think before you decide to work from home, says Fiona Gibson
fields.trailText: This article was written despite the demands of children, a steady stream of visitors, and an ever-beckoning fridge. So think before you decide to work from home, says Fiona Gibson
fields.body:
'You lucky thing, working from home.' My friend lolled on my sofa, sipping coffee. I fidgeted, wondering when she intended to get the hell out so I could steam into some work.

Two days a week, my children are bundled off to nursery. When someone drops in for a chat, I am aware of a loud tick-ticking between my ears, reminding me that the precious day (and therefore my professional reputation and any hope of future work) is slipping down the plughole. People don't think you are actually working if you never go out but just sit around twiddling about on the computer. You are not a professional person in your bobbly sweater and slippers. You are the Pop-in Café.

Yet working from home has whopping advantages: no commuting and you can work to your own, infinitely flexible schedule. You can spend all day repeatedly opening and closing the fridge door and then stay up till 3am, goggle-eyed at the PC. If your child emerges from his bed as one enormous, crusty chicken pox, you take time off and (here's the crux) work all weekend to catch up. But at least you can be there.

In a new study for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, authors John Ermisch and Marco Francesconi at The University of Essex tracked the progress of children born in the Seventies. They concluded - as if we are not awash with guilt already - that full-time employment for mothers of under-fives has 'tended to reduce the child's chances of obtaining A-level qualifications' and 'increase the child's risk of experiencing psychological distress as a young adult'. In contrast, part-time employment by mothers 'appeared to have few adverse effects'. Which makes home-working, with its bendy schedule, seem ideal.

Jane Alexander, author of books on holistic living including The Energy Secret (Thorsons), has worked from home for 10 years. She and her partner share the caring of James, their two-year-old son. 'I'm a workaholic and extremely well-disciplined. It was bliss to come from a hectic office to the peace of home. People dropping in hasn't been a problem - in London I would ignore the doorbell, and when we moved to Somerset I didn't know a soul.'

But there is a downside. Alexander adds: 'Isolation is the worst part. Managing work and a baby has meant lots of evening and weekend working. But the plus side is huge. James is relaxed and confident having both his parents around - although, naturally, he does not always understand that Mummy has to work rather than build a cushion mountain.'

Young children seem to have no concept of why we work or need some degree of solitude in which to do it. I was gobsmacked at reading that Tony Parsons managed to tackle proper, grown-up tasks while his young son played at his feet. I cannot imagine achieving anything worthwhile without tying up my children or resorting to strong adhesive. I have attempted to work with my 10-month-old daughter in the house. Yes, she would happily gnaw at a teething ring next to my chair; moments later I would look down to see a baby-free void and finally locate her in the kitchen, licking the pedal bin.

Although forbidden, my sons break and enter my office to steal pens, leaving me to make notes with a crayon. My husband props up his guitars against my PC. I have made pretend phone calls to shoo my cleaning lady away, and fixed a coffee for a friend with cold water.

Professor Cary Cooper of the University of Science and Technology in Manchester stresses: 'Family, friends and neighbours must understand the nature of your role.' He recommends 'drawing a clear line between work and personal space. When you work in a central office you have a clear exit time; at home the tendency is to work on and on. Home working is all about flexibility, but it is counter productive if you cannot achieve a good work/life balance.'

Ian Winter, a graphic designer based on the Isle of Wight, set up his home-based business when his triplet daughters, now 14, were toddlers. 'When they know you work from home, clients call with work requests at 5pm and expect it to be done by 10am the next day. I keep stupidly irregular hours. There's an undoubted advantage in working to your own schedule, but you have to be careful that it doesn't turn into "I am awake, therefore I work".'

In questioning home- and office-based journalists, Dr Sandi Mann at the University of Central Lancashire concluded that tele-workers were more likely to experience loneliness, irritability, resentment, guilt and frustration. Further mental health problems were evident, such as sleeping problems, having difficulty in concentrating, and feeling 'that things were too much and they couldn't cope'. Dr Mann highlights 'tendencies to over-work' and argues that home-aloners need 'more emotional support' and 'innovative ways to reduce isolation'.

Hence my unappealing habit of pouncing on my husband when he returns home from work, requiring him to be all-singing, all-dancing Entertainment Man. Business coach Rachel Pryor recognises the need for support and is setting up a new facility (from May) enabling professionals at home to 'meet' weekly via teleconference calls (cost £150 a month - visit www.ebedo.com ).

An alternative is the personal coach who, says Pryor, 'will hold you accountable for your whole week, help you to set healthy objectives, and work with you to find the easy way to attract the success you want.'

But coaches communicate mainly via phone calls. You may wish to see real people. Ben Williams, an Edinburgh-based chartered corporate psychologist says: 'It is essential to take social breaks. Meet friends for lunch. Arrange for suppliers to come to you.'

It seems rather tragic, bubbling with excitement because a man is due round with your envelopes. But Williams stresses: 'When structure doesn't exist we need to impose our own discipline. Go out, even if that only means popping out for a newspaper. Say good morning, if it is only to the cat. And keep weekends sacrosanct. If you have a big push on and need to put in extra hours, communicate to loved ones so that they know they cannot come in and shout for juice.'

For the first two years of freelancing I would be unable to start work until around 3.30pm, by which time I would be sufficiently 'revved up'. Now, five years since I had a proper fancy office, I am still in the habit of nibbling on 15 fiddly lunches (none from plates) and wasting valuable working time by picking splodges of food from the sofa.

Jane Bruton, editor of interiors magazine Livingetc , recommends 'keeping workspace separate. If you wander the house, jotting down notes in the kitchen, work invades the whole house. If you must work in the living room, arrange sofas so you are literally turning your back on your desk in the evenings.' She says we should recognise our personal weaknesses: 'A novelist friend keeps an empty fridge because if there is anything in it, she won't get any work done.'

The downside of being in close proximity to a wide and varied food source is not enough to send me scooting back into the 9-5. Working from home is a lonely life; you become aware of background chatter and realise it's you, talking to yourself. But, as Ian Winter points out: 'The children have a strong feeling of us being a family unit rather than a mother at home and a father at the office. It works the other way too. I feel more a part of the family simply because I'm in the family all the time.'

He insists, however, that you owe yourself one hell of a fabulous work chair: 'Why spend your life crammed into grotty surroundings when you could get that any day at an office?'

But coaches communicate mainly via phone calls. You may wish to see real people. Ben Williams, an Edinburgh-based chartered corporate psychologist says: 'It is essential to take social breaks. Meet friends for lunch. Arrange for suppliers to come to you.' It seems rather tragic, bubbling with excitement because a man is due round with your envelopes. But Williams stresses: 'When structure doesn't exist we need to impose our own discipline. Go out, even if that only means popping out for a newspaper. Say good morning, if it is only to the cat. And keep weekends sacrosanct. If you have a big push on and need to put in extra hours, communicate to loved ones so that they know they cannot come in and shout for juice.' For the first two years of freelancing I would be unable to start work until around 3.30pm, by which time I would be sufficiently 'revved up'. Now, five years since I had a proper fancy office, I am still in the habit of nibbling on 15 fiddly lunches (none from plates) and wasting valuable working time by picking splodges of food from the sofa. Jane Bruton, editor of interiors magazine Livingetc , recommends 'keeping workspace separate. If you wander the house, jotting down notes in the kitchen, work invades the whole house. If you must work in the living room, arrange sofas so you are literally turning your back on your desk in the evenings.' She says we should recognise our personal weaknesses: 'A novelist friend keeps an empty fridge because if there is anything in it, she won't get any work done.' The downside of being in close proximity to a wide and varied food source is not enough to send me scooting back into the 9-5. Working from home is a lonely life; you become aware of background chatter and realise it's you, talking to yourself. But, as Ian Winter points out: 'The children have a strong feeling of us being a family unit rather than a mother at home and a father at the office. It works the other way too. I feel more a part of the family simply because I'm in the family all the time.' He insists, however, that you owe yourself one hell of a fabulous work chair: 'Why spend your life crammed into grotty surroundings when you could get that any day at an office?'

webTitle: 'How do I keep everyone happy on holiday?'

fields.headline: 'How do I keep everyone happy on holiday?'
fields.trailText:
Before I married and had children, I travelled extensively. My husband did not do as much as he would have liked. Now we have a family we have to do 'family-type' holidays. However, my husband finds these hard work and is vocal about the fact he would rather be walking in Iceland or visiting a place he has never been before. I've suggested just the two of us go somewhere together, but to be honest, I cannot contemplate leaving the country without my children and walking in Iceland is not really on with a four-year-old and a six-month-old baby. He knows this. How can we compromise?
N.S. of Reading
fields.body:
Before I married and had children, I travelled extensively. My husband did not do as much as he would have liked. Now we have a family we have to do 'family-type' holidays. However, my husband finds these hard work and is vocal about the fact he would rather be walking in Iceland or visiting a place he has never been before. I've suggested just the two of us go somewhere together, but to be honest, I cannot contemplate leaving the country without my children and walking in Iceland is not really on with a four-year-old and a six-month-old baby. He knows this. How can we compromise?
N.S. of Reading

Memories of childhood holidays follow the law of extremes: they tend to be either blissfully idyllic or horror-stories of endurance. Post-war children of my generation remember trying to be jovial in dingy B&Bs with the whole family crammed into one bedroom. But our parents were doing their best in lean times. Your problems are a bit different.

With everyone having different expectations you must aim for a formula that suits them all. The misery of one grumpy member soon diffuses around the rest. Your number one priority is to keep the children contented, which minimises the work for you as well as the irritation.

Young children can only take adventure in small doses, do not appreciate wholesale transformations in lifestyle, especially in diet, and are happiest if much of their daily routine is left intact.

This means that self-catering holidays are the best compromise. If you discover a place that you love, it's heaven to go back year after year as if going to a home from home. For my family this was the New Forest. Pacing the day is vital, with half a day for an outing, then back home to play or read.

Structure a stress-free holiday replete with the simple pleasures of life; child-friendly pubs, walks in wellies over wet heathland, toasting crumpets over a log-fire, wallowing in a wealth of time to stand and stare.

You can become so relaxed that you revert to childhood yourself, climbing trees, flying kites, going mad on the dodgems. Hang loose over discipline and dignity. Children love creating family customs and you quickly find out the things they adore because they insist on doing a repeat on all subsequent occasions.

Many of these traditions involve food - picnics, gathering wild strawberries, cream teas, fish and chips on the last night of the holiday, always munched out of greas paper while ambling along the street.

Take bags of basic groceries with you so your precious time isn't wasted buying tea bags and toilet rolls. If your husband isn't fussy, meals can be kept to the sausage-and-beans level without any one coming to much harm.

The Icelandic walking trips can easily be postponed for a few years. But you may find everyone loves the family hols so much they keep coming back for more.

My sons were in their twenties before they finally pulled out to do their own thing.

Readers' replies

What exactly are 'family-type' holidays and why do you have to do them? We took our four-year-old and four-month baby to Prague, Budapest, Krakow and Zakopane travelling on night trains. It was fantastic. Our daughter loved the trains, parks, cafes and castles, and the baby slept and breastfed in his sling for the fortnight. Personally I would rather die than spend a day anywhere with a kid's club.
A.B. of Frome

Most people find holidaying with small children hard work - your husband should stop whingeing and get on with it. However, your marriage would probably benefit from some time spent together. Would it be possible to ask either set of parents to look after the children while you and your husband go on a weekend walking trip together?'
P.B. Kingston upon Thames

Next week's dilemma

I have a two year old son and am currently divorcing my husband for unreasonable behaviour (he's an alcoholic). Meanwhile, I have met someone new whom I really like.

At the moment, because I'm wary of introducing him to my son - and don't want my not-quite-ex-husband to know about him - he sneaks in and out of the house under cover of darkness, which makes me feel like a teenager living with my parents. Am I going over the top?

How soon should one introduce a new man into a child's life in a situation like this? And would my husband be justified in being angry if he found out?
F.M. Surrey

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

fields.headline: Well, I'll be damned
fields.standfirst: Botticelli's 92 drawings of Dante's Inferno are reunited after nearly 500 years
fields.trailText: Botticelli's 92 drawings of Dante's Inferno are reunited after nearly 500 years
fields.body:
Sandro Botticelli: the Drawings for Dante's Divine Comedy Royal Academy, London W1 until 10 June

What is hell? A subterranean kitchen where Hitler is gutted and boiled in his own blood? Or an absolute zero - darkness visible, howling silence, the eternal absence of God?

The two are not incompatible in Dante's great Inferno, a hell so capacious it can accommodate both in its infinite megalopolis. God is certainly gone - the place is entirely staffed by workaholic demons - and nuclear winter whistles forever through limitless wastelands at the bottom of the pit.

The only problem with Hitler would be precisely where to lodge him - which chamber within which level within which circle of hell. The Inferno is so prodigious and of such mathematical complexity that hundreds of artists, from the renaissance to Blake, Rodin, Dali and Rauschenberg, have illustrated the poem without even beginning to exhaust its vision. But none has been inspired to quite such obsession as Dante's fellow Florentine, Sandro Botticelli.

Botticelli worked on his illustrations for The Divine Comedy for almost 20 years. He made 100 drawings, eight of which are lost. The other 92, which have been repeatedly mislaid and rediscovered since his death in 1510, are reunited for the first time at the Royal Academy in London. Botticelli starts exactly as he continues, with a chart of hell as it drills like a tornado down beneath the earth: tier upon tier of theatrical balconies from which tiny figures topple, descending to that everlasting winter - a semi-circle of icy blue, drawn with the precision of a geometry-set protractor.

This is and remains precisely Dante's idea of hell. Botticelli follows the poet, who is, in turn, led by his imaginary Virgil, past gullies of boiling oil and seas of blood, through rocky ravines, down chasmic holes to perilous ledges and arctic steppes.

In every circle, the punishment fits the crime - the proud are burdened with massive boulders, the jealous have their eyes sewn shut, the corrupt are sluiced through cauldrons of filthy pitch.

Dante and Virgil fall into conversation with the locals on their tour. One burning soul, drawn as a skein of wriggling lines like a forkful of spaghetti, pops up to get the news from back home. In a field of flailing legs - wicked clergymen planted head-down in the earth - Dante takes the opportunity to deliver a retaliatory sermon to his captive audience, Pope Nicholas III.

The demons down tools for a chat. In Canto XXI, Virgil tries to get a backstage pass from Evil Claws, manager of the Eighth Circle devils. Botticelli brilliantly caricatures this pompous jobsworth with his pitchfork, flattered to be consulted but still intent on bureaucratic obstruction. Eventually, the tourists come upon Lucifer, a shaggy beast with bad teeth and three heads, cramming a trio of traitors - Judas, Brutus and Cassius - into his respective mouths. Naturally, the figure is based on Dante, but only to the letter. Botticelli makes an absurd cartoon out of the poet's vision of immortal terror.

Call me a Calvinist, but there is nothing in Botticelli's demonology to strike the mind with fear. His devils are a menagerie of goats, centaurs, trolls and bearded gonks, more Disney or Palitoy than Hieronymus Bosch. If Botticelli ever dreamed of torment, his nightmares never inflected these drawings. Damnation is a diagram, in which thousands of tiny figures are detailed to enact agony.

Each face has individual features, as commentators routinely observe. But true feeling is only reflected in Dante's changing expression as he descends through hell - compassionate, shocked, fearful, exhausted.

What impresses most is what underpins all of Botticelli's art, which is his pure, curvaceous, powerful line. You will never have a better chance to see this, at its very source, than in these illustrations, incised in the parchment with silver- point, like feint pencil, or drawn with a fine stylus in iron-gall ink. So deft, so fast, so razor-sharp, his line skims across the surface - three undulating lines for a river; chins surfacing as quick curves in the tide; flames darting from tortured feet in spiralling whorls; a staircase opening in a rock-face as a dizzying zigzag of acute angles.

Botticelli's pen always reverts to the curve, making curls of toes, hair, tails, wings, even of excrement and devilish forks. He will fill a whole sheet with battling demons or flights of angels and keep the proliferating curves steady with a few straight lines - angled spears or a level horizon. Some of these drawings would be remarkably hard to decipher if it weren't for this lucid geometry.

Unlike his peers, Botticelli didn't make much use of perspective. Only by drawing an elliptical circle around a carpet of contorted bodies does he give any sense that they are trapped alive in a lake of ice, punished, in the poem, for imprisoning their guests.

The devil is in the literary detail of this complex canto. Nobody knows quite why Botticelli persevered with these illustrations - as designs for frescoes, as a deluxe edition of The Divine Comedy, or simply for himself. Vasari says they 'caused infinite disorder in his life' and occasionally, as in the ice pond, there is a visible struggle between Botticelli's linear will and his compulsion to represent every detail of Dante's teeming vision with absolute fidelity. The drawings for the Inferno rarely equal the haunting power of Dante's poem, from its confessional opening - 'Midway along the journey of our life/ I woke to find myself in a dark wood/ for I had wandered far from the straight road.'

But something marvellous happens in the illustrations for 'Paradiso', where the air clears, the crowds vanish and Dante finally meets his beloved Beatrice. The two figures are exquisitely contrasted: Beatrice, with her flowing hair and curvaceous femininity - Botticelli's Venus reprised but animated - and Dante, virile, hieratic and seductively graphic. The last dozen drawings simply represent their dialogue, tender, wry, gently reproachful, as Beatrice takes him up through the planets to explain the mysteries of God's universe.

As Dante's field of vision expands, the figures get bigger and the sense of speed increases. The Moon and stars slip past as perfect circles, beside or behind them. Composition is all - two bodies in rest and motion against the pale space of the page.

All of Botticelli's imagination and draughtsmanship are concentrated in the final, immemorial image - a vision Dante declared unimaginable - the holy family floating in the extreme distance, a tiny constellation transfigured in light.

webTitle: It was an odd night, even before the trumpeter keeled over

fields.headline: It was an odd night, even before the trumpeter keeled over
fields.trailText:
Kagel Festival Royal Academy of Music, London NW1
Evelyn Glennie and Friends Wigmore Hall, London W1/ Radio 3
David Matthews premiere ECO, Barbican, London EC2
fields.body:
Kagel Festival Royal Academy of Music, London NW1
Evelyn Glennie and Friends Wigmore Hall, London W1/ Radio 3
David Matthews premiere ECO, Barbican, London EC2

Nothing like a dose of anarchy, that enemy of aesthetics and slayer of theory, to keep an audience awake. Not that the crowd who gathered to mark the opening of the Royal Academy of Music's fifteenth International Composer Festival were in the slightest respect sleepy. They came anticipating the subversive fabrications of Mauricio Kagel, the 70-year-old Argentine composer who was the subject of this year's event and was a smiling presence at the occasion. His entire career has been based on musical insurrection, as serious in intent as it is bizarre and humorous in execution. Always respectful of musical tradition, his joyful delight in parody and contradiction puts him in a class of his own. How many composers can be said to have earned their reputation from an ability to make an audience chuckle?

Every piece in his enormous output, usually written for a strikingly odd combination of instruments, has the compressed energy of a mini sitcom, brought to explosive life by the extraordinary versatility of the musicians who perform his work. Conventional virtuosity on a chosen instrument is not enough. Each player has to turn himself or herself into a dramatic character, as if out of Beckett or Pirandello. At the start of Rrrrrr_ Vier Soli für Stimme mit Begleitung - from a group of 41 pieces all with titles beginning with the letter R - Cari Burdett, a sultry mezzo-soprano, appeared on stage as bobble-hatted revolutionary chanting slogans in the thick accent of an all-purpose dissident. She transformed herself variously into slinky chanteuse and Afro-American railroad worker, accompanied by laid-back piano and laconic tuba. What was it all about? Kagel's gift is to make you put that question to the back of your mind and simply to accept what you see and hear. In a sense, he flatters the listener. Through this challenge to our own conventional expectations, we feel ourselves to be creatively interesting and as imaginatively untrammelled as the composer himself.

Atem (Breath) for a wind player (1969/1970) was supposedly inspired by Kagel's neighbour, a retired wind player who spent his days making new reeds for colleagues, always playing the same sequence of notes to check for quality. With only a solo trumpeter on stage, Kagel makes brilliant play of the musician opening drawers, dismantling the instrument, oiling the keys, drying off residual saliva and talking to himself. He never plays a note of music. At the climax, after educing a squawking, plaintive melody from a plastic tube and grunting in counterpoint to himself, the soloist plunges his trumpet into a bucket of water. After a few flabby-lipped burbs and gurgles, he blows the residue over the audience in gentle aspersion then keels over on to the floor, 'seemingly dead, awaiting for the hoped-for retirement', as Kagel puts it. Valentin Garvie was the resourceful trumpeter. On the evidence of this performance, he has many career options ahead of him.

One might be to team up with Evelyn Glennie who achieved comparable varieties of sound and invention in the first of three evenings of new works at the Wigmore Hall. Always a mesmerising performer, her face obscured by auburn curls, she bobbed in bare feet from marimba to bass drum to less nameable objects waiting to be struck. The players who joined her were every bit her match, including another (and somewhat more famous) trumpeter, Hakan Hardenberger, trombonist Christian Lindberg and the tuba player Oren Marshall, a droll figure who seems to have learnt his performance skills playing Kagel.

In a programme note, Glennie announced: 'These concerts are not for critics. They are simply a celebration and the audience is almost eavesdropping on this informal music-making.' She has a point. Many of the collaborations involved improvisation, together or alone. In Nebojsa Jovan Zivkovic's Born to Beat Wild Op 30, part notated, part improvised, Hardenberger and Glennie, kneeling on the floor playing a big drum, began with a whisper and ended with ear-splitting frenzy. She hammered out the Balkan rhythms so forcefully one feared for her hands as she slapped them down on the vellum. Dave Heath's persuasive Darkness of Light, for Glennie and pianist Philip Smith, followed a similar climactic path, using the piano as a percussion instrument which unexpectedly evolves into an ethereal jazz mood. The last concert in the series is this afternoon.

If Glennie and friends poured their energies into sound colour and atmosphere, David Matthews's new piece for the English Chamber Orchestra put the emphasis squarely on harmony and melody. His Aubade Op 83, scored with characteristic subtlety for string orchestra with oboe, cor anglais and two horns, draws on Australian bird song for its wistful, melodic impetus. The hushed string textures and luscious cello solo had a diaphanous charm which suited the ECO players. In a provocative, if narrowly focused new collection of essays on the state of contemporary music ( Reviving the Muse: Essays on Music After Modernism edited by Peter Davison), Matthews states his belief that tonality is 'not outmoded, but a living force' and that the great forms of the past, such as the symphony, are still valid. On paper that may not sound exciting. Yet Matthews, in his way, is just as subversive as Kagel, even if his voice is quieter. When the composer is as persuasive as either of these, theories (which in any case tend to follow the music they claim to prescribe) don't much matter.

With only a solo trumpeter on stage, Kagel makes brilliant play of the musician opening drawers, dismantling the instrument, oiling the keys, drying off residual saliva and talking to himself. He never plays a note of music. At the climax, after educing a squawking, plaintive melody from a plastic tube and grunting in counterpoint to himself, the soloist plunges his trumpet into a bucket of water. After a few flabby-lipped burbs and gurgles, he blows the residue over the audience in gentle aspersion then keels over on to the floor, 'seemingly dead, awaiting for the hoped-for retirement', as Kagel puts it. Valentin Garvie was the resourceful trumpeter. On the evidence of this performance, he has many career options ahead of him. One might be to team up with Evelyn Glennie who achieved comparable varieties of sound and invention in the first of three evenings of new works at the Wigmore Hall. Always a mesmerising performer, her face obscured by auburn curls, she bobbed in bare feet from marimba to bass drum to less nameable objects waiting to be struck. The players who joined her were every bit her match, including another (and somewhat more famous) trumpeter, Hakan Hardenberger, trombonist Christian Lindberg and the tuba player Oren Marshall, a droll figure who seems to have learnt his performance skills playing Kagel. In a programme note, Glennie announced: 'These concerts are not for critics. They are simply a celebration and the audience is almost eavesdropping on this informal music-making.' She has a point. Many of the collaborations involved improvisation, together or alone. In Nebojsa Jovan Zivkovic's Born to Beat Wild Op 30, part notated, part improvised, Hardenberger and Glennie, kneeling on the floor playing a big drum, began with a whisper and ended with ear-splitting frenzy. She hammered out the Balkan rhythms so forcefully one feared for her hands as she slapped them down on the vellum. Dave Heath's persuasive Darkness of Light, for Glennie and pianist Philip Smith, followed a similar climactic path, using the piano as a percussion instrument which unexpectedly evolves into an ethereal jazz mood. The last concert in the series is this afternoon. If Glennie and friends poured their energies into sound colour and atmosphere, David Matthews's new piece for the English Chamber Orchestra put the emphasis squarely on harmony and melody. His Aubade Op 83, scored with characteristic subtlety for string orchestra with oboe, cor anglais and two horns, draws on Australian bird song for its wistful, melodic impetus. The hushed string textures and luscious cello solo had a diaphanous charm which suited the ECO players. In a provocative, if narrowly focused new collection of essays on the state of contemporary music ( Reviving the Muse: Essays on Music After Modernism edited by Peter Davison), Matthews states his belief that tonality is 'not outmoded, but a living force' and that the great forms of the past, such as the symphony, are still valid. On paper that may not sound exciting. Yet Matthews, in his way, is just as subversive as Kagel, even if his voice is quieter. When the composer is as persuasive as either of these, theories (which in any case tend to follow the music they claim to prescribe) don't much matter.

fields.headline: Please don't call it building
fields.standfirst: The work of Japan's rising star lives up to his rhetoric
fields.trailText: The work of Japan's rising star lives up to his rhetoric
fields.body:
Under Construction: Toyo Ito's Sendai Mediateque (photographs by Naoya Hatakeyama) Architectural Association, London W1 until 28 April

When Toyo Ito first set up as an architect in Tokyo in 1971, he called his studio Urban Robot. Given that there are still entirely sensible designers in Japan ready to practise under names like Super Potato, it wasn't that out of the ordinary. But it is a touching reminder of Japan's faith in a rather innocent view of the future.

Those were the days when Japan seemed to be building the world of Blade Runner. Indeed, a couple of Ito's projects in the 1980s, especially the neon-and-steel Tower of the Winds rising out of the chaos of Tokyo, seemed as if they had been designed with Ridley Scott in mind, even if by this time he was calling himself Toyo Ito and Partners.

But the gesture of the unlikely name is also a reflection of Ito's continuing determination to cut himself free from any definition of architecture that carried the baggage of history, especially the heaviness implied by the word 'building'.

What makes Ito so interesting is that he has been able to produce architecture that actually lives up to the rhetoric. He has a singular ability to create architecture that dazzles the senses without being bombastic.

His only project in Britain so far has been his brilliant evocation of contemporary Japan for an exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum a decade ago, full of gloriously disorientating, multiscreen, virtual imagery. But he has become one of the handful of Japanese architects who has successfully managed to export his work. He is building an art gallery in Mexico and also has projects in Holland and Belgium.

An exhibition at the Architectural Association in London offers a glimpse of his most significant project to date - the Mediateque in Sendai, which opened at the beginning of this year.

Sendai is a quiet and orderly provincial city, a three-hour train journey north of Tokyo. The streets are lined with trees. It is reassuringly comfortable, but a little dull.

The Mediateque reflects both the limitations and ambitions of its context. It stands on the site of a Pachinko parlour, on one of the city's main boulevards, but, in the jumbled manner of a Japanese city, its other three sides overlook a clutter of garages, car-parks and modest sheds. It replaces a humble civic library, the kind of place in which in Japan, like anywhere else, children consult encyclopedias, flower arranging societies meet and enthusiastic amateur watercolourists stage exhibitions.

But when the city set about rebuilding its library, it looked for something more ambitious. It had to house the existing collection of books, but it would also accommodate an art gallery, cinema, lecture theatre and cybercafé.

But despite Ito's enthusiasm for the impermanence of architecture in an information age, Sendai is, in many ways, a highly traditional building. It is a local monument, an expression of civic pride.

Ito does his best to dematerialise architecture. Every elevation is different, in a defiantly determined effort to avoid any suggestions of formal rigour. The front wall is double-skinned glass with what look like barcode marks tattooed on to them. They are basically decorative, though they probably have an impact on thermal performance and certainly help to heighten the sense of ambiguity of the façade.

There is no conventional structure of any kind. The floors are flat plates of steel embedded in concrete, supported on a forest of tubular-steel trees rising the full height of the building. They twist and spiral their way up the building around a series of voids in a way that seems to deny all conventional ideas of structural logic. Some of the voids are devoted to staircases, others are occupied by lifts and others are just holes rising the height of the building, allowing daylight to penetrate into its very heart, floor by floor, bulging out or twisting inward.

Given that it is a building which has to meet the onerous demands of Japan's structural codes that have been devised to deal with the demands of even a once-in-400-years earthquake, this was by no means an easy task for Mutsuro Sasaki, the engineer, who was initially sceptical that it could be built at all.

This is a remarkable building, one which tries very hard at every level to push architecture in a fresh direction, yet never descends into simple-minded exhibitionism. It is very Japanese and yet also belongs to the international architectural mainstream.

It is beautifully made and yet it relies on the quality of the ideas underpinning its design rather than the jewel-like quality of its detail. It is spatially rich and complex, it has a remarkable presence, and yet it also hints at a wide gap between its architectural ambition and the mundane reality of the activities that will take place inside it.

fields.headline: I think she's got it...
fields.standfirst: Despite flu, Martine McCutcheon sparkles as Eliza Doolittle, but Joseph Fiennes has that poker to worry about
fields.trailText: Despite flu, Martine McCutcheon sparkles as Eliza Doolittle, but Joseph Fiennes has that poker to worry about
fields.body:
My Fair Lady Lyttelton, London SE1
Edward II Crucible, Sheffield
The Servant Lyric Hammersmith, London W6
Spirit Royal Court Upstairs, London SW1

Let's hope Richard Eyre is keeping his eye on the theatre this month. The stage is bursting with possibilities over the next few weeks, with shows so vivid and so different that they might have been designed to gladden the most numb-bummed, dispirited theatre-attender.

First, there's the sure-fire hit. Trevor Nunn's production of My Fair Lady is already sold out - and people who do get in won't be asking for their money back. After all, buying a ticket for this is the opposite of buying a pig in a poke: wouldn't it be luvverly if you set off to see new work at our best-known theatre feeling even half as happy? You know you'll get a stream of Lerner and Loewe numbers; there are no makeweight songs in this musical.

If you're a fan of EastEnders, you know you'll see the face of Tiffany again, and even if you're not, you know that in Martine McCutcheon you'll hear an actress with a bell-like singing voice who, unlike all previous Elizas, won't subject her audience to a display of tonsil-torturing, lor-luv-a-duck cockney.

You get more than that. Henry Higgins, the bullying prof who teaches the flower-girl to pass herself off as a toff by changing her vowel sounds, is played by Jonathan Pryce with a perfectly judged, suave selfishness, and not too much reliance on the male fantasy that women always find contemptuous behaviour irresistible. As his sidekick - the Watson to Higgins's Holmes - Nicholas Le Prevost is inspired: bluff but not too fruity, with an unexpected dash of gay spice; very happy performing a neat flamenco; a bit shifty when interrogated about his know-how on the subject of frocks.

Matthew Bourne brings an Alice in Wonderland touch to the Ascot scene, choreographing it so that the racegoers appear half-human, half-horse: the men lightly paw the ground with their feet; the women toss their peacock feathers as if they were manes. And you get something very unusual from Martine McCutcheon, a thoroughly lovable stage presence. She's sometimes indistinct (perhaps still flu-ridden) in the early market scene, when she gawps and hunches in an alarming, almost neanderthal fashion. But squaring up to her mentor, her face gleams with wit: she makes you feel that you're watching her in close-up and can see the snap and sparkle in her eyes.

Her wonderful ease exposes some guff elsewhere. Can anyone really take those cockney scenes? Matthew Bourne may have drawn the worst of their sting by putting Doolittle's songs (given the right touch of dourness by Dennis Waterman) in more plausible locations, but we still have to watch porters doing a rockabilly dance - all thumbs and elbows and knees and chirpiness. And though Anthony Ward's design is often pretty, it's always more literal-minded than atmospheric; the blokes with baskets on their heads look as if they're advertising seagrass containers from Conran.

At Sheffield, Michael Grandage is taking more of a chance with his star, staging Joseph Fiennes in Marlowe's rarely performed Edward II. Anyone who squeezes into the Crucible just to see Fiennes won't be disappointed. His portrayal of the king, famous for dying with a red-hot poker rammed up his bottom, is at first light, quick and sardonic, later, reflective and self-absorbed.

But this isn't a star-heavy occasion. The triumph of the evening belongs to no single actor, though James D'Arcy flounces alluringly as Gaveston and Lloyd Owen is a commanding, cruel Mortimer. As the murderer, who kisses his victim before dispatching him, Jonathan Wrather is mesmeric.

It's the director who deserves the crown, for making this rarely performed play so clear and so swift, as absorbing as a political thriller. Edward II, often compared unfavourably with Richard II as a portrait of a weak king, is laden neither with beautiful lines nor with inspiriting sentiments; it's stuffed with betrayers and with savourless verse.

Grandage illuminates it and gives it drive by presenting us with a clash between old and new, youth and age, with cronyism and corruption on both sides. He's greatly helped by Christopher Oram's terrific design, an apparently plain expanse of dark flagstones with a (much and gruesomely used) drain in the middle. It's a space which can be shrunk by Tim Mitchell's masterly lighting to a dank, dripping cell, a space which leads into an apparently infinite region of swirling smoke and clangour - both battle and hell.

And it's a perfect, pitiless arena for a struggle. You see this when Edward's band of boys, with golden shorts and tousled hair, are confronted in mid-cavort by a dark circle of accoutred men, the sixteenth-century equivalents of suits. 'What?' demands Edward of his tacit accusers, breaking off for a moment from snogging Gaveston, and spreading his arms in an insolent shrug. The heartlessness of hedonism meets the brutality of political thuggery; the clash can be - a Grandage revelation, this - funny as well as frightening

Neil Bartlett, back as artistic director of the Lyric Hammersmith after a liver transplant, is engaged on a project of rediscovery - showing how many plays, particularly bufferish, buttoned-up plays, are really queer.

He has created a new version of Robin Maugham's 1958 drama The Servant in the light of Maugham's autobiographical homoerotic writings. The dynamic of the play is, as it always was, a nasty seesawing movement: power shifts from an indolent upper-class young chap to the manservant who first makes his life luxurious (with chicken fricassees and quilted lampshades), and then contaminates it.

But now the secret life of this sex-and-class play is made explicit. Bartlett makes one of the master's young seducers a boy rather than a girl. Jack Davenport's convincingly languorous master becomes steadily more camp. His ex-girlfriend begins to assume the glamour of a drag queen, with blonde flick-ups of Barbie proportions. Michael Feast goes from clammy to creepy. Rae Smith's evocative design traps the upper classes in a boxy sitting-room, with the seducing servants gliding silently up and down a long staircase behind them.

On the stage of the Royal Court Upstairs is a big wedge of wood, shaped like a roof. Three heads poke their way through gaps in the tiles and begin to chat, dolefully, humorously. They tell a story like a folk tale, about three baker brothers who live together. They squeeze out of their holes and become those brothers, tucked up together under one long sheet with sacks of flour for pillows; the roof now looks like an alarmingly tilted bed.

This story meanders into the tale of a bombing raid: flat, cardboard towers and houses and trees are pushed from beneath through the slats of the emptied bed - and it turns into a miniature city. On the outskirts of this, a fight takes place between three cloth puppets who don't have heads. In the middle of it, one of the human actors seems to die, and is manipulated by his fellows like a glass-eyed, floppy-limbed puppet.

Improbable? Yes. This is Improbable Theatre, two of whose members directed and designed the now celebrated Shockheaded Peter. 'We thrive on mistakes,' one of them points out in the confessional passage which ends their evening. 'Sometimes that's right. And sometimes it's a bit much.'

Spirit, hard to follow, and too consciously a comment on theatre habits, is in the 'bit much' category. But. Look at the ways in which that wedge of wood is made to assume different shapes. Look at that human puppet. These are moments of true invention. Now that the Royal Court, with its tradition of text-based plays, has boldly welcomed Improbable Theatre's antics, will the National also acknowledge the existence of such dramas?
