fields.headline: The poor are consumers, too
fields.standfirst: Profit potential  is making global giants take notice of the 4 billion people they have long ignored, writes  Terry Slavin
fields.trailText: Profit potential is making global giants take notice of the 4 billion people they have long ignored, writes Terry Slavin
fields.body:
The ground-breaking announcement last week by Bristol-Myers Squibb that it will cut the price of its Aids drugs in Africa from $20 a day to a below-cost price of less than $1 was an act of philanthropy - and good PR in a media climate that has turned sharply against the global drugs giants.

But Bristol-Myers Squibb's move, which will transform its products from a niche market to a need market for the millions of people who could never have afforded them before, highlights the way in which forward-thinking multinational companies (MNCs) are now targeting the 4 billion people, two-thirds of the Earth's population, who have until now been written off in terms of market potential.

Stuart Hart, director of the Sustainable Enterprise Initiative at the University of North Carolina, says it is not surprising that companies have traditionally overlooked the rural poor - what he calls the 'bottom of the pyramid' - as a fertile market. 'The bottom of the pyramid is chaotic and almost totally lacking in infrastructure. Not only that, to buy products and services - one must have money - and these people have little.' He defines the bottom of the pyramid as people with per capita incomes of less than $1,500 a year.

But companies are beginning to dip their toes into these turbid waters. Shell Solar, in a joint venture with South Africa's national power company, Eskom, is bringing affordable solar power to the impoverished and isolated communities of the Eastern Cape for the first time, and with it the first social development many of them have ever experienced. But this is a strictly for-profit business. Shell Solar also operates in Sri Lanka, India, and the Philippines, and has ambitions to break into the mass markets of China and Indonesia.

Dupont, Unilever, Hewlett-Packard and Johnson & Johnson have also recently been experimenting with rural poor markets. Hart predicts that in five years' time this toe-dipping will develop into a substantial element of companies' global strategy.

'It's clear to many multinationals that if they are to grow and prosper in the future there isn't growth potential at the top of the pyramid,' he said in an interview. 'It's also increasingly evident, as a result of the pushback against globalisation, that the traditional business model won't be acceptable in the future.'

Unlike with newly industrialising markets such as Malaysia or Thailand, where MNCs could make small adjustments to the business models they use in Europe or North America before jumping in with both feet, reaching the rural poor involves throwing out the rulebook and rewriting it on the ground - often in close partnership with local companies or non-governmental organisations.

The MNC furthest along this track is Unilever which, under the chairmanship of Niall FitzGerald, has espoused a multi-local, multinational approach across all its operations. Nowhere has this worked more successfully than in India, where its subsidiary Hindustan Lever is, as FitzGerald says, 'totally integrated into Indian society and dedicated to meeting the specific needs of millions of Indian consumers'.

It wasn't always thus. For 50 years, like most multinationals in India, Hindustan Lever catered to India's elite. But when a low-end local company, Nirma, began to threaten Hindustan Lever's detergents business from below, it had to drastically rewrite its business plan.

In order to offer a cheaper product, in small individual packaging, through the thousand tiny outlets where poor people shop, it had to decentralise its production, marketing and distribution to take advantage of India's abundant labour pool and change its cost structure. Its margins were lower, but this was more than compensated for by soaring unit sales.

For a rupee or two, Indians can now buy shampoo in single sachets, handcream in pots the size of a thimble and toothpaste in small disposable sachets. Single rupee sachets comprise about 70 per cent of the company's shampoo sales.

It's a business model that Unilever was able to replicate when the Asian economic crisis brought hardship to the newly industrialising south-east Asian countries. 'When South East Asia was hitting economic difficulties, we were able to adapt by tailor-making smaller-quantity products for those markets, says a Unilever spokesman. 'We came out the other side of the crisis stronger.'

One of the reasons why the very poor are becoming a market is that more and more now have access to credit. Microcredit, the lending by banks of tiny sums to the poor, is catching on all over the world, particularly in the sub-continent. An estimated 2 million families in India have access to financial services, and the Indian government has pledged to reach 25 million families by 2005.

'There [in the West] they are doing it for environmental reasons,' says Miller. 'In developing countries it's a need market. They really need your product.'

Hart acknowledges the risk of exploitation, but says that with the rise of the internet and the global power of pressure groups, companies won't get away with socially irresponsible behaviour for long.

Some villages in Africa will soon have access to solar powered multi-media modems that will be enable them to access the internet.

webTitle: Charging bulls and bears with sore heads

fields.headline: Charging bulls and bears with sore heads
fields.trailText: It was a glittering night at the Grosvenor House hotel last Wednesday, as the Masters of the Universe patted each other on the backs for their work over the past year.
fields.body:
It was a glittering night at the Grosvenor House hotel last Wednesday, as the Masters of the Universe patted each other on the backs for their work over the past year.

The occasion was the Acquisitions Monthly annual awards dinner, and the assembled investment bankers, brokers and venture capitalists were celebrating their multibillion dollar conquests - Vodafone, Glaxo, NatWest et al. But the irony was lost on none that, as they weaved their way to collect their gongs, the US market was sinking like a stone, following the example set by London that afternoon.

And who was responsible? None other than the same self-congratulatory bankers who wined, dined and danced.

They did not want it to happen, of course. No financier in full possession of his marbles would be happy at the fact that world markets had been bombing all year, and that the once-beloved new economy had dragged the rest of the world's equities down in its slipstream. The value of many of the deals that earned them their plaudits had fallen off a cliff, which was obviously not to their advantage. But it was still their fault.

They were the ones who in 1999 and the early part of 2000 had thrown investors' money at the new economy like confetti at a wedding; they were the ones who had swallowed the 'next, next thing' and 'clicks not bricks' lines with the glee of a child in a sweetshop; they were the ones who told us that the likes of Walmart, ICI and Hanson would be swept aside at their first confrontation with the wunderkinder of the web.

It was natural for the internet generation to be intoxicated by their own hype, but how did they persuade the stodgy, middle-aged (mainly) men at the Grosvenor House that their youthful ideas were worth throwing billions of dollars at? Because this is the origin of the bear market that we are now in - the inescapable truth is that share prices will continue to fall purely because this time last year they were so vertiginously inflated by those same people who were last week priding themselves on their shrewdness.

(The Mistresses of the Universe also carry their share of blame. One revealed that she really didn't want to buy any stock at all in Lastminute.com at its ill-starred flotation, but felt she had to - because everybody else was buying it. So much for independent financial advice.)

Make no mistake - this is a real bear market. This not like 1987 which, in comparison, was a short-term correction. As market veteran Brian Winterflood recollects ('Stockbrokers ran stalls on Petticoat Lane to make money'), it has much more in common with the long drawn-out, two-year agony of the early Seventies, which still sends a chill down the spine of those who lived through it. The danger is that it could yet turn into the crash of 1929, which heralded the horrors of the Great Depression.

The market Cassandras - and there are a growing number of them - paint an apocalyptic scenario if markets continue to fall: continuing losses on the new economy force shareholders to sell their old economy stocks to raise cash. The fact that much of the share buying was done on tick, with assets hocked to pay for any dotcom stock they could get their hands, on prompts a credit crunch that forces a crisis in the banking industry. The weakening US economy is fatally infected by the effects of the Japanese disease, which has struck most of Asia. Against this backdrop, the still-resilient economies of Europe stand no chance. Result: global economic and financial depression lasting for years.

That is why the bear market matters, and why we should all be hoping that Alan Greenspan works his interest-rate magic this week. Otherwise, the Grosvenor House hotel might find itself with an unexpectedly vacant ballroom this time next year.

webTitle: City baulks at Pru's walk on the wild side

fields.headline: City baulks at Pru's walk on the wild side
fields.standfirst: The insurer will work hard to sell its £15bn acquisition of American General, says  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: The insurer will work hard to sell its £15bn acquisition of American General, says Heather Connon
fields.body:
Every 7.5 seconds, someone in the United States reaches the age of 50. This was one of the facts used by Prudential chief executive Jonathan Bloomer to explain the lure of American General, the US life assurer it is acquiring in a £15.3 billion deal.

If every 50-year-old bought an American General investment product, the City might start to think it was a good deal. For now, however, the attitude is sceptical at best; downright critical at worst.

It is easy to see why. Price, timing, strategic rationale - on virtually any criterion, investors tick the 'no' box.

The US economy is deteriorating rapidly. No one can predict how much further it will fall, nor how it will affect American General's savings and investments business.

All the more surprising, then, that Prudential agreed to pay a chunky 18 per cent premium over the highest price ever reached by American General's shares (although the collapse in the Pru's own shares over last week eliminated the premium completely).

That American General looks like an expensive expansion in the US at a risky time is bad enough. Much worse, however, is what the deal says about the rest of the business. Bloomer's key justification for the acquisition is the American firm's cash.

Its businesses generate lots, but it has failed to find opportunities to re-invest it for a decent return. Instead, it has been passing it back to shareholders - $450 million last year alone. That cash, said Bloomer, would be needed to fund the Prudential's expansion in its fast-growing Asian business.

'Especially with Japan, India and China coming on stream we could see the risk that, as a group, we would not generate enough cash and capital assets ourselves to invest flat-out in Asia and seize the opportunities.'

That was the biggest shock to the City. Just four months ago, when the Pru took analysts to visit its Asian operations, 'the implication was that they could fund the growth internally', says Roger Doig, insurance analyst at JP Morgan. Now, it is clear that was wrong - and hell hath no fury like an analyst who feels he was misled.

Since the deal was announced Bloomer has been holding meetings with shareholders. He says he is managing to persuade them of the wisdom of it. 'We expected the share price to fall because it was a surprise - there was no leak and because shareholders will not immediately know American General and what a quality business it is,' said Bloomer.

American General certainly looks like quality. Its earnings have grown by an average of 14 per cent over the last five years; revenues and deposits by 16 per cent. It is the leading seller of fixed annuities and second-largest issuer of life policies in the US. Its sales are mainly through the workplace - primarily public sector employers. That fits well with Jackson National Life, the Pru's existing US operation, which sells mainly through broker-dealers and financial advisers.

Bloomer is promising £85m of cost savings from putting the two businesses together. Much more important, he says, is the prospect of boosting sales by distributing Jackson's products through American General's sales channels and vice versa. That, he says, means suggestions that he has overpaid are wrong. 'If you look at it on a discounted cash flow basis, with conservative-based growth assumptions, I canget to what we paid for it, no bother', he says.

Others are less sure. JP Morgan's Doig doubts there will be many synergies. 'Jackson's main products are single premium, sold through broker-dealers - effectively stock market representatives. You can't put Jackson products through the distribution channels of American General - they are not qualified to sell them.'

The new Prudential will be heavily exposed to the US - 57 per cent of its new business will be generated there, up from 27 per cent now. Investors would probably prefer not to increase their exposure to the US when markets are so uncertain. The acquisition also dramatically reduces the importance of the Asian business - the one that is most attractive to investors.

So attractive does the City find Asia that it forgave the Pru another lacklustre performance in the UK because its Asian business was growing so fast. Last year, Asia contributed a quarter of Pru's new business and Robin Savage, insurance analyst at WestLB Panmure, had expected that to rise to 50 per cent by 2005. Following the acquisition, Asia will have fallen to just 15 per cent of new business.

Bloomer is not putting any figure on how much will be invested in Asia - but he says that it has been putting '£200m, if not more, into the business most years'. He also has his eye on Europe, the one serious area of weakness in the Prudential's business, following the appointment of Mark Wood, former chief executive of Axa Sun Life & Provincial to head the group's UK and European business.

Here, too, however, he cannot put a figure on the requirements, although he 'cannot see an acquisition of any significance'.

Bloomer admits expansion in Asia and Europe could have been financed through a rights issues - it is more than 15 years since the Pru raised money - to acquire Jackson. 'But it would not be a rights issue for one big acquisition. It would be difficult to come back regularly with a rolling rights issue.'

While Jackson is acknowledged to be a good business, many analysts think the £670m acquisition of Scottish Amicable in 1997 was a bad deal. 'They bought a half-decent company to take them into the independent financial adviser market but did not retain the management. It now seems to have lost its way big-time,' said an analyst.

The jury is still out on the acquisition of M&G for £1.9bn in 1999. Although Sir Peter Davis was then chief executive, Bloomer - then finance director - was seen as the brains behind it. Strategically, it made sense but M&G's profits are still not big enough to justify that price.

'M&G must begin to deliver returns,' said WestLB Panmure's Savage. 'The pressure to perform is building.'

Bloomer sees acquiring American General as a similarly strategic deal. In the short term it will prove itself through cost synergies and raised revenue. Longer term, the issue will be whether the US earnings have been invested in high-growth areas.

There is, however, another short-term issue. Following the deal, which is expected to be completed sometime in the third quarter, US shareholders will own 49.5 per cent of the group, up from 9 per cent now, yet it will lose its US listing. Many are expected to sell, piling more pressure on the shares.

The Pru's US team is meeting investors to sell them the deal, and Bloomer will make the trip in April. He will have to be very persuasive.

Train ride that created a giant

American General traces its history to a stormy day in 1926, when businessman Gus Wortham and his old friend Judge James Elkins took a train through Texas from Houston to the state capital, Austin, writes Edward Helmore .

In Austin, they registered a company that in the 75 years since has become one of America's largest providers of retirement services, life insurance and consumer loans. Exploiting an oil boom, the company grew in Texas through acquisitions and gradually extended throughout the US.

Over the past two decades it has acquired more than 35 competitors and, like the other leading insurers, it has shifted its emphasis from life insurance to variable and fixed annuities as Americans have become more concerned about outliving their savings than leaving their families in economic straits.

Today, American General is one of the US's biggest insurers, and among the leaders in each part of its business. In December 1999, its diversified financial services arms held assets of $115 billion and served 12 million customers.

The merged Prudential and American General, which will continue to do business in the US as AG and Jackson National Life (an American firm bought earlier by Prudential), will become the biggest US seller of variable annuities and the fifth-largest seller of life insurance.

At the same time, it will become the sixth-largest insurer in the world, moving into a new league with giants such as the American International Group, Axa of France and Allianz of Germany. This new deal will leave only two big American-owned life insurers, Lincoln National and John Hancock.

webTitle: Japan needs another miracle to survive

fields.headline: Japan needs another miracle to survive
fields.standfirst: William  Keegan  on the real roots of the country's plight: US policy and inept economic management
fields.trailText: William Keegan on the real roots of the country's plight: US policy and inept economic management
fields.body:
As the Japanese stock market falls to levels below a third of the peak reached in 1989 (Nikkei index: 39,915.87), concerns have re-emerged about the viability of a banking and financial system that is far from 'transparent' and characterised by cross-share holdings. There is particular concern about the historic cost valuation of bank assets and the possibility of some kind of 'meltdown'.

The worries of overseas investors were exacerbated recently when veteran finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa declared that, after years of public works projects - recommended by, among others, the Americans - the budget position was 'near a state of collapse'. This is not the kind of thing finance ministers are meant to say, even when the budget deficit is some 130 per cent of gross domestic product. Miyazawa later retracted, but the cat was out of the bag.

This is all a far cry from the mid-1980s, when the Japanese economy attracted the envy of the world, and even the mighty US was concerned that it had somehow lost out to Japan's miraculous industrial machine.

Everything changed when the US realised that the - at the time - very strong dollar was in fact a source of industrial weakness. Via various Group of Seven agreements, the Reagan administration first devalued the dollar and then stabilised it.

Central to Washington's international economic policy from then on - under both Republican and Democratic administrations - was the goal of attacking the huge Japanese trade surplus, and assuaging the protectionist sentiment that Japan's economic 'invasion' was arousing in the US.

This involved several successful attempts to drive the value of the yen up to peaks which would damage the Japanese export effort, as well as repeated appeals to Japan to expand domestic demand in order to encourage imports.

Ironically, an earlier contributor to all those deficits whose accumulation now cause such concern was Miyazawa who, as finance minister in the mid-Eighties, introduced several stimulatory economic packages. He is cited in Managing the Dollar: From the Plaza to the Louvre by Yoichi Funabashi as '[enlisting] foreign pressure in an alliance with domestic expansionists to advance his stimulative policies'. Japan also kept interest rates extremely low in the late Eighties, thereby encouraging the notorious 'bubble economy' from whose effects it is still recovering.

There are conspiracy theorists who think the US was in fact attacking two empires in the Eighties - the 'evil empire' of the Soviet Union, which duly collapsed in 1991, and the Japanese economic powerhouse, which needed bringing down a peg or two.

But, in the cliché of the moment, no economy is an island, and there is no knowing what the repercussions might be if the Japanese economy goes 'down the tubes'.

However, let us remember that those very tubes would almost certainly have been manufactured in Japan, to the very highest quality standards. British observers who are beginning to compare Japan's 'plight' to that of the former Soviet Union - on the grounds that there has been a degree of centralised planning which no longer works - are making something of a leap.

Communism produced a 'shortage economy', and exposure to what was possible in the West contributed to its downfall. People all over the world want Japanese consumer goods, and two Japanese multinationals, Toyota and Sony, are among the top 10 corporations.

The Japanese economy has succeeded in making many adjustments over the years, when the sense of crisis was sufficient.

The Nobel laureate Robert Mundell told an audience at City University last week that the 12 per cent per annum growth rate achieved by Japan between 1955 and 1970 was 'probably the most successful economic expansion of any economy at any time in history'.*

Although the envy of the world by the Eighties, Japan, with its heavy dependence on imports of oil and raw materials, had felt vulnerable in the face of the 'oil shocks' of the Seventies. Its modern consumer society, with one of the highest standards of living in the world and huge savings on top, is in part a reaction to those crises. And the Japanese were particularly stung by an EU Commissioner's remark in the late Seventies that they were 'a nation of workaholics living in rabbit hutches'.

Mundell thinks that, encouraged by America, Japan has relied too much on fiscal policy and not enough on monetary policy to refuel its economy. It has also been good at macro-economic policy mistakes: in 1997, for example, it raised consumer taxes just when it seemed to be emerging from the recession that followed the bursting of the bubble.

With almost incredible ineptitude, the Bank of Japan tightened monetary policy last August when the economy was again showing tangible signs of recovery.

To any visitor to Japan, the current period of deflation seems very much a 'golden recession'. Moscow was never like this. And, even if the political system seems paralysed, there is far more awareness in Tokyo now of the need for the next step in Japan's 'catch-up' process with the West.

This is far from saying that simultaneous economic slowdowns in the US and Japan are not worrying. They are, and it is going to be a very difficult year. Japan is aware of the need to catch up with some of the 'reforms' now commonplace in the West, and it needs to address its banking crisis the way the US came to grips with the potentially disastrous Savings & Loans crisis. History suggests it might be capable of the adjustment. But it will be a very hard road.

*'The Thornton Effect: Monetary Instability Arising from Big Wars', City University

webTitle: 'Stockbrokers ran stalls on Petticoat Lane to make money'

fields.headline: 'Stockbrokers ran stalls on Petticoat Lane to make money'
fields.trailText: The way the market has moved over the past year has an uncanny resemblance to the great bear market of 1973-74, when share prices halved over an 18-month period against the background of banking collapses and oil price shocks.
fields.body:
The way the market has moved over the past year has an uncanny resemblance to the great bear market of 1973-74, when share prices halved over an 18-month period against the background of banking collapses and oil price shocks.

Those who were in the market at the time remember vividly the gloom and despondency that settled over the City as share prices continued an almost daily slide, failing to react to increasingly desperate measures by the then Labour government in which Denis (now Lord) Healey was Chancellor.

Brian Winterflood, who runs the Winterflood Securities share-trading division of Close Brothers, was a young trader with a leading broker throughout the period: 'My overwhelming memory is that, after the great shake-out and sell-off, there was nothing for anybody to do.

'Nobody was doing any business, no matter how low prices went. It was a wonder we didn't all get the sack. The standard joke in Christmas 1973 was that the broking firms were all offering partnerships or turkeys as a gift, and they ran out of turkeys.

I remember somebody calculating that the whole of the Jaguar car company was worth the same as 50 of their cars, which shows how far prices had fallen.

'The Bank of England issued a statement saying it was not going bust. A lot of us took other jobs just to supplement our income. Some of my stockbroker mates ran stalls in Petticoat Lane and Portobello Road, and I opened an antique shop called Floods in the New King's Road.

'Trading was different then. There was a lot less credit around, so people were actually losing their assets - houses and cars were flogged to pay off trading losses.

'Apart from 1987, which was really just a correction, we've had a 20-year bull market. So it's hard for young traders to imagine what it was like when people just did not deal. Well, now they know.

'The fear is still the same now - the fear of getting laid off, but things are better managed. Greenspan does actually have a hands-on approach to the whole issue, Bush's tax-cutting plan may help the US turn the corner, and I can't see the rest of the world allowing Japan to go bust.

'But there is still that terrible loss of confidence and spiralling losses. It will still take a long time to get the courage to go back into the market.'

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Cammell order could be halved
fields.body:
Cammell order could be halved

Cruise line Luxus is set to dump one of the two $250 million cruise ships it planned to build at Cammell Laird's Birkenhead yard on Merseyside. It believes the move would increase its chances of gaining Government backing for the project.

The order is crucial for Cammell, which has said 1,500 jobs depend on it. Despite the effective halving of the order, it is optimistic that most will survive.

Luxus last week drew up alternative proposals to the two-ship deal because negotiations over an aid package, including intervention funding and a Government loan guarantee, hit the rocks.

The new deal would leave open the option for a second ship.

Seeboard for sale

A £1.5 billion for sale sign has been raised over electricity group Seeboard by its US parent, American Electric Power, after informal approaches from potential buyers.

AEP is set to appoint investment bank Schroder Salomon Smith Barney to handle the sale, according to online news service Sharecast.com. Seeboard is seen as a prime asset because of its 2 million customers in affluent Kent, Sussex and Surrey.

Last month AEP sold Yorkshire Power for a total £1.8bn in cash and debt to Innogy, the recently demerged UK arm of National Power, marking a renewed shake-up of privatised UK utilities.

Go-ing again?

Dutch national airline KLM is considering a fresh bid for British Airways' low-cost subsidiary Go, despite being outbid last week and leaving venture capitalist 3i apparently in exclusive negotiations.

KLM is understood to be reluctant to top 3i's £100m bid but is examining its options and could attempt to come back to the table.

'I would not rule it out. Go is not sold yet,' said a source close to the negotiations.

KLM wanted to merge Go with its discount airline Buzz, which both fly from Stansted and have yet to make profits.

If it is no longer interested in Go, City observers believe it could sell Buzz or shut it down.

Bold Bradman

Godfrey Bradman, one of the country's leading property financiers, is planning to push the borders of the Square Mile north-eastwards with a huge new office development only yards from the Broadgate complex by London's Liverpool Street that made his name.

Bradman, whose company Rosehaugh went bankrupt in the early Nineties property recession with debts of more than £300m, has agreed terms to buy a 1.5 acre site next to Spitalfields market from a builders' merchant for around £30m. The deal will place Bradman, who is working on a £1.5bn transformation of Elephant and Castle, in prime position to buy two further sites which will allow 1.25m sq ft of new office space.

webTitle: Line of failures feared as telecoms boom hits gloom

fields.headline: Line of failures feared as telecoms boom hits gloom
fields.standfirst: Suddenly, it seems, too many players were chasing too little business. Jamie Doward on how the party ended - and what happens next
fields.trailText: Suddenly, it seems, too many players were chasing too little business. Jamie Doward on how the party ended - and what happens next
fields.body:
Back in October 1999 Ray Dutton thought he was about to become a very rich man. His telecoms company, iaxis, which called itself a 'pan-European network', was looking at a $2 billion flotation to fund further expansion. Dutton, with hubris which then typified the telecoms sector, boasted: 'If you can't make money in telecoms, you should be in an institution for the feeble-minded.'

He now lives in Australia - as far away as possible from angry investors who backed his company only to see it collapse last September. There are question marks, too, over Telemonde, an iaxis offspring chaired by Kevin Maxwell. Its shares have crashed by 85 per cent over the past 12 months.

Both companies are 'carrier's carriers'. They have no infrastructure; they just lease capacity from other telecoms firms and sell it on.

That was the theory. Unfortunately for iaxis and Telemonde, many other firms had the same idea and piggy-backed on companies which owned networks. The result: overcapacity that drove the price of bandwidth down by 80 per cent in little under a year.

The problems facing the carriers' market, which emerged towards the end of last year, were the first true signs that the telecoms bubble was not sustainable, despite predictions heralding an explosion in data traffic as the world embraced the knowledge economy.

Too many players have spent too much money on trying to compete at a time when companies are reining back spending plans in anticipation of hard days ahead. So margins are taking a hammering, and the stellar growth predictions made only a few months ago now look increasingly shaky. Dutton's iaxis is likely to be the first in a long line of failures.

Last Wednesday it was the turn of Cable & Wireless to depress the sector. It issued a profits warning, blaming a sharp fall in the price of internet traffic. Some 4,000 jobs will go. Chief executive Graham Wallace described the price cuts as 'severe' and suggested that rival companies would soon admit similar problems.

Earlier this month US giant WorldCom announced it was laying off 7 per cent of its workforce. Rival AT&T, forced to cut its fourth-quarter dividend last year, is now looking at breaking itself up after its shares plummeted. The problems facing debt-laden BT - now valued at £35 billion, half what it stood at less than a year ago - are becoming worse daily.

Then there is the nightmare mobile phones sector. With the costs of launching a global 3G wireless internet service estimated at more than £150bn, the likes of Vodafone and Orange have seen their share prices slide due to fear that they overpaid.

All this has made the money markets nervous. The banks have overstretched themselves, lending the sector a staggering $300bn. It is only a matter of time before a number of telecoms players default. Only last week ratings agency Standard & Poor's said it 'no longer considers it prudent to rule out the possibility that the operator Viatel [which is in the middle of building a pan-European state-of-the-art network and once enjoyed a huge following on Wall Street] may fall below the junk bond CCC+ rating'.

Concerns over other possible defaults have driven investors away from the telecoms bonds market. As a result, spreads have widened dramatically, and telecom bonds offer average interest of 14 per cent, compared with around 6 per cent for a no-risk Government bond.

'There are too many telecom companies and they're not all going to make a profit,' says Adrian Murray, analyst with broker Teather & Greenwood. 'The financial markets are no longer willing to increase their exposure.'

The problems facing some network operators have in turn started to cut dramatically into the profits of makers of telecoms infrastructures. As their clients have faced a cash crunch, the equipment manufacturers - the very stocks analysts saw as 'safe harbours' because they provided the picks and shovels for the internet gold rush - are suffering.

Why? Because when there is no way of raising new financing, smaller clients simply can't afford capital expenditure. Instead they must use what they've got. 'They can't keep building the networks,' Murray says. 'Every dollar those companies spend now must earn a return. They can't hope it comes in in three or four years.'

Significantly, on the same day as Cable & Wireless was announcing redundancies, Germany's Siemens and Motorola of the US added to the gloom, chipping in with, respectively, a profits warning and news of more job cuts.

This came in the same week that Swedish mobile phone giant Ericsson, which makes the bulk of its revenues from building network infrastructure, announced it expected a first-quarter loss of up to £350m. Rival Nokia later put out a trading statement showing it expected sales growth to slump this quarter.

Earlier this month network equipment giant Cisco said it would make 2,500 staff redundant, 5 per cent of its workforce. On the same day bellwether stock Intel, whose chips are found in everything from internet servers to mobile phones, issued its third profits warning in a row and announced that 5,000 jobs were to go.

Gloom outside the telecoms sector hasn't helped. Cisco, for example, says the motor industry has cut around $100m of investment in telecoms. And as more dotcoms fail, demand for faster, fatter 'pipes' evaporates.

No company is immune. Canadian giant Nortel, the world's largest telecoms equipment maker, stunned the market last October with disappointing sales figures, sending shockwaves through the infrastructure sector.

Bookham Technology, the UK maker of fibre-optic cables and one of Nortel's biggest suppliers, has seen its shares slump as a result. Earlier this month it announced 150 redundancies.

Where will it end? 'The bottom of the market will probably be marked when you see a relatively large telecom company go bust because the banks say they're not going to refinance it,' Murray says.

With the Nasdaq now below 2,000 points, compared with a high of 5,000 last year, the markets' love affair with telecoms stocks, which powered the rise of the IT sector, is clearly over.

Charles Dumas, analyst with Lombard Street Research, who predicted last the Nasdaq's slide last May, is now warning it could fall by a further 50 per cent. 'The tech sector is at best ex-growth, and much of it merely a profit-less call option on a bust,' Dumas says.

So that's that. Time for a new bandwagon.

fields.headline: Join euro in 2003, says Item
fields.trailText: It would be in Britain's economic interests to join the European single currency in 2003, claims one of the country's leading economic forecasters.
fields.body:
It would be in Britain's economic interests to join the European single currency in 2003, claims one of the country's leading economic forecasters.

In its most powerful plea yet for euro membership, the Ernst & Young Item Club claims Britain has now converged with the eurozone, broken its links with the American business cycle and can withstand a downturn in the US.

'Both consumer and business confidence have collapsed in the US,' said Professor Peter Spencer, the Item Club's economic adviser. 'Normally the contagion would spread here, but it is abundantly clear that we're now marching apace with Europe.'

But Spencer warned that indecision or caution by the European Central Bank in the midst of a US slowdown could result in 'a sustained period of slow growth'.

The Item Club, the only economic forecasting group to use the Treasury's own model of the UK economy, now believes that the UK will benefit from joining the single currency.

The formerly tentative Club argues that reduced transaction costs and lower exchange rate volatility should encourage strong expansion in UK trade, while a fixed exchange rate will increase the effectiveness of fiscal policy.

With the economic case sound, the Club believes the political risks of membership are 'much more significant': 'Without a major effort, the outcome of any referendum at the [2003] horizon will almost certainly be a "no".'

Should Labour win the next election, Tony Blair must 'grasp the bull by the horns and start to argue its case immediately' to persuade a sceptical public and give business the green light to begin making the necessary conversion.

webTitle: Sell, sell, sell. A week  of market madness

fields.headline: Sell, sell, sell. A week  of market madness
fields.standfirst: It started with a collapse in hi-tech stocks. Then the exchanges took fright at a Japanese meltdown. But  Paul Farrelly  finds hope amid the jangled nerves: the US economy is still robust, and another bout of rate-cutting by the Fed could just come to the rescue
fields.trailText: It started with a collapse in hi-tech stocks. Then the exchanges took fright at a Japanese meltdown. But Paul Farrelly finds hope amid the jangled nerves: the US economy is still robust, and another bout of rate-cutting by the Fed could just come to the rescue
fields.body:
Can Alan Greenspan, the mighty US Federal Reserve Bank's legendary chairman, pull off his 'confidence trick' just one more time?

In 1998, when global markets were last seized by the blind panic evident last week, the Fed veteran cut US interest rates no fewer than three times to loosen the grip on Wall Street's windpipe. Then Russia's dramatic debt default, the $3.5 billion collapse of Long Term Capital Management, the world's biggest hedge fund, and Asia's economic crisis sent traders into a tailspin.

Each cut, of course, was couched in the chairman's trademark caution. 'Irrational exuberance' has since become Greenspan's catch-phrase. The Fed, he joked - as he no doubt will do again on Tuesday - was not there to bail out motley fools, but bail them out he certainly did.

This year, Greenspan has already surprised with two pre-emptive rate cuts in January. And if the maestro does pull it off, Sir Edward George will be the first to applaud. Last Monday the Bank of England Governor tried a few soothing words of his own, but was ignominiously flattened in the rush for the door.

The stock market has been in a deepening state of depres sion for a year, since the first pricking of the dotcom bubble last March. But the trip- switch that made it manic was a profits warning, complete with 3,000 lay-offs, just before last weekend from a new technology firm with a very real business, Cisco Systems, the giant US internet hardware supplier.

'The volatility just shows how nervous investors are,' said Jeremy Hawkins, chief economist at Bank of America in London. 'They'll change their view on just one piece of news. Unless the Fed cuts decently [this] week, no one has any faith now that Nasdaq or the Dow will turn.'

Cisco's multi-million dollar ad campaign boasts that it 'powers the internet generation'. Sadly, the internet - and the hype accorded to almost every telecoms, media and technology firm - has long blown a fuse.

No matter that cutting-edge firms had warned of a severe slowdown in US hi-tech investment since last autumn. A psyched-out market strung together further gloom from the likes of Intel, Cable & Wireless, Motorola, Ericsson and Siemens, to paint the bleakest of 'new' pictures. On Wednesday, by the time old economy McDonald's warned that mad cow disease had made for spongy burger sales, it was 'sell, sell, sell' - sell everything, in fact.

Mark Haines, anchor of TV network CNBC's morning business news, captured the madness, appearing in a tin hat sporting a big red cross.

Add in the inevitable rumours of a huge financial collapse - this time of the odd Japanese bank or 19, following a credit downgrade by Fitch, the influential rating agency - and by the close of play the hi-tech Nasdaq market was below 2,000 for the first time since the end of 1998 - 60 per cent off its 5,000 peak a year ago. The Dow Jones index tumbled under the magic 10,000 mark. London's FTSE-100 also fell - nearly 400 points in four days - along with markets the world over.

On Thursday, comfort from Nokia steadied nerves (just think of it, global markets hanging on the every word of a Finnish company). But it was brief respite, as sliding profits at Oracle, the US software giant, and a warning from computer-maker Compaq put the skids under the 'dead cat bounce', to round off a miserable week.

Throughout, the biggest bears imaginable came pouring out of the woods. Warren Buffett, the 'Sage of Omaha', scolded the bankers, brokers and Cinderella investors who concocted the internet fairy tale. 'They know that overstaying the festivities... will eventually bring on pumpkins and mice. But they hate to miss a single minute of one helluva a party,' he wrote.

George Soros poured similar scorn, as did Britain's arch doom-monger, top fund manager Tony Dye, warning of more despair to come. 'Historically, when bubbles burst, the trauma is felt for a very long time. It is deleterious for economic and stock market activity,' Dye told The Observer .

'The headwinds are now very strong indeed. It's sad, really, that so many people believed they were cleverer than previous generations and could get so rich, so quick. Everyone is still expecting the good fairy to come along and wave her magic wand, but she won't.'

That things are now very different is plain. In 1998, it was strong US economic growth that powered world markets out of crisis, ably assisted by Greenspan's nudging. Now the decade-long US economic miracle, the longest since records began, is undeniably slowing. At a projected 2.5 per cent this first quarter, growth in US consumer spending will be half the level of last summer.

Last week, too, Washington announced a record deficit on its current account balance of trade: imports exceeded exports by a staggering $435bn last year, up from $331bn in 1999. As US demand is nearly half the world total, the worries over the global knock-on effects of a full-blown US recession are understandable.

'This is a country living beyond its means. The plunge in US confidence is a sign of real problems ahead,' said leading economist Roger Bootle of consultants Capital Economics. 'Interest rate cuts will help, but if the fundamentals are wrong and asset prices are at the wrong levels, a few points off aren't going to help that much at all.'

Dissect the data, however, and perhaps Greenspan has room to conjure after all. First, figures over the last fortnight show the US economy performing more robustly than expected, even though manufacturing output has now dipped for five months in a row. Employment and inflation are steady, new housing starts are holding up and retail sales are still respectably strong. That, indeed, was what George was trying to say last Monday.

Second, it is the 'new economy' that is bearing the brunt of what looks like a traditional business cycle, as US firms cut back on hi tech investment. According to one forecast, this was running at $560bn last year - 5.5 per cent of GDP, against 3 per cent a decade ago - and may take another 10 years to regain that level. As the dotcom threat has petered out, such investment is now inessential and deferrable - bad news for the Ciscos, but not necessarily for their business clients.

'To a great extent, right now the "blood on the streets" view is frankly unjustified. Valuations now are near their recession low points and so offer some comfort on a long term view,' said Richard Kersley, chief equity strategist at investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston. 'A catalyst is needed to turn things round and rate cuts won't be enough. What's needed is evidence that the rate medicine is working.'

Yet there are clear - and present - dangers. Overall, the savings ratio in the free-spending US is now zero. Starved of capital gains if US consumers stop spending and start hoarding, the economy could be in for a very hard landing. A wave of job losses, for example, might spook consumer confidence.

Despite the market crash over the last year, until recently money was still flowing into US equities. In January, a net $33.5bn was pumped into shares out of a record $140bn into markets as a whole. Worryingly, however, in February investors yanked $6.7bn from their savings with mutual funds, the first withdrawals since the crash of 1998. Half of US households hold shares - worth about $9 trillion in all - and the impact of a run on the funds would be cataclysmic.

In 1998, however, it was a bolt from the blue - Russia's debt default - that caused the panic. It also prompted the collapse of LTCM, which itself threatened the stability of world financial markets until the US led a bail-out.

In 2001, a similar spectre looms over Greenspan's Fed. Only now for Russia, read Japan - 'the bullet to our head' says CSFB's Kersley.

The Japanese economy has been at rock-bottom for so long that, until Cisco, the markets had almost become inured to the potential for more problems. As the world's second-largest economy swings between economic and political crisis, tomorrow the Bank of Japan looks set to cut interest rates to zero in a final attempt to nudge the country out of paralysis. After further losses last week, Tokyo's Nikkei index stands at a 16-year low. With Japanese banks holding untold trillions of yen worth of shares as security and their financial year-end due on 31 March, the prospect of another banking crisis is greatly exercising regulators.

Japan has been there and bailed out its banks before. But, with huge public debt, the Japanese government is itself barely solvent.

'The most worrying thing is Japan,' said Bootle. 'You could envisage a scenario which is close to financial disaster. That's more or less unprecedented for a major developed country, despite all the crises we've been through in the last 20 or 30 years.'

fields.headline: Antique trade rejects 'criminal' red tape
fields.trailText: UK antiques dealers are up in arms over legislation designed to crack down on crime which is forcing them to keep detailed records of anyone who buys furniture, art and collectibles from them, writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
UK antiques dealers are up in arms over legislation designed to crack down on crime which is forcing them to keep detailed records of anyone who buys furniture, art and collectibles from them, writes Nick Mathiason.

The legislation, passed by Parliament through Private Bills, is already enforced in eight English counties with a ninth, Kent, set to follow soon.

Dealers are furious that each county has different rules, creating a 'bureaucratic nightmare'.

'These rules make it impossible to trade,' said Malcolm Hord, chief executive of London and Provincial Antique Dealers. 'Dealers buy in one county and sell in another. The red tape is just impossible and will drive smaller dealers to distraction.'

Britain's £3.5 billion antique trade employs 40,000 people nationwide.

fields.headline: A welcome return to 'insanity'
fields.trailText: 'For the best part of a generation, talking about full employment has implied economic insanity. Getting back through 1 million marks the complete rehabilitation of full employment as a credible political and economic concept.'
fields.body:
'For the best part of a generation, talking about full employment has implied economic insanity. Getting back through 1 million marks the complete rehabilitation of full employment as a credible political and economic concept.'

This remark, quoted in the Financial Times, was made by Paul Convery of the Unemployment Unit, a campaigning group that has done much to promote the cause of full employment. In the Eighties and Nineties, as some 30 or so revisions were made to the definition of unemployment - most aimed at lowering, or 'fiddling', the figures - the Unemployment Unit did sterling work in alerting people.

Others who alerted people to what was going on included Gordon Brown, Tony Blair, former Tory Cabinet Minister Lord Gilmour and... I was going to say 'hosts of others' but we often felt like a beleaguered minority.

It is good news that unemployment has fallen below the million mark, but disconcerting that unemployment is still around 1.5 million by the International Labour Organisation's definition of the economically active (5.2 per cent) against the 996,000 (3.4 per cent) indicated by the Government's figure for 'those out of work and claiming benefit'.

The 996,000 figure leaves out those who would like to work but are disqualified for some reason from receiving benefits. Estimates of those people range from 3 million to 4 million - a statistic cited by the Prime Minister himself.

I have not been slow to question a number of aspects of New Labour's economic strategy; but its restoration of the economically 'insane' goal of full employment is laudable.

In the golden age of the Fifties and early Sixties, when unemployment was sometimes below 1 per cent, there were professors at Cambridge who implied that certain professors at the London School of Economics were almost fascists for advocating unemployment rates of 2.5 per cent to keep inflation down.

Through their macro-economic policies, governments or central banks aim to run economies in a way that prevents an excessive degree of inflation. What counts as 'excessive' is debatable. But the main point is that there have been many times in the past when people were accused of being 'workshy' when it was government policy to create a situation where unemployment would rise. It was official, if undeclared, policy to make people workshy.

One of the less attractive aspects of this Government's approach to employment is the element of compulsion about it. The fashion is to work yourself into the ground. Yet a civilised society ought to have room for people to exercise the right not to 'work' - especially if they have the full-time task of raising small children.

A great irony of the present position is that the so-called 'culture of dependency' saw its strongest period of growth during the Thatcher era. To massage the size of unemployment figures that government policies were driving up, masses of people were actively encouraged to sign up as disabled. New Labour is living with the consequences.

And I wonder whether it is wise of this Government to make so much of its New Deal policy that 'staying on benefits is not an option'.

If the world economy turns sour in response to the US slowdown, a re-elected Labour Government may find that, for all its good intentions, the favourable unemployment trend will go into reverse, and unemployment could rise in a way which has nothing to do with being 'workshy'.

In 1997 Gordon Brown inherited good macroeconomic policy conditions. Between them, he and the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee have kept up the trend towards full employment. But the outlook for the world economy seems to deteriorate daily. The news from the US is so disturbing that a Republican Party that wanted 'supply-side' tax reform to benefit the rich has now rediscovered Keynesian fiscal policy and is trying to sell its tax cut proposal as a demand-boosting measure.

Very little of this tax cut seems to be aimed at the current year, and the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts have so far done little to boost morale. A US boom that was allowed to get out of hand via inflated asset values is now in danger of leading to a bust via a reversal of that process. Economic forecasts in continental Europe are being revised downwards, but the European Central Bank remains complacent.

It is not surprising that Gus O'Donnell, the Treasury representative on the MPC, has hinted he expects further rate cuts should the situation deteriorate. The Chancellor is to be congratulated for not bowing to pressure to lower the inflation target in his recent Budget. That would have restricted the MPC's room for manoeuvre, should the pound eventually start falling in response to our alarmingly large trade deficit.

For the truth is that the main reason why the MPC has been undershooting the 2.5 per cent inflation target is the pound's ability - so far - to defy gravity.

Why, there may even be an element of economic insanity in the market's high rating of the pound.

webTitle: Railtrack seeks £1.5bn to avoid losing vital 'A' rating

fields.headline: Railtrack seeks £1.5bn to avoid losing vital 'A' rating
fields.trailText: Railtrack is in danger of losing its precious 'A' credit rating in the next two weeks if it does not secure a £1.5 billion bail-out from the Government to cover a serious cash shortfall.
fields.body:
Railtrack is in danger of losing its precious 'A' credit rating in the next two weeks if it does not secure a £1.5 billion bail-out from the Government to cover a serious cash shortfall.

The rail network owner is in talks with the Government and the Strategic Rail Authority after requesting advance subsidies to avoid defaulting on its debt interest payments.

If the negotiations are not settled by 1 April the company will have to appeal for an emergency regulatory review and City sources predict such a move would send its share price and credit rating plummeting.

fields.headline: Branson hires ex-Barings chief
fields.trailText: Virgin boss Richard Branson has hired a banker who was at the centre of the disastrous Barings collapse to advise on his multibillion pound business empire.
fields.body:
Virgin boss Richard Branson has hired a banker who was at the centre of the disastrous Barings collapse to advise on his multibillion pound business empire.

Peter Norris, who was chief executive of Barings when it was brought down by 'rogue trader' Nick Leeson with £835 million of debts in 1995, has been taken on by Branson to help him with corporate growth and restructuring across the Virgin businesses.

Norris was among several Barings executives criticised by the Bank of England after the scandal. He has been working as a corporate finance consultant since he was banned from being a director by the Department of Trade and Industry in 1998. His ban expires next year.

So far, he has advised Branson on a £27m expansion into the South African health clubs business for his Virgin Active chain.

But a Virgin spokesman said Norris could figure in other mergers and acquisitions activity. 'We've been impressed by the work he's done for us. We'd use him again in the future on other corporate finance things,' he said.

fields.headline: Markets pray for Fed cuts
fields.trailText: The City is praying for a sharp cut in US interest rates this week to stave off a dramatic stock market crash.
fields.body:
The City is praying for a sharp cut in US interest rates this week to stave off a dramatic stock market crash.

Panic selling, traders fear, could plunge London's FTSE-100 index through the 5,000 mark, wiping a further £150 billion off UK blue chip shares.

Last week, the value of Britain's top companies tumbled by more than £80bn, as fears over hi-tech firms and the US economy prompted a global sell-out stampede.

Tomorrow, the Bank of Japan is set to cut interest rates to zero in a final attempt to revive its depressed economy and head off an unprecedented financial crisis.

The markets, however, will continue to tremble before Tuesday's meeting of the US Federal Reserve, the world's most powerful central bank.

Influential voices are urging Fed chairman Alan Greenspan to cut US interest rates by a bold 0.75 per cent to steady the markets and boost the flagging US economy.

Greenspan has already cut them by 1 per cent, to 5 per cent, this year and UK interest rates are likely to follow any further US fall.

On Friday night, the rout on Wall Street continued, with the Dow Jones index down 208 points to 9,823, and the Nasdaq hi-tech market tumbling 50 points to 1,891, a two-and-a half year low.

'Unless the Fed cuts by at least 50 basis points [0.5 per cent] this week, no one will have any faith that the Dow or Nasdaq will turn,' said Bank of America economist Jeremy Hawkins. 'With the Dow below 10,000, many are now urging 75 basis points.'

This weekend, fears of a total Japanese meltdown and banking crisis are weighing heavily on policy-makers, including Bank of England Governor Sir Eddie George.

Japan is also understood to be seeking support for a low yen valuation policy.

'I can't see what is going to bail us out,' said fund manager Tony Dye, an arch-pessimist who heads Dye Asset Management. 'US interest rate cuts won't help Japan, the Far East or the US economy after this bubble.'

This weekend, fears on Wall Street rose on news that US savers pulled $6.7bn out of equity mutual funds in February, the first withdrawal since the 1998 Russian crisis.

webTitle: Corus tells steel unions: Go to hell

fields.headline: Corus tells steel unions: Go to hell
fields.trailText: Steelmaker Corus has secretly thrown out union proposals to save thousands of jobs and keep open threatened UK plants.
fields.body:
Steelmaker Corus has secretly thrown out union proposals to save thousands of jobs and keep open threatened UK plants.

Documents obtained by The Observer show that Corus rejected union plans three weeks before its own deadline for rescue alternatives.

As early as 8 March, the Anglo-Dutch group had dismissed plans from the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation to keep steelmaking at Llanwern in South Wales and spare 1,340 jobs. It also turned down similar plans for other plants, including Ebbw Vale, where 780 workers stand to lose their jobs, and Shotton, in North Wales.

An internal Corus report, entitled Business Restructuring, reviews the plans and concludes: 'The trade union proposal is not a viable alternative to the company's restructuring programme announced on 1 February.'

The blunt rejection of the plans, which are backed by Ministers and MPs, means the steel industry faces its first widespread industrial action since 1980s national strike.

ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy, said shop stewards had written to him demanding strike ballots. The union's national executive will debate them urgently.

Leahy said: 'If the company will not listen to the arguments of reason, they will have to listen to the arguments of force. People are extremely angry because they have approached this issue in a rational way and this has been dismissed.'

Leahy said strike action would be aimed at causing maximum disruption to Corus without forcing all the workers on to strike pay. The strikes would be backed by overtime bans and working to rule.

Corus granted a stay of execution on the 6,000 job losses and closures in Wales and the North East until the end of March to allow the unions to prepare plans.

The unions focused on retaining steelmaking capacity at Llanwern, and the finishing operations at nearby Ebbw Vale, with more effective use of energy, savings on labour costs and reduced charges at harbours which handle steel for export.

In rejecting the plans, Corus said any output would have to be exported at a loss of £40 per tonne.

webTitle: Dole over dinner for BT bosses

fields.headline: Dole over dinner for BT bosses
fields.standfirst: Angry institutions will tell Vallance and Bonfield they must quit to secure rescue rights cash
fields.trailText: Angry institutions will tell Vallance and Bonfield they must quit to secure rescue rights cash
fields.body:
BT's biggest shareholders will this week use the genteel surroundings of a City dining room to launch a putsch against the company's two most senior executives.

At a dinner for key investors on Wednesday, leading institutions will tell chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman Sir Iain Vallance: quit or we won't stump up for a rights issue.

Speculation has intensified in recent weeks that Bonfield and Vallance would have to go if City institutions were to subscribe for more shares, necessary to offset BT's spiralling debt problems.

The institutions are angry the two men have failed to prevent a 60 per cent slide in BT's share price over the last 12 months. Insiders say the biggest shareholders now intend to use the dinner - which BT insiders describe as 'crucial'- to tell the company that it needs an urgent management overhaul.

It was at a similar dinner earlier this year that BT first mooted the possibility of tapping investors for cash. The largest shareholders were open to the idea - provided the company spelt out its restructuring plans.

Bonfield and Vallance had looked to speed up BT's disposal programme in a last-ditch attempt to salvage their reputations. But with the telecoms market depressed, the possibility of obtaining a decent price for BT's non-core assets has disappeared and leading institutions have run out of patience.

All of the investors interviewed by the Observer said they thought it was time for a change at the top, although some argued the two should not quit simultaneously. 'It's not a question of if they go. It's a question of when,' one institutional investor said.

'We believe BT needs a new independent chairman focused on two things: shareholder value and putting in place a good management team,' another said.

A spokesman for BT dismissed suggestions that the company had asked headhunters to speed up plans to find a replacement for Vallance before his contract expires in July of next year. 'All businesses of all sizes have succession plans. We have to find a new chairman before 2002, when Sir Iain goes, and that has always been the position,' the spokesman said.

BT had hoped that a rights issue would not be necessary. Initially the company believed that its plans to float Yell, its Yellow Pages division, and BT Wireless, its mobile phone arm, would raise sufficient cash. Selling some of its non-core assets, chiefly in Asia, would also raise money, BT argued.

But the collapse of the telecoms market has meant such options are now effectively closed. With credit agencies urgently demanding details on how BT intends to pare down its £32 billion debt mountain, the company has no alternative but to tap investors for cash. 'The window is virtually closed now on their accelerated asset disposal programme. The pressure is on the management team,' one investor said.

One way of carrying out the rights issue would be to float BT's Wireless division, but only allow insitutional investors to subscribe for shares at a knock down price. At one stage BT Wireless, which includes BT Cellnet, was valued at more than £40bn. Under the new plans, it might list for only £10bn.

webTitle: Money writes: A holiday to forget

fields.headline: Thanks to our insurer, we had a holidayto forget
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I booked a holiday in Le Touquet last August through Motours. Our daughter could not accompany us because of severe acne and she has not been at school since. While the insurance claim of £63 (minus excess) is irrelevant compared with the anguish she has suffered, we are disappointed by the unhelpful response of Inter Group Claims Services. They kept asking for different documents, and now they say they do not have a file for me and have sent another claim form.
GE, Guildford

Inter Group Claims blames a backlog of claims following last year's fuel blockades and air traffic controllers' dispute for taking such an appallingly long time to pay your claim.

It has now sent you a cheque for £50. Under the Association of British Insurers' Claims Code, which was launched last January, insurers and their claims- handling subcontractors, must initially respond to claims within five working days and, when processing the outstanding claim, reply to any of your letters within 10 days.

To check on how claims should be handled, the full code is on the ABI website at www.abi.org.uk. Click on 'Consumer Advice and Information', then 'Codes' and 'General Insurance Claims Code'.

With-profits bond: A sensible risk

As someone on the point of retirement, I am repeatedly advised to consider with-profits bonds as a cautious approach to achieving income with capital growth. Simultaneously, articles appear which are critical of these investments. Am I missing something?
MM, Welwyn Garden City

There is no clear-cut answer. Some advisers still consider with-profits bonds a valid, comparatively low-risk, long-term stock market investment because they smooth the short-term swings. However, they admit the mechanics are complicated, and they are not tax efficient. Even supporters say you should not put all your money into with-profits bonds, perhaps one-third, and then, most importantly, pick financially strong companies such as Norwich Union and Scottish Mutual.

Other advisers believe unit trusts inside an Isa are better because they give tax relief, are easier to understand and are probably cheaper. They are more volatile, but you can choose low-risk unit trusts such as Royal & Sun Alliance Managed Fund or Deutsche Managed Portfolio.

Pension options: Time to plan

As a teenager in the Sixties, I blithely thought that retirement was something I would not have to think about, convinced that I would be rich. Reality set in at 45. An adviser suggested Standard Life and to remain in Serps but my contributions were small. Retirement at 60 is not an option for me so do I defer both Standard Life and state pension until I am 65 or should I take the state pension at 60 and extend the private pension?
MS, Birmingham

The only way to get more money out of your pension is to put more money in. And the older you are when you take the pension, the better annuity rate you get. So keep contributing to Standard Life, where charges are falling to stakeholder pension levels.

But go back to the original adviser to check that your contributions are being invested in the most suitable funds. Near retirement, you should switch to safer investments.

You cannot contribute more to the state pension through National Insurance contributions beyond the official retirement age, but you can delay taking it. The basic state pension and additional pension increase by about 7.5 per cent for every year you defer for a maximum five years. From 6 April 2010, you will be able to delay taking the state pension for as long as you like and gain around 10.4 per cent a year.

Getting a higher pension is attractive, but you forgo payments while you wait. Missing out on this year's basic pension costs £3,510. This gives you an extra £263.25 next year but you are £3,246.75 out of pocket over two years. It is worth waiting only if you have a long life expectancy.

Isa transfers: Check the rates

I have £6,000 in a mini-cash Isa with Nationwide. I will invest another £3,000 next year but there seem to be better rates than Nationwide's. Can I transfer my £6,000 to another Isa provider or am I stuck with my original choice?
JF, Houghton-le-Spring

You can move your money to another bank or building society without any penalty from Nationwide; some Isa providers charge when you take your money away from them.

Nationwide's rates are competitive. From this month, it is paying 6.2 per cent on its cash Isa with instant access and 6.75 per cent to customers who have had any account with the society for the past three years.

Internet bank Smile pays 6.75 per cent on instant access on every pound. Northern Rock's 30-days notice account will, from April 2, pay 6.55 per cent including a bonus for the first six months and then 6 per cent. Interest rates have been falling in recent weeks, so check whether a rate that tempts you is likely to last.

Mortgage error: £64 write-off

Last September I decided to increase my Bradford & Bingley mortgage payments from £55 to £120. In February I was told I was £64.70 in arrears. They said this was my fault because I had asked to increase payment in August but did not pay the higher amount until September.
JJ, Benfleet

Bradford and Bingley jumped the gun on your instructions to increase payments and adjusted your account after your August payment had already gone through, instead of waiting until September. So its records showed that you should have paid £120 in August whereas you paid the correct £55. It did not warn you at the time because the shortfall was less than one month's payment.

The following February, Bradford & Bingley conducted its annual review of all mortgages. Your higher payment does not come into the calculation because you must reconfirm each year that you want to pay more or set up a separate standing order.

Your basic monthly payment was reduced to £53.60 from February so the £64.70 shortfall now exceeded one month's payment and the bank contacted you.

Bradford & Bingley takes full responsibility for the errors it made. It has written off the £64.70 shortfall, made sure there is no blemish on your credit record and is sending you some flowers to apologise.

fields.headline: In control - and causing trouble
fields.standfirst: Disability campaigner Jane Campbell tells Kate Condon how she gets by despite severe impairment
fields.trailText: Disability campaigner Jane Campbell tells Kate Condon how she gets by despite severe impairment.
fields.body:
When Jane Campbell considers her earnings from various sources, she reflects: 'I'm doing well and have almost got to the top of my career.' It's all the more remarkable because Campbell is severely disabled and for her to be working at all is unusual; 64 per cent of disabled people are unemployed and fewer than 900 severely disabled people have jobs.

Campbell shares a job which brings in £17,500 a year, and her other earnings - from a private consultancy, speaking engagements and a public appointment as a Disability Rights Commissioner - take the total up to about £25,000.

Campbell chose a part-time job so that she could work for the disability movement, but essentially her whole career has been devoted to bringing about changes in policy towards disability. She's currently co-director of the National Centre for Independent Living, a government-funded body that offers disabled people advice and training.

'In the old days, you had people speaking on our behalf; there was a history of paternalism and medicalisation,' she says. 'Now, Independent Living schemes allow disabled people to take control of their lives: it gets them out of institutions and emancipates them.'

Had things been different, Campbell could have found herself in an institution. Her disability - a degenerative impairment - means that she can't move much more than her head and one of her arms. 'I wasn't supposed to reach the age of one, and here I am at 41,' she says. She felt she was educationally deprived but says: 'I had a good family who pushed me quite a lot - and I'm very bloody-minded.'

Since university Campbell has always worked - she started in an equalities unit at the Greater London Council, where she 'shot up the hierarchy'. But she needs a large amount of assistance. She employs six people around the clock, who do everything from working the overhead projector if she's lecturing, to putting her on her ventilator at night. 'I need to eat, go to the loo, wash and get dressed - so personal assistants are vital to my life,' she says.

She has 70 hours' assistance a week, and a personal assistant sleeping over every night. This package costs about £2,500 a month, most of which is paid by Campbell's local authority. She contributes about £150 a month, and meets other costs such as equipment, a van and a driver. Campbell also spends her income on going out. 'I love theatre and music and people. I go out a lot and there will be a day soon when I can't.'

But this doesn't come cheap - being accompanied everywhere means extra tickets, food, even hotel rooms if she goes on holiday.

'It's crazy; the costs are enormous,' she says. She has no pension but she has saved for when she will no longer be able to work.

So a recent government proposal to make better-off disabled people contribute more to the cost of their personal assistance has made Campbell see red. Under the scheme, up to 55 per cent of net earnings could be included in a calculation of income.

Campbell would contribute not her current £150 a month but nearly £150 a week. She says: 'The Government has put millions into the New Deal to get disabled people into the workplace. This proposal is a total disincentive and is means-testing the most severely disabled people in this country. I would need this care even if I didn't work; I'd probably have to go to a day centre.'

Campbell is employing all her bloody-mindedness to fight the proposal. 'I'm causing trouble,' she says. 'If this goes through, I will not work. We could have a mass resignation situation.'

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: The Bonus CashBuilder Plus plan.
fields.body:
A mailshot featuring Carol Smillie may inspire hope of an instant transformation for your finances, courtesy of the makeover queen. But an Axa Sun Life scheme she endorses is the financial equivalent of chintz curtains and floral wallpaper.

The Bonus CashBuilder Plus plan is a 15-year with-profit endowment savings plan - a type seen by many independent advisers as outdated because of their inflexibility, especially for small savers. Bonuses are falling, and there are concerns about their management and charges. The Financial Services Authority is setting up a review.

Axa Sun Life says the CashBuilder offers a way into stock market investment for as little as £10. But the literature reveals that premiums will rise by 20 per cent a year for the first five years, so after five years those who started by saving £10 a month would end up paying double that.

Axa offers the equivalent of half the first year's premiums in cash after a year. But savers who drop out may get nothing back in the first three years and barely break even after five.

One leaflet guarantees a cash return of up to £22,140. But a separate one says this is only for younger savers paying £100 a month. Peter Webb of Axa Sun Life said the company aimed to explain fully its product in the mailshots but no one should buy on the strength of headlines alone.

 Seen an advertisement or mailshot that sounds too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch?, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
