webTitle: Wealthcheck: Great aunt's cash has left us puzzled

fields.headline: Great aunt's cash has left us puzzled
fields.standfirst: Money's tight for Eileen and Julius so they must use a £9,000 windfall wisely, writes  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Money's tight for Eileen and Julius so they must use a £9,000 windfall wisely, writes Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Eileen Cochrane and Julius Nicholson

Ages 31 and 29

Live in West Yorkshire

Occupations Both work for wholefood co-operative

Earn Joint earnings c.£14,000

Mortgage £27,000

Debts Student loan £500

Investments £9,000 in ISAs and bank account

Pension Julius - occupational, Eileen - None

Aims To use Eileen's £9,000 inheritance wisely - to reduce their mortgage, buy her a pension or invest in some other way

Eileen and Julius met at university and tried a variety of occupations before they found exactly the jobs they wanted, where they wanted. Both now work for an independent wholefood co-operative. This enables them to share the parenting of their two-year-old daughter by splitting the working week between them. They are planning to have a second child soon. The only problem with their situation is that they are not particularly flush with money, and were therefore delighted when Eileen inherited £9,000 from her great aunt just before Christmas.

'We are extremely keen to use our windfall as wisely as possible,' says Eileen. 'We are wondering whether to invest the cash in something or whether to somehow use it to reduce our mortgage. Also, as a relatively full-time mother, I am not paying into a pension plan, but we don't know how to achieve this on our very limited income.'

The money is in various Halifax accounts - £3,000 in a mini-cash Isa, £500 in an equity Tracker Isa and the remainder in an instant access account. But Eileen is worried they may be tempted to spend it. They have already dipped into it to help pay for car repairs.

Another reason Eileen wants to do something quite quickly is that she has recently discovered that they would qualify for the working families tax credit - if their savings were lower.

Their mortgage is with NatWest. After taking out a discounted loan initially, they are now paying the standard variable rate. They would like to re-mortgage to get a cheaper deal but are locked into their loan until the end of August by redemption penalties. They are also hoping to switch from an endowment to a repayment mortgage, though they would like to continue with the endowment as a savings policy. Last February, they had to increase their premiums by 20 per cent following predictions that their policy would produce a £5,000 shortfall. They also want to move to a bigger house.

Eileen wonders if she should put part of the lump sum into a pension policy. As she is not earning enough to pay National Insurance contributions, she wants to know whether she should pay them voluntarily to safeguard her state pension.

Fortunately, Julius has a pension with his job and has also transferred bits of pension from previous jobs into his current scheme. He is also making additional voluntary contributions. Together with his pension, Julius has some life assurance. They also have life cover for the mortgage through the endowment. In fact, Eileen wonders if they have too much and could cut back to save money.

Despite being 'very skint' as Eileen puts it, they have never had an overdraft and are not in debt apart from Julius's small student loan.

Adviser 1: Gordon Wilson

Eileen and Julius should consider a remortgage in August to reduce their monthly interest costs. At this point I would also recommend reducing the debt with a large part of the £9,000. As their income is stretched, debt reduction must be a priority. I would not advise a switch to a repayment mortgage as that would merely increase their outgoings.

By remortgaging, there may be some spare income. Their first priority should be to look at how well protected the family is in the event of ill health or death. Julius should confirm how much life assurance he has at work but it is unlikely to be adequate. A cheap way of providing extra cover is a family income benefit pol icy. A policy that would pay £10,000 a year would cost around £16 a month. Illness cover should also be considered, although costs will be greater.

Eileen need not worry about her National Insurance record. Provided she is the claimant for child benefit she will automatically qualify for Home Responsibilities Protection and be credited for NI purposes.

I don't think Eileen should commit a lump sum to a stakeholder pension at present because the money would not be available until she is 50 at least. Eileen's Halifax Tracker Isa should be kept for the medium or longer term.

Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Thomson & Shepherd.

Adviser 2: Sharon Linnard

Eileen and Julius should adopt a balanced approach with their inherited capital rather than using it all for one purpose. Part of it should be used to repay part of the mortgage. This will help offset the higher monthly cost which will result if they switch to a repayment mortgage and maintain the endowment policy as a means of saving.

Eileen could also consider putting some of the money into a stakeholder pension. They have been designed to help women who are taking career breaks to look after children. The advantage is that she can make contributions and receive tax relief even though she is a non-taxpayer. Up to £3,600 per year can be contributed to a stakeholder pension either in a lump sum or by regular premiums.

Once their savings are reduced to less than £8,000, Eileen and Julius could then apply for the working families tax credit. The amount of credit available depends on the family's net earnings and, effectively, is reduced by 55p for every £1 of earnings above £91.45 per week.

Some capital should be kept for short-term needs. Putting money in a mini-cash Isa is wise, although Halifax does not offer the best rates. Any money not kept in the Isa should be in Eileen's name as she is a non-taxpayer and can register for gross interest.

Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG.

 Advice is for guidance only. Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Turf accountant: Race now, pay later

fields.headline: Race now, pay later
fields.standfirst: You can part-own a racehorse on monthly payments, says  Lindsay Vincent
fields.trailText: You can part-own a racehorse on monthly payments, says Lindsay Vincent.
fields.body:
When it eventually takes place, the postponed Cheltenham Gold Cup meeting, the annual celebration of hoof and harness, will remain an event like no other, a three-day, hedonistic ritual that attracts more paying guests than any other in the realm save the British Grand Prix.

Both are arenas of dreams, courage and, above all, excellence - something that rarely comes cheap, even when it concerns something as seemingly irrelevant as which horse will run fastest.

What those who own racehorses - knaves, tycoons, royals or commoners - share is a seemingly ruinous price of entry. It can cost £20,000 a year to have a horse in training, which is more than the fees payable at the country's finest places of learning.

Before this, there's the cost of buying a horse worth training. Men with less sense than cunning have paid more than $13 million for horses that couldn't run faster than a donkey on speed. The bargain basement for yearlings - no horse begins its career until the age of two - starts at around £5,000, and £50,000 is not regarded as anything untoward. This buys the equivalent of an equine Mondeo, but with the possibility of transforming it into a Maserati.

Few people in Britain make racing pay, unlike most other racing countries. The sport is taxed steeply by governments, which treat it like a playground of the rich.

Increasingly, however, racing is attracting a new type of owner who belongs to a partnership or syndicate, and is there for the best reason: fun. Throwing money at keeping a slow horse in conditions and surroundings that few humans can match - the best of food, regular exercise, pampering from devoted servants, and much else - is not everyone's idea of entertainment. But collective ownership is now attracting people with more funds than they need who are willing to experience something a little different.

Although the odds are stacked heavily against it, your co-owned horse could win races and repay the investment handsomely. What's more, the sale of media rights by the industry will go some way towards making ownership much less painful by improving the prize money. So if you fancy a go, where do you start?

Many newcomers are drawn in by adverts in the trade press, largely the Racing Post . On Saturdays they offer shares in horses, mostly modest beasts. Most are placed by impoverished trainers who have horses looking for owners, and are probably best avoided.

This is a self-regulating industry. You must know how to read the form in more ways than one. Spivvy horse dealers have been around since pre-history.

The costs of shared ownership vary widely. They depend, among other things, on how many owners there are in the syndicate or partnership, and whether the agreement is for one season, two or, in rare cases, longer. The biggest cost is buying your horse.

Some syndicate promoters inflate the purchase price before selling shares. Others offer the horse at cost, but take part of any profits when it is sold and the partnership dissolves.

Three outfits you might want to consider are Highclere Thoroughbred Racing, Kennet Valley Thoroughbreds and Peter Harris Racing Stables. Highclere is seen as the 'posh people's syndicate' and has become the trade's high-roller. Kennet Valley, a tightly managed enterprise, prefers to race less expensive horses, while Peter Harris, an innovator in co-ownership, operates at the middle and lower end of the price spectrum.

Highclere is managed by Harry Herbert, a son of Lord Carnarvon, the Queen's racing manager, and a stalwart of the turf. Unpretentious, engaging and hopelessly sentimental, Herbert has been spectacularly successful since his operation began in 1992.

Syndicates under his direction have produced four champions, including a classic-winning filly, Petrushka.

'Twenty per cent of our horses have made money,' says Herbert, 'and 45 per cent [of syndicate members] have got 50 per cent or more of their money back. Since 1993, we have managed 19 syndicates, and the average shareholder has paid £11,800. The average return has been £15,597. We operate at a level where it is easy to lose the lot. Hopefully, our success is assisted by the way we manage the horses.'

Last year, Herbert ran eight syndicates varying from two 10-share groups at £40,000 a share to a 20-share syndicate, where the cost per share was £13,000.

'My job is to make each shareholder feel that the horse is theirs,' he says. 'All contact is person-to-person, and we speak to owners whenever the horse is running, and even when it isn't. Multiple ownership doesn't mean you lose the personal touch.'

Owners can travel to races on Highclere's leased aircraft. 'It is all about having fun,' says Herbert.

While Herbert's background helps explain his choice of career, he learnt the basics from Nick Robinson, head of rival Kennet Valley.

Unlike Highclere, but in common with most other firms offering multiple ownership, Kennet's shares are offered through partnerships rather than syndicates. With Government approval, partnerships allow VAT to be reclaimed, as long as each horse is 'sponsored'. Which explains why all Kennet horses bear the silks of the high-profile public relations firm Bell Pottinger.

Robinson says it is 'crazy' to pay VAT if there is a way of avoiding it. Herbert responds that VAT can be reclaimed, albeit with strings, when a horse is sold.

Robinson, an accomplished author and former editor of Pacemaker magazine, first ventured into multiple ownership in the Eighties with a wealthy gang that included Michael Smurfit, the Irish packaging millionaire. They bought four horses that would, they hoped, make the inaugural running for the Cartier Million in Ireland, the world's richest event for two-year-olds. Competing against 300 rivals, all four of Robinson's horses qualified to run, and two even made it into the money. The gamble paid off, and it was the inspiration for Kennet.

It sold out of this year's offering of horses before Christmas. Four partnerships were filled, each with between 12 and 14 participants, at £4,000 a share. Kennet's top-priced purchase at the autumn sales was £40,000.

'I do not believe in buying expensive horses,' says Robinson, most of whose 'partners' are knowledgeable about the turf.

While not unsuccessful, Kennet has not enjoyed the high, and probably unsustainable, strike rate of Highclere, but one of its partnership horses, Gateman, has won valuable races in the United States and is heading for the Dubai World Cup meeting, the world's richest race, later this month. It may go on to compete in a $2m international race in Singapore.

For participants in shared ownership, Gateman and Highclere's Petrushka represent the ultimate dream.

Owners with Peter Harris, the horse trainer and caravan park operator who last year relieved the Rank Organisation of Butlins holiday camps, have also shared success at a high level, primarily through a colt, Primo Valentino, and a filly, Katy Nowaitee. Her owners include a welder, a publican, and a retired factory foreman.

Harris, one of the first trainers to back multiple ownership, is now king of the partnerships. Three-quarters of the 120 horses in his yard are co-owned.

'There isn't a stable in the land with such a high proportion,' says Simon Double, one of his managers. 'We look after 400 owners, all initially investing for two years.'

Harris differs from most rivals in that investors do not have to pay a lump sum upfront.

'We allow people to pay us monthly by standing order,' says Double. 'Our credit agreements are a bit like those for a car. It makes a big difference to most owners.'

One enthusiast says there are few disadvantages to co-ownership , but adds: 'I think that a maximum of 10 partners is fine. Beyond that, you get further and further from the horse.'

Good luck.

Hopefully, our success is assisted by the way we manage the horses.' Last year, Herbert ran eight syndicates varying from two 10-share groups at £40,000 a share to a 20-share syndicate, where the cost per share was £13,000. 'My job is to make each shareholder feel that the horse is theirs,' he says. 'All contact is person-to-person, and we speak to owners whenever the horse is running, and even when it isn't. Multiple ownership doesn't mean you lose the personal touch.' Owners can travel to races on Highclere's leased aircraft. 'It is all about having fun,' says Herbert. While Herbert's background helps explain his choice of career, he learnt the basics from Nick Robinson, head of rival Kennet Valley. Unlike Highclere, but in common with most other firms offering multiple ownership, Kennet's shares are offered through partnerships rather than syndicates. With Government approval, partnerships allow VAT to be reclaimed, as long as each horse is 'sponsored'. Which explains why all Kennet horses bear the silks of the high-profile public relations firm Bell Pottinger. Robinson says it is 'crazy' to pay VAT if there is a way of avoiding it. Herbert responds that VAT can be reclaimed, albeit with strings, when a horse is sold. Robinson, an accomplished author and former editor of Pacemaker magazine, first ventured into multiple ownership in the Eighties with a wealthy gang that included Michael Smurfit, the Irish packaging millionaire. They bought four horses that would, they hoped, make the inaugural running for the Cartier Million in Ireland, the world's richest event for two-year-olds. Competing against 300 rivals, all four of Robinson's horses qualified to run, and two even made it into the money. The gamble paid off, and it was the inspiration for Kennet. It sold out of this year's offering of horses before Christmas. Four partnerships were filled, each with between 12 and 14 participants, at £4,000 a share. Kennet's top-priced purchase at the autumn sales was £40,000. 'I do not believe in buying expensive horses,' says Robinson, most of whose 'partners' are knowledgeable about the turf. While not unsuccessful, Kennet has not enjoyed the high, and probably unsustainable, strike rate of Highclere, but one of its partnership horses, Gateman, has won valuable races in the United States and is heading for the Dubai World Cup meeting, the world's richest race, later this month. It may go on to compete in a $2m international race in Singapore. For participants in shared ownership, Gateman and Highclere's Petrushka represent the ultimate dream. Owners with Peter Harris, the horse trainer and caravan park operator who last year relieved the Rank Organisation of Butlins holiday camps, have also shared success at a high level, primarily through a colt, Primo Valentino, and a filly, Katy Nowaitee. Her owners include a welder, a publican, and a retired factory foreman. Harris, one of the first trainers to back multiple ownership, is now king of the partnerships. Three-quarters of the 120 horses in his yard are co-owned. 'There isn't a stable in the land with such a high proportion,' says Simon Double, one of his managers. 'We look after 400 owners, all initially investing for two years.' Harris differs from most rivals in that investors do not have to pay a lump sum upfront. 'We allow people to pay us monthly by standing order,' says Double. 'Our credit agreements are a bit like those for a car. It makes a big difference to most owners.' One enthusiast says there are few disadvantages to co-ownership , but adds: 'I think that a maximum of 10 partners is fine. Beyond that, you get further and further from the horse.' Good luck.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Norwich Union Sustainable Future Funds
fields.trailText: Norwich Union Sustainable Future Funds.
fields.body:
Contact 0845 300 3344

Aim To generate income or capital growth through investment in socially responsible companies.

Bells & whistles Norwich Union's socially responsible investment (SRI) team has a good record, having hopped from Jupiter to Henderson via NPI. Clare Brook, head of the team, says: 'We believe the companies and industries that will perform best are those that consider how their actions will affect the world in 25 or 50 years' time.'

How it works The team has developed a 'sustainability matrix', which measures a company's contribution to sustainable development, both in its core business and management vision and practices. There are six funds: Corporate Bond (aiming for an income yield of 6.7 per cent gross), UK Growth, Managed (a mixture of equities and bonds) and European Growth, and the higher risk Global Growth and Absolute Growth, a concentrated international portfolio with about 20 holdings.

Minimum £500 lump sum, £50 per month.

Charges Initial 4 per cent (discounted by 1 per cent until 30 March ), annual management fee 1 per cent for corporate bond fund and 1.5 per cent for all others.

Tax Available tax-free through a maxi or mini Isa, and Pep transfer.

Risk Depends on fund.

Should you buy it? Ryan Hughes of Bath independent financial adviser Chartwell says: 'We really like them. This is a bit different from the run-of-the-mill ethical funds.' He thinks they will suit general investors rather than greens.. Justin Modray of the Bath firm Fundsdirect says: 'Over the short term they will probably be quite volatile and that may deter the ordinary investor.

Points out of 10 : Hughes - 8, Modray - 7.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: walking back to sanity, and getting around the circles under your eyes
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: walking back to sanity, and getting around the circles under your eyes.
fields.body:
'Help, help! Where's the off-button?' I heard someone cry. 'There isn't one!' I shouted back. But they didn't hear, so busy were they, they'd already rushed off to the next appointment. And quite understandably so, too. Can you imagine anything much worse than having to miss the next meeting?

The postmodern global beast is galloping faster and faster now, literally postmodern - completely ahead of even its own future - threatening to overtake our collective sanity, not to mention our email in-trays and voicemail boxes. And we just run around bitching about the ridiculous pace, the pressure and of course the weather, as if we're victims of some grandiose alien plot when all along it was us (and is us) who breathe the life into this beast. The beast is us.

But what is it that drives us, the collective beast, to accelerate so uncompromisingly? You could blame it on technology and say it was the fact that we can now access more or less 24/7 global communications and we want instant responses to our messages. Impatient to have what we want and have it now, before all the resources dwindle completely, we run faster and faster - in ever decreasing circles.

But I suspect at a deeper level we are merely witnessing a remarkable global display of our innate lust for life and all its abundant blessings. We're celebrating, that's all. We vigorously lust after every last bit of goodness this earth has to offer. Trouble is, we're wading through the champagne at an alarming rate. And to keep it flowing, we are forced to do more and more, work harder and harder, and rest less and less. So lots of bubbles but not much peace. With increasing frequency you find the in-tray filling faster than you can think, and phones ringing, and more and more relentless demands being made on you, till you want to scream.

Well, firstly, I strongly advise you do, at the earliest opportunity - scream, I mean. If in public or at work, be polite and announce your intention to scream, then take a good lungful of (polluted) air and with throat, chest and belly fully relaxed to avoid strain, scream from the depths of your pelvis till the last drop of sound has been squeezed out from between your lips and then carry on quite naturally as you were. I think we've even got past the point when anyone would think you odd or crazy in any way. Everyone's feeling the stress. They'll understand, and if they don't, subsequent dialogue will enlighten them, I'm sure. You must have an outlet for this inner beast or it will energetically eat away at your vital organs, causing constriction and reduced blood and energy flow, in turn causing extra stress from within. This will result in immune-response drop, bad moods, fits of temper and depression, as well as diminished libido.

A much more well-behaved way of giving the beast a dose of extra freedom is to take it out for a good walk. No little 10-minute shuffle to the shops, mind you, but a full-blown stride for an hour o'er urbanised hill and dale with arms and shoulders swinging freely and hips and thighs engaging, thrusting and stretching like a lion (or lioness). As you do, try the Taoist 'four-stage' breathing technique, useful for keeping lungs and heart under control during any form of exertion. Halfway through the in-breath, pause for a millisecond, then fill up with air to the top. Halfway through the out-breath, do likewise to create a four-beat rhythmic effect along the lines of 'in-in, out-out'. Time each 'beat' to coincide with your footsteps.

I know you'll immediately find 100 schedule-based reasons to reject this advice, but if you were to begin your day one hour earlier to effect the above ambulatory experiment, you would find your overall muscle tone improve within only two days, your breath capacity increase likewise, your mood improve remarkably, any errant flab fall away as if by magic, and your ability to handle stress grow appreciably. Anyone in the unfortunate position of being temporarily or worse, permanently, without use of their legs will tell you it's a crime to waste this near-incredible facility for self-propulsion or in any way to take it for granted.

You can turn off the mobile and fixed land line. You can turn off the computer. You can turn off the digital telly and radio. You can even turn off the fridge if you don't mind your butter going soft. But you can't turn off the ever-growing stream of obligations. And most importantly, you can't turn off your mind and energy. But you can relax, even for a brief moment every now and then, just by using your (own) mind to command your (own) bones, organs, vessels and nerves to let go of all unnecessary tension (because if you can't command it, who can?).

While relaxation is the best approach to whatever confronts you as you undergo your daily paces, doing absolutely nothing whenever at all possible is always of inestimable regenerative benefit. Giving oneself over completely to the doing of absolutely nothing is total anathema to many, I know. Indeed, it requires great yogic training for most to be able to sit or lie still for even five minutes without the body or mind fidgetting. But idling is an ancient art and one that's indispensable if you wish to stay in the game for the duration. Like those legendary cowboys of the Wild West and the ancient Taoists before them, we need to learn to kick back.

Your questions

Barefoot, I have darkness under the eyes - it looks like rings around the socket. I'm 45 and read about six hours a day. Never had this before. I wear reading glasses. Can reading do this, or stress?
VNS, Warwickshire

Traditionally, sudden appearance of dark rings indicates kidney energy deficiency often caused by anxiety and general stress, and it would be worth exploring acupuncture as a remedy. But it is possible that eyestrain is making the ocular region tired, causing local blood flow to stagnate a little. To relieve tired eyes, use your knuckle to massage around the outer edge of the eye socket (bilaterally), stroking inwards as you go under the eye and outwards as you go above it. Repeat 18 times at least four times a day.

fields.headline: Fry like the Eagle
fields.standfirst: From salted cod and braised goat to gypsy eggs... here's a second bite of London's Eagle pub cookbook, Big Flavours & Rough Edges
fields.trailText: From salted cod and braised goat to gypsy eggs... here's a second bite of London's Eagle pub cookbook, Big Flavours & Rough Edges.
fields.body:
Tortilla de Bacalao - salt cod tortilla

The name of this famous Spanish omelette comes from the word torta , or tart. The main difference between Spanish and French omelettes is that Spanish ones are flat, whereas French ones are rolled. The former usually contain potatoes, too.

Tortilla is eaten widely and often in Spain because of its versatility. It can be served hot or cold, in a sandwich or bocadillo, or as a quick tapa. There are countless variations on the basic tortilla, but one of the tastiest ones is made with salt cod. You could also use roasted red peppers, chopped spinach or, for a spring-vegetable tortilla, peas and broad beans. Recipe by Carlos Vargas . Serves 4-6.

300g salt cod, soaked (see below)
4 tbsp olive oil
4 large potatoes, peeled and sliced
1 medium onion, sliced
8 eggs, beaten
a few sprigs of flat-leaf parsley, chopped
salt

Put the soaked salt cod in a large saucepan of simmering water and cook gently for 15-20 minutes, until the flesh is beginning to flake. Drain and leave to cool, discarding the skin and bones while it is still warm. Heat the oil in a large frying pan until smoking hot, add the potatoes and fry for a few minutes, until golden. Then add the onion and cook for 3 minutes, covering the pan (the condensation softens the potatoes and onion). Once the vegetables are cooked, take them out of the pan with a slotted spoon and mix with the beaten eggs and flaked salt cod. Add the parsley, and some salt if required.

Pour out all but 3 tbsp of the oil from the frying pan and tip in the tortilla mixture, cooking it over a very low heat until it is set underneath and coming away from the sides of the pan. You may need to cover the pan to help cook the middle. To turn the tortilla, remove the pan from the heat, place a plate over it and turn the pan over so the tortilla is on the plate. Then slide the tortilla back into the pan and cook for 3 more minutes, uncovered.

Soaking salted cod

A good fishmonger should stock salt cod, or be able to get it for you. You can also find it in delicatessens and some supermarkets. Buy salt cod that is as thick as possible, without any yellowing, which happens when it has been badly stored. Wash as much salt from the fish as you can and then soak it, skin side up, in plenty of cold water in the fridge for a day. Change the water 2 or 3 times during this period. Even better, and quicker, would be to have a constant flow of water running over the fish, although I admit this is hardly feasible in the average kitchen. The fish should not taste overly salty at the end of the soaking period; the only way to check it is to taste a bit.

Tagliata - cut seared-beef salad

I have modified the original Italian dish with the addition of fresh tarragon - tarragon and beef being a favourite combo of mine. I also prefer to cut the steak after, not before, cooking. Recipe by David Eyre. Serves 2.

100g waxy new potatoes, such as Charlotte, La Ratte (Belle de Fontenay), Jersey Royals or Pink Fir Apple
2 x 225g steaks - forerib fillet (ribeye), sirloin or fillet
100g rocket
1 tbsp good Modena balsamic vinegar (but don't spend silly amounts)
3 tbsp really good olive oil
1 tbsp chopped tarragon
coarse sea salt or Maldon salt and freshly ground black pepper

Boil the potatoes in salted water until tender, then drain. Grill or fry the steaks rare and then leave to rest on a warm plate. Cut the potatoes into pieces. Divide the rocket and potatoes between 2 serving plates. Make a dressing with the vinegar, oil, tarragon, and some salt and pepper. Cut the steaks into thin strips, mix with the dressing and then scatter them over the salad.

Huevos à la Flamenca - gypsy eggs

A robust, down-home Andalucian supper dish. Recipe by David Eyre. Serves 4.

100g Serrano ham, chopped
100g Spanish chorizo, chopped
olive oil
1 onion, finely chopped
2 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 tsp paprika (preferably Spanish pimentón, which is smoked)
2 x 400g tins of chopped tomatoes
100g shelled peas or broad beans
10 new potatoes, sliced (leftovers are fine)
100ml chicken stock or water
8 eggs
salt and freshly ground black pepper

Slowly cook the ham and chorizo in a little olive oil for 5 minutes. Remove the meat from the pan, add a little more oil, plus the onion, garlic and paprika and cook until the onion is soft. Add the tomatoes, peas or beans and potatoes with the chicken stock or water and some salt and pepper. Cover and cook for 10 minutes - or until the potatoes are done, if you are using uncooked ones.

Divide the sauce between 4 individual ovenproof bowls, break 2 eggs into each and scatter the ham and chorizo over them. Then bake in a hot oven for 5-10 minutes, until the egg whites have set.

Porco à Alentejana - pork and clams, Alentejo style

Although it is from the south of the country, this dish is a great favourite with all Portuguese and, while the idea might sound a little wacky, I guarantee it will become a favourite of yours as well. It is typically cooked in a cataplana - a unique cooking vessel in the form of two copper bowls that are hinged rather like a giant clam shell, which can be used on the stove, in the oven or even in a fire. I invariably make it in a heavy saucepan with a tightly fitting lid.

The Portuguese would traditionally use tiny clams, but in my temperate island version I like to use well-washed cockles. You must fry the pork in lard, or the flavour will not be right. Recipe by David Eyre. Serves 6.

500g lean pork (leg or loin), cut into 2cm dice
500g belly pork, cut into 2cm dice
3-4 garlic cloves, finely chopped
1 heaped tsp paprika, preferably smoked
bottle of white wine
2 bay leaves
2 cloves
1kg live cockles or small clams
125g good-quality lard
75ml olive oil
1 onion, finely chopped
3 tbsp chopped parsley
1 generous tbsp tomato purée
salt and freshly ground black pepper

Mix the meat with the garlic, paprika, wine, bay and cloves and leave to marinate for 3-6 hours. Scrub the cockles or clams well, throwing away any open ones that won't close when tapped. Leave them in a colander within a large pan or sink full of cold water to purge them of sand and grit. This may take several hours; shaking them about occasionally will speed things up.

Remove the pieces of meat from the marinade and strain it. Melt the lard in a large frying pan, add the meat, season with salt and pepper, and fry steadily until nicely browned. You may have to do this in two batches. Pour the marinade into the pan and continue cooking the meat until it is tender - about half an hour.

Heat the olive oil in a separate pan and cook the onion in it with the parsley until softened. Stir in the tomato purée and simmer for 5 minutes, then add the cockles or clams. As soon as they have started to open, add the meat and cook, covered, for 3-5 minutes. Check the seasoning and serve.

Cozido de Cabrito - braised goat with rosemary, tomatoes and wine

Kid or young goat is a much-underappreciated meat in the UK. The texture of its pale flesh is not unlike milk-fed veal or spring lamb, while the flavour is slightly stronger. The prime cuts, such as saddle and leg, are good for roasting or grilling. Treat them as you would lamb. The neck and shoulder, or even a whole small animal, are delicious slowly roasted with wine and aromatics. This casserole makes good use of the cheaper cuts. Recipe by Trish Hilferty. Serves 6-8.

100ml olive oil
3kg goat shoulder or neck, on the bone
2 large onions, chopped
4 carrots, chopped
4 celery sticks, chopped
8-10 garlic cloves, sliced
500g tomatoes, chopped
250g black olives, pitted
2 bay leaves
a sprig of thyme
4-5 stalks of rosemary
450ml white wine
salt and freshly ground black pepper

Heat the oil in a heavy-based casserole, add the goat and brown all over. Remove the meat. Add the onions, carrots and celery and fry until golden. Add the garlic, tomatoes, olives and herbs, then return the meat to the pan and pour the wine over it to come two-thirds of the way up the meat - if necessary, top up with water. Bring to a simmer, add a good pinch of salt and black pepper, then cover and transfer to an oven preheated to 160 C/gas mark 3. Cook for 2 hours, then remove the lid and cook for another 30 minutes, until the meat is falling away from the bone. The liquid should be slightly reduced, the meat crusty and brown on top and melting underneath. Serve with potatoes.

 Nigel Slater returns next week.

Serves 4. 100g Serrano ham, chopped 100g Spanish chorizo, chopped olive oil 1 onion, finely chopped 2 garlic cloves, finely chopped 1 tsp paprika (preferably Spanish pimentón, which is smoked) 2 x 400g tins of chopped tomatoes 100g shelled peas or broad beans 10 new potatoes, sliced (leftovers are fine) 100ml chicken stock or water 8 eggs salt and freshly ground black pepper Slowly cook the ham and chorizo in a little olive oil for 5 minutes. Remove the meat from the pan, add a little more oil, plus the onion, garlic and paprika and cook until the onion is soft. Add the tomatoes, peas or beans and potatoes with the chicken stock or water and some salt and pepper. Cover and cook for 10 minutes - or until the potatoes are done, if you are using uncooked ones. Divide the sauce between 4 individual ovenproof bowls, break 2 eggs into each and scatter the ham and chorizo over them. Then bake in a hot oven for 5-10 minutes, until the egg whites have set. Porco à Alentejana - pork and clams, Alentejo style Although it is from the south of the country, this dish is a great favourite with all Portuguese and, while the idea might sound a little wacky, I guarantee it will become a favourite of yours as well. It is typically cooked in a cataplana - a unique cooking vessel in the form of two copper bowls that are hinged rather like a giant clam shell, which can be used on the stove, in the oven or even in a fire. I invariably make it in a heavy saucepan with a tightly fitting lid. The Portuguese would traditionally use tiny clams, but in my temperate island version I like to use well-washed cockles. You must fry the pork in lard, or the flavour will not be right. Recipe by David Eyre. Serves 6. 500g lean pork (leg or loin), cut into 2cm dice 500g belly pork, cut into 2cm dice 3-4 garlic cloves, finely chopped 1 heaped tsp paprika, preferably smoked bottle of white wine 2 bay leaves 2 cloves 1kg live cockles or small clams 125g good-quality lard 75ml olive oil 1 onion, finely chopped 3 tbsp chopped parsley 1 generous tbsp tomato purée salt and freshly ground black pepper Mix the meat with the garlic, paprika, wine, bay and cloves and leave to marinate for 3-6 hours. This may take several hours; shaking them about occasionally will speed things up. Remove the pieces of meat from the marinade and strain it. Melt the lard in a large frying pan, add the meat, season with salt and pepper, and fry steadily until nicely browned. You may have to do this in two batches. Pour the marinade into the pan and continue cooking the meat until it is tender - about half an hour. Heat the olive oil in a separate pan and cook the onion in it with the parsley until softened. Stir in the tomato purée and simmer for 5 minutes, then add the cockles or clams. As soon as they have started to open, add the meat and cook, covered, for 3-5 minutes. Check the seasoning and serve. Cozido de Cabrito - braised goat with rosemary, tomatoes and wine Kid or young goat is a much-underappreciated meat in the UK. Recipe by Trish Hilferty. Serves 6-8. 100ml olive oil 3kg goat shoulder or neck, on the bone 2 large onions, chopped 4 carrots, chopped 4 celery sticks, chopped 8-10 garlic cloves, sliced 500g tomatoes, chopped 250g black olives, pitted 2 bay leaves a sprig of thyme 4-5 stalks of rosemary 450ml white wine salt and freshly ground black pepper Heat the oil in a heavy-based casserole, add the goat and brown all over. Remove the meat. Add the onions, carrots and celery and fry until golden. Add the garlic, tomatoes, olives and herbs, then return the meat to the pan and pour the wine over it to come two-thirds of the way up the meat - if necessary, top up with water. Bring to a simmer, add a good pinch of salt and black pepper, then cover and transfer to an oven preheated to 160 C/gas mark 3. Cook for 2 hours, then remove the lid and cook for another 30 minutes, until the meat is falling away from the bone. The liquid should be slightly reduced, the meat crusty and brown on top and melting underneath. Serve with potatoes.  Nigel Slater returns next week.

fields.headline: Rage has not withered him
fields.standfirst: Nick Cave never thought he'd get past 40, but heroin and self-hate are behind him now. Married   and 'reborn', he writes nine to five in his London office. And his songs are better than ever
fields.trailText: Nick Cave never thought he'd get past 40, but heroin and self-hate are behind him now. Married and 'reborn', he writes nine to five in his London office. And his songs are better than ever
fields.body:
'As you get older,' Nick Cave, aged 43, tells me, 'rock and roll has the potential to be a really embarrassing, even humiliating, way to make a living.' We are talking, inevitably, about age and maturity, about the seeming inability of most rock stars to grow old gracefully, about the need to either reinvent yourself or ossify when you reach an age when anger and angst no longer seem like viable responses to the world.

'I really think the music I make now,' he continues, pausing to consider the connotations of what he is about to say, 'is adult music. There isn't any other word for it. And I really feel that the music I made when I was young is very different. It's a place I can't go back to, even if I wanted to, which I don't. I guess I just feel differently towards the world these days.' He adds, a rare fleeting smile lighting up his puckish features: 'I think it's called maturity.'

Nearly 20 years ago, when I was younger and wilder, and Nick Cave was a whole lot younger and wilder, I would not have bet money that he would make it into his forties, never mind be making adult music, which despite his late blooming maturity still manages to be effortlessly out of step with pop's prevailing mood. Back then, Cave was, to say the least, an extremist, both creatively and recreationally. Time passes, though. Things change. Even the wildest performers must mellow as mid-life encroaches, or, like Shane MacGowan, they become caricatures of their former selves.

Nick Cave, I am glad to report, has mellowed in the most salutary way: he seems focused, settled, still curious; his new music hums with what you might call a calmer intensity. He remains, though, a nervous to the point of twitchy interviewee.

Most popular musicians, bar those for whom the making of music is secondary to the pursuit of fame (and there are an increasing number of them, of course), view promotion as a necessary chore, and approach the interview ritual with a palpable degree of reluctance. Some, like Van Morrison, transmute that reluctance into a kind of combative surliness; others, like REM's Michael Stipe, maintain a detached Zen cool that has to be decoded before any kind of truth emerges. Cave is different. Cave frets. Grave and taciturn at the best of times, his answers, always measured and meticulous, are often arrived at painfully slowly, and with a cautious attention to words that suggests he has been misconstrued to his cost in the past. He has a tendency, too, to punctuate his sentences with a short nervous laugh that is hardly a laugh at all, more an involuntary spasm, a release of tension. Throughout, he shifts uneasily in his seat as if uncomfortable in his own skin. 'I cannot imagine that anyone actually enjoys talking about themselves,' he mutters at one point, and when I tell him some do, he looks aghast.

If his nervousness is palpable, and strangely contagious, he is simultaneously shy and gracious in an almost old-fashioned, unworldly way that befits a more reclusive calling, that of cleric or classical scholar, say, rather than a rock star. And though he has both spiritual and literary leanings (he recently wrote a trenchant introduction to The Gospel According to Mark for the Canongate mini-bibles series, has had two lectures released on CD, and published an acclaimed novel, And The Ass Saw The Angel in 1989 ), and would no doubt wince at the very term 'rock star', Cave is a rock star in the purest sense: a performer who has pursued his most primal urges, and unleashed, if not exorcised, his demons through often extreme performances and self-lacerating songs. A deadly serious and wilfully untypical rock star, then.

His pursuit of the heavens via the gutter began in earnest when he first arrived in London from his native Melbourne in the early Eighties. The dominant themes of his songs were the destabilising effects of love and desire, the prison house of the flesh and the primacy of the soul or spirit. These days, following his marriage in 1999 to the aristocratic English model, Suzie Bick, only the latter two concerns still apply. She recently gave birth to twins, Earl and Arthur, and Cave also has an older son, Luke, aged 10, by a previous liaison with Brazilian art director, Viviane Carneiro.

For a long while, though, Cave was rock's reigning melodramatist, a performer whose stock in trade was the articulation of misery, obsession and a particular strain of unnerving and occasionally liberating self-abjection. Back when the sleek and empty pop of Duran Duran, Spandau Ballet and the like was the soundtrack to the empty, self-serving Eighties, Cave was the rock performer as Nietzschean anti-hero, willing all manner of self-inflicted damage on his gangly, stick thin torso. Like Iggy Pop or John Lydon before him, he believed in the purity of extremes, in the pursuit of transcendence through excess. As lead singer of the Birthday Party - a bunch of like-minded fellow Australians, who remain the most implosively violent, and by today's standards impossibly dissolute rock group I have ever witnessed - he sang: 'I stuck a six-inch gold blade into the head of a girl,' and told an interviewer, 'Perhaps I'm emotionally retarded but I've just written about things how I felt them... things like revenge... there's something noble about revenge... something aesthetically pleasing about it.'

Every Cave song was a protracted howl of anguish at the world, every performance a conscious acting-out of the maxim 'that which does not kill us, makes us stronger'.

His offstage existence, too, was messy and volatile, an exile's survival course made all the more torturous by a burgeoning addiction to heroin, and a subsequent blurring of the already amorphous boundary between Cave's incendiary art and his life. Later, throughout the Nineties - as a strung out solo performer backed by an only slightly less dissolute and equally serious bunch of musicians known collectively as the Bad Seeds - he refined his subject matter and became a kind of bastard offspring of Antonin Artaud and Leonard Cohen. The cruelty and righteous anger of old was now tempered with a creeping melancholy that has remained a constant ever since.

Then, having finally kicked heroin, his adopted persona as rock's reigning prodigal reached its illogical conclusion on an album called Murder Ballads, where he duetted with a colourful cast of foils that included the aforementioned MacGowan, the equally obsessive P. J. Harvey and, unlikeliest of all, erstwhile Australian soap star, Kylie Minogue. In the press his name was romantically linked with Minogue, who became a muse of sorts for a while, even inspiring a lecture, The Secret Life of the Love Song, delivered at the Royal Festival Hall. He had a short but tempestuous affair with Harvey, the breakdown of which was alluded to in some detail on the ensuing album, 1999's The Boatman's Call.

On that record Cave executed one of the most startling turnarounds in recent pop history, suddenly reborn as a singer of slow, softly enunciated and often palpably spiritual love songs. As Simon Reynolds put it in his thought-provoking book Blissed Out: The Raptures of Rock: 'The fireball had become an ember.' Where once he raged against the world on wilfully profane songs like 'Fingers Down The Throat of Love' and 'I'm Gonna Kill That Woman', now he sang of the peace that passeth understanding on compositions like; 'Lime Tree Arbour' and 'Into My Arms'. The latter song, sung to a stately piano accompaniment, evoked a mood of almost hymn-like serenity. As well as having the best and bravest opening line of any recent pop song - 'I don't believe in an interventionist God' - it suggested a profound sea-change had occurred, not just in Cave's subject matter and approach to music but in his way of looking at the world.

It felt, in fact, like he had, literally and metaphorically, been born again. And, in a way, he had. 'All sorts of elements came together at that time,' he elaborates, running his long fingers through his mane of unruly black hair and lighting up the latest of many furiously smoked cigarettes, 'the main one being that I got married. I also made it past the 40 mark, and I'm always, erm, amused by that, if nothing else. Certainly for me, it was a cut-off point in some profound sense. Things fell into place.

'Before that there was always this tremendous sense of panic, the feeling that every song I wrote was going to be the last. It was not, looking back, a particularly clever way to live.' The underlying causes of this all-pervasive sense of panic are detailed in 'The Secret Life of the Love Song' essay, where he writes: 'My artistic life has centred around an attempt to articulate an almost palpable sense of loss that laid claim to my life. A great gaping hole was blasted out of my world by the unexpected death of my father when I was 19 years old. The way I learned to fill this hole, this void, was to write.'

The chaotic living, the drug- taking, and the violent but seldom cathartic live performances were, for a while anyway, another less focused symptom of this profound sense of loss. 'I don't regret all of that,' he says, matter-of-factly, 'absolutely not. I mean, I even had a good time for a while, and felt pretty good despite the way I looked. I was young and I didn't question things back then, I just barrelled along. What I do regret though is the time that I wasted. There was an awful lot of waiting around.'

He pauses for longer than usual, as if he has already revealed too much of himself, then, tentatively, continues: 'Because of the way I was living, and because every day felt like the end of things, it felt like I was just fucking squeezing the toothpaste dry. All the time. Then suddenly I got to 40 and it just became clear that, if I followed certain guiding principles, and didn't do things for the wrong reasons, there was no reason why I could not just carry on. With that realisation came a certain calmness and freedom.'

The new songs bear this out. They sound less frenetic than before but a slow-burning intensity and, at times, anxiety endures. You can hear it in places on the new album, No More Shall We Part, which is, intriguingly, a lot less calm and a whole lot less confessional than its predecessor. He is pleased that I have connected with this shift of emphasis. 'One thing I like about the songs on the new record, and don't like about The Boatman's Call, is that you don't have to know anything about the personal narrative that accompanies them. I find that confessional mode (he all but spits out the phrase) I slipped into back there incredibly difficult to listen to now. There is a school of thought that thinks the confessional is honest and courageous but I don't agree with that. I think it is the easiest way to write provided you are locked into a kind of masturbatory frame of mind, which I was back there. I mean, I was making a big heroic melodrama out of a bog-standard rejection by a woman.'

According to their author, the songs on No More Shall We Part are 'the most straightforward and accurate reflection of the way I feel about things'. Many of them, including the beautifully pitched 'Love Letter', exude an almost luxurious melancholy; some, like 'Oh my Lord' and 'Hallelujah' are filled with the biblical language and imagery that has been his main stock in trade of late; one, the blackly humorous 'God Is In The House', written from the point of view of an American, small-town, God-fearing fundamentalist, even reveals a late flowering gift for social satire.

All the songs were written over the past year in an newly acquired office near his west London home, where, he tells me proudly, he goes to work every day. Songwriting, then, has become a regular nine-to-five job, which is as telling a reflection of the new disciplined and rigorous Nick Cave as his heroin habit was of the unruly, uncentred Nick Cave of old. A man of extremes. In April Penguin will publish The Complete Lyrics of Nick Cave, a literary canonisation which has only previously been bestowed on a select few, most notably Bob Dylan, his long time musical hero. 'I had to sit down and plough through everything I had ever written from 1978 to now, in one day,' he grimaces. 'Page after page of this relentless writing which, on the page, was more amusing than anything. The early stuff was pretty ambitious for its time, but so depressing. It was like I felt I had to thrust everything down everybody's throat all the time to make sure they absolutely got the message.

'That's a fearful way to make music,' he adds, ruefully. 'It takes its toll.' He has come through though. And I for one say Hallelujah to that.

And No More Shall We Part is released on Mute on 2 April. Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds begin a tour at The Olympia in Dublin on 28 April, culminating at Brixton Academy on 5 and 6 May. The Complete Lyrics of Nick Cave is published by Penguin Books on 26 April

fields.headline: When Sue met Jeremy and Michael met Rory...
fields.standfirst: She knows MPs and moguls, CEOs and curators; her parties are legendary, and her only entrance criteria is that she likes you... Hilly Janes meets Carole Stone, the undisputed queen of the networking circuit and some of her 14,000 friends in high places
fields.trailText: She knows MPs and moguls, CEOs and curators; her parties are legendary, and her only entrance criteria is that she likes you... Hilly Janes meets Carole Stone, the undisputed queen of the networking circuit and some of her 14,000 friends in high places.
fields.body:
Carole Stone is already fretting about the venue for her Christmas party. Finding the right place isn't easy when you will be inviting 1,000 guests. Deciding which 1,000 is even harder when you have a personal database of 14,000 names to choose from.

Last year's bash was in a spectacular setting overlooking Westminster Abbey, and the entrance got so bunged-up that a disembodied voice periodically pleaded with guests to move further into the cavernous room to allow new arrivals a look in, rather like the tube in the rush hour. The only glimpse many guests caught of their hostess was when she stood on a podium with her husband, former ITN and Panorama journalist Richard Lindley, to make a little speech in which, as well as thanking everyone for coming, paying tribute to her beloved mother, now dead, and her Auntie Eileen, Carole plugged her new book on networking, her appearance in a BBC programme and her plans to extend her monthly salon to New York.

They may have caught a glimpse, however, of a few great and good faces: recent guests have included Jeremy Paxman and Sue Lawley, top lawyers Baronesses Mallalieu and Kennedy; Michael Portillo and David Milliband, head of Tony Blair's policy unit, and defence minister Baroness Symons. They might have rubbed shoulders with Rory Bremner, Sinead Cusack and Jeremy Irons, or chatted to Deborah Moggach and Sir John Mortimer.

You might be forgiven for thinking that Carole Stone is a pushy socialite, oiling the wheels of a metropolitan elite whose members orbit tirelessly around each other, but you'd be wrong. Carole is an exuberant working-class woman, a career woman who has carved her ability to get on with all sorts of people into a successful niche as a media consultant and the queen of networking. But she is certainly a phenomenon. 'Carole has filled a gap in the market. If she didn't exist, you would have to invent her,' says Will Hutton, chairman of the Industrial Society. Except you couldn't.

She may have been producer of BBC radio's Any Questions for 20 years and be on friendly terms with some of the most influential and powerful people in the land, but public school and Oxbridge couldn't be further away from her origins in Southampton, as the daughter of corner-shop owner and ex-army boxer ('Nobody messed with Nobby Stone'); a shy and gawky girl who, while anxious about her bulky 5ft 10in frame and big nose, desperately wanted to make friends. Her brother Roger, a schizophrenic, suffered from terrible mood swings and was pathologically withdrawn. 'The emphasis was always on getting him to join in,' she recalls. 'I would be so pleased if anyone did get him to.' She would bribe him to go square dancing - just one dance - with a coffee at the Wimpy Bar.

Sixty next year (although she could easily pass for late forties), putting people at their ease and getting them to join in is what Carole is very, very good at. 'I'm always weighing people up,' she says, her beautiful grey-blue eyes looking directly into mine. She makes a cupping gesture with her hands. 'I feel like a potter. I've always enjoyed getting the mould of people. You are always juggling with them until you see them respond and they relax with you.'

Carole began honing her skills as a hostess when she was a typist in the BBC newsroom at Southampton, inviting friends, colleagues and family to her flat for simple lunches. As she worked her way up the BBC, producing Down Your Way , Woman's Hour and Any Questions , her potential guest list swelled with the names of prominent public figures. When she left the BBC in 1990, disappointed that they did not see her as the answer to Oprah Winfrey, she carried on giving lunches at her tiny Covent Garden flat as a way of keeping in touch. It amuses her to recall how she fed the country's opinion- formers on 'TSLs' - tuna salad lunches that took 20 minutes to prepare and cost £4.19 a head, plus wine and water.

They still come to lunch, but now she is paid by half a dozen companies which retain her to introduce senior executives to movers and shakers from business, politics and the media. An agony aunt might find herself chatting to NHS executives; senior officers from the police could be passing the bread rolls to a commentator on race relations; the director of a museum might be sitting next to the people from Camelot. Carole always hopes to land 'a goodie, people who are accountable, in positions of power and influence - an MP, successful company chairmen or CEOs who are normally very, very busy'.

Making sure that guests are at ease and the conversation flowing is far more important. Her new book, subtitled The Art of Making Friends , offers excoriating examples of how not to be the perfect hostess. 'Sally [giving a dinner party] lets everyone sit where they want to. John and Fiona look dismayed to end up sitting next to each other (they've almost run out of conversation), and on her other side Fiona is sitting next to someone she hasn't yet been introduced to. Sally serves the soup, plonks herself down, then continually jumps up and down checking the cheese soufflé, which is the main course.'

At her monthly salon in her second, bigger Covent Garden flat, the entry ticket for the 50 or so guests is simply whether Carole likes you or finds you interesting. The throng includes personal friends as well as contacts, who, unlike those at the salons given by the great political and literary hostesses of the past, cut across the traditional divisions of class, race and age.

Carole's huge smile greets them in the hall, lined with framed press cuttings all about the hostess. 'Lovely to see you! This is Roger Levinson, professor of media and communications at LSE; this is Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister; this is Adam Faith, I loved all his records when I was younger. This is Bill Morris, leader of the T&G. This is my friend Sally.' Richard Lindley circulates with the wine and water, provided by Carole. But there are strictly no nibbles - they might get in the way.

Why is everybody there? Carole, with customary modesty, believes that she acts as a kind of short cut, getting people together who are so busy juggling work and family commitments that they might not otherwise have the opportunity to meet. A self-confessed 'people addict', she points out that those who have reached the top in business may not share her enthusiasm. 'They've got there because they are damned good at figures or strategy, or putting the deal together. But they are not necessarily good at the people business. In some ways, their position makes thing worse. They might think, "Because I'm chairman, people will come and talk to me." Or you often find that the star at a do is a little bit lonely because the other guests think, "He's too important to talk to me."'

Rosalind Savill, director of the Wallace Collection, of which Carole is a trustee, enthuses about the interesting people at Carole's dos, the kind she isn't likely to meet elsewhere. 'Carole has been vital in helping raise our media profile. We needed someone zappy and exciting who makes sure the Collection gets an airing out there.'

Geoff Dunlop, producer and director of Leaders of Society , part of the current BBC series The Middle Classes , has featured the salon in his programme. In a world in which the old certainties of male, upper-class-dominated social hierarchy have broken down, and the network has replaced the old-school tie and the gentleman's club, Carole, he believes, is an example of the 'new fluidity'. 'She is either the lubricant or the glue that sticks things together. She doesn't represent anything significant in terms of influence, or power, or control, but there's a kind of emotional honesty and directness about her that's very unusual in the context in which she operates, where everyone has a hidden agenda, everyone is looking over their shoul der and has a veiled, ironic distance on what they do. Carole completely breaks those rules. She is not like the types she's dealing with, and that's incredibly attractive to people. If you deal with Carole, you are not going to get stabbed in the back.'

And what's in it for Carole, apart from the consultancy fees? Why would anybody want to spend their days, weekends included, 'debriefing': topping up and updating her database, fulfilling promises to pass on a phone number or send out an invitation. Her husband queries her need to answer every single phone call or letter so assiduously, but she feels she must. A former president of the Media Society, she finds invitations to judge the New Statesman 's new media awards or stand for the committee of the Women in Journalism networking group irresistible.

'A lot of what I do is from insecurity,' she claims disarmingly. 'I've always wanted as many friends as I can get, I've never lost that feeling.' But her relationship with Lindley, whom she has known for 12 years and married 18 months ago, is mellowing her. 'It's silly and disgraceful that I still worry that I'm not somewhere I want to be. I think maturity will have finally hit in when someone says, "Didn't you go to so-and-so's last night?" and I say, "Oh, didn't know it was on, what a shame, I'll go next time," instead of going "Aaaargh",' - at which she doubles up and makes stabbing gestures at her stomach.

Dedicating time to writing her book has also grounded her. 'I have realised you can have a spare lunch and live. It used to be beyond me to sit in at lunch. If I wasn't doing anything by 12 o'clock, I'd ring someone up and ask if they were free. But I'll always like meeting new people. Even if we lived in Dorset and saw the same set of 12 people every other week, I'd still be busy introducing people. I'm not ready to give up yet.'

But what if a time comes when everyone wants to give up Carole? Agony aunt Virginia Ironside, who has been a lunch and Christmas-party guest, says she has nothing to worry about. 'She's an attractive character and she'll always make friends. Even in the old people's home, she'd be making everything go with a swing. I'd love to be in an old people's home with her. It doesn't really matter if your friends last if you have that ability. There's nothing odd about it, it's something to be envied, a gift.'

fields.headline: Going live
fields.standfirst: How yogurt can benefit babies. Plus, folic acid as a remedy for male infertility, and how galling fat can be
fields.trailText: How yogurt can benefit babies. Plus, folic acid as a remedy for male infertility, and how galling fat can be.
fields.body:
There can be few things more moving than holding a newborn baby, especially when, like Oscar, they're your nephew and therefore yours for the good times, but not the sleepless nights. Oscar has taken to breastfeeding like a duck to water, so it hasn't taken long for his weight to recover from the normal post-birth dip.

Breast is best for many reasons, not least because mother's milk contains a perfect balance of nutrients in an easily digested form. Breast milk also protects babies from developing childhood atopic conditions, including those that are rife in my family (we all have eczema, asthma or allergies). Indeed, it has a host of immunological and anti-infection properties, and babies who are breastfed for at least three months tend to succumb far less to chest infections, rashes and stomach infections.

One of the main reasons why breast milk protects against infections is that it encourages the growth of bifidobacteria, the 'good' bacteria that live in the gut, thereby preventing 'bad' bacteria from prevailing. It is particularly vital that babies' guts host high levels of them because their immune systems are not yet functioning at full efficiency. Up to 95 per cent of the bacteria in breastfed babies' guts consists of bifidobacteria, as opposed to only 25 per cent in the case of bottle-fed infants.

Recent studies also show that if you give your baby live yogurt (which contains bifidobacteria and lactobacilli, another 'good' bacteria) at six months and older, it can greatly reduce their risk of suffering from diarrhoea and speed up their recovery from stomach upsets and bowel disorders. As we grow older, the proportion of bifidobacteria and lactobacilli in our guts gradually decreases, making us more susceptible to the stomach upsets, food poisoning and other gastrointestinal diseases that 'bad', toxin-producing bacteria can cause. So as well as heading Oscar's list of weaning foods, live yogurt will improve his parents' health. All in all, a small pot of live yogurt a day keeps the bad bugs away.

While taking a 200mg supplement can help to settle a protesting gut, I also advise having a small pot of live yogurt daily, as the lactobacilli and bifidobacteria that it contains boost the immune system and redress the bacterial imbalance in the gut that is frequently caused by infections.

Nutrition news: Fertile territory

It's usually women who are advised to take a folic-acid supplement when they're trying to conceive, folic acid having been shown to reduce the likelihood of babies being born with a neural-tube defect such as spina bifida. Some new research carried out by Professor Ames of the University of California, however, suggests that men who suffer from partial infertility can improve the quality and quantity of their sperm by boosting their intake of folic acid, which, it appears, can prevent breaks from occurring within chromosomes.

Although the recommended intake of folic acid for women who plan to become pregnant is 400iu a day, there is no special guideline for men with fertility problems. If you are having trouble conceiving, however, I recommend that both you and your partner's diet includes foods rich in folic acid, such as green, leafy vegetables, fresh orange juice and wheatgerm-containing wholemeal bread and cereals.

Your questions

I have just had an operation to remove my gall bladder and am now receiving conflicting advice about staying on a low-fat diet. Can you advise?
Carly Jones, Harpenden

Now that your gall bladder has been removed, any fat in your diet shouldn't cause you significant problems because the bile produced by your liver will flow directly into your intestines, where it will help your body to digest the fat. However, I advise that you avoid eating a lot of fat at once, as your body requires a lot of bile to break down large concentrations of fat. It will now take some time for your liver to produce bile, and fatty food may sit heavily in your gut, causing bloating and reflux, or may irritate your bowel, causing diarrhoea.

Your body still needs some fat, which is a valuable source of fat-soluble vitamins and prompts your body to generate sex hormones. It is, however, important to team dietary fat with fibre-containing foods, such as wholegrains, vegetables, fruit, pulses and oats, because slowly digested fibre (along with water) in the gut helps to cushion the irritant effect of fat.

In addition, try to avoid nibbling fatty snacks such as crisps and nuts if you haven't eaten anything for a while, because while your stomach was empty, your liver will have been performing functions other than the generation of bile. If you are still beset by indigestion, drinking a cup of mint tea should help to relieve its symptoms.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. Please note that Jane Clarke cannot enter into any personal correspondence.

webTitle: The cost of... a hi-tech bachelor pad

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... a hi-tech bachelor pad
fields.trailText: ... a hi-tech bachelor pad.
fields.body:
Forget bare floorboards and halogen spotlights (so last millennium), what will really transform an average little flat into a penthouse suite are all the expensive electronic boxes you install.

Of course, home entertainment is a very male fetish: couples may choose a sofa together or discuss myriad shades of off-white, but generally only a man would care about the impedance of a hi-fi's speakers. And the good news for gadget freaks and couch potatoes is that the technology is becoming more exciting by the month.

Want to watch a film on a wafer-thin 50in plasma television hanging on your wall? Buy a £9,000 Pioneer PDP-502MX. Spend another £1,500 on a Ruark speaker package. Plug it into a £2,000 Yamaha amplifier and you can be bludgeoned by surround-sound home cinema.

DVD is to video what the Mondeo is to the Model T Ford and you can pick up a DVD player for as much as £9,000. On top of that, cable TV is a must or consider TiVo, a little black box that automatically records your favourite programmes. While you are watching TV it is continuously recording, so if you're interrupted during a crucial plot development you can rewind and watch it again.

Hi-fi obsessives (or audiophiles) have the opportunity to spend over £5,000 on each separate part of their hi-fi (CD player, amplifier and speakers - they'll probably throw in free cables if you spend that much) or even £55,000 on just a handmade amplifier.

No hi-tech bachelor pad is complete without a games console - if you can't wait for Microsoft's X-box then go for the new £300 PlayStation 2, assuming you can track one down.

Naturally, you'll want to keep in touch with the world beyond your front door, and the best way to do this is by computer, thus avoiding a painful and disorientating encounter with daylight. It has to be an Apple, and the top choice is the new titanium G4 Powerbook, a sleek, widescreen laptop. Given that you are prepared to spend a five-figure sum on your hi-fi, the reasonable £2,850 pricetag won't worry you.

Similarly, some company inside your pad would be welcome, such as the second-generation AIBO 'entertainment robot' or robotic dog. But the best investment you can make is in a decent burglar alarm.

Plasma television £9,000
Surround-sound speakers £1,500
DVD player £9,000
Cable TV £30 per month
TiVo £299
Lifetime TiVo subscription £200
PlayStation 2 £300
Apple laptop £2,850
AIBO robot £1,124

fields.headline: The perfect poker game
fields.standfirst: Al Alvarez, author of Poker
fields.trailText: Al Alvarez, author of Poker.
fields.body:
Play poker in Vegas because it's the only place on earth to have eliminated night and day. There are no clocks or windows and around midnight the casinos pump in oxygen to perk everyone up. The chairs are comfortable and the dealers are really efficient. Everything should be done so that all you have to do is concentrate on the cards. Develop what the Texans call a leather ass because sometimes you can sit for hours in the smoke-filled room.

And just as the game must be insulated from the real world, so too must the money. There's no conceivable way you can play if you regard the chips in terms of what they could buy. Big Julie, a famous player, once said, 'The guy who invented money was smart, but the guy who invented chips was a genius.' Poker requires finely tuned calculations and you can't do that if you're worried about the money. Frightened money never wins.

Money was no object for two genius players, Jack Straus and Eric Drache. I would play my perfect game with them. Jack is dead now, but they had wonderful intuitions about people's strengths and weaknesses. A good player will know another guy inside out, even if they've never met before. The thing about little games is that they tend to be full of people who only want to make £50. But people like Straus and Drache brought a kind of stylishness and wit to the game.

Poker looks like gambling, but it's much more about control than sticking money on a little ivory ball. A good game is an intellectual challenge, but the random element is part of the thrill. You get a burst of excitement every time you look at the cards. That's what keeps you playing until you graduate to the great poker game in the sky.

 Poker, by Al Alvarez, is published by Bloomsbury, £20

fields.headline: Green and pleasant land
fields.standfirst: Forestation of the nation
fields.trailText: Forestation of the nation.
fields.body:
I'm sure you agree with me. Returning from abroad by plane, the view of Britain from the window is one of pretty much unremitting greenness. You're not just struck by it but awestruck - particularly if you're flying into London. In late summer, it seems less like a city than a scattering of buildings over gentle, wooded hills.

Everywhere you look, there are trees. Big clumps of them. Long rows of them. Great marching avenues of them. Nor is this apparent greenness an illusion. London's tree population is currently 5.9m - about three for every four humans. If not quite a forest city, then certainly the world's most tree-blessed megalopolis.

Now imagine you're gazing down at the British landscape as it was 100 years ago. It's Merchant Ivory time. There are fields and farms, complete with water meadows, horse-drawn ploughs and crop rotation. When we sing songs of praise to our green and pleasant land, this is the Britain in our mind's eye. So how many trees do you see in that dreamy late-Victorian landscape? More, far more or about the same as there are now? Wrong, wrong, wrong. In 1900, just 5 per cent of the country was tree-covered. A century later, that figure has more than doubled. Even more surprisingly, a big hunk of that increase is recent.

By 1980, our tree-cover was up to 9.2 per cent. Since then we've not just offset the loss of 19m trees to the storms of 1987 and 1990, as well as 30m to Dutch elm disease, but achieved a 25 per cent increase in tree-cover. According to just-released Forestry Commission figures, it is now 11.8 per cent. In Scotland, the increase is even more remarkable - 17.5 per cent with optimists predicting 25 per cent by the middle of the century.

Paradoxically, this re-afforestation - reversing a process that took 6,500 back-breaking years - has happened over a century of unprecedented urbanisation. When our forebears arrived here in 4500 BC, they found almost solid wildwood. They weren't deterred. In the words of Oliver Rackham's The History Of The Countryside , 'They immediately set about converting Britain to an imitation of the dry open steppes of the Near East, in which agriculture had begun.' It wasn't an easy task. Our native trees are very difficult to kill. Nonetheless, by 500 BC, the very ancient Britons had cleared away half of them and over the next millennia, yet more trees were ripped down to build ships, fuel furnaces, provide space for sheep and lay the foundation for industrial capitalism. This arboricide may even explain why industrial capitalism first emerged here rather than, say, China.

Of course, there are contradictions within today's surge of tree-growing. We're still tearing up ancient woodlands and have only recently stopped overplanting foreign conifers rather than opting for native broadleafed trees. But overall the expansion in tree-growth is set to continue and probably quicken, helped by the greenhouse effect. According to Forest Research, climate change 'is likely to be beneficial' to British trees. 'Elevated carbon dioxide concentrations_ act as fertiliser_ and may reduce the amount of water lost by tree canopies.' Studies show young tree growth up 35 per cent.

So what does this woody boom mean? That we should use more wood for building and furniture. The current surplus of new growth over harvest is 30 times more than what we're using, say the Wood For Good people. And timber is a very 'green' building material. Simply, it locks up carbon rather than setting it free into the atmosphere the way, say, concrete production does. See, I told you my white-oak floor was more than just a fashion statement.

If that's what the boom means for the environment, what does it say about us? I found myself thinking of Ridley Scott's Gladiator . One of the movie's giant subtexts is the opposition between civilisation and barbarism. It's dramatised in the vast battle at the very start of the film - shot on one of southern England's new extra-woody hillsides. The Romans gather and organise on open land. The barbarians mill, disorganised, at the edge of the forest. The battleground is the boundary between trees and field. It's a classic conceit: civilisation ends where the woods begin.

Now, 6,500 years after hacking our way out of the wildwood, it seems we've decided to reverse the process. After all those years of making trees work for us,we're making friends of them again. In our hour of atmospheric need, we're turning to our oldest pals. We're re-embracing the forest we hacked our way out of. We've now decided, it seems, that civilisation begins where the woods begin. I still think Gladiator will scoop the Oscars, though.
