fields.headline: Balancing act
fields.standfirst: Peter Silverton knew something was up when his wife ate 10 meals a day. But they discovered she had Graves' disease
fields.trailText: Peter Silverton knew something was up when his wife ate 10 meals a day. But they discovered she had Graves' disease.
fields.body:
I remember the time when my wife could and would eat four square meals a day, and frequent snacks between, without gaining an ounce. 'Not true,' she said when I reminded her of this. 'It was three breakfasts, two lunches, three teas, two dinners and endless snacks and chocolate.'

She didn't feel the cold either. She'd walk around dressed like a Geordie clubber - T-shirt on a snowy day. That's Graves' disease for you. There was also a time when she slept 10 hours a night and ate nothing but the occasional banana, yet still put on weight. Graves' again. Whether gorging or starving, her muscles got progressively softer - despite long hours of practice for her work as a teacher of dance. Graves', too.

And there was a day she was banned from buses, followed by three weeks when she wasn't allowed within shouting distance of our young son. That was the treatment for Graves' - a shot of radioactive iodine (I-131). It doesn't exactly light you up like Chernobyl but it is potent enough to be a possible danger to strangers for 24 hours and to the developing body of a six-year-old for 21 days. So, long mother-son cuddles were out for three weeks - hard to explain to a small boy who'd just started school and often needed to come home to his mother's arms at the end of a testing day.

So she went away, first to her mother's, then to a dance course. 'Apparently, that was the worst thing I could have done. I should have done something very peaceful which would have helped calm the thyroid.' So not to your mother's, then? 'Exactly,' she laughed.

Graves' disease is the most common cause of an overactive thyroid - the 20g gland in the pit of our throats which controls our metabolism. In the words of the BMA's excellent booklet Understanding Thyroid Disorders (£2.49, Family Doctor), the thyroid 'is responsible for the normal working of every cell in the body'. It's a widespread disease without being exactly common - estimates range between one in 25 and one in 1,000. Many experts think it is considerably underdiagnosed. It's most common in 'women in the middle decades' - eight to 10 times more so than in men. It's not something you can catch, but a susceptibility to it is inheritable.

My mother-in-law had it. Her brother died as a result of it, young. Undiagnosed in life, his thyroid problem was revealed in his autopsy. As is often the case, an overactive thyroid had transformed itself into an underactive one - hyper to hypothyroidism. Untreated with medication, hypothyroidism can lead to heart attack or stroke.

In the 19th century, the mortality rate for the disease was probably 50 per cent. Because its symptoms are mostly just exaggerations of normal behaviour, it is often not spotted, either by the sufferer or their doctor. My wife's first symptom was the shakes. 'I thought it was low blood sugar. I'd eat carbohydrates - bread, biscuits, chocolate - and it would subside. So that convinced me it was low blood sugar.' This went on for years. A demanding physical routine meant discomfort and pain had always been part of her daily life. Also, according to a 1996 article in The Physician and Sportsmedicine , 'certain symptoms can mimic sports-related concerns such as overtraining'. So the way her system was playing up was far less surprising than it would have been to someone less active. 'My shakiness became so bad that my handwriting was affected.' Then her usually thick, strong hair thinned out and her eyes started to bulge.

At its most extreme, Graves' gives people eyes that look like they're coming right out of their heads. 'All the symptoms develop gradually, though, so you don't really notice it. But I do remember flying into furies at you. Things did irritate me a lot. I never felt calm. I had an inability to concentrate. I'd also become totally exhausted. It was a constant switch between being energetic and feeling drained. It was exhausting to do anything.'

As she's always been better at multi-tasking than focusing, I wasn't that struck by her loss of concentration. If it was more pronounced than usual, I suppose I put it down to the strain of overactivity. At the time, it simply seemed as if she was taking on too much. Now I realise it was probably a thyroid-driven hyperactivity. It was like being Mickey Mouse in The Sorcerer's Apprentice : outbursts of energy leading to profound torpor. 'Looking back,' she says, 'I can't believe I put up with it. I thought: this is what happens as you become older. The relief when I found out it was thyroid was huge.'

Eventually, she went to see Dr Bruce Fowler, the consultant who had uncovered her mother's Graves'. Dr Fowler's diagnosis was immediate. He put her on the standard medication, carbimozole, which serves as a chemical blockade on the thyroid. Her progress was checked by regular blood tests. 'The number of tablets went down quickly, to one eventually.' It's not a rapid process, though. The drugs take effect cumulatively. First, the endocrine system stabilises. Only then do you begin to start feeling stable.

Over time, she learned about the disease, progressing to knowledgeable conversations with her doctors about her levels of the relevant hormones - T3, T4 and TSH. Too much T3 and T4 produces a faster heart beat and increases anxiety. The thyroid is a switching point for the body's control of the three Fs - fear, flight and fright. Depression seems to be linked to T3 levels.

Oddly, the final touch of balance came with the birth of our third child - the boy she had to leave behind when she had the radioactive iodine treatment. I say 'oddly' because while some people are predisposed to Graves', it's often only triggered by major physical or emotional events, such as divorce or childbirth. Jennifer thinks hers was set off by the birth of our second child, a girl - so it is possible that the different sexes were having different hormonal effects. 'The birth itself balanced me out. But five months later, when I went back to work, the Graves' came shooting back.'

Till then, she'd strongly resisted the idea of a shot of radioactive iodine. 'But eventually, enough was enough.' Not before she'd tried just about everything else, though. Homeopathy, Chinese herbs and even, one dark Saturday night, a faith healer - the only time the disease caused a serious falling out between us. I'm too much a rationalist not to put faith-healing in the same category as strychnine-drinking - only less interesting. Medical practitioners are insistent that there are no 'natural' cures for Graves'.

The iodine treatment has been around since about 1940 and is perfectly safe - though about one in 10 patients requires a second shot. The amount of radiation used is small and does not cause cancer. But the procedure itself is scary. At the hospital I watched through glass as Jennifer was placed in a lead-lined room. The nurse left the room. She took a pill from a lead-lined box - this was the 400ml of I-131. She took the pill. We left the hospital. I drove her to her mother's, left her there - slightly radioactive - and returned home to look after our (nuclear) family.

The treatment worked steadily rather than quickly. This is common. The best study found that '20 per cent of patients required at least a year before they felt as if they had recovered, independent of the type of therapy'. But gradually, she once again became more the person she felt she really was. 'Carbimozole just suppresses the symptoms. Only after the iodine I-131 did my hair get thicker again and my muscles get their strength back.' As the radioactive zap puts thyroid levels way below the 'correct' level, this imbalance then has to be corrected with thyroxine - a synthetic version of the thyroid's natural T4.

She started out on 150mcg of thyroxine. Two years later, she's down to 50. 'It's still difficult to balance my thyroid, though.' You never really get rid of Graves', it seems. You just even yourself out, with a mixture of treatment, medication and lifestyle. 'I still need to achieve a more regular life,' she admitted - these past few weeks, her thyroid has dipped again. According to the Thyroid Foundation of America, 40 to 70 per cent of those who've had the treatment develop abnormally low levels of thyroid hormone (hypothyroidism) within 10 years.

Another major problem is that Graves' sufferers no longer know what is 'normal' for them. It strikes to the heart of our understanding of our personalities, asking awkward questions about our temperament. How much of the way we act and feel - or, more subtly but maybe more importantly, the way we feel we feel - is down to chemical levels in our endocrine system?

At its most extreme, it can completely distort a personality. John Coogan of the University of Michigan has written a soon-to-be-published paper on one victim, Sir Cecil Spring Rice. While ambassador to the US during the First World War, Spring Rice's condition deteriorated to the point where his dispatches to London became incoherent rants about an international German-Jewish-Irish-Catholic-Democrat conspiracy headed by the Kaiser and his chief lieutenant, the Pope. Despite being quite clearly barking mad, he remained in post till 1917. He died a year later of a sudden heart attack.

Nor is he the only powerful political Graves' victim there's been in Washington. George Bush had it, so did his wife Barbara. We know that it's a genetic thing. We know it's triggered by stress. We know George and Barbara's son has one of the world's more stressful jobs. Maybe we should duck.

Facts and figures

 Graves' disease was first noted in the General Hospital, Bath in 1786 by Caleb Hillier Parry, though his account wasn't published till 1825.

 It's named after RJ Graves, an Irish physician who reported it in an 1835 edition of the London Medical Journal.

 In Europe it's called Basedow's, named after another putative doctor-discoverer.

 According to Douglas S Ross MD of Harvard Medical School: 'It is an autoimmune disease characterised by antibodies against the thyroptin (TSH) receptor. A classic clinical presentation includes diffuse thyroid enlargement, exophthalamos [poppy eyes] and high serum thyroxine (T4) and triodothyronine (T3) concentrations with a high serum T3 to T4 ratio.'

Graves' produces low levels of T3 and T4, combined with a high level of TSH. 'For reasons that are not understood', says Ross, 'the immune system produces an antibody that stimulates the thyroid gland to produce too much thyroid hormone. The current guess is that the antibody is able to do this because it looks like the genuine pituitary hormone.'

 It is associated with the genes HLA (human leucocyte antigen) B8, -DRw3, -Bw36 and -Bw46. About 10 per cent of us have these genes, but only a small percentage of that 10 per cent will develop the disease.

Facts and figures  Graves' disease was first noted in the General Hospital, Bath in 1786 by Caleb Hillier Parry, though his account wasn't published till 1825.  It's named after RJ Graves, an Irish physician who reported it in an 1835 edition of the London Medical Journal.  In Europe it's called Basedow's, named after another putative doctor-discoverer.  According to Douglas S Ross MD of Harvard Medical School: 'It is an autoimmune disease characterised by antibodies against the thyroptin (TSH) receptor. A classic clinical presentation includes diffuse thyroid enlargement, exophthalamos [poppy eyes] and high serum thyroxine (T4) and triodothyronine (T3) concentrations with a high serum T3 to T4 ratio.' Graves' produces low levels of T3 and T4, combined with a high level of TSH. 'For reasons that are not understood', says Ross, 'the immune system produces an antibody that stimulates the thyroid gland to produce too much thyroid hormone. The current guess is that the antibody is able to do this because it looks like the genuine pituitary hormone.'  It is associated with the genes HLA (human leucocyte antigen) B8, -DRw3, -Bw36 and -Bw46. About 10 per cent of us have these genes, but only a small percentage of that 10 per cent will develop the disease.

webTitle: Observer review: The Falls by Ian Rankin

fields.headline: Uptown top Rankin
fields.standfirst: Rebus blunders marvellously as a bloody past haunts Edinburgh in Ian Rankin's The Falls
fields.trailText: Rebus blunders marvellously as a bloody past haunts Edinburgh in Ian Rankin's The Falls
fields.body:
The Falls
Ian Rankin
Orion £16.99, pp399
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Falls is at its best as a series of engrossing character studies. It is a complex mystery novel, as you would expect from Rankin, one of a handful of truly outstanding British mystery writers. But what is most fascinating is the interaction between the misfit cast assembled to help solve the mystery of the disappearance of the student daughter of an influential Edinburgh banker.

Central among these misfits is DI John Rebus, who holds the spotlight even when Rankin is trying to divert attention on to others. You watch with appalled fascination as he blunders on: self-loathing, self-destructive, failing to lose himself in music and booze, fumbling to forge a new relationship, terrified of even the thought of retirement since the job is his only salvation.

Rebus believes Edinburgh's bloody past is casting a long shadow over the present case when a wooden doll in a six-inch coffin is found in the missing student's home village on the edge of the city. With the help of a new friend at the Museum of Scotland, he links it to 16 similar coffins found on Arthur's Seat in 1836. They in turn are linked to the murderous depredations of Burke and Hare. (There is also a name check for Gil-Martin, a central figure in James Hoggs's dark Edinburgh masterpiece, The Private Memoirs and Confessions Of A Justified Sinner.)

Further, the student was involved in an internet role-playing game controlled by someone called the Quizmaster. Rebus's colleague, DC Siobhan Clark, is convinced that if she too plays the game, she will find the person responsible for the young woman's disappearance. The hi-tech Quizmaster plot strand doesn't really work for me. Rebus, decidedly lo-tech, is a denizen of a physically tangible, wholly believable real world. The virtual reality conjured up in the game pales by comparison.

This doesn't matter, because the interaction between Rankin's disparate group of prickly characters is engrossing. They include Rebus's old boss, The Farmer; the Farmer's successor (and Rebus's old flame), DCI Gill Templer, uncertain of her position so taking it out on everyone; and Siobhan Clark, ambitious but infected by Rebus with his loner way of doing things. Observing them ricocheting off each other is a melancholy delight.

One of Rankin's particular strengths is the way he can shade a character with just a sentence. Describing retired pathologist Donald Devlin, he says that he 'took his glasses off and started polishing them again, as if the world could never reveal itself too vividly for him'.

One character jostling Rebus for centre stage is, of course, Edinburgh itself. Several Edinburghs, in fact. The city the tourist sees, the one the romantics see and the one that Rebus sees: 'a state of mind, a juggling of criminal thoughts and baser instincts'. Once more, Rankin renders it in all its complexity. Terrific.

fields.headline: Loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: Stanley Spencer
fields.trailText: Stanley Spencer.
fields.body:
Sounds like a very nice, genteel, well brought-up type.
Actually, he's a YBA.

Not another Young British Artist brandishing dissected livestock, genitalia-strewn mannequins, and videos of themselves running round seaside resorts flashing their front bottoms?
In this case, more like Ye-olde British Artist; Spencer died in 1959. But he could still teach Damien, Jake, Dinos and Tracey a thing or two about stirring up a regular artsy hornet's nest, despite working in the whimsical medium of, er, paint.

How so?
His subject matter. Born in 1891, he was brought up in a devoutly religious family in the village of Cookham in Berkshire, where he lived all his life. He was prone to hearing voices and seeing visions, which went straight on to canvas in epic, teeming, and splendidly dotty masterpieces, such as Christ Preaching at Cookham Regatta and The Resurrection, Cookham , where the Son of God mingles freely with burly rowers and even burlier WI ladies.

So he had the sacred covered, what about the profane?
Stanley married Hilda Carline in 1925, but her devotion to Christian Science and resultant sexual abstention led him to seek a divorce and solace in the unsuitable arms of Patricia Preece, a fellow artist who happened to be a lesbian. Nothing if not opportunistic, she invited Hilda along on their honeymoon. The ménage inspired various self-portraits of the hapless Stan confronting vast slabs of unattainable female flesh, which are among the most explicit and defiantly unerotic nude studies ever painted.

What a fine mess for Stanley to get into! But what's the relevance of this tangled web today?
The artist's biggest-ever retrospective opens this week at Tate Britain and features rarely seen oddities such as the Beatitudes of Lov e series, which shows naked couples toasting crumpets on a roaring fire. As you do.

Hoxton Schmoxton!
In this show, Stan (with a little help from Hilda, Pat and Jesus) ensures that Cookham swings again!

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Marconi's turbulence
fields.body:
Marconi's turbulence

After last week's bloodbath, everyone is trying to spot the next profits warning. Stocks are being marked down on the suspicion of a slowdown and, in a crazy double whammy, on the confirmation, too.

Nowhere is this more true than in the technology sector, the cause of the week's troubles. On Friday alone, shares in the FTSE software quartet - Sage, Logica, Misys and CMG - were clobbered by between 7.6 and 13.8 per cent. The hit on Sage was exceeded only by that on Autonomy, given a 14.4 per cent kicking on its last day in the blue chip index. Woe betide any firms who actually report bad news.

So who's next? Trouble-spotters may want to take a look at Marconi, whose year-end comes on 31 March. The old GEC has firmly repositioned itself as a supplier of advanced telecoms equipment and is therefore highly vulnerable to cutbacks in the US and changes in sentiment.

The City consensus is that Marconi is in line to make £760 million pre-tax this year and £940m for 2001/02. With analysts under pressure from research heads to lop up to 30 per cent off forecasts, just to be safe, Marconi is highly vulnerable to downgrades.

Since August, the shares - now at 409p - have plunged by more than two thirds. Investors who reasonably think they couldn't possibly fall further are wrong. It's silly out there. Sell.

Safe in Halifax

So what, then, is there to buy in this market? Well, all things considered, Halifax, one of The Observer 's tips for 2001, has performed reasonably well. At 671p, they are down just a couple of pence in a rapidly falling market.

Since then results have come in at the top end of analysts' expectations and the former building society's bancassurance strategy is widely viewed as progressing well. Halifax has, of course, also snapped up Equitable Life, which now completes its coverage from the mass market to the very affluent.

As a result, broker Commerzbank has just upgraded its profit forecasts and set an 800p price target. Halifax is exactly the sort of UK defensive share to which the market will retreat in times of global instability. So hold on if you followed our New Year tip, and buy if you didn't.

High street hopes

WH Smith is another familiar high street name to have attracted a following of late. At 517p, the shares are now 60 per cent up on last October, when the newsagent went through one of its regular bouts of misery.

In latest research, two City brokers at least - Schroders Salomon Smith Barney and Seymour Pierce - think they have further to go. After many false dawns, WH Smith is, they think, finally moving into a growth phase.

The Frontline and Seymour distribution contracts have now been renewed, paving the way for disposal of the news wholesaling operation if the price is right.

Both brokers are also impressed with the revamp of the high street chain. SSSB puts a price target of 600p on the shares, while Seymour Pierce has issued a 'strong buy' recommendation.

Blooming Rose

If you had tucked Arcadia into your stocking before Christmas, you would have done handsomely. At 151p, the shares have now more than tripled since Stuart Rose took the helm last November.

Broker Société Générale, however, thinks the stock still has the potential to double over the next year. The former Burtons group is on track for a sharp rise in first-half profits when it reports on 5 April. And SG now thinks its £22.5m profit forecast may be on the shy side, given rising sales and market share.

The broker is a strong fan of Rose and his renewed focus on major brands. Buy.

webTitle: Innovative Smiths dodges traffic jam to get moving

fields.headline: Innovative Smiths dodges traffic jam to get moving
fields.trailText: Smiths Group had a lot to do to win back favour in the City following its unpopular acquisition of TI Group. Last week's interim results were a good first step.
fields.body:
Smiths Group had a lot to do to win back favour in the City following its unpopular acquisition of TI Group. Last week's interim results were a good first step.

JP Morgan, architect of the much-maligned deal, has come up with an elegant facesaver to help Smiths ditch TI's particularly hated automotive business. Car production in the US, half of the division's market, is stuck in a giant traffic jam and, until it is clear that the Federal Reserve can get things moving again, trade buyers are not interested and venture capitalists are cutting the price to such ludicrously low levels that even a desperate Smiths could not accept.

The solution is a demerger, with the twist that Smiths manages to extract £940 million in cash and preference shares, underwritten by JP Morgan, and will retain a 19.99 per cent stake in a business that may, eventually, be worth the £1.2 billion-£1.4bn that buyers were indicating they would pay for it just six months ago.

The reward for innovation was a 4 per cent rise in the price last week from 675p at the start of week - doubly impressive given collapsing shares elsewhere. But the City was also encouraged by other aspects of its performance, particularly the 15 per cent rise in the medical division, fuelled by things such as a needle with a built-in cover, which cuts down accidents when thrown away.

The industrial division also grew faster than analysts had expected, led by supplying small components for mobile masts and other bits of telecoms equipment. Smiths says there has so far been no sign of a slowdown in orders, but it would be foolish to bank on profits growing by 36 per cent indefinitely.

None of these had anything to do with the TI acquisition - they were both in the Smith stable anyway. But there was encouraging news on integration, too. Smiths was obviously stung by complaints that the £25m it was offering in synergy benefits was too low and has upped it to £80m within the next two years, with the hint that there could be still more to come.

But the real reason Smiths bought TI was to get its hands on Dowty, its aerospace business, both to boost its own product range and its customer base. Performance from this division was respectable enough but the synergies are still at the talking stage - it is putting in joint bids for things like the A380 contract. The test of the merger will be how successful that will be - and it will take years before that is clear.

Chief executive Keith Butler Wheelhouse is so confident he is promising earnings of 60p for the year to this July, 70p next and 80p the year after. That sounds dangerously as if he is joining the 20 per cent club, which ejected Rentokil's Sir Clive Thompson. His experience must make us wary of chief executives who make themselves hostages to fortune. But Smiths has a good enough record to deserve the benefit of the doubt. Buy.

Don't B&Q it

Sir Geoff Mulcahy, chief executive of Kingfisher, is signing up to the 10 per cent club. That is what he is promising in earnings growth for the next five years, should he succeed in hiving off the troublesome Woolworths and Superdrug chains.

If he expected the City to be ecstatic, he was disappointed. While earnings fell by 12 per cent last year, for the previous two years the increases were 23 and 16 per cent. While retail growth has slowed - the rest of the retail sector will struggle to achieve 8 per cent growth - Kingfisher's dominance in the UK DIY market through B&Q, its European investments and its forays into exciting places like eastern Europe and China were supposed to make it a cut above the rest.

Of course, Sir Geoff may just be trying to ensure he does not become a hostage to fortune, or leaving room to surprise on the upside. On the basis of last year's results, it will have to work hard to do that. B&Q remains the powerhouse of the business, and its position can only be strengthened when the new owners of Homebase start to take it more into furnishing and fabrics. But Castorama, the equivalent in France, is still having problems.

In electricals, Comet is going through one of its better periods but at Darty in France, margins are being squeezed although profits are racing ahead. In Germany, ProMarkt's dismal performance confirmed everyone's fears about the deal.

Then there is Superdrug and Woolworths. Sir Geoff insists that the plans for demerger are on track but the rumours of buyers for Superdrug continue to swirl. The problem is, a trade sale of Superdrug would leave Woolworths looking exposed. Its new formats, like Big W and the drugstores, sell many Superdrug lines and finding alternative suppliers could add to costs. Woolworths is also absorbing cash, both through investment in the traditional stores and in rolling out the new formats.

Superdrug could throw off enough to finance that: Woolworths on its own would be hard-pressed to do it. Sir Geoff would have to work to persuade investors that it is viable as a stand-alone business. But the venture capitalists seem unwilling to offer more than £700m at best, including £200m of property - less than the City has been led to expect.

Kingfisher's shares have more than halved from their peak two years ago but it is hard to see what will precipitate a real recovery. They are a hold at best.

Cuts no ice

Iceland's Bill Grimsey may prefer not to look too hard at the example of Kingfisher, not to mention retail 'recovery' stories such as Marks & Spencer, Somerfield or even good old Laura Ashley. What they would tell him is that, once profits warnings start, it is hard to get rid of them.

Grimsey last week added another to the two issued since the start of the year. And a chunky one at that: pre-tax profits will be £40m, not £62m, and the costs of sorting out the problems and integrating the Booker acquisition are £66m, not £34m.

Grimsey is confident that is the last of the unpleasant surprises and he can now concentrate on building a recovery. But perhaps the biggest surprise of all is that he expects trading to be flat for the next 12 to 15 months. Those who thought that Iceland alone was a great growth story and that the addition of Booker gave it an even happier ending will find that disturbing.

Grimsey's confidence helped the shares recover lost ground. More cautious investors will want to wait for evidence that he really does have the situation under control before taking the plunge.

webTitle: A gun at the MoD's head

fields.headline: A gun at the MoD's head
fields.standfirst: Defence contractor BAE says it will close down shipyards if Ministers don't promise to give it the orders it wants. By  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: Defence contractor BAE says it will close down shipyards if Ministers don't promise to give it the orders it wants. By Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
Defence is a nasty business. Normal rules of engagement don't apply. The buzzwords of mainstream industry - level playing fields, fair competition - have never sat comfortably with the business of war.

The relationship between the Government (constantly trying to equip forces at reasonable cost, balancing security concerns and maintaining strategically important jobs) and industry (dominated by the UK giant BAE Systems and the host of foreign and smaller defence contractors scrambling for orders) has always been tense. Now it has descended into an open feud.

The phrase 'blood on the carpet' was never more apt, and the most soiled piece of upholstery runs along the top floor of the Ministry of Defence's Whitehall HQ to the office of Sir Robert Walmsley, the urbane Chief of Defence Procurement.

Walmsley is at the centre of a vituperative spat between BAE and defence contractors, which accuse it of trying to monopolise the defence business.

BAE executives are known to have a jaded view of Walmsley, who has fought hard for competition against the background of a consolidation.

The row has broken out over shipbuilding. BAE, which owns 90 per cent of UK naval capacity at its Govan and Scotstoun Clydeside yards and at Barrow-in-Furness, has lobbied Walmsley to halt competitions on major orders, and submitted 'unsolicited' bids for MoD work to patch up its threadbare order book.

If Walmsley does not comply, BAE warns that it could close yards currently losing £3 million a month.

As Martin Jay, head of the smaller South Coast builder Vosper Thornycroft, says: 'BAE is threatening the Government and trying to hold it to ransom by saying it may pull out of shipbuilding unless it is given a monopoly. I hope Ministers will reject these outrageous demands.'

Others are equally scathing, but nervous. One US contractor said: 'It is difficult getting team members for UK work who are prepared to go against BAE. They say "you'll never beat BAE" and if they do agree they often ask for their names to be kept private.'

There are serious concerns not only about BAE's direct approach on the carrier contract, but about the competitive implications of its policy on shipyards.

One contractor points to merger conditions stating that BAE's Marconi yards must remain available to competitors. If Thales were to win the contract, it could place orders with BAEM - although it has also surveyed other British yards, including Swan Hunter on Tyneside and Harland and Wolff in Belfast.

But if BAE yards close before the carrier competition is complete in three years' time, that choice will not be available. BAE could then face a wrangle with the Office of Fair Trading.

DTI sources confirmed that BAE could be forced to continue operating or to sell on yards if the OFT judged it was acting anti-competitively. He added: 'Defence is a unique business, and you often get these threats and manoeuvrings.' Nevertheless, it is almost certain that Thales and others would press for investigation.

Officials point out that BAE has to keep Scotstoun open for Type 45s, whatever strategy is adopted, hinting that the MoD is used to threats to take work overseas, and is not convinced that this one is serious.

BAE, however, maintains it is free to close yards down, and is serious about doing so. But the story spreads wider than shipbuilding. Recently BAE asked that a competition to provide a £9bn new generation of 'airborne petrol stations' for the RAF be scrapped. It is competing against Thales and Raytheon, along with Rolls-Royce and other defence giants.

BAE's bid returned to the 1980s practice of cost-plus contracts. One of the competitors says: 'This blows BAE's cover. It's not about shipbuilding capacity. They want the competition squeezed and they want their own terms.'

US competitors have long found BAE highly skilled at lobbying against foreign bidders. One example was a highly charged bid for a £900m missile contract to arm Eurofighter planes, which a European consortium, Matra BAE Dynamics, won against Raytheon of the US last year. As one observer said: 'BAE skilfully forged a European alliance, which forced Blair to make a choice - Europe or the US. He chose Europe.'

But another pointed out that BAE's strategy is hypocritical. It is building US operations, which now account for 30 per cent of the business. BAE adds that producing long runs of defence orders brings economies of scale and allows improvements to be built in with experience.

That is why, BAE says, it is trying to change the rules on Type 45 and carriers.

Whether BAE's strategy will work is a moot point. As one senior industry figure said: 'BAE is usually subtle. It is not being so now. It is demanding an anti- competitive utopia, and the Government would be mad to grant it.'

Defence contracts are notorious for coming in over-budget and late. This affects several of those at the centre of the arguments between BAE, its competitors and the MoD.

Type 45 destroyer
Intended as a replacement for the Royal Navy's Type 42 destroyers, it will be equipped with the principal anti-air missile system, capable of protecting itself and other ships. The original plan was for a European destroyer, called Horizon, but this was scrapped. Type 45 is the British replacement, and up to 12 will be built. BAE Systems is prime contractor. Costs have risen by £21 million.

Future aircraft carrier
The replacement for Invincible Class carriers, designed for the Cold War, it will carry helicopters and a range of planes, including the future carrier borne aircraft.

Two groups are vying for the prime contract - one led by BAE Systems, the other by Thales of France. The project, worth £2.5 billion plus up to £7bn more on support work, is in the early assessment phase. Prime contractors are to be appointed in three years. The carrier project has so far been below forecast budget.

Nimrod MRA4
The new-generation Nimrod aims to improve anti-submarine and surface capabilities. BAE won the prime contract in 1996, and completed the first design phase in February 2000. BAE has run into difficulties on delivery dates and manufacture, which lay behind the £300m loss on the project it announced earlier this year.

Astute class submarines
GEC Marconi became prime contractor in March 1997 to design and build three replacement vessels for Swiftsure Class nuclear submarines. Design for the project is intended to be complete by 2003. The project has so far run £29m above forecasts.

Future strategic tanker aircraft
Three consortia are currently bidding to win the prime contract for this 'petrol station in the sky'. BAE Systems is lined up against Thales and facilities management group Serco. The project, worth £9bn, is to provide airborne refuelling to the RAF for up to 25 years.

The hard men who play for keeps

BAE Systems
Giant of the UK aerospace industry, BAE Systems is the second-largest defence company in the world. It was formed in 1977 through the nationalisation of the British Aircraft Corporation and Hawker Siddeley Aviation. Shortly afterwards it joined the European airbus consortium. It was privatised in 1981, and won military orders from Saudi Arabia. Later in the1980s BAE began an acquisitions spree, including Royal Ordnance and Rover, which it later sold to BMW. BAE was transformed by the £7.7 billion merger of British Aerospace with Marconi in 1999, creating Europe's largest defence group. It has expanded in the US - last year buying the Sanders defence business. US operations now account for 30 per cent of business, the UK 17 per cent. BAE has a £41bn order book and sales of £9bn. It has 60 UK sites and 39 overseas, employing 120,000. BAE is headed by chairman Richard Evans and chief executive John Weston.

Thales
French defence group Thomson CSF recently renamed itself Thales after the Greek philosopher. Headed by Denis Ranque, it is the second-largest defence contractor in the UK, where operations are headed by Richard Moon. It has 14,500 UK employees, most of whom it acquired when it bought Racal, the UK defence electronics group, for £1.3bn in 2000.

The company's origins go back to 1892, with a Franco-American venture to develop electrical processes, which accounted for the English name. It grew into the electronics group Thomson CSF in the 1960s. It was nationalised in 1982. In 1989 Thales bought the defence electronics arm of Dutch company Philips, and in 1997 it was privatised. In June last year Thales completed the Racal merger and divided into three groups: defence, aerospace and IT services. Thales employs 65,000 people worldwide, with sales of €6.9bn (£4.6bn) and a €15.4bn order book.

Vosper Thorneycroft
Compared with BAE and Thales, shipbuilder Vosper Thornycroft is a tiddler. Based in Southampton, it has supplied 270 warships to 34 countries over the past 30 years. It is headed by chairman and chief executive Martin Jay. It is a pure shipbuilder/designer with capabilities to produce control systems. VT's 2000 turnover was £274m, with pre-tax profits of £34m. It employs some 1,300.

Raytheon
One of the top four US defence contractors, Raytheon was founded in 1922, and its origins lay in making radio tubes. It went on to develop the first guided missiles and microwaves. By the Sixties, it was heavily defence-based, with 80 per cent of revenues from the US government. In the Sixties it expanded by acquisition into commercial marine electronics, publishing and oils and gas seismography.

Now, under chairman Daniel Burnham, it focuses on defence, and commercial electronics - including missile, surveillance and reconnaissance, satellite and simulator systems. It employs 100,000. Its 1999 sales were $14.5bn (£10bn), with an order book of $28.4bn.

fields.standfirst: With Vanessa, Jack Dee and Chris Eubank, it should have been a house of fun. So what went wrong?
fields.trailText: With Vanessa, Jack Dee and Chris Eubank, it should have been a house of fun. So what went wrong?

Celebrity Big Brother C4/BBC1
The Great Dot Con BBC2
Trouble At The Top: Searching for Sex... BBC2

If patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel, then charity is fast becoming the last refuge of the celebrity. The entertainment business has a long, and often noble, tradition of alms-trading, in which good deeds have been profitably exchanged for good publicity. For many years, in this country at least, it was largely a passive and understated transaction that amounted to a few pro-am golf tournaments, Variety Club buses for the handicapped, and the occasional appeal from Bruce Forsyth or Hattie Jacques.

All of that changed in the 1980s when Bob Geldof imported some of the aggressive urgency that has always been a feature of American telethons to galvanise public support for Band Aid and Live Aid. The historic success of those ventures in turn led to Comic Relief, which also has demonstrated an unapologetic willingness to exploit celebrity, by raising profiles to raise funds.

Up until now, any misgivings or reservations that cynics might have harboured about certain aspects of Comic Relief have remained largely unspoken. And there have been misgivings. Specifically, of course, Lenny Henry. Also the juvenile tone of 'say pants to poverty' badgering. But on a more general note, comedy can have no higher agenda than being funny, at least not if it wants to be comedy. And while not being funny has proven to be an irritatingly small impediment to the careers of most British comedians, it can be doubly irritating to see them hide their lack of talent behind a false red nose. Yet not much has been said for the very good reason that if money is going to worthy causes, then any criticism would be in the most literal sense uncharitable, not to say churlish.

But that was before Celebrity Big Brother. Now all bets are off and no holds are barred. We who have suffered - and my toes still ache from curling - can remain silent no longer. OK, nobody was expecting a programme that contained Vanessa Feltz and Anthea Turner to be a life-enhancing triumph. However, it's hard to recall a more deathly televisual experience than the nightly offerings of last week. It was as if that excruciating moment when a comedian dies on stage had been stretched out to last for days. Without a script, no one had anything to say of even fleeting interest. It was like prolonged ad libbing, only without the ad libs.

The concept was misconceived from the start. The key to the appeal of the original Big Brother lay in the transformation of private people to public property, anonymous contestants who were desperate to become celebrities.

In Celebrity Big Brother there were merely desperate celebrities: Feltz, Turner, Keith Duffy (apparently of Boyzone), Jack Dee, Chris Eubank, and Claire Sweeney (from Brookside). No change, no drama, no development. There wasn't even the voyeuristic thrill of gaining a peep into the inner lives of the famous. In part, because so minor was the contestants' fame that it generated negligible curiosity. But also because Feltz and Turner long ago nationalised themselves and placed their emotional utilities in public control. These are people about whose affairs and diets and breakdowns we already know far too much. Which is, no doubt, why they ended up here.

With its high walls and security guards, the Big Brother house really does have the feel of a refuge - a refuge for clapped-out celebrities. Forget the Priory, this is where you come when all else is lost, a home for last-chance entertainers. And charity, as we know, begins at home.

During her brief stay, Feltz did not stop reminding the audience that her confinement in the house was in aid of a good cause. Just as the audience could not stop thinking that the cause was Feltz's crumbling career.

Of the other contestants, all you had to know was this: Chris Eubank, the preening narcissist and absurd poseur, was easily the most charming. He rightly argued that the group allowance should not be spent on alcohol. 'Your drinking has given you an escape route,' he complained. As they were even less amusing drunk, surely they had a responsibility to endure the torture, like the rest of us, in agonising sobriety.

It was only really Dee who attempted humour (while Turner maintained an incessant giggle as a kind of soundtrack of determined niceness). Dee's role was inevitably that of the group cynic, but, like a rebel at a Church meeting, he was seldom convincing. Had he been genuinely barbed, rather than launching pantomime escape bids, then perhaps he could have been funny.

In truth, very few of the participants sheltering under the expanding umbrella of Comic Relief manage that. Instead, the protection of the red nose tends to have the opposite effect. Like the bore who informs you that he's going to tell you a funny story, it heightens anxiety by providing you with a sort of moral obligation to laugh. But rarely does it then follow through with comic relief.

Why ask questions, though, when the money's coming in? That, at least, was the attitude of the investment analysts who helped inflate the value of dotcom shares. The Money Programme 's The Great Dot Con traced the rise and fall of the e-commerce from 1994 to the present. It all started with Amazon.com, the internet bookshop launched by Jeff Bezos.

Bezos, an intense man with the unearthly countenance of someone who has spent many intimate moments with a computer screen, recalled the giddy days of the mid-to-late Nineties.

'We were growing so rapidly we really didn't have many hours in the day to be excited.' You could imagine him entering the words, 'Remember to be excited' in his palm pilot.

Plenty of other people were more actively animated, not least the investment analysts recommending that investors buy into dotcom companies. Like the so-called independent financial advisors who flogged dodgy endowments in the Eighties and Nineties, because they were on a percentage from the mortgage companies, the analysts were also paid by the banks to market the dotcoms.

All the same, the programme-makers erred in assuming that if they found a victim - a 71-year-old who had lost his life savings in the dotcom crash - there must have been a crime. The fact is that people, including the 71-year-old, invested in dotcoms because they thought they were going to make a lot of quick money. Even I, a man who can't deal with a bank statement, knew that a crash was coming. The reason people carried on buying, and the analysts encouraged them, is what's called 'mug theory' - i.e. they always thought there would be a bigger mug to sell to.

If internet businesses had ever coined money with the speed and imagination that they coined new phrases, there would be no talk of economic crisis.

Among other neologisms quoted in the programme were 'burn-rate', to describe the speed at which dotcoms got through cash, and my favourite, the 'fear and greed dynamic', which governs the urge to hold on or sell.

As it stands, the internet, for all its untapped promise, has succeeded only in selling sex. Going into e-commerce at the moment and not going into sex is like drilling in a well-stocked oil field for something other than oil. That is a lesson that 17-year-old Benjamin Cohen, the subject of Trouble At The Top, did not have to learn.

Having made a name, and a notional £5 million business, by setting up a website called SoJewish, the schoolboy entrepreneur branched out into pornography with the backing of his prim but proud parents.

'Money has no morality,' Ben told a doubting friend, and you just knew this kid could recite every Gordon Gekko speech in Wall Street. Ultimately it was a frustrating documentary that largely reinforced the myths that surround the internet. We never found out what it was that Ben actually did, apart from lie around on the floor in jeans and a baseball shirt, saying things like: 'I'm not the moral guardian of society. I'm just a businessman.'

At the end of the film, we saw him suddenly concerned that his shirt was a little wonky. 'I'm sorry,' he explained to his sidekick, 'but I'm a celebrity now.'

Yes, here was a boy who had said pants to poverty. And crotchless knickers, too.

Finally a note of geographical interest. If you come out of the BBC studios in White City and drive north, the first place you come to is Harlesden. If you drive east, the first place you come to is Paddington. On Tuesday night, BBC2 showed Heart of Harlesden and 15 minutes after that finished, BBC1 screened Paddington Green. Let's hope that Acton (west) and Shepherd's Bush (south) soon receive the docudrama coverage they so richly deserve.

fields.bodyText: Celebrity Big Brother C4/BBC1 The Great Dot Con BBC2 Trouble At The Top: Searching for Sex... BBC2 If patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel, then charity is fast becoming the last refuge of the celebrity. The entertainment business has a long, and often noble, tradition of alms-trading, in which good deeds have been profitably exchanged for good publicity. For many years, in this country at least, it was largely a passive and understated transaction that amounted to a few pro-am golf tournaments, Variety Club buses for the handicapped, and the occasional appeal from Bruce Forsyth or Hattie Jacques. All of that changed in the 1980s when Bob Geldof imported some of the aggressive urgency that has always been a feature of American telethons to galvanise public support for Band Aid and Live Aid. The historic success of those ventures in turn led to Comic Relief, which also has demonstrated an unapologetic willingness to exploit celebrity, by raising profiles to raise funds. Up until now, any misgivings or reservations that cynics might have harboured about certain aspects of Comic Relief have remained largely unspoken. And there have been misgivings. Specifically, of course, Lenny Henry. Also the juvenile tone of 'say pants to poverty' badgering. But on a more general note, comedy can have no higher agenda than being funny, at least not if it wants to be comedy. And while not being funny has proven to be an irritatingly small impediment to the careers of most British comedians, it can be doubly irritating to see them hide their lack of talent behind a false red nose. Yet not much has been said for the very good reason that if money is going to worthy causes, then any criticism would be in the most literal sense uncharitable, not to say churlish. But that was before Celebrity Big Brother. Now all bets are off and no holds are barred. We who have suffered - and my toes still ache from curling - can remain silent no longer. OK, nobody was expecting a programme that contained Vanessa Feltz and Anthea Turner to be a life-enhancing triumph. However, it's hard to recall a more deathly televisual experience than the nightly offerings of last week. It was as if that excruciating moment when a comedian dies on stage had been stretched out to last for days. Without a script, no one had anything to say of even fleeting interest. It was like prolonged ad libbing, only without the ad libs. The concept was misconceived from the start. The key to the appeal of the original Big Brother lay in the transformation of private people to public property, anonymous contestants who were desperate to become celebrities. In Celebrity Big Brother there were merely desperate celebrities: Feltz, Turner, Keith Duffy (apparently of Boyzone), Jack Dee, Chris Eubank, and Claire Sweeney (from Brookside). No change, no drama, no development. There wasn't even the voyeuristic thrill of gaining a peep into the inner lives of the famous. In part, because so minor was the contestants' fame that it generated negligible curiosity. But also because Feltz and Turner long ago nationalised themselves and placed their emotional utilities in public control. These are people about whose affairs and diets and breakdowns we already know far too much. Which is, no doubt, why they ended up here. With its high walls and security guards, the Big Brother house really does have the feel of a refuge - a refuge for clapped-out celebrities. Forget the Priory, this is where you come when all else is lost, a home for last-chance entertainers. And charity, as we know, begins at home. During her brief stay, Feltz did not stop reminding the audience that her confinement in the house was in aid of a good cause. Just as the audience could not stop thinking that the cause was Feltz's crumbling career. Of the other contestants, all you had to know was this: Chris Eubank, the preening narcissist and absurd poseur, was easily the most charming. He rightly argued that the group allowance should not be spent on alcohol. 'Your drinking has given you an escape route,' he complained. As they were even less amusing drunk, surely they had a responsibility to endure the torture, like the rest of us, in agonising sobriety. It was only really Dee who attempted humour (while Turner maintained an incessant giggle as a kind of soundtrack of determined niceness). Dee's role was inevitably that of the group cynic, but, like a rebel at a Church meeting, he was seldom convincing. Had he been genuinely barbed, rather than launching pantomime escape bids, then perhaps he could have been funny. In truth, very few of the participants sheltering under the expanding umbrella of Comic Relief manage that. Instead, the protection of the red nose tends to have the opposite effect. Like the bore who informs you that he's going to tell you a funny story, it heightens anxiety by providing you with a sort of moral obligation to laugh. But rarely does it then follow through with comic relief. Why ask questions, though, when the money's coming in? That, at least, was the attitude of the investment analysts who helped inflate the value of dotcom shares. The Money Programme 's The Great Dot Con traced the rise and fall of the e-commerce from 1994 to the present. It all started with Amazon.com, the internet bookshop launched by Jeff Bezos. All the same, the programme-makers erred in assuming that if they found a victim - a 71-year-old who had lost his life savings in the dotcom crash - there must have been a crime. The fact is that people, including the 71-year-old, invested in dotcoms because they thought they were going to make a lot of quick money. fields.headline: Don't worry, it's not the end of the world
fields.standfirst: Costner and the Kennedys emerge as heroes of the missile crisis, while Stalingrad is reinvented as a western
fields.trailText: Costner and the Kennedys emerge as heroes of the missile crisis, while Stalingrad is reinvented as a western
fields.body:
Thirteen Days (145 mins, 12) Directed by Roger Donaldson; starring Kevin Costner, Bruce Greenwood, Steven Culp
Enemy at the Gates (125 mins, 15) Directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud; starring Jude Law, Joseph Fiennes, Ed Harris, Rachel Weisz, Bob Hoskins
Malena (92 mins, 15) Directed by Giuseppe Tornatore; starring Monica Bellucci, Giuseppe Sulfaro
Audition (115 mins, 18) Directed by Miike Takashi; starring Ryo Ishibashi, Eihi Shiina, Jun Kunimura

Nikita Khrushchev, the brutal Ukrainian coalminer and statesman, once loomed large in all our lives. He's now a vague, somewhat clownish figure for those who remember his years in power and those born since then. He said he would bury us, then he himself was buried alive in the Soviet tradition. But history is likely to be moderately kind to him for his role in the denunciation of Stalin and for his sanity during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. In both this week's large-scale historical movies, Khrushchev plays a major part. In one he's an unseen player in a diplomatic poker game during the Cold War where a wrongly played hand might have meant the end of the world. In the other he's prominently on stage as a political commissar at a crucial juncture of World War II.

The film in which he does not appear is by some considerable way the better of the two. Roger Donaldson's Thirteen Days is an engrossing docu-drama relating blow by blow the Cuban missile crisis of October 1962 when Soviet recklessness in testing the resolve of Jack Kennedy's government after the Bay of Pigs and the Berlin Wall nearly precipitated a third world war. This is Dr Strangelove without the black humour and with a happy outcome, a film that seeks to rehabilitate the Kennedy brothers as inspired, idealistic leaders, and to get behind recent historical revisionism.

Virtually all the characters, from Jack and Bobby Kennedy (convincingly played by Bruce Greenwood and Steven Culp) to Major Rudolph Anderson, the U-2 pilot killed in a reconnaissance flight over Cuba, are real figures. As is the man from whose point of view the events are seen - Kenneth O'Donnell (Kevin Costner), the President's special assistant.

O'Donnell was a longtime Kennedy family friend, a Harvard sports star, an Eighth Air Force bombardier with 30 missions to his credit, and a member of the so-called Boston Irish Mafia, whose room at the White House opened directly onto the Oval Office. A Kennedy devotee who yet managed to be a frank counsellor, he wasn't exactly a nonentity, but he wasn't a key decision maker either, so he's someone we can identify with. Costner makes him a plausibly concerned observer, though he comes over as something more ordinary than the real life O'Donnell (he died in 1977 while still in his fifties) of whom Arthur Schlesinger remarked in his chronicle of the Kennedy White House, The 1000 Days, that he 'looked like one of the young IRA men in trenchcoats in John Ford's The Informer and had a grim, cryptic wit which could be devastating'.

The film shows the Kennedy brothers growing day by day during the crisis as they respond to events in Cuba, fence with devious Soviet diplomats, and fight off sabre-rattling cold warriors in the Pentagon and in Congress who advise a pre-emptive strike rather than a peaceful quarantine. The contemptuous attitude of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, stopping just this side of sedition, explains why Jack Kennedy was so helpful in the making of John Frankenheimer's thriller, Seven Days in May, about an attempted military coup against a liberal President. Sensibly, the movie deliberately avoids anything smacking of triumphalism.

Missing from the picture is any sense of what the crisis led to - apart from the American promise never to invade Cuba or destabilise Castro. Also absent, presumably for reasons of time, are the diplomatic efforts to obtain the support of Macmillan, DeGaulle and other free world leaders, as well as the reactions of critics from outside government.

One notable aspect of Thirteen Days is the role of women in the early Sixties. They're there to watch and wait, like the mother of O'Donnell's five children and Jackie Kennedy, who appears on screen only to be rebuked by O'Donnell for trying to invite politically uninfluential people to a party. The nearest woman to power is Kennedy's secretary Evelyn Lincoln, who does a lot of typing, but there isn't a woman 'in the loop' - to employ a phrase they use in the movie though it was not, I think, current back in 1962.

According to Khrushchev's memoirs, Stalin regularly showed contraband American films to specially invited audiences in the Kremlin. 'He liked cowboy movies especially,' Khrushchev recalled. 'He used to curse them and give them the proper ideological evaluation but then immediately order new ones.' He would therefore have been torn apart by Jean-Jacques Annaud's Enemy at the Gates which is in effect the western Shane (released the year Stalin died) superimposed on the 1942 battle for Stalingrad.

Enemy at the Gates has a devastating opening 20 minutes as an ill-equipped, inexperienced infantry battalion is dragged off a train, transported across the Volga under heavy German fire and thrown into the fray. Any soldier jumping into the river is immediately shot by the political officers, who shortly thereafter machine-gun any Soviet troops who retreat in the face of overwhelming enemy fire in the hellish, shattered Stalingrad. Then in comes Stalin's emissary Khrushchev (a prosthetically enhanced Bob Hoskins) to compel the commanding Russian general to commit suicide to encourage the others. Never has the word comrade been used so often and meant so little.

Thereafter matters of strategy and leadership are largely ignored on both sides in this movie made in a German studio by French film-makers with British and American actors in the leading roles, speaking in a variety of accents. Like a dime novelist turning a western gunfighter into a legendary figure, the political officer Danilov (Joseph Fiennes), chief writer for the Red Army newspaper, transforms the ace sniper Vassili Zaitsev (Jude Law), a semi-literate shepherd boy, into a morale-boosting national hero. Vassili was indeed a real soldier and a brilliant shot whom the Soviet authorities aggrandised to personalise the war. What is pure myth, however, is that to counter him, the German invaders brought in Major Konig (Ed Harris), the suave head of the Wehrmacht's sniper training school. Like Wilson, the gunman played by Jack Palance in Shane, Konig arrives in grand style and wearing black gloves. The encounter between Vassili and Konig is characterised by Danilov as 'the essence of the class struggle' - the marksmen as Marxmen, as it were.

There are some exciting shoot-outs between the pair in the stylised rubble of Stalingrad but there are also endless longueurs. Several of the latter involve a Jewish girl soldier (Rachel Weisz) who helps create a half-hearted triangular affair between Danilov, who's also a Jew, and Vassili, the sniper from the Urals with the Estuary accent. As always, Ed Harris enlivens every scene in which he appears.

Written and directed by Giuseppe Tornatore, Malena is - like his most celebrated picture Nuovo Cinema Paradiso - a lyrical, nostalgic, deeply sentimental coming-of-age story set in his native Sicily. The movie begins in 1941 on the day Il Duce declares war on Britain and France and the 13-year-old Renato Amoroso (Giuseppe Sulfaro) gets his first bike. It's also the day that the beautiful Malena Scordia (Monica Bellucci), wife of an army officer serving abroad, struts her stuff though the small town of Castelcuto in a tight white dress, causing male groins to twitch lustfully and female tongues to wag enviously.

To the strains of a lush Ennio Morricone score, Renato develops an obsessional love for Malena, spying on her, stealing her knickers, masturbating as he imagines playing opposite her in movies as Tarzan, a gladiator, a blind suitor. His parents take him to a doctor, a priest, an exorcist and a brothel in their attempts to cure him. The German troops come and go, the Americans arrive to the strains of 'In the Mood', Malena is punished as a Nazi collaborator by the vindictive, guilt-ridden townsfolk, but still Renato's love goes on.

This sort of tale was told better, though not especially well, in Robert Mulligan's Summer of 42, about an American teenager fixated on a lovely war widow in World War II. That too had a swooningly romantic, Oscar-nominated score - by Michel Legrand. If Morricone gets an Oscar next Sunday for this movie it will be to make up for the statuette he ought to have won for Once Upon a Time in the West or The Mission.

In Miike Takashi's Audition, an odd cross between Misery and Ai No Corrida, a Japanese widower in search of a young bride conspires with a movie-producer chum to stage fake auditions for a film about an affair between a dancer and a Down's syndrome boy. The mysterious girl he selects for her beauty, passivity and intelligence turns out to be the stuff of nightmares rather than dreams. But is she a sadistic serial killer seeking revenge for an abusive childhood or is she the fantasy projection of the widower's guilty feelings? Either way the picture, which for much of its way is an intriguing thriller, culminates in a peculiarly repellent torture scene calculated to make audiences flinch, shut their eyes or make for the exit.

fields.headline: Two of a kind
fields.standfirst: Sue Webster reviews more restaurants which share a name
fields.trailText: Sue Webster reviews more restaurants which share a name.
fields.body:
The Greenhouse 27A Hays Mews, London W1 (020 7499 3314).
Like Sir Terence, Joe Levin has a little empire of hotels and restaurants (most notably the Capital in Knightsbridge), but he has no intention of 'rolling out' the Greenhouse 'brand'. In fact he's slightly sheepish about the name, revealing that a major re-furb this summer will not only lighten the interior, but also add water to the garden and more greenery to appease guests who point out the lack of horticultural artefacts. A bigger bar will please Mayfair drinkers. Meanwhile, Madagascan-born chef Paul Merett continues to charm with his subtle spicing of British dishes.

The Greenhouse 331 Great Western Street, Manchester (0161 224 0730).
Previously a greasy spoon called the Cosy Café, this intimate eatery has been a purveyor of vegetarian food since 1983. It has had a few problems of late and had to close down for a few days due to lack of funds, but the staff display a wartime spirit and are determined not to change their meatless menu. They offer no fewer than 100 dishes of all persuasions, from Spanish chickpeas to vegetable samosas and stuffed aubergines to chimi changa. Locals admire the atmosphere, organic wines and excellent value - 'You can eat 'til you're sick for a tenner.'

The Light House 75-77 Ridgway, London SW19 (020 8944 6338).
Not a rocky coast in sight in leafy Wimbledon, of course, but the super-bright, white minimalist interior (with big, big windows) means this year-old restaurant lives up to its name - and besides, it stands on a site which used to be a lighting shop. The chef is Italian, but his cooking exemplifies fusion cuisine as we have come to know and love it. Indeed it's best not to start on the New World wines before you've studied the menu, otherwise you'll be struggling to recall what blue fin tuna tataki or green tea semi-freddo might be. Whatever it is, it tastes brilliant.

The Lighthouse 77 High Street, Aldeburgh, Suffolk (01728 453 377).
Six years ago, when they opened this acclaimed, bistro-style, fish restaurant, owners Peter and Sarah Hill had 'a brainstorming session' and decided that since Suffolk's trendiest seaside town lacked only a lighthouse, they 'would give it one'. Now, it's hard to get in without booking, yet the food remains as deceptively simple as ever: locally caught Dover soles in lemon and butter, skate with blackened butter and capers, bread-and-butter pudding made with brioche, marmalade and whisky. Delicious!

Locals admire the atmosphere, organic wines and excellent value - 'You can eat 'til you're sick for a tenner.' The Light House 75-77 Ridgway, London SW19 (020 8944 6338). Not a rocky coast in sight in leafy Wimbledon, of course, but the super-bright, white minimalist interior (with big, big windows) means this year-old restaurant lives up to its name - and besides, it stands on a site which used to be a lighting shop. The chef is Italian, but his cooking exemplifies fusion cuisine as we have come to know and love it. Indeed it's best not to start on the New World wines before you've studied the menu, otherwise you'll be struggling to recall what blue fin tuna tataki or green tea semi-freddo might be. Whatever it is, it tastes brilliant. The Lighthouse 77 High Street, Aldeburgh, Suffolk (01728 453 377). Six years ago, when they opened this acclaimed, bistro-style, fish restaurant, owners Peter and Sarah Hill had 'a brainstorming session' and decided that since Suffolk's trendiest seaside town lacked only a lighthouse, they 'would give it one'. Now, it's hard to get in without booking, yet the food remains as deceptively simple as ever: locally caught Dover soles in lemon and butter, skate with blackened butter and capers, bread-and-butter pudding made with brioche, marmalade and whisky. Delicious!

webTitle: Wheels: My other car is a 15-year-old Golf

fields.headline: My other car is a 15-year-old Golf
fields.standfirst: The Lexus RX300 SE doesn't smell of tandoori and can accelerate up hills, no wonder Harriet Lane is impressed
fields.trailText: The Lexus RX300 SE doesn't smell of tandoori and can accelerate up hills, no wonder Harriet Lane is impressed.
fields.body:
Lexus RX300 SE
Price £32,550
Insurance group 15E
MPG 21.7
Engine size 2995cc
Max speed 112mph
0-62mph 9.2 seconds
Driven wheels 4

It's dark and we're lost. Really lost. 'In 50 metres, turn left, and continue along this road for 200 metres,' commands the lady in the the dashboard, silkily enunciating her 't's; and, naturally, we obey. Well, I say 'we' do, but in fact, as I can't drive (I much prefer being chauffeured around and being shielded from road rage - my own), the husband is at the wheel, and he's thrilled to turn left, primarily because the 15-year-old Rustbucket left behind at home is seriously short on power-steering. The Lexus crunches down a very narrow, very dark road. Ahead of us, the moon, which is wrapped in shreds of cloud like a yolk in albumen, suddenly gleams off the sea. Can this be right? Wumph! The Lexus abruptly drops a foot. Water flies up over the windscreen. There is a scream which might have come from me.

'Are you sure this is the right way?' I ask a moment later, not meaning to be annoying, while hammering away at the 'Voice' button on the dashboard (more polished dark wood than a Victorian parlour). The lady in the DVD Lexus Navigator system speaks again: calm, authoritative, and evidently not in full possession of the facts. 'Continue on this road for 100 metres. Your destination is on your right,' she says as water sluices over the windows. Wumph! Wumph! Is this really a road, or are we journeying along the bottom of the English Channel? We assume that we are driving out to sea on a jetty, and are debating how we're going to reverse the RX300 back on to dry land when the lights of the hotel appear, twinkling away just ahead of us.

In her wisdom, the lady in the dash has chosen to send us to the hotel via an unmapped shortcut, down the very road - a coastal strip of knackered tarmac poured over railway sleepers, just after torrential rainstorms and high tide - which would best showcase the 4x4 we'd borrowed for the weekend. Were it not for the extraordinary springs (suspension, I believe the experts call 'em), we'd be mashed all over the the ceiling by now. 'Wow,' breathes my husband, pulling up at our destination and regretfully switching off the engine. Comparisons with my map-reading skills are certainly being drawn, so I point out that, unlike the Navigator system, I don't cost £2,340 (including VAT).

As a passenger, I know what I want in a car. I want a heater that doesn't smell of tandoori, a functioning radio and an engine that can actually accelerate up hills. And that's about it. The Lexus RX300 SE fits the bill on this and many other counts. As well as an on-board computer with insider knowledge of every rope bridge and high wire in the kingdom, it also comes equipped with ivory leather seats, a moon roof (which looks very much like a sun roof), a boot the size of Rutland, a six-disc CD player, lushly impractical cream carpet in the footwell, and more cupholders than a very thirsty octopus could shake a bendy straw at.

Knowledgeable types explain that the Lexus RX300 is a curious hybrid of off-roader and people-carrier - and yes, I can see that it doesn't look much like either a box or a balloon. To me, it looks like a big, tall, curvy, muscular way of spending £32,550. You step up into it, fill your lungs with Essence of Bond Street Handbag Shop, and find yourself being eyeballed by cabbies and truckers. They aren't the only people who are interested. A kid on our street pointed the RX300 out to his mum, and the chap in the Lexus saloon next to us on the motorway was so fascinated that he kept veering into our lane. He vroomed off in disgust when it became apparent that we didn't know the secret sign that Lexus owners make to each other. (If 2CV owners give each other cheery proley waves, perhaps Lexus drivers flex imaginary plastic between their thumb and index fingers?)

In fact, the leathery smell is a little overpowering when you're locked in with it, with warm air pouring out of the heaters. But there is a solution. When the next day dawned crisp and sunny, we found that nothing could be nicer than driving around with the moon roof wide open and the button that controls the seat temperature switched right up to 'hot'. Cold face, toasty body: perfect. The seats are in fact so adjustable - seesawing this way and that, with lumbar rolls popping out and shrinking away at the touch of a button - that there is a temptation to ride them as John Travolta rode his mechanical rodeo bull in Urban Cowboy . Indeed, you can busy yourself with the three buttons that electronically control the angles of your seat - all the way from Hepplewhite to Business Class slumber-pod - and find that a quarter of an hour has slipped by. I mean, you might be the sort of person who'd choose to occupy 15 minutes in that way. Not that we had time to waste like that, or anything.

The shingle and floods around Romney Marsh were bread and milk for the Lexus. It ate up the steepest dunes, muddiest roads and deepest fords we could find. The husband heaved little sighs whenever the lights turned green, murmuring about 'confident acceleration' - something the Rustbucket said goodbye to a decade ago. Since we've got into the habit of always building an extra 20 minutes into journeys, to make sure the Rustbucket has enough time to start, we found ourselves arriving everywhere early, which gave us the opportunity to fiddle around some more with the seats - I mean, really familiarise ourselves with the Romney Marsh churches.

Back in London, and the husband morosely dragged himself from the driving seat. 'The Golf's crying,' he said, unkindly. 'I can see the tears squeezing out of its headlights.' As he bade farewell to the Lexus, I was reminded of some old movie starring Celia Johnson and Trevor Howard. How odd that whenever he popped out that evening, to post a letter or buy a pint of milk, I could hear the engine being switched on. Who am I kidding? I miss it, too. Here's a hint to anyone who has ever nagged me to learn to drive. I'll do it if you buy me a Lexus 4x4.
