fields.headline: Blood and chocolate
fields.standfirst: As Belfast struggles to reinvent itself, the Troubles still haunt its people and its artists. Sean O'Hagan has put together a show that unites politics and culture - including an AK47 that's good enough to eat
fields.trailText: As Belfast struggles to reinvent itself, the Troubles still haunt its people and its artists. Sean O'Hagan has put together a show that unites politics and culture - including an AK47 that's good enough to eat
fields.body:
A few months ago, I received a strange postcard from home. It looked, at first glance, like one of those composite images of an impossibly Oirish Ireland, all green hills, blooming flowers and blue skies. Except that it had the words 'Castles of the Border' across the centre and, on closer inspection, the blossoms foregrounded snapshots of four British army hill forts, those foreboding watchtowers that loom ominously above the border lands around south Armagh. On the postcard, though, set in these impossibly idealised settings, they looked almost quaint.

This piece of art provocation, it turned out, came from a mysterious individual called John Byrne, a Belfast-born artist whose latest incarnation is The Border Worrier. Byrne has chosen the Irish border, literally and metaphorically, as the locus for all his anxieties and obsessions about his divided self, as the starting point for an often surreal investigation of his Northern Irishness. He is, as artists tend to be, a true obsessive. Recently, for a month, he created a mock Border Interpretive Centre in a breeze-block hut on a layby between Newry and Dundalk, where the actual border invisibly bisects the main road from the north to the south of the island. He had a local comedian open the centre, sold sticks of border rock and held various exhibitions of border paraphernalia, including bags of soil and various examples of border litter - discarded crisp packets and the like.

Byrne's work is slightly mad but strangely instructive: art that questions our assumptions about, among other things, the theme-park Ireland pushed by the burgeoning heritage industry, the divided Ireland of Republican mythology, and the abiding absurdity of this amorphous, meandering line on the landscape that most of us give little thought to any more, but which, as recent history attests, means so much.

Last week, I received another surreal image in the post - a photograph of a Kalashnikov rifle, the weapon of choice for terrorists/freedom fighters the world over, and a gun whose urgent retort I probably heard as an adolescent growing up on a Republican housing estate in Armagh. (There were even some local youths who claimed to be able to tell the difference between the Armalites and Kalashnikovs used by the Provisional IRA, and the SLR used by the British army, just by the sound they made.) This particular Kalashnikov, though, was made of chocolate. It had been cast and moulded, actual size, from the real thing by Belfast-based artist Rita Duffy (who, unsurprisingly, is remaining mysteriously tight-lipped about her sources). It is a quintessentially Northern Irish art piece that again manages to be simultaneously surreal and deadly serious, darkly humorous and deeply disturbing. (The chocolate, by the way, was made in Portadown, though it is not, as far as I know, orange-flavoured.)

The chocolate AK47, entitled simply 'Dessert', has been commissioned - though decommissioned might be a better word here - by the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London for an event I am curating there next weekend called Belfast: Are We Nearly There? In it, various writers, artists, photographers, comedians and performers (including John Byrne) from Northern Ireland will be addressing issues that have arisen out of the end of the Troubles; and even saying those last five words, I feel like I am tempting fate.

The event is a wide-ranging, even fragmented one which, no doubt, will manage to offend someone, somewhere along the way. If it has an underlying theme, it is this: as the fragile and uneasy peace just about endures, and as the various reinventions of Northern Ireland, and Belfast in particular, continue at an often startling pace, one remarkably unvoiced question endures: what are we going to do with the Troubles? By that, I mean, what are those of us who lived through them going to do with their legacy, with the bottomless well of damage, suspicion, grief, loss and anger that still lingers in their wake? What are we going to do with our experience, our memory - collective and individual - of the conflict, our fractured sense of our selves? Can we simply, as some people (usually on this side of the Irish Sea) suggest, let it be? I, for one, think not, hope not.

The Troubles, though they may be over, continue, to various extents, to define those of us who lived through them, and however much we may wish it otherwise, that is exactly as it should be. For myself, I have been both deeply affected, and relatively untouched by the Troubles. I have lost people I knew, but no family members nor close friends have died as a direct result of the conflict. I have grown up with that conflict as a constant, but have emerged relatively unscathed, not bitter nor even regretful that I was pitched headlong, through an accident of birth, into such murderous times. I have even, it has to be said, some good memories of the Troubles - the exhilaration, the sense of liberation that the early civil rights movement inspired in my generation, the thrill of those early protests and even those early riots.

And, it almost goes without saying, I also carry some some dark and disturbing images in my head, immovable, inescapable, unprocessable. But as time passes and the Troubles recede into history, I realise that, ultimately, I was one of the lucky ones. I felt this most profoundly when I read a book called Lost Lives, an objective, dispassionate chronicle of every death in the Troubles, and thus the single most powerful testimony to yet emerge from those murderous times.

Reading Lost Lives, complied by journalist David McKittrick and others, awakened something deep inside me; something repressed, buried, pushed for a long time way down beyond rational understanding, never mind articulation. I could call it anger, but that's too small and specific a word. It was more like an angry sadness or, to borrow a phase used recently by the young London-Irish playwright Martin McDonagh, a kind of 'pacifist rage'.

For a while, I was angry about virtually every aspect of the Troubles: about the crimes against human life committed in the name of absolute, and exclusive, causes; at the dirty war waged by successive British governments and their army; at the cavalier approach to human life, not just by terrorists but by elected bodies operating within, and with total disregard for democracy. Mostly, though, I was angry that the Troubles had to happen at all, that they were allowed to grow so big and monstrous yet be, in the main, so contained and localised.

I hear and feel that same anger in many people who lived through the Troubles. And as the dust settles, that well of anger seems to rise. I hear it articulated most forcefully by those who have lost relatives or friends, and by those who have suddenly been confronted with the full force of their history by even the most cursory reading of Lost Lives. What that anger seems to be saying is: it would not have been allowed to happen anywhere else on these islands.

Anger, though - untrammelled and unfocused - is self-defeating, as pointless and self-negating, in its way, as guilt. It needs to be transformed, turned into something positive, life-affirming. Which is what next week's event at the ICA is also about. John Byrne's obsessive and often disturbingly funny laying bare of the border within himself, like Rita Duffy's chocolate AK47, or comedian Michael Smiley's autobiographical oral memoir, entitled - wait for it - Confessions of a Catholic Buddhist, may seem like a perverse way of confronting the long shadow of the Troubles, but it makes perfect absurdist sense to me. That it sits, perhaps uneasily, alongside utterly serious debates featuring writers like Tom Paulin and Ronan Bennett, the award-winning Irish journalist Susan McKay and the maverick Unionist politician David Ervine, seems also to somehow refect the seriousness and the oft-overlooked surrealism of everyday life in a still troubled state.

Walking through Belfast recently, I was struck by the sudden awful thought that, with the Troubles gone, the city seemed suspended - despite all the redevelopment and attempted reinvention - in a strange limbo, not really knowing what to do with itself, how else to assert its difference. It occurred to me that peace might succeed in doing what 30-odd years of war failed to do, and steal Belfast's soul. As if on cue, I came across the following statement by Northern Irish poet and Arts Council representative Damian Smyth: 'There is no such thing as cultural politics. It's just politics. In Northern Ireland, political ideology invests every manifestation of social, intellectual, popular and even spiritual life. And none of that is a "bad" thing. In fact, it is a good thing, and we should never lose it.'

I think I know what he means. Next week at the ICA, that temple of cosmopolitan twenty-first century post-modernism, the truth of those words will hopefully emerge in the most positive, self-questioning, funny, fragmented, obsessive, and occasionally surreal way. As a friend from home remarked recently, the problem with the title, Are We Nearly There?, is that 'with Northern Irish people in attendance, you'll not only have to debate the meaning of the word "we" but the meaning of the word "there"'. He was laughing, but I don't think he was joking. We'll see

Belfast: Are We Nearly There? runs from Friday 23 to Sunday 25 March at the ICA, The Mall, London SW1. John Byrne performs at 4.30pm on Sunday. Tickets and information 0207 930 3647 or at www.ica.org.uk

fields.headline: Gunfight ends hostage ordeal
fields.standfirst: Army frees British worker and two Europeans after Danish company pays £100,000 ransom to kidnappers
fields.trailText: A British engineer was last night preparing for an emotional homecoming after army commandos stormed the jungle hideout in Bangladesh where he and two colleagues were being held by tribal kidnappers.
fields.body:
A British engineer was last night preparing for an emotional homecoming after army commandos stormed the jungle hideout in Bangladesh where he and two colleagues were being held by tribal kidnappers.

The soldiers swooped shortly after dawn and found Tim Selby, from Oldham, and two Danes cowering in a bamboo hut. After intense gunfire, the kidnappers fled and the men were bundled into an army helicopter and flown to safety.

After being held for more than a month deep in the remote Chittagong hills, the three had been marched for six hours through dense teak and banana forests before being dumped in a hut on Friday night. Soldiers encircled the village at 6am yesterday.

They used loud-hailers to urge the kidnappers, who had already melted away, to surrender. They then fired several shots into the air. 'There were three huts. We found the hostages in one of the huts. They appeared panicked,' Brigadier Golam Rabbani said. 'The gunmen pushed us to our limits,' he added. Last night, however, sources said they suspected the hostages had been freed only after a large ransom had been paid.

The bandits, who seized the Europeans on 16 February while they were carrying out a road-surveying project, had originally demanded $1.8 million. The kidnapped men's employer, the Danish construction firm Kampsax, had beaten the price down to £100,000, sources had suggested last week.

Selby, 28, whose family lives in Oldham, Greater Manchester, last night appeared to be unscathed by his ordeal. 'He is in pretty good shape physically. He has been chatting today. He is not ill,' Jon Geddes, spokesman for the British High Commission in Dhaka, said.

His father Alf, 61, a retired deputy head, said confirmation of his son's release came after phone calls from the authorities in Bangladesh. 'I didn't have much time to speak to him on the phone and we still don't know exactly what happened.'

After celebrating with champagne, his mother, Margaret, 61, said she doubted the experience would deter her son from working abroad. She added: 'This has just made me realise how precious people are. Without the support of all our friends and ex-colleagues, we wouldn't have been able to cope as well as we have. It has been very stressful and, of course, our imaginations were running wild. But the Foreign Office have been very reliable and steady. Now I know Tim is in safe hands, my worries and fears have gone and we can just get back to a normal life.'

The engineers were flown to the capital, Dhaka, by helicopter. Their shirts and jeans were soaked in sweat, and the three looked exhausted on arrival, but waved to the crowd of diplomats and military officers who greeted them. They were taken to a military hospital for check-ups.

Their release came after four weeks of negotiations in which British diplomats had been forced to sit in a wooden hut by the side of a road for much of the time. They had privately complained of a lack of co-operation from the Bangladeshi authorities. Three trained hostage negotiators from Scotland Yard had also flown in to assist.

Army officials last night maintained that the 'hunt' was continuing for the kidnappers - even though they were offered an amnesty deal two days ago. They are believed to be members of a dissident tribal faction opposed to a peace accord signed three years ago which ended a long and bloody insurgency in the south-east hill region, 210 miles from Dacca.

Yesterday Bangladesh's Prime Minister, Shaikh Hasina, who faces elections in July, welcomed the end to what had become an embarrassment for her government.

Selby faces awkward questions on his return - not least, why he and his colleagues failed to take a police escort with them, as they had done on the same stretch of road three days before they were captured. The area is notorious for robberies and kidnappings - and for its casual army checkpoints. Several criminal tribal gangs are based in the hills behind the paddy terraces and Buddhist temples. Over the past three years, the gangs have murdered more than 20 political rivals and tried to blow up a tribal leader.

Selby has spent the last month surviving on a diet of rice, bananas, and coconuts. Diplomats had been able to send him letters from home via tribal intermediaries - as well as mineral water, clothes and mosquito nets.

The hostages yesterday said their kidnappers changed hideouts several times during the month.

webTitle: Net baby mother: I've been smeared

fields.headline: Net baby mother: I've been smeared
fields.trailText: The custody battle over the twins bought on the internet took a new twist last night when Judith Kilshaw, the British mother who says she legally adopted the American-born twins, accused social services of conducting a vicious smear campaign against her.
fields.body:
The custody battle over the twins bought on the internet took a new twist last night when Judith Kilshaw, the British mother who says she legally adopted the American-born twins, accused social services of conducting a vicious smear campaign against her.

Kilshaw said Flintshire Social Services Department, which goes to court tomorrow to try to prove that she and her husband are not the twins' legal parents, have told court officials that she has shown confidential care documents about the case to journalists. She fears this could lead to her being accused of contempt of court.

Her husband Alan, a solicitor, said: 'This allegation is total mischief and designed to influence the judge. No one has any evidence of Judith's wrong-doing. This smacks of a witch hunt by the establishment.'

He added: 'Showing confidential documents about a court case to other people is a contempt of court issue. But Judith has never even seen the report.'

His wife said: 'There is no proof. They're trying to discredit me.'

The county council was unable to comment.

Last year, the Kilshaws paid an internet adoption agency, run by Californian Tina Johnson, £8,200 for the twins, born to a woman in Arkansas. The Kilshaws returned with the babies to their farmhouse in Mold.

An American couple also claim they paid for the twins, and have disputed the Kilshaws' adoption.

A US court recently ruled that the twins should be returned to America where their rightful home can be decided by the courts.

The Kilshaws will appear in Birmingham Crown Court tomorrow to continue their appeal against the county council's attempts to annul their adoption. They will be represented by a barrister working for free. Alan Kilshaw believes his family are entitled to legal aid for their legal battle.

nick.walsh@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Leader: Glottal stops good, cut-glass bad

fields.headline: Do talk proper
fields.standfirst: Glottal stops good, cut-glass bad
fields.trailText: If only Nancy Mitford were alive today. The woman who tutored a generation of social climbers how to say basin, not sink, napkin, not serviette, and frock, not dress - or was it the other way round? - would have delighted in the response to the National Theatre's new production of  My Fair Lady.
fields.body:
If only Nancy Mitford were alive today. The woman who tutored a generation of social climbers how to say basin, not sink, napkin, not serviette, and frock, not dress - or was it the other way round? - would have delighted in the response to the National Theatre's new production of My Fair Lady. Actress Martine McCutcheon has triumphed playing Eliza Doolittle, but critics have still complained sniffily that McCutcheon, better known as Tiffany from EastEnders, has failed to master the vocal timbre of an aspirant duchess.

Of course, social snobbery is still endemic in Britain. Only yesterday, the Daily Telegraph sported a front-page headline - 'Three British public school girls killed in car crash in Malawi'. (Would they have set aside the same space to mark the deaths of 'three state school girls'?) But most younger people now regard a cut-glass accent as a social impediment.

Film producer Guy Ritchie, the stepson of a baronet, talks of 'shooters' and 'geezers'. Singer Damon Albarn, the son of a headteacher, affects never to deploy the letter 'h'. Even Prince William has acquired a glottal stop. It is only to be hoped, for her own good, that Miss McCutcheon can soon lose whatever middle-class intonation she has managed to acquire.

webTitle: Letters: What is the answer in the hunting debate?

fields.headline: What is the answer in the hunting debate?
fields.trailText: Recent weeks in  The Observer have seen a highly subjective rant on behalf of the vivisection industry by Jay Rayner followed by a brutal diatribe by Cristina Odone seeking to justify mankind's exploitation of animals.
fields.body:
Recent weeks in The Observer have seen a highly subjective rant on behalf of the vivisection industry by Jay Rayner followed by a brutal diatribe by Cristina Odone seeking to justify mankind's exploitation of animals. This was a polemic that would have been wholeheartedly welcomed by factory farmers, stag hunters and badger baiters everywhere.

To cap it all we now have a leader (Comment, last week) which supports the continuation of fox hunting by simply repeating the lies, exaggerations and distortions of the Countryside Alliance. It seems that the rich and powerful vested interests involved in the exploitation of animals have now achieved almost total hegemony over the media.
Chris Mechan
Oxton, Wirral

 The sport of hunting with hounds is not being banned as a result of a personal pledge by Tony Blair. The Hunting Bill was passed by Members of Parliament, on Tuesday 27 February, by 319 votes to 140. It is not a fox-hunting Bill, but is about hunting wild animals with dogs. Of the 318 registered hunts in England and Wales, only 184 are fox hunts. Deer and stag hunting, hare hunting and hare coursing, and mink hunting, are no less cruel than fox hunting. The purpose of the Bill is to ban the lot.

I am not interested in the personal views of high-profile peers, senior aristocratic figures, multi-millionaires, lords and baronesses. I did not vote for any of them - they are neither accountable to myself nor to the rest of the electorate. My political representative, whose views are important to me, is my Member of Parliament. I do not expect his authority and position to be undermined by unelected lords and ladies who appear to lack respect for, and are endeavouring to frustrate, the democratic process.
John Phelps
Exeter

 I was amazed to read the following words in your leader last Sunday: 'Even the most ardent anti-hunt campaigner cannot deny that foxes must be controlled.' The organisation of which I am a director has for many years denied the necessity of a general cull of foxes. Foxes are generally beneficial to the farmer because of their predation upon rabbits. Chicken farmers certainly need to protect their stock with electric fencing, but the problem for sheep farmers is minimal and grossly overstated.
Ivor Annetts
League Against Cruel Sports
Tiverton, Devon

 That foxes need to be controlled does not stand up to serious examination. This is because the fox is a top carnivore: that is, it is at the top of the food chain. It has long been known that the numbers of such animals are controlled by a natural feedback mechanism based on the availability of food and habitat.

Increase either and numbers increase, decrease either and numbers decrease. This is to prevent predators from exterminating their prey. Herbivores by contrast will increase often by 100 per cent year on year, which is why they need keeping in check by carnivores. Just think about it. Foxes are only hunted in the UK across something like 45-50 per cent of their habitat, yet population densities are broadly the same in both. In addition, fox litters are around double the size in areas where they are hunted as opposed to those where they are not. In short, fox hunting as practised in this country is a largely redundant activity, and the motives of whose who practise it are open to the gravest question.

Why else is it in most of the prime hunting areas that large numbers of small but unproductive spinneys are left intact, unless it is to provide habitat in which foxes might breed? In other words, in much of lowland Britain the fox population is maintained for fox hunting and not by it.
Cllr Bob Johnston
Oxford

 I was very pleased to see your leader at the weekend, stating that you consider the Hunting Bill to be 'disastrous policy'. I do not hunt, but I am one of many in the rural community to feel that this is one more restriction that is being imposed upon us by a government which clearly does not understand the countryside, as evidenced by Mr Nick Brown, who is stating that the foot-and-mouth epidemic is under control, while at the same time asking the Army to mobilise to destroy farm animals and wildlife in infected areas.
D.A. Atkin
Yeovil, Somerset

 Congratulations on a well argued, realistic leader. It gets to the heart of the issue without any waffle, digression or bias. More of the same please.
David Jolly
London W1

fields.headline: Sangakkara does the talking
fields.standfirst: Sri Lanka's controversial wicketkeeper has ruffled a few feathers - but he is bright enough to play it by the book
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's controversial wicketkeeper has ruffled a few feathers - but he is bright enough to play it by the book.
fields.body:
I interviewed Kumar Sangakkara before the Colombo Test - or did I have an audience with him? Sangakkara speaks English better than the English and the way that he's been accommodating every media request - and there have been plenty of them - there's a fair chance that by the end of this Test he'll be too hoarse to speak, a state of affairs that is unlikely to dismay the English camp.

Sangakkara has fascinated us all. Partly this is because he's a damn fine player, as he proved in the cauldron of Kandy when his dashing innings of 95 gave Sri Lanka a glimmer of an unlikely victory. His 45 here in Colombo also hinted at a special talent. But Mahela Jayawardena at this stage is the more accomplished Sri Lankan batsman, verging on greatness, and no one was rushing to speak to him last week.

No, what beguiles us is the fact that Sangakkara has been able to get under Mike Atherton's skin in a manner that no other international cricketer has managed throughout Atherton's 12-year Test career.

By his own admission, Atherton, normally a beacon of tranquillity, 'lost it for four overs' on that tempestuous third evening in Kandy and Sangakkara was the catalyst for that. Even so this pair, who have much in common, have agreed to have a beer now that the series is over. They may end up as bosom pals but it could take a while.

Sangakkara is a great talker. As we - or rather he - was chatting away in Colombo, Dav Whatmore, the coach of Sri Lanka, summoned him for some catching practice. He acknowledged Whatmore with a wave and kept talking for another 15 minutes. This week he has been 'working' the press brilliantly. He has been utterly cooperative, enjoying all the attention, yet as he puts his sharp legal mind to use (he's a second-year law student) he has been careful to say nothing too incriminating or controversial.

At the tender age of 23 you sense he could take over Alistair Campbell's job at Millbank tomorrow. Maybe this is what grates with Atherton. He's used to basic sledging from behind the stumps. Usually he responds with haughty indifference. Famously at Sydney on the way to a Test century in 1994 he got an earthy earful from Ian Healy after surviving a fierce and justified appeal. Atherton eventually turned to Healy with a quiet 'When in Rome, old boy.' Healy was nonplussed and confused.

Sangakkara, who happened to study classics at A-level at Trinity College in Kandy, would have understood and, I dare say, have responded with alacrity. Like Atherton, Sangakkara is obviously bright. However Atherton would never yield to playing the press game. He was never prepared to woo the hacks. To him this smacked of hypocrisy. Sangakkara currently does it with relish and he's brilliant at it; another reason why Atherton may be wary of him.

Since he's so sharp it is optimistic to expect Sangakkara to give us chapter and verse of his exchange with Atherton in Kandy. Instead he says that his provocation of the English players is not intentional. 'There was no plan to annoy or irritate the opposition, though I am aware that I have done so. I'm conscious of the spirit of the game. I recognise that we, the players, are the guardians of the game - most definitely so since there are thousands of people watching. I am competitive but I do accept decisions.'

When asked whether he has any regrets about the way he has played in this series, he now has a stock response - 'Yes, that shot against Croft' - a wild drive that denied him his maiden Test century. But there are to be no admissions of overstepping the mark in his behaviour, though he does concede, 'I know it did look ugly out there,' referring to his exchange with Atherton.

'The Sri Lankans are determined to be as tough as anyone on the field,' he says. 'We have learnt that since 1995 from Aravinda [de Silva] and Arjuna [Ranatunga]. We have tried to be tough, both mentally and physically, but not dirty. It is nice to have a clean, wonderful game but it does not always work out like that. Sledging is part of the game. As long as it is not vindictive that's OK - and it helps if it's humorous.'

He says that Sri Lanka's recent, unsuccessful tour of South Africa taught him a lot: 'Playing there certainly toughened me up. The South Africans are hard, ruthless cricketers, who know how to crush you when you're down.' The Sri Lankans aim to be as ruthless.

But Sangakkara is adamant that he would never claim a catch if he knew that he had scooped the ball on the half-volley. He's sure that he caught the ball in England's first innings in Galle when Atherton edged Vaas in his direction (to England's anguish the third umpire was not consulted and this was the spark for the ensuing little feud). But he had no problems with Atherton staying at the crease in Kandy after another edge came his way off Vaas - 'He's perfectly entitled to do that.' In that case the third umpire was consulted and the catch was confirmed.

He recognises that he is not the best wicketkeeper in Sri Lanka by a long way. 'Kaluwitharana [whom he has replaced in the Test side] is a better keeper and he helps me a lot.' But his batting prowess has got him the job and at the moment he's happy to continue with both roles, though he has played for Sri Lanka as a pure batsman and is more than capable of holding his own as a specialist.

Sangakkara came to cricket 'by accident'. In his youth at Trinity College, in whose grounds the Kandy Test was played, he was an outstanding tennis player. Only at the age of 12 did the cricket coach persuade him to play as a wicketkeeper/batsman. Soon he excelled at under-17 and under-19 level and, like all ambitious players, moved from Kandy to Colombo to advance his cricket.

Sangakkara is the youngest offspring of a successful Kandy lawyer and says: 'I almost felt obliged to study law since none of my elder siblings followed my father's profession.' Not that they are malingerers. One is a psychologist and the best woman tennis player in Sri Lanka, another a broker, another in business management. He's now in the second year of what is nominally a four-year law course at the university in Colombo. With his cricketing commitments he's not sure when he will finish this course, but finish it he will. He'd also like to experience county cricket in England - 'a great nursery' - though Sri Lanka's international schedule makes that a tricky proposition for all but Muttiah Muralitharan.

Sangakkara will succeed - probably on the cricket field, but, if not, in any other walk of life that he chooses. Once he's calmed down a bit there's every chance that he'll captain his country. In which case those inevitable pre-match press conferences, usually so dreary, will become a minor art form. Even if he ends up telling us nothing, he will no doubt do it immaculately.

At the tender age of 23 you sense he could take over Alistair Campbell's job at Millbank tomorrow. Maybe this is what grates with Atherton. He's used to basic sledging from behind the stumps. Usually he responds with haughty indifference. Famously at Sydney on the way to a Test century in 1994 he got an earthy earful from Ian Healy after surviving a fierce and justified appeal. Atherton eventually turned to Healy with a quiet 'When in Rome, old boy.' Healy was nonplussed and confused. Sangakkara, who happened to study classics at A-level at Trinity College in Kandy, would have understood and, I dare say, have responded with alacrity. Like Atherton, Sangakkara is obviously bright. However Atherton would never yield to playing the press game. He was never prepared to woo the hacks. To him this smacked of hypocrisy. Sangakkara currently does it with relish and he's brilliant at it; another reason why Atherton may be wary of him. Since he's so sharp it is optimistic to expect Sangakkara to give us chapter and verse of his exchange with Atherton in Kandy. Instead he says that his provocation of the English players is not intentional. 'There was no plan to annoy or irritate the opposition, though I am aware that I have done so. I'm conscious of the spirit of the game. I recognise that we, the players, are the guardians of the game - most definitely so since there are thousands of people watching. I am competitive but I do accept decisions.' When asked whether he has any regrets about the way he has played in this series, he now has a stock response - 'Yes, that shot against Croft' - a wild drive that denied him his maiden Test century. But there are to be no admissions of overstepping the mark in his behaviour, though he does concede, 'I know it did look ugly out there,' referring to his exchange with Atherton. 'The Sri Lankans are determined to be as tough as anyone on the field,' he says. 'We have learnt that since 1995 from Aravinda [de Silva] and Arjuna [Ranatunga]. We have tried to be tough, both mentally and physically, but not dirty. It is nice to have a clean, wonderful game but it does not always work out like that. Sledging is part of the game. As long as it is not vindictive that's OK - and it helps if it's humorous.' He says that Sri Lanka's recent, unsuccessful tour of South Africa taught him a lot: 'Playing there certainly toughened me up. The South Africans are hard, ruthless cricketers, who know how to crush you when you're down.' The Sri Lankans aim to be as ruthless. But Sangakkara is adamant that he would never claim a catch if he knew that he had scooped the ball on the half-volley. He's sure that he caught the ball in England's first innings in Galle when Atherton edged Vaas in his direction (to England's anguish the third umpire was not consulted and this was the spark for the ensuing little feud). But he had no problems with Atherton staying at the crease in Kandy after another edge came his way off Vaas - 'He's perfectly entitled to do that.' But his batting prowess has got him the job and at the moment he's happy to continue with both roles, though he has played for Sri Lanka as a pure batsman and is more than capable of holding his own as a specialist. Sangakkara came to cricket 'by accident'. In his youth at Trinity College, in whose grounds the Kandy Test was played, he was an outstanding tennis player. Only at the age of 12 did the cricket coach persuade him to play as a wicketkeeper/batsman. Soon he excelled at under-17 and under-19 level and, like all ambitious players, moved from Kandy to Colombo to advance his cricket. Sangakkara is the youngest offspring of a successful Kandy lawyer and says: 'I almost felt obliged to study law since none of my elder siblings followed my father's profession.' Not that they are malingerers. One is a psychologist and the best woman tennis player in Sri Lanka, another a broker, another in business management. He's now in the second year of what is nominally a four-year law course at the university in Colombo. With his cricketing commitments he's not sure when he will finish this course, but finish it he will. He'd also like to experience county cricket in England - 'a great nursery' - though Sri Lanka's international schedule makes that a tricky proposition for all but Muttiah Muralitharan. Sangakkara will succeed - probably on the cricket field, but, if not, in any other walk of life that he chooses. Once he's calmed down a bit there's every chance that he'll captain his country. In which case those inevitable pre-match press conferences, usually so dreary, will become a minor art form. Even if he ends up telling us nothing, he will no doubt do it immaculately.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Despite differences in religion and upbringing, not to mention a 40-year-age gap, rock star Nick Cave and blind gallery owner IM Birtwistle share a love of literature, music, painting and... chocolate cake
fields.trailText: Despite differences in religion and upbringing, not to mention a 40-year-age gap, rock star Nick Cave and blind gallery owner IM Birtwistle share a love of literature, music, painting and... chocolate cake.
fields.body:
Nick Cave: It was love at first sight. I'd been taken to Lilla's gallery by a friend I was staying with in Norfolk. I was very low at the time. I loved the eccentricity of the place - the books, pictures and photographs all crowded together in a caravan. The first words she said to me were 'Are you a Papist?' It's typical of her directness. She was so clued-up. The conversation went everywhere. I was just trying to keep up. It's a mystery why she took to me, but I was touched by it. I'd wasted so much time pursuing things that were destructive on all levels. Lilla knows about my past and she accepts it. That's a vital part of our friendship.

She asked me where my spirituality came from and it was a relief to talk on that level because people of my age don't. Although I'm not a Papist, there has never been a moment in my life when I didn't believe in God. I loved the imagery and the language of the Old Testament and God making the world cringe - that appealed to me in my twenties when I had so many chips on my shoulder. Lilla says I'm tugging at God's beard in my music.

I trust her judgement implicitly. She talks about paintings with the same uncanny understanding she brings to everything else, recognising works by the vibrations they give off. I was once there when a young hopeful came into the gallery with some drawings. Lilla couldn't see them and yet what she said about them was absolutely right.

These days I'm happier and more focussed. I have more ideas and get things done. Lilla is very supportive. She knows my work is a spiritual necessity for me and she worries if I'm not doing it. I don't care how many prams there are in the hall, the more the merrier, but sometimes I get so tired I can barely string a sentence together and that bothers her.

I have very few close friends and Lilla is the only one I don't actually work with. Lilla and I have a genuine love for each other.

We're in constant contact, but I tend to be a bit more erratic than she is - life sometimes gets in the way and I may not call for a month. But it doesn't matter because I know she'll always be there for me.

IM Birtwistle: I had no idea who Nick was when we first met, but I'm as enthusiastic about his music now as any of his fans. Nick rushes through life like a meteor. He needs to learn to pace himself to avoid burn-out. I love the stretch of his mind and his search for original ideas, although some of his albums definitely need a government health warning.

Since the births of his four sons and his marriage, he has become a tremendous patriarch and has moved forward musically. His new album is a poetic offering to his wife Susie that bears comparison with Bartók. The imagery ranges from the surreal to the tender, but knowing Nick, you are always on the look-out for the grenade hidden in the bouquet.

Although he doesn't subscribe to organised religion, Nick's life is totally God-centred. There are areas of faith, of course, where we can't meet and this is a sadness, almost like a bereavement, because part of that person is lost to you, but Nick has so many layers that I enjoy exploring his landscape. I can't see him, but I have his voice, like a warm, operatic Leonard Cohen, and like Desdemona 'I see his visage in my mind.'

I have hereditary glaucoma and started losing my sight when I was 49. I'm now 83. Being blind is like being under house arrest in a black box. Nick's friendship has illuminated the walls. Not to mention the golden mice he endlessly lays at my door, like the violet and rose chocolates from Charbonnel et Walker. We also share a passion for home-made chocolate cake. Nick takes his role as a friend and two-legged guide dog very seriously.

Although I am twice his age, the differences between us are often a stimulus. The joy of friendship is that one can dare to differ.

Literature, music and painting have been lifelong passions for me and it has been great fun to exchange some of my old loves with some of his new ones.

webTitle: Cricket: It is time to overhaul Test cricket, says Mike Gatting

fields.headline: One step from anarchy
fields.standfirst: England's ex-captain says the game is in danger of falling apart, and a tough remedy is needed
fields.trailText: It is time to overhaul Test cricket, says Mike Gatting.
fields.body:
This series in Sri Lanka has probably been the most contentious England have played abroad since my bust-up with Pakistani umpire Shakoor Rana in 1987, giving a timely reminder of how easily things can spiral out of control.

At different times in both the first and second Tests the very basics of the game were forgotten or passed over. When that happens and players lose respect for umpires, match officials and each other we are only a short step away from a total breakdown.

I have no doubt that the quality of umpiring and refereeing in recent Tests - highlighted by TV - has left a lot to be desired, and ICC chairman Malcolm Gray admitted as much this week when he promised an overhaul of the way Test cricket is run. But it's not just the officials and administrators we must look to: the players also have a duty of care to the game.

It was good to see in the run-up to this third Test in Colombo a degree of agreement between the captains to ensure the game was played in a better spirit, but that initiative went out of the window on the first day when Aravinda De Silva was caught at slip - and didn't walk.

For the next half-hour you could sense the tension rising again with a few flicks back to the keeper from short-leg to keep De Silva on his toes, and hard looks from the England fielders. In a situation like that players can't heap the responsibility on to the umpire. De Silva isn't a kid. He's been around a long time, captained his country and was well aware of the bad feeling in the series and the attempts to heal relationships - so he nicks one to slip and stands his ground. What was he thinking about?

As a batsman, there is an accepted range within which you leave it to the umpire. The opposite end of the spectrum from nicking one to slip and not walking is getting the faintest of edges that the fielding side don't appeal for and giving yourself out. No-one is expected to do that, either.

The lead for players' conduct must come from the captain. I've always left it up to my players whether they walk or not on the understanding that if they don't walk they surrender the right to complain when they get a bad decision. The exception to that rule was Pakistan in 1987 when we were getting so many poor decisions we decided as a team to stand our ground, obviously within reason.

A captain also has to control the chat that goes on in the middle and the level of appealing, both of which have been unacceptable in this series. A chirpy youngster like Sangakkara should be told to tone it down and the Sri Lankans must learn to restrict their shouts. England haven't been blameless in either area, but they haven't been as bad as their hosts.

Meanwhile, the ICC have the power to cut the grounds for dispute by improving standards of umpiring and refereeing.

Barrie Stuart-King, the chairman of the Association of Cricket Umpires, made some telling points on these pages last week, calling for more training for umpires and suggesting that former players aren't necessarily the best men for the job. Half right in my opinion. Yes, we do need Test match officials to be better trained but having played the game to a reasonable level is an asset for an umpire. I'm sure the same would be true in football.

Former players know what goes on in the game, they have the confidence to give bat-pad decisions, for example, according to the angle and bounce of the ball, and if their judgement is wrong they can always say: 'Come on, lads, we all make mistakes. I don't have a go at you when you get out to a bad shot.'

I like Gray's idea of having a pool of eight full-time 'super umpires', at least one of which would stand in every Test played. They should not be selected on grounds of nationality but on their ability. If that means six English umpires, or none, so be it. What we don't need is a nomination from each country for political reasons.

The troubled tour of Pakistan in 1987 accelerated the arrival of one neutral official, and perhaps the goings-on in Sri Lanka will provide the impetus for another change. But if the ICC take the logical next step to having two neutral umpires in each match that could actually disadvantage England as the majority of the best officials are English and they would never stand in a home Test. Foreign umpires could also be drafted into county cricket and maybe even Australian grade games because, like players, they will improve with practice.

At the same time, the ICC needs to set up a structure for monitoring the performance of officials with de-briefings after each Test on what they did well, and badly. The present system offers very little feedback, never mind censure. If a player is subjected to a post-match trial by video from his coach, why isn't an umpire asked, in private, to account for his mistakes?

Hopefully, the introduction of some form of ICC-controlled centralised umpiring system would also lead to more consistency in interpretation of the laws, particularly the lbw law.

Why ignore technology when you're trying to maintain concentration for every delivery of a five-day Test and making instant judgements on the path of a ball delivered at 80-90mph? Let's not be frightened of the technology.

Unlike my fellow columnist, former Sri Lankan captain Arjuna Ranatunga, I don't think we can rein back on TV advances - that would not be helpful. And why protect an umpire who is consistently shown to be giving wrong decisions?

The ICC's review should also give serious consideration to Duncan Fletcher's idea of three referrals per innings, whereby teams could challenge an umpire's decision on three occasions if they believed it to be wrong. I worry that these referrals could be used up early in an innings leaving the lower order to suffer any bad decisions later in the day. But the idea has merit.

Match refereeing must be addressed. I think Gray referred to them as an old boy network, and that's the problem - they're old, and too often out of touch with the modern game. Someone more recently retired from Test cricket would have a far better understanding of the players' view (and no, I'm not applying for a job).

When Sri Lankan captain Sanath Jayasuriya threw his helmet at an advertising board only the very naive would have expected him to be suspended. Referees have the power but don't use it. Instead they prefer largely meaningless suspended sentences and fines.

Players, umpires, referees and the ICC all care for cricket and need to work together to ensure it not only remains a great game, but also a fair and enjoyable one to play.

fields.headline: Tougher bans in pipeline
fields.trailText: Lord McLaurin, the chairman of the ECB, has advocated a much tougher approach than currently employed towards players who break the ICC code of conduct on the field. 'If players continually transgress they should be banned from playing for one, two or three matches. They'll soon stop then. These suspended sentences are a load of nonsense. We have got to be tough. Maybe we have been too old-school-tie-ish in the past, too genteel,' he said.
fields.body:
Lord McLaurin, the chairman of the ECB, has advocated a much tougher approach than currently employed towards players who break the ICC code of conduct on the field. 'If players continually transgress they should be banned from playing for one, two or three matches. They'll soon stop then. These suspended sentences are a load of nonsense. We have got to be tough. Maybe we have been too old-school-tie-ish in the past, too genteel,' he said.

Nor did McLaurin, who is attending the Test match in Colombo, spare those running the game. 'I blame the administrators,' he said in a clear reference to the current crisis over umpiring. McLaurin's ideas were outlined in a 9 March letter to Malcolm Gray, the president of the ICC. They are certainly not new and indeed some are already on their way. 'I want to see a panel of professional umpires, eight, 10 or 12 contracted to the ICC and the use of two "neutral" umpires in all Tests. In Melbourne [the venue for the last ICC get-together], 10 or 12 names were mentioned and six or seven of them were from our game.' So the prospect of several Test playing countries not being represented on any elite panel of umpires opens up.

McLaurin also stressed the need for an umpire training school. His own suggestion is that this is a task which the MCC is ideally suited to take on. He also favoured the idea of foreign umpires gaining experience in English county cricket. This too is hardly ground-breaking. The theory was the subject of a Seventies experiment.

McLaurin expressed his impatience regarding the umpiring issue, which was second only to match-fixing on the ICCF's agenda. 'We have a responsibility to the game,' he said. 'We should act quickly otherwise cricket will disappear. In business if the company was going downhill there would be an emergency board meeting.' (The ICCF's cricket committee is not due to meet again until May.) Referring to the need to overhaul the way umpiring is organised in international cricket he said: 'I would do it tomorrow. We can't allow the game to drift.'

McLaurin's impatience did not extend to the match-fixing enquiries. Sir Paul Condon's investigations should be regarded as a marathon, not a sprint and his report would be delivered to the ICCF's AGM in June. He confirmed that 12 players would be centrally contracted this summer, though he would like to see that figure rise to 15 or 18 in the future.

On the thorny problem of the Home Office's refusal to issue a passport to England coach Duncan Fletcher, he said 'I am confident that he will get a passport. I hope he does. I have been out of these discussions but the Board will highlight the fine job he has done for English cricket.'

fields.headline: The Britain Uncovered Poll
fields.standfirst: We like our jobs, but most of us take a sickie. We're not always proud of Britain, and lots of us want to live in Spain. This special Observer poll reveals the truth about a complex, changing land. How much of it do you recognise?
fields.trailText: We like our jobs, but most of us take a sickie. We're not always proud of Britain, and lots of us want to live in Spain. This special Observer poll reveals the truth about a complex, changing land. How much of it do you recognise?
fields.body:
Work, Rest and Pay

Which of the following causes you the most anxiety in life? Money 32% Family 28% Job pressures 18% Time pressures 13% Love life 9%

If there were two extra hours in the day, would you prefer to spend them ... With family 49% With friends 25% By yourself 17% Getting more work done 9%

If you had the choice would you prefer to work shorter hours for the same amount of money or the same amount of hours for more money?

Shorter hours - same money 46% Same hours - more money 54%

Money causes the most anxiety in life for 32 per cent. This helps to explain why so many value additional money over free time. Love life causes the least anxiety which, combined with the high levels of confidence in partners' fidelity and the durability of marriage (see below in Love, Sex and Marriage), suggests that we tend to become complacent when we have found a partner. This is reinforced by the evidence that love life is more than three times more likely to be the primary cause of anxiety in the life for singles than those who are married or cohabiting. Money is not the primary source of anxiety for all age groups. Job pressures create more anxiety among 45 to 54-year-olds, while family causes the most anxiety for both the 55-64 and 65+ age groups.

The results of the third question appear to contradict the commonly held belief that longer working hours have made us all victim to a time squeezeê effect. The other interpretation is that we are willing participants in this time squeeze rather than victims. Among those who work and said that they would like to spend more time with the family 50 per cent would opt for shorter hours while 50 per cent would prefer more money. This suggests that while family matters to this group, its importance could be eclipsed by the pursuit of money.

On average, how many days work a year do you miss through 'sickies' - feigned illness? Average overall: 3.6 Average for men: 4.4 Average for women: 2.7

76 per cent of workers in the UK take at least one sickie per year. In addition to the differences in male and female workers, there is also some regional variation with Northern workers taking an average of 4.27 sickies per year in comparison with 3.4 in the South and 3.09 in the Midlands.

If money were no object, would you:

a) Educate your children privately? Yes 61% No 39%

(b) Take out private healthcare? Yes 76% No 24%

Overall, people are in favour of private education and healthcare. The older age groups (55+) appear to have the strongest attachment to the principles of state-supplied education and healthcare. For a significant minority, private healthcare is seen as a necessity while private education provides a moral quandary: 25 per cent of those who would take out private healthcare would refuse to educate their children privately if money were no object. Only 19 per cent of the British population would not take out private healthcare or educate their children privately.

Love, Sex and Marriage

Are you currently in a relationship? Yes 75% No 25%

Are you confident that your partner is or has always been faithful to you? Yes 87% No 13%

If you were to get married today, would you expect to stay married to the same person for the rest of your life? Yes 86% No 14%

Other than the very high level of confidence in their partner's fidelity (which could be interpreted as complacency) one of the most interesting statistics is that there is no significant difference between the answers of men and women. There is a continued faith in marriage: 90 per cent of those who are marrie or cohabiting are confident of their partner's fidelity in comparison to 69 per cent of those who are not living with their partner.

Do you believe that marriage between people of the same sex should be legal? Yes 31% No 69%

Men (75 per cent) are more likely to be opposed to same-sex marriage than women (63 per cent). As with the previous question, the older the respondent, the less likely they are to believe that same-sex marriage should be legalised.

Are you currently satisfied with your sex life? Yes 75% No 25%

A quarter of the UK population is currently dissatisfied with their sex life. Furthermore, this dissatisfaction does not appear to be confined to young men. In fact, there is little significant difference between satisfaction levels across the spectrum of age and social class. As for gender, men, perhaps predictably, are less satisfied, but not by much (72 per cent to women's 80 per cent).

Have you ever paid for sex? Yes 5% No 95%

61 per cent of those who have paid for sex have done so only once or twice suggesting that, for the majority, it is a one-off rather than habitual.

Have you ever been to see a therapist? Yes 14% No 86%

If so, did you find the therapy sessions helpful? Yes 68% No 32%

These results appear to suggest that a stable relationship is the greatest ameliorative for mental turmoil, as 21 per cent of those who are single have been to see a therapist in comparison with 12 per cent of those who are married/living with a partner. There is little difference in tendency to consult a therapist based on social class (which could be used as a crude indicator of wealth). While women (16 per cent) are more likely to have seen a therapist than men (12 per cent), the disparity is not as great as may be expected. Men, it seems, are getting over their traditional reluctance to talk things over.

What religion are you? Church of England 55% Roman Catholic 16% Other Christian 9% Muslim 1% Hindu 0.3% Jewish 0.2% Sikh 0.3% Agnostic 10% Atheist 6.5% Other (eg Buddhist) 1.7%

In your opinion, do you actively practise your religion, i.e. you attend regular religious services? Yes 31% No 69%

While 83 per cent of respondents associate themselves with a religion, only 31 per cent say they actively practise it. With Christians scoring comparitively low. Among those who identified the Church of England as their religion, this figure drops to 23 per cent, which compares unfavourably with those who identified themselves as a follower of a non-Christian religion, 63 per cent of whom actively practise.

The Colour of Love

Have you ever been, or are you now, married to someone of a different colour to you? Yes 5% No 95%

Among those who describe their racial origins as other than white British, this figure of 5 per cent rises to 18 per cent.

Would you consider marriage with someone of a different colour? Yes 54% No 46%

Have you ever had sex with someone of a different colour to you? Yes 18% No 82%

Would you ever consider having sex with someone of a different colour to you? Yes 53% No 47%

Is it a level of hypocrisy or even a fear of the judgment of society that makes 13 per cent of those who have previously had sex with someone of a different colour say they would not consider marriage with someone of a different colour? 14 per cent of those who would not consider marriage with someone of a different colour would, however, consider having sex with someone of a different colour.

Crimes and Misdemeanours

Have you ever been charged with any of the following crimes? If so, please indicate which ones.

Motoring offences 19% Violent crime (including pub brawls etc) 3% Shoplifting 2% Drugs (personal consumption) 1% Theft/burglary 1% Fraud (eg benefit, tax or insurance) 1% Selling illegal goods (eg drugs, stolen property etc) 1% None of these 78%

Have you ever committed any of the following crimes and not been caught or charged? If so, please indicate which ones.

Motoring offences 26% Drugs (personal consumption) 9% Shoplifting 9% Fraud (eg benefit, tax or insurance) 5% Violent crime (including pub brawls etc) 5% Selling illegal goods (eg drugs, stolen property etc) 4% Theft/burglary 3% None of these 67%

The dishonesty of the younger generation is exhibited once more as 9 per cent of 18-34s have sold illegal goods. Although the figures do not give any indication of the nature of these goods, it is likely that drugs are the most common.

Men (12 per cent) are twice as likely to have taken drugs as women (6 per cent). This trend extends to all crimes. Overall, 46 per cent of men have committed a crime and not been caught or charged, in comparison with 20 per cent of women. Among the most striking statistics are that men are three times as likely to have committed a motoring offence (39 per cent and 13 per cent respectively) and four times as likely to have committed a violent crime (8 per cent and 2 per cent respectively).

Likewise, while the AB social group is the least likely to keep the money, a large minority - 27 per cent - would do so.

While religious conviction reduces the likelihood of keeping the money, 23 per cent of those who actively practise religion would keep the money rather than hand it in to the police.

Have you ever lied on... (a) A job application form : Yes 25% No 75%

(b) An insurance form : Yes 11% No 89%

(c) A tax form : Yes 8% No 92%

(d) A mortgage application : Yes 5% No 95%

Men are consistently more likely to lie on official documentation than women. While it is difficult to draw a direct comparison on the basis of age (on the assumption that younger people are less likely to have filled in a mortgage application etc.) it appears that the younger groups have fewer scruples about lying on an application form. 38 per cent of the 18-24 group and 37 per cent of 25-34s have lied on job applications.

18 per cent of 25-34-year-olds have lied on an insurance form. This could be attributed to increasingly stringent questions which have effectively disqualified a myriad of alternative lifestyles. Northerners are the least likely to lie on all forms.

Have you ever taken hard drugs? Yes 12% No 88%

25 per cent and 22 per cent respectively of the 18-24 and 25-34 age groups have taken hard drugs. Men (16 per cent) are more than twice as likely to have taken hard drugs as women (7 per cent). 27 per cent of job seekers have taken hard drugs.

Your Country: Rights and Wrongs

What makes you most proud when you think of Britain? (Top five responses) 1= History 11% 1= Royal family 11% 3= Countryside 8% 3= The people 8% 5. Freedom/free speech 7%

45 per cent of the sample were unable to name anything which made them proud when thinking of Britain. Among the 18-24 age group this figure rose to 61 per cent.

What makes you most embarrassed when you think of Britain? (Top five responses) 1. Hooligans/lager louts 33% 2. Litter/mess 11% 3. The government/New Labour 8% 4. Crime/criminals 6% 5. Racism/xenophobia 5%

Hooliganism was three times as likely to be mentioned as its nearest rival in the embarrassment stakes, litter/dirty streets.

If you had the opportunity to live in another part of Britain, where would you most like to live? (Top five responses) 1. South West (eg Bristol, Cornwall, Devon) 25% 2. Scotland 21% 3. London 12% 4. South and South East (eg Brighton, Portsmouth, Southampton) 11% 5. Wales 8%

Where would you least like to live in Britain? (Top five responses) 1. London 32% 2. Northern Ireland 16% 3. Midlands (eg Birmingham, Coventry, Wolverhampton) 13% 4= Wales 9% 4= North West (eg Manchester, Liverpool) 9%

The demographic sub-group variation in these answers are interesting. London is clearly the most popular region among 18-24-year-olds and respondents whose racial origins are not white British, although it ranks third overall; and yet it also tops the undesirable list. The capital evidently polarises opinion.

Would you prefer to live in an urban or a rural area? Rural 66% Urban 34%

The rural preference was pretty widespread. The only demographic groups who would prefer to live in an urban rather than rural area are 18-24 year olds and those who are single.

If you could live in any country in the world except Britain, where would you like to live? (Top five responses) 1. USA 19% 2. Australia 13% 3. Spain 13% 4. Canada 9% 5= New Zealand 5% 5= Ireland 5%

America was particularly popular among the 18-24 age group, 24 per cent of whom selected it. It appears that the most important consideration for most would be finding another country whose first language was English.

Discounting Britain, which is your favourite European country? (Top five responses) 1. Spain 26% 2. France 13% 3. Italy 12% 4. Ireland 11% 5. Portugal 8%

Spain has across-the-board appeal. It was the most popular European country among every single demographic sub-group irrespective of age, gender, social class, region, marital status or ethnicity.

Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults. Respondents were asked screening questions to establish their demographics then handed a self-completion questionnaire to complete. Once this was completed, they placed it in an envelope for collation.

webTitle: Cricket: Mental power won the series

fields.headline: Mental power won the series
fields.trailText: Two evenly matched teams have produced some brutally tense and competitive cricket, writes Arjuna Ranatunga.
fields.body:
How I miss being out in the middle. Two evenly matched teams have produced some brutally tense and competitive cricket. Sri Lanka must be feeling like the boxer Jake La Motta in Raging Bull after his final bout against Sugar Ray Robinson: so badly beaten that his face is a gushing fountain of blood, yet able to say: 'Never knocked me down, Sugar Ray.'

Sri Lanka can say that now, for they might have been beaten painfully, but they have not been flattened. It would have been the same had England lost. Cricket is a physical game decided by strength of mind.

It is apparent now, following the clearing of the storm clouds around the umpires, that Sri Lanka conceded too much to England after Galle - their attacking batsmen have been planned out, Muttiah Muralitharan has been neutralised. Sanath Jayasuraya was snared just about every time by feeding him his favourite off-side slashes, and Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Craig White trapped everyone else with a well-directed mixture of cutters, bouncers and slower balls. England's bowlers have been happy even to give up consecutive boundaries, as a prelude to the sucker set-up ball. Always playing to a plan, England have out-thought Sri Lanka, and ultimately outfought them.

England's series victory is a credit to their team ethic. Batsmen have really played for their partners in the middle and their team-mates padded-up in the pavilion. And how the fielders have backed up their bowlers. England's catching was phenomenal. Just as significantly, Graham Thorpe and Gough, not content to be heroes with bat and ball, threw themselves around the field resisting the urge to conclude that a saved run or gained wicket before an imminent declaration didn't really matter.

But the small things do matter. They lead to big things, and big things lead to huge things, and huge things lead to team success. It shows every person in the team that they are not fighting alone, that someone will work selflessly hard for you and that you should do the same for them.

Sri Lanka have lost two Tests narrowly. And the reason why can be traced to the win in Galle. The afternoon of the first day in Galle, Robert Croft - then a bowler lacking in confidence - was not punished for his uninspired semi-flatties. He escaped torment, rediscovered the power of flight in time for Kandy and excelled with ball then bat.

England's tail always came up with the goods when required, whereas at times our tail has been close to peacock length. If Sri Lanka had broken Croft in Galle, England's whole series strategy would have been compromised. Another significant difference between the teams can be traced to Marvan Atapattu's innings late on the second day. He should have pressed on after reaching 150 and not crawled to a personal landmark of 200. Lazy journalists and insecure players love landmarks - they are seen as shorthand for ability. But it is context that counts, how and when you perform.

Throughout the series, England were able to raise their game when it mattered. They took vital wickets at momentum and morale-sapping times and the batsmen knuckled down, like Michael Vaughn and Thorpe did on Friday afternoon. It has been tough on Murali who bowled bravely and was denied vital breakthroughs at times which would have really boosted him. Murali is a competitor who has raised expectations to such a level that had he taken 25 wickets this series, people would not have been surprised. Nevertheless he caused England problems, and no English batsman looked thoroughly convincing against him, certainly not while playing him from the crease. Murali will have learnt a lot and should become an even better bowler.

I took pride in building a team of competitors, even though he lost this series, Sanath can be proud also. He is one of those who have hurtled into boundary boards and he has suffered some outrageous slices of fortune. Yet he has come up fighting. For all his young team's relative lack of experience compared to the multi-Test veterans of England, he has led them through the fires of competition. Sri Lankan cricket must build on the experience.

Still, it is always best to learn from others' mistakes. It took England a lot of losing to learn what they are about. The education has been as much physical as psychological and learning has come slowly but surely. They turned themselves around once they started looking inside themselves. Now England are on the crest of a wave that will last as long as Atherton, Gough, Thorpe, Stewart and Hussain are together. England should enjoy this vintage while it lasts.

It is apparent now, following the clearing of the storm clouds around the umpires, that Sri Lanka conceded too much to England after Galle - their attacking batsmen have been planned out, Muttiah Muralitharan has been neutralised. Sanath Jayasuraya was snared just about every time by feeding him his favourite off-side slashes, and Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Craig White trapped everyone else with a well-directed mixture of cutters, bouncers and slower balls. England's bowlers have been happy even to give up consecutive boundaries, as a prelude to the sucker set-up ball. Always playing to a plan, England have out-thought Sri Lanka, and ultimately outfought them. England's series victory is a credit to their team ethic. Batsmen have really played for their partners in the middle and their team-mates padded-up in the pavilion. And how the fielders have backed up their bowlers. England's catching was phenomenal. Just as significantly, Graham Thorpe and Gough, not content to be heroes with bat and ball, threw themselves around the field resisting the urge to conclude that a saved run or gained wicket before an imminent declaration didn't really matter. But the small things do matter. They lead to big things, and big things lead to huge things, and huge things lead to team success. It shows every person in the team that they are not fighting alone, that someone will work selflessly hard for you and that you should do the same for them. Sri Lanka have lost two Tests narrowly. And the reason why can be traced to the win in Galle. The afternoon of the first day in Galle, Robert Croft - then a bowler lacking in confidence - was not punished for his uninspired semi-flatties. He escaped torment, rediscovered the power of flight in time for Kandy and excelled with ball then bat. England's tail always came up with the goods when required, whereas at times our tail has been close to peacock length. If Sri Lanka had broken Croft in Galle, England's whole series strategy would have been compromised. Another significant difference between the teams can be traced to Marvan Atapattu's innings late on the second day. He should have pressed on after reaching 150 and not crawled to a personal landmark of 200. Lazy journalists and insecure players love landmarks - they are seen as shorthand for ability. But it is context that counts, how and when you perform. Throughout the series, England were able to raise their game when it mattered. They took vital wickets at momentum and morale-sapping times and the batsmen knuckled down, like Michael Vaughn and Thorpe did on Friday afternoon. It has been tough on Murali who bowled bravely and was denied vital breakthroughs at times which would have really boosted him. Murali is a competitor who has raised expectations to such a level that had he taken 25 wickets this series, people would not have been surprised. Nevertheless he caused England problems, and no English batsman looked thoroughly convincing against him, certainly not while playing him from the crease. Murali will have learnt a lot and should become an even better bowler. I took pride in building a team of competitors, even though he lost this series, Sanath can be proud also. He is one of those who have hurtled into boundary boards and he has suffered some outrageous slices of fortune. Yet he has come up fighting. For all his young team's relative lack of experience compared to the multi-Test veterans of England, he has led them through the fires of competition. Sri Lankan cricket must build on the experience. Still, it is always best to learn from others' mistakes. It took England a lot of losing to learn what they are about. The education has been as much physical as psychological and learning has come slowly but surely. They turned themselves around once they started looking inside themselves. Now England are on the crest of a wave that will last as long as Atherton, Gough, Thorpe, Stewart and Hussain are together. England should enjoy this vintage while it lasts.

webTitle: Cricket: The force is with us for The Ashes

fields.headline: The force is with us for The Ashes
fields.trailText: Back-to-back series wins on the Indian sub-continent - I'll bet you weren't expecting to read that five months ago. I certainly wasn't.
fields.body:
Back-to-back series wins on the Indian sub-continent - I'll bet you weren't expecting to read that five months ago. I certainly wasn't.

While you always hope for the best, when the England party left for Pakistan I'd have settled for a couple of drawn series, to build on the victories over Zimbabwe and the West Indies last summer.

Success in Pakistan was something special because we hadn't won there for so long and the predictions were for a heavy defeat - but this result in Sri Lanka is even better.

Don't forget it's only three weeks since we lost by an innings in Galle. It's impossible to stress how difficult it is to lift a side that has been beaten by a big margin but also believes it got the rough end of at least half-a-dozen poor umpiring decisions.

Coming back from one-down to win a three-match series is almost unheard of, particularly away from home. Yet this England team don't expect to be beaten and can now claim to be third-best in the world behind Australia and South Africa.

That's one heck of a turnaround from 18 months ago when we were losing at home to New Zealand and were just about bottom of the international ladder. England seem to have discovered that elusive winning habit that comes from confidence and belief.

When the chips are down they dig in - now the feelgood factor runs through the side. Everyone has contributed, even Ian Salisbury who was out of form with the ball in Pakistan, made useful runs and Robert Croft has found some form in the past couple of weeks.

Mike Atherton and Ashley Giles were superb before Christmas, Darren Gough excelled in Sri Lanka and Craig White has chipped in with runs and wickets, although he'll want to forget that shot yesterday.

But the key to the whole winter has been left-hander Graham Thorpe - he worked out how to play the twin threat of Saqlain Mushtaq in Pakistan and then Muttiah Muralitharan. His simple, untroubled approach has shown his colleagues how to be positive against spinners.

Duncan Fletcher and his staff must also take credit. It has been impressive to see every batsman with a personal game plan - and sticking to it - and the bowlers adapting to the alien conditions.

Back home this summer with the ball seaming around we should be favourites to beat Pakistan, and then it's Australia, the biggest hurdle of all. I can't wait for the Ashes to start. After four straight series wins England have a superb platform going into this battle and, given a good start, we have every reason to be optimistic.

To go from near the bottom of the pile to the top in two years is perhaps expecting too much, but this team has faith in itself and the momentum is with us.

fields.headline: Hugs among discord
fields.trailText: James Davis on tour.
fields.body:
The bad blood that characterised the first two Tests between Sri Lanka and England seems to have spread to the media. Sri Lankan papers have brought up Geoffrey Boycott's brushes with French law in relation to 'gentlemanly conduct' and the TV commentators have been described as 'biased' and 'lacking dignity'.

Even the Sri Lankan commentator working for Sky, Ranjith Fernando, has been criticised. One article said: 'No one pays any attention to Fernando's commentaries because it is like replaying what the white men said.' It went on to describe England's spinners as 'mongrels' who 'couldn't bowl out a team of old ladies'. Ashley Giles and Robert Croft must be smiling now.

Despite the on-field bitterness, England's fans have been well received here, especially by the owners of hotels and bars. It was rumoured that one of the breweries was on 24-hour shifts during the Galle Test. Many Sri Lankans cannot understand why so many England fans have travelled, but the consensus in Kandy was that they were crucial to England's victory.

'Without the England fans' support, England would not have made it on the final day,' said one observer. It has been the first Asian tour of duty for a sizeable number of the Barmy Army. A few made it to India and Sri Lanka the last time England toured here in 1992-93 and only a handful were present for the duration of the Pakistan leg before Christmas. A few of the Barmy Army's many songs have been drowned out by whistling from young Sri Lankans. The only chants from the home crowd seem to be 'bowl him out' or 'we want Murali'.

Sri Lanka, as in Pakistan, have their 'chief supporter' who wanders among the spectators. His name is Percy and he carries his Sri Lankan flag at all times. He doesn't lead any chants, but points and jokes about the cricket. He also has a fondness for dancing, hugging and kissing as many England fans as possible.

England's followers have been well behaved and the only cause of concern to the Sri Lankan authorities has been the time-honoured tradition of drinking too much, taking your clothes off and trying to run across the pitch. There were two attempted streaks at Galle, which made the stadium manager furious. Security was increased at Kandy so there would not be any repeat occurrences in the spiritual centre of Sri Lanka. 'Special task officers' and 'brave guards' were in place and dogs patrolled the boundary fence. There were also thorough searches on entering the ground.

The authorities were also concerned that the Friday of the Kandy match was to be held on a full-moon 'poya day', a holiday for Buddhists when they must abstain from alcohol and meat. Announcements were made to warn that there would be no alcohol available at the ground. In fact a day off beer came as a relief to many, but the 'fish dogs' were considered a poor substitute to hotdogs.

The umpiring decisions were a bone of contention between supporters of both teams. At Galle, rumours of poor umpiring spread around the ground in minutes as many spectators had access to a television. In Kandy, I was sitting near a television and each time the dreaded finger was raised, both England and Sri Lankan fans would crowd around the screen. One Sri Lankan will never live down his comment regarding Dilshan's catch that 'the ball only touched the ground a little'.

The umpiring provoked some strong reactions from sections of both sets of fans. In Galle there were choruses of 'cheat' and angry finger-pointing towards Peter Manuel. In Kandy, BC Cooray was on the end of some harsh words from Sri Lankan supporters and was ridiculed on banners.

fields.headline: Top man - Darren Gough
fields.trailText: Man of the series in Sri Lanka
fields.body:
Man of the series in Sri Lanka

Fourteen wickets, taken at a cost of less than 20 apiece, earned him the man of the series award. He announced immediate plans to celebrate in declaring: 'It's time to go and get absolutely hammered.

'We knew it was going to be hard, but the team effort has been absolutely brilliant. After the first Test [against Pakistan in Lahore] I thought: "It's going to be one hell of a long winter," but I came back well after that.

'Here the spinners came in and did it when we needed them to, the seamers bowled well again and it was a great performance. We deserve everything we get.'
