webTitle: Cricket: Whetting the appetite for a delicious summer

fields.headline: Whetting the appetite for a delicious summer
fields.standfirst: England may not be the best - but they are a team
fields.trailText: Vic Marks says England may not be the best - but they are a team.
fields.body:
England have a team. They are by no means the best team in the world, but with the return of Michael Vaughan to the Test side there is now the expectation that every member of the eleven might make a significant contribution. That's a team.

This may seem a strange place to start after such an astonishing victory and it is also a a sad indictment of Graeme Hick, omitted from the Test side again - perhaps for good this time - but the blunt fact is that the sight of Hick walking out to bat in a sub-continental Test match this winter has had us clinging to hopes rather than expectations.

For Hick, Test cricket is an ordeal; for Vaughan a challenge. In his own quiet way, Vaughan, even though dismissed twice yesterday for eight runs, is excited by Test cricket, not intimidated by it. That makes 11. As Duncan Fletcher pointed out, Vaughan was fortunate to have Graham Thorpe at the other end when he started his important little innings on Friday.

Thorpe, at peace with himself off the field, which has not always been the case on tour, has been inspired on it this winter. He's taken dazzling catches everywhere and his batting in his last three Test innings has been brilliant. To use the Aussie vernacular 'Thorpe's been on fire' and he's been playing like the modern Aussie, too: grabbing the initiative as soon as he comes to the crease, racing to 30 in no time, counterattacking in a crisis. His 46 in the second innings at Kandy was crucial because of the pace he scored his runs. So it was on Friday in Colombo when England were stumbling in mid afternoon. Soon Murali, yes even the maestro, was bowling to him with just one slip and no one else around the bat.

For once, Murali's first instinct was to control the batsman rather than dismiss him. Once the field had retreated and his authority was established, Thorpe reined himself in, determined to keep Vaughan company as the young Tyke reacquainted himself with taut Test cricket. That's batting straight out of the Steve Waugh manual.

He seems to have been batting ever since then. Yesterday morning, with a little help from Umpire Orchard, he was stranded and unbeaten thanks to Chaminda Vaas and some dangling English bats.

Not since Graham Gooch's heroic knocks at Headingley against the West Indies and Pakistan in 1991 and 1992 respectively has one player stapled together an England innings with such isolated authority. And there he was again last night, just as he was on that gloomy - except for English cricket - evening in Karachi three months ago. Now he aped Steve Waugh as the iceman and the finisher.

Just as England were wobbling in pursuit of their incredibly meagre target, there was Thorpe as exhausted as he's ever been on a cricket field to see them home. They used to wonder about his commitment; he was too insular, didn't like touring much. Cricket wasn't everything to him. Now this sense of perspective is perceived as a strength. Thorpe is mature enough not to fret about the headlines or his place in the team. Now he'll go for the big shot, the one that relieves the pressure and accept the consequences if it doesn't come off, something he has done regularly in the past two Tests.

In recent times, England have not had many candidates for a notional World XI. On current form, Thorpe of the batsmen would be the first Englishman to be considered; Gough, of the bowlers, would demand a lengthy discussion. Yet again he has been superb. Sub-continental pitches don't worry him any more. No longer does his body look strained as he strives for extra pace. He's a big boy now; the puppy fat has gone and the central contract system should keep him going for a while.

Individually, England's bowlers are not a terrifying prospect, especially in the sub-continent - especially their spinners. Steve Waugh and co, while recovering from their humiliation in Calcutta, will not be spending much time debating how they are going to combat the twin threat of Giles and Croft this summer. Indeed, when the Australians are in England it is highly improbable that both spinners will play, and quite possible that neither will.

We won't embark here on a treatise on the resurgence of English spin. Before this match Giles had taken one for 239. But in Colombo we saw for the first time since England were in New Zealand in 1996-97 two England spinners in harness undermining the opposition. The current duo are unlikely to go down in the annals of the game alongside Laker and Lock but they are contributing at crucial moments.

Giles has certainly been hampered by his dodgy Achilles; he may have been hampered by his startling success in Pakistan. It's easy for delusions of grandeur to set in even for the most level-headed of characters; this can result in placing four men around the bat instead of two, which was too often the case in Kandy. Here in Colombo pragmatism returned. He went back to basics: conservative fields at the start of his spell, pressure bowling rather than the pursuit of the unplayable ball and, as he slowed his approach to the wicket, his control improved. After his traumas in Galle and Kandy, this was a gutsy performance from Giles. Again here was a man stimulated by the situation, who was at his best when the match hung in the balance.

That's a team. webTitle: Cricket: Thorpe battles fatigue  to claim England glory

fields.headline: Thorpe battles fatigue  to claim England glory
fields.standfirst: Hussain's double triumph completes winter of content
fields.trailText: Graham Thorpe batting at the start and at the end of an astonishing day of Test cricket, in which England secured their second series victory of the winter and their fourth in succession. In between Thorpe's two unbeaten innings, England, with a flawless display of outcricket that was both intense and controlled, contrived to bowl the Sri Lankans out for 81 to set up a stunning victory by four wickets.
fields.body:
Graham Thorpe batting at the start and at the end of an astonishing day of Test cricket, in which England secured their second series victory of the winter and their fourth in succession. In between Thorpe's two unbeaten innings, England, with a flawless display of outcricket that was both intense and controlled, contrived to bowl the Sri Lankans out for 81 to set up a stunning victory by four wickets.

'Bring on the Aussies' was the cry, though not from Nasser Hussain. Even in his jubilation there was the measured, common-sense reaction to England's latest triumph that has been a characteristic of this touring party. 'No, I'm not going to give you boys a "Bring on the Aussies" headline. One step at a time.' Even so the thought of having a crack at the Australians was hard to resist in the glow of another superb victory.

Hussain and Thorpe professed themselves to being shattered, knackered and incredulous at England's win. It was debatable whether they would have enough energy to celebrate with gusto. If they try Hussain will have to hobble to the bar; someone may have to carry Thorpe, but after a performance of such monumental skill and courage (he scored 145 runs without being dismissed in a bowler's match), there will be no shortage of volunteers to get him there. Thorpe was the undisputed man of the match; Darren Gough was declared Man of the Series.

Hussain said, 'When we turned up we thought it was just another day of Test cricket, but it's been an unbelievable day.' He outlined the strength of his side throughout the series: 'Losing three tosses out here could have been a massive psychological blow. In the old days heads would have dropped in that situation.' Not any more. How has the change come about? 'From the coach, the captain [he's never been one for false modesty and no one begrudges him that] and from winning.'

He identified the Kandy Test as the crucial one. That kept the tour alive. Here in Colombo he announced to his team after they had been bowled out for 249 in their first innings with a meagre lead of eight, 'This is now a one innings match. Forget how tired you are or when you are going home.' But no one could quite believe that this one innings match would be over in two sessions; moreover this dedicated bunch only allowed their fatigue to hit them after Ashley Giles called Thorpe for the winning run at 6.12pm.

It was an extraordinary day from the moment it was announced that, despite cloudless skies and intense heat, play would be delayed for half an hour because condensation had left a damp patch on the pitch. There was nothing wrong with this pitch; it was similar in character to those in Galle and Kandy, yet 22 wickets were to fall in the day for 227 runs.

Eight players registered ducks yesterday and there was a record of 12 in the match.

England's start was ominous. In his first over Vaas removed Michael Vaughan and Craig White with consecutive and identical balls, which were edged to the keeper. Thorpe on 73 then had his one major slice of luck. Propping forward to Murali he gave a bat pad catch, which was taken at silly point by Russel Arnold, but umpire Orchard had not spotted the obvious nick. This match was better umpired than the previous ones: Orchard made some mistakes, but it's worth noting that Asoka de Silva, the inexperienced Sri Lankan had an excellent game.

Giles soon followed, edging Vaas, who was to achieve his best Test figures, and Robert Croft, after another handy little innings, was run out before Thorpe swept Murali to record his eighth Test hundred. Only a few lusty blows from Gough alongside the imperturbable Thorpe enabled England to take a slender lead.

It was soon wiped away as Sanath Jayasuriya, determined to return to his old swashbuckling ways, crashed four boundaries. But Atapattu, hopelessly out of touch despite his double century three weeks ago soon lobbed an easy catch to mid-on and in the next over Sangakkara edged Caddick to the keeper. Then the irrepressible Gough intervened a second time. A full-length inswinger crashed into Jayasuriya's front pad and umpire de Silva quite properly sent the Sri Lankan captain on his way.

Now the Sri Lankans rallied briefly as de Silva went for his strokes. But Caddick, usually the mechanical bowler in the side, duped him with a brilliant piece of cricket. De Silva pulled him for a boundary dismissively. The response of Caddick and Hussain was unusual, to say the least. The man on the square-leg boundary was brought up to save the single. Next ball de Silva, eyeing the gap in his favourite area, pulled another boundary; he seemed to be winning this stormy little duel. Now Caddick bowled his slow off-cutter and this time de Silva clipped the ball into the diving hands of - who else? - Thorpe at square leg. I can safely say this is the first time that Caddick has taken a Test wicket with that off-cutter.

Arnold's dismissal was also noteworthy for less good reasons. Croft bowled him a ball that ended up, after some juggling, in the hands of Hussain at slip. Orchard signalled to the third umpire, one BC Cooray, thereby implying that the ball had been edged but that he was unsure whether it had been caught cleanly. Cooray gave the correct response - it had carried - but there were grave doubts whether Orchard had been right to conclude that the ball had ever hit Arnold's bat on its way to first slip.

Now the Sri Lankans disintegrated against a rejuvenated Giles. He took four cheap wickets including the vital one of Mahela Jayawardena and had a hand in the other remaining dismissal, which epitomised the brilliance of England's outcricket. When Fernando top-edged a hook off Gough, Giles, no gazelle and nursing that dodgy Achilles, dived forward at long leg to take a beautifully judged catch. Murali summed up the Sri Lankans' disarray. When he came out to bat against Gough he didn't bother to take guard and he was out, lbw to his third ball, trying to reverse sweep Giles.

Even so England's pursuit of 74 was not without alarms. Although the required total was so small Hussain said that he had rarely known the dressing room so nervous. So much hinged on attaining that target. Atherton avoided the indignity of being out to Vaas in every innings of the series; instead he became the only man to be dismissed by Fernando as he offered a gentle return catch. Jayasuriya, rather than Murali, whom England have neutered so decisively throughout the series, caused the most problems.

Murali did manage to bowl Vaughan through the gate, but Jayasuriya disposed of Trescothick cutting, Stewart prodding, White sweeping and finally with three runs required England's lame captain was grabbed at silly point. But Thorpe, even though he was dizzy with fatigue at the start of his innings - they had thought of dropping him down the order - was not going to move until this memorable match was won.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 100 die in explosions at flats
fields.body:
100 die in explosions at flats

More than 100 people were killed and 38 injured as explosions tore through four blocks of flats in the northern Chinese city of Shijiazhuang. Police blamed 'criminal elements' for the blasts, which took place before dawn on Friday. One explosion occurred near the local Communist Party headquarters. Everyone in the five-storey building appeared to have been killed. Another blast brought down one of a line of five-storey apartment blocks. All the victims appear to have been ordinary workers.

Change of plans for Mir space station's final journey

The Russian space station Mir will crash to earth on Thursday, not Tuesday as previously predicted, say officials. The flightpath for its journey has been changed so that it will not fly past Japan, because of fears of falling debris, before it plunges into the Pacific.

Pyramids tourist stabbed

A woman Japanese tourist was stabbed yesterday by a man trying to steal her camera during a visit to Egypt's pyramids. Police chased and opened fire at the attacker, wounding him in the leg. The attack happened next to the second pyramid in Giza, the twin city of Cairo. The tourist's condition was 'stable'.

Fury at threat to Vatican radio

Catholic officials have denounced an Italian government threat to cut off electricity to the Vatican's radio station. Its broadcasts have led residents to complain of interference with home appliances, and to voice fears of leukemia from radio mast emissions.

Five shot in nightclub fracas

Five people were wounded outside a Lisbon nightclub early yesterday. Three individuals opened fire at guards who had refused them entry. The trio escaped by car.

Haider's copyright

The Austrian far-right politician Jörg Haider, above, has copyrighted his name to stop what he calls exploitation of his fame. He says politicians in Italy are using it in campaigning for elections.

Wolf cull row
Norwegian hunters yesterday killed a fifth wolf as part of their controversial cull of the animals. The hunt, launched to placate local farmers, has infuriated conservationists and Swedish environment officials.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: A part-time nurse was subjected to a vicious attack by an alleged sex offender at Britain's most violent prison.
fields.body:
Jail nurse attacked after being left alone with alleged rapist

A part-time nurse was subjected to a vicious attack by an alleged sex offender at Britain's most violent prison.

The nurse received 'horrific' injuries to the inside of her mouth and throat during the attack last month at Feltham Young Offenders Institution, near London.

She had been left in a room with a teenager on remand for multiple rape and false imprisonment and was only saved when other workers heard her screams. The nurse, who works for an agency contracted to the prison, has been too traumatised to give a statement to the police. The attack is not as yet being investigated as a sexual offence. A prisoner has been arrested and moved to another jail.

Gap year deaths inquiry opens

An investigation has been launched into the deaths of three British teenagers in a car crash in Malawi. Amber Montgomery, Arabella McDonald and Kate Morgan were killed in the accident, which did not involve any other vehicles. The girls were gap-year volunteer teachers.

Babies woman 'smeared'

Judith Kilshaw, who says she adopted twins bought on the internet, claims she is the victim of a smear campaign. Kilshaw says social services told court officials she showed confidential papers on the case to journalists. She fears being accused of contempt of court in a case over the babies' future, which continues Birmingham tomorrow.

Fishermen rescued

Eight British fishermen were rescued after their boat, Dean, sank off North-west Spain. Three were flown to hospital, with hypothermia. The rest were picked up by a Spanish rescue vessel.

Tatchell protests to embassy

Gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell has protested to the Belgian Ambassador in London about his treatment by bodyguards of Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe in Brussels two weeks ago. He claims he was assaulted.

Handcuff Houdini

A man appearing in court at Dover on gun and drugs charges escaped after persuading guards to remove his handcuffs.

Robbie's treasures

Robbie Williams's fans will be able to bid online - at www.sothebys.com - for some of the singer's most prized possessions. Items will include his king-sized bed, costumes from his videos, as well as hand-written lyrics from his hit single 'Angels'. Proceeds will go to charities that include Great Ormond Street Hospital and Unicef.

Maggot's fate

The triumph of the winning maggot in the Maggot Championships at Ditchling, East Sussex, was shortlived. A group of excited children, who had gathered to try to get a closer look, trod on the victor and squashed it to death.

Politician calls English 'rapists'

Welsh politician Michael Brittain has been reprimanded by Plaid Cymru bosses over allegedly racist remarks. The councillor told a BBC Wales current affairs programme that 'the English in every country they've been in, have raped and taken the wellbeing out of that country'.

Driver, 22, dies

A 22-year-old man was killed when his car hit a wall while being followed by police at Croft-y-Genau, St Fagans, Cardiff.

Harry Potter hits the screen

Harry Potter fans can get their first glimpse of their hero's film exploits today. More than 200 cinemas are to show a two-minute preview of the movie. Venue details are listed at www.harrypotter.co.uk.

Comic Relief set for £23m

Comic Relief is set to raise a record total after Friday night's TV marathon brought pledges of more than £23.5 million. More than 12 million viewers saw Jack Dee win Celebrity Big Brother, while Ali G's interview with Victoria and David Beckham attracted 11.9 million.

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers are: 1 3 15 26 45 46, bonus 48. Thunderball numbers are: 8 14 16 19 32, Thunderball 4. The Lottery Extra numbers are: 17 23 26 35 42 46.

webTitle: English hotels really are the last resort

fields.headline: English hotels really are the last resort
fields.trailText: English hotels are among the most expensive in the world but just one makes it into the top 30 in the latest guide to the globe's most luxurious places to stay.
fields.body:
English hotels are among the most expensive in the world but just one makes it into the top 30 in the latest guide to the globe's most luxurious places to stay.

Only London's Lanesborough merits a mention - at number 14 - in the American travel bible for the better-off, Zagat. Italy has three hotels in the top 30. The average cost of a luxury room in London is $403 compared with $319 in Rome and $278 in Hong Kong which boasts two top-ten hotels.

Scotland fares little better than England, with just one hotel in the top 100, Glasgow's One Devonshire Gardens. But Bath punches above its weight and is featured for the Royal Crescent and the Bath Priory Hotels.

The guide's authors say European cities are losing out to far-flung destinations favoured by the elite such as game lodges in South Africa, Caribbean idylls, palatial hotels in India and New Zealand Lodges.

'These hideaways take time and patience to get to but reward the well-heeled with the ultimate in service, comfort and exotic postcards to send back home. Head for some of the more unusual corners of the globe and you could be hobnobbing with an in-the-know elite,' they promise.

Independent tour operators said they are not surprised that other European countries, especially Italy and France, were ranked higher than England and Scotland.

'It comes down to service,' said Ted Wake, sales director of Kirker Holidays. 'We cover 50 cities and a third of our brochure is Italian. I would say the top five hotels in the world are Italian because they offer outstanding service for about half the price you would pay elsewhere.'

He said the travel business has become increasingly aspirational. 'People have higher life expectations now as well as life expectancy. They want to splash out. A lot of people have a wish list of places they want to stay and they use wedding anniversaries and birthdays as an excuse. People have done the adventurer bit.'

It is not uncommon for small groups of people to spend up to £45,000 on one, short trip, he said.

But English and Scottish hotels could miss out unless they catch up with the likes of the Ritz in Paris and the Cipriani in Venice.

'Some of them could be doing a better job for the money they are charging,' said Susan Kessler, managing director of Zagat in the UK. 'Many are actually continuing to raise their rates because they have invested huge amounts of money in upgrading.'

The boom in boutique hotels - small, elite establishments tucked away at exclusive addresses - could offer the boost London needs, she said.

London is described in the guide - which was based on the views of 12,000 travellers - as an 'in' capital which 'can't seem to introduce hip hotels fast enough'. Gleneagles and Turnberry are the only UK representation in the guide's top 50 resorts.

Get the best service

* Get the best rates: Call the hotel and always ask: 'Is this the lowest price you have?'

* Research online: You can usually find online-only bargains, including city hotel weekend packages and off-season discounts.

* Check the facts: Ask before you book about the room's view and facilities and inquire about airport transfers which many hotels offer. Get confirmation of the details faxed back to you.

* Hidden costs: Watch out for local hotel taxes which tend to vary greatly from country to country.

* Go against the grain: Beware of trade fairs which push up prices and festival weeks. Aim for off-peak for less crowding and more value.

* Complain: Call the front desk, ask for the manager and be calm but firm in your request.

Assume that any decent hotel will want to please you.

fields.headline: Haven could drown in blood
fields.standfirst: There are just 10 days to avoid a mass conflict that could draw in Nato, writes  Misha Glenny
fields.trailText: There are just 10 days to avoid a mass conflict that could draw in Nato, writes Misha Glenny.
fields.body:
Macedonia is now the apex of conflict in the former Yugoslavia following a decade as the only republic of the old federation to have escaped war. Leaders of both the Macedonian and Albanian communities have worked hard at staving off confrontation.

Successive Macedonian governments wooed the main Albanian parties with Ministerial seats and open dialogue. President Boris Trajkovski and the Prime Minister, Ljubco Georgievski, have persuaded nationalists that talking is the only way forward. In Arben Xhafari, leader of the Democratic Party of Albanians, they found an exceptionally reasonable and wise interlocutor.

The crisis was sparked by incursions of Albanian militants from Kosovo. Evidence is growing that growing small-scale clashes are radicalising both populations. The two élites are now holding back the dam of resentment. The next week to 10 days will probably decide whether floods drown the country in blood.

Its neighbours - Serbia, Bulgaria, Albania and Greece - have denounced the clashes and offered support to Macedonia. However, the fighting in Macedonia and the related conflict in southern Serbia have put extreme pressure on moderate Kosovo Albanians. The links between them and their kin in Macedonia are close, and the insurgent Albanian guerrillas there enjoy wide support in Kosovo.

If the situation deteriorates, the major land route between the northern and southern Balkans will be disrupted. Work on the reconstruction of the region will be harmed, and the little foreign investment will halt.

The Macedonian army is small and ill-equipped to deal with a popular Albanian insurgency. During flashes of tension in the last 10 years, there have been popular calls for the Serbian army to come to their aid. In eastern Macedonia, the preference is for the support of the Bulgarian army.

Throughout the last 10 years, Bulgaria has acted with wisdom and restraint. They have assisted Western policy whenever asked.

The Serbs, post-Milosevic, are co-operating on almost every level with Western demands. The Serbian government will be reluctant to intervene in Macedonia unless the fighting affects the insurgency in southern Serbia.

So, initially, a conflict in Macedonia would be a Kalashnikov war, with many civilian casualties in both communities.

This would change if the fighting spread to the capital, Skopje, and Ohrid, in the South-west. Skopje has a large concentration of Albanians, living cheek-by-jowl with Macedonians. Fighting would be ruthless. Regional forces and the international community would find it hard to stand by and watch the mutual slaughter.

Ohrid, which is roughly 50-50 Albanian-Macedonian, is a spiritual home of the Orthodox religion, and its history has a special resonance for Bulgarians. If Ohrid went up in flames, it would be a brave Bulgarian government that resisted calls from the Macedonians for fraternal assistance. If any neighbour intervenes, the southern Balkans will find itself trapped in a very dark hole.

All this will agitate the restless Albanians of Kosovo. Nato may soon find itself involved in the conflagration, whether it likes it or not.

Nato cannot deploy in Macedonia. It can, however, stop permitting the Albanian militants in southern Serbia and Macedonia to use Kosovo as their base. But using force against the insurgents is only half the story. The Macedonian government must concede some of the main Albanian parties' fundamental demands which it has often side-stepped. Firm action and political compromise is the only way out of a real nightmare.

fields.headline: The garden of Eden
fields.trailText: To the strains of Cornish bagpipes, two builders abseiled down the world's largest greenhouse and officially opened the Eden Project yesterday.
fields.body:
To the strains of Cornish bagpipes, two builders abseiled down the world's largest greenhouse and officially opened the Eden Project yesterday.

In the first hour, 3,500 visitors trod through the disinfectant-soaked matting laid as a precaution against foot and mouth disease, as the £86 million attraction near St Austell.

Its exotic plant-filled domes, known as biomes, opened up with the informality that is the project's hallmark. There was a buzz of excitement among visitors and staff, but no celebrity-filled stand or royal ribbon-cutting of the type that heralded the ill-fated Millennium Dome. Minutes after the opening, project manager Barry Johnson had his sleeves rolled up and was repairing a waterfall that refused to fall.

Tim Smit, a former record producer and the brains and passion behind the six-year project, whisked his family around for a last-minute tour before meeting the public.

However, the lack of famous faces did not dampen the spirits of those who first came through the doors. 'Usually these things are an anticlimax,' said Tim James, of the University of Cornwall Support Group. 'It is the best thing to happen to Cornwall for a century.'

Visitors loved the lack of signs ordering them not to touch things and telling where not to walk. 'Wow! said six-year-old Hugh McCann as he walked into the heat of the Tropics Biome. 'It's amazing, just like a real jungle.'

webTitle: 'I won freedom, but those years in jail smashed my life to bits'

fields.headline: 'I won freedom, but those years in jail smashed my life to bits'
fields.standfirst: Mike O'Brien wants to stop other wrongfully convicted prisoners suffering as he did.
fields.trailText: Mike O'Brien wants to stop other wrongfully convicted prisoners suffering as he did.
fields.body:
Mike O'Brien was three days shy of his twentieth birthday in 1988 when he was arrested for a murder he did not commit. His son was just three, his young wife was eight months pregnant for a second time, and he had forged a new relationship with his alcoholic father after a lifetime of acrimony.

Two years ago O'Brien finally won his freedom. He is now 33 and has only ashes to show for his life: his second child, a daughter, died in her cot when she was two months old; his wife left him a couple of months later for a string of other men; his father, broken by his son's imprisonment, drank himself into the grave.

'When I fought for freedom during all those years in prison, I thought I was fighting to get out from behind bars,' said O'Brien. 'But prison smashed my life to bits. It was when I got out that my troubles really started.'

O'Brien was one of the Cardiff Newsagent Three, wrongfully jailed for the 1987 murder of newsagent Philip Saunders, beaten to death with a shovel after a botched robbery near his home.

To this day, O'Brien cannot understand why the police decided to sacrifice his life to close the Saunders case, but when he left prison he swore to become the Crown Prosecution Service's worst nightmare, destroying the system which destroyed him with a strong and careful hand.

He fulfilled his promise last week with the launch of the Miscarriages of Justice Organisation, Mojo, alongside Paddy Hill, one of the Birmingham Six, in a Pugin-wallpapered parliamentary hall with the support of the Prime Minister and the Chancellor. After the ceremony, O'Brien told the full story of his nightmare for the first time, emphasising that his tale, however awful, is just one of dozens of similar stories throughout the country.

O'Brien was born Michael Bonello in Ely, Cardiff, in 1977, the second of six children brought up by his mother Marlene and their alcoholic and abusive step-father, Jimmy O'Brien. He was a lonely, painfully shy boy who escaped the constant bullying at school by wandering around the local wasteland until it was late enough to go home each night.

At 15, O'Brien left school and found work as a shelf stacker. Two years later he met his future wife: Donna Purcigo was just 15 but they fell in love immediately. When they married in 1986, Donna was eight months pregnant and they were both delighted. 'It was the most secure I'd felt in a very long time,' said O'Brien.

Kyle, their son, was born on 24 August, 1986. 'I couldn't wait to get him home and do all the silly things dads do,' said O'Brien. 'I wanted to bath him and play with him. I'd never been so happy.'

Despite their happiness, the marriage started disintegrating. Donna began having affairs and O'Brien followed suit. But the collapse of his marriage disturbed him and when he was attacked and sexually abused by an older man soon afterwards he fell into a deep depression, spending time in a mental hospital.

Donna became pregnant again and O'Brien turned to drink: 'I'd always refused to touch alcohol because I'd seen what it had done to Jimmy, but I didn't even think about Jimmy; I just turned to the first thing that gave me comfort.'

On 12 October, 1987 - the night Saunders was murdered - O'Brien, his brother-in-law Ellis Sherwood, and Darren Hall stole a car and went joyriding. 'It was the first time I'd done anything worse than nicking crisps, but I went along because I was too cowardly to say no,' he admitted. O'Brien was still in bed next morning when the police called. There were three cars and 10 officers. They surrounded the house and smashed the door down with a sledgehammer.

At the police station, O'Brien was refused a solicitor. 'They were shouting and screaming at me. They lied to get me confused and twisted my words to try to get me to admit to things I hadn't said. They wanted Ellis more than they wanted me because he already had a criminal record, but they said that if I didn't give evidence against him they'd take me down too. And that's what they did.'

Unable to keep O'Brien in custody for more than 72 hours without charging him, the police freed him with a promise that it was only just beginning. One week later, they burst into O'Brien's house a second time and took the 19-year-old to the station. This time he was charged with murder and taken to Cardiff prison on remand.

When Kylie, O'Brien's daughter, was born a few weeks later he was not allowed to attend the birth and could only see her for 15 minutes each day. 'The closing-up I did of my emotions in those first months was extreme, but I had no choice,' he said. 'I could only survive what was happening by cutting off entirely.'

Six months later, O'Brien had a visit from his solicitor. 'He said he had something important to tell me.' A priest was waiting for him and O'Brien was told to sit down: his daughter had died of cot death that morning. 'It wouldn't sink in,' he said. 'Half of me died that day; it was burnt out at the root.'

Two months later, O'Brien had another visit: Donna was leaving him. 'She smashed me to bits with that news,' he said. 'The rest of me died a few weeks later at the trial.'

The trial lasted for three weeks. 'As soon as it began, I knew we were finished,' said O'Brien. 'I spent most of the time just staring at my family: I wanted to make sure I'd remember them.'

O'Brien was sent to Long Lartin prison. 'I saw seven men murdered in front of me during my time there; one was stabbed in his groin, heart and his lungs,' he said. 'I had to learn to defend myself: I carried a knife in one pocket and a screwdriver in the other.'

O'Brien met Carl Bridgewater, Vincent Hickey and Michael Shirley during his years in prison, but the support of other innocent men was lost on O'Brien: he was losing control, taking all the drugs he could find and retreating into his own world.

Then he met Paddy Hill. 'Paddy was a hero to us all. He took me in hand. He told me that unless I started using my anger constructively, I'd spend the rest of my life behind bars. Something flick ered inside me then for the first time in years. I lay awake that night thinking, and by the morning I knew that he was right,' said O'Brien.

O'Brien visited the prison psychologist and the doctor. He began weaning himself off drugs and studying law. 'I saw how wrongly I'd been treated and how many laws the police had broken,' he said. 'My mind began opening up and I began fighting back.' O'Brien divided up his day: three hours for criminal law, one hour for human rights and one hour for prison law.

He organised press releases around every anniversary possible: the date of the murder and the date of his trial. He co-ordinated the first mass hunger strike across 20 prisons around the country.

'We began getting headlines and I realised the scope for publicity was there.' He successfully sued the then Home Secretary, Michael Howard, twice: once for allowing prisoners to be stripped and searched on CCTV, and again when Howard banned journalists from talking to prisoners, winning his case in 1996. When Jack Straw reneged on the ruling a year later, O'Brien started the fight again, winning again in 1999.

'The screws tried to intimidate and threaten me. They moved me away from my family and took away privileges, but I tape-recorded their threats and each time I won,' he said. With Michael Mansfield QC as his barrister, O'Brien's efforts were re-warded: on 18 December, 1999, the Court of Appeal took under 20 minutes to quash the convictions of all three men. But after fighting for his freedom for 11 years, O'Brien found that problems began anew.

'For years I'd been living on my anger and frustration,' he said. 'That doesn't go away now I'm out: I never got a chance to see my son growing up, my daughter and father are dead, my wife is gone and my health, both mentally and physically, is wrecked.

'I thought I'd find freedom outside the prison, but it's not here,' he added. 'I don't know if I'll ever find it now.'

Five cases taken up by Mojo

 Headmaster Sion Jenkins was jailed for life in 1997 after being found guilty of murdering his foster daughter Billy-Jo, 13, at their home in Sussex. Jenkins claimed he found her body after returning from shopping but he was found guilty after forensic experts discovered blood spots on his clothes.

 Satpal Ram was convicted of murder after killing Clarke Pearce at a Birmingham curry house in 1986, despite witnesses' claims that he was protecting himself against a racist attack.

 Mark Barnsley, a 33-year-old father of three from Sheffield, was sentenced to 12 years for grievous bodily harm after being attacked by 15 students in a pub in 1994. He claims the students were drunk and under the influence of drugs.

 Eddie Gilfoyle was sentenced to life in 1993 for killing his pregnant wife and faking her suicide. His counsel, Michael Mansfield QC, maintained that crucial evidence had been destroyed or discarded.

 Jamil Chowdhary was 25 when he was jailed for life in 1992 for the murder of a teenager during a robbery at a petrol station in Winchester. Chowdhary claims he was framed.

Jenkins claimed he found her body after returning from shopping but he was found guilty after forensic experts discovered blood spots on his clothes.  Satpal Ram was convicted of murder after killing Clarke Pearce at a Birmingham curry house in 1986, despite witnesses' claims that he was protecting himself against a racist attack.  Mark Barnsley, a 33-year-old father of three from Sheffield, was sentenced to 12 years for grievous bodily harm after being attacked by 15 students in a pub in 1994. He claims the students were drunk and under the influence of drugs.  Eddie Gilfoyle was sentenced to life in 1993 for killing his pregnant wife and faking her suicide. His counsel, Michael Mansfield QC, maintained that crucial evidence had been destroyed or discarded.  Jamil Chowdhary was 25 when he was jailed for life in 1992 for the murder of a teenager during a robbery at a petrol station in Winchester. webTitle: Cleared rap star could still face ruin

fields.headline: Cleared rap star could still face ruin
fields.trailText: The rap mogul Sean 'Puffy' Combs faces a billion dollars-worth of civil suits as he seeks to keep his corporate empire and image intact - in spite of his triumphant acquittal on charges of witness bribery and gun possession in Manhattan's federal court on Friday.
fields.body:
The rap mogul Sean 'Puffy' Combs faces a billion dollars-worth of civil suits as he seeks to keep his corporate empire and image intact - in spite of his triumphant acquittal on charges of witness bribery and gun possession in Manhattan's federal court on Friday.

In an unusually candid interview with the New York Times, Combs yesterday confessed that he wishes he had shed his 'gangsta' act years ago. He also wept when questioned about his break-up with fellow superstar Jennifer Lopez.

Combs's entertainment, clothing and food companies gross more than $300 million (£200 million) a year and employ more than 400 people. But five lawsuits now threaten him, in an echo of the OJ Simpson case in 1994.

Simpson was acquitted of criminal charges, but civil suits carrying a lower burden of proof were successful, and crippled his image. The criminal case must prove allegations 'beyond reasonable doubt', while civil law only requires proof 'on the balance of probabilities'.

The suits against Combs include one filed by his chauffeur, Wardel 'Woody' Fenderson, an intriguing figure who dominated the courtroom as key prosecution witness, and who claims he was offered $50,000 by Combs to say a gun Combs had put in his waistband, later fired and recovered by police, belonged to him.

The management of the Club New York, in which the fracas took place on December 27, 1999, has also filed a suit, as have three of the people injured when Combs's fellow rapper and protege Jamal 'Shyne' Barrow opened fire.

A crucial ingredient in the civil hearings, unaffected by the criminal acquittal, will be affidavits that Combs used his power and influence to swagger in the club, thereby causing chaos around him.

Combs confessed in the New York Times interview: 'I am definitely a victim of my own image.' He has, he admits, spent 'too much time...strutting' his power and his wealth.

Pop's Bad Boy beats the rap

webTitle: People-zapper fires microwaves at the enemy

fields.headline: People-zapper fires microwaves at the enemy
fields.trailText: Riot shields and water cannon may soon be made obsolete by a revolutionary weapon that can stun a hostile crowd with invisible microwaves.
fields.body:
Riot shields and water cannon may soon be made obsolete by a revolutionary weapon that can stun a hostile crowd with invisible microwaves.

The US Vehicle Mounted Active Denial System (VMADS), a radar dish mounted on the back of a tank or jeep, is interesting British police forces.

The VMADS, or 'people zapper', uses a 'directed energy beam', according to a Pentagon spokesperson. 'When it comes into contact with skin it causes a sensation of heat to an uncomfortable level.' The Pentagon insists the beam causes no permanent damage - no one gets hurt, but the crowd or enemy soldiers retreat hastily.

The weapon harnesses the beams found in kitchen microwaves. Travelling at the speed of light, the energy of the beam penetrates less than a millimetre under the skin, quickly heating the skin's surface. This triggers the body's defence reaction: pain. When the subject moves out of the beam, the pain stops. Scientists will start testing the weapons on goats and humans soon.

Jane's Defence Weekly said recently the 'non-lethal' nature of some weapons 'might ... encourage military forces to use them directly against civilians and civilian targets'.

'It's part of this new political correctness on the battlefield,' said a spokesperson. 'The problem today in situations like Palestine is that you have adversaries mixing with innocent civilians. Forces now need a suite of weapons for different situations. You can score so many own goals by killing innocent civilians.'

Scientists have spent $40 million developing the weapon at the Air Force Research Laboratory, New Mexico. Demand for non-lethal weapons grew after the disastrous US military mission to Somalia in 1993, when marines died because they could not shoot back without hitting civilians.

The VMADS is the most sophisticated development in the search for the ultimate non-lethal weapon. The SAS recently began training with 'glue guns' that fire a web of resin from a gun-mounted aerosol. The resin hardens around opponents, paralysing them.

fields.headline: Feeding lies
fields.trailText: So now the consumer is to blame for the ills of British farming and the quality of British food?
fields.body:
So now the consumer is to blame for the ills of British farming and the quality of British food?

Let me tell Matthew Fort (News, last week) that food is cheap and extremely well regulated in the United States and in the rest of the European Union. In the US all beef is graded from prime to manufacturing; here all you know is that it is less than 30 months old.

Strange that I go to France to buy as much food (butter, cheese, salami, bacon) as I can carry because it is better quality and cheaper than here. When was the last time Mr Fort was told in this country whether his chicken was fed antibiotics or recycled chicken waste, or whether that free range label really meant other than that it was reared in a hut with a few holes giving access to grass?

No, the problem in this country is lack of regulations and standards for rearing and labelling for which we thank governments in hock to producers, manufacturers and retailers.
Charles Sinclair
Manchester

webTitle: Mothers put careers at risk with second child

fields.headline: Mothers put careers at risk with second child
fields.standfirst: A new study shows that women struggle to cope with work and more than one toddler - and 50 per cent leave their jobs. Report by  Ben Summerskill and  Sarah Ryle
fields.trailText: A new study shows that women struggle to cope with work and more than one toddler - and 50 per cent leave their jobs. Report by  Ben Summerskill and  Sarah Ryle.
fields.body:
Decades of progress for working mothers count for nothing once they have a second child, according to major new research.

Seventy-five per cent of mothers go back to work after their first baby, but half still drop out of the workforce completely after the arrival of a second child.

The confirmation of this 'second-child syndrome' is a setback for campaigners who believed that improvements in maternity leave and childcare would resolve the stark choice between career and family which has plagued women for generations. The research is the latest in a bewildering range of surveys into women and work which often offer starkly divergent conclusions.

'It's when women are pregnant with their second child, and have found it hard enough to cope with just one, that they decide they cannot cope with a full-time or even part-time job,' says psychologist Diane Houston from the University of Kent. Most of the 400 women tracked by Houston and her colleagues said they did not have the energy to juggle work with the social, health and educational needs of more than one child.

'We weren't intending to study the second child, but a number of our respondents got pregnant again very quickly. In terms of the actual choices that women make about working outside the home, it's the second child that makes the real difference,' said Dr Houston.

'I returned for two days a week after my first baby was born in 1998,' says Helen Dennis from Surrey, who was a senior nurse until she gave up work. 'He was cared for by a childminder. But I gave up completely after our daughter was born last year.'

Radio journalist Sinead Cooper, from north London, also gave up work completely after her second son was born last year. 'We just decided we were earning enough money, but never saw our eldest son. When they go to nursery you get into having to pick them up at 3pm. Trying to do that alongside any normal job is impossible.'

Author Rebecca Abrams, whose new book, Three Shoes, One Sock and No Hair Brush: Everything You Need to Know About Having Your Second Child, identifies 'second-child syndrome', says: 'Most women are totally unprepared for the impact of a second child on their working lives. It isn't just the cost of childcare, although that's important. It's the lack of time, the strain on relationships of having both parents in work, the complex logistics of working life with two children. All these factors together prompt - and sometimes force - women to re-evaluate their priorities.'

Richard Reeves of the Industrial Society said: 'Tragically, what we've done is replaced an unfair, but sustainable model of the family - where the women stayed at home - with a fairer but unsustainable model. The only outcome is likely to be that couples will simply stick to having one child. It's crazy.

'Too often it's not understood that having another child when you've already got one does not just require an incremental increase in time, energy and financial commitment. It requires a gigantic leap. There's still never enough asked about whether men can be permitted to do more and whether work itself can be more flexible.'

The Daycare Trust, which campaigns for better childcare, discovered last year that, far from becoming more family-friendly, almost a quarter of British employers now require some staff to work regularly between 6pm and 6am. Sixty-one per cent of working families now have parents away from home during early evenings, nights and weekends, and 34 per cent have a parent who works at weekends. The numbers are expected to double by 2007.

The second-child syndrome joins a catalogue of new studies into childcare and the impact of work on women and their careers. New research published last week by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, which tracked children over 30 years, suggested that children of working parents suffered from lower educational attainment. But Abrams cautions: 'It was a historical exercise. The children in that study were in childcare in the Seventies. Childcare conditions then were very different from what they are now.'

ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

The busy parent's survival guide

 Spend 'planning time' with your partner, to organise diaries, childcare, shopping.

 Menu planning for a week in advance takes pressure off weekday mealtimes.

 Don't overload. Ask friends and relatives to help share school runs and childcare.

 Make specific family time which cannot be cancelled, such as all going swimming on a Sunday.

 Involve the whole family in chores and meal preparation - it shares the load.

 Weekday mornings are stressful and chaotic. Plan as much as possible the night before - get clothes ready, organise packed lunches, etc.

 Use star charts to encourage the children to get up/get dressed/have breakfast. The domestic rush-hour is much easier when everyone's pulling together.

 Try going to bed 15 minutes earlier and getting up 15 minutes earlier - you'll feel less like you're against the clock in the morning and more in control.

Source: National Family and Parenting Institute.

fields.headline: Scared to tax?
fields.trailText: Neal Ascherson (Comment, last week) ascribes the lamentable state of welfare provision in this country to a management culture inherited from the worst traditions of British business. He is right.
fields.body:
Neal Ascherson (Comment, last week) ascribes the lamentable state of welfare provision in this country to a management culture inherited from the worst traditions of British business. He is right.

But surely a more important reason is the assumed refusal of most of the electorate to regard an equitable taxation system as an acceptable part of civic duty. The present Government hasn't dared seriously to challenge this assumption. If restored to office in the next election, it should. What's it got to lose, except pariah status?
Jack Seddon
Chesham, Bucks

fields.headline: False economy
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown says full employment is achievable. Problem is, half of UK jobs produce no 'real wealth', no resources or services useful to human life.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown says full employment is achievable. Problem is, half of UK jobs produce no 'real wealth', no resources or services useful to human life. These pointless jobs (many in financial services) have no effect except to move money around in databases, benefiting the rich. It used to be called usury. People burn up fossil fuels travelling to these pointless jobs.
Brian Dean
Chester

webTitle: Critics fail to see funny side of Pompidou's Pop extravaganza

fields.headline: Critics fail to see funny side of Pompidou's Pop extravaganza
fields.standfirst: Visitors are puzzled by huge and confusing exhibition of Sixties art
fields.trailText: Visitors are puzzled by huge and confusing exhibition of Sixties art.
fields.body:
Paris was supposed to go Pop this spring. Nostalgists were to be whisked back to the era of Mary Quant mini-skirts, uncomfortable inflatable chairs, Roy Lichtenstein cartoons and Andy Warhol screenprints of Marilyn Monroe and Elizabeth Taylor, all thanks to the world's largest exhibition of Pop Art at the Pompidou Centre.

Called Les Années Pop (The Pop Years), the exhibition was to be the great cultural event of the French year and likely to break box-office attendance records. It's also aimed at helping a younger generation to appreciate the revolutionary creative years in art, film, music and design between 1956 and 1968.

Department stores and boutiques have been getting in on the act too, stuffing their shelves with lava lamps, curvilinear plastic chairs and see-through Pop Art watches.

Haute couturiers are recycling the Sixties. Last week Paco Rabane launched his ready-to-wear collection for winter 2001-2002 with a plastic dress decorated with red pastilles (a copy of a Verner Panton design), as well as a sweater made of aluminium and Plexiglass.

'After so many years where everything has been black and white, or grey, after so many years marked by the dramas of Aids and drugs, the young generation today feels a need for a return to optimism,' says Catherine Grenier, chief curator of Les Années Pop.

'The exhibition comes at a moment when young people can no longer dream of a political utopia, but can dream of a cultural utopia. Indeed, Pop is one.'

However, many of the critics who reviewed the show last week saw it as a confused nonsense. Five hundred exhibits - including sculptures, paintings, films and music - have been stuffed into the sixth floor exhibition rooms with, they say, little art-historical coherence and no sense of fun.

One critic suggested that, with the sculptures of crushed cars, petrol pumps, old shower units and Claus Oldenburg's giant ice creams and hamburgers, it was more like a junk shop than an exhibition.

Le Figaro 's art critic Michel Nuridsany wrote: 'What's really good about the exhibition is that it shows Pop was not just an artistic movement but a spirit. It was born in England, spread through all of Europe, but was embodied, as in nowhere else, in America.

'But, because it's concerned to show the detail rather than the broad outlines of those years, the exhibition shows a profusion of things but loses sight of the essential too often.'

Some critics suggest this largely Anglo-American outburst of creativity isn't to French tastes at all. 'One doesn't laugh very much here,' wrote Hervé Gauville and Elisabeth Lebovici in Libération. 'Perhaps there's something in the Anglo-Saxon sense of humour which is incomprehensible to the conservative French spirit.'

The exhibition is pitted with Anglo-American gags: there's Richard Hamilton's 1956 collage 'What is it that makes today's homes so different, so appealing?' There's a picture of James Rosenquist wearing a paper suit and being eyed by average Americans in a street; there's Andy Warhol's 'Brillo Box dress'; and screenings of 45 films by Warhol, very short on laughs.

Gauville and Lebovici reckon the exhibition's problem is deeper than Gallic incomprehension. 'Like the pop art exhibition at the Royal Academy in London in 1991, this exhibiton wants to cover everything: junk art, neo-dadaism, new realism, the beat generation, happenings, capitalist realism, the architectural designs of the Archigram studio, the posters of May 1968, and - why not - the surrealist objects of Marcel Duchamp and Salvador Dali. It's all done according to the old principle: everything is in everything and the vice is in the versa.

'In our day, even to understand a movement, a group or an epoch, an exhibition based around a single artist would have been better. This type of sprinkling of exhibits which museums are very keen on doesn't enable one to get the full picture.'

The Richard Rodgers and Renzo Piano-designed building was deemed ideal for such an exhibition. In wearing its innards on its outside, the Pompidou Centre looks as though it had been inspired by Pop Art insouciance.

Visitors are guided through the rooms by chevrons painted on the floor, but there are side arrows leading off into little rooms filled with people and even more exhibits, some tiresomely kitsch, others badly displayed.

'I've had it,' said one frustrated American visitor, stomping away from David Bailey's photograph of Marianne Faithfull. 'You get lost in all the digressions. Where can a guy get a coffee round here?'

There's a picture of James Rosenquist wearing a paper suit and being eyed by average Americans in a street; there's Andy Warhol's 'Brillo Box dress'; and screenings of 45 films by Warhol, very short on laughs. Gauville and Lebovici reckon the exhibition's problem is deeper than Gallic incomprehension. 'Like the pop art exhibition at the Royal Academy in London in 1991, this exhibiton wants to cover everything: junk art, neo-dadaism, new realism, the beat generation, happenings, capitalist realism, the architectural designs of the Archigram studio, the posters of May 1968, and - why not - the surrealist objects of Marcel Duchamp and Salvador Dali. It's all done according to the old principle: everything is in everything and the vice is in the versa. 'In our day, even to understand a movement, a group or an epoch, an exhibition based around a single artist would have been better. This type of sprinkling of exhibits which museums are very keen on doesn't enable one to get the full picture.' The Richard Rodgers and Renzo Piano-designed building was deemed ideal for such an exhibition. In wearing its innards on its outside, the Pompidou Centre looks as though it had been inspired by Pop Art insouciance. Visitors are guided through the rooms by chevrons painted on the floor, but there are side arrows leading off into little rooms filled with people and even more exhibits, some tiresomely kitsch, others badly displayed. 'I've had it,' said one frustrated American visitor, stomping away from David Bailey's photograph of Marianne Faithfull. 'You get lost in all the digressions. Where can a guy get a coffee round here?'

webTitle: Billionaire is greedy to run New York

fields.headline: Billionaire is greedy to run New York
fields.standfirst: Mogul Michael Bloomberg is set to inject glitz into the race to be mayor, reports  Ed Helmore
fields.trailText: Mogul Michael Bloomberg is set to inject glitz into the race to be mayor, reports Ed Helmore
fields.body:
With New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani's eight-year tenure drawing to its close later this year, the city's political machinery is grinding into gear. The field of candidates has done little so far to quicken the pulse of voters. Most of them are diligent, civic-minded operators with none of the colour of Giuliani.

But one potential candidate may yet enliven the race: Michael Bloomberg, the financial information mogul with a fortune of $4 billion, is positioning himself as a Republican candidate.

Like any shrewd businessman, the 59-year-old former Wall Street trader knows the importance of test-marketing a new product - especially if the product happens to be himself. In recent weeks he has hired pollsters and advisers and conducted focus groups to determine whether New Yorkers will buy the product.

Inevitably, the first question he faces is whether voters will buy the main thrust of his argument: that running a city like New York is not a job for a political insider but is better suited to a man who knows how to run a multi-billion-dollar global business.

'What's being a billionaire got to do with it?' he said recently. 'I mean, would you rather elect a poor person who didn't succeed? Look, I'm a great American dream.'

He has switched his political allegiance from Democrat to Republican to have a better hope of winning, but what he may lack in political conviction - he calls himself a social democrat and fiscal conservative - he makes up for in self-confidence.

In his 1997 autobiography, Bloomberg by Bloomberg, he wrote that as a bachelor stock trader he 'had a girlfriend in every city'. He flies his own helicopter and jet and throws parties worthy of a billionaire. 'Do you want to know the secret of giving a good party?' he said. 'Number one, get a place that's a little too small, and number two, make sure that everyone who wants to come can't.'

He threw a Seven Deadly Sins party given by the Bloomberg office in London that included a 'lust room' with a 25ft-wide, purple satin-covered bed. He hired entertainers - representing avarice - to wave bundles of cash and shout: 'Money, ain't it gorgeous?'

Now divorced, Bloomberg is a big catch on the social circuit and a favourite of the gossip columns on both sides of the Atlantic. He's rarely without a statuesque blonde on his arm. But Bloomberg's professional life is at least as interesting as his personal one and his life has the rags-to-riches contours that Americans especially love. A bookkeeper's son from a blue-collar town outside Boston, he got into Harvard Business School on a scholarship and then joined Salomon Brothers. Fired in 1981, he was handed $10 million which he used to start a company that provides data to bond traders and has grown into a global information powerhouse with 150,000 subscribers, 79 news bureaux and 10 television networks.

In his opinion, running New York would not be so different from running his company. The mayor, he says, 'is the chief executive officer, not the chief operating officer'. The job is about 'coming up with a policy that tries to blend what the experts say with what's practical with what your constituents say'.

But others have doubts that business success and government bureaucracy are so easily married. 'Even though the city has come a long way since the Seventies in terms of being much more business-oriented,' says Felix Rohatyn, the financier credited with saving the city from bankruptcy in the mid-Seventies, 'how much you can really run the city like a business is very much an open question.'

Bloomberg's philanthropy has also been questioned. Last year he gave away more than $100m to more than 500 groups, among them the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Committee to Protect Journalists, the United Negro College Fund and the Gay Men's Health Crisis. 'Whether it's my work or my wisdom or my wealth, it's me.'

So what drives him? One clue lies in a paragraph from his autobiography. Describing the anxiety he felt about starting his own company, he wrote: 'Did I want to risk an embarrassing and costly failure? Absolutely. Happiness for me has always been the thrill of the unknown, trying something that everyone says can't be done, feeling that gnawing pit in my stomach that says "Danger ahead".'

So why would he want the mayor's job? 'Because everybody tells me that you can't do it,' Bloomberg said. 'Everybody says "unsolvable". And they're wrong.'

fields.headline: IT's all wrong
fields.trailText: So Tony Blair wants to train single mothers to fill the skilled IT shortage (News,  last week)? Well, I'm a single mother and for the last four years I've worked full time as a computer programmer, and I say, forget it!
fields.body:
So Tony Blair wants to train single mothers to fill the skilled IT shortage (News, last week)? Well, I'm a single mother and for the last four years I've worked full time as a computer programmer, and I say, forget it! Tight deadlines, stress and long hours (40-, 50- and even 60-hour weeks, sometimes working till 1am) make this the hardest job I've ever done.

The burgeoning technological emphasis means that you are almost certainly better off if you start out with a computer science degree (I didn't), and when my colleagues - all young, married men - go home, my next port of call is 24-hour Tesco followed by whatever cooking, washing and cleaning I can manage. Despite the job satisfaction I get, I wouldn't recommend it to any other single mother.
Stella Fisher
York

fields.headline: Pension fallacy
fields.trailText: I have just finished the article about hard-up pensioners (Cash, last week) and quite frankly I cannot understand the whinging tone. My wife and I live very comfortably on an income of less than £10,000 per year. We have wine with our main meal, have lunch out once or twice a week, buy clothes as and when required, own and drive a car, entertain friends, go to the theatre and cinema, occasionally, and have holidays.

Jack Woodburne
Lynton, Devon

fields.headline: Everton get a Tessem lesson
fields.trailText: Victory yesterday meant that, for the first time, Southampton have won five consecutive Premiership matches. This team, for so long one of the top flight's perennial strugglers, have entered spring with a flourish and can afford in their most optimistic moments to dream of Europe. As a result, their manager Glenn Hoddle is attracting jealous glances from Tottenham.
fields.body:
Victory yesterday meant that, for the first time, Southampton have won five consecutive Premiership matches. This team, for so long one of the top flight's perennial strugglers, have entered spring with a flourish and can afford in their most optimistic moments to dream of Europe. As a result, their manager Glenn Hoddle is attracting jealous glances from Tottenham.

It is not hard to see why Spurs want him. Having assumed control of an unremarkable team (familiar) in difficult circumstances (growing excitement), he has spent little money (pure joy) in creating a top-10 Premiership side (exultation).

The Tottenham fans also remember Hoddle's greatest days as a player at White Hart Lane while, unlike George Graham, his teams tend to play with a style that Spurs supporters, with little basis in recent history, seem to believe is their birthright.

Hoddle has a clause in his contract that allows him to talk to any team - not just Spurs - about management vacancies. If he agrees to leave, a transfer fee believed to be £800,000 would be payable to his present employers.

But if it is easy to see why Spurs want to tempt him away, it is equally simple to understand why he might stay. With an improving team and on the verge of moving into an improved new stadium, Hoddle could be taking the Saints into the most exciting period in the club's history.

The first half was certainly not the most exciting period in the club's history. The home side began brightly but failed to test Paul Gerrard despite a string of threatening crosses from right and left. Their quest for a seventh consecutive League clean sheet was helped by an Everton selection that, with all alternatives injured, featured Duncan Ferguson as their only forward.

On a wet, strength-sapping pitch, much of Southampton's early vigour appeared to have waned after the restart. Rather than attack down the wings they shot from distance, with both Matthew Oakley and Mark Draper guilty of poor efforts that flew high from outside the box.

But in Jo Tessem they had the one player happy to run with the ball and, in the 58th minute, he ran in the opening goal. The Everton defence stopped, anticipating a pass to the offside James Beattie, but Tessem simply skipped through, carried the ball 30 yards and scored off the advancing Gerrard. Three minutes later, Marian Pahars missed a gaping net from Tessem's right-wing cross.

Everton attacked only once they had fallen behind, but once they started never stopped. Despite a string of set pieces, however, they came no closer than Ferguson's 71st-minute header, turned over by Paul Jones.

fields.headline: Away blues hit home
fields.trailText: A magnificent performance by Don Hutchison pointed Sunderland to their first League win in seven matches. Hutchison scored twice and made another goal as Chelsea were soundly beaten.
fields.body:
A magnificent performance by Don Hutchison pointed Sunderland to their first League win in seven matches. Hutchison scored twice and made another goal as Chelsea were soundly beaten.

There could be no complaints from a side who have been almost invincible on their own ground. They led twice, but Sunderland oozed resilience with Hutchison, playing up front alongside Kevin Phillips, terrorising their defence. His side went on to complete a double, having beaten Chelsea 1-0 at the Stadium of Light in October, and even the most ardent Stamford Bridge supporter could not argue that they deserved it.

Chelsea paraded Kerry Dixon - the last player to score 20 goals for them in a season - before the game. Within 10 minutes Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink should have matched that record, set in 1990.

Hasselbaink was played clear by Albert Ferrer but unselfishly - some would have said unwisely - declined a shot on goal in favour of pulling the ball back to Jesper Gronkjaer. The pass, however, was slightly forward and Gronkjaer was ruled offside as he slid the ball over the line.

That golden chance came against the run of play, though. Sunderland, starting at a brisk pace forced three corners in the first five minutes, and when they won a fourth, Don Hutchison pulled a chance wide. Mario Stanic climbed high to knock a free-kick from Graeme Le Saux over the bar, and shortly afterwards Chelsea went ahead.

Hasselbaink sent a short corner to captain Dennis Wise, accepted the return pass and then delivered a low cross to the near post. There, Eidur Gudjohnsen cleverly scooped the ball up for Marcel Desailly to head in from almost on the line.

Sunderland were quick to reply, Kevin Phillips seeking out Hutchison who escaped the attentions of Le Saux to find Julio Arca, whose shot was blocked. Not to be denied, Arca curled in a free-kick for Hutchison to get in front of Frank Leboeuf and touch in the equaliser.

The pace of the game was relentless. Hasselbaink blazed over after Wise and Gudjohnsen created another opportunity. But a minute later Chelsea were back in front when Slavisa Jokanovic played Gudjohnsen clear of the defence, with Chelsea appealing - justifiably it seemed from a replay of the incident. Gudjohnsen turned inside a defender and scored off the crossbar.

Gudjohnsen was presented with another chance at a far-post position just before half-time, but this time his control let him down.

Leboeuf had to be alert with an interception as Hutchison tried to play in Phillips, then Stefan Schwarz twice had shots blocked as Sunderland started the second half as they had launched the first. Their reward came when Phillips directed his centre beyond the far post where Hutchison, from an acute angle, placed a precise header into the net.

A swerving drive from distance by Gavin McCann, turned aside by the diving Carlo Cudicini, kept the pressure on Chelsea, who cracked again to fall behind following more good work by Hutchison.

This time he turned provider, releasing McCann, who left Desailly on his backside before angling his shot wide of Cudicini. It was no more, at this stage, than Sunderland in general and Hutchison in particular deserved.

webTitle: Boksic is the key to Boro win

fields.headline: Boksic is the key to Boro win
fields.trailText: Alen Boksic versus the entire Newcastle United defence was always likely to be a mismatch and so it proved as the Croatian scored twice to considerably enhance Middlesbrough's survival prospects.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
Alen Boksic versus the entire Newcastle United defence was always likely to be a mismatch and so it proved as the Croatian scored twice to considerably enhance Middlesbrough's survival prospects.

Boksic is a class act, arguably as accomplished and effective as any striker in the Premiership and a man who has consistently scored against the best defenders in the world.

Here he confronted a Newcastle back four unable to keep a clean sheet for nearly five months and took advantage with two first-half goals that left Middlesbrough comfortably in command before the stupidity of Phil Stamp drastically altered the pattern of the game.

Stamp had already been booked when he scythed down Robert Lee in the 45th minute. The red card was inevitable and his reception from the bench as he headed down the tunnel was an indication of what they thought of him.

Coaches Terry Venables and Bryan Robson totally ignored the midfielder, whose crass challenge guaranteed an awkward second-half for Middlesbrough.

'Stamp should know better. He could have been in big, big trouble, but the players got him out of it,' said Venables.

Middlesbrough's 10 men defended with admirable determination after the interval, although they only emerged with a crucially important win after Newcastle's Nolberto Solano missed an 86th-minute penalty.

An equaliser would have been particularly cruel on Boksic, who opened the scoring in the 28th minute when he exposed Newcastle's marking to head in Christian Karembeu's free-kick.

Five minutes later, Boksic took his Premiership total for the season to 11 with a free-kick stylishly steered over the United wall and inside the post from the edge of the area.

'Two great goals from a great player,' said Venables. 'Alen showed again that he's simply a wonderful player. It's terrific to have somebody of his quality, but the rest of the team played their part.'

Carl Cort, back after a long injury absence, volleyed Newcastle back into contention on the hour. Stamp's popularity among the Middlesbrough hierarchy dipped even lower at that moment, but he was rescued by a climax that echoed Alan Shearer's miss from the spot as United lost the St James's Park derby against Sunderland earlier this season.

This time, Paul Ince brought down Carl Cort for a penalty disputed by the Middlesbrough players before Solano's effort rebounded from the bar.

Newcastle have now picked up only one point from their last 15 and even Robson is starting to look anxiously at the bottom end of the Premiership only weeks after they were ranked among contenders for a place in Europe.

Robson said: 'I am more aware than anybody that we've lost four of our last five games and might be getting sucked into the tip of a relegation battle.

'We are not there yet, but we have to warn the players about it.

'Give Middlesbrough credit for pretty good defensive work, but we had a chance after Phil Stamp was sent off. We missed one or two chances and a penalty.

'I am not going to complain about players who miss penalties but, if he had knocked it in, we might have gone on to win the match.'

The only disappointment for Middlesbrough was the loss of new signing Dean Windass, ruled out after ricking his back while picking his bag out of the boot of his car only hours before the start.

'I thought it wasn't a lucky omen for us,' admitted Venables. 'He really worked hard in training and was dying to play, so he's very, very upset. Dean was in agony and I'll be surprised if he's back very soon.'

fields.headline: Bradford 2 - 2 Man City
fields.trailText: Goater saves City's bacon to ward off Bradford threat
fields.body:
Shaun Goater's close-range equaliser allowed Manchester City to cling on to their hopes of Premiership survival but their performance suggested it will take a Herculean effort, such as the one performed by Bradford 12 months ago, to avoid relegation. For Bradford, of course, the issue is becoming largely academic as a return to the First Division looms ever larger.

It is still extremely hard to predict whether Manchester City will follow them down with Middlesbrough staking their own impressive claim for the position third off bot tom. Ultimately, City may yet be saved by Boro's incompetence and victory at Valley Parade would have further enhanced their survival chances. They looked well on course for just such a result in the 23rd minute when Gerard Wiekens capped a spell of pressure by shooting the visitors in front.

Darren Huckerby, a lively early presence from attacking positions wide on the left, won a free-kick for a foul by Gary Locke and himself sent a long free-kick to the far post where Steve Howey headed back across goal for the unmarked Wiekens to finish, unconvincingly, from eight yards.

But this City team never does anything simply - when has one ever? - and some mediocre defending for the remainder of the first half presented Bradford with a number of chances which better teams would have accepted.

Ashley Ward squandered the best as he found himself with only Nicky Weaver to beat in the 25th minute but struck the ball straight at the keeper. Later Stuart McCall's snap shot flew two feet wide of the post and Benito Carbone wasted a promising position by skipping to create space for a shot which he hit directly at Laurent Charvet.

But City failed to heed those warnings, with disastrous consequences as an untimely substitution saw Bradford score twice in five minutes early in the second half. Robbie Blake and Eoin Jess both had long-range shots saved by Weaver before Joe Royle brought on Jeff Whitley to galvanise a midfield in danger of being over-run.

His decision to replace Huckerby, rather than the ineffective Tony Grant, seemed odd. It seemed catastrophic a minute later when Blake equalised. Ward poked through a clever little pass and, with the midfield absent and the defensive line back-pedalling, Blake was given time and space on the edge of the area to shoot past Weaver.

Five minutes later, the pattern was repeated. Gareth Whalley was gifted the space to try a shot from the edge of the area which Weaver could only parry into the path of Blake. The initial strike was blocked but Ward was on hand to force it over the line.

In the 70th minute, City salvaged a point after Jeff Whitley's through ball caught the Bradford defence square and appealing for offside while Goater pushed the ball beneath the body of Gary Walsh.

fields.headline: Dogfight at the bottom
fields.trailText: The tension at the bottom of the Premier League got worse yesterday, with the gap between St Mirren and Dundee United being cut to one point.
fields.body:
The tension at the bottom of the Premier League got worse yesterday, with the gap between St Mirren and Dundee United being cut to one point.

St Mirren were given fresh hope of avoiding the drop through the Steven McGarry goal in the first half which brought them a 1-0 win over a St Johnstone team not only hampered by injuries, but also by suspensions.

Dundee United came from behind to draw 1-1 with Aberdeen. Robbie Winters gave Aberdeen an early lead but Charlie Miller got United's equaliser with a penalty awarded for handball against Derek Whyte.

United were then saved by defender Jim Lauchlan, who produced an outstand ing tackle on Darren Young.

Hibs, with Russell Latapy conspicuous by his absence, were disappointing at Dunfermline. A superb volley by Steve Crawford gave Dunfermline a half-time lead, and after Tom McManus had missed two glorious chances to bring Hibernian back on level terms, Steven Hampshire put them further behind after 58 minutes.
