webTitle: Too much talent, not enough grit

fields.headline: Too much talent, not enough grit
fields.standfirst: Arsenal's old warhorse, Tony Adams, needs to gee up a work-shy strike force if his team are to progress.
fields.trailText: Into the quarter-finals of the European Cup, in which they will face Valencia, the semi-finals of the FA Cup and second in the Premiership, Arsenal would seem to be enjoying a successful season. Why then, do they give such an impression of underperforming?
fields.body:
Into the quarter-finals of the European Cup, in which they will face Valencia, the semi-finals of the FA Cup and second in the Premiership, Arsenal would seem to be enjoying a successful season. Why then, do they give such an impression of underperforming?

The answer surely lies in the depth and volume of talent that Arsène Wenger has assembled. With such an array, it never surprises you that they win matches, but genuinely does when they don't. At times they remind you of Tiger Woods; with his game 'ossum' as the Americans call it, he should win everything.

Then you remind yourself that football, sport, is never just about talent. If it were, Holland would have won the World Cup in 1974. It is also about industry and attitude, character and determination. George Graham's Highbury mantra of a decade ago - 'desire plus talent equals success' - summed it up. The problem in Graham's latter days was that there was simply not enough talent.

Wenger was fortunate when he took over as manager that he still had access to the reservoir of desire. It may well be that now, however, the balance has shifted too far the other way. If the manager decides to extend his contract beyond the summer of 2002 - and he has insisted that he will at least see it out, even if noises out of Barcelona put him in demand there - he may have to sacrifice some of the talent for more of the desire; some steel to go with the style.

He himself is forced to accept the point that in a season that has seen Arsenal suffer more heavy defeats than in living memory - in Moscow, at Anfield and Old Trafford - there have been flaws in the psyche of the team. 'I feel in some games we have been lacking in character,' he admits.

Never has it been seen in Tony Adams, whose intention to retire in 15 months' time will give Wenger an even bigger hole to fill. Of late, back to fitness, Adams has often been seen rampaging upfield as if to reinforce a message to some of the gifted but laissez-faire members further forward that attitude is as important as aptitude.

Adams has already said that this is probably the most talented squad he has known in his 18 years as a first-teamer and that there should be a trophy in it this season. So, after the limp performance in Munich on Wednesday, is it time for him to be telling the team as much? 'I've done that,' he says. 'The time for talking is past.'

He personally is not too concerned by Arsenal's stumbling into the quarter-finals, and being seen as the weakest of the last eight. 'I don't mind people saying we are not good enough,' he says. 'That's what they said in '94, through every round of the Cup Winners' Cup. Even after we won it, people were saying we weren't good enough.

'What is happening at the moment is talk of extremes. But we are not as bad as people are saying, though I have to say that we are not as good as we think we are sometimes.' It is classic Adams; always seeking the balanced view as well as reminding his team that effort is still needed to accompany ability.

Just as Manchester United have six midfield players and strikers who can win a game on their own any given day, even if five are misfiring, so do Arsenal. The difference is in the work ethic and fierce competition that those six also bring to the team. Unlike United's, frequently when they lose the ball, some of Arsenal's forward players shrug their shoulders and wait for it to be returned to them, rather than join in the collective attempt to recover it.

Thierry Henry especially, along with Sylvain Wiltord and Robert Pires - the latter pair fined earlier this season for some late-night, pre-game revelries that also betray a lack of solidarity with the team - can be particularly culpable. It is at odds with managers' assertions that teams should both attack and defend as units. It has also given Arsenal an uncharacteristic them-and-us, individualistic feel at times, defence divorced from attack.

As a consequence, Patrick Vieira - probably still pining for Emmanuel Petit alongside him - has looked isolated in his attempts at the marriage- guidance role of holding it together and implementing the cherished Arsenal system of shielding the back four, the more so when Ray Parlour is injured. In addition, the older legs at the back are suffering from more fatigue than they should be. Take this from Lee Dixon after Munich on Wednesday: 'I felt tired in the last 10 minutes but then I looked over at Tony and he looked more tired than me.'

Much has been made that their replacements, such as Igor Stepanovs and Oleg Luzhny, are inadequate - and indeed Arsenal were humbled 6-1 at Old Trafford when they were without any of their Olde Englishe rearguard for the first time in a decade - but you could only sympathise with the way the stand-ins were left exposed by forward players who absented themselves when the going got tough.

Wenger is clearly aware of the issue and the need to address it. Might he have to sacrifice some talent to recruit or instil some desire (and it is significant that the players he has been linked with in the past week, Sol Campbell and Marko Rehmer of Hertha Berlin, are both physically and mentally strong)?

'To sacrifice is difficult to say,' he replies, 'because at the level we play, to play without talent you have no chance. But also character alone is not enough. I believe we have talent and character but I concede in some games this year we have shown signs of weakness of character. Bayern Munich was one but we got away with it. Now, if we want to turn our season into a successful season we have to show character.'

Today at Aston Villa, in the sort of bread-and-butter away game that some at Arsenal have treated with apparent disdain this season, is a good starting point to rediscover some resilience for the huge challenges of a few weeks hence.

More of the attitude of Adams - determined to play despite a cold developed while being up all night with his ill son last Thursday - will be needed. 'It's an important game because I want to be in the Champions League again next season,' he says. 'The big games will take care of themselves. We need to take care of these ones ourselves.'

fields.headline: Aldridge resigns after Tranmere collapse
fields.standfirst: The end of an era as Aldo calls it a day.
fields.trailText: Tranmere Rovers manager John Aldridge resigned from his post on Saturday night, after watching his side allow a two-goal lead to slip against Barnsley. Rovers, rooted to the bottom of Nationwide Division One, lead through Scott Taylor and Jason Koumas, but Barnsley hit back to win 3-2. Isaiah Rankin was the man who eventually destroyed the home team in the last minute leaving Aldridge happy to tender his resignation.
fields.body:
Tranmere Rovers manager John Aldridge resigned from his post on Saturday night, after watching his side allow a two-goal lead to slip against Barnsley. Rovers, rooted to the bottom of Nationwide Division One, lead through Scott Taylor and Jason Koumas, but Barnsley hit back to win 3-2. Isaiah Rankin was the man who eventually destroyed the home team in the last minute leaving Aldridge happy to tender his resignation.

The Tranmere board accepted and that was that. After a tremendous FA Cup run this season, it was the club's league form that proved too much for the former Liverpool striker.

Paul Rideout, experiencing a new lease of life with Tranmere, at the age of 36, is continuing to cling to the hope that his playing career can be extended beyond this season.

When he joined Tranmere at the start of the season, Rideout planned that it would be his last and intended to concentrate on a coaching career in the United States from this summer. However, his impact at Tranmere, highlighted by his hat-trick in the remarkable FA Cup win at Southampton has prompted second thoughts. In an interview on Tranmere's official website, he explained: 'I did not realise how much I would enjoy it [playing]. I haven't had any offers for next season and that could continue, but I will sit down with my wife and agent and discuss things. It would be nice to feel wanted at my age.'.'

Rideout, who will be 37 in August, stressed that he cannot be compared with Aldridge, who was 39 when he finally called it a day as a player. Aldridge, he points out, was more of a goal poacher than he is. 'The gaffer just sat in the six yard box and was the best in the business at what he did,' Rideout said. 'There is nothing more important in football than a striker who scores goals.

'As for myself, I have not scored that many this season, although I have been helping out in other areas.'

Blackburn's manager Graeme Souness had warned that Wimbledon had the ability to bring his team down to earth after their midweek win over Birmingham, and it proved spot on.

Having emerged as strong favourites to fill the second automatic promotion spot behind Fulham, Blackburn were held to a draw - a result that helped Bolton increase their lead over their Lancashire neighbours from goal difference to two points. The one consolation for Blackburn was that it could easily have been worse. Wimbledon took the lead through Jason Euell, but Matt Jansen equalised near the end.

The biggest surprise was Birmingham's 2-0 defeat at Stockport. This game would have been of more than passing interest to Sven-Göran Eriksson; Stockport's striker, Shefki Kuqi, who is expected to face England in the forthcoming World Cup qualifier, scored both goals.

In addition to Bolton, the other winners among the promotion race leaders were Preston, who came from behind to overcome Norwich 2-1. Fulham took only 14 minutes to go in front against struggling Crystal Palace, through Luis Boa Morte, and he hit Palace again to make it 2-1.

Huddersfield, 2-1 winners over Sheffield United, increased the gap between Tranmere and themselves at the bottom to three points.

West Brom's manager, Gary Megson, was given a huge verbal pat on the back yesterday - from one of his biggest rivals. With West Brom facing Wolves at Molineux today, the Wolves assistant-manager, John Ward described the job Megson has done in getting his team into the promotion play-off zone as 'fantastic.'

This will be the first time that West Brom defender Matt Carbon and Wolves striker George Ndah have played against each other since the Carbon tackle that caused Ndah's broken leg last season. But Carbon insisted that Ndah bore no grudges towards him: 'I spoke to George after the incident to see how he was and again later on, and he was perfectly fine with me.'

fields.headline: Lennon: It's for real
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill seems to have given Lent a body-swerve, refusing to give up any of life's good things since the traditional period of sacrifice kicked in 18 days ago. In fact, the game has become sweeter for the Celtic manager, as his revolutionised team have streaked further ahead of a Rangers side in deep distress.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill seems to have given Lent a body-swerve, refusing to give up any of life's good things since the traditional period of sacrifice kicked in 18 days ago. In fact, the game has become sweeter for the Celtic manager, as his revolutionised team have streaked further ahead of a Rangers side in deep distress.

If the bookmakers' odds and the expectations of 99 per cent of Scotland's football followers are vindicated at Hampden Park this afternoon, however, O'Neill will be perfectly happy to abstain from a habit to which he has become unshakably attached in the past few months.

'We haven't won anything yet,' has been an almost daily retort from O'Neill to media representatives looking for comments on the Parkhead side's prospects of lifting the treble of Premier League championship, Tennents Scottish Cup and CIS Insurance Scottish League Cup.

The first leg, the League Cup final, will be settled between Celtic and Kilmarnock at the national stadium today and, despite a lengthy list of absentees from his recognised first XI because of injury, suspension and ineligibility, O'Neill will probably be as astonished as anyone outside the Ayrshire town if the favourites are beaten.

Goalkeeper Robert Douglas (cup-tied with Dundee), wing-back Didier Agathe (cup-tied with Hibs), Jackie McNamara and Alan Thompson (suspended) and Bobby Petta, Stilian Petrov and Chris Sutton (injured) make a formidable group, but an examination of O'Neill's resources reveal that he should be able to field a side capable of winning the cup.

Much depends on the availability of Petta, who, with Sutton, retains some hope of taking part. 'I'll give them until the last minute,' said O'Neill yesterday, 'and I mean that literally. They can have until the team bus is pulling away from Celtic Park to head for Hampden. If either or both come on the bus and say they feel ready, they'll be in.'

The unavailability of Agathe, Petrov, Thompson, McNamara and Petta would mean that Celtic would be without five of the seven players who contest the positions across the middle of O'Neill's favoured 3-5-2 formation. But having Lubomir Moravcik as a deputy for one place is no hardship and the so-far matchless duo of Neil Lennon and Paul Lambert remain intact.

If Petta were to start, O'Neill would have to resort to just one makeshift selection, either Tom Boyd, Olivier Tebily, or the young Irishman, Colin Healy, wide on the right. Without Petta, he could summon the experienced Stephane Mahe or the youngster, Stephen Crainey for the left flank. Either way, his defensive foundations - Joos Valgaeren, Ramon Vega and Johan Mjallby at the back and Lennon and Lambert in the middle - would be undisturbed and Celtic would still appear worthy odds-on favourites.

There are those who would argue that as long as Lennon and Henrik Larsson are in the team, no matter the identities of the other nine, Celtic would still be at prohibitive odds. Larsson's contribution is easy to measure - 44 goals this season - but Lennon has endeared himself to the Parkhead faithful as quickly and as deeply as a man bringing water to stranded desert travellers.

The Northern Ireland midfielder's commitment to the club was established many years before he actually signed, as he confirmed in a revealing conversation on Friday. The protracted negotiations for his transfer from Leicester City for £5.75 million caused some doubt about his willingness among Celtic supporters, but his contribution in the three months since he signed has brought an adulation which is likely to be heightened by his comments on O'Neill and his own allegiance to the Parkhead club.

'I think what Martin has done is to stamp his personality on the place. There was a certainly a feeling of déjà vu for me when I arrived. It was as though I'd never been away from him. Like the others who have come in, I was very quickly assimilated.

'It's what he puts into players' heads, how he makes them feel immediately part of the team. I go back to the day I signed for Leicester. He made me feel I was going to be the greatest player in Leicester City's history. Now, you don't have to believe that, but it doesn't half pick you up.

'My life changed dramatically the night he came to my house. I had been around the lower leagues for some time and I was going to sign for Coventry the next day. I might not even have been at home the night Martin called. He had John Robertson with him, and he was a hero of mine. They're real football men, my kind of people. Real coaches, and I like being coached.

'Leicester weren't even in the Premier League and Coventry were, but Martin persuaded me that they would go up and that they were going places. When I signed a new deal with Leicester City this season, I was happy and I thought the chance to join Celtic had gone cold.

'But I kept wondering if I'd done the right thing. I kept thinking, why didn't I force the issue the first time Celtic came? When they came back, I did force the issue and there is absolutely no doubt I did the right thing. And I would have signed for Celtic even if it had been another manager, rather than Martin.'

Kilmarnock, who lost 6-0 on their last encounter with Celtic, have a serious problem in attack, where there is a glaring goals deficiency and an ongoing difficulty with creating chances. The manager, Bobby Williamson, may resort to veterans such as Ian Durrant and Ally McCoist in the attempt at preventing the expected result.

But it is impossible to escape the conclusion that Celtic, no matter their personnel, are destined for the podium.
fields.bodyText: Martin O'Neill seems to have given Lent a body-swerve, refusing to give up any of life's good things since the traditional period of sacrifice kicked in 18 days ago. In fact, the game has become sweeter for the Celtic manager, as his revolutionised team have streaked further ahead of a Rangers side in deep distress. If the bookmakers' odds and the expectations of 99 per cent of Scotland's football followers are vindicated at Hampden Park this afternoon, however, O'Neill will be perfectly happy to abstain from a habit to which he has become unshakably attached in the past few months. 'We haven't won anything yet,' has been an almost daily retort from O'Neill to media representatives looking for comments on the Parkhead side's prospects of lifting the treble of Premier League championship, Tennents Scottish Cup and CIS Insurance Scottish League Cup. The first leg, the League Cup final, will be settled between Celtic and Kilmarnock at the national stadium today and, despite a lengthy list of absentees from his recognised first XI because of injury, suspension and ineligibility, O'Neill will probably be as astonished as anyone outside the Ayrshire town if the favourites are beaten. Goalkeeper Robert Douglas (cup-tied with Dundee), wing-back Didier Agathe (cup-tied with Hibs), Jackie McNamara and Alan Thompson (suspended) and Bobby Petta, Stilian Petrov and Chris Sutton (injured) make a formidable group, but an examination of O'Neill's resources reveal that he should be able to field a side capable of winning the cup. Much depends on the availability of Petta, who, with Sutton, retains some hope of taking part. 'I'll give them until the last minute,' said O'Neill yesterday, 'and I mean that literally. They can have until the team bus is pulling away from Celtic Park to head for Hampden. If either or both come on the bus and say they feel ready, they'll be in.' The unavailability of Agathe, Petrov, Thompson, McNamara and Petta would mean that Celtic would be without five of the seven players who contest the positions across the middle of O'Neill's favoured 3-5-2 formation. But having Lubomir Moravcik as a deputy for one place is no hardship and the so-far matchless duo of Neil Lennon and Paul Lambert remain intact. If Petta were to start, O'Neill would have to resort to just one makeshift selection, either Tom Boyd, Olivier Tebily, or the young Irishman, Colin Healy, wide on the right. Without Petta, he could summon the experienced Stephane Mahe or the youngster, Stephen Crainey for the left flank. Either way, his defensive foundations - Joos Valgaeren, Ramon Vega and Johan Mjallby at the back and Lennon and Lambert in the middle - would be undisturbed and Celtic would still appear worthy odds-on favourites. There are those who would argue that as long as Lennon and Henrik Larsson are in the team, no matter the identities of the other nine, Celtic would still be at prohibitive odds. Larsson's contribution is easy to measure - 44 goals this season - but Lennon has endeared himself to the Parkhead faithful as quickly and as deeply as a man bringing water to stranded desert travellers. The Northern Ireland midfielder's commitment to the club was established many years before he actually signed, as he confirmed in a revealing conversation on Friday. The protracted negotiations for his transfer from Leicester City for £5.75 million caused some doubt about his willingness among Celtic supporters, but his contribution in the three months since he signed has brought an adulation which is likely to be heightened by his comments on O'Neill and his own allegiance to the Parkhead club. 'I think what Martin has done is to stamp his personality on the place. There was a certainly a feeling of déjà vu for me when I arrived. It was as though I'd never been away from him. Like the others who have come in, I was very quickly assimilated. 'It's what he puts into players' heads, how he makes them feel immediately part of the team. I go back to the day I signed for Leicester. He made me feel I was going to be the greatest player in Leicester City's history. Now, you don't have to believe that, but it doesn't half pick you up. 'My life changed dramatically the night he came to my house. I had been around the lower leagues for some time and I was going to sign for Coventry the next day. I might not even have been at home the night Martin called. He had John Robertson with him, and he was a hero of mine. They're real football men, my kind of people. Real coaches, and I like being coached. 'Leicester weren't even in the Premier League and Coventry were, but Martin persuaded me that they would go up and that they were going places. When I signed a new deal with Leicester City this season, I was happy and I thought the chance to join Celtic had gone cold. 'But I kept wondering if I'd done the right thing. I kept thinking, why didn't I force the issue the first time Celtic came? When they came back, I did force the issue and there is absolutely no doubt I did the right thing. And I would have signed for Celtic even if it had been another manager, rather than Martin.' Kilmarnock, who lost 6-0 on their last encounter with Celtic, have a serious problem in attack, where there is a glaring goals deficiency and an ongoing difficulty with creating chances. The manager, Bobby Williamson, may resort to veterans such as Ian Durrant and Ally McCoist in the attempt at preventing the expected result. But it is impossible to escape the conclusion that Celtic, no matter their personnel, are destined for the podium.

webTitle: Why Gerrard cannot take it two games at a time

fields.headline: Why Gerrard cannot take it two games at a time
fields.standfirst: Liverpool's young midfielder will not be risked by England against both Finland and Albania.
fields.trailText: A funny thing happened on Thursday night at Anfield: Sven-Göran Eriksson saw Steven Gerrard as well as Robbie Fowler, Michael Owen and Emile Heskey.
fields.body:
A funny thing happened on Thursday night at Anfield: Sven-Göran Eriksson saw Steven Gerrard as well as Robbie Fowler, Michael Owen and Emile Heskey.

Gerrard played very well against Porto, and can confidently expect a call-up this evening into the England squad for the games against Finland on Saturday and Albania the following week. Except that Gerrard is unlikely to be going to Albania. After omitting him from the last squad so that he could take part in the Worthington Cup final, Eriksson appears willing to accede to Gérard Houllier's request to use the 20-year-old midfielder sparingly.

'The boy is still growing, and he is not ready to repeat games at that level,' Houllier said. 'International football is a step up from club games, and two games in five days would be too much. I am perfectly happy for him to be involved against Finland if Mr Eriksson wants him, especially as the game is at Liverpool. But going straight out to Albania would be too much of a rush, especially as it is the travelling that gives Stevie a problem.'

It is a sign of how highly Eriksson and Tord Grip rate Gerrard that they are apparently prepared to go along with the Liverpool manager's wishes. 'Mr Eriksson knows the situation, and in any case he would realise it for himself,' Houllier said.

Grip was unable to confirm that Gerrard would be in England's starting line-up on Saturday, although he seems certain to get the vote ahead of Nicky Butt in a midfield likely to feature David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Steve McManaman, but he indicated Eriksson had agreed to use the player cautiously. 'We know he can't play too many games in a row,' Grip said. 'If his club say he can't play in both these games we have to accept that. This will not always be the case, as Gerrard's strength is improving all the time. He has played in 35 games this season, I think, but only because Liverpool have been careful.'

Butt, who played well against Spain at Villa Park last month, will presumably get his chance against Albania. Midfield prospects such as Michael Carrick and Joe Cole should make the squad, but Butt's international experience at club level should count in his favour. Similarly, Eriksson seems ready to bring in Real Madrid's McManaman as a replacement for Nick Barmby on the left of midfield. After scoring the first goal of the new regime, Barmby can consider himself unlucky. He was one of England's best players against Spain and but for injury would surely have kept his place in the starting line-up.

McManaman was injured last time round, but is now back in action for Real, and not only playing well but playing on the left. 'He is doing very well, and playing on the left in every game.' Grip said. 'If he can do that for Real Madrid he can play in the same position for the national team.'

Between them, Eriksson and Grip place a great deal of importance on selecting players in their usual positions. The only player used out of position against Spain was Heskey, who played wide right in the second half, and Eriksson apologised about that afterwards. As far as Grip is concerned, the debate about Beckham's best position is a non-starter. 'He plays on the right wing for Manchester United, and I'm sure Sir Alex Ferguson would know if there was a better place to play him,' he said. 'I accept that United have Roy Keane in their midfield, but if that is where Beckham plays his football every week then that is where he will feel most comfortable playing for England. We don't have the players for long, it is too wasteful of time to give them new roles.We want them to feel confident and secure It is the same with Paul Scholes. If he plays in a certain position for his club then it is important to keep him in the same position for his national team.If we are going to change anybody's position, then there would have to be a very special reason.'

Grip habitually writes down the formation of every team he watches, so he can be sure which players he has seen in which positions. 'Some players can fill more than one position for their clubs - I have seen Gerrard in different roles for Liverpool,' he said. 'I have also seen Liverpool play Michael Owen as a secondary striker, playing slightly deeper than the front man, which is why we tried him in that role against Spain. I think it suits him. Perhaps he finds it easier to come into the game from there, where you are not so well marked. If you just play two strikers right up the field you make it easy for the opposing defence to know who to mark. I could see the big men in the Finland defence just soaking that up while the rest of the team waited to counter. But if Owen drops off the front man to pick up the ball he poses a problem for defenders, as well as finding the space to start his movements.'

Houllier, as it happens, is in complete agreement. 'I was not surprised Eriksson played Owen off Cole,' he said. 'No team plays with two strikers these days.' Liverpool actually play with four, and the lot of them could be involved at Anfield - with Jari Litmanen orchestrating the Finns' attacks. 'Jari is what every manager wants,' Houllier said, 'an ideal link between midfield and the striking line.'

Litmanen terrorised England in Helsinki after hardly figuring in the Barcelona side for months, so what he might do at his new home ground when approaching full fitness is anyone's guess. He is not the Finns' only dangerous forward - Charlton's Jonatan Johansson will also be playing in familiar surroundings - but if the evidence of the last game is anything to go by Litmanen will be the brains behind the operation.

How will England approach the game? 'Professionally, I hope,' Grip said. 'We need points, but we should not play into Finland's hands by storming forward at every opportunity. We must try to control the game in the same way Liverpool did against Porto. They controlled that game all night. They were excellent.' It sounds like England might be ready for a new SAS. Sven Admires Scousers.

fields.headline: Spain 7, Italy 0
fields.standfirst: Not a single place for Italy's finest in the European competitions' quarter-finals, while Spain have seven, and England four. Do Italians put money ahead of medals?
fields.trailText: There was a certain dignity about Paolo Maldini as he took the long walk across the San Siro pitch towards the dressing room. Milan had just completed the melancholic procession of Italian clubs eliminated from Europe.
fields.body:
There was a certain dignity about Paolo Maldini as he took the long walk across the San Siro pitch towards the dressing room. Milan had just completed the melancholic procession of Italian clubs eliminated from Europe.

While some of his team-mates made a cowardly dash away from the embarrassment and others crashed melodramatically to the turf, Maldini strode solemnly, shaking his head as he went. He was the only player whose body language expressed, unmistakably, that it was the club, not just the individual, who had been shamed. Oh, that it had come to this.

Back home Maldini has a hat-trick of European Cup medals. He is a veteran of the Milan of the late 1980s and early '90s, the Milan of maestro Baresi and Dutch wonders van Basten, Gullit and Rijkaard, the Milan of impeccable teamwork fused with irresistible flair. From halcyon days to dark nights: the Milan of today have lost their aura and that, for Maldini, is hard to stomach. They used to strike awe and dread into their opponents; last week Deportivo La Coruña arrived cocksure, relaxed and eager to take advantage of the tangible fear of the rossoneri. 'Everybody knows what Milan has done before in the past, but we won in Barcelona in front of more people than tonight,' remarked Deportivo's striker Roy Makaay dismissively.

San Siro, so what? In 66 days' time, this magnificent stadium, with its spacecraft architecture, its amphitheatre vastness, its smell of occasion - and its dreadful pitch - will host the Champions League final. How dearly Milan wanted to be there. One bang of a firecracker shuddered through the night air to signal the end of a dream - then you could barely hear a whimper as the fans filed silently away, reflecting the air of resignation among the majority of their idols, super-rich failures who later shrugged their shoulders at the media because they had nothing to say. What did we expect - apologies?

Read what you will into Billy Costacurta's icy disdain. Up in the tribune of honour the club's owner, Silvio Berlusconi, was surrounded by television cameras, grabbed a microphone, and blamed the coach, Alberto Zaccheroni, who had worn the look of a man expecting to be offered his last cigarette all game long. The press, generously as it turned out, reckoned the coach would be gone within 48 hours.

By morning Zaccheroni was history. There is a pattern here: of the eight Italian clubs who faltered in Europe this season, five have parted with a manager (Parma excelled themselves by sacking two) and Udinese are expected to follow suit any day now. There is no stability, and as a consequence Italian clubs' European status is in decline. Not since 1982 have Italy failed to provide a representative in the quarter-finals of European club competitions. (Let's not pretend Udinese's march to the final of the Inter-Toto pre-season kickabout is worth a popped champagne cork.)

The Gazzetta dello Sport summed it up with a stinging paradox: 'I ricci straccioni' - the rich down and outs. For all the zillions of lire coursing through Italian football, the clubs are poor in spirit, and consequently out of Europe. The Gazetta seethed about Milan's half- baked effort against Deportivo. It was symbolic of the country's football this season: 'Bombastic, arrogant and chased out of Europe.'

The inquest rages. One local journalist, with hangdog look and umpteenth cigarette, came up with a simple explanation: loadsamoney. Milan, he suspected, were more interested in being in the Champions League than winning it, the result of a guaranteed return of £8million per group phase. He envisaged a cycle of participating, picking up the profits, then going out to concentrate on finishing high enough in Serie A to qualify for more easy money again next year.

As if to prove his point, Zaccheroni insisted all season that a top-four finish was what was asked of him (past performances give Italian clubs four places in the Champions league). 'Would being told before the season to finish in the top three of the Premiership be acceptable to Manchester United?' asked the scribe. Italy is confronting the reality that Serie A has toppled from its European pedestal. Giovanni Trapattoni, coach of the national team, entered the debate by suggesting calcio take a long hard look at itself. It is important not to overdramatise, as Latin footballing countries are prone to do, but be rational. 'It's not that we have suddenly got much worse, but that the others have caught up with us,' he said. 'Until recently all the best foreign players played in our league. Not any more. We had a tournament with more class, more fantasy and the best tactical preparation, which gave us the potential to be at our best in the cups. Not any more.'

Instead we look to Spain. There can be no more powerful case made for the strength of La Liga than their current European domination. Ten years ago in the Uefa Cup quarter-finals, it was Italy 4, Spain 0. Now it's Spain 4, Italy 0. Over in the Champions League, it's Spain 3, Italy 0 (even more emphatic than last year's 3-1 scoreline). The biggest boon is the arrival of competition debutants Deportivo - to join more experienced campaigners Real Madrid and Valencia - at the expense of the Italians. 'In the first stage Juventus was the favourite and we finished first, this time Milan was the favourite and we finished first again,' points out Makaay. 'We have a good team, we have demonstrated that in La Liga and in Europe. The most important thing was to go through, although being first in the group makes it even better. Very nice. Now we have fun.'

Beware, Leeds. In contrast to the rampant top dogs Spain and the chasing pack from England, Italy, the most decorated nation in European competition over the past decade, has endured extraordinary humiliation. Internazionale take the ignominy prize for being dumped out of the Champions League qualifying round by the Swedish club Helsingborgs, and following up by blowing their second chance in the Uefa Cup, appropriately against a Spanish club, little Alaves. There is a morality tale here. Inter, who have gone through nine managers and more than £250 million-worth of players since Massimo Moratti took over in 1995 (return: one Uefa Cup) conquered at home by Alaves? Che? Inter were mortified.

World Champion Laurent Blanc launched a scathing critique: 'I've been here a year-and-a-half but results demonstrate that we're not a great team or a great organisation. Something is missing... heart, character, gameplan, personality, initiative.' It begs the question, what do they have? The answer is a glut of expensive players whose egos are as delicate as eggshells.

Liam Brady, who wore the Inter shirt during his spell in Italy and remains a great friend of their current manager, Marco Tardelli, believes this is the root of their problem. 'It is the curse of the squad system. At this level, there are too many players who think they are first choices. We're not talking about 15, as you find at Manchester United, but 25. It must be a headache to pick the bench. When I played for Juventus [champions two seasons running] the team picked itself. We had five or six substitutes who were young, realised they had to learn, and accepted their position. Now, players who expect to be in the team but aren't cause trouble and therefore the coaches aren't able to create a team spirit that can flourish. It's difficult for the coaches in Italy to find a winning character.'

Inter's 'ultras' rail that the problem is not only one of numbers, but also of nationality. According to a recent report in the magazine Rigore , 80 foreigners have arrived this year alone in Serie A , yet only 27 are considered regulars. If there is a lesson there it has escaped the newspaper Tuttosport , still obsessed with the manic movement of players. Small forests are dedicated to endless speculation. On the day of Milan-Deportivo, page one insisted the rossoneri were hot on the heels of Lyon's young whiz Sidney Govou, page three reckoned Sol Campbell and Fabio Cannavaro were close to joining Lazio, Chelsea were tempted by Filippo Inzaghi, while Juventus wanted Alessandro Nesta (maybe in exchange for Edgar Davids) although Patrick Vieira was their out-and-out priority, before pages four and five charted every squad's wantaways and wish lists. It goes on and on, rumour after rumour, page after page, day after day.

Brady adds a warning note: 'Some clubs in Italy thought money would buy success. They have been short-circuit ing to try to get success and it has blown up in their face. The problem is that team planning is done by the directors, not someone technical like Alex Ferguson, Arsène Wenger or David O'Leary.'

Meanwhile, back in Milan, Berlusconi acted swiftly to replace Zaccheroni. Paolo Maldini's father, Cesare, was quickly installed as caretaker coach alongside former club captain Mauro Tassotti. The pair have 12 games this season to make a positive impression - and qualify for next season's Champions League, of course. If not, the feisty Turk Fatih Terim, who walked out on Fiorentina not long ago, is the hot favourite to try his luck next season, although Marcello Lippi is also said to be in with a shout. Take your time, Signor Berlusconi. Someone in modern calcio has to halt the costly compulsion for the quick fix.

Internazionale take the ignominy prize for being dumped out of the Champions League qualifying round by the Swedish club Helsingborgs, and following up by blowing their second chance in the Uefa Cup, appropriately against a Spanish club, little Alaves. There is a morality tale here. Inter, who have gone through nine managers and more than £250 million-worth of players since Massimo Moratti took over in 1995 (return: one Uefa Cup) conquered at home by Alaves? Che? Inter were mortified. World Champion Laurent Blanc launched a scathing critique: 'I've been here a year-and-a-half but results demonstrate that we're not a great team or a great organisation. Something is missing... heart, character, gameplan, personality, initiative.' It begs the question, what do they have? The answer is a glut of expensive players whose egos are as delicate as eggshells. Liam Brady, who wore the Inter shirt during his spell in Italy and remains a great friend of their current manager, Marco Tardelli, believes this is the root of their problem. 'It is the curse of the squad system. At this level, there are too many players who think they are first choices. We're not talking about 15, as you find at Manchester United, but 25. It must be a headache to pick the bench. When I played for Juventus [champions two seasons running] the team picked itself. We had five or six substitutes who were young, realised they had to learn, and accepted their position. Now, players who expect to be in the team but aren't cause trouble and therefore the coaches aren't able to create a team spirit that can flourish. It's difficult for the coaches in Italy to find a winning character.' Inter's 'ultras' rail that the problem is not only one of numbers, but also of nationality. According to a recent report in the magazine Rigore , 80 foreigners have arrived this year alone in Serie A , yet only 27 are considered regulars. If there is a lesson there it has escaped the newspaper Tuttosport , still obsessed with the manic movement of players. Small forests are dedicated to endless speculation. On the day of Milan-Deportivo, page one insisted the rossoneri were hot on the heels of Lyon's young whiz Sidney Govou, page three reckoned Sol Campbell and Fabio Cannavaro were close to joining Lazio, Chelsea were tempted by Filippo Inzaghi, while Juventus wanted Alessandro Nesta (maybe in exchange for Edgar Davids) although Patrick Vieira was their out-and-out priority, before pages four and five charted every squad's wantaways and wish lists. It goes on and on, rumour after rumour, page after page, day after day. Brady adds a warning note: 'Some clubs in Italy thought money would buy success. They have been short-circuit ing to try to get success and it has blown up in their face. The problem is that team planning is done by the directors, not someone technical like Alex Ferguson, Arsène Wenger or David O'Leary.' Meanwhile, back in Milan, Berlusconi acted swiftly to replace Zaccheroni. Paolo Maldini's father, Cesare, was quickly installed as caretaker coach alongside former club captain Mauro Tassotti. The pair have 12 games this season to make a positive impression - and qualify for next season's Champions League, of course. If not, the feisty Turk Fatih Terim, who walked out on Fiorentina not long ago, is the hot favourite to try his luck next season, although Marcello Lippi is also said to be in with a shout. Take your time, Signor Berlusconi. Someone in modern calcio has to halt the costly compulsion for the quick fix.

webTitle: Cricket: Fletcher fury over Flintoff injury farce

fields.headline: Fletcher fury over Flintoff injury farce
fields.trailText: As expected, Nasser Hussain will be taking no part in the one-day series. What was not anticipated, and what clearly rankles with the England management, is that Andrew Flintoff may also be ruled out of the series. Unbeknown to the management, Flintoff strained ligaments in his left ankle three weeks ago while playing soccer as part of Lancashire's pre-season training regime. This represents a terrible breakdown in communication for which Lancashire - and Flintoff - are to blame. Hussain will fly home on Tuesday along with Michael Atherton, Jason Brown, Paul Nixon and Matthew Hoggard. Flintoff has until Monday to prove his fitness. Duncan Fletcher, normally so non-committal in his public statements, is clearly very unhappy about this situation. 'We are very disappointed that nobody informed the England team management,' he said. One-day dates: 23 March (Dambulla); 25 March (Colombo); 27 March (Colombo).

webTitle: Cricket: Athey takes on the devil, by Will Buckley

fields.headline: Athey takes on the devil
fields.standfirst: 'Between us we'd played 120 years and there were laws we didn't know'
fields.trailText: 'Between us we'd played 120 years and there were laws we didn't know'.
fields.body:
Anyone who fleetingly believed that punk would change the world might have been surprised by last weekend's headlines. Certainly they would have been gratified that a state of anarchy had finally been declared, but perhaps somewhat disappointed to discover that all it seemed to involve was 15 men dressed in white muttering at each other and occasionally wagging a finger or chucking a helmet.

Ah well, time moves on and life is full of surprises. In one regard the headlines weren't over-blown. Matters become anarchic when 'there is a state of lawlessness due to the absence or inefficiency of the supreme power'. In Kandy the laws of cricket were broken with impunity and the umpires, while not quite absent, were clearly inefficient.

Not that this was entirely their fault. To recall the words used by Norman Lamont when he made his sole beneficial contribution to British political life, the umpires were 'in office, but not in power'. They were, to continue the analogy, as hamstrung as John Major at his weakest: bereft of respect, uncertain what to do and when they eventually resolved to do something entirely dependent on the Ulster Unionists, that is to say, the third umpire. And as he dithered, everyone criticised. Shortly thereafter, the Tory party imploded into irrelevance.

And last week that grandee of umpires, Dickie Bird, predicted that by October there would be no need for umpires. Now Dickie has no known form as a predictor of trends, but he can't always be wrong. And it is safe to say that it is not the most propitious time to be considering becoming an umpire. Which is exactly what Bill Athey is contemplating. Athey, numerous England caps, more than 20 years a cricket pro, three years a coach, is about to sit the exam that will enable him to become an umpire.

We meet at the cafe at Worcester station - not too far from his home in the Herefordshire countryside. It is a suitably anonymous spot to catch up with someone about to join such a put-upon profession. Why do it? 'The number of jobs in cricket is very limited,' says Athey. 'It's not like football where you have 92 clubs. In cricket there are only 18 and if one has just got rid of you [he was coach at Worcestershire until they terminated his contract] that leaves 17. It's a very narrow field.'

Last month Athey and fellow professionals Tim Robinson, Richard Illingworth and Rob Bailey went on a four-day course. 'There were laws that came up and we thought "We never knew that" and between us we've played for about 120 years.' The lbw law? 'No, the slightly more obscure laws. Most players know the bones but the devil is in the detail.'

So what has gone wrong recently? 'Umpiring at Test level is a tremendously hard job,' says Athey, 'which is made even more difficult by the players' attitudes and more difficult again by everything being scrutinised, not only in slow-mo but super slow-mo. Umpires are only human and their confidence can be shattered within the first half-hour of a Test.'

And then the players take advantage? 'Well, they think we'll test this bloke out, keep shouting and he'll give something. It happens in village cricket. It happens everywhere. Cricket has an image of it being a gentlemen's game.' He exhales, almost raises an eyebrow. 'Well, I'll leave anyone to make up their own minds after watching on television.'

Indeed, despite all the nonsense written about the game's great traditions of honour and dignity, it has always provided opportunities for chicanery and skulduggery. The problems arise when, as with Mike Gatting and Shakoor Rana years ago, matters bubble out of control. On that occasion it was Athey who stepped in between England captain and Pakistani umpire. 'When that blew up,' says Athey, 'I remember Tom Graveney being quoted as saying this has been going on for 38 years.'

Nothing new under the sun, but time for something to be done. 'Everyone's agreed on that. The players know it, everyone knows it. The umpires feel they're the most put upon people in cricket.' Little wonder because they are placed in the invidious position of having all the responsibility and none of the power. Uniquely, they are charged with keeping control of the game but have no sanctions to aid them. They can't penalise or dismiss a player, they can merely threaten to report them to the ineffectual headmaster - the match referee - after play ends for the day - a fat lot of use when it comes to defusing potentially inflammatory situations. 'There's talk about bringing in penalty points,' says Athey. 'So that if a bowler is running on the wicket intentionally then the umpire will make the "patting for batting" sign and award five runs extra. And if a batsman does the same thing five runs will be awarded to the fielding side.' And why stop here? Why not give the umpire a yellow and red card, so that if a player flagrantly breaks the laws of the game the umpire has the power to first caution him and then dismiss him?

Of course, such decisions would be hard but the umpire standing in the middle would be best-placed to make them. Power would be transferred from the third umpire - who would be called upon to back up rather than overrule the umpire - to the man in the middle and the umpire would consequently have more authority and, if this is not abused, engender more respect. 'In the near future it could well happen if people keep going over the boundaries,' says Athey. 'And the players might think "bloody hell, if I carry on like this my team might be at a disadvantage".

Back to the current series. 'There's no doubt the umpires have been poor but you have to look at the bigger picture. Both England and Sri Lankan batsmen have stayed at the crease after they've known they were out.' Did you ever walk? 'We're not hear to talk about that.'

webTitle: Official: We're not as nice as we think we are

fields.headline: Official: We're not as nice as we think we are
fields.trailText: Britons are less liberal, more stressed, more dishonest and much less patriotic than we like to think. A major survey of private attitudes reveals today that our national image of ourselves as a high-minded and confident race is starkly different from the truth.
fields.body:
Britons are less liberal, more stressed, more dishonest and much less patriotic than we like to think. A major survey of private attitudes reveals today that our national image of ourselves as a high-minded and confident race is starkly different from the truth.

In a remarkable insight into Britain in the first year of the new millennium, the poll, carried out for The Observer, reveals that almost half of us would not consider marriage to someone of a different race and just 11 per cent of us are proud of Britain's history. And 33 per cent say that hooliganism makes us embarrassed to be British. We remain a nation that is certainly not at ease with itself.

In spite of greater affluence than ever before, and last week's announcement of the lowest levels of unemployment recorded for a generation, 32 per cent of Britons complain of money worries. If offered higher pay, half of us would still work the longest hours in Europe to take home more cash in spite of our claimed wish to improve our work- private life balance.

The poll also reveals the extent of the crisis facing Britain's drug laws. One in five 18-to 24-year-olds has consumed drugs unlawfully. And 12 per cent of the adult population has used hard drugs at some time.

One in 10 adults has shoplifted without being caught, and 5 per cent admit having committed a benefit, tax or insurance fraud.

We take an average of four days a year off work when not really sick - losing British employers 10 million days' work every month. And while 55 per cent of the population claim to be followers of the Church of England, 10 per cent of men - more than two million - have paid a prostitute for sex at some point in their lives.

Clinical psychologist Oliver James said: 'These results confirm a stark dichotomy between British people's public persona and their private morality.

'People's claim to be religious is often linked simply with a desire to believe in something bigger than them rather than any active belief in a Church. But a claimed belief in God doesn't necessarily connect with someone's own ethics.'

Ann McIntyre of ICM, who carried out the poll, said: 'Privately people are less liberal in their social attitudes than they appear to be when in public. It is, if you like, a political correctness factor. It's perceived as popular and fashionable to be liberal. However, polling people confidentially reveals less "acceptable" perceptions.'

On all social issues, younger people proved much more progressive than their older counterparts. Just one third of respondents said they supported gay marriage, now legal inthe Netherlands. But while 53 per cent of 18-to 24-year-olds support same-sex wedlock, backing fell to just 9 per cent of the over-65s.

'As a nation we have a superficial outward cloak of political rectitude,' said James. 'But while some talk about change and insist we all live in a modern society, this is an illusion fostered by politicians and reinforced by the media.

'British culture is incredibly resilient in all sorts of ways. It will take more than one generation to change deeply rooted views, whatever people might wish.'

However, the news that large numbers of Britons still feel uncomfortable with ethnic minorities or gays might bring little comfort to politicians keen to exploit issues such as race and the controversial section 28 in the run-up to a general election. The polling shows that on almost every issue involving social tolerance, key C1 voters - or the swing 'lower middle-class' electorate which brought Margaret Thatcher to power - prove to be more tolerant than their upper middle-class counterparts.

Conservatives will take succour, however, from the revelations that three in five people would educate their children privately and more than three-quarters would use private medicine, if only they could afford it.

ICM polled 1,200 people across the country. The full results of the survey appear in a special 64-page magazine with today's Observer.

webTitle: No strings attached: the happy singles

fields.headline: No strings attached
fields.standfirst: What do women want from a man? Not too much, it seems - sex, the odd bit of DIY. But increasingly they can do without cohabitation
fields.trailText: What do women want from a man? Not too much, it seems - sex, the odd bit of DIY. But increasingly they can do without cohabitation. Fiona Gibson meets a group of happy singles in Glasgow.
fields.body:
A friend in her late thirties confides that she intends to end a four-month relationship with a man who initially came round to plaster her living room ceiling. 'We have nothing to talk about,' she announces. 'No common ground. We do have very good sex - and I'll miss that - but I would like to have very good sex with someone I can talk to afterwards.'

Sounds reasonable. I wonder when she intends to inform him that his services are no longer required. 'In three or four weeks.' Three or four weeks having sex - even very good sex - with someone with whom you cannot communicate sounds like stretching it a bit. I suggest she deals with it sooner (these things are never easy, but cruel to be kind and all that). She explains: 'He's putting up shelves. I'll wait until he's done the bedroom because it's driving me nuts, having nowhere to put my magazines.' How we howl. I am reminded of my three-year stint as editor of more! magazine in the mid-Nineties, largely spent inventing features along the lines of 'Useful jobs for a boyfriend to have' and jacking up sales with supplements with titles such as 'Men: A User's Guide'. The whole premise was that men were to tease, have fun and frolic with; not 'please' or 'turn on' or crowbar into commitment as the previous generation of women's magazines had kindly instructed us. The editorial team - in their early twenties, like our readers - dreamed up 'features'; games involving the staff consuming enormous quantities of alcohol and pouncing on men enjoying quiet after-work drinks. On one occasion, the sole male staffer was 'auctioned off' and dispatched on a trip to the States with a young female reader who yelped with delight at having 'won' him. Which is precisely how young women are supposed to behave. We were raised on Just Seventeen - all cockiness and no-messing sex advice - not Jackie, in which agony aunts Cathie and Claire would sternly warn readers not to 'go too far' or 'let' boys fiddle with the clasps of their teen bras. The remainder of the magazine consisted of tips on ïgetting him to notice you', implying an awful lot of time dawdling about on drizzly football pitches, batting eyelashes hopefully.

In the Corinthian, a vast, ornate bar off George Square in Glasgow, there is major hair, make-up and flirtation going on. I meet a lively group of women. 'The older I get, the more picky I'm becoming,' says Jill Riddiford, a 36-year-old actress. 'The other night, a gay male friend and I were discussing how intolerant we'd become: how we ruled out men who were rude to waitresses or bank clerks, who were badly dressed, or too well-dressed' Jill has been single for three years and says: 'If you're not interested in marriage or children - and I'm not - you don't have that pressure to do the expected thing. The beginnings of relationships are great, that heady rapture, all that adrenaline flying around, but it's not a state that lasts. You can derive that excitement from other places like landing a great job.' Her friend Adele, 39, who works in market research, is on the verge of moving in with her partner of eight months. She is pragmatic about the arrangement: 'We met, like each other and I was looking for a flat - I feel OK about it. But I've been married before and am more cynical, less naive.' Comparing her current attitude to her younger self, she reasons: 'Now, I look for certain qualities - intelligence, humour - rather than just putting up with stuff. I think, does he make me laugh or bore me to death?' Adele admits that, if a relationship is not working, she is 'completely honest' and ended one liaison with a quick call to his mobile. She says: 'If I don't have children it's not the end of the world. I wouldn't feel out of the norm. And I wouldn't rule out bringing up a child on my own, if that's how things work out; a baby would have a good life with me.' In the next booth, a cluster of women in their late twenties swivel round in unison when a waiter brings a note from a group of men at the bar. Watching, amused, is Mags, a 29-year-old full-time mother whose 10-year-marriage ended at Christmas. 'Do women use men? Of course. They want to have their wicked way exactly in the way that men do,' she says. Mags concedes that she might 'catch someone's eye and get talking Ü if it happens, it happens. I don't want to get married again and I have two children so I could just do with a laugh, to be honest'.

Joan Smith, author of Moralities: Sex, Money & Power in the 21st Century believes that, rather than 'using' men, women are simply having lots of different types of relationships. 'When I was growing up, there was a clear template: date boys, get engaged, get married, have kids - and a relationship for life. It was how life worked. It doesn't any more. Women don't necessarily want men as partners in child rearing. Some like going out with lots of men; others want a passionate engagement with one person. There is no one pattern. It's a fantastically fluid situation.' In researching her book, Single and Loving It, author Wendy Bristow encountered two distinct attitudes: 'The man-obsessed 'he hasn't phoned" type and the phenomenally sussed woman who wants sex on a first date because, if the sex isn't good, she doesn't want to know.' One woman in her thirties told Bristow: 'Frankly I'd rather find out at the beginning than mess about and shilly-shally and be let down in the end. I've slept with 10 men and half of them have been bad in bed. That's 50 per cent of men. They were all lovely men, but no use in bed.' Bristow believes that the latter group of women 'aren't sex mad - just practical. We're seeing it across all ages. Women in their forties have had the big relationship, and look what happened. They love sex and miss it when they donÍt have it but don't necessarily want to live with a partner.' She reports that the late twenties/early thirties bracket appears to be 'the vulnerable group - more concerned with finding 'the one'. Increasing divorce rates affect the expectations of young, single women. 'The splitting-up of your parents inevitably brings down your own expectations of marriage,' says Bristow. 'We are seeing less of a desire to have a man at all costs. Most of the women I met in their twenties appeared fantastically confident, and many are not interested in a relationship. They just want lots of nice sex.' No-strings sex is a viable option. I left home at 17 to live in Dundee and hooked up with a gang of women who had arrived from various corners of England and Scotland. It was a heady, busy time; more phone numbers scribbled on hands than peering hopefully into jewellers' shops. A colleague from that time points out: 'We had absolutely no one to please but ourselves. The fact that we had escaped our parents' clutches meant there were no real restrictions on our behaviour. You wouldn't have been quite so eager to have a man in your flat if your mother was likely to turn up next day, banging on your door with a casserole.' We are more mobile, and richer than ever before. Between 1986 and 1998, an extra 15 per cent of women joined the workplace. 'We are seeing an extension of adolescence - physically and emotionally - and postponement of emotional development.' According to Weeks, there is a marked increase in the number of sexual partners and range of sexual experimentation during the 10 years after puberty. The 2001 Durex report reveals that 16 to 20-year-olds were 15 on average when they first had sex; over-45s were 18. 'Morality is not perceived in the same way as in previous generations,' says Weeks. 'The parents of women in their twenties and thirties - post-war baby-boomers - had comparatively easy lives and a desire to protect and do whatever they could for their children. Smaller families meant that those children could be indulged. We moved into a more permissive society.' Women are taking advantage of freedom that, until now, they have never had in such abundance'. She and her partner of three years split up recently and she is badgering her friend Elise to leave the bar and go dancing. 'I can't stand a night in. I'm out, flirting with millions of men, ripping the piss out of them Ü being a total bitch really.' To boost her ego? 'No.' For sex? She looks aghast. 'I don't do that. Some women do. I just lead men on. Tease them a bit. They should be able to take it.'

Ben Renshaw, author of Success But Something Missing, believes that women want what they have seen men having in the past. 'Given the fact that women are more emotionally mature than men of a similar age, they are perhaps better equipped at playing the dating game and handling it well.' Renshaw adds that women's increased earning power and associated work commitments mean that 'time is at a premium. Women are less prepared to put up with relationships that are clearly not working - and freedom is a highly prized commodity'. Hardly surprising, then, that we are seeing a decline in agony aunts' advice on snaring a man and hauling him, yelping for mummy, to choose flowers and agree on the order of service. I ask Karen McKee, a single 30-year-old advertising assistant at Radio Clyde, how she would react if a partner appeared to be steering her towards marriage and Mothercare. 'Panic. Friends used to say, 'Wait until you're 30 and you'll change your mind"; here I am, 30, and I haven't.' She has been the one to end most of her relationships: 'I always seem to do the splitting-up. I'm straightforward about it; I don't believe in playing games. I'm not willing to put up with nonsense.' Karen acknowledges that she and her peers have a different - though not necessarily easier - agenda than that of their parents: 'My mother was married at 21 and had me at 24. Sex felt dark and scary Ü the prospect of all that fun and fumbling marred by rumours that you could get pregnant by having a bath after your brother and, weirdly, passing a boy on the stairs. The Durex Report 2000 reveals that 40 per cent of women using condoms take the responsibility for buying the condoms themselves. I witnessed a fantastically direct pick-up recently. The ratio of women joining internet dating agencies is growing. However, Danny Smith at www.midsummerseve.com, says, 'You will find fewer women attaching photos to their profiles than men. Women seem to prefer to look out for a chap they like the look of and then make the first move - rather than allowing any number of strange men contact them.' Mary Balfour, at the introduction agency Drawing Down the Moon, has launched a new dating service, Only Lunch, 'for those who want to meet casually, perhaps just for an hour. You're not giving up an evening'. There is mileage inthe 'low-pressure package', Balfour believes. 'It is becoming increasingly difficult to find a mate; the old matchmaking routes - extended family, factory floor - have long gone. fields.headline: Growing pains: the boys
fields.trailText: Iestyn Jones with the boys of generation next.
fields.body:
Ross is 17 years old. He plays in a band called Macer. His best friend Matthew, also 17, says that the band is going to be massive. Ashley is a year younger. He's not that bothered about the music, if he's honest, but he's still there at the foot of the stage, moshing with Matthew. Hip-hop is his life, he says, but he'll do anything for a laugh. Wayne, 17, says his liver hurts, so he's taking it easy tonight. Yesterday he was on work experience at Cash Generator, an electrical goods store, in Pontypridd. He sold a DVD to a woman who came in for a hairdryer.

All four are big music fans. 'I hate Eminem, though,'sneers Ashley, who rates the late rapper Tupac Shakur highest of all. 'I just don't believe in Eminem. He's a bad boy with a chainsaw onstage at his concerts, then he's a little kid with glasses in court.' Ross's creative influences jump straight off the pages of the New Musical Express - the Beatles, Jeff Buckley, Nirvana, Massive Attack. 'I'd rather see the up-and-coming bands at Clwb Ifor Bach [a fashionable Cardiff small venue] than the stadium bands,' he explains. Porth has a population of just 6,500. It charted at 199 in a report published last year by the Welsh Index of Multiple Deprivation; 198 places were worse off, 601 were better. Breaking the figures down, Porth would appear to be relatively free of child deprivation, and good on education and housing. Yes, the heavy industry has long gone and unemployment is higher than the national average (the figure for Rhondda Cynon Taff county borough is 0.2 per cent higher than the Welsh average of 4.5 per cent). But as the people from Porth can see, by surveying places just a mile or two away, things could be worse. With no knowledge of these statistics, Ross offers his own, far more succinct, analysis of the situation. 'Everyone's the same,' he says, with a shrug. 'Nobody's loaded, but nobody's living in poverty either. I like it here.' Ross, Matthew and Wayne are sixth-formers at Porth County Comprehensive, studying movement and drama A-level. Much to Ross's annoyance, there's no music department, but there is a cybercafe - though none of the boys seem overly interested in the computer hardware at hand. 'I'll send emails and go to chat rooms when I'm at home,' admits Matthew, 'but there's this group of nerds in school who are obsessed with Bill Gates.' They've noticed a lot more people staying on for sixth-form studies these days. The school no longer just concentrates on academic subjects, explains Matthew. 'They want people to stay on and make a bit more of themselves.' The boys have part-time jobs. Ross works in Somerfield in nearby Tonypandy, Ashley does the odd cash-in-hand job for his dad, who fits suspended ceilings, while Matthew helps out at 'The Res', Trealaw's Sports and Social Club. Wayne plays football for Porth Senior Seconds, AFC Rhondda under-17s and AFC Rhondda Senior Seconds. Ross works on his music. There's not a lot of time for mooching about. 'We don't see as much of each other as we used to,' admits Ashley, 'because of girlfriends and working an' that.' The geographical intensity of the area breeds local rivalries. Trealaw, where Ross and Matthew live, has a rough reputation locally. So does Trebanog, Wayne's home patch. Lads from each village look after their own. A symbolic example of this is the annual battle which used to take place over a bridge between Dinas and Trealaw. 'The story goes that thereÍs always been arguments over whose bridge it is,' explains Matthew. 'You'd have 10, 11-year olds, right up to 17, 18 fighting every St David's Day. Trealaw always had the advantage because we were up on the bank and we'd just pile them with stones.' Nobody knows of any boxing clubs around. Everybody's into martial arts these days. 'Bodybuilding is popular,' says Ross. 'You'd be surprised how many people our age are into steroids and that,' nods Matthew. 'They want to be big.' 'This comes from the guy who wanted to give up drink to keep his six-pack, by the way,' laughs Ross.

Occasionally they'd get stopped by police and have their booze poured into the gutter. 'Or sometimes the cops would just put it in the boot of the car and take it back to the station,' recalls Matthew with a smile. 'They'd give you this handwritten note, nothing official, just on an A4 piece of paper.' Ross and Co now spend their leisure time in pubs, although they are underage. 'But we don't get any hassle. It's money in their pocket, no matter where it comes from,' says Ross. 'It's not just to get hammered. Sometimes we'll go in for a game of pool and a pint,' continues Matthew. 'Then sometimes I go after work on a Sunday just to watch the rugby highlights, to relax. It's my dad's local, so they don't mind. But when you get younger kids going, that's when the owners start taking notice. Our parents donÍt mind. I've got my mobile on me, so if it gets really late, around three or something, then she'll phone me.' Occasionally, Matthew's mother will stay up until he gets home, just to make sure he's all right. There seems to be enough common ground between the generations to allow a certain level of trust and understanding. Surprisingly, perhaps, the boys have few complaints about their parents. Offering up something of a statistical anomaly, all four boys are from nuclear families. 'Generally, I think our parents understand the difference between their lives when they were teenagers and ours,' states Ross. 'That's one of the main reasons we get on OK.' 'They want us to turn out better than they did, in a way,' observes Matthew. 'They want us to go off to university. We've got more choices than our parents had.' 'There's more expected of us, though,' adds Ross.

'You don't want to go in there,' he laughs, ushering me upstairs to his room. 'Someone's in there, walking around the room wearing my boxer shorts.' Of course, they still get pulled up by their parents over phone bills and spending too much money. As for drugs,the boys say they don't use them but know enough to make an educated decision either way. Socially, they say, it's a loser's game - hanging about in shabby company, getting involved in violent crime. They know plenty of people who take ecstasy, particularly those who go on clubbing jaunts to Cardiff. 'I can't see the point,myself,' says Matthew, flatly. 'You wouldn't really want to take it round here, anyway, because there's not a lot of use getting that excited about things.' One complaint is that parents never seem to understand the idea of being 'friends' with a girl. Small wonder, considering the level of teenage pregnancy in the area. Statistics for outer London in 1996-98 showed an average of 42 pregnancies per 1,000 women between the ages of 15 and 17. In Rhondda Cynon Taff there were 68.7 per 1,000.

A girl in Matthew's street had had two children before her sixteenth birthday. By the time the second was born, the father of both was in prison. Even without being fed the facts, Ross is uncharacteristically judgmental. 'People in this community are more irresponsible, definitely,' he states. 'They're just so isolated in their upbringing. People are having sex a lot younger, to impress their mates or pretend they're more mature than they actually are.' 'Why they're getting pregnant ,though, is anyone's guess,' adds Matthew. 'It's not like we're short on advice about contraception.' Friday night upstairs at the Rhondda Hotel. The poster in the window advertises Macer's second gig, supporting local band Nine Mile Burn. Everyone's there in support including Ross's girlfriend Sarah, who's a couple of years older than him, and her livewire friend Debbie. She wears a tight black T-shirt printed with the words: ïI hate boys, but I love men.' There's a New Year's Eve air about proceedings; it feels like a special occasion. The girls are dressed up - mock Burberry, silky trousers, hair gelled into place. The boys are smart-casual, trying hard to look like they're not trying too hard. Everybody's hugging one minute and grappling the next, looking for half an excuse for some kind of playful physical interaction with a member of the opposite sex. Ashley's showing off his dancing biceps, Wayne challenges him to an arm-wrestling competition and beats him every time. Wayne's holding court about his work experience at Cash Generator. 'They took a grand today and I reckon I did almost half of that. I could make a fortune, I reckon.' Matthew and Ashley, meanwhile, are full of enthusiasm. 'Macer: remember the name,' says Matthew. 'In years to come you'll be telling people you saw them before they were famous.' A member of Nine Mile Burn's smaller entourage, probably 10 years older, looks on with a wry look as he discreetly rolls a joint out of sight of the management. The gig is like a stadium performance in miniature. The band has recorded some songs and distributed a few copies of a 'home-made' CD, so the audience is primed, bellowing every word to all four of Ross's songs, which are punctuated by covers of Nirvana and Beatles songs. After disappearing for a while with Sarah he returns to receive the plaudits and the gentle ribbing in equal measure. 'It was crap compared to last week,' he says, 'but it's what I love more than anything. I'm not that career-orientated. In a year's time I'll still be in school and hopefully the band will still be together. But beyond that, I don't know. I dream, but I don't plan.'

fields.headline: Gunfight ends ordeal for hostages
fields.trailText: A British engineer was last night preparing for an emotional homecoming after army commandos stormed the jungle hideout in Bangladesh where he and two colleagues were being held by tribal kidnappers.
fields.body:
A British engineer was last night preparing for an emotional homecoming after army commandos stormed the jungle hideout in Bangladesh where he and two colleagues were being held by tribal kidnappers.

The soldiers swooped shortly after dawn and found Tim Selby, from Oldham, and two Danes cowering in a bamboo hut. The kidnappers fled and the men were flown to safety in an army helicopter.

After being held for more than a month deep in the remote Chittagong hills, the three had been marched for six hours through dense teak and banana forests before being dumped in a hut on Friday night. Soldiers encircled the village at 6am yesterday.

They used loud-hailers to urge the kidnappers, who had already melted away, to surrender. They then fired several shots into the air. 'We found the hostages in one of the huts. They appeared panicked,' Brigadier Golam Rabbani said. 'The gunmen pushed us to our limits,' he added. Last night, however, sources said they suspected the hostages had been freed after a ransom had been paid.

The bandits, who seized the Europeans on 16 February while they were carrying out a road-surveying project, had originally demanded $1.8 million (£1.2 million). The kidnapped men's employer, Danish construction firm Kampsax, had beaten the price down to £100,000, sources had suggested last week.

Selby, 28, last night appeared to be unscathed by his ordeal. 'He is in pretty good shape physically. He is not ill,' said Jon Geddes, spokesman for the British High Commission in Dhaka.

His father Alf, 61, a retired deputy head, said confirmation of his son's release came after phone calls from the authorities in Bangladesh. 'I didn't have much time to speak to him on the phone and we still don't know exactly what happened.'

After celebrating with champagne, his mother, Margaret, 61, said she doubted the experience would deter her son from working abroad. She added: 'This has made me realise how precious people are. Without the support of all our friends and ex-colleagues, we wouldn't have been able to cope as well as we have.'

The engineers were flown to the capital, Dhaka, by helicopter. Their shirts and jeans were soaked in sweat, and the three looked exhausted on arrival, but waved to the diplomats and military officers who greeted them. They were taken to a military hospital for check-ups.

Their release came after four weeks of negotiations. Three Scotland Yard hostage negotiators had flown in.

Army officials last night maintained the hunt was continuing for the kidnappers - who were offered an amnesty deal two days ago. They are believed to be members of a dissident tribal faction opposed to a peace accord which ended an insurgency in the south-east hill region, 200 miles from Dacca.
