fields.headline: Relatives split by Oklahoma execution
fields.trailText: A bitter dispute has broken out among the survivors and relatives of the 1995 Oklahoma City blast over the impending execution of bomber Timothy McVeigh.
fields.body:
A bitter dispute has broken out among the survivors and relatives of the 1995 Oklahoma City blast over the impending execution of bomber Timothy McVeigh.

As McVeigh's death date draws closer, the minority of families who disagree with capital punishment are being ostracised. Some are now too afraid to express their views for fear of retribution.

Emmett Welch, whose 23-year-old daughter Julie was one of the 168 who died in the April 1995 bombing of the Alfred P Murrah federal building, has been sent hate mail and marginalised from the survivors' association after speaking out against capital punishment.

McVeigh, 32, who has never admitted guilt, is on death row in Indiana and is due to be executed by lethal injection on 16 May, the first federal prisoner to be put to death in the US since 1963.

The Gulf war veteran has waived his rights to further appeals. His only chance of clemency rests with President George Bush, an advocate of capital punishment.

The president at the time of the bombing, Bill Clinton, called for the death penalty within eight hours of the explosion. One of McVeigh's co-conspirators, Terry Nichols, is serving life imprisonment, but Oklahoma is about to spend £3 billion to retry him under state laws so that the death penalty can also be invoked for him.

The emotive case is a major setback to anti-death penalty campaigners, turning back what had been a growing tide of disquiet among Americans over capital punishment.

'A thirst for vengeance is so driving people here that they are poisoning themselves with it,' said Welch.

'I know one woman who - well, they'd better cut off one of McVeigh's ears and send it to her: she's so hellbent on seeing this man die.

'I know another woman who's aged 20 years in the past five. They need this execution. But rage and vengeance just destroys you, I know, I felt that way for the first year or so. That's what drove McVeigh. He was raging against the government - that's why this happened. But Americans are slow to learn.

'Killing him isn't helping anyone, I try to tell the survivors it doesn't bring anyone back - but they just treat me like the freak.'

Five other survivors told The Observer they backed Welch, but would not go on record. One woman said: 'I'm sorry to say I've lied in the face of the others. I'm not going to stand up and say "That boy shouldn't die" because they'd be looking to lynch me.'

The split has been cemented by last month's opening of a new memorial centre next to the site of the bombed building.

Among its exhibits is a buckled steel door and the broken and battered belongings of visitors and staff inside it. The centre also shows TV footage from the day, as well as eyewitness reports and emergency services' tapes.

It includes a display on a successful campaign led by Glen Seidl and Diane Leonard, whose spouses died, to speed up the appeals process associated with capital punishment.

Leonard went to Washington to lobby politicians before McVeigh had been convicted.

'We decided that this immense tragedy called for a positive aggressive response,' she said. 'I didn't want a killer sitting comfortably on death row for 17 years when we'd give anything for 17 minutes with our loved ones.'

But Welch and anti-death penalty groups like Amnesty International believe applause for their efforts is a political statement out of place in a memorial.

'How many of those 168 people would want another death? I don't know and they don't know,' said Welch.

A spokeswoman for the centre said Welch was 'out on a limb'. The majority of Oklahoma people share the views of Peggy Broxterman, whose 43-year-old son died.

'I do feel a little bit of sadness for his [McVeigh's] dad and sister,' she said. 'But as for the punishment, I'm thrilled to death. It's a big, big burden off my heart and when he dies I feel I can get on with life.'

The emotional toll on Oklahoma City has been high. About 20 per cent of its population knew a victim or knew someone affected by the massive 4,800lb homemade bomb.

The victims ran into thousands: hundreds were injured, and there have been several related suicides.

Ajamu Baraka, director of Amnesty International's US anti-death penalty programme, said: 'We have been expecting some national backlash but we feel strongly that on principal we must be as visible in the McVeigh case as any other.'

fields.headline: Our Manics in Havana
fields.standfirst: The hype surrounding their tour of Cuba, shot the Manic Street Preachers into the top 10. But with unprecedented access behind the scenes, Andrew Smith asks who really got the most of the media frenzy - the band, the Sony corporation or a wily old communist called Fidel Castro?
fields.trailText: The hype surrounding their tour of Cuba, shot the Manic Street Preachers into the top 10. But with unprecedented access behind the scenes, Andrew Smith asks who really got the most of the media frenzy - the band, the Sony corporation or a wily old communist called Fidel Castro?
fields.body:
Thursday morning and the short journey to the national radio station affords a first look at Havana, which turns out to be exactly what I was expecting, only more. Salsa rhythms collide with rock and disco in the desiccated streets. Fifties-vintage Chevys clang past, flanked by buildings which appear ready to crumble to nothingness in the face of the first stiff breeze to blow in from the Caribbean.

Everything seems hand-tinted, washed by the sun. The only primary colours you see are worn by the prostitutes who keep hawkish watch on most street corners. You notice: the unusually pungent smell of the car fumes, because fuel is in short supply and almost anything flammable is put into petrol tanks; the massive 'camel' buses pulled by ancient Soviet trucks; the muddle of skin tones, from pale European to dark African, making it the first place you've ever been where you simply forget about race altogether after a while. You mark the fact that there are no overweight people at all, and no homeless on the streets.

Slightly later, in the almost comically chaotic radio studio, a DJ will ask Nicky Wire, Manic Street Preachers' lanky bass player-lyricist, why his band has come here.

'Well, the first gig we did last time was in Kettering,' he deadpans. 'So this seemed as far from that as we could go.'

Wire was being flippant, of course, and a little disingenuous. The idea of commemo rating tomorrow's release of a new Manics album by becoming the first major non-communist rock act to play Havana since 1979 came to them eight months ago and has cost a small fortune to realise.

Back home, it has also re-opened the old debate about pop stars playing with politics. The argument for is that they have access to a large audience. The more compelling case against has in one way or another touched everything from George Harrison's Concert For Bangladesh to Rock Against Racism, Live Aid, Red Wedge and the current Jubilee 2000 campaign around Third World debt. Who gains most from such involvement in the long run - cause or artist? Is hitching a serious issue to the ephemeral and fashion-sensitive pop counter-productive and self-serving? These questions have never been more urgent than they are in our age of mandatory celebrity endorsement of all things. And on the face of it, what cause could be more natural for a rock group to endorse than the Cuban revolution?

Most of the scepticism around Manic Street Preachers' decision to go to Havana has centred on the human-rights failings of the Castro regime. After a couple of days in the place, my concern about their presence here is different. Following the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 and consequent loss of its sponsorship, the government had little option but to open up to outsiders and now, if you listen, you begin to hear tales of a village to the south which has become a sex tourism destination for Canadian men. Meanwhile, amid the colonial splendour of the Nacional Hotel, where the Mafia held court in Batista's day, we watch two Englishmen acquire a prostitute for the duration of their stay and send her out to 'find her mate Charlie'.

Cuba is changing and no one is quite sure where the changes are leading. Fidel is 75 this year and can't last forever. Many Cubans still express what appears to be genuine respect and affection for him, blaming the US embargo for their plight: those who don't usually refuse to speak. A typical conversation is one I have with a taxi driver who used to earn $15 a month as a mechanical engineer - the average is $20 - after I've asked what people think of Fidel these days.

'Oh, some love him, some do not,' he edges. 'What about you?' I enquire and there is a long, long pause. 'I cannot answer you. Questions like that are.. dangerous. I don't know who you are. I could lose my job.'

And this is a good job, he adds. The fact is that there are two economies now, one driven by near-worthless pesos and the other running on US dollars, and like the legions of prostitutes, he makes dollars. Do people lose their jobs for saying the wrong thing? He shrugs, clearly wanting the conversation to end. Amnesty International reports that people do lose their jobs for saying the wrong thing, that there are political prisoners in Cuban jails (whose offences can and do consist merely of criticising the annual report of the Communist Party - a couple were handed three years for this), while gay people languish in squalid correctional institutes as a direct result of their sexuality. Until someone works out a way to look into Castro's soul, no one can say how much of this is purely a defensive reaction to years of US hostility, but it's a fact. Nicky Wire has been firmly instructed not to wear a skirt onstage, as he often does at home.

The one thing everyone agrees upon is that there is no obvious candidate to replace Castro and people start to hedge again around the question of what happens when he's gone. Now along come Manic Street Preachers, heavily subsidised by the multinational Sony corporation, perhaps paving the way for others.

By showtime, things seem a little different. It's 7.30pm on a clear, warm Saturday night and I'm standing on the pavement, listening to the gentle hiss of surf mingling with the chatter of thousands of young Cubans who are pouring excitedly into the Karl Marx Theatre to see a band they know next to nothing about. British rock is popular here and seems to contribute to a charming but laughable impression that we represent some kind of feisty, independent-minded alternative to American cultural hegemony. No one has the faintest idea of what the audience will make of them.

I'm out front, chatting to members of the audience, when word comes that Fidel is here, that he has been backstage for an impromptu summit with the band. No one can quite believe it. During the jovial exchange, the old man happens to mention that he has seen the lyrics to one of only two weak songs on the otherwise vivid Know Your Enemy - 'Baby Elian', about the Cuban boy who became the focus of a tussle between the US and Cuban governments last year - and that he finds them 'beautiful'. The problem is that the Manics hadn't intended to play the song ('We thought it would just be too much,' grins Wire), meaning that Bradfield has to bail them out with a solo acoustic version, at the end of which Castro rises in a flamboyant show of appreciation. What's all that about then? I find myself wondering.

Chatting again with members of the audience afterwards, most seem to have been impressed, not least by the scale of the show. I do manage to find one girl who spits, 'No, I don't like this - I am a punk!' and another who says 'I prefer alternative music', both of which cause Wire to roar with laughter later.

'I suspect that this concert will be talked about for years to come,' suggests Michael White, the British Council's country direc tor, at a reception he hosts afterwards. And despite myself, I have to acknowledge the pleasure ordinary Cubans appear to be taking in the mere fact that a well-known foreign band have made the effort to come here and lessen their sense of isolation.

That said, cultural solidarity isn't the only talking point afterwards. Bumping into Nick Naysmith, the amiable keyboard player, I ask him what his impressions of Fidel were.

'Well,' he offers, 'I can tell you one thing. He dresses to the left.'

'Er, sorry?'

'Yep. It was huge.'

Everybody's talking about it and it's not long before word gets out that Fidel has two local nicknames, these being 'The Beard' and 'The Horse'. Unable to quite believe what I'm hearing, I consult the ever-down-to-earth Bradfield. 'It was halfway down his leg,' he twinkles. 'Now we know the source of his power, don't we?'

For the first time, that old story about the CIA attempting to assassinate the father of the revolution by poisoning his underpants makes a kind of sense.

The next morning, Wire wakes to a deep sense of anticlimax. He'd played a blinding show, met one of his heroes, Fidel Castro, then two more, the athlete Alberto Juanterino and Felix Savon, an impossibly statuesque ex-boxer whose samba skills had mesmerised us all. Wire had retired early to his room to phone his wife and tell her about his adventure, then crashed. Now he feels drained.

Fidel has invited the Manics to be guests of honour at the opening of a new state university, la Escuela de Instructores de Arte Manuel Domenech, inland in Santa Clara. Right from the off, the atmosphere is strained, with the band becoming truculent as the day-long excursion wears on ('It was like a return to the old days of Communism,' Wire comments later. 'We were carted around, with no one giving us any information about what was happening'). Eventually, we arrive at the college, which is festooned with student artwork, a bizarre proportion of which deals with familiar images of Che. Wire and his colleagues are in a foul mood by this time, talking of going straight home and fucking Castro.

We are herded into a small theatre and take up positions at the end of three narrow rows of seats, where we wait for a further 20 minutes or so. Then there is a bustle at the door and he is among us. In fact, he is at the end of my row and one of his aids is motioning urgently for me to come forward. Unfortunately, by the time I've understood the instruction, Fidel has already started towards me. We meet in the middle and both instantly realise that there is no possibility of circumnavigating each other. I look at him. He looks at me. He offers his hand and I respond tentatively, fearful that I might miss and accidentally shake his penis instead, thereby ensuring that I spend the rest of my days festering in a military dungeon. Eventually, there is nothing for it but to clamber over the seats in the most undignified way imaginable. My big moment, blown.

He banters with the band, through an interpreter. Everyone is entertained: being all military bearing, mischievous grin and raised eyebrows, he is essentially Mel Brooks with a beard. Provided you're not gay, of course, at which point he becomes Adolf Hitler with a beard.

Before yesterday's show, Wire had cautioned that 'It might be a bit loud tonight' and Castro had replied, brilliantly, 'Will it be as loud as war?' - despite the fact that he hasn't been to one for 42 years. Now Wire has the chance to ask if it had been as loud as war and the older man shoots back, with mock incredulity 'It was louder!', before ribbing drummer Sean Moore about his role as artillery. He is animated as he compares notes on song composition and speeches and wisecracks about relations between the Welsh, Scots and English. Then, as if on cue, he seems to turn towards the battery of media and raises the subject of Baby Elian.

Instantly, it is as if we have stepped into one of those old-fashioned TV soap powder ads, where Bruce Forsyth or Leslie Crowther collars a housewife in a supermarket and hustles her into saying something nice about a product she's probably never seen before. She needed to be there, but it wasn't about her. As it isn't about the Manics now - or me, as a representative of the foreign media. We are being monstered, used to help facilitate a bit of nationalist fervour.

I find myself laughing. You don't get to be in power for forty years without knowing how to turn on the charm, or without recognising a useful photo opportunity when you see one. The long journey back is spent happily compiling top 10s with Bradfield. If you're going to be monstered, you might as well be monstered by the best.

By the next day, Wire's version of events has undergone a revisionist rewrite. He had merely been exhausted, rather than pissed off, during the pre-Fidel part of the trip. The adrenalin rush of Saturday night had been 'so gigantic' that there was bound to be a reaction. 'Everybody could have just burst out crying,' he says. He doesn't mind having been used for propaganda purposes.

'Oh, I thought that would happen anyway. I'm not naive enough to believe that they wouldn't use us to promote something for them. And let's face it, we're using them just as much. To think of it in terms of being used and abused.. it might have felt like that for a couple of minutes, but it just wasn't.

So you're sold, then? 'Well..' There is a deep sigh. 'I think it's different to anywhere else I've ever been. It has a different spirit. And, for all the things we might disapprove of, Castro stands out as someone who's really tried to do something good.

'The literacy rate here is higher than in the UK and the health service works. There are no homeless people. They have kind of jumped on Baby Elian, but I don't think that was pre-planned. And to be honest, I wouldn't have wrote the song if I didn't feel strongly about it myself.'

Wire's good at being a pop star and seems to be enjoying it again. On the last album, he suggests, they were all pretty happy in their outside lives and some of the desire had gone. Now, he feels less contended and has more that he wants to say.

He aims gleeful tirades at a range of subjects including the cult of celebrity, the supineness of the media, John Lennon's 'Imagine' ('Sexy Sadie', he rightly points out, is much truer to the man's spirit) and is happy as a sandboy until we get on to the subject of Richey Edward - the troubled guitarist/lyricist who played Che to his Castro but disappeared under mysterious circumstances in 1995. Manic Street Preachers have now made as many albums without him as with him. It seems like an important watershed, but Wire admits that they still haven't grieved for the colleague who had been his best mate since the age of 10, though his feelings are changing with time.

'I think that's true and that's the frightening thing and that's why I try not to dwell on it too much. You do read about what delayed grief can do to people when it settles on you. But, however bad you feel about that last year, I'm still romantic enough to think that those pictures of Richey in Thailand with blood all over his chest are fucking beautiful and magnificent - I mean, it's better than looking at Brian Moloko [singer in gothy angst-merchants Placebo] or any of those other dead-weight, useless imposters... I still can't think of him as being dead, though. None of us knows.'

And after a while. you start to suspect that Nicky Wire sees Fidel Castro and the Cuban revolution in a similar way.

fields.headline: We are not worthy
fields.standfirst: Philip French  salutes the most deserving winners of all time... and condemns the least deserving
fields.trailText: Observer critic Philip French has seen every major Oscar-winning film. Here he salutes the most deserving Oscar winners of all time ... and condemns the least deserving
fields.body:
With the exception of Coquette (starring best actress Mary Pickford in 1929) and Skippy (made by best director Norman Taurog in 1931), I think I've seen all the movies that have won major Oscars since the Academy Awards began in 1928. I began disagreeing vociferously with the Academicians when they gave only a minor prize to Ford's Cavalry Trilogy in the Forties and I started to get angry in 1958 when Paths of Glory was ignored in favour of Bridge on the River Kwai . Still, these lists are my bests (or in one case worsts) of their bests. Feel free to provide an alternative list.

Best Film

1. Casablanca (Michael Curtiz, 1943)
The work of a fine team behind the camera and a perfectly cast ensemble in front of it, this great collaborative product of the Hollywood system perfectly caught the mood of the war years in a story of love, duty and sacrifice. It gets better as time goes by and has helped in bridging the gap, or blurring the distinction, between art and popular culture.

2. On the Waterfront (Elia Kazan, 1954)
The Method style of acting and the documentary style of filming are united with unparalleled force.

3. Lawrence of Arabia (David Lean, 1962)
A film that brings together an epic visual sweep with an intimate view of individual psychology.

4. Unforgiven (Clint Eastwood, 1992)
A complex moral western that challenges and renews the cinema's greatest genre.

Worst Film

1. Titanic (James Cameron, 1997)
Astonishingly, hardly any truly terrible pictures have won Oscars, though a famously acerbic British director recently opined in my presence that the two worst pictures he's seen in the past decade were American Beauty and The English Patient, and compared the latter to a maple-syrup enema. But in my view, Titanic is awful in every way, from its banal dialogue and bad acting to its forced romanticism and strident Oscar-winning song.

2. The Greatest Show on Earth (Cecil B. De Mille, 1952)
De Mille was one of the great silent directors, but his sound films, peaking with this empty offering of stale bread and circuses, were over-inflated.

3. Rocky (John G. Avildsen, 1976)
Impossible to separate the aspirations of character actor Stallone and dim-witted boxer Balboa in this sentimental paean to the American Dream.

4. Terms of Endearment (James L. Brooks, 1983)
Dreadful comedy covering 30 years; soap opera as the ultimate detergent.

5. Forrest Gump (Robert Zemeckis, 1994)
A non-satirical Candide and a feelgood Huckleberry Finn served up as pap history for Middle America.

Best Director

1. John Ford - The Grapes of Wrath (1940)
Hitchcock, Lubitsch, Lang, Hawks and Welles never received a best director Oscar. But Ford got four, for The Informer (1935), The Grapes of Wrath (1940), How Green Was My Valley (1941) and The Quiet Man (1952), though never for a western.

America's greatest literary critic, Edmund Wilson, observed that The Grapes of Wrath is 'the sole serious story on record that seems equally effective as a book and as a film'. Welles once said: 'I learnt from the old masters - by which I mean John Ford, John Ford and John Ford' and said that he didn't mind Citizen Kane losing to How Green Was My Valley.

2. William Wyler - The Best Years of Our Lives (1946)
A meticulously handled examination of a nation turning its hand from swords to ploughshares.

3. John Huston - The Treasure of the Sierra Madre (1948)
A great director pursues his constant theme of doomed questers in pursuit of an elusive, perhaps unattainable, grail.

4. Joseph L. Mankiewicz - All About Eve (1950)
The New York theatre as a metaphor for life itself in a scintillatingly witty, dazzlingly performed picture by a writer who turned director to protect his scripts

5. Francis Ford Coppola - The Godfather Part II (1974)
Arguably the greatest sequel since the New Testament or Henry IV Part II , it demonstrated the reckless ambition of Hollywood's new auteurs.

Best Actress

1. Vivien Leigh - Gone With the Wind (1939); A Streetcar Named Desire (1951)
Leigh's two vulnerable Southern belles, one a resilient antebellum survivor, the other a crushed postbellum victim, constitute a diptych and must now be taken together. She got Oscars for her best movie roles, unlike Katharine Hepburn, who won four Oscars, three for mediocre, largely forgotten films, but wasn't honoured for her finest work (eg Bringing Up Baby, Philadelphia Story, African Queen).

2. Joan Crawford - Mildred Pierce (1945)
A great actress at her sado-masochistic best in a noir melodrama worthy of her talents.

3. Audrey Hepburn - Roman Holiday (1953)
In her first starring role as a fugitive princess, Hepburn melted many a republican heart as she revealed her swanlike grace, puckish wit and emotional generosity.

4. Simone Signoret - Room at the Top (1958)
Strong emotions and confident sexuality were not considered proper for Englishwomen at the time, so Signoret crossed the Channel to give this incandescent performance as a neglectful Yorkshireman's adulterous wife.

5. Holly Hunter - The Piano (1993)
The Nineties Oscars went to actresses playing assured women and actors playing demoralised men, and Holly Hunter's performance as the mute immigrant in nineteenth-century New Zealand was arguably the best.

Best Actor

1. George C. Scott - Patton (1970)
As with actresses, few top actors won Oscars with their best work. Two-time winner Spencer Tracy was ignored for his great string of pictures with Katharine Hepburn and for Bad Day At Black Rock; James Stewart wasn't honoured for his westerns or his Hitchcock pictures; Paul Newman, unrewarded for The Hustler (1961), had to wait until its inferior sequel, The Color of Money (1986), to receive his dues. But Scott's towering portrayal of the most controversial general of the Second World War is his greatest performance, a complex portrait that is the cinematic equivalent of a Rembrandt painting. Like the maverick he was, Scott refused to accept the Oscar.

2. James Cagney - Yankee Doodle Dandy (1942)
The actor who best embodied the vitality of big-city life finds a perfect role as the brash Irish-American composer and dancer George M. Cohan, laureate of the American Dream.

3. Gary Cooper - High Noon (1952)
Cooper brought his powerful probity to the role he was born to play, the decent, inner-directed sheriff standing alone against ruthless outlaws in a liberal western reflecting the cowardice of Hollywood in the McCarthy Era.

4. Marlon Brando - On the Waterfront (1954)
Brando's shambling, failed pugilist in search of redemption is the Everest of an up-and-down career, and there are scenes in this film where he comes close to breaking your heart.

5. Robert De Niro - Raging Bull (1980)
De Niro is the greatest screen actor of his generation, and his impersonation of the brutal prizefighter Jake La Motta is a physical and dramatic tour de force that nods towards Brando's Terry Malloy in On the Waterfront .

fields.headline: How to cut your bill in eight easy(ish) steps
fields.standfirst: Virginia Wallis on the £4.6bn a year that UK taxpayers wrongly give to the Inland Revenue and some - legal - ways of paying less this time
fields.trailText: Virginia Wallis on the £4.6bn a year that UK taxpayers wrongly give to the Inland Revenue and some - legal - ways of paying less this time.
fields.body:
As a nation, we squander an estimated £5.7 billion a year in unnecessary tax.

According to the latest TaxAction investigation by IFA Promotion, £1,128 million was paid in fines and penalty interest by 971,000 taxpayers who failed to get their tax returns in on time, but the research showed that the remaining £4.572bn was wasted through people paying more tax than they legally have to as a result of financial inertia or not understanding the rules.

Deliberately concealing income or gains or claiming bogus expenses is tax evasion - and a crime. Taking legitimate steps to avoid tax by exploiting the tax rules is perfectly acceptable. So what can you do to cut your bill?

Use up your Isa allowance

If all taxpayers made use of their annual Isa allowance of £7,000, they could save more than £550m in total by sheltering investments in an Isa or moving savings (up to a maximum of £3,000) from an ordinary deposit or savings account.

Free your capital gains

If you plan to sell shares, unit trusts or other assets which attract capital gains tax, and you anticipate making gains of more than £7,200, act before the end of the tax year to make the most of your annual capital gains tax exemption. All gains are tax-free if the investments were held in a Pep or Isa.

Don't pay tax

Non-taxpayers - which includes most children and anyone else whose income falls below the current personal allowance of £4,385 - could save a total of £300m by registering to have interest on savings accounts paid without the deduction of tax.

Unless you register to have interest paid gross by filling in form R85 - available from your bank or building society - savings tax of 20 per cent will be deducted from the interest. This also applies to people over 65 whose income from all sources (excluding tax-free income) is less than £5,790 (the amount of the lower age-related personal allowance). The allowance for those aged 75 is £6,050.

Claim back tax

Non-taxpayers can also claim back tax overpaid in any of the past six years by completing claim form R40, available from your tax office. If you pay tax only at the starting rate of 10 per cent, you can't register to have interest paid gross, but you can claim back half the tax of 20 per cent that is deducted from it. This is likely to apply if your before-tax income for this tax year (excluding tax-free income) is more than your personal allowance but less than your personal allowance plus the starting rate band of £1,520. This works out as: £5,905 if you are under 65; £7,310 if you are over 65; and £7,570 if you are over 75. If you also paid tax at 10 per cent in the 1999-2000 tax year, but haven't yet reclaimed tax for that year, you can backdate your claim to 6 April 1999.

Split your assets

Independent taxation of married couples is 10 years old but an estimated £500m a year goes begging because couples aren't exploiting it to the full.

If one partner pays tax at a lower rate than the other - or pays no tax at all - a couple can save tax by transferring the ownership of assets which are liable to capital gains tax - such as shares and unit trusts - and interest-generating savings accounts to the lower-earning partner.

This is particularly beneficial where one partner is a higher-rate taxpayer or, if aged 65 plus, is not entitled to the full amount of age-related allowances because his or her income is more than £17,000 (the point at which age-related allowances start to be reduced).

When the new Children's Tax Credit comes into being after 6 April, transferring assets to a lower-earning spouse could also help to bump up the entitlement to this allowance of a parent who pays higher-rate tax.

Pay more into your pension

Any pension contributions you make - whether to an employer's scheme or to a personal pension - reduce your taxable income.

Claim your allowances

Allowances reduce your taxable income too, but only if your tax office knows that you are entitled to them. The basic personal allowance of £4,385 is given automatically but you will get the following allowances only if your tax office knows that you are in a position to claim:

 the new Children's Tax Credit because you have a child under 16

 a higher personal allowance because you are aged 65 or over

 the married couple's allowance available to married couples where one spouse reached the age of 65 on or before 5 April 2000;

 the blind person's allowance - worth £1,400 - for those registered as blind.

Delve into the past

With the exception of the Children's Tax Credit, which does not come into force until the next tax year, if you could have claimed one of the allowances, but haven't, you can claim them retrospectively. And provided you contact your tax office before 6 April 2001, you can go back as far back as the 1994-95 tax year.

This is also true of allowances which were axed for the 2000-01 tax year and which include: married couple's allowance for people under 65; additional personal allowance for lone parents; widow's bereavement allowance which was available for two tax years for women widowed before 5 April 2000; maintenance deduction which was available to people making enforceable maintenance payments to an ex-spouse.

By making a retrospective claim, someone who married before 5 May 1994, for example, but who failed to make a claim for the married couple's allowance, could get a tax rebate of more than £1,500. The amount and yearly tax saving for the married couple's (and related) allowances for past tax years is given below.

fields.headline: Invest in your pension now, while the breaks are there for the having
fields.standfirst: Until 5 April, you can 'carry forward' unused tax relief from past years, writes Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: Until 5 April, you can 'carry forward' unused tax relief from past years, writes Virginia Wallis.
fields.body:
If you have a lump sum to invest and you want to boost - or kick-start - your retirement savings, you had better get a move on. The end of the tax year on 5 April also signals the end of valuable tax breaks available to anyone currently eligible to pay into a personal pension.

There has always been an end-of-tax-year deadline for making the most of tax relief on contributions to an employer's pension - including that on top-up payments made in the form of additional voluntary contributions (AVCs). If you don't pay the maximum of 15 per cent of your earnings by the end of one tax year, you can't save up the unused relief and carry it forward to use in future tax years. With personal pensions you can - but not for much longer.

As part of the simplification of the tax rules for both personal and stakeholder pensions, from 6 April 2001, the mysteriously-named 'carry forward' rules - which let you mop up unused tax relief from up to six (sometimes seven) past tax years - will be abolished.

Although regarded by some as the preserve of the wealthy self-employed, the carry forward rules can also be useful for less well-off individuals who have not paid as much into their personal pensions as they could have and now want to make good their underpayments.

Making use of the carry forward rules is also worth considering for people who have an unexpected lump sum - a legacy, for example - and who have not yet made any pension provision beyond paying National Insurance.

Once the new pension rules come into force on April 6, the most you will be able to pay into a personal or stakeholder pension each year will be whichever is the higher of £3,600 (£2,808 after tax relief) and a fixed percentage of your earnings (which is based on your age at the start of the tax year).

In the meantime, to make use of the carry forward rules you must pay the maximum contribution allowed in the current tax year. Once you've done that, you can add unused contributions that you could have made (what you were allowed to pay minus what you actually paid) from up to six years earlier, starting with the year longest ago. For help with the calculations, ask your tax office for Helpsheet IR330: Pension Payments.

The unused relief could add up to a sizable amount - but the most you will be able to pay as a lump-sum contribution is limited by your earnings. So even if you calculate that you have unused relief of £30,000, if you earn £25,000, the most you can pay (before tax relief at this year's basic rate of 22 per cent) is £25,000.

If you want to boost your personal pension payments but don't have enough spare cash to pay the maximum allowed in this tax year - and so make use of the carry forward rules - you can still use the 'carry back' rules.

With these, you ask your tax office to treat a pension payment made this tax year as though it were paid in the last tax year (or the tax year before last if you didn't have any earnings last tax year). So if you could have paid £3,000 last year, but paid only £2,000, you can allocate £1,000 of this year's contributions to last year.

Tax relief is given at the rate which applied in the year to which a contribution is carried back. For payments carried back from 2000-2001 to 1999-2000, this means that you get tax relief at 23 per cent rather than 22 per cent. The deadline for making contributions that you want to carry back to last year is 5 April 2001, although you have until 31 January 2002 to tell your tax office how you want it to deal with your pension payments.

Although the Government won't be scrapping the carry back rules next tax year, it will change them slightly. You will have to tell your tax office you want a contribution carried back a tax year either before or at the time you make the payment.

And the deadline for making contributions that you intend to carry back will be the 31 January (rather than 5 April) following the end of the tax year to which you want a payment carried back.

webTitle: Tax planning: Act now for jam today

fields.headline: Act now for jam today
fields.standfirst: Virginia Wallis offers a round-up of imminent changes which may affect your tax planning
fields.trailText: Virginia Wallis offers a round-up of imminent changes which may affect your tax planning.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's fifth and final budget before the general election was the usual mix of genuinely new changes, repeats of the good bits from previous announcements, and promises of jam tomorrow (assuming Labour wins).

The Chancellor also stayed true to form in not bothering to remind us about less palatable changes from earlier Budgets, some of which will come into force in less than three weeks' time: 6 April, when the 2001-02 tax year begins. Others, such as the change in the way company cars are taxed, won't come until 2002-03.

Yet failing to take account of these changes now could mean higher tax bills in the future. The following round up of what happens when gives the good - and bad - news in the tax years ahead.

5 April 2001

Last day of the current tax year and the deadline for tax breaks which operate on a 'use-it-or-lose it' basis. Act within the next 18 days if you want to make full use of:

 The annual investment limit for Isas of £7,000, of which £3,000 can be saved in cash and £1,000 in investment-type life insurance if you don't want to invest the whole £7,000 in equities.

 Tax relief of up to 15 per cent of earnings given every tax year for contributions to an employer's pension and additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) made to a top-up pension plans which runs alongside an employer's main pension scheme.

 The 'carry forward' rules for tax relief on contributions to a personal pension: these allow you to make use of unused tax relief from up to seven years ago. (The 2000-01 tax year is the last in which you will be able to do this).

 Unused tax allowances from the 1994-95 tax year which you were entitled to claim but didn't.

6 April 2001

The start of the 2001-02 tax year, which brings higher personal allowances (see table) and an increase of:

 £360 in the 10p starting rate band, which applies to the first £1,880 of taxable income (broadly, your before-tax income after subtracting pension contributions and your personal allowance).

 £640 in the band of taxable income taxed at the basic rate, which remains unchanged at 22 per cent.

 £1,000 in the amount of taxable income you can have before becoming liable to tax at 40 per cent.

New this year is the implementation of the Children's Tax Credit, first announced in the 1999 Budget. This will be worth a maximum tax saving of £520 a year for working parents who are financially responsible for at least one child under 16. Where either parent pays higher-rate tax, the value of the credit will be reduced by £1 for every £15 of income taxed at the higher rate. A parent whose taxable income exceeds £37,200 (equivalent to a gross income of around £42,000 after pension contributions) is unlikely to benefit from this new allowance.

The 2001-02 tax year also sees the long-awaited stakeholder pension become a reality and new tax rules for both stakeholder and personal pensions which do away with the need to be earning in order to benefit from tax relief on pension contributions.

Stakeholders will be a non-event for people who earn more than £30,000 and are members of employers' pension schemes (unless it is a money-purchase scheme which has chosen to be governed by the new tax rules - check with your employer).

Anyone else can pay £2,808 (made up to £3,600 once the Revenue has added basic-rate tax relief) into a new stakeholder or existing personal pension without reference to earnings. However, if you want to contribute more than this, whether you can - and how much - depends on what you earn and your age at the start of the tax year.

Beyond increasing the annual limit for tax-free capital gains from £7,200 to £7,500 for the 2001-02 tax year, and confirming that annual Isa limits would remain unchanged at £7,000 until April 2006, the only really 'new' change for savers is the measure, announced last November, to allow 16- and 17-year olds to deposit up to £3,000 a year in a cash Isa.

This will not, however, provide parents with an opportunity to bump up their own Isa savings. If parents give their child money to save in an Isa and the interest earned comes to more than £100, the whole of the interest counts as the income of the parent who gave it and, as such, is liable to tax.

6 April 2002

The 2002-03 tax year promises a new 'baby credit', worth a proposed maximum of £1,040, which will be available to parents for the tax year in which a child is born. On top of this, the Chancellor has promised to increase Statutory Maternity Pay and the Maternity Allowance from £60.20 to £75 a week.

This is also the year in which taxation of company cars undergoes a complete overhaul, designed to encourage use of environment-friendly cars. Under the current system, the basic taxable value of a company car is 35 per cent of its list price less whatever the driver pays for personal use. But the more business miles driven, the lower the taxable value. The new system will abolish discounts for high mileage and the taxable value will be a percentage of the car's list price based on its carbon dioxide CO2 emissions. The lowest basic charge will be 15 per cent of the price for cars emitting 165 grams per kilometre of CO2. Company-car drivers will still be able to reduce the taxable value by deducting the amount they pay for personal use of the car.

6 April 2003

fields.bodyText: Gordon Brown's fifth and final budget before the general election was the usual mix of genuinely new changes, repeats of the good bits from previous announcements, and promises of jam tomorrow (assuming Labour wins). The Chancellor also stayed true to form in not bothering to remind us about less palatable changes from earlier Budgets, some of which will come into force in less than three weeks' time: 6 April, when the 2001-02 tax year begins. Others, such as the change in the way company cars are taxed, won't come until 2002-03. Yet failing to take account of these changes now could mean higher tax bills in the future. The following round up of what happens when gives the good - and bad - news in the tax years ahead. 5 April 2001 Last day of the current tax year and the deadline for tax breaks which operate on a 'use-it-or-lose it' basis. Act within the next 18 days if you want to make full use of:  The annual investment limit for Isas of £7,000, of which £3,000 can be saved in cash and £1,000 in investment-type life insurance if you don't want to invest the whole £7,000 in equities.  Tax relief of up to 15 per cent of earnings given every tax year for contributions to an employer's pension and additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) made to a top-up pension plans which runs alongside an employer's main pension scheme.  The 'carry forward' rules for tax relief on contributions to a personal pension: these allow you to make use of unused tax relief from up to seven years ago. The lowest basic charge will be 15 per cent of the price for cars emitting 165 grams per kilometre of CO2. Company-car drivers will still be able to reduce the taxable value by deducting the amount they pay for personal use of the car. 6 April 2003 Maternity pay, which will be extended to adoptive parents, will go up to £100 and will be paid for 26 weeks, not 18. Fathers will be entitled to two weeks of paid paternity leave at the same rate as maternity pay. Using current inflation forecasts, the personal allowance for someone over 65 but under 75 is estimated at £6,510; for someone aged 75 the estimate is £6,800. fields.headline: Venture out of the ordinary
fields.standfirst: You can protect your retirement package from capital gains tax, if you take a risk, writes Alistair McArthur
fields.trailText: You can protect your retirement package from capital gains tax, if you take a risk, writes Alistair McArthur.
fields.body:
When David Brown, 59, took early retirement from Robert Fleming, following the takeover by Chase Manhattan, he wanted to defer the capital gains tax (CGT) that would be payable on part of his retirement pay.

David took some cash from the takeover to invest for capital growth. But, unlike the shares and loan notes that were also available, the cash would immediately attract CGT. However, following advice from Martin Eckersall of Edinburgh-based tax advisers Scott Oswald, Brown decided to invest cash in a venture capital trust (VCT) and an enterprise investment scheme (EIS).

There are a number of tax benefits linked to VCTs. First, investors can shelter any capital gains that may otherwise be subject to tax, which defers 40 per cent tax. Second, investors receive a 20 per cent income tax rebate on the sum invested.

The next benefit is that the VCT pays no tax on any growth in the underlying investments, and any dividends paid to the investors are tax-free.

Finally, any gains made on selling the VCT are tax-exempt.

The maximum investment that an individual can make into a VCT is £100,000 each tax year. However, to qualify for the tax breaks, a VCT must invest a large proportion of its capital in young and developing companies - a very high-risk strategy.

David says: 'The scheme was also a way for me to diversify my investment holdings. I am interested in investing in young companies where I realise I am taking a few risks.' David used some of his retirement cash to help set up an internet company, buyersview.co.uk, which is an independent online service that rates shops on the internet. This has been structured as an EIS. An EIS attracts similar tax breaks to those enjoyed by VCT.

The maximum investment into an EIS is £150,000 a year. This type of scheme is even more risky than a VCT, because all the capital is invested in just one company.

David says: 'The tax breaks available to the EIS will be very useful. We will be able to attract money in the future if we need it, with investors able to obtain tax relief and deferment.'

webTitle: Few options left for Meg, Jeff and Tim

fields.headline: Few options left for Meg, Jeff and Tim
fields.standfirst:
It's the end of the dotcom pay substitute, says Simon Caulkin

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Guardian Unlimited Work
More net news
fields.trailText: It's the end of the dotcom pay substitute, says Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
Whatever else it betokens, the management turmoil at Yahoo represents the spectacular collapse of one of the main load-bearing beams of the internet economy: the stock-option culture, no less.

The scaffolding remained in place a bit longer at Yahoo because the company is profitable - just (it forecasts break-even this quarter).

Yet in the past few weeks the roof has fallen in. Although he remains chairman, the departure of chief executive Tim Koogle puts the cap on an exodus of management talent that has included the heads of European and Asian and Korean operations. More departures are predicted to follow.

Meanwhile, and not coincidentally, Yahoo has become a member of the dreaded 90 per cent club of companies whose share price has shrivelled by that amount from its all-time high.

Yahoo is not alone in its disarray. Lycos, Alta Vista and broker Ameritrade are other dotcoms sporting high-profile vacancies. No fewer than 26 of them lost their chief executive officer (CEO) in January, according to Business Week.

This falling masonry is the result of several powerful tremors that have opened up the ground beneath new-economy hopefuls. The first, and most spectacular, is the stockmarket meltdown, which has had the unanticipated effect of yanking all those hand-crafted option-based incentive schemes into reverse. Instead of holding the company together, they are now pulling it to bits.

'Virtually all dotcoms have relied disproportionately on stock options as a form of pay,' says Vicky Wright of remuneration specialists Hay Management Consultants. 'This is tantamount to letting the stock market decide your pay policy.'

The danger is obvious. When the price tanks, so does the incentive for the best people to stay - exerting further pressure on the share price, since people are most companies' best asset.

The consequences ripple outwards from there. Companies' initial response was to reprice their options to a sharply lower base, or issue new ones. But persuading investors to dilute their anaemic stock still further is getting harder, even in the US. A full 15 per cent of Microsoft is under option to its employees. 'There has to be an end to that story,' says Wright.

The other alternative - redeeming the equity element by raising all cash salaries 50 per cent - is also fraught. Equity payments don't figure on income statements.

Cash payments do. So paying people a normal salary may double your losses, or reduce profits by half (that was the point of using options in the first place).

It is not just employment costs that have been kept artificially low by stock options. Dotcoms have habitually also used them to pay suppliers - especially professional advisers. In reverse, removal of the option alternative can thus have the effect of substantially raising the cost base.

This makes struggling dotcoms less attractive to potential buyers. So do 'change of control' conditions attached to senior remuneration packages. These often specify that if a company is acquired, all outstanding options vest (that is, they become immediately exercisable). In that case, 'the handcuffs are loosed,' says Professor Tim Morris at Imperial Management School. Either the former captives leave at once - or they must be offered shed-loads of options to stay. 'It's a high-pressure, fluid market anyway - this just increases the fluidity,' notes Wright.

A second source of instability is growing pains within the companies themselves. Entrepreneurs will jump through almost any hoop for the sake of a £10 million option payout, points out John Stork of career strategy adviser Stork and May.

But this isn't normal behaviour and it doesn't necessarily make them good executives - sometimes the reverse - warping judgment and distorting behaviour.

Either way, says Stork, these are tense and uneasy partners for the more sober and grey heads increasingly being sought to drag the dotcoms into the real world.

Enter at this point the third element in the triple whammy that has sent the dotcoms' management structures reeling: a growing revolt against 'always-on' internet work cultures.

For Stork, this is the reason that CEO jobs generally - and especially those at dotcoms - are getting harder and harder to fill. 'People say to themselves, "Been there, done that",' says Stork.

'They know the markets will give them at most four years. Why should they continue to sacrifice their health and families to the impossible job of holding the share price up against impossible economic conditions?'

Morris sees the same current at work in ranks below the top brass. Commitments to employers and work status are becoming more instrumental and short-term, he believes; commitment to self is correspondingly stronger. Thus, when the option dream dies, people suddenly realise that it came at a cost: absurd hours, often not very good working conditions and mediocre pay. Even if the company survives, it's unlikely to be enough to compensate for the 'quite complex' mental processes of disappointment, Morris believes.

How can the dotcom remuneration framework be stuck together again? Not easily, experts reckon. Even if stockmarkets boom anew, for obvious reasons it's unlikely companies or their employees will turn to share options with their former abandon.

For one thing, the employment landscape has been permanently changed by the events of the last few years. For companies, the account ing authorities will eventually disallow the fiction that options somehow aren't a cost, while all the signs are that individuals will continue to shift their priorities towards a work/life balance.

Few companies, notes Wright, have been as creative in working out how to pay their people as they have in their internet accounting. One exception is the free-form Brazilian company Semco, where staff have a menu of 11 different payment options to mix and match. A few others are allowing new hires job portfolios at different firms.

Others had better follow suit fast. Otherwise, as the stock options that inflated the internet bubble explode, they will take the houses that Tim, Jeff and Meg built down with them.

webTitle: 'Colleagues were forced to tells lies about me'

fields.headline: 'Colleagues were forced to tells lies about me'
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: My life has been wrecked by being unfairly dismissed seven years ago. It has taken me a long time to piece together the truth, but I believe colleagues were pressed to make false statements about me being violent. I don't know what to do - and I have been suffering severe depression as a result.
fields.body:
My life has been wrecked by being unfairly dismissed seven years ago. It has taken me a long time to piece together the truth, but I believe colleagues were pressed to make false statements about me being violent. I don't know what to do - and I have been suffering severe depression as a result.

In all honesty, your best recourse is probably to try to put those events behind you and try to do something different with your life. There are strict time limits on claims for unfair dismissal - three months after departure.

You are also on the wrong side of a personal injury claim for the depression you are suffering if it is a result of workplace stress. In general terms, the allegations you are making about colleagues being pressed to lie are obviously far better handled nearer the time the events took place.

Whether your allegations are true or not, you would find them far harder to prove now - some of those staff members may have left, records may have been lost, and people's memories will have faded.

For other people in a similar situation, there are places to go for help - trade unions, citizens' advice bureaux or specialist charities such as Public Concern at Work (020 7404 6609), which helps whistleblowers.

webTitle: Till death do our joint income part

fields.headline: Till death do our joint income part
fields.standfirst: Virginia Wallis reports on the dangers of leaving retirement plans to your partner
fields.trailText: Virginia Wallis reports on the dangers of leaving retirement plans to your partner.
fields.body:
Unless you are a long-term fan of Coronation Street, you will have missed a vital lesson about pensions and why you should not leave the planning entirely to your other half.

Audrey Roberts learned the hard way. When widowed by husband Alf - a man considered to be careful with his cash - Audrey assumed that she would be left well-provided for. However, not only had Alf failed to renew his life insurance but also, when he died, his pension died with him. Why? Because instead of buying a joint life annuity, which would have carried on paying Audrey a pension until her death, he had used the proceeds of his personal pension to buy a single life annuity.

So could such a thing happen in real life? It's unlikely that the widow of someone who had been receiving an employer's pension would be left penniless - but she could still face a sharp drop in income. Although the tax rules allow for a widow(er)'s pension of two-thirds of the pension paid before death, according to a survey by the National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF), the majority of schemes pay half the original pension while a handful pay less than one third.

The situation for unmarried couples is less clear-cut. While NAPF found that 5 per cent of private-sector schemes would pay the equivalent of a widow(er)'s pension 'as a matter of course', half said that it would be 'at the trustees' discretion' while 12 per cent replied 'not in any circumstances' - an answer given by just under 60 per cent of schemes in the public sector.

Married or not, whether a surviving partner gets anything from a personal pension (which includes the imminent stakeholder pensions) is largely at the discretion of the person buying the annuity. The rules for contracting out of the state earnings related pension scheme (Serps) say that the part of the pension fund made up of rebated national insurance must be used to provide a widow(er)'s pension. There are no such restrictions on the kind of annuity that has to be bought with the fund built up from other contributions. And buying a joint annuity means less to live on.

A man retiring at 65 today with a pension pot of £100,000 could buy himself a pension which stopped on his death of just under £9,100 a year, according to annuity specialists The Annuity Bureau (020 7902 2300). The same lump sum would buy a couple a yearly income of £7,985 up to the man's death, followed by a pension for his widow of half that amount - although if the woman died first, the man would carry on getting a pension of £7,985. That assumes that both partners are the same age. If the wife was five years younger than her husband, the couple's initial pension would be £7,755. With a ten-year age gap, it would fall to £7,535. Given the choice between a lower pension and leaving a spouse in the financial lurch, Peter Quinton of The Annuity Bureau believes that most men opt for the lower pension.

All this assumes that it's the man's job to provide the pension. Margaret Craig, pensions development manager at Scottish Equitable, doesn't think it should be and says that the only way a woman can be certain of having a decent income in retirement is to make her own pension provision. She says: 'Now that the vast majority of women are economically independent, why on Earth would anyone want to give that up in retirement?' But having two pensions rather than one also makes sense from a purely financial point of view.

For example, if a couple each built up a fund of £50,000 and at age 65 each bought an annuity, the man could have a yearly income of £4,000 and the woman an income of £3,850, which gives a joint income of £7,850. Before tax, this is slightly less than the £7,985 they would have got if the man alone bought an annuity with a single fund of £100,000. After tax, it's a different story. If only the man builds up a fund and buys an annuity, all the income from it is taxed as his and - assuming he also got the full state pension of £3,510 - would mean a tax bill of just over £1,000. But buying separate annuities brings the couple's tax bill to £500 because they can each make full use of the higher age-related personal allowance of £5,790 (due to increase to £5,990 in the 2001-02 tax year).

Provided both partners buy joint annuities - or both have an employer's pension - having two pensions has particular advantages for the woman after the death of her partner. Although she may get only half of her dead partner's pension, her own pension would be unaffected. This results in a reduction in income of 25 per cent rather than the 50 per cent drop she would face if she had relied wholly on her partner.

There is a moderate disadvantage to sharing pension provision for a man which wouldn't happen if he were wholly responsible for buying the couple's pension income. If the woman dies first the man would also see a reduction in pension income of 25 per cent because he would get half his partner's income after her death. But since this puts both partners on a more equal financial footing and since a single person needs less to live on than a couple, it's a price worth paying.

Given the choice between a lower pension and leaving a spouse in the financial lurch, Peter Quinton of The Annuity Bureau believes that most men opt for the lower pension. All this assumes that it's the man's job to provide the pension. Margaret Craig, pensions development manager at Scottish Equitable, doesn't think it should be and says that the only way a woman can be certain of having a decent income in retirement is to make her own pension provision. She says: 'Now that the vast majority of women are economically independent, why on Earth would anyone want to give that up in retirement?' But having two pensions rather than one also makes sense from a purely financial point of view. For example, if a couple each built up a fund of £50,000 and at age 65 each bought an annuity, the man could have a yearly income of £4,000 and the woman an income of £3,850, which gives a joint income of £7,850. Before tax, this is slightly less than the £7,985 they would have got if the man alone bought an annuity with a single fund of £100,000. After tax, it's a different story. If only the man builds up a fund and buys an annuity, all the income from it is taxed as his and - assuming he also got the full state pension of £3,510 - would mean a tax bill of just over £1,000. But buying separate annuities brings the couple's tax bill to £500 because they can each make full use of the higher age-related personal allowance of £5,790 (due to increase to £5,990 in the 2001-02 tax year). Provided both partners buy joint annuities - or both have an employer's pension - having two pensions has particular advantages for the woman after the death of her partner. Although she may get only half of her dead partner's pension, her own pension would be unaffected. This results in a reduction in income of 25 per cent rather than the 50 per cent drop she would face if she had relied wholly on her partner. There is a moderate disadvantage to sharing pension provision for a man which wouldn't happen if he were wholly responsible for buying the couple's pension income. If the woman dies first the man would also see a reduction in pension income of 25 per cent because he would get half his partner's income after her death. But since this puts both partners on a more equal financial footing and since a single person needs less to live on than a couple, it's a price worth paying.

fields.headline: Holes in the net
fields.standfirst: Making pension payments after tax rather than gross has its drawbacks, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Making pension payments after tax rather than gross has its drawbacks, writes Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
If you are self-employed and paying into a personal pension, 6 April will be a significant day for you. Instead of paying your pension contributions gross of tax - as you do now - you will start paying them net.

To coincide with its launch of the cheap and cheerful stakeholder pension on that day, the Government is changing some other rules on pensions.

An unfortunate side-effect is that many self-employed people will miss an easy opportunity to increase the amount they pay into their pensions.

Instead of making a £100 gross payment once a month, for instance, Mr Bloggs might now reduce his monthly payment and pay the net equivalent -£78, after basic-rate tax.

If he decided to carry on paying £100 a month rather than going for the £78-a-month option, he could have increased the value of his fund by up to 28 per cent.

A gross payment, which people make now, is gross of tax and is followed by a repayment to the individual of the tax paid.

A net payment is good for cashflow in that you pay net of tax in the first place. You do not get a repayment later, however, because you did not pay that tax yourself at the start.

Many people paying into personal pensions will be using the new stakeholder pension as a vehicle. The annual limit for a lump-sum investment in the stakeholder pension is £3,600, but this assumes tax relief is included, and the maximum a basic rate taxpayer pays from his or her own pocket is £2,808.

Insurers are now writing to their clients to explain the rules and ask them whether they want to keep their payments the same or pay in the lower amount, which is net of basic-rate tax at 22 per cent.

'The default position for those who don't do anything is that we will net their contributions down,' says Adrian Boulding of Legal & General.

But if you can afford it there are good arguments for writing back and asking to maintain your present level of contributions.

'Most people are going the other way - but actually this could be a very good planning opportunity,' says Donna Bradshaw of independent financial adviser Fiona Price & Partners. 'A lot of self-employed people don't put enough into their pensions anyway.'

So, if you decided to keep your £100 monthly payment the same, your contributions would increase overnight by 28 per cent to a gross level of £128. (Paying £128 less basic-rate tax at 22 per cent works out at a net contribution of £100.)

You would need to check, however, that you were not breaking the rules on maximum contribution levels. There are strict age-related rules on the amounts you are allowed to pay - rising from 17.5 per cent of net relevant earnings (NRE) - your income after deducting allowable expenses - for the under-35s to 40 per cent of NRE for the over-60s. More flexibility is being introduced into the calculation of your NRE figure. Instead of having to base your NRE on the current tax year, you can chose your highest year out of the past five.

'It's very important that you check you are not over-funded,' says Bradshaw. 'It is very easy to pick up if an employee is paying too much - but that won't be picked up easily for the self-employed.'

If you do end up paying too much into your pension, you will eventually get a refund of your overpaid contributions (but not the tax relief) from the Inland Revenue. But you will have lost the use of that money in the meantime.

In return for introducing greater flexibility in some areas, the Government is getting tougher in others. The 'carry forward' rules are being abolished on 6 April, stopping the self-employed from making retrospective contributions to their pension plans to mop up any unused tax relief on pension contributions over the previous six years.

But people who want to make one final use of carry forward may be able to do so if they act before 31 January 2002. You can lock into the carry-forward system until that date if you are still entitled to make use of another set of rules, the carry-back rules, which let you carry back payments made in one year to the previous year.

webTitle: Children special: If all your problems are little ones...

fields.headline: If all your problems are little ones...
fields.standfirst: Joanna Moorhead  on the joys - and financial juggling - involved in raising a Walton-sized brood
fields.trailText: Joanna Moorhead on the joys - and financial juggling - involved in raising a Walton-sized brood.
fields.body:
Let's face it, if we counted the cost before we started none of us would have any children at all. But when it comes to four, five or even - God help us - six or more, you're talking megabucks.

Kids cost a lot - and as they get older, they cost even more. Goodness knows why the baby magazines are always making so much of the cost of a cot, an all-terrain buggy and a complete set of outfits from Baby Gap. OK, so this can run into thousands - but it pales into insignificance once they're at school and you're shelling out on trainers as well as Start-rite school shoes, regulation blazers as well as an extensive trendy wardrobe for weekends, and ballet classes and swimming courses as well as a private tutor or even - and here you're really talking about being in at the deep end - independent school fees.

So what makes an otherwise sane couple decide to throw caution to the wind not just once or twice, but four or five times? 'We always knew we wanted lots of kids,' says my friend Sophie, a mother of five.

'I'm one of a family of four myself, and though my husband has only one sister he was always very attracted to the idea of a big family. You know it's hard work, you know it's going to be chaotic a lot of the time, but it's also lots of fun - and that's why we did it.'

But if hordes of children spells fun, penny-pinching spells misery. And yet - here's the odd thing - most of the parents I know with lots of children don't see lack of funds as a particular downside.

'If you were the sort of person who cared a lot about lifestyle and spending money and having luxurious things, I don't think you'd have a big family,' says Sophie bluntly. And it's a gross generalisation, but parents with four or more tend not to be big worriers, either, which definitely helps.

Not many families with loads of kids also have oodles of dosh, but a few do. Anecdotal evidence suggests four-plus children has become a kind of status symbol in some well-to-do leafy London suburbs. You've got the huge house, you've got your two cars (one a people carrier, of course). You can afford to both pay and house a nanny and an au pair, and (often on one amazing City salary) you can even stretch to forking out for a private education for the brood, too.

Most big families, though, don't have someone like Nicola Horlick for a mum or dad - so how on earth do they manage to make ends meet?

'The number one tactic is to budget,' says father-of-four and independent financial adviser Chris Wicks of Bridgewater Financial Planning in Glossop in Derbyshire. 'What you need to do is to sit down and take a long, hard look at your finances.

'I think everyone should budget, but if you're running a family of six or seven it's even more vital that you do. It's easy to shy away from examining your income and looking at where it's all going, but it's always better to go into something with your eyes open.'

Having said all that, there are plenty of ways for six to live as cheaply as four. It all comes down to choices: more children mean a bigger house in a cheaper area, less expensive holidays, more time at home than out (and often fewer invitations, because you're a major undertaking to invite to lunch).

If you feel those are compromises you wouldn't want to make, stick to your 2.4: but for those who take the plunge and go for broke, the rewards are counted in a very different currency from pounds and pence.

fields.headline: Can two become one?
fields.standfirst:
Alexander Garrett asks if the marriage of benefits and employment services can be anything but unhappy

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Alexander Garrett asks if the marriage of benefits and employment services can be anything but unhappy
fields.body:
It could prove one of the biggest mergers of the year, but you are unlikely to read about it on the City pages. It will have around 80,000 employees, upwards of 2 million customers and more than 1,000 offices around the country. It will have a budget of something like £1 billion in its first 12 months; and if you're out of work at any time in the next few years, you will probably be hoping some of that money will come in your direction.

The organisation in question is the Working Age Agency - a working title - which is shortly to be created by a merger between the Benefits Agency and the Employment Service.

Announced a year ago last Friday by Tony Blair, it is intended to provide a one-stop shop for anybody of working age looking for work or receiving benefits and will eventually replace both JobCentres and benefits offices.

It will be the biggest government agency by far - dwarfing even the Inland Revenue - and its mission statement will be one of New Labour's mantras: 'Work for those who can, security for those who can't.'

But having grabbed the headlines last March, the new agency has been slow off the ground. A chief executive was chosen only in January, and the staff of the Benefits Agency and Employment Service still have little idea of how they will fit in. The agency is expected to be formed legally in June, with 'pathfinder' locations up and running by October.

Despite unemployment falling to a 25-year low at fewer than 1 million, the new agency will have plenty to do. Last week Chancellor Gordon Brown announced a second stage in the 'New Deal' programme that will concentrate on coaching and counselling for the unemployed.

Meanwhile, there is growing concern about whether the 'personal advisers' who will deal with the agency's disparate clients will be able to act as experts on the benefits system one moment and provide advice on job-seeking the next.

There is particular concern about the Budget announcement that lone parents of children under five would be required to attend 'work-focused interviews' to discuss their future careers. They will not be forced to look for work - but Kate Green of the National Council for One-Parent Families says: 'Parents may feel under pressure to get into work.'

The idea that every person will have a 'personal adviser' has been born out of Labour's New Deal programmes, and is intended to ensure that people out of work do not have to chase from pillar to post, but have a single contact who can handle all their needs.

Nick Burkitt, research fellow at the Institute for Public Policy Research, the centre-left think-tank, says personal advisers might find themselves having to 'find a job for someone who hasn't worked in 10 years; understand a benefit system with a rulebook the size of a phone directory; be sensitive to the needs of local businesses; and be able to defend themselves against a client with a skinful of Special Brew.'

It sounds like an impossible brief, and it probably is. At the least, it will require a huge training exercise; benefits officers will learn how to advise on jobs and training schemes while their JobCentre counterparts learn the ins and outs of incapacity benefit.

Burkitt believes the agency will have to consider allowing staff to specialise in particular client groups; and staff will have to know when to ask for help. 'They won't know everything,' he points out.

The PCS union, which represents many of those who work in the Benefits Agency and the Employment Service, is concerned about the safety of employees. 'Staff in benefits offices work behind security screens, while those in JobCentres don't,' says Keith Wylie, the union's national officer.

The union is also worried about redundancies, given that the new agency will end much of the duplicated administration currently involved in paying benefits and providing advice to the same people.

Paul Convery, director of the independent policy research group Unemployment Unit and Youthaid, says the merger will mean a huge cultural shift for those working in benefits offices. 'Ten years ago the Employment Service managed to get rid of their screens and move to an open-plan, user-friendly environment, and although there were some difficulties they managed it,' he says. 'Now the Benefits Agency people will have to go through the same thing.' He believes that claimants are far less likely to become violent if they are not kept at bay behind security screens.

Like most corporate marriages, this is unlikely to prove a merger of equals.

Convery says: 'The Government's agenda in setting up this new agency is very much about bringing a work focus to people the benefits system has actively taken away from the labour market.'

One key role of the new agency will be to take a more pro-active stance in finding work for everyone capable of doing it, rather than leaving them to languish indefinitely on benefits.

But it will be impossible to provide a personal adviser on Day One for every one of the million-odd people claiming jobseekers allowance, the 2.9 million claiming sickness and disability benefits, and the 900,000 single parents claiming benefits.

The emphasis to begin with is likely to be on new claimants as well as those who express the desire to find work.

But the thorny issue of compulsion is sure to rear its head. So far, only unemployed claimants in the 18-24 age group have been compelled to take either a job or a training course, but other groups may soon have to take a more active part in looking for work - or risk losing their benefit.

The name under which the new agency will actually be launched remains a secret - if it has been chosen. If Working Age Agency is deemed too boring, the Government could always take a leaf out of the Post Office's book and call in the identity consultants. Any new name would presumably need to say something about the virtues of hard work. How about Exertia?
