webTitle: Money for old bricks: Equity release schemes

fields.headline: Keys to a happier old age
fields.standfirst: Equity release schemes allow you to gain income without selling up
fields.trailText: Equity release schemes allow you to gain income without selling up.
fields.body:
You may regard your home as your castle, but by the time you retire it could have become a prison.

Many pensioners discover that after using a large proportion of their life-time earnings to pay off the mortgage, all their money is locked up in their homes. Soaring house prices over the past few years mean that thousands of elderly homeowners have made huge capital gains, but are left with little free cash to spend.

However, according to Dean Murfin, western regional manager for independent financial adviser Countrywide Assured Retirement Services, the development of a wide range of schemes to release equity from properties means that there is no need for someone who has paid off a mortgage to be 'asset-rich, but income-poor'.

The schemes on sale now should not be confused with the old type of home income plans that caused terrible problems for elderly homeowners in the late Eighties and early Nineties. The old-style plans charged variable interest and left many homeowners facing the loss of their homes when interest rates soared and property prices crashed.

The new schemes guarantee that owners can stay in their homes for as long as they want and guarantee that they can sell them to move elsewhere. Cash can normally be taken as a lump sum, a regular income (by using the lump sum to buy an annuity) or a combination of the two.

There are two main forms of equity release, or home income, plans currently sold. The reversion plan involves the homeowner selling a share in his or her property for cash. After the owner dies, the property is sold on the open market and the lender claims its share in the property. The rest is paid into the late homeowner's estate.

As you are given the right to live in your home for the rest of your life, the lender does not pay you the full value of the portion of your property that it is buying. The percentage you receive depends on your age and sex - if you are likely to live longer, the percentage you receive will be smaller.

David McGrath, manager of home income plan specialist adviser Hinton & Wild, says that some homeowners dislike the idea of giving up ownership of part of their property through a home reversion plan. However, it does guarantee that you can pass on a certain percentage of equity in your property to beneficiaries.

The second type of scheme - the cash release or roll-up mortgage plan - is more of a gamble. It requires the homeowner to take out a loan secured against his or her home. Interest charged at a fixed rate is added on to the home income plan loan, and the loan and interest is paid off from the proceeds when the house is eventually sold.

This offers the advantage that you retain full ownership of your property and your estate will benefit from all the increase in its value. But if you live a long time, the loan plus interest could soak up much, if not all, its value when you eventually die. McGrath says that a loan fixed at 7.5 per cent effectively doubles in size after 10 years.

Interest on home income loans is usually fixed or capped at a slightly higher rate than that charged on prevailing conventional mortgages. Northern Rock, for example, is charging 8.99 per cent on its capped equity release mortgage.

Watch out for penalties on early repayment as well. Some, such as the Julian Hodge bank, levy charges in the first five years, but Norwich Union reserves the right to make an early repayment charge - the size of which is determined at the time of repayment - right up to the homeowner's death.

The terms of these schemes vary considerably, so you should consult an independent financial adviser specialising in home income plans before signing up. Call IFA Promotion (0800 085 3250) for a free list.

Ship (Safe Home Income Plans) was set up after the Eighties home income plan scandal to introduce product standards to protect customers. For a list of its members and details of their schemes call 01242 523281.

Traditional mortgage interest rates are cheaper than those charged by home income plans. But if you are on a variable interest rate you could end up paying more in the long term. As you get older, you may also find it more difficult to borrow a traditional mortgage. Even if you find a willing lender, it could be harder to meet the monthly payments once you are living on a pension.

However, a few schemes have been designed to tackle these problems. The Halifax Retirement Home Plan, for people aged 55 or more, is designed to keep costs to a minimum by requiring borrowers to pay just the interest every month. When the borrower dies, the property is sold and the mortgage repaid out of the proceeds.

Borrowers can draw up to 75 per cent of their property's value, subject to income multiples of 2.5 times joint income, or 3.25 times one income plus one times the second (based on pension income, income from investments and income from part-time jobs). The plan can be applied to any mortgage in the Halifax range.

Although the Halifax will lend on properties in sheltered accommodation, it may refuse if the property is one of just a few owner-occupied homes in the surrounding area. A spokeswoman explains: 'We believe that if there are just one or two owned properties among a whole lot of rented homes, it may affect its saleability.'

However, the Norwich and Peterborough Building Society's Retired Mortgage Scheme will consider all sheltered accommodation.

The society will lend up to three times a single income, or 2.5 times joint income and up to 75 per cent of the property's value. The scheme is currently offered with a 2 per cent discount off the society's standard variable rate for 18 months, producing a current rate of 5.24 per cent.

There is no age limit, and the loan can be used for buying or remortgaging, but Stephen Penlington, the society's general manager of products and marketing, stresses that great care is taken to make sure that borrowers do not over-extend themselves.

'Our primary concern is that we shouldn't encourage retired homebuyers to over-commit themselves, so we look carefully at applicants' circumstances before they take out the mortgage.' says Penlington.

'In fact we even go so far as to recommend in the mortgage offer that customers [and any relatives/heirs who may have a vested interest in the property] obtain legal advice first.'

Robert Burton,77, took out a £40,000 mortgage to move to a warden-controlled flat last year.

The flat, part of a converted locomotive shed in Stamford, Lincolnshire, cost more than his previous home. Rather than dip into his savings, he took a loan from the Norwich and Peterborough building society.

Mr Burton is using his money to lead an active retirement.

He has just returned from a seven-week holiday in Venezuela, Chile and Florida and has bought a $35,000 'manufactured home' about 50 miles north of Orlando. It comes complete with air conditioning, fixtures and furnishings. 'All I have to provide is my toothbrush,' he says.

Burton chose to borrow in the UK rather than the US because it is cheaper. His interest-only loan, at a discounted rate of 5.24 per cent, costs £175 a month. When the discount ends and he pays the standard variable rate after 18 months, if it is similar to the current 7.24 per cent, it will cost £241 a month.

webTitle: Market meltdown: A bumpy ride, but sit tight

fields.headline: A bumpy ride, but sit tight
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott and Jill Insley offer advice during worrying times for shareholders
fields.trailText: Maria Scott and Jill Insley offer advice during worrying times for shareholders.
fields.body:
These days, when the stock market sneezes, most of us catch at least a sniffle, if not a fullblown dose of 'flu.

There are 12 million small shareholders in the UK now, more than double the number 15 years ago. Even more people have indirect stakes in the market through their pension funds, endowment policies, Isa investment plans and 'pooled' funds such as unit trusts. Sixteen per cent of quoted UK shares are in the hands of private investors, while 20 per cent are held by pension funds, 3 per cent by unit trusts, 2 per cent by investment trusts, and 5.5 per cent by other financial institutions including life insurance funds.

Anecdotal evidence suggests that the investing public, including those who invest directly in shares - and feel the pain of falling prices first - are less prone to panic in falling markets than before the 1987 market crash. But tum bling prices are unnerving, even for indirect investors.

For those with beleaguered life insurer Equitable Life, market mayhem has brought more pain, in the form of increased exit charges, up from 10 to 15 per cent. Advisers were still assessing the implications of this announcement at the end of last week although immediate reaction was that it would make a switch out of Equitable too expensive for many now to contemplate.

Market experts expect share prices will recover, although they are nervous about how long the slump will continue.

For most shareholders, direct and indirect, the best advice is sit tight. Many people will hold money in investments that they cannot move out of. Others face dilemmas about whether to commit more money to the market, or to hold their funds in cash.

Here we look at the effect on different investments - and what action investors should take.

Isas

Investors who haven't used their Isa allowance yet are faced with a daunting choice. The deadline for using the 2000/2001 allowance is 5 April - any unused allowance is lost after this date. But if you invest now to maximise your tax savings, you could end up with heavy losses.

Justin Modray of Bath independent financial adviser Fundsdirect advises anyone with moderate amounts to invest to hold on to their money until the stock market settles and maximise use of next year's £7,000 Isa allowance instead. He says: 'It's great having tax-efficient investments, but losses aren't so attractive.' Alternatively he suggests investing in a less volatile corporate bond fund for the time being, possibly switching when the equities market becomes more attractive.

Jason Hollands of London firm Best Invest disagrees: 'At these levels, when there's doom and gloom all around, you should be investing, taking advantage of the low prices and the tax savings.'

Investors who want the best of both worlds - to use their allowance and defer investment in the market - can use a 'drip feed' scheme such as that available through Fidelity's online supermarket FundsNetwork.

This allows you to invest a lump sum now, which is then phased into your choice of funds in six equal portions over six months. However, the first tranche is invested immediately, and there's no guarantee that the market will have improved in one month or even six months.

Endowments/With-profit bonds

Homeowners and savers with money in with-profits endowments will be cushioned from the full pain of market losses.

Insurance companies aim to smooth returns on with-profits investments by the allocation of bonuses. Money can be withheld in good years to add in poorer years.

But endowment investors are not immune to market falls and insurance companies have been reducing bonuses in anticipation of falling returns.

David Carrington of Policyplus, a company specialising in secondhand endowments, says policyholders should not try to get out unless they need the cash. If they do, they should look to sell in the secondhand market rather than surrendering to the insurer. He also points out that investors have limited choice over where to obtain positive returns; it is possible to buy as well as sell in the secondhand market.

'In the past, such volatile stock market conditions would come at a time when interest rates were rising, so cash returns would be that bit better. What we have at the moment is interest rates falling and no prospect of a decent cash return in the next few years.'

Companies running with-profit bonds - lump sum investments - may apply special exit penalties, known as market value adjusters, as a result of falling share prices. These don't affect returns on bonds - though falling bonuses will - but would hit investors cashing in.

Pensions

Members of 'final salary' pension schemes, where pensions are determined by salary at retirement and length of service, may not be affected by market falls.

Employers would have to make good any shortfall but there could be consequences from a prolonged period of market losses

Employers have already begun to shy away from final salary schemes replacing them - for new employees - with 'money purchase' plans where employees bear the risk of markets plunging; a pension depends on the value of the investor's stake in the pension fund.

John Turton, pensions specialist at independent adviser Best Investment, says a sustained period of losses could be the death knell for final salary schemes.

People with money purchase company schemes, or personal pensions - which also invest directly in the stock market - are likely to see the effects of falling mar kets in their next valuation statements.

Patrick Connolly of Chartwell Investment Management says: 'For most people this isn't a problem. There will be plenty of time for the market to recover. The only problem is where you are coming up to retirement and haven't planned in advance.'

You should check the arrangements with your pension for protecting funds before retirement. These vary and although many company schemes and personal pensions offer auto matic switching facilities - from shares to bonds- through 'lifestyle' schemes, Mark Green at actuary Watson Wyatt says that these are not universal. Even where they exist, people taking early retirement can be caught out.

Advisers say those near retirement who have not moved their money may have to postpone retirement or accept a smaller fund.

Investors who have their money in with profit funds, should be insulated from market gyrations although Mark Green thinks pension savers should also review these close to retirement, though it is important to check any possible loss of maturity bonus if switching.

Equitable Life provided a reminder last week that with profit funds are not immune from market mayhem, increasing exit penalties from 10 to 15 per cent.

For those with longer to go to retirement, it is impossible to withdraw pension funds as cash, so the temptation to cut and run is not one they can pursue. Some, most likely those with personal pensions, may wonder whether to switch funds.

Turton warns: 'Never sell out when markets have crashed.'

A troubled stock market could cast gloom over the launch of stakeholder pensions next month. Turton says investors worried about committing money can save in a cash mini Isa or corporate bond Isa until the picture is clearer. Investors may have a wider choice of stakeholder plans to choose from later in the year.

Shares

There is one golden rule for investors as stock markets fall: Don't panic.

'If you own shares, stick with them,' says Justin Urquhart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers. 'Selling now would only crystallise losses.'

The markets have always recovered, given enough time, says Urquhart Stewart. He predicts that although there may be a few 'bear' rallies soon, the real recovery will start when the US economy starts showing signs of improving health, probably in the autumn.

Jeremy King, director of private share ownership at the Proshare campaign, says many small investors have already absorbed a lot of shock, through the falls in technology stocks last year: 'While people are not happy to see the value of the market dip, there is more resignation than panic.'

Ideally you should invest in the stock market only money that you can afford to forget about, so you can sell up when it suits you rather than because you are forced to by low prices.

However if you do have to sell now, Proshare, which promotes share ownership, points out that if you invested your money more than a couple of years ago, your investment has probably increased in value by more than if you had left the money in a building society.

Some investors may be tempted to take advantage of last week's falls to buy some cheap shares, but Urquhart Stewart advises them to keep their money on deposit for now: 'There are some very, very good value stocks out there but I'm not sure I'd buy them yet. I'd wait a few weeks.'

You should also consider adopting a 'stop loss' policy in future to preserve the value of your portfolio. This involves setting a price of, for example, 20 per cent less than the amount you paid for a share. If your share falls to that point - the stop loss - you sell. Then if you still like the company, buy the share again as the price bottoms out. The stop loss should be readjusted if the share moves up in value.

What will happen to my income?

Income investors should come through the stock market volatility relatively unscathed. So far most of the share price falls have been in growth stocks such as technology companies that typically pay little or no dividend and, therefore, are not included in equity income funds.

Income funds tend to buy shares in more established companies that offer little prospect of growth but pay a good dividend, such as banks, breweries and utilities. These are less volatile. Over the past year, the average UK growth fund has fallen by 10 per cent, while UK equity income funds have grown by 6.97 per cent, according to figures supplied by Lipper.

Corporate bond funds have also done well compared with growth funds, up an average of 6.81 per cent over the past year, and prices of bonds have risen in the past week. Anna Lees-Jones, manager of M&G's corporate bond fund, says this is partly because proposals announced last week could enable pension funds to use corporate bonds rather than lower-yielding gilts to underpin payouts. But she adds: 'Bonds are less volatile, and if equity markets are rough, investors do tend to move to bonds.'

fields.headline: Dear things? You don't know the half of it
fields.standfirst: A step by step guide to how to make ends meet with four or more
fields.trailText: A step by step guide to how to make ends meet with four or more.
fields.body:
Insurance

When money's tight and there are lots of immediate needs it's easy to overlook the long-term, says Chris Wicks, a financial consultant at Bridgwater Financial Planning, but you ignore life insurance at your peril.

'The breadwinner's life has absolutely got to be insured, because the conse quences are going to be disastrous if something happens and it isn't,' says Wicks.

Couples often neglect insuring the life of a non-working spouse, but this too is more vital than ever in a large family - imagine the cost of employing a full-time nanny and a cleaner and (quite possibly) an au pair or mother's help to take the place of a mother-of-five, and you'll see how crucial it is.

Term insurance, which pays out if the insured person dies during the term of the policy, is the cheapest life cover. There are several different types - level term costs the same amount and pays out the same amount throughout the policy, decreasing term reduces the payout during the policy and is designed to be used with a repayment mortgage, while the family income benefit policy pays a series of regular payments from the insured person's death until the policy ends.

Term insurance is one of the few financial products you can choose purely on cost. Ask your independent financial adviser for help in selecting a contract. Alternatively discount brokers such as TQ Direct (Tel: 0800 056 1838), and Direct Life & Pension Services will find you the cheapest policy and rebate some of the initial commission.

Education

The spiralling costs of living in a city with expensive housing and iffy schooling means sooner or later couples who've opted for four or more kids tend to move out. Out to where they can afford more bedrooms, a bigger garden, and where their children stand a better chance of a decent state education. 'Outside London, even if you end up deciding to educate one or two of your children privately, it's often a lot cheaper,' says Wicks.

But wherever you live, it's important not to forget the cost of seeing your brood through university. This now costs around £6,000 per child per year all told, and the way to pay for it depends on how many years you have to save, according to Jason Hollands of independent financial adviser Best Investment. He says: 'If you've got a short time to go, you should consider zero dividend preference shares, which pay a pre-determined capital gain on a set date.'

If you've got just one year before your child starts university, he recommends the M&G Recovery zero, which will yield a return of 7.2 per cent (tax-free if you haven't used your CGT allowance) on 3 April next year. If you have three years to go, he recommends the Govett Enhanced Income zero, which has yield of 7.6 per cent and pays out on 31 March, 2004. For a full list of zeros and their yields visit Best Invest's website, www.bestinvest.co.uk.

But if your children are young, you should consider equity investment through a unit trust or Oeic Isa. Hollands says: 'If you are investing for 15 to 18 years, you won't want to chop and change funds every year, so consider a low-cost index fund such as HSBC's FTSE Allshare tracker or a diversified managed fund such as Fidelity International.'

Transport

Transport eats into the income of a big family. Once your children number more than three, an ordinary car won't do any more. New people carriers can set you back £30,000 or more, and even for a second-hand big car you're usually talking around £10,000.

If you can't afford the outlay, consider a low-cost loan. Check out the cheapest deals online at www.moneygator.com or www.moneysupermarket.co.uk. Checking the costs of a £10,000 car loan over three years on the latter site produced an 8.7 per cent APR loan with Lloyds TSB Loan Direct, costing £315.08 a month.

Holidays

Holidays are another big expense. Karen Simmonds, who runs the Balham-based family travel specialist Travel Matters in south London, says the cheapest option for a family with four children aged between four and 10 would probably set them back around £1,400 for campsite accommodation in the Vendée region of France, including the ferry crossing in mid-summer.

'For those with a bit more to spend, a self-catering holiday in Corsica would come in at around £4,200 for flights, accommodation and transfers.' Cheaper still, of course, is to stay in Britain and hire a big house near the sea (out of season for a bargain) or even an entire youth hostel (really cheap, especially if you team up with another large family).

Food

If holidays are optional - and some, of course, would argue that they shouldn't be - the weekly shop certainly isn't. 'Don't go to Tesco's more than once a week,' is Wicks's advice. Buying in bulk makes a lot of sense, and eating pre-prepared convenience food is out of the question - an M&S ready meal for three or four might be OK as a blow-out treat, but for six or seven it's an impossible indulgence.

Clothes

When it comes to clothes you'd think a family with four or five children would be able to hand everything down and hardly ever go shopping - but you'd be wrong. Clothes bought new for child number one are usually faded for child number two, frayed for child number three and fit only for the bin by child number four.

Shoes are one of the scariest expenses of all: it's perfectly possible to pay £35 for a reasonable pair of school shoes for a six or seven-year-old, and you can reckon on at least two and maybe three pairs needed per child per year.

You can spread the cost by using a low-cost credit card. Capital One Bank ( 0800 952 5252) charges no interest in the first six months, then reverts to a higher standard variable rate so be prepared to switch cards again at that point.

Avoid taking out store cards, as these charge the highest interest.
fields.bodyText: Insurance When money's tight and there are lots of immediate needs it's easy to overlook the long-term, says Chris Wicks, a financial consultant at Bridgwater Financial Planning, but you ignore life insurance at your peril. 'The breadwinner's life has absolutely got to be insured, because the conse quences are going to be disastrous if something happens and it isn't,' says Wicks. Couples often neglect insuring the life of a non-working spouse, but this too is more vital than ever in a large family - imagine the cost of employing a full-time nanny and a cleaner and (quite possibly) an au pair or mother's help to take the place of a mother-of-five, and you'll see how crucial it is. There are several different types - level term costs the same amount and pays out the same amount throughout the policy, decreasing term reduces the payout during the policy and is designed to be used with a repayment mortgage, while the family income benefit policy pays a series of regular payments from the insured person's death until the policy ends. But wherever you live, it's important not to forget the cost of seeing your brood through university. webTitle: Trust me. I'm an insurance salesman

fields.headline: Trust me. I'm an insurance salesman
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles  on how to judge the competence of a financial adviser
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles on how to judge the competence of a financial adviser
fields.body:
Leading life insurance company Allied Dunbar has ordered 4,700 of its agents to take new exams after many of them were found to be 'not competent'.

Allied is the latest of a string of insurers to send its salespeople back to the classroom, focusing attention on the training and competence of financial advisers. So how do you know the salesman across the table from you knows his or her stuff?

Agents working for Allied Dunbar, which has 2.5 million customers in Britain, were found to have 'gaps in their product knowledge' by a monitoring team from the insurer's regulator, the Personal Investment Authority. The gaps were in all four key product areas: pensions, investments, mortgages and protection.

The Government watchdog stopped short of demanding that the agents be suspended after Allied Dunbar agreed to undertake urgent and stringent tests on all sales staff .

Before an insurance salesman can begin selling products, they must pass a benchmark exam called the financial planning certificate (FPC). They follow a course that requires 240 hours of study, then sit three different exams on subjects such as income tax and portfolio planning. The adviser can start selling after passing the first exam, but only under supervision. They are not allowed to operate on their own until they have passed all three.

The FPC, which is also sat by independent financial advisers, is being reviewed by the Financial Services Authority. It is an old exam and there are concerns that it is out of step with the current market, particularly with regard to investments. But experts say the real fault may lie with post-exam professional development, such as it is.

The Life Insurance Association, the professional body that represents 12,000 direct salespeople and 10,000 IFAs, wants to standardise continuing professional development in conjunction with several other organisations, including the FSA.

Allied Dunbar will certainly be taking follow-up training more seriously from now on. In future the life office will subject its agents to a five-day annual training regime, which will culminate in an exam.

In the meantime, how do you judge the competence of a salesperson or an IFA? You can recognise what exams they have by looking at the letters after their name. If a salesman has no letters ask him which exams he has passed.

Members of the Society of Financial Advisers use the letters FPC but LIA members use MLIADip for the same qualification.

While FPC is the minimum required by regulators, it is by no means the only exam. Advisers can take others, including the advanced finance planning certificate (AFPC), which is like an A-level to FPC's GCSE. It tests subjects such as tax law and pensions through in-depth case studies.

Only 5,500 advisers hold all parts of this qualification at present. The Society of Financial Advisers can put you in touch with an adviser who has passed the advanced FPC exam through its website: www.sofa.org.

Theoretically, a salesman can notch up 24 letters after his or her name, although no one is thought to have reached this enormous total. The FSA realises the proliferation of letters is bewildering and plans to simplify the alphabet soup.

fields.headline: Work with a megalomaniac
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: 1 Understand just how difficult megalomaniacs are to deal with. Driven by an overbalanced lust for power, they will sacrifice everything and everyone else en route - colleagues, principles and the survival of the organisation they claim to serve.
fields.body:
1 Understand just how difficult megalomaniacs are to deal with. Driven by an overbalanced lust for power, they will sacrifice everything and everyone else en route - colleagues, principles and the survival of the organisation they claim to serve.

While Robert Mugabe uses violence in Zimbabwe, your office megalomaniac will, in a smaller way, be equally ready to corrupt your workplace.

2 Decide whether to engage or disappear. Packing your bags is a wise move in more brutal cases. The litmus test is whether they can care about the viewpoint of others, says psychologist Michael Carroll: 'If they can begin to learn empathy, they can learn to move away from hurting others.'

Ask them questions such as: 'Can you see how someone else might see that?' Don't expect a promising response from true megalomaniacs.

3 Tackle them on their behaviour, not on their intentions - unless you want to go the discursive route. Most megalomaniacs will portray themselves as very moralistic (think of Stalin, Hitler, the Real IRA...) in order to justify their appalling actions.

Carroll says: 'Most megalomaniacs have no concept of the impact of their behaviour on others. Appealing to their better nature does not help - because they don't have one.'

4 Be careful about complaining to their bosses - megalomaniacs are often very charming and cunning and will somehow have the boss in their pocket too. Remember the huge hold that Iago had over Othello.

But you can win the odd battle - by making sure you are acting in full view of others rather than in a back street, where the megalomaniac will be perfectly happy to fight dirty.

To do this, you need to be taking steps such as copying memos to a wider circle of colleagues, holding public meetings, and putting all agreed decisions in writing.

5 Keep a close eye on the subordinates of megalomaniacs. 'If you don't screw them down, they will create real difficulties for you,' says Philip, a psychotherapist. 'They create inefficiencies through their distorted view of things.'

Megalomaniacs in the computer department, for instance, are well placed to control the use of computer systems by staff - and may hold back some of the more imaginative workers who want to use the systems freely.

webTitle: Tax planning: Capital ideas to soften the blow

fields.headline: Capital ideas to soften the blow
fields.standfirst: Scottish Widows policy holders are among 750,000 facing a CGT bill, reports Richard Murphy
fields.trailText: Scottish Widows policy holders are among 750,000 facing a CGT bill, reports Richard Murphy.
fields.body:
At least 750,000 people face a capital gains tax bill this year.

On top of the usual 250,000 'high net worth' suspects who incur CGT every year, an estimated 500,000 Scottish Widows policy holders received cheques for more than £7,200 through the insurer's demutualisation last summer. Others are likely to have incurred CGT through price increases on holiday or rental properties - gains made through the sale of second homes are also liable to tax.

If you are at risk of paying CGT, now is the time to plan.

First make sure you are really likely to be liable for CGT. If the gains that you have realised in the current tax year are going to be less than £7,200 (the capital gains allowance for 2000/2001) you do not have to pay. You do not even have to declare realised gains if they are less than this amount.

Many Scottish Widows policyholders took a loan note option that enabled them to defer any tax problem. If you did this and have realised no other gains during the current tax year, now is the time to cash in up to £7,200 to make use of this year's CGT allowance. You can also cash in a further £7,500 ( the 2001/2002 CGT allowance) after 5April without incurring a tax liability, provided you realise no other gains during that year.

Remember that if your gains (other than Scottish Widows) were generated within an Isa, they too are tax-free. However, if you have made a gain of more than £7,200, or you sold assets on which gains could arise for more than £14,400 in total, you have to declare your gains, even if no tax is eventually due.

Ask the Inland Revenue for a tax return and complete it, or you could face big penalties. Don't despair if you think you are facing CGT - there may be a way around it:

 If you have quoted shares not held in an Isa, check current prices. They may well be down on what you paid for them. Providing you are willing to sell them now, you can offset the loss against your gain. (Isa losses do not count.)

 You cannot sell and immediately re-buy shares now, to realise capital gains, but there is nothing to stop your spouse buying what you sold. You are quite independent from your partner for CGT purposes.

 Think about reinvesting to defer the gain. Any capital gain can be deferred where the capital gain (not the sale proceeds) is reinvested in new shares in a Venture Capital Trust or an Enterprise Investment Scheme company. In both cases you may also get a 20 per cent income tax saving as well.

Up to £100,000 can be deferred by way of VCT investment, and up to £150,000 in an EIS. But note that the gain is deferred, not cancelled (although of course you may have no bill in another year) and this sort of investment is risky. You also do not need to rush to do it by 5 April, so long as you do so within 12 months of making the gain.

Finally, remember that Scottish Widows' demutualisation is not the only way you might generate an inadvertent capital gains tax bill. Property prices have soared in the past few years and many people have taken the chance to sell second or rented properties.

If you have sold a property you have never lived in, you will have to declare the sale on your tax return. As importantly, if you've sold your own home after letting it out, either between periods when you lived in it, or, as is increasingly popular, for a time after you moved out, the gain may also need declaring. Again there are lots of reliefs available - the gain is free if you sold the property within three years of living in it. But you must still declare the gain and claim the relief.

If you think this applies to you, get a tax return, seek advice now and tell the Inland Revenue all the facts before 30 September.

 Richard Murphy is an independent chartered accountant based in south London.
